DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST ROC COMMERCIAL SATELLITE TO BE IN ORBIT IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first commercial satellite, which is expected to greatly advance the island's television and telecommunications services, is scheduled to be launched on May 26 by the French rocket Arianne 4 in Guyana, South America.

The ST-1, Taiwan's first self-owned communications satellite, will be launched under a collaborative sponsorship agreement between Taipei's Chunghwa Telecom Co. and Singapore's Singapore Telecommunications Corp., Chunghwa officials announced on Sunday.

Taiwan has long planned to launch its own communications satellite, but the plan has not been implemented because Taiwan is not a member of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU), a United Nations affiliate, and therefore cannot obtain the right to put satellites into orbit.

Singapore came up with a cooperative plan in 1991 which would allow the two sides to jointly launch a satellite. Singapore, a UN and ITU member, undertook to apply for the orbit right for the project.

Under the cooperation agreement, signed in April 1996, Taiwan and Singapore will each contribute US$120 million to the project and the two countries will enjoy equal use of the satellite based on the principles of "equality and reciprocity."

The French Matra M-Space company (MMS), one of the four largest satellite manufacturers in the world, has been commissioned to build the satellite which will be launched into a geostationary orbit 36,000 km above northern Taiwan's Yangming Mountain.
Under the terms of the agreement, Taiwan and Singapore will each build a control station and each will own seven C-band and eight Ku-band transponders.

Chunghwa Telecom will use the 15 transponders to provide technically advanced television, telephone and digital telecommunications services to a huge market encompassing Taiwan and its offshore islands, Japan, and South Korea, as well as the entire Asia-Pacific region and most of mainland China, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 20 TRADE MISSIONS TO GO ABROAD IN FOUR MONTHS

TEXT.P: More than 20 Taiwan trade missions will go abroad before the end of May to promote the sales of steel, garments, sewing machines, gifts and souvenirs, foods, candy and biscuits, and many other goods.

An official of the Board of Foreign Trade said Sunday that a trade mission organized by the Taiwan Steel and Iron Industries Association will visit Southeast Asian countries in March, and that the export-import trade associations of Taitung County, Kaohsiung County, and Taipei City will visit Japan. The export-import trade association of Keelung City will visit Indonesia in March.
A trade mission of foods producers will visit the United States, and another mission of candy and biscuits producers will visit Singapore during the period.
The official also said that trade missions of garment and sewing machine producers will visit France, Italy, and Russia before the end of May.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL MAINLAND CHINA OFFICIALS LINKED TO PIRACY

TEXT.P: Local government officials in southern mainland China are involved in pirate attacks on commercial ships, including Singapore-flagged vessels, in the South China Sea, according to the International Maritime Bureau (IMB).

Ports in southern mainland China are being used to shelter vessels hijacked by pirates dressed in Chinese military uniforms, the IMB said in its annual report on piracy and armed robbery against ships. The IMB was set up and is sponsored by the International Chamber of Commerce.
The IMB said that it is worried by the fact that pirates in Chinese military uniforms -- and equipped with modern automatic weapons -- are intercepting passing ships in the South China Sea.

"This is not the first time that southern Chinese ports have been used to shelter hijacked ships," the IMB was quoted as saying. "Local officials have been previously involved in criminal activities."

The IMB was quoted as commenting: "It is unacceptable that China, a major maritime nation, has failed to take action against this type of criminal activity, where local government officials are clearly involved."
At least 12 such pirate attacks were reported last year, The Straits Times reported on Sunday.
There were 229 incidents of piracy reported worldwide in 1997, one more than the previous year, according to figures compiled by the Kuala Lumpur-based Piracy Reporting Center.
These attacks spanned the globe, from Albania and Indonesia to Nigeria and Venezuela.

East Asia and Southeast Asia had the highest number of incidents (105), with Africa next (37), followed by South Asia/Persian Gulf and the Americas (both 34). The rest of the incidents occurred in European countries and in Russia.
The Piracy Reporting Center, a 24-hour information agency, was created by the IMB and is supported by contributions from the shipping industry.
Besides the mainland Chinese attacks, the report also identified these other trends:
-- Highest risk area:
Indonesia was the highest risk area, although the number of attacks was reduced from 57 in 1996 to 47 last year.

Many of the attacks were carried out by armed pirates who threatened and assaulted crew members before robbing them. In the majority of these attacks, the ships were boarded while they were at anchor.
-- More violent:
Modern-day pirates are becoming more violent. The number of crew members killed in pirate attacks last year was 51, double the number in 1996.
Pirates are also more trigger-happy. There were 26 incidents of ships being fired upon last year, compared to only six in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIPLOMATIC TUG-OF-WAR TO INTENSIFY IN 1998

TEXT.P: The diplomatic tug-of-war between the archrivals on either side of the Taiwan Strait is expected to become even more intense this year as Beijing increases its checkbook diplomacy aimed at the Republic of China's allies, local academics said on Sunday at a roundtable meeting.

Intensified diplomatic jockeying will also deal a further blow to the already fragile state of cross-strait relations, although a silver lining may become apparent in March with the possible resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue, said Prof. Pan Hsi-tang of Tamkang University.

Referring to the latest diplomatic switch from Taipei to Beijing -- by the Central African Republic on Jan. 29 -- Pan said similar money-fueled "diplomatic raids" by mainland China will become even more of a problem in coming years as Beijing continues its attempts to isolate the ROC in the international community.
The Central African Republic's recognition of Beijing brings down to nine in Africa and 28 worldwide the number of nations maintaining formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.

To prevent this figure from diminishing further, Pan suggested that President Lee Teng-hui should preside over a nine-nation summit in Africa when he visits that part of the world in April this year, in an effort to smash Beijing's "one-by-one" diplomatic strategy.

Pan reiterated that talks on political issues, such as the interpretation of the "one China" policy, should be at the top of the agenda when negotiators from the two sides meet for a fresh round of cross-strait dialogue.

Prof. Huang Hsiao-hsiang of Fuhsingkang University offered the opinion that the main prerequisite for getting both sides back to the negotiating table is a consensus on an end to this type of diplomatic jockeying, which is one of the bones of contention keeping the two sides of the Taiwan Strait apart.

Prof. Wu Heng-yu, also of Fuhsingkang University, said that unless the widely differing ideologies in Taipei and Beijing are narrowed down, chances of the two sides sitting down to talk seriously are slim.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECULATION RIFE IN TAIPEI OVER CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Speculation over a forthcoming Cabinet shakeup is rampant in Taipei, as the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday draws to close and Premier Vincent Siew prepares to make good his promise to reorganize his three-month old team.
Although the exact lineup of the new Cabinet is still anybody's guess, some common factors seem to be emerging from media reports of the last couple of days.

Legislator and ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Central Policy Coordination Committee Vice Executive Director Huang Chu-wen is reportedly to replace Yeh Chin-feng as interior minister. Yeh will be reassigned as a KMT vice secretary-general.

Education Minister Wu Jin, who enjoys the highest poll ratings among the Cabinet, despite his whimsical ideas about education reforms which often draw fire from critics, will possibly be replaced by Lin Ching-chiang, a member of the Examination Yuan.
Wu could be appointed as a minister of state in the Cabinet, but the reports say Wu might turn down this new job offer.

Chiao Jen-ho, secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation will replace James C.Y. Chu as chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission. Chu's possible new job was not revealed in the reports.

Government Information Office Director-General David Tawei Lee and Vice Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen are expected to switch jobs with each other, while scholar-turned Minister of State Chan Hou-sheng is tapped to head the Council of Labor Affairs. There was no word on current CLA chairman Hsu Chieh-kwei, who offered to resign at the end of last year because of low popularity ratings.

Chairmanship of the National Science Council, which became available when former head Liu Chao-shuan was promoted to vice premier, may be taken up by Minister of State Yang Shih-chien, although Huang Chen-tai, president of Feng Chia University, has also been named as a possible candidate.
Chen Po-chih, Professor of Economy at National Taiwan University, is expected to be brought into the new Cabinet as a minister of state.

The mass-circulation United Daily News said on Sunday that Lee Chi-chu, professor of economy at the National Chengchi University will take the helm of the National Youth Commission, while the commission's current chairman, Huang Teh-fu, will take over as director-general of the KMT Youth Affairs Department.
However, another newspaper, the China Times, listed Lee as the new KMT youth department head.

In addition to the possible new KMT vice secretary-general Yeh Chin-feng and the possible new head of the KMT youth department, Chang Jung-kung, deputy editor-in-chief of the Central News Agency and an expert on mainland China affairs, is said to be a potential appointee as director-general of the KMT's Department of Mainland Operations.

Siew, who is presiding over the shakeup in conjunction with KMT Secretary-General John Chang, is expected to submit his new Cabinet list to President Lee Teng-hui for his endorsement later on Sunday before presenting it to the KMT's policy-making body -- the Central Standing Committee -- for official ratification on Wednesday, according to the evening daily China Times Express.

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. GOVERNMENT ASKED TO GIVE CITIZENS FINANCIAL RELIEF

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions began to collect signatures Sunday morning at subway stations for a petition asking the special administrative region government to give financial relief to citizens in the budget to be promulgated later this month.

Many people who signed the petition said they hoped that the economy of Hong Kong will recover this year and that they will not be laid off this year. Unemployment has become a big problem for Hong Kong people as more and more big companies have been closed down and more people laid off amid economic recession.
The federation of trade unions has predicted that more people will lose their jobs after the lunar New Year holiday.

Meanwhile, at a public forum, members of the Democratic Alliance for Betterment of Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Democratic Party, and the Hong Kong Progressive Alliance Sunday urged the government to lower income tax and business tax in order to help attract foreign investment and reduce the financial burden on ordinary citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PUPPET TROUPE PROMOTING TIES BETWEEN TAIWAN AND AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The 17-member Hsiao Hsi Yuan Puppet Theater is serving as a bridge to promote people-to-people ties between the Republic of China on Taiwan and Australia.
In its first tour of Australia, the troupe, led by Hsu Wang, is staging five performances in different venues around the capital, Canberra.

In an interview with the CNA on Sunday, Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Justice Minister Gary Humphrey, who represents Chief Minister Kate Carnel, said the troupe will serve to promote people-to-people relations between Taiwan and Australia.
"We would like to see more of this kind of performance from Taiwan in Australia," he said.

Liu Po-lun, the ROC representative in Australia, acknowledged that both the ACT and Australian federal governments pay great attention to multicultural development and have invited a number of countries to take part in the Multicultural Festival in Canberra.
Before embarking on its first performance on Sunday afternoon, the troupe conducted a ritual performance to offer its blessing to the newly built Tuggeranong Art Center in Canberra.

A spokesman for the center said the Taiwan troupe is promoting friendship and people-to-people contact and offers multicultural awareness. "It is very, very important. It must be fostered for the benefit of everyone throughout the world."
Hsu Wang said his troupe is on its first visit to Australia.
"We have visited many countries and are happy to come to Australia to perform. We feel very glad to have the opportunity to perform here," he said in an interview.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADS EAST ASIAN COUNTRIES IN MACROECONOMIC POLICY-MAKING

TEXT.P: Taiwan leads a grouping of 12 Asian countries in the quality of its macroeconomic policy-making, according to a report authored by Knox Lovell, professor of economics at the University of Georgia in the United States.

Lovell measured the quality of macroeconomic policy-making using the Okun Misery Index, which adds unemployment rates to consumer price inflation rates, the Calmfors Index, which subtracts the ratio of trade surplus deficit to that of gross domestic product (GDP) from unemployment rates, and the OECD Index, which adds GDP to the ratio of trade surplus\deficit to GDP then subtracts unemployment rates and consumer price inflation rates.
In his study, Lovell found that Taiwan leads the Asian countries included in the study in all three categories, giving it the highest quality of macroeconomic policy-making.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIRE BLOWOUT HORRIFIES AIRLINE PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: Passengers aboard a TransAsia Airways flight were frightened out of their wits on Sunday afternoon by an explosion beneath their feet soon after the aircraft took off from Hsiaokang International Airport near the southern port city of Kaohsiung, en route to Taipei in the north.

Flight No. 562 suffered a blowout in one of its tires during takeoff at around 1:00 p.m., but the cool-headed pilots managed to bring the plane safely to Taipei's Sungshan domestic airport at 2:30 p.m., although it had to circle above the airport for more than half an hour before receiving clearance to land.
Hsiaokang airport was closed to air traffic for 20 minutes while the affected runway was cleared of rubber debris scattered by the blowout.
Horrified passengers prayed for a safe landing, and blamed the incident on over-burdened air traffic during the Lunar New Year holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SKYROCKET ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices jumped 4 percent on the Taiwan stock market Monday, the first trading day after the Chinese New Year holiday.
Dealers indicated that the hot buying, especially for technology shares, was promoted by a rebound in regional stock markets.
The weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) soared 319.64 points to close at the day's high of 8,405.11.
The bourse opened at 8,260.28, and experienced a low of 8,245.42.
Gainers overwhelmed losers 438 to 13, with 20 stocks unchanged.
A total of 1.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$115.47 billion (US$4.69 billion).
All eight major stock categories enjoyed gains.

Electrical engineering issues registered the largest gain at 5.7 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks, which posted a gain of 5 percent; financial shares, 3.1 percent; construction stocks, 3.0 percent; textile issues, 2.8 percent; both paper-making and foodstuff shares, 2.6 percent; and cement stocks, 2.3 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were First Bank, United Micro Electronics, China Steel, Chang Hwa Bank, Winbond Electronics, Hua Nan Bank, Mosel Vitelic, Mitac International, Formosa Chemical and Fiber, and China Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA'S LIMITS ON US WHEAT IMPORTS MAY HURT WTO BID

TEXT.P: Beijing's continued refusal to accept US wheat imports that are shipped from Pacific Northwest ports could hurt mainland China's bid for membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to reports of the Geneva-based world trade body Sunday.

For years, mainland China has barred US wheat imports that move through Pacific Northwest ports -- including more than a third of North Dakota's wheat production -- citing fears it is infected with a fungus called TCK smut. But US scientists and others have argued there is no scientific basis for those fears.

US officials have cited the restrictions as an unfair trade barrier designed to protect mainland China's domestic wheat production, but mainland China still refuses to lift the restrictions, the report said.

In a letter to Sen. Byron Dorgan, D-ND, US President Bill Clinton said he raised the issue in a face-to-face meeting in October with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, indicating it could hurt mainland China's chances of gaining entrance to the WTO, according to the report.

He also said he will continue to pursue the matter with mainland Chinese officials and will present additional scientific evidence to support the US position that mainland China's restrictions are unjustified, the report said.

The restrictions have hurt US wheat producers, particularly in North Dakota. In 1996 mainland China sold US$40 billion more of its goods to the United States than it purchased from America. That trade deficit is expected to have grown to US$50 billion in 1997.

Mainland China's wheat imports have fallen drastically as the result of increased domestic production. Total wheat imports have gone from 12.52 million metric tons in 1995-96 to a projected 2.0 million metric tons in 1997-98.
During the same period, US wheat exports fell from 33.78 million metric tons in 1995-96 to a projected 29.26 million metric tons in 1997-98.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD BANK STUDYING WAYS TO SLOW DOWN CURRENCY FLOWS

TEXT.P: The World Bank is studying ways to moderate foreign currency flows in the light of instability in Asian financial markets, World Bank President James Wolfensohn said in Singapore Sunday.

"One of the issues raised by (Malaysian) Prime Minister Mahathir was the impact of currency speculation and I think that it is an issue that deserves serious attention and that's why we're studying it," he said after a meeting here with representatives of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions from the region.

At last September's World Bank/International Monetary Fund annual meetings in Hong Kong, Mahathir had proposed regulating currency trading, particularly in relation to hedge fund activities. He later said the World Bank had asked for a Malaysian expert to be seconded to the organization to assist it in looking into the matter.

Wolfensohn said Sunday that he would be "getting ideas" from both Mahathir and Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim when he visits Kuala Lumpur as part of his Asian tour to study the social impact of the ongoing financial crisis.
His other stops include Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and the Philippines.
Among the suggestions to curb currency flows was the levying of a tax on foreign currency transactions, also known as a Tobin Tax, after the Nobel Prize-winning economist James Tobin.
"There are other ideas like deposit schemes, barriers that can be put up at the borders; but each one of these is difficult," he said.
"And you've got to look not only whether it's going to cut down the flow of trading, or whether it's going to cut down the flow of real resources and so it needs to be looked at."

Although he declined to say when the study would be completed, he added: "I don't think the answer is simple. Nor do I think that currency speculation is the cause of all the problems in Asia. What we need to do is to have some sort of balance."
Wolfensohn said that the purpose of his visit to Singapore was to consult with the Singapore government on regional developments.
He is scheduled to meet Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong Monday. He had a dinner meeting with Finance Minister Hu Tsu Dow Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS SEEN CUTTING AUSTRALIA'S ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE

TEXT.P: The Asian economic crisis is expected to cut about 1 percent from Australia's gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate, according to Westpac Banking Corp., one of the country's four biggest banks.

In a televised interview Sunday night, Westpac chief executive Bob Joss said: "Our economists feel that it will knock about one percentage point off growth, so instead of 4 percent growth, we'll have 3 percent growth.
"I think ... it might even be worse than that, but it's just a guess at this stage, nobody really knows," he added.
Joss' forecast is in striking contrast with the Federal government's forecast over the impact of the Asian economic turmoil.

Prime Minister John Howard has repeatedly said that there is no reason to revise Australia's economic forecast of about 4 percent in GDP growth in fiscal 1998-99. Howard and Treasurer Peter Costello have said the Asian crisis would only wipe out 0.5 percent of Australia's economic growth rate.
That means Australia's GDP would drop to 3.25 percent from the original forecast of 3.75 percent.
Howard said the Australian economy will be protected from the Asian impact because of his strong economic management and measures taken to address the budget deficit.
But Joss was more circumspect, noting the already substantial impact on the Australian dollar, which has sharply fallen to the current 68 US cents from almost 80 US cents in March 1997.

"If you look at the foreign exchange markets and the markets in terms of the debt of these countries, it has had a very large immediate impact ... but you don't see the real economic impact where it starts to impact orders and sales and business decisions," he said.
"It always takes a while to flow through, whether it is the American economy or the Australian economy," he added.

He said the impact of the Asian crisis will be felt throughout the year. "Asia is a fourth of the world's population, and we are all tied up in the world. I mean, we are an international trading country and our economy is very intertwined with Asia, so of course we'll be impacted, as will the Americans," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS 'MAINLY ABOUT BAD BANKING': MIT ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: Bad banking is mainly to blame for Asia's current economic problems, according to Professor Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), who contends that the region's poorly regulated financial institutions and massive asset inflation caused the current turmoil.
Krugman made the comments in a paper on the subject presented recently at a conference in Japan last month, The Straits Times reported Monday.
The renowned economist asserted in his paper that the Asian financial crisis is "mainly about bad banking and its consequences."
No fan of the Asian economic miracle, he has argued consistently that the region's growth rates would slow down eventually as diminishing returns set in, according to the laws of economics.
However, even he was astonished at the speed and extent of the current turmoil, having predicted a long-term slowdown.

"What we have actually seen is something both more complex and more drastic: collapses in domestic asset markets, widespread bank failures, bankruptcies on the part of many firms, and what looks likely to be a much more severe real downturn than even the most negative-minded anticipated," he was quoted as saying.

In just seven months since the crisis was sparked off by the devaluation of the Thai baht last July, some regional currencies have shed more than half their values, losing more than a decade's advance against the US dollar.
Some economists have used traditional "textbook" theory to blame the present problems on the poor fundamentals of the region's economies.
However, Krugman rejected this, reasoning that economic fundamentals of the nations involved were largely sound, the report said.
The governments were in fiscal balance and had responsible credit creation and monetary policies, while inflation and unemployment rates were low, he wrote.
According to traditional economic theory, investors will pull out of a currency only if they believe it is likely to fall due to weak fundamentals, resulting in a self-fulfilling crisis.
Instead, Krugman argued that the woes were "brought on by financial excess and then financial collapse" in which the currency crisis is "more a symptom than a cause."
The root of the problem is the implicit government guarantee to financial bodies and the absence of adequate supervision, he contended.
For instance, he said, Thai finance companies had guaranteed liabilities until recently.

In December last year, Thailand closed down 56 of its 58 crippled finance firms, which had accumulated US$16 billion in bad debts, as part of the conditions of the International Monetary Fund-led bail-out of the economy.
Another example is South Korea, whose government arranged bank loans to the country's highly leveraged conglomerates, which were seen as the engine of growth.
South Korean bank debt, said Krugman, was in the process of being taken over by the government.
He pointed out that with such guarantees, Asian financial institutions were encouraged to undertake excessively risky investments, and engage in "the logic of moral hazard."

Moral hazard is a term used by economists to describe a situation when decision makers do not fully bear the consequences of their decisions. This then gives the banks an incentive to "play a game of heads I win, tails the taxpayer loses," said Krugman.
Since deposits are backed by the state, with underregulation there is little accountability for financial institutions that have fewer qualms about overlending or lending to high-risk borrowers.
The result of such an over-guaranteed and under-regulated finance sector, Krugman argued, is excessive investment.
This in turn fuels asset inflation, especially since the supply of assets -- such as property -- tends to be less responsive to price changes.
So the bubble of over-investment, increased debt and rising asset prices gets bigger and bigger, until one day, when over-optimistic returns to investment are not realized, the bubble bursts.
The system collapses when implicit guarantees, in the form of bank bail-outs and liquidity injections, become too expensive for the government to honor, Krugman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS BUSINESS IN TAIWAN TO LAUNCH IN JULY

TEXT.P: The satellite communications business in Taiwan is scheduled to kick off in July, two months after the launch of the island's first commercial satellite, the Chunghwa Telecom Co. said on Monday.

An official with Chunghwa Telecom said that the satellite, named ST-1, is being built by Europe's Matra Marconi Space Group, one of the world's top four satellite makers, and is scheduled to be launched in May on a French Arianne 4 rocket in Guyana, South America into a geostationary orbit 36,000 km above northern Taiwan.

The official said that the satellite is a joint venture of Chunghwa Telecom and its Singapore counterpart, Singapore Telecom, with both sides splitting the US$240 million project cost under a cooperative agreement signed in April 1996.

The ST-1, to be equipped with a number of advanced transponders, will cover the entire Asia-Pacific area, including Taiwan, mainland China, Japan, South Korea and Singapore and other Southeast Asian countries. It is expected to be especially helpful to businesses involved in remote communication, video and audio broadcasting and information transmission.

Chunghwa Telecom and Singapore Telecom will each build a control station, the official said, adding that several communications companies in Taiwan have contacted Chunghwa to learn the details of operating satellite communications businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO BRITAIN ASSUMES HIS POST
DOC.DATELINE: London, Jan. 1 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's new representative to Britain, Tzen Wen-hua, arrived in London from Taipei on Sunday to assume his post.
Tzen was greeted at the airport by a gathering composed of members of the Chinese community and officials from the ROC representative office to Britain.

Tzen took part in a party Sunday night that the Chinese community sponsored in celebration of Chinese New Year. Tzen wished the 200 people present at the festivities good luck in the "year of the tiger," adding that the representative office will do its best to serve the local Chinese population and others.

Before being assigned to his new post, Chen, 62, spent July 1996 through January 1998 as vice foreign minister. He has also previously served as deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, ROC deputy representative to the United States, ROC representative to Indonesia and ROC representative to New Zealand.

Former ROC Representative to Britain Eugene Chien returned to Taipei at the end of last year to serve as a member of the advisory committee at the National Security Council. Chien's tenure as ROC representative to Britain began in June 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FM BEGINS VISIT OF SOUTHERN AFRICAN COUNTRIES
DOC.DATELINE: Mbabane, Swaziland, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu arrived here Sunday from Taipei, Taiwan, to begin his visit to Swaziland and Malawi, the two countries in Southern Africa with diplomatic ties to the Republic of China.

In an interview with the CNA at Manzini airport near the country's capital of Mbabane, Hu said that during his two day stay in Swaziland he will extend President Lee Teng-hui's greetings to King Mswati III.
Swaziland, which is bordered by South Africa and Mozambique, has maintained close relations with the ROC since the two nations forged diplomatic ties in 1968.

In addition to King Mswati III, the ROC foreign minister said he will also call on Swaziland Prime Minister Sibusiso Dlamini, Foreign Minister Arthur Khoza and other high-ranking officials to exchange opinions on issues on mutual concern.

Hu noted the trip is aimed at strengthening the ROC's ties with its allies in Southern Africa in the wake of the Central African Republic switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing last Thursday.
With the switch, the number of countries maintaining official relations with the ROC has been reduced to 28.
During the brief interview, the foreign minister stated the fact that China has been divided since the 1949 civil war.
He stressed that the 21 million people on Taiwan have the right to enjoy democracy, freedom and prosperity and that the ROC on Taiwan deserves space in the international community.
Beijing, which regards Taiwan as a renegade province, spares no effort to stamp out international recognition of the ROC.
Hu added that although the unification of China is important to every Chinese person around the world, its realization must guarantee a better, not worse, life will follow.
Hu is scheduled to leave for Malawi on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OPENS CONVENTION ON FUTURE STATUS

TEXT.P: Australia began a historic constitutional convention on Monday that will determine whether or not the country becomes a republic.

Altogether 152 delegates from all walks of life throughout Australia are taking part in the two-week meeting to discuss in detail how the country might become a republic and how the head of the newly-defined government -- a president -- would be elected.
Half of the 152 delegates were elected, while the rest were appointed by the federal government.
With most of the delegates declaring themselves republicans, the convention is expected to dump the British monarch as Australia's head of state, analysts said.

On the eve of the conference in Canberra, Malcolm Turnbull, chairman of the Australian Republican Movement (ARM), said he had an open mind on provisions that would give the prime minister the power of dismissal, codify the president's powers in the Constitution rather than leaving them to convention and have a public nomination process for presidential candidates.

The ARM has the largest single group at the convention, with 27 elected delegates, while Australians for Constitutional Monarchy (ACM), which supports keeping the British monarch Australia's head of state, has 18 elected delegates.
ACM executive director Kerry Jones said her group would be calling for a referendum as soon as possible to decide the future of the country.
"We say to republicans: It is your responsibility to get your act together and say what model you want to fight us on in a real referendum so we can all stop wasting time and money," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-M'LAND TWO-WAY TRADE TOPPED US$21 BILLION IN JAN-NOV

TEXT.P: As a result of hot trading between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, two-way cross-strait trade reached US$22 billion in the first 11 months of last year, up 10.7 percent from the same period of 1996, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) revealed on Monday.

Releasing these latest statistics, the bureau pointed out that the amount accounted for 10.2 percent of Taiwan's entire overseas trade in that 11-month period, and that spurred on by active business activities, the island's trade surplus with mainland China surged to US$14.9 billion.
According to the BOFT statistics, Taiwan exported US$18.47 billion worth of products to the mainland during the January-November 1997 period, up 8.1 percent from the same months in the previous year.
The BOFT attributed the growth in exports to the mainland's increasing demand for raw materials for chemical products, and for mechanical parts and components originating in Taiwan.
During the 11-month period, the statistics showed, Taiwan's imports from mainland China, mostly agricultural products and industrial raw materials, reached US$3.53 billion, up 26.5 percent.

November saw cross-strait trading reaching two new record highs, with the island's exports to mainland China climbing to US$2.07 billion and its imports from the mainland registering US$380 million in that 30-day period, according to the BOFT tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARCHBISHOP SHAN LEAVES FOR THE VATICAN FOR ELEVATION

TEXT.P: Archbishop Paul K.H. Shan of Kaohsiung left for the Vatican on Monday to accept the honor of being elevated to the post of cardinal by Pope John Paul II in a ceremony Feb. 21.

Shan was named a cardinal on Jan. 18, making him the first clergyman in Taiwan to hold that title since the death of Cardinal Yu Pin in 1978. Yu was raised to the cardinalship in Nanking on the Chinese mainland before the government of the Republic of China relocated to Taiwan in 1949.

John Paul's move was seen by Taipei as indicative of the importance the Vatican attaches to Taiwan's political democratization and religious freedom, as well as to the long-lasting relations between the Holy See and ROC.

During his stay in Vatican City, Shan will also attend preparatory meetings for a gathering of Asian archbishops. ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Raymond Tai will host a gala for the clergyman in recognition of Shan becoming the first cardinal in Taiwan in 20 years.
Shan is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Feb. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: US RELIGIOUS LEADERS TO VISIT M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation of three prominent US religious leaders will leave for mainland China next week for a three-week trip to observe the climate for religious freedom under communist Chinese rule.

The three religious leaders are Rabbi Arthur Schneier, president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation; Archbishop Theodore McCarrick of the Roman Catholic diocese of Newark; and the Rev. Don Argue, president of the National Association of Evangelicals.
President Bill Clinton appointed them to the delegation to observe religious freedom in mainland China when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin was visiting Washington in late October last year.

The delegation will depart on Feb. 8 for a three-week trip that will take the three American religious leaders to Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Hong Kong and Lhasa, the capital of Tibet. They will meet with Jiang Zemin, other senior mainland Chinese officials, and religious leaders of the Buddhist, Catholic, Protestant, Moslem and Taoist communities. In Hong Kong, they will also meet with leaders of the Jewish community.
The delegation will call on White House National Security Adviser Sandy Burger Monday to discuss the goals and nature of the forthcoming trip.

During the past year, violations of religious freedom in mainland China have become a focus of US congressional debate. Shortly before going into recess in November, the House of Representatives passed a bill by a 366-54 vote to deny US visas to all mainland Chinese officials who help Beijing carry out its policy of religious persecution. The action was largely symbolic because the Senate did not take up the legislation before adjournment.

Both the US State Department and Human Rights Watch/Asia put out detailed reports in the second half of last year criticizing Beijing for its violations of religious freedom. According to the reports, Tibetan Buddhists, Moslems in Xinjiang, and the Catholic underground churches in various cities of mainland China have suffered the most under the repression of the communist Chinese authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T SPOKESMAN CALLS JAPAN TRIP FRUITFUL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's government spokesman, David Lee, on Monday described his current trip to Japan as fruitful, saying that he is glad to have had the chance to meet with the leaders of Japan's mass media.

At a luncheon with Taiwanese reporters stationed in Japan, Lee said that in the past six days he visited the Yomiuri Shimbun, Mainichi Shimbun, Asahi Shimbun, Sankei Shimbun, Nihon Keizai Shimbun and NHK, exchanging views with the leaders of these mass media organizations on issues of mutual concern.

Lee said that the Japanese mass media is most concerned about and interested in the effect the financial turmoil that has swept the Asian area might have on the rest of the world and the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, adding that Hong Kong-related issues and the possible devaluation of the Reminbi were also often discussed in the meetings.

Lee said that on many occasions he told the Japanese media leaders that with the Cold War era over, the zero-sum paradigm should no longer be used in interpreting relations involving Tokyo, Beijing and Taipei.
He also expressed the hope to the influential mass media leaders that while developing its relations with the mainland China, Japan will also further its friendly and substantial ties with the ROC.

On news reports in Taiwan that he will exchange his post of director-general of the Government Information Office for that of vice foreign minister in a proposed cabinet shuffle, Lee said that he is not sure about this.
This is Lee's first trip to Japan since assuming his current post last May. He arrived in Tokyo on Jan. 28 and is scheduled to return to Taipei on Tuesday. (F.M. Chang & Lin Wen-fen)

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZI KING REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Mbabane, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By J. S. Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Swazi King Mswati III on Manday reaffirmed his country's firm commitment to the Republic of China, saying Swaziland will continue to support the ROC's bid to join major international organizations and activities.
Mswati made the statement while meeting with ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu, who arrived here on Sunday for a brief visit aimed at shoring up friendly relations between the two countries.
Mswati said he is grateful for all the assistance and encouragement the ROC has extended to his country over the past years.
"I hope ROC-Swazi cooperation will be further reinforced in the future," Mswati said, adding Hu's current visit to Mbabane signifies the ROC's sincerity to promote bilateral relations.

The Swazi king went on to say that South Africa's switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1 will by no means affect his country's relations with the ROC. Because of geographic proximity, Swaziland has traditionally maintained close ties with South Africa.

Nevertheless, Mswati said Swaziland will not follow the lead of South Africa in adjusting its relations with the ROC. "As an independent sovereign state, Swaziland will decide on its own with which country it will maintain formal diplomatic ties," he stressed.
Noting that he fully understands the difficulties the ROC faces in the diplomatic front, Mswati said his country will continue to support the ROC in the international community.

For his part, Hu said he appreciates the Swazi government's firm commitment to the ROC. He also assured the Swazi king that the ROC government and people will work hand in hand to boost cooperative ties with Swaziland.
Hu was accompanied by ROC Ambassador to Swaziland Enti Liu during his meeting with King Mswati.
Earlier in the day, Hu also met with Swazi Prime Minister Sibusiso Dlamini to discuss concrete measures to promote bilateral cooperation.
Dlamini assured Hu that Swaziland will neither adjust its 30-year diplomatic ties with the ROC nor waver in its support for Taiwan's basic stance.

Dlamini said Swaziland will sign an investment protection accord with the ROC in March when the two countries will hold a ministerial-level economic and technological cooperation conference in Mbabane. "The accord is aimed at attracting more Taiwan companies to invest in our country," he added.

Dlamini said the Swazi government has set up an Investment Promotion Authority to lure investors from Taiwan and other countries around the world. "We need foreign capital and expertise to help upgrade our agriculture, education and infrastructure as well as boost our general economic development."

The Swazi prime minister told Hu that Taiwan's Tuntex Group has set up a garment production facility in Swaziland, which currently hires 500 Swazi workers. Dlamini said he hopes more Taiwan entrepreneurs will establish plants in Swaziland to help lower its unemployment rate.
On Monday, Hu also met with his Swazi counterpart, Arthur Khoza, and invited him to visit the ROC in the second half of this year.
Hu will travel to Malawi on Tuesday for a three-day visit as part of his effort to cement the ROC's relations with the southeastern African ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHONY POLICE HIJACK MILLIONS IN MICROCHIPS

TEXT.P: A truck filled with SDRAM (synchronous dynamic random access memory), one of the most widely used microchips in the digital industry, was hijacked in broad daylight Monday outside a company in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.
The SDRAM, worth over NT$170 million (US$5 million), was loaded in a freight company truck that was taking the chips to the airport for transport to customers in Japan and Germany.

Huang Yun-chang, the 25-year-old truck driver, told police that about 8:55 a.m., only a few minutes after he picked up the cargo from United Test Center (UTC) Inc. in Taiwan's silicon valley, five men dressed as police ordered him to pull over, shouting, "This is the police!" and "Security check!"
The driver said that after he stopped, one of the men dragged him into a sedan that had been following his truck, and that two of the other robbers took off in the truck.
Huang was blindfolded and then driven to an isolated rural area, where he was left stranded.
Police located the truck in Chutung township, near Hsinchu city, around noon Tuesday. A small portion of the cargo was found inside.

A UTC spokesman didn't rule out the possibility of an inside job, noting that few people knew the chips -- which were tailor-made for notebook computer makers in Japan and Germany -- were to be delivered Monday, the first working day after the Chinese New Year holiday.
He said the robbers were clever and well-prepared, and that they probably knew the chips they made off with could be used in almost any PC manufacturing plant.
Police have been on high alert since noon Monday, particularly at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, suspecting the robbers may try to smuggle the chips to buyers overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REP CALLS FOR BETTER COMMUNICATION MECHANISM WITH HK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top liaison official in Hong Kong on Monday renewed his call for the creation of a more efficient and effective communication mechanism between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Cheng An-kuo, managing director of the Chung Hwa Travel Service, the Republic of China's representative office in Hong Kong, admitted that Taiwan-Hong Kong relations have improved since the former British territory's reversion to mainland Chinese rule on July 1, 1997, citing that he can communicate directly with Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa's special advisor Yip Kuo-hwa.
He said, however, that relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong are less close than he had expected they would become.

Citing figures showing two-way trade between the two areas reached US$29 billion in 1997 and that Taiwan residents made 1.64 million visits to Hong Kong last year, he argued that the two sides should have a smoother and more effective mechanism for communicating with each other.
His remarks, made during an interview with a Hong Kong radio station on Monday, were published in several local newspapers the next day.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOODY'S DENIES DOWNGRADING OF TAIWAN BANKS' RATINGS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Jane-jane Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Moody's Investors Service, one of the world's two leading credit rating companies, on Monday denied a foreign wire service report that Moody's has downgraded its credit ratings for 10 major Taiwan banks.
"The report was erroneous," Jerome S. Fones, a senior Moody's executive, said, adding that the performance of Taiwan's banking sector remains good compared with its Asian counterparts.

Fones said the company issued an "outlook report" on Taiwan's banking institutions on Jan. 27. "The report was not a credit rating report. It was mainly aimed at reminding investors of possible changes in Taiwan's financial situation in the wake of the recent Asian financial turmoil," he explained.
Fones further said the credit ratings of the 10 Taiwan banks mentioned in the Moody's "outlook report" have remained unchanged.

In its "outlook report," the Moody's revised its rating outlook for Taiwan's banking sector to "negative" from "stable" because "there is heightened vulnerability of the sector to the ongoing economic crisis in Asia" and due to resulting risks linked to pressures on the New Taiwan dollar.
"These factors could impact the highly leveraged corporate sector and ultimately affect the asset quality of the banks," the Moody's report said.

According to the report, the Taiwan banks to be affected included Bank of Taiwan, Bank SinoPac, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, Chiao Tung Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Chinatrust Commercial Bank, E. Sun Bank, First Commercial Bank, the International Commercial Bank of China and the United World Chinese Commercial Bank.
However, Fones said, this doesn't mean that these Taiwan banks will face an impending downgrading of their credit ratings.

If necessary, Fones said, the Moody's will form a special task force to further investigate the credit status of Taiwan's financial institutions. Relevant Taiwan banks can provide related data or documents within three months for Moody's reference. "We would then decide whether to adjust our credit ratings for relevant Taiwan banks."
But to date, Fones said, the Moody's has no plans to form such a panel to look into Taiwan banks' credit situation. "We have no timetable for such a plan," he added.
Generally speaking, Fones said, most Taiwan banks perform fairly well and are highly efficient. In contrast, the performance of many mainland Chinese banks are rated "poor" by the Moody's.

US-based Moody's is one of the world's two largest credit rating institutions. Its rating reports consistently have a significant impact on general investment activities of investors around the world. For instance, the stock markets in South Korea and Indonesia tumbled substantially shortly after Moody's rated corporate bonds issued by some South Korean and Indonesia banks and companies as "junk bonds" last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 109.07 points to finish at 8514.18.
The bourse opened at 8583.38 and experienced a high of 8585.94 and a low of 8478.31.
Losers outnumbered gainers 220 to 218, with 40 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$186.57 billion (US$5.59 billion).
Electrical engineering issues posted the largest gains at 5.0 percent, while other sectors registered losses with paper and pulp stock losing the most at 1.5 percent.

Cement shares fell 1 percent, plastic and chemical shares dropped 1.0 percent, foodstuff issues moved down 0.8 percent, financial stocks declined 0.5 percent, and both construction and textiel shares edged down 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST ASIAN STOCK MARKETS POST DOUBLE-DIGIT GAINS

TEXT.P: Asian financial markets greeted the Year of the Tiger with a roar Monday, clawing back some of the losses incurred over the past few months.
The Indonesian rupiah led a widespread recovery of Asian currencies as markets gave the thumbs-up to reforms introduced by Indonesia last week.

Most major Asian stock markets followed suit with double-digit gains -- led by the Hong Kong bourse, with the Hang Seng Index rising 14.3 percent to 10,578.60 points, The Straits Times said in an analysis Tuesday.
In Singapore, the Straits Times Industrials Index posted the biggest single-day gain in its 25-year history, rising 173.07 points to close at 1,432.99 points.
The Singapore dollar, however, ceded some of its gains last Friday. At the close of Asian trade Monday, it was trading at S$1.7185 to the US dollar, weaker than Friday's S$1.7170.

The rupiah surged 28 percent to 9,750 to the US dollar before weakening to 10,275. Frenzied buying added a hefty 68.17 points or 14 percent to the Jakarta Composite Index, which closed at 554.11 points.
In Thailand, the baht closed 5.6 percent higher at 50.88 to the US dollar, while the benchmark SET Index rose 12 percent to 554.75 points.
Last Friday, Thailand lifted controls on the baht which were introduced last year in a futile attempt to prevent speculators from attacking the currency further.
In the Philippines, the peso rose 3.7 percent to close at 41.30 to the US dollar. The Philippine bourse also registered a 10.2 percent gain to close at 2,145.70 points.
South Korea's Composite Index shed earlier gains, losing 4.2 percent to 543.68 points.
Regional sentiment was buoyed Monday by South Korea's restructuring of US$24 billion worth of short-term debts and Thailand's scrapping of its two-tier system for baht trading, said analysts here.
Foreign institutions were involved heavily in mopping up stocks across Asia, they said. They bought up mainly blue-chip banking and property stocks.

Last week, the Indonesian government announced a slew of confidence-boosting measures such as a temporary freeze on corporate debt repayments, the opening up of local banks to foreign acquisition as well as committees to deal with the country's US$65 billion corporate debt.

The declaration of a voluntary corporate debt moratorium, coupled with the implementation of a host of market-friendly measures, should boost the rupiah substantially in the near term, said an Asian markets researcher.

But some analysts warned that it was still too early to say if Asia's fortunes had changed for the better, citing the specter of "real economic pains" like inflation and unemployment, the report said.
Indonesia, for example, announced a higher set of inflation figures Monday, analysts said. Rising prices of food and basic commodities are likely to spark social unrest, they warned.
And even though South Korea delayed payment of its short-term debt, it still has more than US$50 billion due over the next 12 months, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.282 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$33.08.
The greenback opened at 33.20 and was traded between 32.85 and 33.24.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$569 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG BANK OF CANADA BUYS NATWEST CANADA

TEXT.P: Hong Kong Bank of Canada announced Monday it has purchased the National Westminster (NatWest) Bank of Canada. It did not disclose the price tag for the expansion.

Hong Kong Bank of Canada is the largest foreign bank in Canada. NatWest Canada, which had its parent company in Britain, employs 32 people in Toronto and had net assets of C$107.3 million (US$73.5 million) at the end of fiscal 1997.

Hong Kong Bank of Canada has grown rapidly in the last decade through acquisitions. Since 1990, the bank has acquired the Canadian operations of Barclays and Lloyds banks, Metropolitan Trust Co. of Canada and ANZ Bank of Canada.
It now has about 117 branches across Canada and assets of more than C$24 billion. It is three times the size of its nearest foreign competitor, German-owned Deutsche Bank Canada.
"We believe this acquisition will enable us to serve a wider range of business customers in Canada," Youssef Nasr, president of Hong Kong Bank of Canada, said in a release.

Hong Kong Bank of Canada is an indirectly held, wholly owned subsidiary of Britain's HSBC Holdings, one of the world's biggest financial services companies, with assets of C$632 billion and operations in 79 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINATRUST SAID EYEING BANGKOK BANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chinatrust Commercial Bank is making an ambitious approach to buy a slice of the Bangkok Bank as a stepping stone to the wider world, according to an Australian daily.

In a report Tuesday, the mass circulation newspaper The Australian reported Chinatrust's Chairman Jeffrey L.S. Koo is planning to take a slice of the Bangkok Bank, Thailand's largest bank, in order to give him access to the tremendous cash flows of Thailand's ethnic Chinese business community.
The daily's Asia business editor, Geoff Hiscock, said the timing of Koo's ambition to enter the Thai financial market is good because it is relatively cheap to buy a stake in the Bangkok Bank now.
Bangkok Bank is owned by Chatri Sophonpanich, an old friend of Koo.

Chatri Sophonpanich earlier told the Nation newspaper that the Bangkok Bank wanted to raise additional capital of up to 25 billion Thai baht (US$465 million) and planned to lift the limit foreign investors could hold in the company from the current 25 percent to 45 percent.
The daily reported the Bangkok Bank traded around 95 baht per share on Monday, well below its one year high of 193 baht in March 1997.
The daily also reported Koo might be negotiating to buy up to a 20 percent stake in the Bangkok Bank at a cost of around US$300 million.

Chinatrust, with assets of US$15.5 billion, is now one of the top 10 banks in Taiwan, according to the daily. It has several branches outside of Taiwan, including in the United States, Indonesia and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S TRADE DEFICIT HITS 2.5 YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Australia, hit by the Asian economic crisis, suffered a trade deficit of A$880 million (US$599 million) in December 1997, the highest monthly deficit in two and a half years, as a result of rising imports, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
This compared to a trade surplus of A$509 million in November.
ABS officials attributed the sudden rise of Australia's deficit to a 12.1 percent rise of imports of goods and services in December, the biggest increase of imports in almost 10 years.

The A$880 million deficit surprised the financial market, which considerably dumped the Australian dollar, causing the currency to fall, closing at 68.18 US cents Monday, down from 68.40 US cents last Friday.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello, however, moved quickly on Monday to calm jittery markets, noting that the deficit was largely due to the strength of the domestic economy.
"It's probably too early to say that this reflects the impact of Asia. What the figures are demonstrating is the strengthening of domestic demand," he told reporters.

But economists, who only expected a trade deficit of A$50 million in December, warned that the larger-than-expected deficit could widen Australia's current account deficit because they believe the Asian crisis has finally begun to take its toll on the country's export performance.
"The mix of strong internal demand and weakening external demand is a very unfavorable one for the current account deficit outlook," said Peter Osborne of the Merrill Lynch Equities (Australia).
Costello also admitted that the current account deficit remains a problem for Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW THERAPY MAY OFFER HOPE TO CANCER PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Long Island doctors have entered the future of cancer care by inserting working copies of a tumor-suppressing gene into a 55-year-old man to help counteract liver cancer.
Known as gene therapy, the technique can be used against dozens of hereditary disorders but provides new roadways into the molecular mechanisms that seed and drive the development of cancer.

Liver cancer is a key gene-therapy target, Newsday quoted doctors as saying Monday, because 80 percent to 90 percent of cases involve mutant or missing "p53" genes. The hope is that getting healthy copies of p53 into chromosomes of cancer cells will help suppress the rampant cellular proliferation characteristic of the disease.
Overall, according to Newsday, a mass-circulation New York daily, researchers believe that replacing p53 holds promise in 50 percent of all human tumors.

William Watrous, a retired elementary school teacher, received laboratory-engineered versions of p53 on Jan. 22 at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. The genes, carried in deactivated adenoviruses -- the viruses that cause the common cold--were injected through his liver's main artery, allowing the bloodstream to distribute the molecular packages to the four inoperable tumors that have invaded the organ.
Immediately afterward, Watrous felt some discomfort but says he's happy he made the decision. "It's the only hope I have," he explained. "There were no cures on the market for me."

Last Tuesday, during his first examination after the procedure, all appeared to be going well, his doctors said. Still, only time will tell whether the genes enter tumor cells, as they're supposed to, and switch off growth.
The hope is that the new genes will produce a protein that leads to apoptosis, or cell death, within the tumors, helping to shrink them.

The procedure, the first in what North Shore doctors hope will be a long line of genetic studies conducted there, was part of a Phase 1 trial. Generally, Phase 1 trials examine a drug's toxicity. Later, in other trials, scientists will study dosage and effectiveness

Gene therapy has long been one of the futuristic dreams of medicine. But clinical results aren't always in lockstep with scientific theory, researchers say, and there have been mixed results in many studies using gene therapy during the past 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN WOOL EXPORTS TO ASIAN MARKETS DOWN SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Australia's wool industry is suffering sharp declines in its exports to major markets, including Taiwan, South Korea, Japan, mainland China and Hong Kong, according to the Australian Council of Wool Exporters (ACWE).
An ACWE spokesman said the wool market has started to deteriorate at a fairly rapid rate because of the Asian economic turmoil.
He said 1998 will be a difficult year for the Australian wool industry.
He said the International Wool Secretariat (IWS) has also expressed "deep concern" with the gravity of the Asian situation.

The South Korean market, the sixth largest for the Australian wool industry, has been lost for an indefinite period, he said, adding that sales to Taiwan plunged by 31 percent in the first five months of 1997-98 compared to the same period in the previous fiscal year.
Exports to Japan also dropped 26 percent, and both mainland China and Hong Kong imported 14 percent less Australian wool during the same period.

IWS Chairman Alex Morrison said: "No one had foreseen the scale and speed of the current downturn and its implications are still difficult to assess. The next item on the agenda is whether or not China becomes embroiled in the financial and currency turmoil."

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER TO VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chen Chien-jen confirmed on Tuesday that Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will visit Taiwan on Feb. 11-12.
Chen said Anwar, who concurrently serves as Malaysia's finance minister, would come to Taipei following a visit to Japan from Feb. 7-10.
"Anwar's Taipei visit is private," Chen said, adding that his itinerary has yet to be finalized.

Chen would not say whether Anwar, who is widely seen as heir apparent to Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, will meet with Premier Vincent Siew and other senior ROC officials during his stay in Taipei.

Malaysia's English-language Sun daily quoted Anwar's personal aide as reporting over the weekend that Anwar would make a private visit to Taiwan following his Japan visit. The paper said Anwar is expected to meet with senior Taiwan officials, including Premier Vincent Siew and Finance Minister Paul Chiu, as well as local business and industry leaders, to discuss possible cooperative measures to address the Asian financial turmoil which has hit Malaysia hard.

Other press reports quoted Anwar as saying that he is not going to seek help for Malaysia during his visits to Japan and Taiwan, and that Malaysia is more interested in developing regional efforts to cope with the crisis.
Taiwan is one of the few countries in the region that have remained relatively unscathed by the financial storm.

Mahathir held closed-door discussions on Asia's financial woes with Siew on a transit stop in Taiwan after he attended an informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum held in Vancouver late last year.
For his part, the ROC premier managed to visit the Philippines and Indonesia in January to meet with their top leaders on feasible measures to resolve the regional financial issues.

Siew's whirlwind visits to the two Southeast Asian countries signified Taiwan's sincerity in wishing to join forces with other Asian nations to weather the current regional financial and economic difficulties, local observers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGSAYSAY AWARD WINNER HO MING-TEH DIES AT 77

TEXT.P: Ho Ming-teh, winner of the 1995 Ramon Magsaysay Award for community leadership, died at the age of 77 on Sunday night at his home in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.

Ho, a prolific bridge builder in central and southern Taiwan, was hospitalized on Jan. 27, the eve of the Chinese New Year, because of chronic liver disease. He returned home on Sunday morning and passed away that night, his family said.

Ho received the Ramon Magsaysay Award in 1995 for his selfless dedication to "improving rural Taiwan through good deeds and sturdy bridges," making him the ninth Republic of China citizen to receive the prestigious award, named after a popular Philippine president who died in a plane crash in 1957.

Ho and other volunteers built their first bridge in June 1971 after a flood took the lives of two young brothers on their way to school. Since then, more than 200,000 supporters have contributed to the Ho-founded Chiayi Philanthropy Group, either financially or in the form of volunteer labor in the construction of the bridges.
Over the past 27 years, the group has built a total of 228 bridges in remote rural areas of central and southern Taiwan, with another two bridges currently under construction.
The bridges built by the group, ranging from 6 meters to 160 meters in length, have all stood firm since their completion, strong enough to brave the typhoons that sweep Taiwan.

However, Ho's family said on Tuesday that if no one can take over the running of the Chiayi Philanthropy Group, it might have to be dissolved after the completion of the 230th bridge, located in Chiayi County.
Unwilling to see the dissolution of the charity group, several group members are planning to register the group as a civic organization to continue the good work initiated by Ho.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT RECEIVES ROC LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Eduardo Chen & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Acting Panamanian President, First Vice President Gabriel Altamirano, on Monday received Wu Ke-ching, head of a 22-member legislative delegation, and six other legislators from the Republic of China, who were named as Kao Yang-shen, Chen Han-chiang, Hsu Chen-kwen, Hsieh Chin-chuan, Hwang Kuo-chung and Fong Ting-kuo.
Earlier in the day, the high-profile delegation visited Minister of Industry and Commerce Raul Arango, to exchange views on ways to further strengthen Panama-ROC economic cooperation.

Arango expressed his thanks for the warm welcome extended to him by the government and people of Taiwan during his most recent visit to Taiwan in July, adding that he will add his efforts to the promotion of bilateral ties.
The delegation arrived in Panama on Sunday for a four-day visit. They will also visit Belize, Costa Rica and Mexico before returning to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM DENIES CHARGES OF INDUSTRIAL ESPIONAGE

TEXT.P: The Nanya Technology Corp. (NTC) on Tuesday denied reports on its involvement in an industrial espionage case in South Korea.

According to a CNA dispatch from Seoul, South Korean prosecutors said they have arrested 16 people on charges of stealing top secret semiconductor technology for producing 64 megabit dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips from Samsung Electronics Co. and LG Electronics Co. and selling it to NTC.
South Korea is the largest producer of memory chips in the world, accounting for 30 percent of the world market.

Seoul prosecution officials said that Kim Hyong-ik, a former Samsung researcher, set up Korea Semiconductor Technology Co. (KSTC) in Seoul in 1997 and has received monthly payments of US$100,000 from NTC in exchange for technology it has stolen from Samsung and LG.
NTC, a subsidiary of the Formosa Group, one of the largest conglomerates in Taiwan, said however that it has found no evidence of wrongdoing regarding its cooperation program with KSTC.

NTC said in a statement that under the terms of the agreement it signed with KSTC in September, 1997, KSTC was to send engineers to NTC to jointly explore technology for making a new generation of semiconductors.

To show its respect for intellectual property rights, NTC specifically asked KSTC to give its assurance that it would not supply unauthorized information or secrets belonging to others while developing the new technology.
"So far we have found no evidence of violation of the agreement by KSTC, and we will absolutely terminate the contract if any such evidence is found," the NTC statement added.

Meanwhile, officials with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs refused to comment on the reports, saying that Taiwan is capable of developing the technology for making 64 megabit DRAM chips without outside help.
Industrial sources said that aside from NTC, at least five other Taiwan firms will begin mass production of 64 megabit DRAM chips this year.
Although Taiwan lags behind South Korea and Japan in 64 megabit DRAM chip technology, it's very likely that the island will catch up by the end of this year, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST ASIAN STOCK MARKETS POST DOUBLE-DIGIT GAINS

TEXT.P: Asian financial markets greeted the Year of the Tiger with a roar yesterday, clawing back some of the losses incurred over the past few months.
The Indonesian rupiah led a wide-spread recovery of Asian currencies as markets gave the thumbs-up to reforms introduced by Indonesia last week.

Most major Asian stock markets followed suit with double-digit gains -- led by the Hongkong bourse, where the Hang Seng Index rose 14.3 per cent to 10,578.60 points, The Straits Times said in a round-up analysis report in today's edition.
In Singapore, the Straits Times Industrials Index posted its biggest single-day gain in its 25-year history, rising 173.07 points to close at 1,432.99 points.
The Singapore dollar, however, ceded some of its gains last Friday. At the close of Asian trade yesterday, it was trading at S$1.7185 to the US dollar, weaker than Friday's S$1.7170.

The rupiah surges 28 per cent to 9,750 to the US dollar before weakening to 10,275. Frenzied buying added a hefty 68.17 points or 14 per cent to the Jakarta Composite Index, which closed at 554.11 points.
In Thailand, the baht closed 5.6 per cent higher at 50.88 to the US dollar, while the bench-mark SET Index rose 12 per cent to 554.75 points.
Last Friday, Thailand lifted controls on the baht which were introduced last year in a futile attempt to prevent speculators from attacking the currency further.
In the Philippines, the peso rose 3.7 per cent to close at 41.30 to the US dollar. The Philippine bourse also registered a 10.2 per cent gain to close at 2,145.70 points.
South Korea's Composite Index shed earlier gains, losing 4.2 per cent to 543.68 points.
Regional sentiment was buoyed yesterday by South Korea's restructuring of US$24 billion worth of short-term debts and Thailand's scrapping of its two-tier system for baht trading, said analysts here.
Foreign institutions were involved heavily in mopping up stocks across Asia, they said. They bought up mainly blue-chip banking and property stocks.

Last week, the Indonesian government announced a slew of confidence-boosting measures such as a temporary freeze on corporate debt repayments, the opening up of local banks to foreign acquisition as well as committees to deal with the country's US$65 billion corporate debt.

The declaration of a voluntary corporate debt moratorium, coupled with the implementation of a host of market- friendly measures, should boost the rupiah substantially in the near term, said an Asian markets researcher.
But some analysts warned that it was still too early to say if Asia's fortunes had turned for the better, citing the specter of "real economic pains" like inflation and unemployment, the report said.
Indonesia, for example, announced a higher set of inflation figures yesterday, analysts said. Rising prices of food and basic commodities are likely to spark social unrest, they warned.
And even though Suth Korea had delayed payment of its short-term debt, it still had more than US$50 billion due over the next 12 months, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPEDITES EFFORTS FOR WTO MEMBERSHIP BID

TEXT.P: Taiwan will hold trade talks with the United States and the European Union on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) later this month, according to officials in the Ministry of Economics.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will meet with high-ranking US economic officials on Feb. 17-18 in Washington, D.C. to discuss policy-related issues, while an EU trade delegation will visit Taiwan to hold another round of trade consultations from Feb. 23, the officials said.

Prior to Wang's US visit, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu will hold trade negotiations with US officials on Feb. 9-14 to work out their remaining differences. Tariffs on agricultural products remain the greatest stumbling block in the US-Taiwan WTO talks.

Since Taiwan filed its application in 1990 to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) the forerunner of the world trade regulatory body, an ROC working party on Taiwan's WTO membership has held nine rounds of meetings. The Economics Ministry said on Tuesday that they have asked the WTO secretariat to arrange another round of working party meetings in mid-April.

Taiwan has finalized talks with 23 of the 26 WTO signatories that requested trade negotiations with Taiwan. In addition to the United States and the 15-member European Union, Switzerland is the other economy that has yet to reach agreement with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADER LEAVES FOR 10-DAY JAPAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, left for Japan on Tuesday for a 10-day visit.

He is scheduled to attend a two-day Asia-Pacific business forum sponsored by the computer giant IBM in Tokyo. The meeting has invited business and political leaders from around the Asia-Pacific region to discuss the promotion of regional cooperation.
Hsu will also attend Saturday's opening ceremony of the 18th Winter Olympic Games, to be held in the Japanese city of Nagano.
He is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Feb. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO TALKS WITH US TO ENTER FINAL-PHASE

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday that he will depart for the United States on Feb. 14 for talks with Washington on Taiwan's bid for membership of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Wang said he will conduct policy negotiations with ranking US officials on Taiwan's WTO membership in Washington, D.C. on Feb. 17-18, while his deputy Lin Yi-fu will hold technical talks with his US counterparts on Feb. 9-14.

According to Wang, Taiwan's negotiations with the US on the island's terms for entry into the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body have entered the final and hardest stage, centering on the agricultural sector.

The economics minister revealed that he is planning to hold supra-ministerial talks with Council of Agriculture officials on relevant issues prior to his US trip, adding that major discussion topics with the US side will focus on the opening of Taiwan's market to US rice, pork, chicken, and poultry offal.

Out of a total 26 WTO contracting parties which have voiced concern over Taiwan's trade regime, Taiwan has concluded bilateral negotiations with 23 of them, 17 of which have signed formal protocols with the island on its WTO membership, Wang elaborated.
The US, European Union (EU) and Switzerland are the three remaining WTO members to conclude two-way consultations with Taiwan.

Officials with the Ministry of Economic Officials (MOEA) said the ministry has contacted the WTO secretariat to arrange a tenth working party meeting in mid-April, while the EU is slated to dispatch a delegation to Taiwan for WTO talks on Feb. 23-25.
