DOC.HEADLINE: THINK-TANK ADJUSTS GROWTH DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: Affected by the Asian financial turmoil which has challenged global economies over the last few months, Taiwan's economic growth is expected to go slower than expected, reaching only 6.25 percent in 1998, rather than the 6.45 percent predicted earlier, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) reported on Wednesday.

According to TIER President Wu Jung-yi, despite the volatile economic situation in the Asia-Pacific region, Taiwan can still manage to maintain an overall economic growth of more than 6 percent this year, due to its solid foreign exchange reserves, low foreign debts, and steadily growing foreign trade.

Researchers at the private economic think-tank predicted that Taiwan's economy will grow 6.16 percent in the first quarter of this year, and 5.97 percent, 6.06 percent and 6.78 percent in the second, third and fourth quarters, respectively.

The TIER forecast that investment from the private sector will reach its apex this year, with total private investment reaching NT$408.2 billion (US$12.37 billion), up a whopping 36 percent over the figure for 1997.

Public investment from the government sector, however, is expected to diminish to post negative growth of 0.09 percent as a result of the increase in the number of BOT (build, operate and transfer) projects, the think-tank said.

Even though the New Taiwan dollar has depreciated substantially over the last several months, consumption from Taiwan's private sector will continue to pick up steam this year under the favorable economic climate, which includes the implementation of a five-day work week and a sustained boom in exports. Private consumption is expected to grow 7.06 percent this year, the researchers predicted.

The TIER also forecast that Taiwan's currency, which depreciated some 20 percent in late 1997, will fluctuate at an average annual rate of around NT$32 to the greenback this year as the economies in the region gradually stabilize.
The New Taiwan dollar posted an average annual rate of 28.7 against the US dollar in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINBOND ACCUSED OF PATENT INFRINGEMENT

TEXT.P: Facing accusations of infringing upon the patent right of the EMI Group, Winbond Electronics Corp., one of Taiwan's largest manufacturers of semiconductors, stressed Wednesday in Taipei that they have never committed any such infringement.

A Winbond spokesman told the press that his company always conducts thorough investigations into every new product, to prevent possible patent infringements, saying that the company's cautious and careful measures make it impossible for Winbond to violate the intellectual property rights of other firms.
The spokesman added that Winbond will spare no effort in gaining in-depth knowledge of the case before taking proper steps to deal with it.

The EMI Group's American affiliate based in the US state of Delaware on Monday accused Winbond Electronics and its two branch firms in the United States of infringing upon two of their patent rights relating to semiconductor technology.
The EMI Group, which utilizes multiple technologies to support a wide range of products including video, voice and data services, is listed as the largest musical publisher in the United Kingdom.

This is the second accusation of patent right infringement against Winbond Electronics since last July, when an American technology firm sued the Taiwan semiconductor giant for infringing upon their patent right related to a process for manufacturing CD-ROM drives.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC, DAILY AIR ENTER INTO JOINT VENTURE

TEXT.P: The state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) and the Daily Air Corp. signed a joint venture on Wednesday as part of their efforts to seize a slice of the international helicopter repair market.
The signing ceremony was held at the Civil Aeronautics Administration, presided over by AIDC President C.H. Tsai and Daily Air Corp. President C.F. Huang.

Tsai said AIDC, which currently handles only military aircraft, signed the agreement in the hope of breaking into the world's private sector helicopter repair market. He estimated that this market will be worth more than US$50 billion by 2000, a surge from the current level of about US$29 billion.

Daily Air is Taiwan's sole licensed helicopter carrier. The company owns six twin engine helicopters and has plans to introduce 10 Russian-made 28-seater MI-171 helicopters within the first half of 1998 to crash in on Taiwan's lucrative travel market, which has been given a boost following the government's lead in implementing a new five-day work week scheme since the beginning of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RULING PARTY OK'S NEW CABINET NOMINATIONS

TEXT.P: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Wednesday approved a new package of personnel nominations which will shape the new Cabinet led by Premier Vincent Siew, who was sworn in just four months ago.
ROC President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui urged all party members to render their full support to the premier in the wake of the reshuffle.

In the reshuffle, Legislator and KMT Central Policy Coordination Committee Vice Executive Director Huang Chu-wen replaced Yeh Chin-feng as interior minister. Yeh, meanwhile, accepted a KMT invitation to be a vice secretary-general of the ruling party.

Lin Ching-chiang, a member of the Examination Yuan and former president of National Chung Cheng University, replaced Wu Jin as education minister. Wu enjoyed the highest poll ratings among the old Cabinet, despite his whimsical ideas about education reforms which often drew fire from critics.

Wu turned down the KMT's offer of a position as a minister of state in the new Cabinet, insisting instead on returning to teach at National Cheng Kung University, where he was president before being recruited into the Cabinet some 20 months ago by Lee Teng-hui.

Chiao Jen-ho, secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), replaced James Chu as minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission. Chu's possible new job was not revealed in the report on the shakeup.

Vice Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen and Government Information Office Director-General David Tawei Lee switched jobs with each other. Scholar-turned minister of state Chan Huo-sheng was nominated to head the Council of Labor Affairs, replacing Hsu Chieh-kwei. Hsu's new job was not revealed.
Lee Chi-chu, 38, professor of economics at National Chengchi University, took the helm of the National Youth Commission, making her the youngest ever Cabinet minister in Taiwan.
Huang Chen-tai, president of Feng Chia University, filled the position of National Science Council chairman vacated by Liu Chao-shuan, who was promoted to vice premier earlier this year.
Chang Jung-kung, deputy editor-in-chief of the Central News Agency and an expert on mainland Chinese affairs, was appointed as director-general of the KMT's Department of Mainland Operations.
Lai Kuo-chou, a university professor, chairman of many scholarly associations and son-in-law of Lee Teng-hui, was appointed director-general of the KMT's Department of Youth Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices ended 0.5 percent lower on the Taiwan stock market on Tuesday, the result of investors' profit-taking after two days of hot buying, dealers said.
Technology shares remained investors' favorites due to their competitiveness, but strong stock prices in this area absorbed most market funds, leading to cold trading in other share categories.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index lost 43.57 points to close at 8,470.61, after a market opening of 8,539.81.
The bourse experienced a low of 8,453.42 and a high of 8,578.3.
Losers outnumbered gainers 286 to 148, with 47 stocks unchanged.
A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$194.8 billion (US$5.8 billion).
Electrical engineering stocks rose 1.8 percent, and construction issues moved up 0.4 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were: United Micro Electronics; ACER; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; Winbond Electronics; ADI; ASE; Chuntex Electronic; Mosel Vitelic; Mitac International; and Compal Electronic.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI REAFFIRMS SOLID TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Malawian President Bakili Muluzi on Tuesday reaffirmed his nation's determination to maintain steadfast diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.

During a meeting with visiting ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Muluzi expressed sincere gratitude to the ROC government for its assistance to Malawi in areas such as medicine and agriculture, saying the aid has significantly raised standards of living for the Malawian people.

Hu, who flew into Malawi on Tuesday afternoon after visiting Swaziland, presented Muluzi with a personal letter from President Lee Teng-hui, in which Lee promised to try his utmost to strengthen bilateral ties between the two countries.

Hu also made a cash donation on behalf of the ROC government to victims of a flood which ravaged the African country recently, to rural primary schools for the purchase of desks and chairs, as well as to financially aid the building of several army dormitories.
Meanwhile, Malawian Foreign Minister Mapopa Chipeta refuted recent reports that Malawi is considering "normalizing" relations with mainland China.

Chipeta said Information Minister Sam Mpasu has never said that Malawi is planning to "normalize" formal ties with Beijing, adding that certain media agencies have apparently made reports which are completely untrue.
Chipeta made the remarks at Blantyre airport, where he personally welcomed his ROC counterpart's arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE MILITARY EXPANDS INFLUENCE ON TAIWAN AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Military leaders of mainland China have expanded their influence on Taiwan affairs, in the fields of both policy making and military exercises, exposing Beijing's two-sided approach to war and peace, observed the Department of Mainland Operations (DMO) of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT).

An article in the biweekly journal of the DMO points out that military leaders in mainland China tried to persuade the Beijing authorities recently to let the military have a bigger say in the sphere of diplomatic and Taiwan affairs. In order to improve the support of the military, mainland China's president Jiang Zemin is considering granting a bigger role to the military in those spheres, according to the biweekly.

In an analysis of the DMO's research, several facts are cited as evidence of the bigger role the mainland Chinese military is playing in terms of policy making toward Taiwan and other relevant matters.
One of the most important of these is that Zhang Wannian, vice chairman of the Central Military Commission of the Communist Party of China (CPC), advocates resolving the "Taiwan problem" by 2020.

In addition, it is rumored that the role of the "Central Taiwan Affairs Leading Group" may be promoted to a higher level by taking senior leaders and members of the CPC's Central Military Commission into its fold.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO LAUNCH TOURIST PROMOTIONAL DRIVES

TEXT.P: Australia, hit by declining numbers of tourist arrivals, will launch a A$5 million promotional blitz in Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and four other Asian countries in a bid to lure Asian tourists, the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) announced on Wednesday.

In a statement faxed to the CNA, ATC managing director John Morse said the campaign "is designed to deliver a strong message of Australia's price competitiveness and affordability to Asian consumers."

"The ATC recognizes that there is a need to re-evaluate our strategies and become even more aggressive in our approach, given the current circumstances. We have developed a modified regional strategy to minimize the effects of the economic crisis on the Australian industry, and build business immediately," he said.

Asian tourists from Taiwan, Thailand and other countries either showed a decline or the growth of their numbers dropped due to the Asian economic crisis and the racial debate triggered by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson.

Morse said: "The campaign, to be launched in seven countries across Asia (Hong Kong, Singapore, Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Taiwan and Thailand) at the end of February, will run through until the end of June this year, and is aimed at generating traffic to Australia now."

"The timing of the campaign, scheduled to kick off after the Chinese New Year, is strategically aimed at generating a quick response during a period which the ACT knows will see the real impacts of the currency changes begin to kick in," he added.
Morse said Asian tourists have become a major market for the rising tourist industry in Australia.
In 1991, Australia attracted less than 400,000 visitors from Asian countries. By 1997, the figure had skyrocketed to about 1.3 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DROP IN AIDS DEATHS IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: The number of New York City residents dying of AIDS plummeted by a dramatic 48 percent last year from 1996, dropping to just 2,600, the lowest it's been in more than 10 years.

It is the second consecutive substantial drop recorded by the New York City Health Department. Last year, the health department reported that deaths had dropped by 29 percent, from 7,046 deaths in 1995 to 4,944 in 1996.
The decrease follows the introduction of new, effective forms of treatment in 1995. But it also comes as the number of Americans becoming newly infected with HIV annually remains stable.

The good news is that many people infected with HIV can expect to live far longer than did their counterparts just three years ago. The bad news, experts said, is that the pool of Americans who are surviving thanks to costly and sometimes toxic combinations of drugs will continue to grow for years because thousands more Americans are contracting HIV every day.
As a result, the costs and burdens associated with sophisticated HIV treatment -- amounting to US$25,000 to US$60,000 a year per patient -- can be expected to swell dramatically.

The Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in Atlanta reported on Tuesday that national figures for deaths from AIDS were also on the decrease. 12,040 Americans died of AIDS in the first half of 1997, compared with 21,460 in the first half of 1996, a 44-percent decrease. The total nationwide figures for last year will not be tallied until July.
Meanwhile, a second species of AIDS virus, designated HIV-2, has surfaced in New York City, according to the New York City Department of Health.

Making a presentation on Tuesday at the fifth Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections in Chicago, Dr. Sara Beatrice of the health department said that because New York City has a large African population, it has long been suspected that HIV-2, which is almost exclusively seen in West Africa, might be present in the city.
In West Africa, HIV-2 is less virulent than HIV-1. It causes AIDS, but far more slowly, over the course of 20 to 40 years. Nationwide to date, the CDC has identified 75 HIV-2 cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN COMPANY LAUNCHES NEW BUSINESS UNIT

TEXT.P: Northern Telecom (Nortel) of Canada on Tuesday launched a new business unit on Enterprise Data Networks which will focus on delivering high-performance data networks globally.
F. William Conner was named president of the new line of business designed to help carry out the company's "Webtone" project.

John Roth, Nortel president and chief executive officer, has put forward a goal of becoming the world's top manufacturer of "Webtone" networks -- Internet networks that offer the same ease of use and reliability as telephone "dialtone" networks.

Nortel has been building data networks for businesses and communications carriers for more than twenty years. In 1997, Nortel's revenue from data and multimedia communications products was US$785 million.

"As corporations increase their use of the Internet and intranets for communicating with customers, suppliers and employees, new data network requirements are forming. Our vision for Webtone, in which customers will be able to rely on the Internet with the same sense of trust and security as they do with their voice networks, is designed to meet those requirements," said Roth.

Enterprise Data Networks are targeted at three customer groups -- global businesses with sophisticated networking requirements, and general business markets with multipurpose networking needs. In addition, it will continue to offer next generation data networking infrastructures to carriers and service providers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN FOREIGN MINISTER REAFFIRMS TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Panamanian Foreign Minister Ricardo Alberto Arias reiterated on Tuesday that Panama will continue to maintain diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.

Facing the changes in global conditions, Panama should adjust its foreign policy, Arias said, but added that no matter how the adjustment is made, it will not affect ties between the Republic of China and Panama.
Arias made the statements during an address at a ceremony in which the Republic of China donated the equivalent of US$685,713-worth of office equipment to Panama's Foreign Ministry.
Arias expressed his thanks for the ROC donation, saying that the equipment will greatly help modernize and upgrade Panama's administrative efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOWERING BLOOD CHOLESTEROL WON'T CUT HEART ATTACK RISK

TEXT.P: Aggressively lowering blood cholesterol levels does not lead to a greater reduction in the risk of heart attack, according to an expert from Scotland's University of Glasgow.
On a visit to Melbourne, Dr. Allan Gaw said his seven-year findings could overturn the conventional wisdom that the less fat in your veins, the better for your heart.
He said the research is the first in the world to chart the relationship between lowering cholesterol and reducing the risk of heart attack.
The research looked into the effects of a new generation cholesterol drug called pravastatin on 6,550 men who had raised cholesterol levels but had never had a heart attack.
He said the research found that men who dropped their blood cholesterol by up to 20 percent reduced the chance of their having a heart attack by one third.

He said he hoped his research would convince specialists to change the way they "look at lowering cholesterol" in patients, by placing a greater emphasis on lifestyle factors, including patients' diets, smoking and high blood pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SINGAPORE SATELLITE TO BE LAUNCHED IN MAY

TEXT.P: The first communications satellite jointly owned by the Republic of China and Singapore, ST-1, will be launched on the French-built Ariane 4 rocket in French Guiana in May this year.
The US$220-million satellite is owned jointly by the Singapore Telecommunication Corp. and the Chunghwa Telecommunication Co. of the ROC, The Straits Times reported on Wednesday.
The two companies signed an agreement in 1995 to commission Anglo-French firm Matra Marconi Space to build ST-1, which will support video-broadcasting, telephone and data services, the report said.

A spokesman for Aerospatiale's Space and Defense Branch told Singapore reporters during a briefing this week at its rocket production facility in Les Mureaux, just outside Paris: "ST-1 will be the 109th satellite to be launched by an Ariane 4 rocket. It is scheduled to take off at the end of May or in early June."

The Aerospatiale Group, with 38,000 employees and sales of US$10 billion, is one of the top aerospace companies in Europe, the report said. It makes commercial aircraft, such as the Airbus series, helicopters, satellites, rockets and tactical missiles such as the famous Exocet.
Its Ariane 4 program, which began in 1982, now commands more than 60 percent of the open international satellite launch market.

The satellite, which will have an estimated life span of 12 years, will become operational a month after its launch. It will provide services to Southeast Asia, East Asia and mainland China, with 24 transponders apportioned equally to Singapore and Taiwan, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA'S RECOVERY COULD SPUR ECONOMIC CRISES ELSEWHERE

TEXT.P: The same type of experts who failed to forecast the Asian meltdown last year at a World Economic Forum session now predict the worst is over for Asia, a Canadian columnist said on Tuesday.
In a dispatch from Davos, Switzerland, Diane Francis of The Financial Post said the good news is this means opportunities for investors.

"The bad news is plans by Asians to export themselves back to health will likely cause a currency crisis in Brazil, Russia and some of their Latin American and Eastern European neighbors this year," she added.
Worse yet, Francis pointed out, a rapid recovery by Asia based on exports could sow the seeds for future crises if it creates a US backlash toward bailouts and free trade.
A policy of protectionism by the US would have dire consequences for the global economy, she quoted the experts as saying.

She observed that the fear of a flood of exports is not unfounded. Mexico worked its way out of its 1994 currency collapse with cheap exports. Since then Mexican exports to the US are up 18 percent, while US exports to Mexico have declined 14 percent, she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE CORPORATE GOVERNANCE STANDARDS HIGHEST IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Singapore has the highest standards of corporate governance in Asia, well ahead of Japan and Hong Kong, according to global consultancy firm Price Waterhouse.
The Republic of China was bottom of the list of countries surveyed, in terms of standards of corporate governance.

A survey of 75 listed companies conducted with support from the Stock Exchange of Singapore showed that companies in Singapore feel the quality of local rules is well ahead of other Asian economies, it said on Tuesday.

"This confirms the view expressed by world economic and political leaders recently that Singapore is best placed in Asia to regain international confidence in its business affairs and bounce back from the current regional downturn," a Price Waterhouse statement quoted a senior economist here as commenting.

However, the survey also showed that business leaders believe Singapore still does not approach the best international standards -- especially those of Britain and the United States. Eighty percent of the respondents favor strengthening the rules to enhance standards.
According to the survey, the following countries and areas were rated, on a scale of one to five, in their corporate governance standards as follows:
-- The Republic of China 2.24
-- Malaysia 2.30
-- Hong Kong 3.09
-- Japan 3.18
-- Singapore 3.62
-- Australia 3.77
-- Britain 4.23
-- United States 4.35

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR RELEASES OVER 5,000 HECTARES OF LAND

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. has released more than 5,000 hectares of land over the past 15 months to help meet the private sector's demand for land lots, the United Daily News reported on Wednesday.
According to the report, Taisugar, dubbed "Taiwan's largest land owner," had released 5,597 hectares of land as of the end of 1997 under instructions of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The report, citing Taisugar statistics, said 4,237 hectares of the land will be developed for industrial use, while 530 hectares are allocated for environmental protection and medical care uses. Only 30 hectares are for public housing, with the remaining land being used for more than one dozen other purposes.

Taisugar was quoted as saying that it agreed to release the property in line with the government's policy to open state-owned land to satisfy private demands and that it hopes the move will help the government's efforts to keep Taiwan's businesses on the island, reduce the gap between urban and rural areas and give an overall boost to the development of Taiwan society.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PROPOSES GUARANTEE PLAN FOR INDONESIAN IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong announced in Jakarta on Tuesday night a Singapore initiative to help Indonesia "unlock" part of its international financial crisis -- a scheme involving several countries that would guarantee payment for Indonesian imports, The Straits Times reported on Wednesday.

The proposal, which he discussed with Indonesian President Suharto during a 95-minute meeting, could, if accepted, provide the Indonesian Central Bank with up to US$20 billion in foreign guarantees, Goh said.
Goh was in Jakarta for an overnight visit -- his second so far this year.

"Letters of credit issued by Indonesian banks are not being accepted by foreign banks. We have to unlock this. If we do not unlock this, LCs are not accepted, imports cannot go in," Goh said after his meeting with Suharto.

The Indonesian government announced last week that it would guarantee all deposits and debts of Indonesian banks, but many foreign banks are still not accepting their letters of credit, the report said. Analysts said even some of the big banks in Jakarta had been using customers' deposits to cover other obligations and delaying payment to LC holders.
There were two ways out of this dilemma, Goh noted. One was for individual countries to provide guarantees to their own banks that exports to Indonesia would be paid for.

A multilateral forum would be "more flexible", Goh said. It would take a little more time to implement compared to a bilateral agreement, but if only eight countries joined the consortium and put up US$1 billion each, there would be US$8 billion for Indonesian imports "straight away."
Indonesian authorities, with central bank reserves currently at around US$20 billion, have long said that the amount would be good for five months' worth of imports, the report said.
Suharto said he welcomed the multilateral scheme, the report said.
He said Australia had already agreed to guarantee Indonesian imports of certain commodities, as had the United States.
"I believe that we will be able to restore the economy," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS SEEN CAUSING NEW TRADE WAR BETWEEN AUSTRALIA AND US

TEXT.P: The Asian economic turmoil is expected to cut the export growth rate of Australia's commodities to the region but also raise the prospect of a new trade war between Canberra and Washington as a result of an aggressive US drive to sell more grain and other agricultural produce.
The warning was made by Dr. Brain Fisher, executive director of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) at the Outlook 1998 conference in Canberra on Tuesday.

He said Australia's commodities exports in 1997-98 would only rise 1.2 percent to a record high of A$64 billion, compared to the 1996-97 level. But the rise is small, compared to the original forecast of 4.2 percent.
He said Australia will face difficulty for the next decade because of the Asian currency crisis, which has generated more uncertainty than any world event since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

He said sharp declines in foreign exchange, property and equity markets combined with fragile banking systems and higher interest rates in the financially troubled Asian economies were expected to make a significant impact on Australia's short-term economic growth.
To make matters worse, he said evidence is surfacing that the US is aggressively trying to grab commodity markets in Asia by helping American farm exporters through its export guarantee funding.
The US is targeting Indonesia's imports of 38 percent of the Australian cotton crop, offering credit terms Australia could not match, according to Primary Industries Minister John Anderson.
The Australian officials said the US is also trying to grab the other Australian commodities markets in Asia through similar schemes.
Anderson said Australia would call on the World Trade Organization to police US trade credit terms as low as two or three percent over 30 years.
He said the US practices were "not quite cricket" in terms of trying to attract business with extensive credit.

He said Australia intends to target the architect of the US Asian credit strategy, US Agricultural Secretary Dan Glickman, at a meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris next month.

He said Glickman has sent US officials to Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta, Hong Kong, Seoul and Tokyo recently to "help banks and importers understand" the program of the US$2 billion in export credit guarantees the US has made available to the region and "to be on hand to troubleshoot should any wrinkles in our assistance crop up."

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.181 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.907.
The greenback opened at 32.901 and was traded between 32.85 and 33.085.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$416.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYDNEY FLU REACHES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has confirmed that an influenza virus, identified as Sydney-H3N2, the same strain of the disease that has already swept across much of the United States this winter, has landed on the island.

The DOH's National Quarantine Service (NQS) has issued a warning about the new flu virus here and is urging residents islandwide to guard against becoming ill, especially with the recent arrival of a cold front.
Meteorologists reported the front, which hit Taiwan on Wednesday, would bring rain and low temperatures of around 10 degrees Celsius.
According to NQS statistics, more than 134,000 people in Taiwan came down with various strains of the flu last week, the most cases of the disease in the health history of the island.

So many people became ill that the island's doctors saw an average of 198.8 patients each last week and scribbled out many prescriptions to reduce such discomforts as high fevers, coughing, headaches, fatigue, sore throats, runny noses, dizziness, vomiting, muscle aches and chills, the NQS tallies showed.
NQS Director Wu Tsung-neng said 26 US states are now listed as areas infected with the Sydney flu virus and that the bug has had a serious impact on society in the regions it strikes.
Noting that no vaccine exists yet to ward off the Sydney flu, Wu warned that the new intruder will almost certainly worsen the island's current flu epidemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM AGAIN DENIES CHARGES OF INDUSTRIAL ESPIONAGE

TEXT.P: The Nanya Technology Corp. (NTC) on Wednesday again denied purchasing technology allegedly stolen from a South Korean high-tech firm.

NTC President Chuang Yen-shan said that NTC has had no more than a cooperative relationship with the Korea Semiconductor Technology Co. (KSTC) -- the South Korean company reportedly behind the industrial espionage case -- and has not spent even a single penny to purchase other companies' top secrets.

According to news reports from Seoul, South Korean prosecutors have arrested 16 people on charges of stealing top-secret semiconductor technology for producing 64 megabit dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips from Samsung Electronics Co. and LG Electronics Co. and selling it to NTC.
South Korea is the largest producer of memory chips in the world, holding 30 percent of the global market.

Seoul prosecution officials said that Kim Hyong-ik, a former Samsung researcher, set up KSTC in Seoul in 1997 and has received monthly payments of US$100,000 from NTC in exchange for technology his company stole from Samsung and LG.

Chuang said at a press conference that KSTC approached NTC last May or June about forging cooperative ties and that the two companies subsequently signed an agreement on the joint development of new semiconductor technology.

Under the terms of the agreement, he said, NTC began paying some US$60,000 every month to KSTC for several engineers the South Korean firm sent to Taiwan, and that the amount was recently raised to US$100,000 because more KSTC engineers have joined the team to explore new technology.
"The allegation that NTC has paid US$100,000 to buy the technology is absolutely groundless," Chuang said.
NTC is a subsidiary of the Formosa Group, one of the largest conglomerates in Taiwan.

To show its respect for intellectual property rights, NTC specifically asked KSTC to give its assurances in the agreement that it would not supply unauthorized information or secrets belonging to others while developing the new technology, Chuang said.
"So far, we have found no evidence KSTC violated the agreement, but we would certainly terminate the contract if any such evidence is found," he said.
NTC is confident of its ability to develop new technology on its own, Chuang said, adding, "Even if our cooperation with KSTC is terminated, our development program will not be affected."
He said that NTC's 64 megabit DRAM chip plant will become operational next week and is scheduled to begin mass production in June.
NTC will, if necessary, take legal action to protect itself, Chuang said.

Meanwhile, officials with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs refused to comment on the reports, but said that Taiwan is capable of developing the technology for making 64 megabit DRAM chips without outside help.
Industrial sources said that aside from NTC, at least five other Taiwan firms will begin mass production of 64 megabit DRAM chips this year.
Although Taiwan lags behind South Korea and Japan in 64 megabit DRAM chip technology, it's very likely that the island will catch up by the end of this year, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA COULD FACE LARGER TRANSSHIPMENT PENALTIES

TEXT.P: US importers could see this year's quotas on mainland Chinese textiles and apparel filled more quickly if Washington moves ahead with transshipment charges against Beijing, according to a report in the Journal of Commerce Wednesday.

The two trading partners met in Beijing recently to discuss US allegations that mainland China transshipped about US$1.7 million worth of mainland Chinese-made goods through Hong Kong in 1995 and 1996.
Last autumn, Washington initially accused Beijing of transshipping about US$800,000 worth of textile items, but the amount has veered upward with additional information.

In November, the transshipment allegations involved US$800,000 worth of textile and apparel products, mostly gloves and underwear. The talks in Beijing were the second round after the initial consultations held in Washington in November. The US government is waiting for the mainland Chinese authorities to respond with additional information.

According to the terms of the bilateral textile agreement, if the United States goes ahead and slaps mainland China with single charges of US$1.7 million, then the volume of transshipped goods will be deducted from the current quota year. But if Washington decides to slap on triple charges -- in which the penalty would equal three times the volume of transshipped goods -- then the penalties would be spread out over the three remaining years of the textile pact.
The four-year pact expires at the end of 2000.

According to the Journal of Commerce report, US importers aren't overly concerned about the impact of possible transshipment charges. "It is not a lot," Laura Jones, head of the US Association of Importers of Textiles and Apparel in New York, was quoted as saying.

She was referring to the US$1.7 million in imports now under US scrutiny, a tiny portion of the nearly US$5 billion of textile and apparel that mainland China shipped to the United States last year. Jones said she did not know what type of apparel was part of the disputed shipments, the journal said.

But the possible combination of transshipment penalties, along with the Asian financial crisis, might mean some categories of goods from mainland China will be filled earlier than usual, she was quoted as saying.

Jones did not expect Asian apparel makers to flood the US market because existing quotas will keep a cap on the products, no matter how inexpensive they may be because of the devalued Asian currencies. "Maybe some products will embargo a bit earlier," she added.
The vast majority of products don't embargo until November and December.

If the United States moves to lodge transshipment charges against the Asian economic giant, it would be the fourth consecutive year that the US Customs Service has determined that mainland China evaded US quotas, the Journal of Commerce added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: In his first press conference since Chinese New Year, Premier Vincent Siew said that his recent reshuffling of the Cabinet was mainly aimed at filling Cabinet positions with the most suitable people and bringing new blood into the administration.

Job performance was not a major consideration behind the reorganization of his working team, Siew said. Wu Jin, who has just been replaced as minister of education, enjoyed a higher approval rating in several opinion polls than any other Cabinet member. His dismissal has caused public uproar.

Siew expressed his appreciation for the contributions and achievements of the outgoing ministers, who also include Interior Minister Yeh Chin-feng, Chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs Hsu Chieh-kwei, Minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission James Chu, National Youth Commission Chairman Huang Teh-fu, Director-General of the Government Information Office David Lee.

Citing his decision to tap Legislator Huang Chu-wen to be minister of the interior as an example of his reasoning, Siew said the interior minister -- as the man in charge of the body responsible for local autonomy, social security and other concerns -- needs the Legislature's support to accomplish the revision of related laws and regulations.
The premier said the need to reinvigorate the administration by bringing in new blood was another reason behind the shakeup.

He vowed to improve the administration's performance and called on members of his new Cabinet to work aggressively and in solidarity for a stable economy, the reorganization of the government, better laws, improved social order, higher living standards and warmer relations with Beijing.
Boasting his administration is action-oriented, Siew said maintaining economic stability will be a stern challenge for the government amid the financial crisis that swept through the region.
Noting that Taiwan was not immune to the turmoil, he said that his administration has taken steps to carefully monitor the unfolding crisis and minimize its impact.
Upgrading the quality of people's lives by wiping out industrial accidents and social disturbance is another goal high on the Cabinet's agenda, he said.

Siew vowed to improve relations with Beijing, but insisted that the dialogue across the Taiwan Strait should resume initially with working-level negotiations rather than political talks as Beijing has demanded.

He said that given the wide gap between the political stances of Taipei and Beijing, "political talks would only lead to confrontation -- and therefore a stifling of further contacts -- rather than to the improvement of bilateral ties."

Noting that the international community, and Washington especially, is urging the renewal of cross-strait contacts, Siew called on Beijing to live up to the world's expectations by reopening dialogue with Taipei in a pragmatic manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUINEA-BISSAU PREMIER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Guinea-Bissau's Premier Eng Carlos Augusto Correia is to visit Taiwan Feb. 10-14, said the Foreign Ministry on Wednesday.
Correia and his 10-member entourage will meet with Premier Vincent Siew to exchange views on the ties between Republic of China and African states and issues of mutual concern.
He will also call on the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Council of Agriculture and visit local cultural and economic sites.
Guinea-Bissau and the ROC established diplomatic ties in 1990. Joao Bernardo Vieira, the president of the West African country, has visited Taiwan three times: in 1990, 1995 and 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL HEADS FOR WASHINGTON FOR PRAYER BREAKFAST

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, departed for Washington on Wednesday for a prayer breakfast to be presided over by US President Bill Clinton.

Chang and his wife, Huang Mei-lung, are slated to arrive in Washington on Wednesday night and to attend the annual prayer breakfast on Thursday morning, which will bring together high-level political and academic figures from around the world.

Chang is expected to meet with several US congressmen, attend a seminar in Boston, deliver a speech at Harvard University and visit Chinese communities around the United States before returning to Taiwan on Feb. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHI HWEI-YOU TO BE SEF DEPUTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Shi Hwei-you, director-general of the ruling Kuomintang's Department of Secretariat, will succeed Chiao Jen-ho as vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), C.F. Koo, SEF chairman, confirmed Wednesday.
Chiao has been named minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in the latest Cabinet reshuffle.
Chiao previously served as SEF deputy secretary-general and vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council.
Shi's appointment will be formally approved at an extraordinary meeting of the SEF's directors and supervisors this weekend.
SEF was an intermediary organization established by the government to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties.
Koo said that Shi's rich experience in Taipei's negotiations with Beijing was the main reason he was chosen for the important position.

Shi was one of Taiwan's major negotiators with the mainland before Beijing unilaterally suspended cross-strait talks in the summer of 1995 to vent its anger over ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June of the same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN LU-AN WON'T EMIGRATE: CHEN'S WIFE

TEXT.P: Chen Chau-chien, the wife of 1996 independent presidential candidate Chen Lu-an, on Wednesday denied a local news report that she and her husband will emigrate to Macau.
Ms. Chen said that they love Taiwan and will not leave it, adding that although her husband has spent most of his time since the March 1996 presidential election abroad, his heart remains in Taiwan.

A mass-circulation local daily reported that the Chens, tired of being kept under surveillance by secret agents when in Taiwan, have decided to emigrate to Macau, where the cost of living is lower and housing more affordable.

According to the report, the former candidate has visited many places since the election, including Southeast Asia, Australia, the United States and Europe, and has made three trips to mainland China. Chen, a devout Buddhist, also went to Nepal and Tibet along with his master Sun Chun-hwa and his second son Chen Yu-ming to help the poor and contribute to the repair of temples there.
Ms. Chen said that her husband has gradually withdrawn from the political arena since the race some two years ago and is focusing his attention on charity work.

Not long after the 1996 vote, which marked the first time in the Chinese world that a president has been popularly elected, Chen Lu-an went to Nepal for three months to help establish a Chinese language school there and to assist in the repair of temples, she said.
She said her husband has always said that he likes to go abroad to enrich his horizons.

Ms. Chen said that last September the two of them went to the southern part of the Chinese mainland to collect local embroidery and woodblock prints. The visit, she added, was very fruitful despite its difficulties.

When in Taiwan, Chen Lu-an prefers either to go to his office to handle matters related to the foundation and magazine he began or to stay at home, she said, stressing that he has many things to do and will not emigrate to Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG EN ROUTE TO TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Governor James Soong on Tuesday commented for the first time on the sensational allegations of a scandal involving one of his top aides, saying that he was "very shocked."
Soong, who flew to Hawaii last week for his son's wedding before going on to San Francisco for a vacation, took a midnight flight back to Taiwan on Tuesday, earlier than scheduled.

Asked how he would deal with the accusations against his chief spokesman, Taiwan Provincial Government Department of Information Director Huang Yi-chiao, Soong said that he has to understand the whole situation before he can decide.

On Monday, Clara Chou Yu-kou, a well-known journalist, author and broadcaster, publicly accused Huang of having a two-year affair with her that ended soon after he allegedly forced her to have an abortion in October.

Chou also accused Huang of simultaneously carrying on an affair with a rich and pretty woman named Emmy Ho, who is very active in the island's business and political circles. Chou said that Ho and Huang have had intimate relations since last August and that Ho also had an abortion only one week after her own identical operation.
According to Chou, when Ho heard rumors of her affair with Huang, the woman asked him if they were true and Huang said no.
Chou said that Ho, at the prompting of her friend, well-known TV entertainer Pai Ping-ping, telephoned her in January to try to learn the facts.

After several conversations over the telephone and a meeting, the journalist said, she and Ho decided that Huang is a dishonest man who had been shuttling between two lovers and resolved to make public the whole incident to "teach Huang a lesson."

Accusing Huang of being a liar, Chou said that a man inconsistent in his words and deeds is not qualified to be a government spokesman. Chou also wrote a letter to Soong, asking the provincial governor to investigate the matter and to replace Huang.

Ho, however, declined to comment on all of the allegations, saying she didn't know Chou would make public the affair. While acknowledging that she has been seeing Huang for more than half a year and disclosing that he proposed to her, she stressed that she did not have an abortion as Chou claimed.

Huang, who divorced his wife one-and-a-half years ago, on Tuesday denied the allegations against him, saying that although he and Chou had spent some time together in the past, their relationship was never sexual.
He declined to characterize his relationship with Ho.
Facing the toughest challenge of his political career, Huang took a three-day leave on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHUT OUT OF US-SPONSORED FINANCIAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be shut out of a high-level international financial meeting to be sponsored by the United States later this year to discuss effective measures to fight regional financial crises similar to the one that has hit Asia since last summer.

The Clinton Administration announced on Wednesday that it has invited the finance ministers and central banks governors of 21 economies around the world to attend the meeting "scheduled to be held in the next few months."

The economies invited to the planned conference included mainland China, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, India, Australia, Britain, France, Germany, Canada, South Africa, Russia, Mexico, Poland, Argentina and Brazil.

Asked why the US has not extended an invitation to Taiwan, an economic powerhouse in Asia, Treasury Department spokesman Kelly Crawford said the US has only invited some representative economies. "Another Asian economy, the Philippines, has also not been invited to the meeting," he added.
The Republic of China's representative office in Washington, D.C. said American authorities have not made any contacts with it for the planned financial meeting.

The meeting will be chaired by US Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan. The exact conference date has yet to be decided. Treasury Department sources said the meeting is likely to take place immediately after a joint board meeting of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank to be held in Washington, D.C. in mid-April.

The sources said the planned meeting will discuss financial challenges faced by developing countries, particularly the recent Asian financial turmoil, as well as concrete measures to cope with such a regional financial crisis and to prevent recurrence of similar financial fiasco.

Testifying at a congressional hearing on Wednesday, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said the US should not adopt a hands-off policy in face of the current Asian financial meltdown. "We should financially support the IMF to offer aid to Asian countries in trouble and demand them to undertake fundamental financial reforms in order to prevent the regional crisis from triggering a worldwide financial storm," he stressed.
