DOC.HEADLINE: TSINGHUA U. PROFESSOR MAKES BREAKTHROUGH FIND IN FOSSIL RECORD

TEXT.P: The recent discovery of fossilized sponges and animal embryos dating back 580 million years ago in Guizhou, southwestern mainland China, has moved back the date of the earliest appearance of complex and varied forms of life on earth by 40 million to 50 million years, Professor Li Chia-wei of National Tsinghua University said on Thursday.

The discovery, which Li made with Professor Chen Junyuan of the Nanjing Institute of Geology and Paleontology, could lead to the overthrow of the current scientific view of the origin of most of the world's animals.
Li and Chen's findings were published simultaneously in separate reports in the most recent editions of Nature, a British journal, and Science, a US periodical.

Before their discovery, the existing fossil record showed that almost all animal phyta appeared within five million years in the early Cambrian period, about 530 million years ago. This apparent sudden evolutionary growth spurt is known as the "Cambrian explosion."
Such dramatic diversification in such a relatively short time puzzled scientists.
Molecular biologists advanced the idea the process actually began a billion years ago and proceeded gradually. Proponents of this theory, however, lacked solid evidence.
Li and Chen's discovery of plant tissues and animal embryos in rocks 580 million years, however, will supply important data toward understanding the mystery of evolution's "big bang."

"Our discovery of the oldest animal fossils, including sponges and various kinds of animal embryos, indicates there were probably varieties of animals belonging to several known phyta that lived 40 million to 50 million years before the Cambrian explosion," Li said in the Science report, which he co-authored.

"The results suggest the evolution of animals is a continuation of a process that began long before. Furthermore, the preservation is so superb, details of some cellular structures can still be observed. It may open a new window of exploring ancient biomolecules," he said.
Li told a CNA reporter that his and Chen's findings "may lead to the smashing of the myth of the Cambrian explosion."

The two scientists first became acquainted in July 1996, when Taiwan's Museum of Natural Sciences, which Li then headed, hosted the world's first international exhibition focusing on the Cambrian explosion. Chen was one of those invited to Taiwan to bless the exhibition.
The exhibition sparked Li's curiosity enough for him to quit his job as the museum's curator and return to teaching.
Since resigning his museum post one-and-a-half years ago, Li, a veteran molecular biologist, has frequently gone with Chen to Guizhou's Wengan County, where they finally made the landmark discovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AUSTRALIAN MINISTERS BACK REPUBLICAN MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard, an avowed monarchist, has had to watch as more and more members of his own Cabinet have come out in support of the republican cause.

So far, four of Howard's ministers -- Treasurer Peter Costello, Health Minister Michael Woodridge, Attorney-General Daryl Williams and Environment Minister Robert Hill -- have expressed their support at the ongoing Constitutional Convention in Canberra for Australia becoming a republic.
Other senior officials, including Finance Minister John Fahey and Defense Minister Ian MacLachlan, had already expressed they would support a republican Australia.
Other officials such as Employment, Education and Training Affairs Minister David Kemp and Industry Minister John Moore also said it's inevitable that the country will become a republic.

Only four officials -- Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, Communications Minister Richard Alston, Industrial Relations Minister Peter Reith and Social Security Minister Jocelyn Newman -- remain undeclared on the issue of a republic.
Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer wants Australia to keep the status quo but he also previously expressed support for an elected head of state.
The two-week Constitutional Convention is underway with 152 representatives from all walks of life taking part in an extensive debate on whether and when Australia should become a republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAO JEN-HO SWORN IN AS OCAC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Chiao Jen-ho, new minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), said in his sworn-in ceremony Thursday that it is one of the important goals of the government to improve service to all overseas Chinese in the world.

Chiao, former secretary general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), replaced James Chu as OCAC minister in a cabinet reshuffle. The SEF is an unofficial intermediary organization established in 1991 to handle matters relating to the civilian exchanges between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland in the absence of formal relations.
Chiao pointed out in the sworn-in ceremony that Chinese culture is a great force that can unite all Chinese people together to build a united and strong Chinese nation.

He also pointed out that communism and communist systems are "the greatest obstacles" to the modernization of the nation. "We shall explain to overseas Chinese that only democracy, freedom, and free economy can make their mother country a great nation," he said.
It is estimated that there are 36.1 million overseas Chinese in the world, including 30.6 million in Asia and 3.73 million in North and Latin Americas.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEN AS MERE SPECTATOR TO ASIAN TURMOIL

TEXT.P: Australia is an unimportant player standing on the sidelines of the Asian economic turmoil, according to Singapore's Information Minister George Yeo.

In an exclusive interview with foreign editor Greg Sheridan of the mass circulation newspaper The Australian, Yeo, who also serves in Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry, said Australia was seen as a friend who expresses concern but does not want to get involved.
"It is the reaction of someone on the margin, not an important player, not a crucial partner," Yeo said.

"If there's a melee and you get fully involved, then you bond with the people whose side you take and you bond permanently. But if you stay on the sidelines, then there is no bonding and you stay out permanently," he continued.
Yeo said Australians were possibly feeling some relief that they were "not more a part of the region and therefore not more affected."

But he said the regional economic crisis would be a defining moment in the lives of a whole generation of young Asian leaders. And the way powers such as the United States, mainland China, Japan and Australia responded to the crisis would define the way young Asian leaders think of them for the rest of their lives.
"How Australia presents itself and defines itself during this crisis is of infinitely more importance than Pauline Hanson and the speeches of leaders," Yeo said.
Hanson is an Independent Member of Parliament from Brisbane who triggered racial debate in Australia because of her remarks against Asian immigration.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ACCUSED OF GRABBING AUSTRALIAN COMMODITY MARKETS IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard has accused the United States of using the Asian currency crisis to grab Australia's agricultural export markets in the region.

On Wednesday, Howard announced that the government would give emergency credit insurance to Australian exporters to Indonesia and other Asian countries on a case-by-case basis so that they would not be threatened by their American counterparts, who receive export guarantee funding from the US government to sell their farm produce in the region.
Howard said the move is needed because Australia's Asian markets could be threatened by "actively avaricious" US export insurance schemes in Asia.
He said Canberra is "gathering material" on the American activities and is considering diplomatic and trade retaliation against Washington.

"At a time like this, when our exporters are facing fierce, even on occasions actively avaricious, competition from United States exporters into Indonesia who are not being shy in the export methods being employed in order to gain access to the Indonesian market, it is very important my government ... stands up for the interest of Australian exporters," he said.
"There is evidence that some US activity is designed to take advantage of the situation, and I certainly won't be silent ... in saying what needs to be said to counteract that," he continued.
The Howard government will give the credit insurance to Australian exporters through its Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC) when they sell commodities in Indonesia and elsewhere.
Last month, the EFIC provided about A$300 million (US$205 million) to Australian exporters when they sold agricultural produce to South Korea.
Australian trade officials have warned that the US push to grab the Asian markets might trigger a trade war between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.086 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$32.821.
The greenback opened at 32.85 and was traded between 32.93 and 32.75.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$387.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTOCOL, POLITICAL MATTERS CAN BE DISCUSSED AT SAME TIME: KOO

TEXT.P: The resumption of talks between Taipei and Beijing depends on whether the Singapore Agreement the two sides reached in 1993 is adhered to or not, and Taiwan and mainland China can simultaneously discuss both political and technical matters in the future, remarked Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, on Wednesday.

Once talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume, they can be conducted "without division between phases," Koo said, indicating that political discussions could take place at the same time as talks on matters of technical issues.
Cross-strait discussions should proceed gradually, he stressed, adding that the two sides "should never let their hands become tied."

Noting that political issues tend to restrict the options of both sides, Koo said that it would be better to settle technical matters before proceeding to a political dialogue and finally to political negotiations.

Koo's remarks echo those of Premier Vincent Siew, who, in his first press conference since the Chinese Lunar New Year, stressed more than once on Wednesday that while Taipei does not rule out cross-strait political dialogue, the government believes it would be better to resume talks initially with working-level negotiations rather than with political talks. This arrangement, Siew said, would better serve the interests of both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE NAVAL OFFICERS TO SERVE ON KNOX-CLASS FRIGATES

TEXT.P: Nineteen senior female Chinese Naval Academy cadets will be assigned to serve on the Republic of China Navy's Knox-class missile frigates after they graduate from the academy in November, a high-ranking naval officer announced on Thursday.

It will be the first time that the ROC Navy has dispatched female career officers to serve on missile frigates. Until now, female naval officers only serve on Ta Kuan (wide vision) observation vessels or on troop transport ships.

Hu Tsai-kuei, chief of staff at Navy General Headquarters, said female career officers have performed consistently well in the navy. Over the past few years, Hu said, the naval academy has assigned female sophomore and junior cadets to receive one-month training courses on tank landing-supply ships, pointing out: "The programs show that female officers are as competent as their male counterparts in terms of both physical strength and capabilities."

Against this background, Hu said, the navy has decided to assign the 19 naval academy graduates to serve on the six Knox-class missile frigates leased from the United States. Hu said all six frigates are equipped with living facilities especially designed for female officers.

Responding to reports that the US has agreed to sell three Knox-class frigates to Taiwan, a naval officer said the navy would only purchase two of the vessels, because the third is not in good condition. "We'll discuss the issue further with the US authorities," said the official, who preferred anonymity.

Asked whether the navy can detect activity by Russian-built Kilo-class submarines purchased by mainland China, the official said it's not easy to monitor the submarines because their hulls are made of special materials to reduce noise. The navy's S-70C anti-submarine helicopters are equipped with low frequency sonar to detect submarine activity in the waters around Taiwan.

"We hope the US will sell us ultra-low frequency sonar to beef up our anti-submarine capabilities," he said, adding that as mainland China has acquired several of the Kilo-class submarines, the ROC Navy has intensified patrols in waters surrounding Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINBOND TO NEGOTIATE IPR INFRINGEMENT CHARGE WITH EMI
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Winbond Electronics Corp., one of Taiwan's largest semiconductor manufacturers, said on Wednesday that it will begin negotiations on Thursday with the EMI Group over a patent infringement dispute.

The Delaware-based American affiliate of the London-based EMI Group neither denied nor confirmed Winbond's statement, but an EMI spokesman pointed out that it's not uncommon among high-technology companies to settle patent right infringement disputes out of court, as it usually takes many years to resolve such cases through the court system.

The spokesman said EMI has asked the Delaware court to ban circulation of products made by Winbond and its two US affiliates that have allegedly infringed upon EMI's patent rights. The company has also demanded that Winbond pay EMI damages of three times the value of its counterfeited products, he added.

Responding to EMI's move, Chang Shou-tung, a senior Winbond executive stationed in the US, said that although EMI has filed a lawsuit, Winbond has not received any court order. According to US law, EMI's charge against Winbond won't take effect until 120 days following receipt of the court order.
The EMI Group's American affiliate on Monday sued Winbond and its two US branches on charges of infringing upon two of its patent rights related to the production of integrated circuits (ICs).

The EMI Group, which utilizes multiple technologies to support a wide range of products, including video, voice and data recording services, is the largest musical publisher in Britain. EMI's American affiliate recently acquired Colorado-based Inmos Co., thus obtaining patent rights on a number of semiconductor and other related high technologies.

This is the second patent infringement lawsuit against Winbond since last July, when another American firm sued the Taiwan semiconductor giant for infringing upon its patent right relating to the production of CD-ROM drives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONNEL SHIFT WON'T AFFECT M'LAND POLICY: MAC

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), stressed on Thursday that Taiwan's policies toward mainland China won't be affected by the change at the top of one of the island's agencies related to cross-strait affairs.

Chang made the remarks during the inauguration of Shi Hwei-you, director-general of the ruling Kuomintang's Department of Secretariat, as vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official intermediary body established to handle private exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.
Shi is replacing Chiao Jen-ho, who was named head of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in the latest Cabinet reshuffle.
Shi, trained as a lawyer, earned a reputation as a tough negotiator by refusing to budge during several rounds of talks with his mainland Chinese counterparts.

Chang reiterated that the Republic of China has but one mainland policy, calling the MAC -- the highest government agency in charge of charting this policy -- and the SEF "virtually two sides of one mechanism."

Even though Beijing unilaterally suspended the cross-strait dialogue more than two years ago, the SEF has continued to work for communication and to push for exchanges with mainland China, Chang noted.

Chang renewed Taipei's calls for the resumption of the cross-strait dialogue, denying Beijing's accusations that Taiwan's policy makers have been lukewarm or even intentionally reluctant to return to the negotiating table.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices increased by 1.8 percent on the Taiwan stock market on Thursday, due to vigorous buying of technology shares.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index skyrocketed 151.36 points to close at 8,621.97, after a market opening of 8,492.92.
The bourse experienced a low of 8,484.37 and a high of 8,626.8.
Gainers outnumbered losers 261 to 173, with 47 stocks unchanged.
A total of 3.27 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$213.02 billion (US$6.46 billion).

Construction stocks registered the greatest gains, at 3.9 percent, followed by electrical engineering shares, which jumped 3.5 percent; plastic and chemical shares and financial issues, which both saw an increase of 1.1 percent; and textile shares, which rose 0.6 percent.
Cement stocks dropped 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 0.3 percent, and foodstuff shares moved down 0.1 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were: United Micro Electronics; Winbond Electronics; ACER; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; Mosel Vitelic; ADI; ASE; Chuntex Electronic; Macronix International; and China Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA'S MONTHLY INFLATION HITS 25-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Indonesia's monthly inflation rate for January hit a 25-year high of 6.88 percent due to sharp increases in the prices of food, housing, clothes and services, Minister of Information R. Hartono said on Wednesday.
Hartono said the January inflation rate was much higher than the previous record high -- December's 2.04 percent.

"The January figure brought the cumulative inflation rate for the April to January period, the first 10 months of the current fiscal year, to 15.97 percent. That's up from 4.24 percent in the corresponding period last year," he was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying, following a regular monthly cabinet meeting on economic affairs.
In January, food prices surged 10.15 percent, while housing prices were up 3.64 percent. Clothing prices rose 12.56 percent and services increased in price by 4.16 percent.
Indonesia's annual inflation rate was 11.05 percent during the last calendar year, the first double-digit inflation rate since 1983.
According to the Central Bureau of Statistics, the inflation rate in calendar 1997 was much higher than the 6.47 percent figure recorded for 1996.
The government estimates the annual inflation rate will hit 20 percent in the next fiscal year which begins in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, JAPANESE AIRLINES INK ACCORD ON PILOT TRAINING
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The local branch of Taipei-based EVA Airways (EVA AIR) Corporation announced on Wednesday that the company has inked a five-year flight training agreement with Japan's All Nippon Airline (ANA).

Under the terms of the accord, all personnel recruited by EVA AIR for pilot training in Taiwan will be trained by ANA's International Flight Training Academy based in the United States, EVA AIR's Panama branch said.

All the trainees will first receive a 26-week course of ground training in Taiwan and a second-phase nine-month pilot training course at the academy before presenting for pilot certificates for commercial airplanes from the US Federal Aviation Administration, it added.
All the airplanes used by ANA at its US academy are high-end training aircraft with an average age of five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DENIES CONCESSIONS IN WTO TALKS WITH US

TEXT.P: Senior government officials on Thursday unanimously denied press reports that the Republic of China would make concessions to the United States in agricultural trade talks next week in exchange for Washington's support for its bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said it's unthinkable that the government would agree to compromise on the thorny farm trade issues before a new round of Taipei-Washington WTO talks starts.
"We would firmly uphold our basic stance in negotiating with the US for joining the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body on the best possible terms for us," Chen stressed.
Chen Pao-chi, director of the Council of Agriculture's Animal Industry Department, also said the council would not sacrifice any agricultural sector in negotiating with the US for Taiwan's WTO bid.

The mass-circulation China Times reported on Thursday that Taiwan would offer to cut tariffs on pork and chicken, among the few items over which Taiwan and the US have yet to reach agreement, but would stand firm on imports of rice, the island's staple food.

The US reportedly has demanded that Taipei cut import duty on pork by 15 percent in the first year of its WTO entry, and that the tariff be slashed by a total of 50 percent to 7.5 percent over a six-year period.

On rice imports, the US has proposed that Taiwan follow the formula Japan used in opening its rice market, but Taiwan has rejected the proposal. Under the Japanese model, Taipeil would have to allow rice imports equalling 4 percent of overall domestic rice consumption in the first year of accession to the WTO. Imports would be increased by 0.8 percent annually over a six-year period.
Chen said the report is erraneous, stressing that the government would not compromise on pork issues because the pig industry has played an important role in Taiwan's agricultural sector.
Meanwhile, chicken and pig farmers as well as animal feed producers have threatened to boycott American agricultural products in protest of its pressure on Taiwan.

Taipei and Washington had held 16 rounds of WTO talks. Differences over agricultural trade, particularly terms related to rice, pork and chicken imports, have hindered the two sides from reaching a final agreement.

The two countries are scheduled to meet again on the issue starting on Feb. 9. Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu will head a delegation of senior trade and agricurltural officials to Washington, D. C. this weekend for working-level consultations with American officials on Feb. 9-14.

Meanwhile, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will leave for the US on Feb. 14 to chair policy negotiations, scheduled for Feb. 17-18, with relevant American officials over terms for Taiwan's WTO entry.

Taiwan has completed WTO talks with 23 of the 26 major trade partners that have expressed intention to hold bilateral talks with it concerning its WTO bid. The three WTO contracting parties that have yet to finalize such talks are the US, the 15-member European Union and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S FIRST AIRCRAFT VENTURE HITS SNAG

TEXT.P: Singapore's first foray into the development of new commercial aircraft could end before the project gets off the ground.

The fate of Singapore's participation in the Asia-Europe AE31X program is likely to be decided at talks expected to take place during the Asian Aerospace '98 Show to be held in Singapore later this month, The Straits Times reported Thursday in a dispatch from Toulouse, France.

"At the air show, we will have a meeting with the Singaporeans to come to a definitive conclusion on their participation," Jean-Paul Perrais, Aerospatiale's senior vice president and adviser to the president, told Singapore reporters.

Aerospatiale's Airbus Industrie and Alenia of Italy have established a special subsidiary company, AIA, as the European partner in the joint venture with Aviation Industries of China (AVIC) and Singapore Technologies (ST) to build a new family of 100-seater aircraft, the report said.
AIA will own 39 percent of the venture program, AVIC 46 percent and ST, the remaining 15 percent. The work will be shared according to this participation rate.

Perrais estimated that the development cost would come to US$2.2 billion, the report said. Two versions of the single-aisle aircraft are planned: The AE316 will be a 95-to-105-seater and the AE317, a 115-to-125-seater.
Both aircraft -- which will have a flight deck similar to the A320 -- will have a range of up to 2,760 nautical miles (5,112 kms).
Airbus forecasts some 5,400 deliveries in the 70-to-150-seater category. Over the next 20 years, the joint venture aims to win at least 30 percent of this market.
First deliveries are planned for 2003.
Meanwhile, talks on Singapore's participation have hit a snag, the report said.
According to Perrais, this was because of ST's insistence on a comprehensive business plan and an assessment of the rate of return before the program can begin.
"We cannot make an assessment of viability immediately. What we need first is a clear definition of the aircraft we're producing," he was quoted as saying.
"We cannot have a theoretical definition. We have to see if China, where the final assembly of the aircraft will take place, can produce them at low cost.
"This takes time. Only after defining the specifications of the aircraft can the partners decide on pricing and operating cost," he noted.
He commented: "ST does not have the experience in aircraft programs, which are not the same as those of, say, producing cars. There are quite different factors at play."

Asked what would happen if Singapore withdrew from the program, Perrais replied: "Well, we will have to find another partner. Or possibly, there can be only the two remaining partners. However, we hope Singapore will keep an interest in the program.
"The technical leadership for the program will be given to the Europeans, but personnel from China and Singapore will be integrated into it," he said.
The United States has been identified as the main market for the planes, where they would replace aging aircraft such as the Boeing 737.

"For this reason, the aircraft will have to meet the requirements of the United States if we want to compete with Boeing's 717, which will go into service in 1999, three years before our own 100-seater," said Perrais.
He calculated that 40 percent of the market will be in the United States, 20 to 25 percent in Europe, 12 percent in mainland China and the rest in Asia and Africa.
"The 100-seater would be operated by the largest of the regional airlines and the smallest of the big airlines," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENJOYS SOUND FINANCIAL FUNDAMENTALS: REPORT

TEXT.P: After successfully avoiding damage from the regional financial storm, Taiwan, widely seen as a haven for funds, has been recently given a high grade in financial performance.

According to a ratings report by Standard and Poor on the long-term credit performance of foreign currency issuers, Taiwan scored an "AA+" because of the low percentage of debt burdens enjoyed by all financial institutions on the island.
This performance has contributed to the island's escaping any big impact from the financial crises which have resulted in heavy economic recessions in most Asian countries.

The S&P assessment marked Taiwan as a country enjoying "stable" financial prospects, while the rating placed the island in third position among the Asian economies behind Japan and Singapore, both of which scored "AAA," representing remarkable capacity for managing currency circulation and monitoring financial operation, the report showed.
The S&P report, released last December, contains the US-based consulting and rating company's risk assessment of over 70 developed and emerging markets worldwide.

In the report, S&P gave most of the Asian countries suffering severe damage from the financial turmoil negative evaluations, with Thailand scoring "BBB," Indonesia "BBB-," mainland China "BBB+," Hong Kong "A+," Malaysia "A-," and South Korea "A+."

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU TO VISIT SIX AFRICAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu of the Republic of China is scheduled to visit six African countries later this month.

Hu, who will return to Taipei Friday after visiting Swaziland and Malawi, is scheduled to leave Taipei again on Feb. 14 for a week-long trip to Chad, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso.

His trips to the eight African countries are seen by analysts as a step to enhance Taiwan's relations with those countries after South Africa and the Central African Republic switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing earlier this year.
King Mswati 3rd of Swaziland and President Bakili Muluzi of Malawi reiterated their governments' friendship and support for Taiwan, when Hu visited them a few days ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER EXPRESSES WILLINGNESS TO RETURN TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Germany-based Bayer Group on Thursday told a visiting Taiwan delegation that it hopes its investment plan for central Taiwan's Taichung Harbor will receive a construction license from the relevant authorities in March so that construction can begin in September.

Although some difficulties remain to be overcome, a Bayer spokesman said the company still hopes that the investment plan, which has been temporarily shelved as a result of fierce opposition from Taichung County residents, will proceed smoothly.
Residents in the area fear Bayer's construction of a planned chemical plant will cause pollution, but the spokesman urged the people of Taiwan to have confidence in Bayer's technology and sincerity.

He made the remarks while making a presentation on Bayer's safety measures and management to the delegation composed of more than 30 academics, opinion leaders and government officials of the Republic of China.
The government-led delegation, which departed Taipei for Germany on Wednesday, was visiting Bayer headquarters in a last-ditch effort to woo the pharmaceutical giant back to Taiwan.

Y.S. Liu, one of the delegates and vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said ROC Premier Vincent Siew is very concerned about subsequent developments in the matter and has asked the delegation to bring back first-hand and detailed information to serve as a reference for policy decisions by the relevant government agencies.
Liu said the central government has been actively coordinating with the country's provincial council, in the hope that it will call a session in mid-February to review the Bayer case.

Bayer announced in December that it was withdrawing a NT$50 billion plan to build a production plant for toluene di-isocyanate near central Taichung Harbor after Liao Yung-Lai, the then newly elected Taichung County Magistrate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, vowed to hold a public referendum to decide the fate of the controversial plan.

Siew and Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong both wrote to Bayer, in late December and early this year respectively, suggesting the group reconsider its withdrawal, but the company claimed to have already found an alternative site in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN MUST PLAY ACTIVE ROLE IN HELPING OTHER ASIAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky has blasted Japan for what she called "woefully inadequate" efforts to help other Asian nations emerge from the ongoing financial crisis, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Thursday.

"Japan, as the world's second-largest economy, must play a more active role in helping to bring Asia out of its current economic crisis," the WTO report quoted Barshefsky as saying. "Its efforts to date have been woefully inadequate."

"Japan must stimulate domestic demand. It must deregulate its economy. It must open up to provide a market of first resort for the tremendous productive capacity of the region," the US trade representative was quoted as saying.

On the other hand, Barshefsky praised communist China for playing the "most constructive" role in the crisis, citing Beijing's recent commitments to economic reforms and exchange rate stability without devaluating its currency.
Her remarks echoed recent comments by other top US officials who have urged Tokyo to take further economic action, including fiscal and banking measures, to ensure a solid recovery.
In Washington, concerns are spreading that the US may become the only and last resort, with its strong economy to absorb more imports from Asia, to help the affected nations.
But Barshefsky reiterated the US commitments to restoring stability in Asia as long as crisis-hit nations continue to proceed with economic reforms imposed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

"We cannot expect that Asia will sort out its problems without us, and we cannot afford the consequences if does not," the WTO report quoted Barshefsky as saying, noting that affected Asian economies "must reform or recovery is impossible.

"We must be in a position to help them do it," Barshefsky said in urging the US Congress to authorize US$18 billion in funds planned to be extended to the IMF to beef up its functions, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL TO VISIT SEOUL
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Bear Lee & Chiang Yuan-chen)

TEXT.P: John Chang, Secretary-General of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is scheduled to visit Seoul on Feb. 11-14, according to informed diplomatic sources here.
Chang will be the highest-ranking Taiwan politician to visit South Korea since the two nations severed official diplomatic relations in 1992.

He is expected to meet South Korean President-elect Kim Dae-jung for discussions on a wide range of issues, including ways to improve substantive ties and trade and economic cooperation between the two nations.
Kim will be sworn into office on Feb. 25.

Chang will also call on officials from the major South Korean political parties, including Kim's National Congress for New Politics (NCNP) and its conservative ally, the United Liberal Democrats (ULD).
The KMT secretary-general will also meet representatives of Chinese communities here.
Accompanying Chang during the trip will be his deputy, Chung Jung-chi, KMT Organization Affairs Department chief Cheng Chun-tsan, and Overseas Chinese Affairs Department chief Wang Neng-chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR REPLACES SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan Governor James Soong on Thursday assigned new posts to his chief spokesman in a quick response to sensational allegations that have for days captured Taiwan's media spotlight.

Soong made his decision several hours after he returned from a US trip, opting to remove Huang Yi-Chiao from his post as Taiwan provincial government information chief and demoting him by one rank to the post of "acting deputy secretary-general," as well as "consultant" in Soong's administration.

In a statement issued at noon, Soong reaffirmed Huang's ability, professional performance and dedication to the job of provincial government spokesman, but stressed the importance he attaches to a civil servant's moral character.

Considering the fact that the allegations against Huang might have a negative impact on society and harm the image of the provincial government as a close-knit team, Soong decided to relieve Huang from his post immediately, the statement said, adding that if Huang were to remain in the position, he might encounter difficulties in carrying out his duties in the wake of the scandal.

"Public figures and civil servants should impose strict moral standards on themselves to meet public expectations, as what they say and how they act will in some way serve as a model to the public," said Chin Ching-sheng, Huang's successor and former deputy secretary-general in the provincial administration, reading from Soong's statement.

"The governor has set high moral standards for himself and always demands the same self discipline from his staff. In addition to ability and performance, the governor attaches much importance to the moral character of his staff members.

"The governor believes that decency and honesty among civil servants is essential to win the trust of the people. Being honest and upright is not only the basic requirements for civil servants, it is also their responsibility to society" the statement said.

Huang, who has not been seen in public since taking a three-day leave on Tuesday, entered Soong's official residence at around 8:35 a.m., where he reportedly apologized for the adverse attention he has brought on the provincial government and asked Soong to forgive him.
Local reports said that Soong didn't scold him.
Clara Chou Yu-kuo, a popular journalist, author and broadcaster who accused Huang of carrying on simultaneous affairs with her and noted socialite Emmy Ho, declined to comment on Huang's demotion.

Emmy Ho, who appeared for the first time in public in an evening interview with local TV channel TVBS on Thursday, said that she felt the provincial government has made the appropriate response to the incident, adding that she hopes the incident will now come to an end.
The sex scandal broke out on Monday when Chou publicly accused Huang of having a two-year affair with her which ended soon after he allegedly forced her to have an abortion in October.

She said that while involved with her, Huang also carried on an affair with the rich and pretty Emmy Ho, who is very active in business and political circles. Chou said that Ho and Huang have had intimate relations since last August and that Ho also had an abortion only one week after her own.

According to Chou, she and Ho, after several telephone conversations, decided that Huang is a dishonest man who had been shuttling between his two lovers, and resolved to make public the whole incident to "teach Huang a lesson."

Before Chou made the affair public, she wrote a letter to Soong demanding that Huang be fired. Chou said that a man like Huang, inconsistent in his words and deeds, is not qualified to be the provincial government spokesman and should be replaced.

But when reporters turned to Ho to try to learn her side of the story, Ho declined to comment on all of the allegations, saying in several newspaper interviews that she didn't know Chou would go public with the affair. While acknowledging that she had been seeing Huang for more than six months and disclosing that he had proposed to her, she stressed that she didn't have an abortion as Chou claimed.

One day after the outbreak of the scandal, Huang, who divorced his wife one-and-a-half years ago, denied the allegations against him, saying that although he and Chou had spent some time together in the past, their relationship was never sexual.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET RESHUFFLE APPROVED BY 40 PERCENT OF POPULATION

TEXT.P: Although Premier Vincent Siew has urged the public to trust his new Cabinet lineup, only 40 percent of the people are buying his claims that the shakeup is aimed at boosting the effectiveness of his administration, according to the results of a survey released on Thursday.

The opinion poll conducted on Wednesday afternoon by the local office of the consultancy firm Louis Harris International, showed that 39.9 percent of those surveyed agreed that the shakeup is a step towards improving the government's overall performance, compared to 25.9 percent who disagreed, 10.2 percent who said it's difficult to say, and 24.1 percent who had no idea, or who refused to reply.

The reshuffle, which has seen seven ministers replaced, has caused an uproar among the local mass media, because some of the outgoing ministers enjoyed high approval ratings in recent opinion polls or had just been sworn in.

Anticipating the criticism, Siew emphasized at a press conference on Wednesday that the reshuffle was needed to enhance the government's operation and was not just an exercise to bring in new faces. He called on the public to trust him, just as baseball fans trust the coaches of their favorite teams.

The survey also found that 36.1 percent of the respondents believed that Siew, rather than his political mentor President Lee Teng-hui, was firmly in charge of the reshuffle, while 39.5 percent described the scale of the reshuffle is "appropriate."

Among the seven new Cabinet members, Chiao Jen-ho, designated as the new head of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, was ranked in the poll as the most appropriate choice, followed by the incoming director-general of the Government Information Office Chen Chien-jen and the new interior minister, Huang Chu-wen.

When asked what field of government affairs most needs improvement, an overwhelming majority -- 62.7 percent -- named domestic policy, an answer reflecting the public's concerns about affairs related directly to their own well-being.

The telephone survey, carried out between 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m. on Wednesday, interviewed 1,087 adults, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent, according to the consultancy firm. (By Maubo Chang) EENITEM ZCZC CEP026 02-05-98 USE OF VISA CARDS SURGES IN TAIWAN

Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) A total of 6.74 million VISA cards were issued in Taiwan as of the end of 1997, up 46 percent from the previous level of 4.62 million posted a year ago, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Visa International Service Association.

VISA cardholders spent more than NT$270 billion in 76 million transactions last year in Taiwan, both figures representing a 44-percent increase over 1996 levels. Each transaction was worth an average NT$3,500, the organization said.

More than 2 million gold VISA cards were issued in Taiwan as of the end of last year, an annual growth of 68 percent, while the number of normal cards rose by 38 percent to 4.68 million, the credit card company noted.
The VISA International Service Association said it plans to introduce several new types of credit card this year in Taiwan to bring the island closer to becoming a cash-free society.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLOVAK REPUBLIC TO SET UP REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Slovak Republic will set up a representative office in the Republic of China next year to promote economic relations between Taiwan and the East European country, a visiting Slovak business leader said on Thursday.

Peter Mihok, Chairman of the Slovak Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Martin Hrivik, the chamber's secretary-general, arrived in Taipei on Monday for a week-long visit to woo Taiwan investment, at the invitation of the Central European Trade Promotion Council (CETPC).

Mihok said during an investment seminar that Slovakia will soon be included in the European Union, and cited low labor costs and an abundant supply of high-quality manpower as other advantages in investing in the country.

He told local businessmen at the seminar that labor costs in the Slovak Republic are 18 percent lower than in the Czech Republic and 23 percent lower than in Hungary. The country produces some 12,000 highly educated personnel annually, 20 percent of whom enter high-tech industries.

To facilitate the exchange of visits between the two countries, Mihok said that Slovakia has decided to set up a representative office in Taiwan next year, which is likely to be given the authority to issue visas. The CETPC for its part proposed that Slovakia grant ROC passport holders the privilege of obtaining landing visas.

However, some businessmen with experience of doing business with the East European country mentioned the poor quality of customs services there. Some of them also pointed out that the tax burden is quite heavy in Slovakia, adding that income tax can be as high as 40 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES TO DEVELOP SUBMARINES

TEXT.P: Owing to the difficulty in acquiring submarines from overseas, the ROC armed forces have decided to develop indigenous conventional submarines, said Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling on Thursday at a lunch party he hosted for local reporters.
Chiang said that in the preliminary stages, the armed forces will focus on the development of submarine hulls, torpedo launch systems and radar systems.
He didn't rule out the possibility of purchasing the technological know-how from foreign countries, assuming such know-how cannot be obtained through technology transfers.
Development of radar and torpedo launch systems is already underway at the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, said Chiang.
The complete plan, which is still in the preliminary stages, will be finalized only after more comprehensive studies have been made, according to Chiang.
Although Beijing goes out of its way to block Taiwan's arms purchases, the ROC Navy has still managed to buy two diesel-powered submarines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND MALAWI SIGN AGREEMENT TO BUILD HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Wednesday attended the signing ceremony of an accord between the ROC and Malawi, whereby the ROC promised to finance the construction of a hospital at a cost of US$15 million in Muzuzu, about 300 km north of the Malawi capital, Lilongwe.

The agreement between the African nation's Health and Population Ministry and a Taiwan construction firm, calls for the construction in 18 months of a 300-bed hospital which will also serve as a training center for Malawi medical personnel.

Hu, who flew to Blantyre in south Malawi from Swaziland on Tuesday, called on Malawi President Bakili Muluzi, and Foreign Minister Mapopa Chipeta, following which he took a four-hour drive from Blantyre to Lilongwe, where he called on Health and Population Minister Harry Thomson.

ROC Ambassador Robert C.J. Shih was scheduled to host a dinner for Hu on Wednesday night at his residence. Embassy staff, their families and members of ROC agricultural technical missions in Malawi were also expected to attend.

Malawi is the second leg of Hu's two-country, six-day African trip which is aimed at strengthening Taiwan's ties with its allies on the continent after the Central African Republic switched recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 29.
Hu left Taipei on Jan. 31 and is slated to leave Malawi for Taiwan on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND SCIENTIST WILLING TO COME TO TAIWAN FOR JOINT RESEARCH

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese scientist who, working together with a Taiwanese professor, recently discovered the oldest-known fossils of complex animal life forms, said on Friday he would like to be able to visit Taiwan to jointly conduct scientific research with his counterparts on the island.

Professor Chen Junyuan of the Nanjing Institute of Geology and Paleontology and Professor Li Chia-wei of Taiwan's National Tsinghua University together discovered fossils of embryos from the Precambrian era, millions of years before the evolutionary growth spurt known as the "Cambrian explosion."

Their findings -- published simultaneously in separate reports in the most recent editions of Nature, a British journal, and Science, a US periodical -- look set to rewrite the history of life on the planet.

In a telephone interview with the Taipei-based United Daily News, Chen said he was thrilled that a personal friendship across the Taiwan Strait -- the two sides of which are political arch rivals -- has developed into such a rewarding scientific cooperation.
He called his collaboration with Li "nearly perfect."

Chen recalled that he first became acquainted with Li in July 1996, when he visited Taiwan to attend the world's first international exhibition focusing on the Cambrian explosion hosted by the Provincial Museum of Natural Sciences in Taichung, central Taiwan. Li was then the curator of the museum.
After a talk on the Cambrian explosion, the two scientists developed a friendship that led to Li's frequent visits to mainland China for relevant studies, Chen noted.

Chen, who has just been elected a member of the ninth National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, pledged to do his utmost to push for closer scientific and technological cooperation between Taiwan and mainland China, saying working together in this way would eventually benefit people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Li and Chen's discovery of fossilized sponges and animal embryos dating back 580 million years ago in Guizhou, southwestern mainland China, has moved back the date of the earliest appearance of complex and varied forms of life on earth by 40 million to 50 million years.
The discovery, according to Li, could lead to the overthrow of the current scientific view of the origin of most of the world's animals.
Before their discovery, the existing fossil record showed that almost all animal phyta appeared during the Cambrian explosion, a five million year span in the early Cambrian period.
But such dramatic diversification in such a relatively short time puzzled scientists.
Molecular biologists advanced the idea the process actually began a billion years ago and proceeded gradually. Proponents of this theory, however, lacked solid evidence.
Li and Chen's discovery of plant tissues and animal embryos in rocks 580 million years old, however, will supply important data toward understanding the mystery of evolution's "big bang."

"Our discovery of the oldest animal fossils, including sponges and various kinds of animal embryos, indicates there were probably varieties of animals belonging to several known phyta that lived 40 million to 50 million years before the Cambrian explosion," Li noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, AUSTRIA FIRMS COOPERATE TO PRODUCE 'NATURAL RICE'
DOC.DATELINE: Vienna, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Ou Chun-lin & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Do you love rice but worry about eating something that may still be coated with pesticides and other chemicals? If so, a wedding of Austrian technology and Taiwanese equipment may soon put your mind at ease.
An Austrian firm recently agreed to transfer its patented technology for removing chemical residues to a company in Taiwan.
Not a trace of pesticides remains on foods that have been processed through this new technological method, which was originally developed to rid coffee beans of harmful chemicals.

With the expansion of the demand for "natural foods," scientists with the Austrian firm turned to expanding the technique for use in cleaning unpolished rice, said an executive from one of the companies involved.
Rice is a deeply-rooted part of the diet in much of Asia, including Taiwan.

Having successfully developed a method for cleaning unpolished rice, the scientists began working on an application for polished rice, the executive said. He asked that the firms not be identified, citing commercial competitiveness concerns.
So far only Germany and Austria have this technology, he claimed.
If the cooperation goes well, he said, a "natural" polished rice, which might have a different appearance from unprocessed rice, could be on the market by next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved down 0.9 percent on the Taiwan stock market Friday amid heavy trading.
Dealers said that technology stockholders' profit-taking resulted in the drop, following active buying over the past few days.
The weighted price index of Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) dropped 77.83 points to finish at 8,544.14.
The market opened at 8,712.25, experienced a low of 8,469.36 and a high of 8,775.67.
Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 186, with 50 stocks remaining unchanged.

A total of 4.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$277.69 billion (US$8.46 billion), the highest so far this year, compared to the previous session's 3.24 billion issues valued at some NT$213 billion.

Electrical engineering stocks dropped 2 percent, followed by 1.2 percent losses posted by both cement shares and plastic and chemical issues; a 0.9 percent decline in textile stocks; and a 0.2 percent loss in cement shares.
Foodstuff stocks grew 0.3 percent, while financial shares rose a slight 0.1 percent and paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, ACER, Winbond Electronics, Mosel Vitelic, Mitac International, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, China Development, ADI, Macronix International and Chang Hwa Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
DOC.TEXT:
