DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AFFAIRS CHIEF CALLS FOR IMPROVEMENT OF ABORIGINES' LIVES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs official on Friday proposed that whenever the island's construction businesses hire foreign laborers, they also take on a certain number of aboriginal workers.

Chan Huo-sheng, the newly-inaugurated chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), instructed his council to study the feasibility of a quota that would require companies in the construction sector that hire foreign laborers to employ a certain percentage of aborigines as part of the effort to improve the livelihood of Taiwan's poorest ethnic group.
Chan demanded that CLA officials put out an initiative within six months aimed at quickly solving the unemployment problem that has long plagued the island's aboriginal people.

Meanwhile, he also instructed the CLA to begin a survey next week of aboriginal people's willingness to receive vocational training and be employed. The government should work to raise the living standards of Taiwan's native inhabitants by "giving them a fishing net rather than fish," he said.

Chan gave the instructions Friday after visiting an aboriginal village in Hsichih, suburban Taipei, where some 500 native mountain people originally from eastern Taiwan's Hualien and Taitung counties reside in shacks without electricity or running water.

Chan met with the village residents, many of whom lamented that their already difficult lives will become even harder because their shelters are soon to be torn down to make way for the new high-speed rail line.
The CLA chief promised them he would waste no time before looking into their problems.
The rim of greater Taipei is home to about 30,000 aborigines of various tribes, most of whom are poor and have little hope of better lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS HITS AUSSIE TOURISM INDUSTRY HARD

TEXT.P: The Asian currency crisis is taking a serious toll on the Australian tourism industry as tourist arrivals from Taiwan, South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand, Japan and Malaysia into Australia have dropped substantially, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The ABS figures show that tourist arrivals from South Korea led the plunge with a drop of 66 percent in December 1997 compared to the year-earlier figure.
Indonesia ranked second in the drop with 53 percent; followed by Thailand, 39 percent; Malaysia, 31 percent; Taiwan, 23 percent; the Philippines, 15 percent; and Japan, 12 percent.
Tourism industry analysts believe the sharp drop will continue in the months to come as the Asian crisis shows no clear signs of ending.

Earlier this week, the Australian Tourist Commission, which promotes the tourism industry and lures foreign tourists to Australia, announced it would spend A$5 million (US$3.4 million) for a promotional blitz in Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea, Indonesia and three other locations.
Tourism promoters worry that the decline in tourist numbers could cost the Australian economy up to A$3.5 billion. Market economists, however, believe the loss could be about A$1.5 billion.
"The sharp drop in in-bound tourists is a concrete sign that the Asian crisis is already having a marked impact on the Australian economy," said Colonial State Bank chief economist Dr. Craig James.

"The drop in tourist numbers since July (1997) -- 17 percent in seasonally adjusted terms -- is the most severe for around nine years. The last downturn of this magnitude occurred in early 1989 after the 1988 bicentenary celebrations," he added.
The number of tourist arrivals to Australia dropped by 6 percent or 20,000 to 328,700 in December 1997 from the month before.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40 TAIWANESE WORKING IN C. JAVA

TEXT.P: Taiwanese are the second largest group of foreigners working in Central Java, according to Soedarsono, head of the provincial Investment Coordinating Board.

He was quoted by the Antara news agency as saying in Semarang Wednesday that of 309 foreign workers in the province, 72 are Japanese, most of whom are engaged in the industrial sector, a field where Indonesia still lacks qualified personnel.
There are 40 Taiwanese foreign workers, followed by South Koreans (32), Indians (22) and Europeans.
These workers are spread out in 95 companies in 25 areas in Central Java, with 96 working in 32 companies in the provincial capital of Semarang, he added.

They are employed in various fields, including agriculture, forestry, fishery, mining, the processing industry, wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transportation, insurance and property leasing.
Most of them hold important positions, working as directors, managers or supervisors, while others are technicians and operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW MEETS WITH LEADER OF WORLD JUNIOR CHAMBER

TEXT.P: Petri Niskanen, world chairman of Junior Chamber, visited Premier Vincent Siew Friday and explained to him the organization's goals to "promote world peace."
Niskanen said later at a press conference that Junior Chamber will try to reach the goals through its 125 national branches in the world.

A spokesman for Junior Chamber/Republic of China said at the press conference that the number of Junior Chamber organizations in the Taiwan area may increase to 230 this year, and that Junior Chamber will hold its 2000 and 2004 Asian Pacific Conferences in the Taiwan cities of Kaohsiung and Chungli respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL MEETS WITH WEI JINSHENG
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang, met with mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jinsheng, who now lives in exile in the United States, on Thursday in Washington, D.C., and expressed an interest in Wei visiting Taiwan.

Chang and Wei, both of whom were in town for the annual US National Prayer Breakfast hosted by President Bill Clinton Thursday morning, met for a casual talk at a Chinatown restaurant prior to a dinner meeting Chang hosted there in honor of KMT members and representatives of the academic and overseas Chinese communities in the eastern United States. Wei also attended the dinner.

Wei told Chang that he would likely visit Taiwan in September, taking advantage of a scheduled trip to Japan at that time. He said, however, that he would not visit Taiwan at the invitation of any of the island's political parties.
Wei, who spent the better part of two decades off-and-on in mainland Chinese prisons because of his outspokenness, offered some of his insights concerning relations across the Taiwan Strait.

He blamed mainland China for the standstill in cross-strait dialogue. Beijing established many prerequisites for the resumption of talks, he said, because it knew Taipei could not accept them. This allows mainland China to accuse Taiwan of obstructionism, he noted.

Wei said that Beijing's motive for setting Taipei up to look uncooperative is to isolate Taiwan from the international community. Mainland Chinese authorities "cut off all connections around a rival before dealing a blow to the opponent," he said.

He agreed with Taipei's stance that for cross-strait dialogue to resume, Beijing should first accept the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are separate political entities. "Otherwise, chances for the dialogue to reopen would be slim," he said.

If the two sides restart the dialogue, he said, they should meet in a third location. He however warned against holding the talks in Singapore, saying, "Everybody knows that the city-state is pro-PRC."
Meanwhile, Chang hinted that the Taipei-headquartered World League for Freedom and Democracy will probably invite Wei to visit Taiwan in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES CANNED BEEF TO PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Ambassador Liu Tin-tsu of the Republic of China Thursday donated on behalf of his government US$100,000 worth of canned beef to the government of Paraguay for distribution to the victims of floods that hit the country recently.

Liu said at the donation ceremony that the Republic of China and Paraguay are long-time good friends, and that the canned beef was purchased from the local market for donation to the flood victims as a token of friendship and support from the people on Taiwan.

Paraguayan Interior Minister Miguel Angel Ramirez, who accepted the donation on behalf of his government, described the donation as "timely aid" that may enhance the friendship between the two countries.
President Juan Carlos Wasmosy, Foreign Minister Ruben Melgarejo Lanzoni, and other Paraguayan government officials witnessed the donation ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.034 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$32.855.
The greenback opened at 32.85, and was traded between 32.8 and 32.945.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$394 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK OF CANADA INSISTS INFLATION CONTROL REMAINS URGENT

TEXT.P: Canada's central bank reiterated Thursday that inflation control remains a priority for the country, despite Canada's falling currency and the economic turmoil in Asia.

"From a monetary policy perspective, the best contribution your central bank can make to helping the economy cope with external shocks is to ensure that inflation remains under control," Bank of Canada Governor Gordon Thiessen told a business group in eastern Canada.

"Nothing is as important to investors, especially during turbulent times, as the assurance that comes from the protection that low and stable inflation provides for the value of money," he said in a speech to the Saint John Board of Trade in New Brunswick.

Thiessen acknowledged that Canada's economic growth this year will not be as strong as was predicted last fall, partly because of the continuing economic crisis that began last summer in Thailand and spread to other Asian countries.
"Some Canadian regions and industries, particularly those with heavier reliance on primary commodities and exports to Asia, will no doubt feel the impact more than others," he noted.
But he stressed that as a whole, Canada's economic outlook is "still favorable for continued expansion in output and employment, and for a further gradual reduction in the margin of unused capacity."
The Canadian dollar has recently lost about 5 percent of its value against the US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIG PLAYERS POUR FUNDS INTO REGIONAL STOCK MARKETS

TEXT.P: The big boys are back. So say stock analysts and dealers as waves of foreign institutional buying continue to rack up gains on the Singapore and Malaysian bourses.
All key indices in Singapore were up Thursday, indicating that the buying spree was broad-based, The Straits Times said in a market analysis report Friday.
The benchmark Straits Times Industrials Index climbed 66.92 points or 4.7 percent to close at 1,492.15 Thursday.

A vice president of a foreign brokerage in Singapore was quoted as saying, "Since the Lunar New Year holidays, there has been a real flow of funds into our stock market from overseas, particularly the United States."
The strengthening of regional currencies against the US dollar was an indication of foreign funds buying into the regional stock markets, she noted.
"Funds selling their US dollars and sterling for local currencies to invest in the stock markets shored up the regional units," she said.
The Singapore dollar firmed to 1.663 Thursday from Wednesday's 1.686 against the greenback.
Gains in the Malaysian ringgit and the Thai baht mirrored rises in the respective bourses, the report said.
The ringgit firmed to 3.945, its highest level against the US dollar since the start of the year, from 4.065 previously.
The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.2 percent to 712.81, fueled by the "merger mania" involving RHB Capital and Commerce Asset Holdings, the report said.
In Bangkok, Thai stocks rose 5 percent, rebounding from Wednesday's 9.5 percent plunge.
In Manila, the benchmark index rose 7.01 points to 2,049.15, and the peso eased to 40.62 against the US dollar from 40.17 previously.
In Kuala Lumpur, there were tales of financial and dual-listing mergers as well as share buybacks by cash-rich companies, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICE OCCUPANCY COSTS SET TO BE CHEAPER THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: It will be cheaper to run an office this year in the cities most affected by the Asian currency crisis, according to a new property market survey.

Southeast Asian capitals such as Kuala Lumpur, Bangkok and Jakarta -- which saw their currencies depreciate up to 60 percent for the 12 months to last December -- are likely to experience the greatest falls in occupancy costs, said the annual survey of such costs in 74 office districts across 68 cities worldwide.
The survey, which was conducted in December, showed that Hong Kong had overtaken Tokyo as the world's most expensive city in terms of office occupancy costs.
Hong Kong topped the list with occupancy costs of US$10.11 per square foot per month (psf pm).
Rates in the five central wards of Tokyo -- the city's prime business district -- stood at US$8.64 psf pm, pulling the Japanese capital down three rungs to fourth position.
London's West End came in second with an average cost of US$9.18 psf pm, with the City of London third at US$8.69.
Despite the currency crisis, seven Asian cities were in the top 10. Singapore was ranked ninth at US$5.22 psf pm, and Beijing tenth at US$4.64.

The bottom end of the list was dominated mainly by Australian cities. The cities with the lowest occupancy costs were Perth, with 62 US cents psf a month, and Adelaide, at 78 US cents. The four property consultancies which conducted the survey were Edmund Tie and Co. of Singapore, Hong Kong's C.Y. Leung and Co., DTZ Debenham Thorpe of Britain and CB Commercial of the United States.

An executive with Edmund Tie and Co. said that because of new supply as well as demand being affected by what is happening in the region, "we will expect further consolidation in occupancy costs this year."
This will make Asia more competitive as a business region, she added.

This is especially so given that the cities largely unaffected by the fluctuations in regional currencies last year are expected to see their costs remain stable or firm up, said the survey report, referring to cities in mainland China, New Zealand and Australia.

It defined occupancy costs as the average costs, in US dollars, of leasing new office space in modern office buildings in prime central business district locations. They include rents and other expenses like property taxes and maintenance costs.

In Bangkok, where the devaluation of the baht sparked off a region-wide sell-off of currencies last year, occupancy costs plunged 56 percent between the end of 1996 and December 1997 to US$1.05 psf pm, the survey showed.
In the same period, the Thai unit shed about 45 percent of its value against the US dollar.
According to the Singapore consultancy firm, the extent of the falls in occupancy costs were unavailable, as the latest survey provided only broad-based indications of cost movements.
While companies do not look at costs alone when choosing a location, competitive occupancy costs do make a location more attractive, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS HAS 'CONTACT AGAIN' WITH SEF: TANG SHUBEI

TEXT.P: Regarding the long-stalled dialogue between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Beijing-based counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), by sending a letter to the SEF last November and issuing a related news release the same month, ARATS has "contact again" with the SEF, according to ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei.
Tang made the comment in an interview published in the February edition of Cross-Strait Relations, an ARATS journal.
Upon Beijing's suspension of cross-strait dialogue in 1995, ARATS wrote to the SEF on June 16 of that year, declaring ARATS would "contact the SEF when the time is proper," the journal noted.

Since the SEF proposed last year that SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu lead a group to visit Beijing, a response from ARATS would be appropriate if ARATS is sincere about resuming cross-strait dialogue, it said.

Tang pointed out in the interview that ARATS sent a letter on Nov. 6, 1997 to Chiao Jen-ho, who was then the secretary-general and vice chairman of the SEF, inviting him to lead a group of directors and supervisors of the SEF to a symposium titled "Outlooks on Trans-Century Cross-Strait Economic Relations" and to visit Xiamen, Shanghai and Beijing later on.
This was done, Tang said, in order to enhance communications and exchanges between the two organizations.
ARATS clarified its stance on Koo's proposed Beijing visit and the renewal of cross-strait discussions in a news release on Nov. 13, he added.

Tang remarked that Taipei authorities should respond clearly on the issue of political negotiations as soon as possible, and that the SEF and ARATS should arrange procedural issues for the political talks at an early date.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHI'S CAPABILITY TO DEAL WITH CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS PRAISED

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) chairman, Koo Chen-fu, on Friday praised Shi Hwei-you, who has been offered the post of SEF vice chairman and secretary-general, for his capability in dealing with complicated cross-strait affairs.

Koo paid the compliment amid an ongoing personnel reshuffle in the SEF, the quasi-official intermediary body founded to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal contact between the Republic of China and mainland China.

The political heavyweight described Shi as a person who sticks to his beliefs and principles and said he hopes Shi can also develop a sense of give and take without sacrificing his uncompromising spirit during negotiations.
Koo stressed that the person appointed to be in charge of the mission to restart cross-strait talks must possess just these characteristics and capabilities.

On Saturday, Shi will formally replace Chiao Jen-ho, who has been named to chair the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in Premier Vincent Siew's recently reshuffled Cabinet. Prior to his new appointment, Shi, who currently serves as secretariat director-general of the ruling Kuomintang, has held positions as vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and as SEF vice secretary-general.
During several rounds of talks with mainland Chinese officials in the past, Shi, also an expert in legal affairs, won a reputation as a tough, uncompromising negotiator.

With his wide experience of cross-strait affairs, Shi has been commissioned to mold the SEF and the MAC into virtually two parts of the same mechanism, in order to execute the government's mainland policies in the most practical manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC, SIKORSKY TO CO-PRODUCE S-92 CHOPPERS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) and American helicopter giant Sikorsky Co. are slated to sign a memorandum of understanding for the joint development and manufacture of S-92 helicopters.

Relevant sources disclosed Thursday that chairman Tsai Chun-hui of AIDC -- formerly the military-run Aero-Industry Development Center, which built Taiwan's locally-designed Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs) -- will lead a Taiwan mission to Sikorsky's headquarters on Feb. 12 to ink a memorandum of understanding for business cooperation.
The memorandum is the follow-up to a pact forging a strategic business alliance that AIDC and Sikorsky agreed to in October 1997, the sources noted.
Test flights of the 20-seat S-92 are scheduled to kick off in the spring, they said, adding that if everything goes smoothly, mass commercial production will follow immediately afterward.

The S-92 helicopter -- which boasts better avionics, cabin layout, performance and safety features than the earlier S-70 model -- is being researched and developed in a project directed by Sikorsky and conducted jointly by experts from Taiwan, the United States, Japan, Spain, Brazil and mainland China.

Taiwan's AIDC will be responsible for the most important portion of the cockpit, 6 percent of the entire development project, while mainland China is in charge of developing the tail pylon, about 1 percent of the project.

Sikorsky, an offshoot of United Technology, which is one of the top 500 enterprises in the United States, is a major manufacturer of helicopters. In addition to maintaining a liaison office in Taiwan for the distribution of Sikorsky products, the firm also maintains close business connections with local companies on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FARMERS SEE MAINLAND CHINA AND HK DEVALUING CURRENCIES

TEXT.P: Australian farmers, hit by slumping trade with South Korea, have predicted that there are signs that mainland China and Hong Kong will have to devalue their currencies in order to compete with other Asian countries which have seen their currencies depreciate during the Asian economic crisis.
They said Australian agriculture is now bracing for the inevitable inclusion of mainland China and Hong Kong in the Asian financial meltdown.

The impact was drawn to the attention of delegates attending the Outlook 1998 conference in Canberra on Thursday, with a report that 40 containers of processed wool were being shipped back to an Australian processor from South Korea because of credit difficulties in that country.

"Otherwise, other Southeast Asian countries will take an enormous part of China's export markets -- especially textiles, which account for a massive 20 percent of China's export income," David Montgomery, managing director of the Australian division of the US cotton firm Dunavant Enterprises, told the mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said mainland China and Hong Kong will be under pressure to devalue their currencies or they will not be able to compete with other Asian countries.

ABARE chief commodity analyst Terry Sheales said: "My understanding is that China's domestic economy is under some pressure. A resultant reduction in Chinese demand for imported commodities would have widespread implications for Australia's economy and world trade generally."
Montgomery said Indonesia's 350 percent devaluation since August 1997 will make its exports, including textiles, much cheaper and put "enormous pressure on China and Hong Kong to devalue."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL CALLS FOR US CONGRESSIONAL SUPPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C., Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said on Thursday that the US Congress is very concerned about developments in cross-Taiwan Strait ties and the recent elections held in Taiwan, and that following a meeting with several key Congress figures, he gave them a detailed explanation of the two issues.

In addition to Representative Richard K. Armey, Chang also met on Thursday afternoon with David E. Bonior, minority whip in the House, Doug Bereuter, chairman of the House Asian-Pacific Affairs Committee, and John F. Kerry, a Democratic heavyweight at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Chang described the four congressmen as very concerned about the current state of cross-strait relations and Taiwan's recent elections. He said he provided them with detailed explanations covering both areas and urged them to continue supporting the ROC.

The KMT secretary-general, who arrived here on Wednesday night at the head of an ROC delegation which was to take part in the White House's annual prayer breakfast on Thursday morning, made the remarks during a meeting with the local Chinese press later in the day.
According to Chang, he chatted with House Speaker Newt Gingrich during the prayer breakfast and said that Gingrich promised to visit Taiwan again if he can find the time.
Gingrich was quoted by Chang as saying that he found his first visit to Taiwan in April 1996 as very productive and meaningful.

Although prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng also attended the prayer breakfast, Chang did not actually meet him until he attended a seminar held by Chang with local Chinese communities at a Chinese restaurant later Thursday evening.
Chang also met Richard Bush, head of the Washington-based American Institute in Taiwan, and other China experts later in the day before proceeding to Boston on Friday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT SIX AFRICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu will embark on a six-nation African tour on Feb. 14, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOEA) announced on Friday.

Timothy C.T. Yang, director of the MOEA's African Affairs Department, said Hu is scheduled to visit Chad, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso, all six of which maintain formal diplomatic relations with the ROC.

In addition to visiting the heads of state and ranking government officials of the six countries to discuss issues of mutual concern and international interest, Hu will meet personnel of ROC agricultural and medical missions stationed there to express the government's appreciation for their contributions overseas, according to Yang.

He added that Hu will also take part in Gambia's 32nd independence anniversary celebrations on Feb. 18 as the representative of the ROC government. It will be Hu's third visit to Africa since he assumed the post in October 1997. He is scheduled to return to Taipei on Feb. 23.

The foreign minister, who just returned here on Friday morning following a week-long visit to Malawi and Swaziland, chaired a working-party meeting in January in Dakar, capital of Senegal, with representatives of ROC diplomatic missions stationed throughout Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENTS ABROAD INCREASING

TEXT.P: Taiwan investments in foreign countries totaled US$2,893.82 million last year, an increase of 33.64 percent over the previous year, according to statistics released Friday by the Investment Commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The statistics showed that the investments involved 759 projects, mostly in Virgin Islands, the United States, Singapore, Hong Kong, Panama, Japan, and some European countries.
Taiwan investments in these countries and area increased substantially, but reduced greatly in South Korea and some Southeast Asian countries last year, the statistics indicated.
The investments dropped 94.27 percent in South Korea, 32.38 percent in Indonesia, and 14.9 percent in Vietnam last year from a year earlier, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN AND OVERSEAS CHINESE INVESTMENTS IN TAIWAN INCREASING

TEXT.P: The government approved 683 foreign and overseas Chinese investment projects in Taiwan last year, an increase of 36.6 percent over 1996, according to statistics released Friday by the Investment Commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The investments amounted to US$4,266.62 million last year, a jump of 73.38 percent over the previous year. The investment of each of the top 47 projects exceeds US$15 million.
About 70 percent of the investments went to finance and insurance, international trade, electronics and electrical appliances, basic metals and metal products, and other industries.

An official of the Investment Commission attributed the increase of foreign and overseas Chinese investments in Taiwan to the government's policy to cut red tape, to improve the economic system, and to promote free economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VCD MAKERS SIGN SELF-DISCIPLINE AGREEMENT ON IPR PROTECTION

TEXT.P: At the prompting of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), Taiwan's major VCD manufacturers on Friday agreed to contribute to the protection of Intellectual Property Rights (IPR).

Twenty-one local VCD makers, including RITEK and CMC Magnetics Corp., signed a self-discipline agreement in which they promise to respect and protect IPR. BOFT deputy director Wu Wen-yah and chairman of the Taipei Computer Association Liu Re-fu were witnesses at the signing ceremony.

Wu said that in recent years, local makers have taken steps to promote IPR protection, evidenced by the establishment of the ROC Information Products Anti-Piracy League and the ROC IPR Protection Association.

Coupled with regulations enacted by the Economics Ministry which require VCD makers to put the S ID code on their VCDs to identify the sources, Taiwan is gradually cleansing itself of its notorious reputation as the "piracy kingdom," Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 600 MAINLAND CHINESE STUDYING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Some 600 mainland Chinese who have come to Taiwan to live with their lineal relatives are currently studying in local schools and 12 percent of them say they have encountered difficulties living in Taiwan, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Friday.

The MAC official said that as of the end of last May, more than 6,000 mainlanders have entered Taiwan under government regulations allowing mainland Chinese to live in Taiwan with lineal relatives who are ROC nationals.

He said that a survey conducted by the MAC shows that 584 of the mainlanders are currently studying at various levels in schools around the island, adding that most of them are the grandchildren of elderly veterans and that 70 percent of them are from Fujian Province.

Four hundred and forty-eight of the students are studying at primary schools, while 110 are junior high school students and 25 are senior high school or vocational school students. Sixty-nine of the students said they have encountered difficulties living in Taiwan.

These difficulties are mostly financial, because most of them are living on their grandfathers' pensions or have to work part-time to support themselves. Some of them have had to be referred to social welfare organizations or to other relatives following the death of their grandparents. Some of them also expressed difficulties in adjusting to school life in Taiwan.

The MAC official said that his council will ask school counselors, local education authorities, and social welfare organizations to gain a better understanding of the difficulties these students have encountered and take concrete measures to help them.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER URGES MOVES TO HELP NEIGHBORING COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that the government, under the principle of mutual benefit, should promote greater Taiwan investment in Southeast Asian countries in order to help them recover from their ongoing financial woes.

Siew said that as a good neighbor to the countries of Southeast Asia, Taiwan should consider feasible means of helping those countries recover from the current turmoil, including merging with or acquiring local enterprises of sound structure and helping Taiwan businesses interested in investing in the region to join together in setting up a system of collective holding companies.

The Central Bank of China, in conjunction with other Taiwan-based banks and their overseas branches, could consider extending loans to hard-hit Southeast Asian countries, using international mechanisms such as the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank, and the International Monetary Fund, he added.

The premier made the remarks after hearing a report by Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang on his recent fact-finding tour of four of the Southeast Asian nations suffering the most from the financial crisis which broke out in the region last year.
Siew said the countries of Southeast Asia have very high expectations of Taiwan and that Taiwan should extend a helping hand to assist them in overcoming their difficulties.

In addition, the government is also planning to sponsor exhibitions and trade fairs in Taiwan to display products made by Southeast Asian countries, and will also assess the feasibility of trading with those countries in their own currencies, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL DELEGATION TO ATTEND ARCHBISHOP SHAN'S ELEVATION

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China will send a delegation to attend a ceremony at the Vatican on Feb. 21-22 in which Archbishop Paul K.H. Shan of the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung will accept the honor of being elevated to the position of cardinal by Pope John Paul II, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Friday.

R.T. Yang, ROC director of European Affairs, said that Pope John Paul II named Shan as a cardinal on Jan. 18, a move seen by Taipei as an indication of the importance the Vatican attaches to the long-lasting relations between the Holy See and the ROC.

The appointment makes Shan the first Taiwan clergyman to hold the title of cardinal since the death of Cardinal Yu Pin in 1978. Yu was raised to the position of cardinal in Nanking on the Chinese mainland before the ROC government relocated to Taiwan in 1949.

Yang said that in line with the international practice that the countries to which the would-be cardinals belong send official delegations to attend the ceremony, the government will send a three- to five-member delegation to the Vatican. The names of the members of the delegation have yet to be announced, he added. Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih will also lead a separate 15-member delegation to the event.
It is estimated that some 300 or 400 Roman Catholics from Taiwan, the US and Europe will attend the ceremony.
ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Raymond Tai will host a gala for Shan in recognition of his becoming the first cardinal in Taiwan in 20 years, Yang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER CONCLUDES SECOND AFRICAN TRIP

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu revealed on Friday that the foreign ministers of Malawi and Swaziland will visit Taiwan in April and September, respectively.

Upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after a week-long trip to Africa, Hu told reporters that his visits to Swaziland and Malawi have successfully conveyed to both countries Taipei's determination to strengthen ties with them.
He said he was favorably impressed by the host countries' warm receptions and that he is confident that the island will succeed in increasing its presence on the African continent.
However, the foreign minister pointed out that Taiwan's diplomatic ties with its African allies will thrive even more if they are based on solid economic and trade ties.
Referring to a proposed African tour by President Lee Teng-hui, Hu said the proposal will take a more definite shape after he has finished his own series of visits to all the ROC's African allies.

Hu left Taiwan for Swaziland via South Africa on Jan. 31 in a bid to prevent an African "domino effect" after the Central African Republic followed South Africa in switching diplomatic recognition to Beijing on Jan. 29.

During his two-day stay in Swaziland, he met with King Mswati III and won his assurance that South Africa and the Central African Republic's diplomatic reversals will in no way affect his own country's diplomatic policy .
At a press conference after the meeting, Mswati reiterated publicly his assurance that Swaziland is an independent state with its own foreign policy which is not subject to foreign influence.

Swaziland Premier Barnabas Sibusico Dlamini echoed the king's stance. Vowing that the 30-year-old friendship between the two countries will survive and thrive, he promised that his state will continue its steadfast support for the Republic of China in international organizations.

Malawian President Bakili Muluzi later extended similar assurances to Hu during his visit there between Feb. 2-6, putting to rest the ROC's fear that Lilongwe could be lured into Beijing's fold after the media wrongly quoted Malawian Information Minister San Mpasu as saying that his country will move toward normalization with the People's Republic of China.

Hu has already visited Senegal on a previous African trip, and is scheduled to visit Chad, Guinea-Bissau, the Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso on his next African trip scheduled for Feb. 14-22.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SEYCHELLES PRESIDENT VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is seeking to play a greater role in the international community and the ROC government welcomes all friendly countries to establish relations with Taipei, an official with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOEA) said on Friday.

Timothy C.T. Yang, head of the MOEA's African Affairs Department, told the CNA that building an enhanced international presence has long been one of the government's goals and that it will not rule out the possibility of establishing ties, no matter which country is involved.

Yang was referring in this case to the Republic of Seychelles, in a statement prompted by the current private visit to Taiwan of former President James Mancham, at the invitation of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Although Seychelles has no diplomatic relations with the ROC, nor does its maintain a representative office here, Yang said, the ROC has some goods friends within the country's ruling and opposition camps.
Mancham served as Seychelles's first president after the tiny island nation off the east coast of Africa in the Indian Ocean declared independence from Britain in June 1976.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU PLANS INTENSIFIED RELATIONS WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The European Union's executive body is working on proposals to intensify relations with Beijing and do more to recognize communist China as a global power, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.
"We need to set out our agenda for a more active relationship with China between now and the end of the century," European Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan was quoted by the WTO report as saying.
Brittan said the proposals would be set out in a document from the European Commission, the EU's executive body, expected to come out soon, the WTO report pointed out.
The policy would have to be adopted by the commission and approved by the EU's 15 member states before it would take effect.
"There is no alternative to engagement with China, which has one-fifth of the world's population and a booming economy," Brittan was quoted as saying.
The proposed new policy would upgrade and deepen political dialogue, boost cooperation programs and aim to speed up mainland China's incorporation into multilateral and international structures.
"First of all, the European Union needs to do more to recognize China as a global power," the WTO report quoted Brittan as saying. "The level of our dialogue should be commensurate with this status."
Brittan welcomed plans for a first EU-Beijing summit on the sidelines of a scheduled EU-Asia summit in London in April.
He said the EU should talk to mainland China on a range of global issues, from reform of the United Nations to anti-personnel mines.

However, Brittan said mainland China's conditions for membership of the WTO still fall far short of what is required, but he added that European and American leaders could help to bring it substantially closer, and that a deal might even be clinched this year, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC CAPABLE OF BUILDING SUBMARINES

TEXT.P: The state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) on Friday boasted of its ability to build and maintain submarines, following an announcement by the Defense Ministry that the ROC plans to develop its own submarines.

Although the construction of submarines involves technology far more complicated than that required to build conventional vessels, the Kaohsiung-based CSBC said it is capable of building and maintaining such craft.

However, CSBC sources elaborated, saying the shipyard will limit itself to building submarine hulls, since the weapons and radar systems have to be developed or acquired from abroad by the armed forces.

The sources said that the navy currently uses the company to build hulls for its conventional warships, while the navy or the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, a state-run institute for the research and development of weaponry, provides the necessary combat and navigational equipment.
Meanwhile the Kaohsiung-based China Steel Corporation (CSC) revealed on Friday that it has developed a special steel exclusively for the construction of submarine hulls.
The steel, which meets specifications laid down by the Defense Ministry, can also be mass-produced if required.

At present, the navy has four diesel-powered submarines in its fleet, two aged ones provided by the United States, and two others purchased from the Dutch. It would like to acquire more to defend the island but has been blocked by Beijing, which opposes arms sales to Taiwan by any country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CALLS FOR RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Friday repeated his calls for the resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations without any preconditions.

Lee made the call at a dinner party he hosted for over 80 foreign envoys and their wives at the presidential auditorium. Beijing unilaterally suspended scheduled talks with Taipei following Lee's visit to the United States in 1995.

However, he reiterated Taipei's opposition to Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, saying the ROC government expects a healthy cross-strait relationship under the principles of peace, cooperation and prosperity so as to help safeguard regional peace and development.

The president thanked the foreign ambassadors and representatives for their contributions to promoting relations between the ROC and their own countries, and encouraged the international community to render greater support to the ROC in the year of the tiger, as the tiger in Chinese mythology is a symbol of the power of justice and courage.

In the coming year, Lee stressed, the ROC government will continue to push ahead with various reforms to ensure greater success for its constitutional system and to upgrade its administrative effectiveness and international competitiveness.

He assured his guests that as part of its efforts to promote regional prosperity, the ROC, which has suffered only relatively slight impact from Asia's financial turmoil, will lend a helping hand to its neighbors embroiled in the crisis, using all possible bilateral or multilateral mechanisms.
Government officials also present at the party included National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, Premier Vincent Siew, Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei and their wives.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY SUCCESSFUL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government's "no haste, be patient" economic policy toward mainland China investment has been partly effective, as government-approved investment projects in the mainland dwindled in magnitude last year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Friday.

Tsai Lien-sheng, executive secretary of the MOEA's Investment Commission, said that a total of 728 mainland-bound investment projects were approved by the commission in 1997, at a combined value of US$1.61 billion, representing a 90.08 percent increase in the number of projects and 31.34 percent growth in total value from the 1996 level.
Tsai said that although it seems that mainland-bound investment projects almost doubled last year compared with the previous year, this is not actually the case.

In the past, many Taiwan businesses invested in the mainland without first obtaining government approval, but last April, the Legislative Yuan passed revised regulations governing cross-strait relations that stipulate a system of punishment for unapproved mainland investment, Tsai said, adding that because of this, official applications for investing in the mainland have increased since then.
Tsai also pointed out that the average value per project stood at US$2.22 million last year, representing a significant drop from the average value of NT$3.21 million registered a year earlier.

He noted that according to statistics made public by mainland Chinese authorities, the actual investment value by Taiwan businessmen between January and September edged down 0.49 percent from the same period of 1996. During the same period, mainland-approved investment projects proposed by Taiwan businessmen decreased by 9.1 percent in number, while the combined investment value plummeted 54 percent.
The figures released by the mainland authorities show that mainland-bound investment projects are decreasing, both in number and in value, he said.
Under the "no haste, be patient" policy, the ROC government has banned projects valued at over US$50 million, as well as large-scale public construction and infrastructure projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: US READY TO FINALIZE WTO TALKS WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Clinton Administration said on Friday that the United States is ready to finalize bilateral talks with Taiwan on the island's terms to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

"Yes, we are ready to complete consultations (concerning Taipei's entry to the WTO)," said an American negoitator with Taiwan, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "We have high expectations of the upcoming round of talks."
The official further said Taiwan could finalize WTO negotiations with the US ahead of mainland China if it presented commercially viable or reasonable entry terms.

The US will separately hold WTO talks with Taipei and Beijing next week. Assistant Trade Representative Robert Cassidy will head a delegation to the mainland for bilateral talks, while David Burns, a senior advisor to the US Trade Representative (USTR), will chair negotiations with Taiwan.

USTR officials said Taipei-Washington talks have nothing to do with Washington-Beijing negotiations. The US won't consider the pace of its negotiations with Beijing and won't rule out the possibility of finalizing WTO talks with Taipei during the 17th round of such consultations scheduled to start on Monday in Washington, D.C.

The officials said agricultural trade will be a critical point whether the upcoming talks can achieve a major breakthrough, adding that Taiwan must present reasonable timetables for opening its pork, chicken, rice and animal intestines markets.

Commenting on reports that Taiwan's husbandry industry operators have threatened to boycott imports of American grains and soybeans in protest of US market-opening pressure, the USTR officials said they believe such a threat was not driven by the Taipei government. "It's simply a natural reaction," they added.
The reports concerning Taipei's "boycott" threat have caused slumps in prices for related products on the Chicago futures market in the past few days.

Taipei will send a large delegation of trade and agricultural officials to Washington for the 17th round of WTO talks. The first-stage talks will be held on Feb. 9-14, with Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu heading the Taipei mission, while Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will meet with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Feb. 17-18 to seek policy breakthroughs.

Taiwan already completed bilateral WTO consultations with 23 contracting parties to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body. The US is one of the three contracting parties that have yet to finalize such talks with Taiwan. The other two are the 15-member European Union and Switzerland.
