DOC.HEADLINE: SON OF CONVICTED MURDERER APPEALS FOR HELP
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Philip Liu & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The son of Tzuo Ming-hsin, a national of the Republic of China and a permanent resident of Alaska who was convicted of first-degree murder there seven years ago and sentenced to 198 years in prison, on Friday called for financial aid to help his father's cause.

Tzuo Tzu-cheng, son of the convicted murderer, called a press conference to appeal for donations from Chinese communities on the US West Coast and elsewhere so he can hire US-based lawyers to help his father get another chance at justice.

Tzuo Ming-hsin, a cook, was arrested on charges of the murder of a Chinese man and the man's daughter in 1989. A jury found him guilty in 1991 of first-degree murder and sentenced him to 198 years in prison.
The prisoner's sister, Tzuo Hsiao-ling, and three attorneys -- including Charles Mathews, a noted Pasadena-based criminal-case lawyer -- were also present at the press conference.

Mathews noted Tzuo was convicted on the basis of a tape recording but said that he has found other clear sounds on the tape that show that the murder was committed not by Tzuo but by one or more others.
Another problem with the trial, he said, is that Tzuo never had the opportunity to testify for himself and say, "I'm not guilty."
The California attorney said he is willing to be Tzuo's defense lawyer and to investigate the case.

Chinese-American lawyer Yu-Tai Lin-chang, who has fought for Tzuo for months, hoped that Tzuo will end his fast in his prison cell, saying that the hunger strike won't help solve problems. She urged Tzuo to stay healthy and cooperate with his lawyers.

Yu-Tai also stressed that there were many faults in the case and trial, including that Tzuo was denied his right to express himself during the trial; that the tape, the only evidence, was made by Chiang Meng-jo, a man with a criminal record who was acting under police instructions; and that the Alaskan police decided Tzuo was the guilty party after only one day and without investigating anyone else.

It is also unbelievable that the Alaskan court could have convicted Tzuo only on the basis of a tape without having physical evidence such as the murder weapon, fingerprints or blood stains, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER INVESTS IN JOINT VENTURE PC ASSEMBLY PLANT IN TURKEY
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By C.H. Kuo & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Acer Group and Turkey's Ihlas Group on Friday announced a US$1.5 million joint venture in a personal computer assembly plant in Istanbul.

Under the agreement signed Friday, Acer Group will hold a 49 percent stake in the joint venture, while Ihlas Group will hold 51 percent. The assembly plant is to produce 3,000 personal computers per year with components and parts imported from Taiwan.

The Ihlas-Acer computer company will employ 85 staff members for the assembly plant in Kozyatagi, Istanbul. With the the establishment of the assembly plant, the sales turnover of the company for this year is estimated at US$35 million and is expected to climb to US$100 million by 2000.

Acer, the fifth largest computer manufacturer in the world, is the first international computer giant to team up with the Turkish enterprise to produce personal computers. Acer is also the first foreign investor in Turkey since the outbreak of financial turmoil that has swept the Asian area.
Acer made inroads into the Turkish market in 1996, when it appointed Ihlas as its agent to sell its "Aspire" personal computers. Acer President Stan Shih visited Turkey in September the same year.

The sales volume of Aspire personal computers stood at some 5,000 units at a combined valued of US$18 million last year, accounting for 1.6 percent of the Turkish market. Ihlas-Acer hopes to gain a 5 percent market share this year.
Turkey's largest personal computer maker is Escort, which has a sales turnover surpassing US$100 million.

Ihlas, which employs over 25,000 people, is one of the largest business groups in Turkey. The group operates in a variety of sectors, including books, printing, mass media, home appliances, cars, beverages, banking and finance. The group has cooperative relations with several other famous car and home appliance makers in South Korea and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION FAVORABLY IMPRESSED BY BAYER'S SAFETY MEASURES

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation visiting chemical giant Bayer's German headquarters at Dormagen was favorably impressed Friday by the company's safety precautions in producing Toluene diisocyanate (TDI) and said the opposition to the firm's proposed mega-investment project in Taiwan was ill-advised.

Taiwan Provincial Assemblyman Sung Ai-ke, a member of the delegation consisting of assemblymen, industrial experts and academics, told a CNA reporter in Taipei on the telephone that phosgene, a poisonous gas necessary for the production of TDI, is not so terrible as those who oppose Bayer's Taiwan investment claim, especially if handled appropriately.

The New Party assemblyman predicted that the Taiwan Provincial Assembly will approve a land-lease contract for Bayer on Feb. 16, assuming that the ruling Kuomintang can get its deputies to back the party's pro-Bayer stance.

In addition to using double-walled pipes and containers to transfer and store the gas, Bayer surrounds that plumbing with ammonia vapor, which would react with any leaking phosgene and transform it into poison-free urea, said Sung.
He doubted the claims by opponents of the project that phosgene is so poisonous that a leak would kill everyone within 20 km of the plant.

A local daily, the United Daily News, quoted a Bayer official as saying in Dormagen Friday that phosgene could pose a risk only to people within a three-km radius of the plant, while the company's proposed plant in Taichung, central Taiwan, would be a safe four km from the nearest residential area.

Even Chou Ching-yu, an assemblywoman with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party who had been skeptical about the proposed plant's safety, echoed Sung's support after visiting Bayer's German headquarters, according to the daily.
She blamed Taiwan authorities for the level of opposition to the project, saying that if they had shown enough credibility in the past, the anti-Bayer campaign would not have grown so large.

The daily also quoted Horst Mueck, chairman of Bayer Taiwan Co., as telling Sung that his company would provide the maximum compensation called for by local rules for any damage caused by an accident at its Taiwan plant, stressing that such problems would be extremely unlikely.
He also promised Sung that the plant would be shut down in case of any major industrial accident.

Meanwhile, Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai, who came to power in November's election on the strength of the anti-Bayer group, said he will conduct opinion polls on the issue and submit the results to the Provincial Assembly before it votes on Bayer's land-leasing contract.

Liao, a leader of the local anti-Bayer league, said he will carry out his campaign promise to put the issue to the people but that a referendum takes time to prepare and so will not be held before the Feb. 16 assembly vote.
Bayer began its negotiations with Taiwan authorities in 1995 for the NT$49.2 billion (US$1.5 billion) plant in Taichung Harbor with a capacity of producing 100,000 tons of TDI a year.
But the project was hit by opposition from local environmentalists, and the Taiwan Provincial Assembly delayed its vote on Bayer's land-leasing contract on Dec. 18, after Liao was elected magistrate.
The Provincial Assembly will open debate on the contract again on Feb. 16 as to whether to allow Bayer to construct the plant on a plot of government-owned land.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MISINTERPRETS SEF'S PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE: SHEU KE-SHENG

TEXT.P: Beijing is wrong to see the recent personnel reshuffle at the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) as an attempt by Taipei to delay the resumption of cross-strait talks, Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said Friday.

Since dialogue across the Taiwan Strait has proceeded under a systemic framework, discussions between the two sides will therefore not be affected by the shuffle of personnel at the SEF, he said, adding that there is no need for misunderstanding.

The directors and supervisors of the SEF held a provisional meeting on Saturday morning to approve the nomination of Shi Hwei-you, who currently serves as director-general of the ruling Kuomintang's Secretariat, to replace Chiao Jen-ho as vice chairman and secretary-general of the SEF.
Beijing responded to the news of the change at the SEF by accusing Taipei of trying to delay the resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
Shi's role and functions in the SEF will be the same as those of all others who have held the secretary-general's post in the past, Sheu stressed.

When asked how the government would respond if the SEF's Beijing-based counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), invites Shi to visit mainland China, Sheu said Taipei would weigh the matter carefully.

As to whether Taipei would insist that SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu lead the delegation to the Chinese mainland, Sheu remarked that the SEF is still waiting for a formal response from ARATS to a proposal that Koo go to mainland, and that Taipei's reaction will hinge on ARATS' reply.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE BACKS 'GET UP SIGN UP' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday threw his support for a "Get Up Sign Up" signature campaign launched by the Amnesty International (AI) to promote human rights protection around the world.

President Lee signed his name on a declaration initiated by the London-based human rights promotion organization and pledged to do everything in his power to ensure that the rights set forth in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights become a reality throughout the world.

During his talks with senior AI Taiwan branch executives, including honorary Chairman Po Yang and Chairperson Lin Min-tse, Lee said human rights are universal world values and that respecting human rights is an important symbol of a modern civilized country.
"Human rights are inherent," Lee said, adding that all people around the world should enjoy basic human rights, regardless of their nationalities or geographic locations.

He also pointed out that the ROC government has spared no efforts to protect basic human rights over past years. "We'll continue to do our best to protect and safeguard basic rights and realize the goals set forth in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights."
The Amnesty International launched a global "Get Up Sign Up" signature campaign on Dec. 10, 1997 to enlist support for further improving human rights conditions around the world.

"The drive is aimed at collecting signatures of political and business leaders, social celebrities and general members of the public worldwide to push for realization of various fundamental rights set forth in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights," said Po Yang, honorary chairman of the AI Taiwan branch, who was jailed for nearly 10 years for political dissent in the 1970s when Taiwan was still under martial law.

The AI Taiwan branch is responsible for collecting signatures on the island. The campaign started here on Saturday. In addition to President Lee, several senior government officials, including Huang Kun-hui, secretary-general to the President, Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, and Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu, have also signed their names to signify the ROC government's support for the drive. The local signature campaign will last until November.

The AI headquarters will present signatures collected worldwide to the United Nations during a meeting to be held in Paris on Dec. 10 to mark the 50th anniversary of the issue of the UN-sponsored Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Top leaders from more than 10 countries have thrown their support behind the campaign. US President Bill Clinton said late last year that human rights protection should be the cornerstone of the US diplomatic policy forever. Russia has declared 1998 as its "year for human rights."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HEAD HOPES FOR BLOSSOMING OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES IN SPRING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China said on Saturday that he hopes that the current impasse across the Taiwan Strait will be dispelled soon, just as the blossoms of spring follow the chill of winter.

C.F. Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Taiwan's quasi-official organization authorized to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, hoped that the SEF, under the guidance and supervision of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), will continue functioning as an intermediary body for better cross-strait relations.

Koo expressed the wish in a provisional meeting of the SEF board of directors. During the meeting, the 37 board members unanimously passed the resignation of SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Chiao Jen-ho, who was appointed head of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in the latest reshuffle of the Cabinet, and the appointment of Shi Hwei-you to succeed Chiao.

Shi is actually returning to his previous workplace. Before he became director-general of the ruling Kuomintang's Department of Secretariat, he was legal advisor to the SEF and the organization's deputy secretary-general.
Shi, trained as a judge, earned a reputation as a tough negotiator by refusing to budge during 16 rounds of talks with his mainland Chinese counterparts.

During the board meeting, Koo stressed that the SEF and the MAC, virtually two sides of one mechanism, should work and cooperate closely with each other for the sake of the interest of all Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The top task of the SEF is to negotiate and to coordinate, Koo said, adding that only when the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sit down and talk together will there be hope for peace.
Koo also urged Beijing's leaders to respect the agreements and consensus reached with Taiwan several years ago.

Despite the fact that the two sides reached a consensus on a "separate interpretation" of the use of the term "one China" and scored eight agreements on technical issues during previous preparatory meetings, Koo said Beijing turned down the holding of the long-planned second meeting between Koo and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, in 1994, claiming "the atmosphere for talks wasn't good."

DOC.HEADLINE: CURRENCY DROP DROVE UP PRICES IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan are beginning to feel the pinch of the lower value of Taiwan's currency against the US dollar.

The consumer price index rose 1.82 percent in January, while the wholesale price index moved up 7.59 percent, according to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
Analysts attributed the price rise to the depreciation of the local currency, which has lost nearly 30 percent of its value against the US dollar since the middle of last year.
The fall of the NT dollar has driven up the cost of imports and brought price increases on local goods and services as well.
With hikes in local taxi fares and school tuition brewing, the analysts predicted increased pressure for even higher prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN TRADE VOLUME IN JANUARY DROPS FROM ONE YEAR AGO

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade volume in January stood at US$15.12 billion, the lowest level since March 1996, according to statistics compiled by the Finance Ministry.
Taiwan exported US$7.63 billion worth of goods in January, down 26.3 percent from the same period of last year, while imports also decreased 19.4 percent to US$7.49 billion.
This brought Taiwan a trade surplus of US$140 million in January, significantly less than the US$1.06 billion surplus registered in January 1997.
An official with the Finance Ministry on Saturday attributed the low export-and-import volume to the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays, which this year began at the end of January.
The official pointed out the trade surplus in January, though a drop from the same period of last year, was an increase from last December's US$80 million.

He cited the US$3.99 billion trade deficit Taiwan suffered with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) -- the island's first such deficit with ASEAN since 1990 -- and a sharp decrease of up to 141 percent in Taiwan's exports to South Korea due to the sharp depreciation of the South Korean won as the two main reasons behind the drop in the island's trade surplus.
He predicted that Taiwan's two-way trade will continue to grow stably this year since the economic situations in Taiwan and other economic powers are improving.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS DECLINING GOVERNMENT APPROVAL RATING

TEXT.P: The government's approval rating has declined over the past year, with the public most dissatisfied with worsening social order, according to a public opinion poll released by the private 21ST Century Foundation on Saturday.

The telephone poll of 1,069 adults, conducted on Dec. 8-9, 1997, found that the government's overall approval rating dropped from 73.84 points recorded in the foundation's 1996 survey to last year's 72.34 points.

The rating plunged most significant in the category of social order, according to the poll. In the 1996 survey, about 74 percent of the respondents said they were satisfied with the government's performance in maintaining law and order, but only 30 percent gave the thumbs up to the government's performance in this regard last year.
The poll found that 65.8 percent were dissatisfied with the government's inability to curb the crime rate, up from 19.1 percent recorded in the previous survey.

Poll results also showed that public dissatisfaction with the government's diplomatic policy and mainland policy as well as its performance in improving welfare services and narrowing the gap between the rich and the poor all shot up, while the approval ratings for these aspects all plunged.

For instance, only 40 percent said they were satisfied with the government's foreign policy, down from 56 percent recroded in the 1996 survey. Meanwhile, the percentage of critics to the country's foreign policy increased from 27 percent to 43 percent.
The government managed to post slight gains in approval ratings for environmental protection and national security.
Accroding to the poll, only 46 percent were satisfied with the performance of various cabinet ministers and 58 percent said they don't believe what many high-ranking government officials have said.
Meanwhile, 48 percent said they were satisfied with the general performance of all government employees, compared to 35 percent who said they were dissatisfied with their performance.

Only 22 percent were satisifed with the performance of the country's judges, compared to 26 percent of naysayers. As high as 59 percent of those surveyed said they were dissatisfied with the performance of legislators, while only 25 percent gave the thums up.

As high as 74 percent of the respondents said they think political graft or corruption is rampant in Taiwan, and 47 percent said the government often gives the top priority to partisan interests in making decisions on major policy issues.

On relations with mainland China, nearly 58 percent said they prefer to maintain the status quo; 7.5 percent said they hope Taiwan would declare independence as soon as possible; 3.3 percent said they look forward to see national reunification in the near future.

The poll also found that 35 percent of the respondents said they think they are Taiwanese; 34 percent said they consider they are both Taiwanese and Chinese; and 22 percent said they think they are Chinese.
Despite a decline in political satisfaction, 63.4 percent of the respondents still said they are confident in Taiwan's future, according to the survey.

Legislator Kao Yu-jen, who concurrently serves as chairman of the 21ST Century Foundation, said poll results show that local people are most concerned about social order, environmental protection, welfare services and equitable distribution of wealth. The newly installed Cabinet should redouble efforts in these aspects in order to meet the public demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSING MARKET'S DARK DAYS LOOK TO BECOME DARKER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's housing market, which has been in a slump for more than eight years, is facing its worst prospects in recent decades with the announcement that a horde of local banks will increase their interest rates.
Higher interest rates will make it more difficult for the sluggish housing industry to move ahead, insiders complained.
To stimulate sales, real estate companies are now offering previously unheard of incentives, including a BMW for an order at a resort in Taoyuan County.

Incentives elsewhere include free interior decorations and a complete set of household electrical appliances with the purchase of an apartment in Tamshui, Taipei County. In Yangmei, a suburb of Taoyuan, one developer is offering to let buyers move in after making a down payment of only 10 percent of the home's cost, while arranging for a bank to finance the remaining 90 percent.
In another case, buyers need only pay interest on their housing loans for the first three years, after which time they can sell the house back to the builder, if they so desire.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, NEW PARTY SEE FALLING SUPPORT RATES

TEXT.P: Both the ruling Kuomintang and the minor opposition New Party have seen their support rates decline over the past year, while the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has managed to post a gain in its support rate, according to a public opinion poll released on Saturday.

The telephone survey of 1,069 adults, conducted by the private 21ST Century Foundation on Dec. 8-9, 1997, found that 27.3 percent of the respondents said they hope the KMT will remain in power, down from 38.8 percent recorded in the foundation's 1996 poll.
In contrast, 15 percent said they look forward to seeing the pro-Taiwan independence DPP rise to power, compared to only 8 percent who pinned their hope on the party in the previous survey.
The poll also found that only 2.7 percent of those surveyed said they hope to see the pro-reunification New Party take the helm of the country, down from 5.3 percent registered in the 1996 poll.

Asked about which party they support, 22.3 percent said they support the KMT, down from 31.3 percent found in the 1996 poll; the DPP's support rate rose from 14.4 percent to 19.1 percent; while the New Party's support rate dropped to 4.8 percent from 9.9 percent.

Kao Yu-jen, a KMT legislator who also serves as chairman of the 21ST Century Foundation, said the rise in the DPP's support rate may be related to the party's landslide win in last November's mayoral and county magistrate elections.

Responding to the findings of the poll, New Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang said New Party politicians should speak more about public policies and should reduce talks about promoting reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in order to win more popular support.

Lin attributed the increase in the DPP's support rate to its reduction in advocating Taiwan independence and to the departure of a group of radical independence activists from the party. "These two developments have helped the DPP to win increasing support from middle-class voters," he noted.

Lin further said the New Party, which was founded by a group of maverick KMT politicians a few years ago, should follow suit in order to win the support of voters who prefer to maintain the political status quo.

He also said the New Party should intensify contacts with grass-roots communities in southern or rural parts of the island in order to root itself firmly in Taiwan. Otherwise, he said, the party may not be able to increase its seats in the Legislative Yuan in the year-end election.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOHN CHANG URGES BEIJING TO RECOGNIZE POLITICAL REALITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Boston, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By David Wang & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang, on Friday said that mainland China should recognize and accept the fact that the ROC is an independent and sovereign state.

Chang made the remarks during a speech he gave at Harvard University on cross-strait relations between 1987 and 1997." He also stressed that the eventual reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can only be achieved gradually.

Ever since ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo lifted the ban on visits by Taiwan people to the mainland in 1987, not long before his death, economic, trade and cultural exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have greatly increased, Chang said.

In the past 10 years, Taiwan has done much more for promoting cross-strait exchanges than the mainland authorities, he said, adding that only because of security concerns does the ROC government restrict visits to Taiwan by mainland Chinese.

Chang told his audience of some 100 people that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait conducted 20 rounds of talks between 1991 and 1995, when mainland authorities unilaterally suspended the discussions in protest against ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June that year.

He also noted that in the days leading up to the March 1996 ROC presidential election, the mainland authorities staged war games in waters near Taiwan to deter what they called mounting "pro-independence" sentiment on the island.
Chang called Beijing's accusations against Taiwan "groundless," pointing out that the ROC government has never supported "two Chinas", "one China, one Taiwan", or "Taiwan independence."

He stressed that the ROC is willing to resume cross-strait talks but said that the dialogue must be conducted without any preconditions. The ROC also insists that the two sides should discuss practical issues first and then political ones, he said.

Chang reiterated the ROC's stance that Beijing's attempt to use the "one country, two systems" scheme as a paradigm for national reunification is totally unacceptable, adding that unlike Hong Kong, the ROC is a sovereign state.
In a recent survey, 48 percent of those polled said that they would like the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to maintain the status quo, he noted.
Chang cited another survey whose results showed that for the first time more people in the ROC identified themselves as "Taiwanese" than as "Chinese" -- by 55 percent to 33 percent, respectively.

Taiwan's democratic achievement, he said, is the island's most powerful trump card in dealing with mainland China. He went on to say that though the two sides of the Taiwan Strait both use the expression "one China," Beijing does so in "present tense," while Taipei uses "future tense."

In his speech, Chang called on US friends to continue to lend their support to the ROC. He said that the ROC will carry on its democratic reforms and is willing to reopen talks with mainland China at any time if Beijing does not set preconditions for the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES REBOUND STRONGLY

TEXT.P: Share prices rallied strongly in the Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) on Saturday following a slight drop on Friday, with the weighted price index climbing 139.32 points to close at 8,683.46.
Market analysts attributed the rise in part to an overnight gain on Wall Street, saying the strong rally in the high-technology sector was partly sparked by surges in the New York's NASDAQ.
The analysts predicted that high-tech stocks, which accounted for about 60 percent of Saturday's overall turnover, will continue to be Taiex mainstream throughout the first quarter of the year.

A total of 2.75 billion shares changed hands during the two-hour weekend trading session, with turnover reaching NT$186.97 billion (US$5.69 billion). The trading volume was among the highest for weekend sessions.
Gainers outnumbered losers, 263 to 148, with 66 issues remaining unchanged. High-tech, food and financial stocks posted largest gains in Saturday's trading.

United Microelectronics, Acer and Taiwan Semiconductor stocks all registered significant gains on unconfirmed reports that several major American mutual fund companies have purchased large quanities of stocks of the three firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOLLAR GAINS GROUND

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan rose slightly against the US dollar on Saturday to close at NT$32.846. The local currency finished at 32.855 on Friday.
The currency opened at NT$32.861 against the greenback and reached a high of NT$32.82 at one point.
Market turnover amounted to US$116 million in the three-hour trading session.
Currency dealers said the NT dollar will remain strong in the short term if the local stock market continues its current rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILY EXPOUNDS WHY ASIA'S 'CRONY CAPITALISM' FALLING

TEXT.P: It's becoming increasingly clear that the financial meltdown in Southeast Asia represents the economic equivalent of the end of the Cold War and of the demolition of the Berlin Wall, a Canadian columnist said Friday.

Market capitalism is triumphing over state capitalism, claimed Richard Gwyn of The Toronto Star. Once, there was an "Asian model." Since the meltdown, however, this has been castigated as "crony capitalism" -- insiders building up fortunes through their political and banking connections, Gwyn noted.
The essence of the Asian model, supported by so-called "Asian values," was a system of lifelong employment, he said.
Now the Asian model is being turned into a variation of the Anglo-Saxon model, he said. In all Southeast Asian countries, unemployment is rising toward unprecedented levels, he pointed out.

Gwyn said it's just being realized in Asia that the obverse side of the system of lifelong employment is lifelong unemployment. It's also being realized that the system of lifelong employment has meant that none of these countries (except Japan) has any program of unemployment insurance to sustain workers when they are in-between jobs.
Lifelong employment, he said, can only work if the economy is growing rapidly or when recessions only last a year or two, as in Japan during the "oil shock" of the mid-1970s.
All Southeast Asian countries, though, are undergoing a fundamental economic change that will last for years, according to Gwyn.
Thus, he continued, one radical political change only now being considered in Southeast Asia is to create procedures to enable companies that have failed to go bankrupt.
There's no question that Southeast Asian countries, with their resource of well-educated, hard-working and low-paid workers, will eventually make the economic transition, he said.
But once they do, they're going to emerge as different kinds of societies -- "far less distinctively Asian and far more like the rest of us (in the West)," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN EMBASSIES WATER DOWN PARTIES DUE TO ECONOMIC CRISIS AT HOME

TEXT.P: Some Asian embassies in Canberra, hit by economic troubles at home, are set to water down their cocktail parties as a result of budget cuts, according to a survey by the mass circulation newspaper, The Australian.

The daily reported on Saturday that the days of hors d'oeuvres and champagne will be gone at the embassies of Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines and possibly Indonesia because of budget cuts from their countries.
The daily quoted Malaysian high commissioner Dato Adnan Othman as saying that his embassy will cancel the annual Malaysian National Day reception.
The Indonesian embassy is expected to follow suit. Five of its staff members have already been recalled to Jakarta due to budget cuts.
Filipino Ambassador Dealia Albert said: "This year is our centennial of independence from Spain and, of course, we would like proper celebrations. But we have to do it within constraints."

Thai diplomats are not being replaced when their postings end. And they are required to reduce spending on their lifestyles, taking a 30 percent cut in their accommodation allowances after their current leases run out, according to the daily.
Despite the low exchange rate for the won, however, the South Korean embassy will not cut back on staff but will increase its trade promotions in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO REFORM MEASURES FOR ENTRY OF SKILLED MIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The Australian government will introduce new measures in which the approval of entry for new skilled migrants will be based not only on English proficiency but also on capital backing, according to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said skilled immigrants could be denied entry to Australia unless they have capital backing, which is expected to be in the amount of tens of thousands or even hundreds of thousands of dollars.
This is being done, he explained, so Australia would know the immigrants would not have to rely on social welfare during their first two years in the country.
The department has sharply reduced the intake of immigrants to 68,000 in 1997-98 from almost 100,000 in 1996-97.
Ruddock said the reform is in the nation's interest and will keep new skilled migrants "away from welfare dependency."

"I think that one of the major problems that we have experienced in relation to the ... ugly immigration debate that we have seen is because people have lost confidence in the way the program was being conducted," he said.
As for independent migrants and those wishing to reunite with family members, Ruddock said his department has yet to decide whether the requirement of capital backing would apply to them as well.
Australia has been hit by budget deficits for a number of years, partly because of rising generous welfare payments to new immigrants.
The budget deficits have boosted the country's foreign debt. The Australian government wants to change the situation so that it can reduce spending and achieve a budget surplus in the coming years.
The new measures will be introduced on July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE-US JOINT VENTURE TO PRODUCE MORE CARS FOR EXPORT

TEXT.P: A leading Australian carmaker and its partner, General Motors of the United States, will invest A$1.4 billion (US$952 million) to increase car production for export to Asia, including Taiwan and Japan, the Middle East and Latin America.
Company chairman Jim Weimels said the new investment will help increase annual production of the company to between 150,000 and 160,000 units a year, up from 123,450 in 1997.

He said he anticipated an initial volume of 5,000 cars a year for export to the Middle East, rising to 15,000 in the future. The long-term sales potential in Latin America will be around 6,000 a year, while the target for exports to Asia will be about 10,000.
Last year, Australia was allowed for the first time to sell 2,000 cars to Taiwan alone, and the number will be increased to 6,000 units a year after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization.

The Australian-US joint venture will carry the Australian name of Holden, one of the best-selling cars in Australia. Holden reached a peak of 86,000 cars a year in 1971 during its last big export drive, when its vehicles were sold to 73 markets worldwide.
But Holden began losing its markets to Japanese cars after that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: OSCAR NIGHT AMERICA PARTIES TO EXPAND TO 31 CITIES

TEXT.P: Los Angeles isn't the only city that will be throwing a big party on Oscar night. Films fans in 31 cities across the United States will celebrate the 70th Academy Awards in high style March 23.
For the fifth year in a row, thousands of people will help raise money for various charities at Academy-sanctioned Oscar Night America fundraising galas.
"Over the years we have observed that there were hundreds of charity fund raisers taking place on Oscar Night," said Rick Robertson, executive administrator of the Academy.

"We developed Oscar Night America as a way for at least some of those events to benefit by a relationship with the big show out here. Receiving official Oscar Night America status seems to make their parties just a bit more special and make people nationwide really feel part of the excitement happening at our awards presentation in Los Angeles," he said.

Only one charity party in a given city may participate in Oscar Night America. Events are produced entirely by local non-profit charitable organizations, with the active participation of the local ABC Television Network affiliate station. All of the money raised remains with the sponsoring charity.
The Academy provides official Oscar Night America parties with the same printed Academy Awards programs as those handed out at the awards presentation in Los Angeles.
Oscar Night America began in 1994 with parties in two cities, Minneapolis and San Francisco. By 1996, the program had grown to 12 cities. Events vary from black tie galas to less formal dinners.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG MOVIE STAR DENIED ENTRY INTO CANADA

TEXT.P: Stephen Chiau, one of Asia's most popular comic-action heroes, has lost his bid to immigrate to Canada because of his links to Asian organized crime, the Canadian Press reported.
The Hong Kong movie star has been trying to come to Canada to further his career, the Canadian Press said in a Vancouver-datelined report.

It noted that Chiau has been refused twice by Canadian immigration officials, who believe he's being planted in Canada by a powerful triad called Sun Yee On to control the Asian film industry in North America.
Federal Court Justice Jean-Uedes Dube dismissed Chiau's appeal, according to the report. It cited Dube as saying the immigration visa office had reasonable grounds to believe Chiau is a triad member.
But the judge left the door open for Chiau to appeal his case to the Federal Court of Appeal, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GARUDA TO CHANGE FLIGHT SCHEDULE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Indonesian flag carrier, Garuda Indonesia, will change its flight schedule from Jakarta to Taiwan and Hong Kong to support fishery exports from the eastern parts of Indonesia.
Bambang Sunan, head of the Garuda representative office, said in Ujungpandang Friday that the flight schedule from transit airports such as Jakarta and Surabaya will begin at the end of March.
He said fishery exporters from eastern Indonesia, particularly South Sulawesi, had complained about the absence of flights from Ujungpandang to Jakarta and Surabaya.
"Until now, fishery products had to spend one night at transit airports before Garuda takes them to Hong Kong and Taiwan," he was quoted by the Antara news agency as saying.
In South Sulawesi, there are 18 exporters of fishery products and eight of them send their products at a rate of one ton a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE PRIVATE HOME PRICES DROPPED 12.5 PERCENT LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Singapore's private home prices fell 12.5 percent last year, the biggest annual drop since the 1980s property slump, and transactions plunged 42.8 percent to 6,990.
Prices fell a higher 16.5 percent by the end of last year from the peak achieved in the second quarter of 1996 -- just before anti-speculation measures were introduced in mid-year.

Apartments suffered the biggest price fall of 16.8 percent last year, followed by terrace homes, which shed 16.4 percent, and condominiums, which eased 11.9 percent, according to the official price index for private housing released Friday by the Urban Redevelopment Authority.
It pointed out that prices were squeezed by over-supply and the regional financial crisis that began in the second half of last year.
Analysts and property consultants said regional economic problems are likely to depress prices by another 20 percent before the market recovers.
They predicted the number of private home sales this year will not exceed last year's and that this will probably depress prices even further.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA EXPORTS MEDICINAL HERBS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Indonesia's efforts to make its medicinal herbs become reliable export commodities have succeeded in increasing demand for them in the international market.

Data from the Central Bureau of Statistics showed that export of Indonesian medicinal herbs from January to October 1997 reached a total value of US$6.28 million, up sharply from 1996's US$4.41 million.
Most of Indonesia's medicinal herbs are exported to Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Germany, Japan, South Korea and Malaysia, the Antara news agency reported.

The increase in the 1997 export value, however, was not followed by an increase in volume, given that in the first ten months of 1997 Indonesia only exported a total of 2,294 tons of medicinal herbs, a decrease of 34.25 percent from the same period of the previous year, when exports totaled 3,489 tons.
In 1996, the total export of medicinal herbs reached 4,160 tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LISTED 11TH MOST EXPENSIVE CITY IN THE WORLD
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Commodity prices in Taipei, Taiwan, have been listed as the 11th highest in the world, according to a survey conducted in December by the British-based Economist Intelligence Unit on 121 cities worldwide.
The survey results show that Tokyo is the world's most expensive metropolis, followed by Osaka, Hong Kong and Moscow, with the latter two ranked as third equal.
Prompted by rapid development, costs in Taipei have jumped rapidly, making the city the world's 11th most expensive, up from its previous rank of 18th, the results show.
The statistics indicate that Oslo, Norway's capital, ranked fifth, ahead of Zurich, Paris and Geneva.
New York was listed as the world's 19th most expensive city.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US ADMISSION TEMPORAIRE TO BE ENACTED

TEXT.P: Goods which are imported to Taiwan from the US for specific use or which are to be processed for re-export are soon to enjoy duty-free "admission temporaire" in Taiwan, according to Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

A BOFT statement said the already signed Taipei-Washington accord on temporary admission of profession equipment, commercial samples and advertising materials will be officially implemented on Feb. 27, when the US enacts a set of modified customs regulations.
The accord is expected to facilitate Taiwan-US exchanges in trade, technology, expertise and culture.

Since Taiwan began permitting admission temporaire in 1990, it has signed agreements for mutual opening of tariff-free import and export of the categorized goods with 22 countries worldwide. The US will be the 23rd.
Taiwan must forge separate agreements with each economy wishing to gain admission temporaire because it does not belong to a global group promoting cooperation in customs affairs.

In March, 1995, the Taiwan-US admission temporaire agreement was reached during talks on investment and trade frameworks between the two nations, and the accord was then formalized and signed to ensure its implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL VISITS NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Ranan Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said on Saturday that the KMT will never deviate from its goal of fighting for the existence and continued development of the ROC.
Chang, who arrived here on Saturday from Boston for a two-day visit, made the remarks at a news conference in response to questions raised by some of the more than 200-strong audience.

Rebutting the argument that "the term `Taiwan' contains a pro-independence sentiment," Chang stressed that the alternative use of "Taiwan" does not signify the promotion of Taiwan independence, since the nation is faced with fierce pressure from Beijing, which spares no effort to prevent the ROC from using its formal designation in the international community.

"All overseas Chinese who are concerned about the future of the ROC should develop a more comprehensive understanding of the term `Taiwan,' and realize that it is not equal to the `Republic of Taiwan.' No one can deny the reality that the ROC on Taiwan is an independent sovereignty," he noted.

The KMT secretary-general called on all ROC nationals residing abroad not to dance to Beijing's tune or the tune of the proponents of Taiwan independence, emphasizing that the pragmatic foreign policies adopted by the ROC government, including its "no haste, be patient" policy governing Taiwan investment in mainland China, is aimed at securing Taiwan's survival and continued development.

Elaborating on his policy, described as "using war to stop war," which he espoused while serving as ROC foreign minister before assuming his current post, Chang said it is out of the question that the hegemonic Beijing regime will give way to Taiwan's international presence, and only brave confrontation of the Chinese communists' bullyragging will guarantee the nation's survival.

Addressing the current political situation in Taiwan, Chang said the KMT would welcome former justice minister and minister without portfolio Ma Ying-jeou to run in the next election for Taipei mayor if Ma decides he wishes to.
Ma, who has since returned to work in the academic sector, is widely regarded as the KMT's most competent rival to incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Chang is scheduled to return to Taipei on Monday via Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO IMPORT INDONESIAN MARBLE

TEXT.P: Taiwan, Spain and Japan are all to import marble from Southeast Sulawesi, an Indonesian official said on Saturday.

"Business representatives from the three countries came here in January and after examining the quality of our marble, they told us they wanted to import the commodity," Antara quoted Edison Dayoh, head of a local mining office, as saying.
The marble in the area, estimated at billions of metric tons, is produced by two national companies, Edison said, adding that each of the three countries will import 5,000 tons of marble per year.
He said some other countries, including Iran, Saudi Arabia, Canada, the Netherlands, the US and Australia, have also expressed interest in importing Indonesian marble.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY DELEGATION HEADS FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation composed of 25 public opinion leaders belonging to the opposition New Party will depart on Monday for mainland China for an eight-day visit.

H.S. Feng, a National Assembly deputy and spokesman for the delegation, said the New Party is willing to play the role of "mediator" in cross-strait relations, "navigator for China's eventual unification," and "protector of Taiwan business," at a time when Taiwan's relations with mainland China remain sluggish.

According to Feng, the visit was prompted by an invitation from the mainland-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), which sent him a letter on Jan. 26 inviting him and his "friends of the New Party" to take part in a seminar on cross-strait ties slated for early February.

As it is the first invitation ever extended by ARATS to a Taiwan political party since the release of mainland China President Jiang Zemin's "eight-point" statement in January 1995, Feng said, the delegation's visit carries historic significance and reflects the mainland's sincerity in finding solutions to Taiwan business interests there.

Feng expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will engage in negotiation instead of confrontation and replace hatred with communication. Claiming that the New Party is the only political party in Taiwan which advocates China's unification, he said the New Party's officeholders should be brave in injecting a new lease of hope to the present stalemate in cross-strait ties.

The delegation, which considers itself the "voice of the Taiwan people," will speak out in the interest of the people of Taiwan at the seminar scheduled to take place on Tuesday, he said, adding that the purpose of the visit should not be tainted by attacks from rival political parties.
According to Feng, the group will also meet officials of mainland China's State Department and the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN LEGISLATIVE LEADER POSTPONES VISIT TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Soon Se-il, president of the Korean-Taiwan Lawmakers' Friendship Association and good friend of Korean President-elect Kim Dae-jung, is expected to postpone his visit to Taipei by one week.

An informed source said Sunday that Soon is so busy with his work in Korean Congress that he has to postpone the visit from Feb. 9 to Feb. 16. John Chang, secretary general of the ruling Kuomintang, is scheduled to visit Seoul Feb. 11-14.
Soon, chairman of the Trade and Industry Committee of Korean Congress, is now preoccupied with bills concerning corporate lay-offs and business restructuring, the informed source said.

Soon's visit to Taipei is seen by some analysts as a sign of thawing in the relationship between the two countries, which severed diplomatic relations in August, 1992, when Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Meanwhile, Kim Jong-pil, honorary president of the Korean United Liberal Democrats (ULD), is scheduled to leave for Beijing Sunday for a four-day visit. He will bring with him a letter from President-elect Kim to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, according to local news reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE BACKS MALAYSIA'S PROPOSAL ON ASEAN CURRENCIES

TEXT.P: Singapore has backed Malaysia's proposal for ASEAN countries to use their own currencies for regional trade, Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said in Singapore on Saturday.
After a two-hour lunch meeting with Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, Mahathir said that he and Goh agreed that the region's central bank governors should meet to flesh the idea out.
The two leaders also discussed the regional financial crisis and bilateral matters.
Mahathir's visit was part of a regional trip which included visits to Thailand and the Philippines, to discuss the regional currency crisis with his ASEAN counterparts.

Referring to an earlier meeting, Mahathir said: "I met Goh only a few weeks back and we agreed to work together. Today, we went into greater detail about how we can cooperate, in particular with regard to the economic problem and currency turmoil, and what role Singapore can have on investments in Malaysia."
He added that they had agreed about the use of "our own currencies" for trade between ASEAN countries, and the need to have a meeting of governors of the respective central banks to work this out.

It was reported that last Friday, after meeting Thai Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai in Bangkok, Mahathir said the ASEAN countries were hoping to introduce a single regional currency similar to the euro, which is to be launched next year in Europe.

This, he added, would be a long-term solution to reduce dependence on the US dollar, conserve foreign exchange reserves and cushion the effects of currency speculation, which he said sparked off the current crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHILDREN'S BOOKS AND MAGAZINES TO BE EXHIBITED IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Some 5,000 volumes of Taiwan children's books and magazines will be exhibited in Beijing on May 29-June 4.

The exhibition, to be sponsored by the "China Development Fund" of the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, will be held at the "Beijing Chinese Children Activity Center." It will be followed by a symposium on the reading materials and publications for the children of Taiwan and mainland China.
A delegation of Taiwan publishers of children's reading materials will visit Beijing later this year.
The activities are aimed at promoting cultural exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1997 OBU ASSETS TOPPED US$39 BILLION

TEXT.P: Offshore Banking Units (OBUs) of all financial institutions with operations in Taiwan totaled US$39.1 billion as of the end of 1997, up 6.93 percent from a year ago, according to statistics compiled by the Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China.
Taiwan-based banks owned US$20.9 billion, or 54 percent, of the total, while foreign banks made up the remaining 46 percent, which stood at US$18.2 billion, the statistics show.

As of the end of last year, a total of 71 banking offices and branches, 38 belonging to Taiwan-based banks and the other 33 to foreign affiliates, were allowed to conduct OBU operations in Taiwan, the tallies indicate.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YORK-BASED ORGANIZATION URGES EARLY RELEASE OF WANG BINGZHANG

TEXT.P: The New York-based overseas preparatory group for the formation of "Chinese Justice Party" issued a statement Saturday, urging the government of free countries to help obtain early release of mainland Chinese dissident Wang Bingzhang.
Fu Shenqi, spokesman for the dissident group, said Wang was arrested Friday noon in Bengbu City, Anhui Province. Wang Tingjin, a dissident living there, was also arrested at the same time.

Wang reportedly sneaked into the Chinese mainland from Macau about two weeks ago for the formation of an opposition party in mainland China. He founded the U.S.-based Chinese Alliance for Democracy and the magazine China Spring in early 1980s.

The statement said that mainland Chinese dissidents have legitimate rights to go back to the China mainland, and that Wang went back to the mainland in an "unusual way," because Beijing has deprived dissidents of such rights. It urged Beijing to release Wang Bingzhang and Wang Tingjin immediately.
Beijing should hold dialogues with dissidents at home and abroad in order to find out solutions to the various complicated problems facing mainland China, the statement said.
Beijing should not take advantage of Wang Bingzhang's case and step up its efforts to crack down on pro-democracy movement, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,694 PEOPLE IN SINGAPORE DECLARED BANKRUPT IN 1997

TEXT.P: The number of people going bankrupt in Singapore rose 30 percent last year, hitting a new peak, and is expected to rise even further this year.

A total of 1,694 people were declared bankrupt last year, almost 10 percent more than the last peak in 1987, when recession had bitten into Singapore, said a spokesman for the Official Assignee which handles all bankruptcy cases in Singapore.
"We expect the number to rise in 1998," he added.
Lawyers who handle such cases confirmed the trend, adding that there had also been a significant rise in people defaulting on their loans since last October, The Straits Times reported on Sunday.
However, some lawyers said that the comparison with the figure of 10 years ago should be seen in perspective.

"Today, our total number of businesses is much larger than 10 years ago, and many bankruptcies are due to business failures of sole proprietorships and small partnerships," a lawyer was quoted as saying.
The number might also have been swelled by the 1995 Bankruptcy Act, which could have led to a bunching of cases last year as lawyers adjusted to the changes.
The new Act, replacing the harsher Bankruptcy Act of 1888, was "more forgiving" to the debtor, he said.
It raised the level of debt at which people could be declared bankrupt to S$2,000, up from S$500 under the old law.

Most bankrupts failed to pay their loans to banks and other financial institutions, he said, adding than in recent months, people were not only not paying their banks but were also failing to pay their trade creditors.
"There is a major cash-flow problem, especially if you are doing business regionally," he was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOME OF KISS AND TELL MISTRESS BROKEN INTO

TEXT.P: Chou Yu-kuo, the media celebrity who was allegedly forced to have an abortion by her lover, former chief spokesman for Taiwan's provincial government Huang Yi-chiao, on Sunday was reported to have been deeply frightened by a break-in at her Taipei residence.
According to local police, Chou's apartment in downtown Taipei was found to have been entered by force on Saturday night. Chou was not in at the time.

Police rushed to the scene after being alerted by the apartment building's security system. Following a preliminary investigation, they found that the intruder had entered the apartment by breaking into a closed-off porch area at the back of the house, the police said.

Chou was soon informed of the break-in, said a police spokesman, who added that although the apartment had been ransacked, it appeared that nothing had been stolen. The spokesman said it was likely that the intruder fled when he heard the alarm go off.

However, he added that the police were not ruling out the possibility that the break-in might have been an act of revenge for Chou's use of her radio talk show to publicize the sleazy details of her alleged affair with Huang, who was demoted by his boss, Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, as a result of the scandal.
The journalist, author and broadcaster has recently been in the media spotlight since accusing Huang of carrying on simultaneous affairs with her and socialite Emmy Ho.

The sensational nature of the allegations have sparked discussion islandwide on the morals and behavior of civil servants who are often in the political limelight, especially since Soong has a reputation of having strong moral fiber and Huang was his right-hand man.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPY SATELLITE FOR SALE TO ANYONE WITH US$200M

TEXT.P: Some Southeast Asian nations have been offered the chance to purchase their own spy satellite and collect information on a permanent basis -- if they can cough up US$200 million.

At the moment, only a few developed countries have access to the technology to build, launch and control their own military spy satellites, The Straits Times reported Sunday in a dispatch from Cannes, France.
Others can purchase time on commercially-available satellites or commission space-imaging companies to take surveillance or reconnaissance photographs, it said.

Another option is to purchase commercially-available photographs, which are widely available in the market following the relaxation of regulations on the use of American spy satellites by the US government.
However, these have restrictions on their areas of coverage, especially in situations when the security of the country providing the service is compromised.
Not any more, the report said.
France's Aerospatiale Space and Defense Branch, Europe's leading exporter of satellites, is putting its Isys mini-satellite space observation system up for sale on the open market, it said.

For US$200 million, the buyer receives, on a turnkey basis, the launch -- with insurance -- of a satellite into orbit, a spare satellite, a ground control station, a mission center and one or more image-processing stations which are compatible with existing commercial satellites such as Spot, Landsat and Radarsat, the report said.
Associated services like training and image interpretation are also provided.
What is attractive about the Aerospatiale deal is that there are no legal constraints of overflight.
Said a spokesman for the Satellites Division, located on the French Riviera: "We have done marketing presentations in Southeast Asia and there is strong interest in such a system."

The Isys satellite, a small platform, can take photographs from a height of 1,500 km. It is highly accurate, with an accuracy of up to 3.5 meters. For accuracy as little as 2 meters, a bilateral agreement with the French government is required, the report said.
The early-warning satellite, with a lifespan of seven to eight years, has a footprint of 1,000 km in radius extendible to 2,000 km. It will cross over the area of coverage three times daily.
"Isys is a good complement to tactical reconnaissance," said the spokesman.

Asia has tremendous potential for the commercial satellite industry, particularly in communication satellites. Outside of the US, the region represents close to half the worldwide satellite market of US$40 billion.
Of the six satellites launched by Aerospatiale last year, two are owned by Asian countries -- Thaicom 3 for Thailand's Shinawatra company and Sinosat-1 for mainland China, the report said.

It quoted Joel Le Breton, senior vice president (commercial), Satellite Operations, as commenting: "I believe that technological development in Asia is so fast that there are new demands for satellites. Basic telecommunication needs in Asia will remain very strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORST OF REGIONAL CURRENCY CRISIS NOT OVER

TEXT.P: The worst of the regional currency crisis will not be over until after the election of the Indonesian president and vice president early next month, Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said on Saturday night.

Speaking at a Chinese New Year and Hari Raya dinner at his constituency, Lee pointed out that the Indonesian rupiah will weaken again if the market is uncomfortable with the choice of the next Indonesian vice president.
This would lead to higher inflation, more companies going bankrupt, and greater unemployment, he said. "The resulting social problems will be widespread," he added.

"It is vital to Indonesia that the rupiah is stabilized and the stock market begins to recover. Otherwise, the fallout will be bad for Indonesia and may again spread panic over the region," he commented.

The crisis, he said, is beyond the control of Singapore, but it should do whatever it can to help. This is why Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has called on President Suharto three times over the last few weeks.

Giving his audience of grassroots leaders and residents an overview of the crisis, Lee said that unlike Thailand and South Korea, investors have not been able to find a renewed sense of confidence in Indonesia.

During his hour-long speech in English and Mandarin, Lee also analyzed the causes of the regional crisis, saying that investor confidence evaporated when the ballooning current account deficits of countries like Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea, which had borrowed heavily in US dollars, were noticed.
Their overspending, he noted, was made possible because of weak banking systems, and exacerbated by corruption and cronyism.
But the root of the problem was political, as governments were more preoccupied with political difficulties and did not heed the warning signals from the market, he said.

"The Thais had six governments in five years and none had the time to attend to the gaping current account deficit. The Malaysian prime minister shifted the blame to foreign speculators, while Suharto thought that he could ride out this crisis as he had ridden so many others in the past 30 years," he said.

"It is a crisis of confidence, and confidence has not yet been restored... Where the market is not convinced that the leader is doing what is necessary, they have withheld their votes of confidence, leaving the currency vulnerable," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD RELEASES DRAFT ON OFFSHORE CASINO INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The government has completed a draft on development of Taiwan's offshore islands, paving the way for the establishment of legal casinos in those areas, sources from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Monday.

The CEPD made public the development plan on Monday after coming under pressure from the Legislative Yuan, which has pushed for the legalization of casinos in offshore areas. Residents of the offshore islands had also lobbied for the establishment of such business to help generate income in the relatively backward areas.

The draft, which may lead to the birth of legalized casinos in the Taiwan area after years of debate in the Legislature and the private sector, considers the casino business a legitimate industry, rather than an umbrella for gambling operations.
The CEPD plan suggested that an "offshore development fund" be established before any casinos open for business.

As residents in the offshore islands, including Penghu, Kinmen and Green Island, have long complained of primitive and neglected economic conditions in their hometowns, the council decided to give them the "beef," CEPD officials said.

That includes establishment of the development fund, to be co-financed by the central and local governments, which will enable infrastructural projects in the offshore areas to kick off with less difficulty.
The draft also proposed that the offshore development plan be included in the central government's annual budget screening list, entitling it to regular governmental funding.

In addition, the draft proposed that the government liberalize land use restrictions in the offshore areas to speed up development. Economic and cultural development in the islands should also be enhanced simultaneously so as to increase the appeal of those areas, the draft indicated.

The draft, however, left many key questions undecided, including whether Kinmen, the frontline outpost near mainland China's Fujian Province, Penghu, an archipelago in the Taiwan Strait, or Green Island, an islet lying in the Pacific Ocean off Taiwan's southeast coast, should be the first or perhaps the only location for development of the casino industry.
The draft also did not indicate whether the entire territory or only designated areas of the island or islands chosen for casino development should be zoned for the money-making enterprises.

The question of which government agency should be in charge of the casinos is yet another issue to be addressed. According to CEPD officials, the Tourism Bureau does not support the idea of making casinos a part of the tourism industry. And the bureau is reportedly reluctant to assume responsibility for supervising the risky business.
The CEPD, meanwhile, believes the Interior Ministry should be the responsible agency for the casinos, since the operations involve land use and public order issues.
Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, who took office only a week ago, said on Monday that he personally opposes the offshore island casino proposal.

Huang said the establishment of casinos in offshore areas goes counter to the principles of the Ministry of Interior, which is authorized to maintain the country's public order. He claimed that the casino industry is a collective name for money laundering, gangland fighting, organized crime and smuggling.
