DOC.HEADLINE: JOHN CHANG WINDS UP US TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 9 (CNA) (By Ranan Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: John Chang, visiting secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Sunday urged overseas Chinese to rally behind the government in working for the future development of Taiwan.

Speaking to members of the overseas Chinese community in New York, Chang said the ROC, under the leadership of President Lee Teng-hui, has steadily moved forward in the face of adversity and tremendous pressure from mainland China.
He expressed hope for continued support from overseas Chinese and asked them to exert their influence in compelling mainland China to handle cross-strait relations in a more pragmatic manner.
He said that cross-strait issues require wisdom form both sides of the Taiwan Strait, adding that mainland China should not impose the Hong Kong formula or any other political model upon Taiwan.
Instead, he urged the resumption of the disrupted cross-strait dialogue on a rational basis in order to foster mutual trust in anticipation of further negotiation and cooperation.

He also stressed that President Lee's "no haste, be patient" policy does not seek to disrupt trade exchanges between the two sides. Rather, he said, it attempts to regulate Taiwan investments in large-scale and infrastructural projects on the mainland in order to protect the stability and security of the island.
Chang, who led a delegation to attend a national prayer breakfast at the White House Tuesday, concluded his trip to the United States to return home Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO VISIT FOUR AFRICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is planning to make state visits to four of the Republic of China's allies in western Africa this spring, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Monday.

Based on considerations of climate and flight security, the sources disclosed, President Lee is likely to visit Senegal and three other ROC allies in western Africa between late March and early April on a tour lasting no longer than two weeks.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who returned from Africa last week, however, declined to confirm the precise itinerary of Lee's proposed African tour. He said details of the trip would be worked out after his Feb. 14-22 visit to Africa, the third of its kind in recent months.

Citing the government's new diplomatic action plan under which "everybody mobilizes to go abroad," Hu said overseas visits by ranking officials, including the president, vice president and premier, are clearly beneficial to bolstering ties with the ROC's allies.
The number of nations maintaining relations with the ROC was recently reduced to 28 after South Africa and the Central African Republic switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST SINGAPOREANS CAN SURVIVE THREE MONTHS WITHOUT WORK

TEXT.P: Three months -- this is all the time that most Singaporeans can afford to go without work.
An international survey found that 62 percent of working Singaporeans polled have enough savings to tide them over for less than three months without work, The Straits Times reported Monday.
Another 20 percent believe that they can remain unemployed for three to six months.

The poll, conducted by Gallup International and Joshua Research Consultants, also found that only 6 percent of Singaporeans could get by without employment for more than two years. The rest said they could do without their jobs for seven months to two years.
Over four in 10 expected unemployment to rise this year, while 29 percent thought that the number of workers without jobs would remain the same. The rest thought it would fall.

Three-quarters thought their present jobs were safe, while 18 percent feared that they might be out of work this year. Among the 18 percent who thought that there might be chances of unemployment, the most pessimistic were those in their 50s or those who worked in blue-collar jobs and had little formal education.
Significantly, the report said, it was the blue-collar workers and the less-educated who were the ones least able to miss work for more than three months.
As for personal savings, nearly three-quarters said they were able to save, besides contributing to the Central Provident Fund. Those who could not save were mainly blue-collar workers.
Singaporeans also appear to be satisfied workers, with 82 percent expressing happiness with their jobs, according to the survey.
Even if they were not, they were generally cautious about making their next move -- half of them said they would secure a new job before leaving the present one.

As for loyalty, three in five believe in being loyal to the firm and would stay with it for at least five years. Not surprisingly, those holding a different opinion were mainly the younger generation, or employees in sales and service-related jobs.

The findings were among those in the survey which showed that Singaporeans were expecting hard times ahead, with 35 percent saying this year would be worse than the last, and 43 percent expecting economic difficulties in the months ahead, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICE PROTEST ENDS IN VANDALISM

TEXT.P: A protest against the rising prices of basic commodities was held in Ende on Sunday, but ended in vandalism, Regent Frans Gedowolo said.

The incident, which is the latest in a spate of food riots that have taken place in several Indonesian cities over the past few weeks, resulted in damage to at least 16 shops, two cars and two motorcycles. Some of the properties were set on fire, while others were pelted with stones.
"The disturbance was purely because of the rising prices of basic commodities," the Jakarta Post quoted Gedowolo as saying Sunday night.
Gedowolo denied rumors that one man was stoned to death during the disturbance. "It was just a coincidence. A man, a local, not a Chinese, died near where the disturbance broke out," he said.
He gave no other details.
Resident sources said the disturbance broke out at about midday. The demonstration involved about 200 people and started on Saturday. There was not yet any information as to why it turned violent.
No arrests were reported. Local police and military authorities could not be reached for comment.
"The police chief is out in the field monitoring the situation," a police officer at the Ende police precinct said when contacted from Jakarta on Sunday night.
The disturbance in Ende happened a day after similar unrest broke out Saturday in the Bima regency in the neighboring West Nusa Tenggara province.
Three shops were set ablaze and seven others damaged during unrest following a demonstration against price hikes that turned violent.
"It's returned to normal here now," an on-duty military officer told the Post Sunday night, adding, however, that shops remained closed.
He said "hundreds" of soldiers and police were still "on red alert," guarding the town against more unrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA ALLOCATES 260 BILLION RUPIAH FOR DROUGHT VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The National Development Agency in fiscal 1997/1998 allocated 260 billion rupiah to help alleviate the financial burden of drought victims in the eastern Indonesian province of Irian Jaya, an official said.

Robinson Sihite, head of the Agriculture Ministry's Provincial Office in Irian Jaya, was quoted by Antara news agency as saying in Jayapura on Sunday that the fund was part of the crash program for the development of the agricultural sector from December 1997 to March 1998.

He said 2.08 billion rupiah of the fund had been allocated for the agricultural sector in the districts of Jayawijaya, Puncak Jaya and Merauke, which suffered from the drought that began in the middle of 1997.

The fund had been earmarked for the purchase of corn seed, soybean and agricultural equipment so that the residents in the three districts would not face a shortage of foodstuffs in the dry season, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SET TO SUPPORT US-LED STRIKE AGAINST IRAQ

TEXT.P: Australia is set to support a US-led military strike against Iraq in response to an appeal by President Bill Clinton as it did during the Gulf War against Saddam Hussein in 1991, government sources said Monday.
They said Clinton has made a request to Prime Minister John Howard for support if and when the United States decides to strike against Baghdad.

Howard said he and Clinton agreed in their telephone conversation last Saturday that the "first priority" was to find a diplomatic solution to the building crisis over the enforcement of United Nations efforts to locate and destroy weapons of mass destruction inside Iraq.
The Australian federal cabinet will hold a meeting Tuesday to finalize its decision on how to support Washington. The options of support include the use of air and maritime forces.

The cabinet is expected to declare that Australia fully commits itself to support any United States attack and to state that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein cannot be allowed to retain and possibly use chemical or biological weapons.
"The proliferation of weapons of mass destruction is an important national security issue, not only for Australia, but also for other nations," Howard told reporters in Sydney on Sunday.
During the 1991 Gulf War, Australia sent two warships to the Middle East in support of the US-led war against Iraq in addition to allowing Washington to use its military facilities.

Among the capabilities certain to have been canvassed by Australian military planners are the use of the Royal Australian Air Force's F-111 aircraft and the deployment of ships to the Gulf in support of the US carrier group already stationed there.

The joint Australia-US intelligence and communications facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar in central Australia are expected to play a significant role in any renewed conflict between the United States and Iraq as in 1991.

Members of the Australian National Security Committee were briefed on Friday by Defense Force Chief Gen. John Baker and Hugh White, deputy secretary for strategy and intelligence of the Defense Department.
Ministers and defense officials here are meeting Monday to discuss preparations of military units for the possibility of rapid deployment to the Gulf, sources said.
Australian Defense Minister Ian McLachlan on Sunday night said Australia was considering both military and nonmilitary options for supporting the United States.
So far, Washington has received support from Britain and Germany in its plans to strike against Iraq. But France, mainland China and Russia have opposed a military strike.
Australia's opposition leader Kim Beazley said, "I think it is very important that there is bipartisan support ... the resolution of the weapons of mass destruction issue is critical."
Senior Australian officials told reporters that they expect the threatened US attack could take place within a week to 14 days if last-minute diplomatic initiatives fail.
They expect a fierce and sustained air attack lasting several days but no commitment of ground forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ACCUSES ROC OF EXPLOITING ECONOMIC CRISIS IN SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: Beijing has accused the Republic of China on Taiwan of exploiting Asia's financial crisis to win diplomatic prestige through high-level exchanges with regional governments that are seeking financial aid to restore their own economic stability.

In a dispatch from Beijing on Monday, mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald reported that most regional governments usually avoid high-level contact with Taiwan to placate mainland China. But the financial crisis has emboldened top officials from Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore to hold regular talks with senior ROC counterparts.
The daily reported Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is to visit Taipei and meet Premier Vincent Siew and other senior officials this week during a two-day visit.
Siew made surprise visits to the Philippines and Indonesia last month where he was reported to have met top government leaders, including Indonesian President Suharto.
Taiwan's Vice President Lien Chan also visited Singapore last month, where he met Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew.
Goh and Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir met Siew on their way home from an APEC leaders meeting in Vancouver last November.
The daily reported that mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang has accused Taipei of making diplomatic capital from the Asian financial crisis.
But Beijing has so far refrained from attacking Southeast Asian governments for seeking advice and assistance from Taiwan as they grapple with the economic meltdown.

The daily quoted diplomatic analysts as saying that Beijing has little choice but to accept Taiwan's enhanced stature and its offers of help while the regional economic instability poses a threat to the Chinese mainland economy. They also believe Taipei has so far delivered little tangible help to regional governments in Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARENTS OF WANG BINGZHANG URGE BEIJING NOT TO HARM SON
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 9 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The parents of longtime dissident Wang Bingzhang on Monday wrote to mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, urging the Beijing authorities not to harm their son.
It was reported that the fugitive dissident was arrested last Friday in the city of Bengbu, Anhui Province, by local security police.

Lu Siqing, who runs a dissident monitoring group in Hong Kong, told a CNA correspondent that Wang's parents, currently residing in Canada, wrote to Jiang on Monday morning (Hong Kong time), calling for Beijing not to injure their son.
"We are about eighty years of age now. We wish that our son is safe and well, and that we can have a happy family reunion," Wang's parents, Wang Chunshun and Wang Gueifang, said in the letter.
They don't have any knowledge about the reasons for their son's arrest, said Lu, adding that it is not necessary for the Beijing authorities to provide an excuse for detaining a dissident.

Wang Youtsai and Cheng Fan, two dissidents now living in the Chinese mainland, also made a statement early Monday through the Hong Kong-based monitoring group, calling on Beijing to release Wang immediately and to allow exiled mainland dissidents to return to their own country.

Wang Youtsai, one of the 21 student leaders of the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy demonstrations, was sentenced to four years in prison for his role in the protests. He is currently working in the city of Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province.
Cheng Fan, who was a local student leader in Zhejiang Province during the 1989 protests, is currently working in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CONTAINMENT PRESSURE 'UNIMAGINABLY FORMIDABLE' SAYS HU

TEXT.P: Beijing's attempts to repress Taiwan's activities in the international community have created a degree of pressure that is beyond imagination, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said Monday.

Citing Africa as an example, Hu, who returned last week from his second visit in four months to that continent, said Beijing has considerably stepped up its activities there, including the recent establishment of 10 commercial promotion centers, in an apparent attempt to lure away the Republic of China's diplomatic allies.

Under Beijing's containment pressure, which is strategically fueled by a new economic foray, including the creation of the trade promotion centers and the formation of an African economic guidance task force, Taipei's diplomatic policy toward Africa is now at a critical juncture, Hu pointed out.

To ensure sufficient room for the ROC's national survival and sustainable development, Taipei will not consider suspending or cutting back its promotion of pragmatic diplomacy, Hu said, adding that consolidating friendship with allies will remain the government's "top task."
Hu said he does not believe that mainland China's disposition toward Taiwan will improve even if Taipei should agree to abandon its pragmatic diplomacy in a bid to appease Beijing.
The ROC foreign minister told Beijing authorities to abandon any notion that they can press Taiwan back to the negotiating table simply by stamping out international recognition of the ROC.
Beijing's effort to contain and isolate Taiwan in the international community will only backfire and can make no contribution to positive interaction across the Taiwan Strait, Hu stressed.

Meanwhile, Hu expressed hope that the ROC diplomatic corps in Africa will be staffed by more personnel with economic or financial backgrounds so as to upgrade the nation's embassies from "windows of friendship" to "windows of development." The ROC currently has embassies in nine of the 54 African nations.

Hu is scheduled to visit Africa again on Feb. 14-22 for his third trip there in four months, to further consolidate ties with allied nations and to clear the way for President Lee Teng-hui's planned trip to western Africa between late March and early April.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL TALKS ABOUT COMMUNISM

TEXT.P: An official of the Republic of China said here Saturday that communism has been failing in various parts of the world, and that only after communism is abandoned by Beijing can cross-strait talks on national unification begin.

Speaking at a symposium on the political situation on Taiwan, Stephen S. F. Chen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, said it would be illogical for Beijing to continue to cling to communism.
He said it would greatly disappoint the Chinese people in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macao if Taiwan agreed to unite with mainland China under communist rule.

Taiwan has been a beacon of hope to those Chinese people because of its success in democratization. If the "beacon effect" disappeared, Beijing would easily reneg1 on its promise to the people in Hong Kong and Macao, he added.

Nataleh Bellocchi, former board chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, said at the symposium sponsored by Friends of President Lee Teng-hui in Washington that Taiwan's achievement in democratization is the real foundation of American support. Taiwan's success in democratization is instrumental in the improvement of relations between the two countries, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DECLINES COMMENT ON US SALE OF AIR TRAINING EQUIPMENT TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) of the Republic of China on Sunday declined to comment on a newspaper report that a planned US sale of air force equipment to Beijing will alter the balance of air power over the Taiwan Strait, saying only that it is aware of the news and will continue to monitor mainland Chinese troop movements on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

The United Daily News, citing sources within the ROC Air Force, reported recently that the US is proceeding with the sale of the advanced air combat mock instrument (ACMI) system to Beijing, which the newspaper predicted will enhance the combat capability of mainland China's pilots.
The ACMI uses a remote computer system to process data received during battle training simulations and is far more advanced than any training device previously used by mainland China.

However, an ROC Air Force officer said it remains to be seen whether Washington's ACMI sale will help boost the capabilities of the mainland's air force, as the bulk of its current air fleet, Su-27s and Su-31s, are all Russian-made.

Relevant sources indicated that the mainland also uses locally made airplanes modeled after the Kfir fighter planes jointly developed by Israel and the US in the engine, control and operating systems, and pointed out that the planned ACMI sale will largely upgrade the training capabilities of the mainland's air force once its home-built airplanes begin mass production and become the backbone of its future air fleet.
According to the sources, such a scenario will indeed have a negative effect on Taiwan's air superiority over the Taiwan Strait.

An official with the MND expressed confidence that the ROC Air Force will continue to maintain its superiority over the strait with the deployment of its second-generation indigenous defense fighters and its 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5s and 150 US-made F-16s. He added that the air force is also seeking to strengthen the training and combat skills of its pilots and further develop the capabilities of its combat planes.

Although the mainland air force has also acquired high-end combat airplanes and has the advantage in terms of numbers, the official said, the quality of Taiwan's pilots far surpasses those of mainland China.
But he admitted that the ACMI sale is still worth noting and added that the MND is closely watching subsequent developments.

Meanwhile, Hau Pei-tsun, who formerly served as ROC national defense minister and chief of the general staff of the ROC Army, said that the ACMI sale will undoubtedly have a negative impact on Taiwan, but that cross-strait disputes should be addressed through political rather than military means.

The major purpose of recent visits by mainland China's military chief Chi Haotian to several foreign countries is aimed at blocking Taiwan in the international community, Hau pointed out, adding that Taiwan and the mainland should reopen negotiations as soon as possible to replace military confrontation as a way of mending their differences.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OUTPOSTS IN MIDEAST READY FOR IRAQI CRISIS

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Monday that outposts of the Republic of China in the Middle East are all on alert and have made full arrangements for any emergency situation which may arise should tensions further escalate in the region.
Hu made the remarks at a news conference at the Government Information Office in response to questions from reporters about the current crisis between the United States and Iraq.

The foreign minister said his ministry has had an emergency plan worked out since the crisis blew up in November and that all its missions stationed in the region will do their best to protect ROC nationals residing there.

Meanwhile, 16 workers with ROC agricultural missions in the Central African Republic left the country safely on Sunday night, while another four diplomatic personnel, including ambassador Liu Hsiang-pu, will leave within the next two weeks.

The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided to cut all cooperative ties with the Central African Republic following Bangui's announcement late last month that it will shift diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, up NT$0.122 from the previous trading day of Saturday to close at NT$32.968.
The greenback opened at 32.94, and was traded between 33.14 and 32.9.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$336 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved down 0.6 percent on the Taiwan stock market on Monday, a result of profit-taking on high-tech shares.
Investors adjusted their stockholdings in the wake of last week's heavy market trading, analysts said, noting that the adjustment of technology stocks reflected strong plastic and chemical issues.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index dropped 48.85 points from the day's opening at 8,778.98 to close at 8,634.61, the day's low.
Gainers outnumbered losers 262 to 165, with 54 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 3.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$224.62 billion (US$6.84 billion), up from the 2.75 billion issues valued at NT$186.97 of the previous session.

Paper and pulp stocks posted the largest gain at 4 percent, followed by rises of 3.4 percent for foodstuff issues, 2.3 percent for plastic and chemical stocks, 0.7 percent for textile shares, and 0.5 percent for cement issues.
Electrical engineering shares dipped 2.5 percent, financial stocks lost 0.5 percent, and construction issues registered a slight 0.1 percent drop.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics; ACER; Taiwan Semiconductor; Macronix International; First Bank; Winbond Electronics; Chuntex Electronic; Pacific Electric Wire; Chang Hwa Bank; and First International Computer.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTS OF MOEA CHIEF'S VISIT TO SOUTH KOREA DENIED

TEXT.P: A high-ranking economic official denied on Monday that Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang will lead a delegation on a visit to South Korea.
Yiin Chii-ming, vice economic affairs minister, said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has "no plans" for such a visit.
Yiin was responding to a local news report which said the MOEA is planning to lead a delegation to Seoul to reopen long-stalled trade talks with South Korea.

The report in the China Times said that if Wang's trip goes ahead, it will be the first ministerial-level exchange between Seoul and Taipei since the two countries severed ties after South Korea switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in August 1992.

The report also said that the delegation was hoping to wait until the inauguration of President-elect Kim Dae Jung and the swearing in of the new South Korean Cabinet in March before making the trip, adding that the most likely time for the visit will be late April or early May.
Yiin denied the reports, saying that there is "no such plan or idea at the present stage."
He added that the resumption of high-level exchanges "will involve a lot of issues," but would not elaborate on what these issues were.
South Korea sent a delegation to Taiwan in mid-January which communicated with Taipei on the technical aspects of issues such as the resumption of air links and reciprocal barter trade in fruit.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH COMPANY BEGINS DEMINING CONTRACT IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: A British demining company on Monday began preparatory work on the island of Kinmen, formally kicking off a project to clear landmines from the Republic of China's frontline outpost off the coast of mainland China, which has been plagued by the danger posed by landmines for over four decades.
Eight demining experts of Specialist Gurkha Services UK Ltd., headed by Mark Ranson, director of the operation, began preliminary security work around the No. 6 minefield in Kinmen's Hsipu Village.

The No. 6 minefield, located in front of the General Li Kuang-chien Temple, is the major site among nine locations listed by the Kinmen Command where demining work is to be conducted over the next two years.
The British company won the bid to clear the No. 6 minefield, and is scheduled to complete demining in the area before May 20 this year.

Gurkha Services UK Ltd. is staffed mainly by retired Nepalese veterans from Britain's famous Gurkha Regiment. The company has undertaken demining jobs in more than 10 nations around the world, including Afghanistan, Cambodia, Kuwait and Mozambique.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMISTS NOT IN FAVOR OF USING S$ AS ASEAN PEG

TEXT.P: While economists say the Singapore dollar has all the attributes of an international currency, they have given the thumbs down to a Malaysian proposal to use it as peg for trade among ASEAN countries.

There would be spin-offs for the further development of Singapore as a financial center, but it is not feasible, as the economy is neither large nor strong enough, said economists polled by The Straits Times.
The economists said the Japanese yen would be a better alternative as a peg to reduce the volatility of ASEAN currencies, the report said.

Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad suggested last Friday that ASEAN should consider using the Singapore dollar as a common trading currency. This followed earlier suggestions by him that ASEAN currencies be used for intraregional trade to offset regional dependencies on the US dollar.
All the economists polled agreed that the Singapore dollar has strength, stability and familiarity, the report said.

But "if the Singapore dollar is to be used as a regional trading currency, then its strength will not only depend on the strength of the Singapore economy, but also on the strengths of the regional economies," Goh Mou Lih, a strategist at the Daiwa Institute of Research, was quoted as saying.

Another economist said that it may not be appropriate unless Singapore's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is larger than the rest of ASEAN. "This is necessary to provide a buffer against regional developments," he added.
According to the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 1997, Singapore's GDP was US$93 billion in 1996 -- behind those of Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia.

On a proposal that ASEAN countries should trade using their respective currencies, one economist said a better solution would be for ASEAN currencies to be pegged to "a basket of currencies with heavier yen weighting."
Other economists said that in view of the Japanese government's intention to promote the internationalization of the yen, this might be a more feasible solution, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA SEEN AS IMPORTANT BASE FOR TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Malaysia has become an important base for Taiwan investors because of its good investment climates, Tso Chi-kuo, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the country, said here Monday.

Speaking at a lunar Chinese new-year gathering, Tso quoted chairman Chiang Pin-kung of the Council for Economic Planning and Development of the Executive Yuan as saying during his visit here last month that Malaysia is one of the best places for Taiwan businessmen to make investment.

Tso also quoted President Lee Teng-hui as saying to Taiwan business leaders in December that the government's "Going South" policy can bring about a "win-win situation" for Taiwan investors in Malaysia and other countries in Southeast Asia.
There is amply room for the two countries to step up cooperation because Malaysia's labor-intensive industries are transforming into technology- and capital-intensive industries, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO DEBATE RELATIONS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a conference Friday to debate Taiwan's future relations with mainland China.

The "China Policy Conference" has attracted the attention of some foreign countries. The American Institute in Taiwan, the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei, the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, and the news media and political figures of some other countries have shown interest in observing the meeting.

Shi Hwei-yow, secretary general of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), will also attend the meeting. The SEF is an unofficial intermediary organization established in 1991 to handle the issues relating to the civilian exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China.
The agenda of the meeting includes three sessions for debates on the new world order, the strategy for cross-strait talks, and the cross-strait economic and trade relations.
Shih Ming-teh, former DPP chairman; Lin Yi-hsiung, chief advisor to the party; and Yu Shyi-kun, former magistrate of Ilan County will serve as moderators of the three debate sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM TO OPEN BRANCH OFFICE IN BANGKOK

TEXT.P: The state-run Chunghwa Telecom Co. will formally open its fourth overseas branch on Tuesday in Bangkok, Thailand, hoping to establish close links with the telecommunications business in Southeast Asia.

According to a Chunghwa Telecom news release, representatives from the Thai telecommunications and information business circle, foreign telecoms carriers and ROC agencies in Bangkok will attend the opening ceremony.

Chunghwa Telecom, established to promote the modernization of Taiwan's communication network and the liberalization of the island's telecom business, currently provides local, long distance, international, mobile, pager, data and satellite telecommunications services to its some 14 million subscribers.

The company gained revenue of US$5.96 billion in fiscal year 1997, according to the press release, which also revealed that the local telecom giant aspires to build Taiwan into a hub for telecommunications traffic operations in the Asia-Pacific region and plans to further explore overseas telecom markets.

Chunghwa Telecom already has branch offices in Washington, Tokyo and Hong Kong. The inauguration of the office in Bangkok is expected to help the company open Southeast Asian telecommunications markets and win business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS FROM XINJIANG DEMONSTRATE AGAINST BEIJING IN ISTANBUL

TEXT.P: Some 100 dissidents from Xinjiang were intercepted by police Monday on their way to the Consulate General of mainland China in Istanbul, where they wanted to stage a demonstration.

A spokesman for the "East Turkistan National Center" in Istanbul said about 50 of them were detained briefly by police. Only a few of the dissidents successfully made their way to the consulate for demonstration.

The spokesman said that the demonstration was held in commemoration of the conflict between mainland Chinese and Uighurs in February, 1997 at Yining, Xinjiang. Many Uighur separatists have been arrested and killed for their connection with the conflict.

Another spokesman for the center said representatives of 18 groups of dissidents from Xinjiang planned to attend a rally in Istanbul Sunday in commemoration of the independence of East Turkistan and in protest again mainland Chinese atrocity in Xinjiang, but the rally was banned by police beforehand. The rally was also intended to mark the first anniversary of the 1997 conflict in Yining.

The spokesman said Turkish government officials have told leaders of dissidents from Xinjiang not to hold any demonstration against mainland China, because Turkish Foreign Minister Ismail Cem is scheduled to visit Beijing next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILD WORKERS ARE RISING: ILO

TEXT.P: The world has a quarter of a billion child workers and their numbers are set to rise, the Geneva-based International Labor Office (ILO) said Monday.

The problem is particularly severe in Africa, where the ILO says the number of child laborers could increase by a quarter to 100 million by 2015. The ILO report revealed that previous research based on household surveys underestimated the number of child workers.

At least 120 million young people worldwide aged between five and 14 work full-time, the report said, also noting that another 130 million children do significant amounts of work in addition to going to school.

The ILO estimates that 41.4 percent of African children aged between five and 14 are economically active, compared with 21.1 percent in Asia, 16.5 percent in Latin America and the Caribbean and 10.4 percent in the Pacific region.
Poverty is the primary reason African children work, the report said. Children typically contribute between 20 and 25 percent of the family income, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AMCHAM URGES EARLY CONCLUSION OF ROC-US WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei has called for the bilateral negotiations between the Republic of China and the United States on Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) to be completed soon.

In a letter to US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky that was released at a press conference here Monday, Taipei AmCham President Jeffrey Williams asserted, "We believe that now could be an ideal time to close the bilateral phase of the ROC's WTO negotiations."
Williams praised Taiwan's dramatic improvements in opening market access to foreigners in many industries and many other positive changes in the island's investment climate.

The completion of Taipei's bilateral talks with Washington about Taiwan's entry into the WTO, the latest round of which is scheduled to open in Washington on Monday, would bring the ROC one step closer to gaining full entry into the world trade body.

Reports that the authorities would agree to open Taiwan's markets to US pork while shutting out US rice or poultry have outraged local pig farmers, who have threatened to launch a protest rally of 10,000 people in front of the presidential office on Wednesday.

Trade and agricultural officials denied the reports. Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming and Animal Industry Director under the Council of Agriculture Chen Pao-chi said on separate occasions on Monday that government negotiators will not protect any particular industry at the expense of others.
In response to reporters' questions, Williams said that agriculture is a politically sensitive sector for both Taiwan and the United States.

Although the Taipei AmCham consists predominantly of businessmen involved in banking and financial industries, Williams added his organization's voice to the agricultural dispute by calling for the matter to be solved through mutual concessions.

In a veiled rejection of Beijing's demand that Taiwan be granted entry to the WTO only after Beijing becomes a full member, Williams said at the press conference that the WTO applications of Taiwan and mainland China should be considered separately on their own merits rather than have Taipei's accession linked to that of Beijing.

"We hope that the remaining issues, including agricultural issues, can be resolved in this round of negotiations so that both Taiwan and US business can begin to enjoy the benefits of Taiwan's WTO membership as soon as possible," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOLE VISITS FINANCE MINISTER IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Former US Senate Republican leader Bob Dole called on Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu here on Monday to exchange views on the current Asian financial crisis.

Dole, who retired from politics after losing his third presidential bid in 1996, in January accepted an offer from the Republic of China's representative office in the United States to be a "foreign agent" for Taiwan.
The well-known political figure was a strong supporter of Taiwan during his nearly forty years in the US Congress. This is his first visit to the island since becoming an advisor to Taipei.

During the meeting, Dole expressed great interest in Taiwan's escape from most of the financial storm that has attacked the region and undermined the economic development of other Asian emerging economies.

Chiu told his visitor that Taiwan was able to pass through the destructive financial assault relatively unscathed because of sound monetary fundamentals, relevant governmental agencies' perfect coordination in dealing with the regional crisis and the government's policy to encourage the development of Taiwan's information industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: GOV'T TO FIGHT FOR ALL INDUSTRIES EQUALLY IN NEGOTIATIONS

TEXT.P: Denying that the government will open Taiwan to US pork in exchange for Washington dropping its push to pry open the island's rice market, Premier Vincent Siew emphasized on Monday that the government's policy is to protect all agricultural sectors equally.

Taiwan and the United States are scheduled to begin another round of bilateral negotiations this week on Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO). The import of US agricultural products into Taiwan is expected to be an especially difficult issue in the talks.

It has been widely reported that the authorities here, in order to win Washington's endorsement for Taiwan's WTO bid, are ready to bow to US pressure and open the island's markets to US pork in exchange for being able to continue excluding US rice or poultry.

The reports have set off panic among local pig farmers, who are still reeling from a foot-and-mouth disease epidemic early last year that wrought havoc on the local pig population and wiped out the island's US$1.5 billion pork exports industry.
The pig farmers have called for a protest against the alleged trade-off in front of the presidential office on Wednesday, saying they would rally 10,000 people.

Siew called the reports that the government will abandon the hog ranchers "absolutely groundless," telling reporters Monday afternoon that he has been briefed on the Taiwan negotiators' bottom line and that no industry will be sacrificed in the bilateral negotiations.

He refused to elaborate on what Taiwan would be willing to give up in the negotiations, saying it would be inappropriate to discuss this before the talks. He added, however, that the negotiating team will seek to gain as much as possible for Taiwan's public.

Lee Jen-chyuan, vice chairman of the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said on a separate occasion Monday that the government would never sacrifice any particular industry -- be it rice production, pig farming or poultry -- for the sake of concluding the WTO bilateral negotiations.

Vowing he would risk the breakdown of the negotiations rather than abandon local industries, Lee urged the farmers to swing behind the government's line in the negotiations and to refrain from any dramatic protest that might cause Washington to miscalculate Taipei's intentions and thus to affect the forthcoming talks negatively.
Meanwhile, a group of swine farmers met in Chiayi, central Taiwan, on Monday and decided to go ahead with the protest in Taipei despite government leaders' frantic efforts to head it off.

Protest organizers have said more than 10,000 pig farmers from around the island will rally in Taipei and march on the presidential office, the headquarters of the ruling Kuomintang and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The protesters will demand that the government not give in to Washington's pressure and will call for their industry to receive an adjustment period of at least six years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL RETURNS FROM US TRIP

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said on Tuesday that the KMT will study the possibility of holding intraparty preliminary elections in order to field a competent candidate to contest the year-end elections for the mayorship of Taipei and Kaohsiung cities.

Chang made the remarks at a news conference following his return from a weeklong visit to the United States, where he attended the White House's annual prayer breakfast in Washington D.C. on Thursday and met with US academics and representatives of Chinese communities in New York and Boston.

Regarding comments made by incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to local newspapers on Monday that he may not take part in the next race, the KMT secretary-general said he will assess and gain a more thorough understanding of Chen's remarks.
When asked whether he will visit Moscow in March as reported in the local media, Chang was reluctant to elaborate, saying only that the matter needs further arrangements.
"Not only does the ROC government need to reach out, the KMT also should speed up their pace in globalization," he added.
Local newspapers have reported that Chang, in conjunction with China Airlines' planned inauguration of its Taipei-Moscow route, is scheduled to visit Moscow in late March.
Meanwhile, Chang will depart for South Korea on Wednesday in an effort to seek a breakthrough in bilateral relations.
