DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CONCERNED ABOUT SAFETY OF ETHNIC CHINESE IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is concerned about the safety of ethnic Chinese in Indonesia after reports that rioters in a provincial town had attached them, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday.

Hu was responding to reports that rioters on the island of Flores in eastern Indonesia had attacked stores and homes owned by ethnic Chinese for a second day in anger over rising prices. A dusk-to-dawn curfew was imposed on the town Monday, the reports added.
Ethnic Chinese make up only about 4 percent of Indonesia's 202 million population, but they dominate commerce and are often targets of discontent when prices of basic commodities rise.
Hu said that the ROC Foreign Ministry hopes the Indonesian government can control the situation and that no harm will come to ethnic Chinese living there.

He said that the ministry is very concerned over the protests and has drawn up several contingency plans. In the past week, the ministry has advised relevant government agencies to take precautionary measures, adding that the matter was not publicized so as to avoid creating panic.
Hu expressed hope that the situation will not worsen, and that no injuries will be inflicted upon members of Indonesia's ethnic Chinese community.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FEED GRAIN COUNCIL EXECUTIVE ON 3-DAY VISIT TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Mike Callahan, Asian affairs director of the US Feed Grain Council, is currently on a three-day visit to Taipei to look into a boycott of US grain products by private Taiwan importers in retaliation against Washington's pressure on Taipei to lower import tariffs on chicken meat, pork and byproducts.
A spokesman for the Taipei office of the US Feed Grain Council said Callahan hopes to learn more about the local grain importers' stance and their opinions about the issue.
Callahan arrived in Taipei on Monday and is scheduled to leave for home on Wednesday.
Taiwan has been the third largest market for US grain. It imported 6 million tons of US grain in 1997, worth more than US$650 million.
Since Feb. 4, private Taiwan importers have boycotted US grain in retaliation for Washington's pressure on Taipei to open its chicken meat, pork, rice and animal intestines markets.

Private Taiwan grain traders usually make 95 percent of their purchases from the United States. But local press reports said local grain buyers turned away from US grain last week to buy 214,000 tons of soybeans and corn from Central and South American countries and are expected to tender for a further 54,000 tons of Latin American grain this week.

Local grain buyers are concerned that Taiwan's husbandry industry, still recovering from an islandwide outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease that forced the slaughter of 4 million hogs last year, will be hurt if Taiwan opens it market to cheaper US meat products.

Alarmed over reports that Taiwan may cut a deal with the United States in the ongoing round of talks in Washington, D.C., on terms for the island to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), local feed and meat industry operators reportedly have planned a mass protest outside the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei on Wednesday.

Government negotiators have denied unsubstantiated media reports that Taiwan was prepared to make "major concessions" to the United States on farm trade issues, including market opening and tariff cuts, during the current round of WTO talks.

Nevertheless, reports from Washington said American feed grain and pork industry associations have exerted strong pressure on the US government to push Taiwan to lift its pork import ban and lower tariff rates on various meat products.

The reports further said that if the current working-level trade consultations fail to achieve any breakthroughs, the Clinton administration may not arrange a meeting between ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky.
According to the reports, Deputy US Trade Representative Richard Fisher may replace Barshefsky to meet with Wang if the Feb. 9-14 Taiwan-US WTO negotiations fail to resolve some differences.
Wang is scheduled to arrive in Washington next week to seek policy breakthroughs concerning bilateral WTO-related talks.

Taiwan and the United States have failed to resolve their outstanding trade differences in the 16 previous rounds of WTO talks. Wang said on Tuesday he hopes his Feb. 17-18 visit to Washington can help finalize the bilateral consultations to facilitate Taiwan's entry to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

Wang further said the ROC government will do its best to protect interests of all local farmers in negotiating for Taiwan's WTO accession. "We won't sacrifice the legitimate rights and interests of any farming sector," he said, dismissing as "unfounded" the reports that the government will protect interests of rice farmers at the expense of hog ranchers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCORD FOR JOINT US-PHILIPPINE MILITARY EXERCISES SIGNED

TEXT.P: The Philippines and the United States on Monday formally signed a visiting forces agreement (VFA) which would pave the way for the resumption of the joint military exercises in the country of Filipino and American troops.
The accord is scheduled to be signed at 5:00 p.m. at the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) by Foreign Affairs Secretary Domingo Siazon and US Ambassador to the Philippines Thomas Hubbard.
Once it is signed, the DFA will have to submit the agreement to the Senate for ratification.
The agreement establishes the manner for disposing of criminal cases against any member of the US forces as well as a procedure for resolving differences that may arise between the two sides.

The DFA maintains that the agreement pertains solely to the legal treatment of US troops temporarily visiting to the Philippines and that it does not offer access arrangements for the US armed forces or allowing the stationing of US troops in the country.

A VFA primer prepared by the DFA stated that the United States has entered into similar agreements with more than 50 countries during the last 20 years. Thus, the accord is not unique to the Philippines.

The primer added that it is a well-established international practice that a country like the Philippines visited by friendly foreign troops enters into arrangements with the sending country on the legal treatment of its troops while in the host country.

But despite these assurances, there are still some sectors, especially anti-nuclear groups, which have been voicing strong opposition to the agreement. They have expressed fear that it would mean the return of US bases in the country. The joint military exercises have been put on hold due to lack of clear guidelines since 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT SPEARHEADS ASEAN COOPERATIVE EFFORTS

TEXT.P: In a gesture of concern for a fellow member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), Philippine President Fidel Ramos on Monday conveyed to Indonesian President Suharto the readiness of the Philippines to help Indonesia surmount its economic woes.
"Please let me know if there is anything that the Philippines could offer to assist Indonesia in these difficulties," Ramos said in his letter to Suharto.
"Allow me now, your excellency, to reciprocate Indonesia's kindness," he added.

The president's letter to Suharto, dated Feb. 5, preceded his Sunday meeting with visiting Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad wherein both leaders agreed to facilitate the use of the Philippine peso and the Malaysian ringgit in bilateral trade between their two countries.

Ramos' offer to help Indonesia, and his agreement with Mahathir underscore the close friendship and the collaborative efforts among ASEAN member nations in resolving common problems besetting the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS HITS AUSSIE ECONOMY EARLIER THAN EXPECTED

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis is wreaking havoc on the Australian economy much earlier than expected with the country's job market weakening in January, according to a new survey by the Australian New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) on Tuesday.
The job advertisements plunged 6 percent in seasonally adjusted terms in January, compared to a rise of 0.1 percent in December, according to the survey.
The survey suggests the Asian crisis is already biting into Australia's economic performance, with worse to come.
But Prime Minister John Howard dismissed the slump on the job market, saying it was too early to draw such a conclusion.
However, his view was not shared by ANZ chief economist Saul Eslake, who warned that the falling figures might be an early indication of the impact of the Asian crisis on employer-hiring intentions.

Banker Trust (BT) Australia, a leading economic forecaster, also joined the ANZ and other market economists to predict that Australia's average growth this year would drop by at least one percentage point because Asian demand for Australian products would drop.
The ANZ survey shows that the number of jobs advertised in January fell by 6 percent and that New South Wales was worst hit with an 8.8 percent fall.
The fall in retail sales in December and sagging foreign tourist arrivals reflected the problems in Asia, one economist said.

Job advertisements are served as a leading indicator of the Australian economy and employment growth. Any fall in the number of ads does not augur well for the Australian government's efforts to cut jobless rate from its current 8.1 percent, economists said.

"The sharp decline in the number of job advertisements ... would be consistent with evidence already to hand of the effect of Asian crisis on the tourist industry, which is particularly labor-intensive," Eslake said.
It was also consistent with "evidence from business surveys and individual companies which suggests that firms trading with Asia have begun to experience reductions in sales and orders," he added.

"Asia will detract 1 percent from Australia's growth rate. This will push growth to 4 percent in 1998 from 5 percent (of the country's gross domestic product)," BT Australia's economist Rory Robertson said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS SAID INFECTING MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis is now infecting mainland China with warnings that its exports and foreign investment will slump, which will pressure Beijing to devalue its currency, thus deepening the regional turmoil.

In a dispatch from Beijing, mass-circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald's correspondent David Lague reported that official media and Chinese mainland leaders are acknowledging that stiff competition from exporters with sharply lower currencies, including Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea, threatens mainland China's trade as regional demand for its goods drops.

Foreign investment in the Chinese mainland is also expected to fall sharply because traditional Asian investors have suffered huge losses through the financial crisis and Western companies are worried about the higher risks of doing business in the mainland, according to the daily.

If Beijing does devalue the yuan, this might force regional economies into a new round of damaging devaluations and undermine the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the US currency, which could trigger further regional turmoil.
Mainland China's trade minister Wu Yi admitted last weekend that her country faced "stark challenges" in trade this year, mainly because of the crisis.
The daily also quoted the official China Daily as sounding an unusually frank report warning that mainland China's exports and foreign investment there were at risk.
The daily reported that the Hong Kong-based Asian Hedge Fund (AHF) made a similar warning. AHF director William Kaye said that Beijing would come under enormous pressure to devalue the yuan.
"It would in all likelihood be the catalyst for another round of competitive devaluations throughout the region that could throw the world into a 1930s-type scenario," Kaye said.

Western diplomats in Beijing believe the mainland would suffer a painful loss in prestige if it devalues the yuan in the short term because Vice Premier Zhu Rongji and other senior officials have ruled out the depreciation of their currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US SENATOR DOLE WINDS UP SHORT VISIT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former US Senator Bob Dole on Tuesday afternoon left Taipei for Seoul after concluding a short visit here, Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said.
Hu said that the 1996 Republican presidential nominee arrived in Taipei on Monday. Dole came here to better understand the effect of the Asian financial turmoil on Taiwan, he added.

According to Hu, during the short visit, Dole met with Minister of Finance Paul Chiu, Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce Chairman Jeffrey Koo and other economic experts to exchange views on the impact of the Asian financial crisis in Taiwan and other countries in the region.
Hu said he had lunch with Dole before his departure. The former US senator will stay in Seoul overnight and return to the United States on Wednesday.
This was Dole's first visit to Taiwan after he agreed earlier this year to work as an advisor to the ROC government for a period of six months.

On Jan. 6, Dole registered with the US Justice Department as a "foreign agent" for Taiwan. According to the agreement he signed with the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, Dole will be paid US$30,000 per month for his services. The two parties maintain an option to extend the contract.
Hu has said that Dole will work as an adviser to the ROC government but will not engage in any lobbying activities involving members of the US Congress or the Clinton administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR TO GO OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: In the face of Taiwan's long-expected entry into the World Trade Organization, the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation (Taisugar) is actively planning to explore new horizons overseas, a spokesman for Taisugar said on Tuesday.

Taisugar has worked out plans to relocate its hog and cattle raising, orchid growing, and sugar production operations to countries in Southeast Asia, the Americas and Australia, according to the spokesman.

In cooperation with Taiwan-based and Vietnamese food processors, Taisugar is scheduled to build a sugar mill in northern Vietnam, with an annual production of 90,000 tons, he said, adding that the state-run unit will also set up a hog-raising farm on its own in Ho Chi Minh City in southern Vietnam, annual output of which is set at 60,000 hogs.
Another joint-venture stud-hog farm will be established in the Philippines, and it will have an annual production of 6,000 stud pigs and 22,000 hogs.

He went on to say that Taisugar also has reached agreement to run a cattle ranch with a branch of the Australia-based Elders Corp. in that country, while it has purchased a 60 percent share of Australia's Euphror Group, which sells 300,000 pigs and produces 150,000 metric tons of feed each year.

In Canada, Taisugar has acquired a three-hectare lot in British Colombia for the establishment of an orchid-growing facility, while the company, in conjunction with central government policies aimed at strengthening ties with Central American countries, is also planning to set up a production center for phalaenopsis in Costa Rica, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY BEARS FRUIT: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The government's policy toward investment in mainland China is one of cautious moderation and is not intended to put cross-strait trade exchanges back on track, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yu said on Tuesday.
Chang made the remarks when he reiterated the government's "no haste, be patient" policy at a gathering of Taiwan businessmen with investments on the mainland.

He said that the policy has borne fruit, adding that although the scale of the mainland investments has been scaled back after its implementation, the number of such projects remains largely the same.

Stating that the policy does not aim to backpedal in the handling of cross-strait relations, Chang said the government has merely implemented necessary restraints on hi-tech, infrastructural and large-scale investment projects on the mainland that might affect Taiwan's financial security.
He said that the policy has not disrupted Taiwan's small and medium-sized investments in the mainland.
Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, speaking on the same occasion, urged Taiwan businessmen to support the government's policy for the dignity of the nation.
Kao also urged Taiwan businessmen to help push for the early resumption of long-stalled cross-strait talks.

A Taiwan businessman leader at the gathering said the "no haste, be patient" policy is basically sound in principle. He pointed out that Taiwan's hi-tech development, quality of personnel and capital resources are superior to those of the mainland, and said that large enterprises should keep their roots in Taiwan.

But Tsai Yu-cheng, president of a Taiwan enterprise association in Ningpo, Zhejiang province, urged the government to quicken the pace of opening direct shipping links, saying that Taiwan businessmen could save the time and money in transportation and increase their profits.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN DEPUTY PM COMING FOR PRIVATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Wednesday for a private visit.
Anwar, who concurrently serves as Malaysia's finance minister, will meet with local industry and business executives Wednesday afternoon to discuss Asia's current financial crisis.

This will be Anwar's first visit to Taiwan, which does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Malaysia. His visit comes as part of the Malaysian government's drive to seek joint means of tackling regional financial woes.

As part of such efforts, Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has already visited Singapore, the Philippines and Thailand, while his deputy, Anwar, left Kuala Lumpur on Sunday for a three-day visit to Japan.
In Tokyo, Anwar met with senior Japanese government officials, bankers, financial experts and business leaders to exchange views on regional financial and economic issues.
Anwar, an heir-apparent to Mahathir, will travel to Taipei after winding up his Japan visit on Wednesday morning.

Anwar told Malaysian media prior to his departure that his trip is not aimed at asking neighboring countries to offer special assistance to Malaysia, but rather at seeking joint efforts to resolve regionwide financial problems.

ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu would not reveal details of Anwar's itinerary here. As the visit is of a private nature, Hu said he must respect Anwar's personal wishes. "Without his consent, we can't disclose his itinerary," he added.

Meanwhile, the Legislative Yuan caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday urged Malaysia to sign an investment guarantee agreement with Taiwan to protect the rights and interests of Taiwan investors in the Southeast Asian country.

According to Malaysian tallies, Taiwan entrepreneurs had funneled more than US$8 billion into Malaysia for 1,501 investment projects as of October 1997, making Taiwan Malaysia's second largest source of foreign capital after Japan.

DPP parliamentary whip Chang Chun-hsiung said Taiwan investors face many major problems in Malaysia. For one thing, Malaysia still bans foreign banks from setting up branches on its territory. Secondly, the Malaysian government would not offer permanent residency to Taiwan investors. Moreover, public order in regions where Taiwan investors reside has continued to deteriorate.

Chang said the DPP welcomes Anwar's visit to Taipei and will be pleased to see Taiwan and Malaysia cooperate in resolving regionwide financial issues. "Nevertheless, we hope the Malaysian government will sincerely help Taiwan investors address their problems," Chang said, adding that signing a bilateral investment guarantee pact will make Anwar's Taipei visit more meaningful.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar on Tuesday lost NT$0.127 against the New Taiwan Dollar on the Taiwan foreign exchange, closing at NT$NT$32.841.
The US dollar opened at NT$32.906 and was traded between NT$32.810 and NT$32.920. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$403.5 million. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: DELEGATION OF SCHOLARS OF THREE PARTIES TO VISIT M'LAND

TEXT.P: A fact-finding delegation of Taiwan scholars is expected to visit the Chinese mainland sometime this month, remarked Lee Ching-ping, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), adding that the exact date will be determined after the new secretary-general of the SEF takes his post.

At the invitation of the All-China Taiwan Affairs Research Society, a delegation of Taiwan scholars led by Lee Ching-ping was scheduled to visit Beijing on Jan. 12. Before the group left, however, the SEF received a letter from its counterpart, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, calling for the journey to be postponed until after the Chinese Lunar New Year for the sake of the traditional holiday season.

The final itinerary of the delegation is not settled yet, Lee said Monday afternoon. He denied reports that the departure date would be Feb. 14, saying this would be impossible, adding that an appropriate time would be after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) completes its debate on its policy on mainland China in the middle of the month.

During its visit to Beijing, the delegation is expected to meet with researchers at the All-China Taiwan Affairs Research Society, Institute of Taiwan Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Beijing University of National Defense, Peace and Development Research Center and China Strategy and Administration Research Society, to discuss cross-strait relations.

The 10-member delegation from Taiwan will comprise experts and scholars from the ruling Kuomintang, the DPP and the New Party, including Lee Ching-ping as head of the delegation; Bao Chung-ho, a member of the National Unification Council and head of the Department of Political Science at National Taiwan University; Professor Chou Yu-jen of National Chunghsing University; Professor Yang Nien-tsu of National Sun Yat-Sen University; Yen Wan-chin, the SEF's supervisor and head of the China Affairs Department of the DPP; and Lin Yu-fang, New Party whip and a professor at Tamkang University.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices fell on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 66.95 points to finish at 8567.66.
The bourse opened at 8667.41 and experienced a high of 8673.35 and a low of 8546.59.
Losers outnumbered gainers 299 to 117, with 63 remaining unchanged. In all, 2.60 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$166.51 billion (US$4.90 billion).
Electrical engineering issues edged up 0.6 percent, the only category that rose, while paper and pulp stocks dropped the most at 2.7 percent.
Plastic and chemical stocks fell 2.1 percent, finance shares dropped 1.8 percent, construction issued fell 1.7 percent, textile issues fell 1.4 percent, and cement stocks edged down 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET COMMERCE EXPO '98 KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday he hopes the number of Taiwan's Internet users will increase to three million in three years.

Lee made the remarks in his keynote speech to the opening ceremony for the Internet Commerce Expo '98 sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to promote the use of Internet here and the development of related products and services.
Lee said Taiwan has emerged as the world's third largest information-technology (IT) products manaufacturing country through concerted efforts by the government and local entrepreneurs.

"Taiwan has become one of the world's most important suppliers of personal computers and peripherals," Lee said, adding that many foreign professional magazines have advised their readers to buy Taiwan-made hardware because prices for those products are highly competitive and their quality is very good.

Lee said Taiwan also plays a leading role in OEM (original equipment manufacturing) production of various IT products. Nevertheelss, Lee said, Taiwan should step up research and development in order to maintain its niche in the highly competitive world market.

The president went on to say electronics commerce has become increasingly important. "Local companies should strengthen the use of Internet to cut their operational costs and upgrade managerial efficiency. And by so doing, we can also enhance our country's overall competitiveness in the international community."

Lee said the national information infrastructure promotion task force has outlined five medium-range goals, including raising the number of Internet users around the island to three million in three years; promoting the use of Internet to elementary and junior high schools; developing Taiwan into a regional pivot of Internet use in the Asia-Pacific; establishing a global Chinese-language Internet information center; and developing various Internet-related multi-media industries.

The three-day Internet Commerce Expo '98 kicked off at the Taipei International Convention Center on Tuesday. A total of IT and Internet industry experts from the United States, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan will lecture on related topics during the three-day event. Meanwhile, 33 well-known corporations from major IT products manufacturing countries are displaying their latest products and services at the exhibition center.
James A. Johnson, a former adviser to US President Bill Clinton, delivered a speech on Internet commerce development during a plenary session on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN EXPLAINS ROC POSITION ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Executive Yuan, said Tuesday that it is one of the basic goals of Taiwan, the Republic of China, to maintain benign and mutually-beneficial relations with mainland China.

He pointed out that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now under separate rule, and that Taiwan wants to maintain such relations on the basis of mutual respect before the goal of national unification is reached.

Chang made the remarks when asked to comment on a recent proposal by Professor Kenneth Lieberthal of the University of Michigan that Taipei and Beijing sign an agreement to govern mutual relations in the next few decades. Under the agreement, both Taiwan and mainland China are part of "one China."
The proposal was discussed in a closed-door meeting attended by scholars and experts from Taiwan, mainland China, and the United States in mid-January.

When asked whether the proposal was intended to suggest that the two sides temporarily put aside their hostility to each other, Chang said he has not studied the proposal, but he said that Taiwan has had no hostility to mainland China since the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion was abrogated in 1991, although Beijing has not renounced the use of military force against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE'S GDP GROWTH FORECAST A MERE 0.8% THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Lehman Brothers, a leading US investment bank, on Monday forecast that Singapore will have economic growth of a mere 0.8 percent this year as the region slides into a recession.

Both Singapore and the Republic of China, "two countries with strong underlying economic fundamentals but heavy trade competitiveness exposure to the region" should be able to avoid a recession -- "but only just," it said.

A dramatic slowdown in domestic demand in the crisis-hit countries of Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines and South Korea will result in their economies contracting this year, and this will have a significant fallout on Singapore, the bank said.
Lehman Brothers made the forecasts in its outlook for the global economy for 1998 presented at a seminar in Singapore Monday.
Collectively, it said, the Asian economies -- excluding Japan -- "seem likely to enjoy little, if any, growth" this year.

"The rate of increase in (their collective) gross domestic product (GDP) may well slow sharply, from around 6 percent in 1997 to a mere 1/2 percent or so in 1998, before staging a limited recovery to, say, 4 percent-odd in 1999," it added.
The bank is predicting that Singapore could rebound quickly and chalk up 6.5 percent growth next year, after the worst of the crisis has blown over.
This year's outlook differs importantly between Asian countries, it pointed out.
The worst performers are expected to be South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand, where severe recessions are likely, it said.
Less-severe recessions are forecast for Malaysia and the Philippines.
Although Hong Kong might manage to expand, "if the exchange rate peg were to go -- which at present we do not expect -- an outright recession would most likely follow," the bank said.
Significantly, the Asian crisis could also cut US GDP growth by nearly half to around 2 percent, said Lehman Brothers' global chief economist, Dr. John Llewellyn, at the seminar.

Cheaper imports from the Asian countries that experienced depreciations of their currencies will widen the US trade gap this year, added Lehman Brothers' chief economist for North America, Stephen Slifer, at the seminar.

This will shave one percentage point from US economic expansion as domestic production suffers. A further one percentage point of growth could be lost as US businesses cut back on their capital spending as they may withhold expansion in view of the Asian crisis, he warned.
Overall, world economic growth will slow to about 2 percent this year, down significantly from the estimated 3.1 percent growth achieved last year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ANNOUNCES SUPPORT FOR MILITARY ACTION AGAINST IRAQ

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard, declaring that Baghdad should not be allowed to "thumb its nose at the rest of the world," announced that Australia will join an international coalition backing possible US-led military action against Iraq.

At a press conference in Canberra, Howard said: "It is our fervent desire that this matter be settled without resort to force. We will continue in cooperation with the United States and other countries to urge upon the Iraqi leadership the common sense ... that Iraq comply with the resolutions of the United Nations and allow inspection by the UNSCOM (UN Special Commission) teams of particular sites in Iraq.
"But if it does become necessary for a US-led coalition to use force, then Australia has decided that it will make a contribution to that effort," he said.

Howard continued that if Iraq is "allowed to thumb its nose at the rest of the world" by continuing to develop its capacity to deliver chemical and biological weapons, the use of force "would become regrettably necessary."
"If Iraq were allowed to go on unchecked, then, of course, other countries might be tempted to imitate what Iraq has done," he said.

He said Canberra is discussing with Washington the sort of contribution Australia would make, including up to a company from its Special Air Service regiment to support US search and rescue activities, two Boeing 707 tanker aircraft to provide air-to-air refueling and specialist personnel to provide back-up in medical and technical support, which together would involve up to between 200 and 250 people.
He said the government will also be prepared to consider providing other capabilities of a similar order in support of a US-led war against Iraq.
In 1991, Australia sent personnel and two warships to support the UN-approved attack against Iraq during the Desert Storm strike.

Earlier Tuesday, Howard announced in a statement that the Cabinet had agreed in principle to a request from the United States to participate in an international coalition should military action against Iraq become necessary.

"Our aim in doing so is to help enforce the UN Security Council's resolutions, ensure that Iraq's chemical and biological arsenals are not used or expanded, and prevent Saddam Hussein again becoming a threat to the security of the Middle East and the world," the statement said.
Howard said backing the possible use of military force against Iraq is "in the national interest of Australia."

"Australia may be beyond the reach of Iraq's missiles. But we have a direct national interest in ensuring that these weapons do not proliferate and that the mechanisms established by the international community to prevent this are as effective as possible. There can be no doubt that allowing Iraq to flout its obligations will increase the risks for the rest of the world, including Australia," the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA SUPPORTS FORCE IN IRAQ IF DIPLOMACY FAILS

TEXT.P: Canada supports the use of military force against Iraq and its leader Saddam Hussein if diplomatic efforts fail to end an impasse over United Nations weapons inspections, Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien said Monday.

"Tonight I want to lay out clearly before the people of Canada why we believe their government should support military action if he (Saddam) does not comply," Chretien said as the House of Commons began an emergency debate on Iraq.
He told the House: "This gives us no pleasure. Canada is not a nation that rushes to embrace the use of force. We do not lightly endorse military action. For us it is always the last resort."
Canada's Parliament was debating a request from the United States for Canada's help in possible strikes against Iraq, which could be just weeks away.

"Saddam has shown very clearly that he will not respect diplomatic solutions, unless of course, they are accompanied by a threat of intervention or an intervention. The least sign of weakness or hesitation on our part will be interpreted as an incitement," Chretien said.
He said Canada will lend military support to the US-led action, "not combat troops, but it will mean a Canadian presence in the action against Saddam Hussein."

The right-wing Reform Party and Conservative Party lean toward supporting the United States but have called into question Canada's military preparedness after government cutbacks to the defense budget.

As in 1991, the leftist New Democratic Party (NDP) said, Canada should be leading the search for a peaceful solution instead of joining in military action. "There's nothing to be gained in the long run through a strategy of provocation and saber rattling," said NDP leader Alexa McDonough.
Canada sent planes, warships and 2,200 soldiers during the 1991 Gulf War.

A spokesman for Chretien said Sunday that Canada might contribute transport and search-and-rescue services, but Defense Minister Art Eggleton and Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy said Monday there had been no detailed request from Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLIMMER OF HOPE IN PENG'S MURDER CASE

TEXT.P: Police are hopeful that the discovery on Sunday of the cash card belonging to the late prominent women's activist Peng Wan-ju may help them finally discover who was responsible for her rape and murder more than one year ago.

Peng's ATM card, along with a telephone card and Taipei mass transit system tickets, was found by local residents in a remote mango orchard in Hsinyuan, Pingtung County, south of Kaohsiung County. The cash card carries Peng's signature.
Peng last used the card on Nov. 30, 1996 at Sungshan Airport as she was leaving Taipei for a meeting in Kaohsiung, the police said. Her husband canceled use of the card soon after her murder.
Police are hopeful they can discover the murderer's fingerprints on the card.

Peng, 48, the director of the women's affairs department of the Democratic Progressive Party, went missing on Nov. 30, 1996, after she left the Top Plaza Hotel in Kaohsiung City. Three days later, she was found raped and murdered near a factory in Kaohsiung County. One month later, Peng's purse was discovered under a bridge in Tungkang, Pingtung.
Believing Peng had been murdered by a taxi driver, the police launched a comprehensive investigation of all taxi drivers in Kaohsiung city and county, but turned up no suspects.

Though one of the Top Plaza Hotel's security cameras recorded that Peng left in a taxi, the tape was too fuzzy for the license plate number to be made out. The tape was later sent to the United States; but even American aerospace laser technology failed to make the number clear enough to be read.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NO HASTE' STRATEGY AIMED AT URGING BEIJING TO ADJUST POLICY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that the ROC government's "no haste, be patient" strategy is aimed at pushing Beijing to review and adjust its irrational policy toward Taiwan.

Siew made the statement during a Chinese New Year cocktail reception for Taiwan entrepreneurs with investment in mainland China. The party was jointly organized by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and the private Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI).

Siew said as communist China has not renounced its attempt to use force against Taiwan, the government must continue its "no haste, be patient" policy to discourage investment across the Taiwan Strait.

"On the one hand, the policy will help reduce Taiwan companies' business risks," Siew explained, adding that the policy is also expected to press mainland authorities to modiy its irrational policy toward Taiwan so as to create a more favorable climate for development of cross-strait relations.

Siew urged local investors not to set their sights solely at the mainland market. "We should be more far-sighted and broad-minded. We should set our sights at the entire Asia-Pacific region and even the whole world."

The premier also expressed his hope that Taiwan investors, while developing their business on the mainland, can forge positive interactions with various mainland sectors and convey to mainland officials and ordinary citizens Taiwan's good will, sincerity and basic stances on developing cross-strait ties. "Your efforts in these aspects will certainly help push cross-strait relations to move in a stable, harmonious direction," he added.

Siew said Taiwan has always kept its doors open for cross-strait dialogue. "We hope mainland China will realistically face the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is now ruled by two separate governments, and will make positive response to our call for resumption of long-stalled consultations on many practical issues," the premier said, adding that continued contacts and dialogue are the best way to foster good will and mutual trust.

Siew further said the government will set up a one-stop service counter to offer more convenient information services to Taiwan companies with interests on the mainland and to assist them in overcoming various obstacles they have encountered there.
"We'll also cut red tape to allow local bsuinessmen to more easily invite relevant mainland celebrities or business leaders to visit Taiwan," the premier promised.

Speaking on the same occasion, MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh said the "no haste, be patient" policy is not intended to cause a retreat in cross-strait trade and economic exchanges. Under such a policy, the government only imposes restrictions on mainland-bound investment in high-technology industries, infrastructure construction and some massive-scale invesmtent projects that might affect domestic financial and economic development. "The policy doesn't restrict other cross-strait invesment activities and will have no impact on local small- and medium-sized enterprises," he stressed.

CNFI President Kao Ching-yuan also urged local companies with interests on the mainland to support the government's "no haste, be patient" policy aimed at upholding the Republic of China's national dignity and interests. He further advised them to pool wisdom and resources to help push for early resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, COSTA RICA TO SIGN VOCATIONAL EDUCATION ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Costa Rica are preparing to sign an agreement on vocational training cooperation.

Vice Education Minister Lee Chien-hsing, at the head of a six-member ROC educational mission, is leaving Taipei on Tuesday evening for Costa Rica, where he will sign a vocational training cooperation accord with Costa Rica on behalf of the ROC government.

Under the agreement, the ROC's Ministry of Education will dispatch professors and experts, particularly in the fields of electronics and electrical engineering, to Costa Rica over the next two years to help nurture teaching staff and develop a good training environment. Costa Rica may also send some of its citizens to Taiwan for training if necessary, according to ministry officials.

Lee's delegation will include Liu Ching-tien, president of National Taiwan University of Technology (NTUT); Professors Lin Jung-ching and Yang Chien-chiao, both of NTUT; one official from the Ministry of Education; and an official from the Council of Labor Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIMA AND ENDE CALM AS PROTEST HITS JAKARTA

TEXT.P: Riot-hit Bima and Ende in Indonesia's Nusa Tenggara were calm Tuesday as security authorities managed to bring the two towns under control, local officials said.
In Jakarta, scores of people staged a peaceful protest at Bank Indonesia and the State Logistics Agency over the soaring prices of essential commodities.

West Nusa Tenggara deputy police chief Col. Budiman Sulaeman told the Antara news agency that 15 men were arrested following Saturday's riot in Bima, where a mob burned down three stores and damaged 20 others.
Hundreds of police officers backed up by scores of soldiers were still deployed in the streets to maintain order, Budiman said.
In Ende in East Nusa Tenggara, residents of Chinese decent, whose stores and houses were targeted in Sunday's riot, have been taking refuge in local police and military stations, it said.

Monday, the security officers in Ende fired several warning shots to disperse a mob returning to the town center after East Nusa Tenggara Governor Herman Musakabe -- accompanied by provincial military chief Col. Bambang Sumardji and other officials -- visited the riot scene.
A curfew from 7 p.m. to 6 a.m. has been imposed in Ende since Sunday night.
At least 21 stores, mostly belonging to residents of Chinese descent, were set ablaze and 71 damaged in Sunday's riot in the town. All were looted, the news agency said, quoting Musakabe.
A different account, however, was given by Ende's regent, Frans Geddowolo, when contacted by the Jakarta Post from the East Nusa Tenggara town of Maumere.
He said 16 stores, two cars, and two motorcycles were torched in the unrest in downtown Ende, after a demonstration by around 200 people turned violent.
Meanwhile, a bomb hoax caused panic at Polonia airport in Medan on Monday, forcing authorities to delay several flights.
The airport chief, Col. Benyamin S. Dandel, said activities at the international airport were not seriously affected but admitted that several flights were delayed "for a little while."
Local military spokesman Lt. Col. Agus Ramadhan said Monday night that an object thought to be a bomb turned out to be only a "toy" containing no explosives.
No one claimed responsibility for the bomb scare.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S BILLIONAIRES CLIMB IN LIST OF ASIA'S RICHEST FAMILIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's billionaires have moved even higher in the list of the top 100 wealthiest families in Asia as their counterparts in the region have suffered in the Asian financial crisis, according to a new survey by Asia's Wealth Club magazine.
Geoff Hiscock, author of the report, said in the mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Tuesday that two Taiwanese tycoons made this year's list of the 10 richest families in Asia.
They are Tsai Wan-lin and his family, with their wealth at US$7.7 billion, and Wang Yung-ching and his family, worth US$4.9 billion.
Tsai is listed as No. 3 among the Top 100 Wealthiest Families in Asia, while Wang ranks ninth. Tsai was No. 5 in 1997, while Wang was No. 14, according to the Asia's Wealth Club survey.
Nine billionaires from Taiwan made the list of the 100 richest families in Asia.

In addition to Tsai and Wang, Taiwan's super rich include Wu Tung-chin and his family, No. 11 in 1998 with riches of US$4.1 billion, up from No. 14 in 1997; Hsu Yu-ziang of the Far Eastern Group at No. 37 with US$1.9 billion, up from No. 39; and Chang Yung-fa of the Evergreen Group at No. 40 with assets of US$1.7 billion, climbing from No. 48 in 1997.

Also among Taiwan's -- and Asia's richest -- people are Koo Chen-fu and his family at No. 48 with US$1.5 billion, up from No. 65; Shi Wen-long of the Chi Mei Corp. at No. 51 with US$1.4 billion (unlisted in 1997); Chen Yu-hau of the Tuntex Group at No. 63 with US$1.1 billion, up from No. 73 in 1997; and Huang Shi-hui of the Chinfon Group at No. 67 with a wealth of US$1 billion, up from No. 75 in 1997.

Topping the list of the richest people in Asia is the Sultan of Brunei and his family, with their wealth totaling US$37 billion, followed by Japan's Yoshiaki Tsutsumi and his family, worth US$9.6 billion.
Some billionaires in Hong Kong declined in rank due to falling property prices in the former British colony.
Walter, Thomas and Raymond Kwok of Hong Kong's Sun Hung Kai Properties, with their wealth of US$7 billion, are No. 4 this year, down two places from 1997.
Lee Shau-kee of Henderson Land ranks No. 5 with assets of US$6 billion, down one notch from 1997, while Li Ka-shing and his family remain unchanged in their ranking of No. 6.
The Asian billionaires hardest hit by the region's financial crisis are in Indonesia and Thailand.

Indonesian President Suharto and his family rank No. 34 in 1998, plummeting from ninth in 1997. The richest Chinese-Indonesian tycoon, Liem Sioe Liong, and his Salim Group rank No. 39 this year, compared to No. 18 in 1997.
Chatri Sophonpanich and his family of the Bangkok Bank, the largest in Thailand, suffered falling fortunes and rank No. 44 in 1998 compared to No. 30 in 1997.
Also hard hit are some billionaires in South Korea, including Lee Kun Hee of Samsung, Chung Mong-koo of Hyundai, Kim Woo-choong of Daewoo and Chey Jong-hyon of Sunkyong.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOG RAISERS TO STAGE DEMONSTRATION IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Some 300 hog raisers in Pingtung county, southern Taiwan, will go to Taipei in chartered bus Wednesday to stage demonstrations near the Presidential Office and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
A spokesman for the demonstrators said they want to urge the government not to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) at the expense of hog raisers.

Taiwan importers are boycotting American grains in retaliation for U.S. attempt to open the pork and chicken markets of Taiwan and pressure Taiwan to lower the tariffs on the two products. Negotiators of the two countries are finalizing their talks on the terms of Taiwan's admission to the WTO.
Pingtung is an agricultural county, where foot-and-mouth disease wiped out one million hogs early last year. Farmers are now raising 1.5 million hogs in the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC HEAD EXPRESSES CONCERN OVER CHINESE DISSIDENT'S ORDEAL

TEXT.P: Chiao Jen-ho, head of the Republic of China's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), on Tuesday expressed concern over US-based Chinese pro-democracy activist Wang Bingzhang's recent ordeal in mainland China.

Wang, who recently traveled to mainland China under an assumed name in an attempt to drum up support for the establishment of an opposition political party, was first arrested by mainland Chinese public security officials in Anhui province on Feb. 6 and then deported on Feb. 9 on charges of subversion.

Chiao ridiculed the mainland Chinese authorities' irrational treatment of Wang, asking why Chinese people are not allowed to show concern over human rights in mainland China while they can do so in the United States.

If Chinese people can express concern over human rights in the United States but cannot do the same in mainland China, it is obvious that mainland China must have different standards of human rights than the United States, Chiao said.

Chiao reiterated the OCAC's stance of supporting all activities that uphold democracy and human rights. He said he cannot understand what is wrong with Chinese being concerned over Chinese affairs, or what is wrong about Chinese promotion of freedom and democracy in Chinese society.

According to CNA sources in Los Angeles, Wang, founder of the pro-democracy activists magazine "China Spring," told the public security authorities who escorted him during his deportation that he will try again to sneak back to mainland China whenever he gets the chance.

Wang, 50, who is on mainland China's most-wanted list of exiled dissidents, returned covertly to mainland China in mid-January. He remained undetected for the first two weeks until Feb. 5, when one of his relatives in Nanjing was taken away for questioning by public security authorities.
Wang escaped to the central province of Anhui, where he stayed with friends before being detained on Feb. 6 and held for three days of questioning.

He was deported and flown back to Los Angeles on Feb. 9 following a relatively quick decision by the mainland authorities, a move which human rights groups said was probably made out of political consideration.
Before expelling Wang, the mainland authorities confiscated his video camera, tape recorder, camera, wallet and credit cards.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HUNGARY TO SWAP CARNET PRIVILEGES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Hungary are scheduled to kick off a bilateral carnet agreement on March 1 to allow temporary admission of professional equipment, commercial samples and advertising materials from each other's country without the levying of customs duties.

Taiwan and Hungary signed the agreement and an implementation protocol on Aug. 9, 1996, but the two sides did not complete the relevant paperwork until January this year, when both Taipei and Budapest agreed to begin the program on March 1, according to officials from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

Hungary was the first country in central or eastern Europe to sign such an agreement with Taiwan, and the BOFT officials said it will definitely benefit commercial, cultural, technological and academic exchanges between the two sides.
To date, Taiwan has signed similar bilateral pacts with Singapore, South Korea, South Africa, Switzerland, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND WON'T CONFIRM US ARMS SALES TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: Although denying any knowledge of US sales of air combat maneuvering instrumentation (ACMI) to Beijing, a spokesman for the Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday that US arms sales to Taiwan are in no way affected by Washington's engagement with Beijing and that the ROC armed forces have the will and means to protect the island.

In response to a report published in Monday's local daily United Daily News that Washington is set to sell the ACMI system to Beijing to allow mainland China's air force to upgrade its pilots' combat tactics and techniques, MND spokesman Kung Fan-ding said that thus far, the MND cannot confirm the news, let along the specifications of the ACMI system mentioned in the reports.
However, Kung said, the armed forces is pushing ahead with a program to upgrade its own ACMI system, which will be patterned upon the latest system used by the US Air Force.
He said the MND is confident that the new program, as well as the new generation jet fighters acquired by the armed forces, will ensure ROC air superiority over mainland China.

Regarding concerns raised by the newspaper that the increasing military exchanges between Beijing and Washington might lead to cuts in US arms sales to Taiwan, Kung said that Washington is sticking to its obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act to provide Taiwan with sufficient weapons for its defense, despite persistent pressure from Beijing to stop such sales.

This policy was reconfirmed in Oct. 1997 when US President Bill Clinton met Beijing's visiting leader Jiang Zemin in Washington and told him that US arms sales to Taiwan are absolutely legal and brook no foreign interference.

US Defense Secretary William Cohen reiterated this policy in January, 1998 when he told Beijing leaders at the end of a visit to mainland China that "we will keep on selling military equipment for defensive purposes to Taiwan."

Furthermore, Kung added, Washington has responded positively to repeated calls from Taiwan made at various conferences and meetings with US officials that US engagement with Beijing should not jeopardize Taiwan's interests, and that the US should live up to its obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act by continuing to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, on a related subject, Kung said the ROC Navy's plan to build its own submarines is still under careful review, adding that the navy has not given up its efforts to acquire submarines from abroad, despite Beijing's attempts to block such purchases.

Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said on Thursday that Taiwan is considering building indigenous submarines because of the vociferous objections raised by Beijing when any foreign country attempts to sell military equipment to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST WORLD INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY CONGRESS IN 2000

TEXT.P: Taiwan has won the right to sponsor the World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT) in 2000, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said on Tuesday.
The congress has been held once every two years in either Europe, America or Asia under the commission of the World Information Technology and Service Alliance (WITSA).

Previous congresses have been held mostly in European and American countries since the inaugural congress in Spain in 1978. Japan is the only Asian country to have hosted the meeting, in 1984 and 1994.
The 2000 congress will be the first time Taiwan has hosted the international event, which will be officially opened by the Republic of China's second popularly elected president.
Yiin said that he will attend this year's WCIT congress in the US state of Virginia, when he will hold a press conference to announce Taiwan's sponsorship of the 2000 event.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUINEA BISSAU PREMIER ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Guinea Bissau's Premier Carlos Augusto Correia arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a five-day official visit.
Accompanied by a 10-member entourage, Correia was greeted at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport by Foreign Minister Jason Hu and other Republic of China officials.
During his stay, Correia will meet with his ROC counterpart Vincent Siew to exchange views on international issues, bilateral ties and Taiwan's relationship with African states.
He will also visit the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Council of Agriculture as well as touring the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the Taipei World Trade Center.

The ROC forged diplomatic ties with Guinea Bissau in 1990. The West African country's President Joao Bernardo Vieira visited Taiwan three times in 1990, 1995 and 1996, respectively, but this is Correia's first visit. He is scheduled to leave on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM OPENS BANGKOK OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Vice Prime Minister Supachai Panitchpak of Thailand said on Tuesday that the Thai government welcomes the opening here of a branch office of the Taipei-based Chunghwa Telecom Co. Ltd. and called for greater cooperation between the business communities of Thailand and Taiwan.

Addressing those attending the inauguration of the office, including more than 200 local and Taiwan business leaders, Supachai hailed the move by Chunghwa Telecom, which he said will upgrade the level of Thailand's telecommunications industry and help strengthen cooperation in the field among Asian countries.

Supachai said Thailand is actively pushing for the opening up of its telecommunications market by 1999 under the liberalization guidelines set by the World Trade Organization. Over the past five years, the number of underground telephone lines in Thailand has increased threefold to 7 million, while there are now more cellular telephones and pagers in the country than ever before, at 1.5 million and 1.1 million, respectively, he added.

Supachai stressed that Chunghwa Telecom has grabbed a good opportunity to venture into Thailand, as both the Telephone Organization of Thailand and Communications Authority of Thailand (CAT) are undergoing privatization.

Speaking on the same occasion, Stephan Hsu, the Republic of China's representative to Thailand, said the move by Chunghwa Telecom amid the ongoing financial crisis plaguing the Asian region shows that Taiwan businesses have confidence Thailand will recover from the current turmoil and that bilateral cooperation will prove fruitful.

Pointing out that Chunghwa Telecom and the CAT have long enjoyed a cordial friendship under the framework of international organizations, CAT President Asauvin Saovaros expressed the hope that the opening of Chunghwa Telecom's office in Bangkok will help boost two-way cooperation.

Telephone Organization of Thailand President Satien Pitaganun said the memorandum of understanding signed between Chunghwa Telecom and his organization will pave the way for greater bilateral cooperation in the future, while Chunghwa Telecom President Chen Yao said the accord is a step toward breaking into the Thai market.
Under the terms of the agreement, the two sides will hold regular meetings on the exploration of business opportunities and engage in exchanges of information and visits by personnel.
The Bangkok office is Chunghwa Telecom's fourth office abroad. The firm already has branch offices in Washington, D.C., Hong Kong and Tokyo.
A 7-member Chunghwa Telecom delegation led by Chen, which arrived here on Monday, is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
