DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTING FARMERS SHOWER POLICE WITH EGGS, PIG FECES

TEXT.P: Farmers showered police guarding the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) with eggs and pig feces during a protest on Wednesday against the government's alleged move to open Taiwan to US pork in exchange for Washington dropping its push to pry open the island's rice market.

The farmers first threw pig feces toward the doors of AIT, Washington's de facto embassy here, located on Hsinyi Road in eastern Taipei. They then vented their anger on the police, adding eggs to their arsenal.
Nearly 5,000 pig farmers turned up in Taipei from around the island Wednesday morning in 110 tourist buses.
Protest organizers among the farmers had said earlier they would rally 10,000 people on Wednesday in front of the Presidential Office to protest the alleged trade-off.
Taipei and Washington are now engaged in bilateral talks over Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Fearing that Taiwan negotiators would push ahead with the island's bid to join the WTO at the expense of local pig farmers' interests, the protesters took to Taipei streets to make their message heard.
AIT responded to the barrage by lowering its outer steel gate. The liaison office had not been informed about the protest in advance, according to AIT officials.
Daniel Martinez, chief of AIT's Agricultural Affairs Section, stepped out from the building later and received a protest letter from representatives of the rally.
Martinez promised to convey the letter and the farmers' concern to authorities in Washington.

At noon, Peng Tzuo-kuei, the Republic of China's top official in charge of agricultural affairs, again reassured the pig farmers that the government would never sacrifice their interests in an attempt to protect Taiwan's rice market.

The ROC officials currently in Washington for the ongoing WTO bilateral talks with the United States will try their utmost to safeguard Taiwan farmers' interests to the greatest possible extent, he added.

Meanwhile, Ling Shiang-nung, vice chairman of the Council of Agriculture and Taiwan's top negotiator in agricultural talks, asked Taiwan pig farmers not to worry, saying that he and his colleagues will try their best to seek America's understanding of the equal importance of Taiwan's rice, pig and chicken farming sectors, and that none of them should be harmed in international negotiations.

ROC negotiators, headed by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, failed to reach a significant consensus with their US counterparts on Tuesday in the ongoing WTO bilateral talks, scheduled to be the final round of US-ROC consultations before Taiwan is formally admitted into the world trade regulatory body.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Prompted by active buying on Wall Street overnight, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) surged 1.7 percent Wednesday.
Technology shares were the most popular with investors, dealers said.
The TAIEX's weighted price index jumped 145.76 points from the previous day's close of 8567.66 to close Wednesday at 8,713.42.
The market, which opened at 8.693.99, experienced a high of 8,753.54 and a low of 8,682.16.
Advancing stocks outnumbered losers 269 to 147, with 66 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$197.49 billion (US$6.01 billion), up from the 2.60 billion issues valued at NT$166.22 billion in the previous session.

Electrical engineering issues, which increased 3.5 percent, posted the largest gain among the eight major stock categories, followed by a 1.4 percent rise for textile shares, 1.0 percent for construction shares, 0.9 percent for banking stocks and 0.3 percent for both foodstuff issues and plastic and chemical shares.
Paper and pulp shares dropped 0.7 percent, and cement stocks lost 0.2 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers in the three-hour session were United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor, ACER, Macronix International, Yageo, Winbond Electronics, Compal Electronic, ASE, Mosel Vitelic and the GVC Corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIZ LEADERS SHOULDN'T ACCEPT M'LAND POLITICAL POSTS: MAC

TEXT.P: The time is not ripe for Taiwan businesspersons to accept appointments to the national committee of the mainland Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), a spokesman for the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Wednesday.

Fu Don-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, said that without government approval, Taiwan businesspersons who accept a CPPCC post or other prominent politically sensitive jobs in mainland China may risk being fined or experiencing entrance problems upon their return to the island.

Fu was referring to Huang Tzi-yu, vice chairwoman of the Taiwan Business Association in Beijing and a big name in mainland China's real estate sector, who was reportedly appointed to the Ninth National Committee of the CPPCC in late January.

Since Beijing has long politicized Taiwan people's economic activities in mainland China, the motives behind Huang's CPPCC appointment are highly complex, Fu pointed out, saying that it is not yet time for any Taiwan businessperson to accept a politically sensitive position, such as on a CPPCC committee.

Although Fu said that the MAC has not received any information on Huang's alleged appointment, he noted that according to the 33rd Article of the Statute on Relations between the People of Taiwan and Mainland China, Taiwan individuals or organizations that become members of or take jobs in public-run organizations or institutions in mainland China may receive fines ranging from NT$100,000 to NT$500,000 (US$3,049-US$15,244).
According to a United Daily News report, Huang's father was formerly a heavyweight figure in the ruling Kuomintang who was once a National Assembly member.

The report said Huang began doing business in mainland China more than one decade ago through a front company in Hong Kong. Venturing into the real estate business only a few years ago, she became famous by developing the renowned European-style "Ziyun Villa" near Beijing.

Some members of the mainland-based Taiwan business sector believe that Huang further impressed the Beijing authorities with her recent donation of 1 million yuan (US$120,337) to earthquake victims in Hebei Province's Zhangbei area.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENT WANG BINGZHANG TELLS OF ARREST BY MAINLAND POLICE
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The clandestine journey of mainland Chinese exiled dissident Wang Bingzhang came to a dramatic end with his expulsion on Monday by the Beijing government. In an interview upon his arrival in Los Angeles from Shanghai, Wang told his side of the events surrounding his mainland China sojourn.
Wang, 50, slipped into mainland China via the Portuguese enclave of Macau on Jan. 23, with the intention of forming an opposition party.
Wang said he stayed in the mainland for about three weeks, during which period he met and exchanged views with democracy campaigners in Shanghai and nearby provinces.

Nothing much happened until Feb. 5, according to Wang, when police issued an arrest warrant for him and began detaining and questioning dissidents and relatives he had met. Since he had nowhere to hide, he went to the residence of his friend Wang Tingjin in the city of Bengbu, Anhui Province, a veteran of the democracy movement of the late 1970s.

However, Wang Tingjin has always been under close surveillance by the mainland security police and Wang Bingzhan was seized by the security police on Feb. 6 in Bengbu and detained till the afternoon of Feb. 8.

During his three days in captivity, Wang Bingzhan was questioned repeatedly by security police. The investigation stopped abruptly on Feb. 8 when five armed policemen came in and escorted him back to Shanghai.

Arriving in Shanghai in the very early hours of Feb. 9, he was given breakfast and taken directly to the airport to be returned into exile. A formal document was read by a security police official asserting that Wang had sneaked into mainland China to subvert the government.
His camera, tape recorder, video camera, wallet and credit cards were all confiscated by security police prior to his departure.

Wang speculated that his swift release was the result of moral support from the international community and bargaining between Washington and Beijing, pointing out that Beijing has probably learned from past experience that is better to drop a hot potato than to hold on to it. He added that the Beijing leadership is most likely trying to foster a more liberal image by its handling of the situation.
Wang said that he is confident the democratic movement in mainland China will continue to develop, and that if necessary he will try to return to his own country.
He was slated to leave Los Angeles for San Francisco on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL LEAVES FOR PRIVATE SOUTH KOREAN VISIT

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), left for Seoul on Wednesday for a four-day private visit.

Chang's trip is being seen by some analysts as a sign of a thaw in the relationship between South Korea and Taiwan, which severed formal relations in August 1992 when Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Prior to his departure from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Chang declined to confirm whether he will meet with South Korean President-elect Kim Dae Jung during his stay in Seoul, but pointed out that he will meet with some of South Korea's high-ranking officials.

There has been some speculation that Chang will meet Kim, who will be sworn into office on Feb. 25, and other officials from the major South Korean political parties, including Kim's National Congress for New Politics and its conservative ally, the United Liberal Democrats.
The former foreign minister-turned KMT brasshat said substantive bilateral ties between the two countries are expected to be further improved after his Feb. 11-14 visit.
Accompanying Chang on the trip are his deputy, Chung Jung-chi, KMT Organizational Affairs Department chief Cheng Chun-tsan, and Overseas Chinese Affairs Department chief Wang Neng-chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALF MILLION TAIWAN VISITORS CAME TO S'PORE IN 1997

TEXT.P: Nearly half a million visitors came to Singapore from Taiwan last year, according to figures released by the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) Tuesday.
Taiwan stood as Singapore's fourth largest tourist market, with 499,782 visitors in 1997.

Indonesia topped the list of Singapore's top 10 tourist markets last year, registering 1,171,564 visitors from that neighboring country. Japan was second with 1,094,040 visitor arrivals, followed by Malaysia, with 681,829 visitors.
After Taiwan, Singapore's top tourist markets in 1997 were Australia, the United States, Britain, South Korea, Hong Kong and mainland China, in fifth through tenth places, respectively.

The STB reported that a total of 7,197,963 foreign visitors arrived in Singapore last year, marking a 1.3 percent drop from 7.29 million in 1996. The fall in the number of visitor arrivals to Singapore was the first since 1983, it said.

While predicting a further decline of 8 to 10 percent this year, the STB said it will double its efforts to lure more foreign tourists here by turning its attention to Australia, Europe and North America, instead of those from the ASEAN countries which were hard hit by the current regional financial turmoil.
It will also further explore other markets with potential, such as mainland China, India, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIONAL WOES TO HIT S'PORE TOURISM FURTHER THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: For the first time since 1983, the annual figure of visitor arrivals to Singapore has fallen, dropping 1.3 percent last year, with an even greater fall expected this year.
The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) said Tuesday that the numbers of visitors to Singapore have come down from 7.29 million in 1996 to 7,197,963 last year.
This year, the STB is expecting an 8 to 10 percent drop, which means that some 6.5 million visitors might come here in 1998.
Given these figures, the target of 10 million visitors by the year 2000 in the STB's tourism blueprint, Tourism 21, has been put back four to five years.
STB chief executive Yeo Khee Leng attributed the decline in numbers to the haze and the regional economic crisis in the second half of last year.

The haze, caused by forest fires in Indonesia, hit long-haul travel to the ASEAN region, while the currency crisis made it more expensive for people from the affected Southeast Asian countries to visit Singapore.
The drop became noticeable in the last quarter, when tourist arrivals fell by 14.4 percent. In the first three quarters of last year, Singapore was on target for a 3 to 4 percent growth, Yeo said.
Spelling gloom for the rest of this year, he pointed out that besides the threat of haze and the regional economic crunch, a third factor looming ahead was a potential crisis in the Persian Gulf.
If war breaks out in the Gulf, Singapore can expect even fewer visitors, he said.
The number of visitors from ASEAN countries, hit by the economic crunch, is expected to decline by 15 to 20 percent this year.
Hotels in Singapore are expected to feel the brunt of the decline. Average hotel occupancy rates -- about 79.5 percent last year -- are expected to go down.
They may also be forced to lower their room rates.

To lure tourists to Singapore, the STB will turn its attention to Australia, Europe and North America. Other markets with potential, such as mainland China, India, Hong Kong and Taiwan, will also be tapped.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CRACK DOWN ON TAIWAN'S LARGEST EROTIC WEBSITE

TEXT.P: A pornographic website that billed itself as the largest of its kind for Taiwan residents has been raided by local law enforcement personnel, marking a victory for the police in their crackdown against the world of cyber-crime.

Since the Chinese-language "Big Black Market" began operating through a foreign-based website three months ago, around 400,000 Internet users have visited it and sampled its thousands of erotic pictures, a spokesman for the Taipei-based Criminal Investigation Bureau said Wednesday.
The spokesman revealed that the website, developed by a disabled male nicknamed Hsiau Yang, had 10 pages of selections and provided links to similar foreign sites.
In addition to erotic pictures, the Big Black Market also provided illegal services such as introductions to prostitutes and gambling, the bureau said.

The police arrested Hsiau Yang on Tuesday in downtown Taipei, charging him with violating intellectual property rights, offending morality, allowing minors access to sexual material and other related crimes.
They seized a number of erotic books and compact discs, and many receipts for money allegedly gained through illegal means.
The case has been delivered to prosecutors for further investigation, according to the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN URGED TO SUSPEND TRADE ACTIVITIES IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday urged Taiwan businesses to temporarily stop their commercial activities in Indonesia, where anti-Chinese riots have not yet been suppressed.

Citing an already signed accord on investment guarantees between Taiwan and the Southeast Asian country, Wang said that if any Taiwan businessmen suffer losses as a result of the unrest, Taipei will help them to seek compensation from Jakarta under the terms of the agreement.

He noted that his ministry is very concerned over the riots which have endangered the safety of Taiwan businessmen in Indonesia, adding that a task force is standing by to deal with any sudden occurrence.

According to foreign media reports, large-scale violence sparked by price hikes and shortages of essential goods has forced numerous ethnic Chinese in Indonesia to seek the protection of the military and police.

Soaring prices and mass layoffs caused by the destructive Asian financial and economic crisis are tearing the Southeast Asian country apart, with recent reports saying that rationing of basic foodstuffs has been implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA READY TO SEND ELITE TROOPS TO BACK US AGAINST IRAQ

TEXT.P: Australia is preparing to send elite troops to the Middle East to support a US-led offensive against Iraq if Washington should decide to order a military strike to destroy Iraqi facilities for chemical and biological weapons.
Defense Department sources said it will be the first time Australia has sent troops into combat since the Vietnam War.
The deployment of about 110 Special Air Services (SAS) troops would be one of the most dangerous military assignments undertaken by Australians since the Vietnam War, the sources said.
The elite soldiers would be used to rescue US or British pilots brought down behind Iraqi lines, they said.

Armed with a submachine gun or carbine fitted with a grenade launcher, a knife, a pistol, medical equipment, and a variety of grenades and other explosives, the SAS are among the most highly trained personnel of their type in the world, the sources said.
They would be divided into small teams of perhaps of five or six men, each of them multi-skilled, or in the jargon "cross-trained."

The SAS was established in the late 1950s as part of Australia's Special Forces designed to build on the unconventional warfare skills learned by commandos during World War II. They train and operate largely in secret, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING AUSTRALIAN MAGAZINE MERGES WITH TIME INC.

TEXT.P: Australia's biggest magazine -- The Bulletin -- will soon merge with Time Inc. of the United States in a new joint venture.
Owned by Australia's richest man Kerry Packer and his family, The Bulletin is a publication of the Australia Consolidated Press (ACP). The merger will create a new company, to be called Premier.

Premier will merge The Bulletin with Time's two Australian publications -- Time and Who Weekly -- and the company will be headed by Time Inc. executive Marty Gardner, who has just arrived in Australia from New York.

Gardner told reporters that Premier is expected to generate a revenue of about A$100 million a year from the six magazines and will move quickly to launch new titles, starting with an Australian version of Time Inc.'s US fashion and lifestyle magazine InStyle.
The merger has taken the Australian magazine industry by surprise and has led some to suspect it may lead to closure for The Bulletin, which has struggled in recent years with falling circulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN DEPUTY PM VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim called on Premier Vincent Siew on Wednesday shortly after arriving in Taipei at around noon at the start of a private visit.

Anwar's visit, the first of its kind, is part of a Malaysian government drive to seek cooperative measures to tackle the financial crisis that has battered most of the economies of the region since last July.
The drive has already taken Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad to Singapore, the Philippines and Thailand, while Anwar visited Japan before coming to Taiwan.

Anwar, who concurrently serves as Malaysia's finance minister, will also meet with ROC Finance Minister Paul Chiu, Central Bank of China Governor Sheu Yuan-dong, and Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, to exchange views on ways to tackle the financial turmoil.

Anwar, widely regarded as heir-apparent to Mahathir, told Malaysian media prior to his departure that his trip is not aimed at asking neighboring countries for special assistance to Malaysia, but rather at seeking joint efforts to resolve the regionwide financial problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD DELEGATION RETURNS FROM GERMAN TRIP TO WOO BAYER

TEXT.P: A ranking government official and chief delegate of a fact-finding mission to Germany said on Wednesday that the Bayer Group's safety measures are well above standard levels and that the delegation will report to the provincial council on the issue in a last-ditch effort to save a NT$50 billion investment by the German pharmaceutical giant in central Taiwan.

Y.S. Liu, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said the delegation will make the report at a temporary session called by the Taiwan Provincial Assembly on Monday, which he said will be the last chance to woo Bayer back to Taiwan.

The company announced in December that it was relocating the proposed site of a new production plant for toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) from central Taiwan's Taichung Harbor to the United States after then-newly elected Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party insisted on holding a public referendum to decide the fate of the plan following strong opposition from local residents.

Liu said Bayer promised to carry out the investment project in Taichung Harbor, as long as the Taiwan Provincial Assembly approves the land lease contract for Bayer by the end of this month, opening the way for construction of relevant facilities in September as scheduled.

Liu, who returned on Tuesday after a six-day visit to Bayer's headquarters in Dormagen at the head of an 11-member delegation composed of petrochemical experts and public opinion leaders, said the delegation found Bayer's safety and environmental protection measures to be very satisfactory and that Bayer is still willing to set up the TDI plant at Taichung Harbor as long as the project can proceed smoothly.
He said that the company made several pledges to the local communities if they allow the project to go ahead:
-- to set up a task force to monitor construction of the facilities and to communicate with local neighborhoods on a regular basis
-- to employ local people
-- to ensure that Bayer executives will live inside the harbor area
-- to ensure that local production facilities are built in accordance with parent company regulations in Germany
-- to provide technology transfers from Bayer to Taiwan businesses
-- to provide insurance for workers at the plant and local residents

Referring to phosgene, a poisonous gas necessary in the manufacture of TDI and the element most feared by local residents, Liu said it is not as terrible as is widely believed by its opponents, if handled correctly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN FROM AROUND THE WORLD TO GATHER IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Some 1,000 Taiwan businessmen from around the world will take part in the annual meeting of the World Federation of the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Taipei on May 18-20, an official from the Overseas Chinese Commission (OCC) said on Wednesday.

The official said that the three-day meeting will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center under the joint sponsorship of the OCC, the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC, the Chinese National Federation of Industries, and the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

He said that the annual gathering is aimed at promoting cooperation and relationships between Taiwan businessmen around the world. Ever since the first meeting took place in 1963, it has made a significant contribution to closer bonds between businessmen from Taiwan, he added.

He also said that the OCC hopes local banks will set up overseas branches around the world to help Taiwan businessmen develop their businesses, adding that at the prompting of the OCC, the Bankers Association of the ROC will send a delegation this year to investigate the financial investment climate in the major countries of Central and South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.131 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.710.
The greenback opened at 32.800 and was traded between 32.650 and 32.800.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$470.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT SACRIFICE FARMERS' INTERESTS IN WTO TALKS WITH US

TEXT.P: The government will not sacrifice the interests of Taiwan's farmers in its current round of talks with the United States over Taiwan's terms for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang reaffirmed on Wednesday.

Wang said the opening of Taiwan's markets to US agricultural products has been one of the toughest issues in the latest round of talks, but he stressed that the government will not seek early entry into the world trade regulatory body at the expense of local farmers.
The 17th round of Taiwan-US WTO talks opened in Washington D.C. on Monday.

Reports have said that Taiwan is ready to make major concessions regarding the opening of Taiwan to US pork in exchange for Washington dropping its attempts to pry open the island's rice market, in order to facilitate early WTO entry.

According to the reports, Taiwan will first lower tariffs by 15 percent on imported US pork belly and offal after it enters the WTO. After the sixth year, the tariffs will be lowered by another 50 percent and eventually they will be brought down to below 7.5 percent. After one year at this level, Taiwan will cut tariffs on pork products altogether, the reports said.

According to an official from the US pork producer's association, Taiwan people consume the most pork per head in Asia, but has refused to open its markets to imports of US pork belly and offal, which he said runs counter to WTO norms.
Wang's words came amid angry protests from domestic pig farmers over the US pressure on Taiwan to open up to imports of chicken and pork products.

Some 5,000 demonstrators from all over the island, representing pig farmers, meat producers and the animal feed sector, took to the streets of Taipei on Wednesday morning and marched to the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the de facto embassy of the United States in Taiwan.
They waved banners reading "Americans are exploiters," and "no concessions in US-Taiwan talks" and threw eggs and pig manure at the door of the AIT building.
Minor scuffles were reported between the protesters and police, but no one was arrested. An AIT official later accepted a letter of protest from the demonstrators.
Around 300 of the protesters went to the Ministry of Economic Affairs later in the afternoon to continue to publicize their cause.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yiin Chii-ming said the Taiwan government will never succumb to the US requests to open Taiwan's meat markets in exchange for Washington dropping its push to pry open the island's rice market, pointing out that if Taiwan succumbs to the requests, the country's pig population will drop by 2.1 million within three years, and the production value of the pig raising sector will stand to lose over NT$12 billion (US$363 million) annually.
Yiin assured the representatives that his ministry will continue to fight for their best interests.

Taiwan has so far concluded bilateral WTO consultations with 23 contracting parties to the world trade regulatory organization. The US is one of the three WTO members that have yet to finalize negotiations with Taiwan, the other two being the European Union and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS FORCES AUSTRALIA TO ADOPT TOUGH BUDGET

TEXT.P: Australia, suffering the effects of the Asian economic crisis, is expected to adopt a tough budget for fiscal 1998-99, with Treasurer Peter Costello admitting the impact from the Asian meltdown is worse than first thought.
"Don't underestimate the impact of Asia. We haven't seen anything like this before in our lifetime and it will have an effect on Australia," he said.
"We have to continue to work at strengthening the Australian economy because we are in very uncertain times, and this is going to have a big impact," he added.
He said the upcoming budget will need to be tough to deal with the impact of the Asian crisis.
Several surveys and authoritative forecasts point to a much harder landing for the Australian economy this year.
Two months ago, Costello predicted that the Australian government would have a budget surplus of A$2.5 billion for 1998-99, rising to A$5 billion in 1999-2000 and A$10.4 billion in 2000-2001.
But now he is unsure whether the targets can be met in the face of declining exports to Asia.

The Asian crisis will slash Australia's economic growth to 2.4 percent in 1998 from 3.6 percent and will drive the unemployment rate back to 9.6 percent from the current 8.1 percent, as well as blowing out the country's current account deficit, according to the influential Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) in London.
The EIU also warned that Australia's "reforms will proceed more slowly" if the Labor Party wins this year's general election.
The organization said Australia's current account deficit will become "the most pressing problem in 1998," as rapid domestic growth sucks in imports while slowing demand from Asia hurts its exports.

It predicts the external deficit will peak at 5.3 percent of Australia's gross domestic product this calendar year but will remain above 5 percent for a further two years until Australia shakes off the adverse impact of an El Nino-generated drought as well as the effects of the regional downturn and falling commodity prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG LANTERN FESTIVALS KICK OFF

TEXT.P: An estimated 1 million people were on hand to watch Premier Vincent Siew light up the theme display at the Taipei Lantern Festival in downtown Taipei which kicked off its five-day gala Wednesday.

Premier Siew and his wife Chu Shu-hsien walked into the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall amid the drumbeats of the Chu Percussion Group in the early evening. Siew pressed a button at 6:30 p.m. to light up the theme lantern, which was in the shape of a giant tiger to signify the Year of the Tiger, which began on Jan. 28 according to the Chinese lunar calendar.
Spectators gazed in awe as the huge display began to beam laser lights in all directions.

Organizers of the festival distributed small lanterns to children in the afternoon. The flickering of small lanterns as well as various colorful lanterns displayed all around the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza added to the festive atmosphere under a full moon.
Meanwhile, President Lee Teng-hui presided over a similar lantern festival in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

The theme lantern, a 15-meter-tall structure in the shape of a large ship sailing the high seas, cost about NT$10 million (US$303, 000) and is equipped with laser lights and features changing patterns of sound and light.
As President Lee lighted up the theme lantern, ships moored in the Kaohsiung Harbor also sounded their horns for one minute to celebrate the first lantern festival held in Kaohsiung.

Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Jason Hu hosted ambassadors and representatives from other nations to celebrate this year's Lantern Festival, which falls on the 15th day of the first month in the lunar calendar.
About 200 guests attended the party at the Grand Hyatt Taipei Hotel on Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIME-FILLED TV NEWS CONCERNS PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: Concerned over the extensive coverage of violent crimes seen in television news reports, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman and ROC President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday instructed KMT Secretary-General John Chang to consult with the heads of three TV networks on their reporting.

After hearing a report by KMT member Lin Cheng-chih, who is also chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, on a government promotion of international cultural exchanges at a regular meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, Lee expressed serious concern over the fact that local TV news reports often lead off with coverage of criminal cases.

KMT spokeswomen Huang Lee-ching quoted Lee afterward as saying that the unanimous priority given by TV stations to criminal cases could mislead people into believing that Taiwan is a crime-infested society.

"The Republic of China is not a place where crime is the only news worth reporting," Lee was quoted as saying. Huang said the party chairman also worried about the often graphic descriptions of criminal acts in news reports which, he said, might negatively influence young viewers.

Out of concern about the negative national image projected by crime-oriented news coverage, Huang said that Lee had asked Chang to urge the heads of three local TV stations -- TTV, CTS, and CTC, which are either owned by the KMT or controlled by the ruling party through government agencies, to alter their editorial policies by giving more prominent coverage and precedence in reporting sequence to cultural news items.

Such concern is understandable after angry protesters demanded that Lee apologize for the government's alleged failure to maintain law and order last May amid mass-media criticism of failure by police to solve several high-profile criminal cases.

In response to the KMT chairman's criticism, the news department heads of the three networks on Wednesday, were receptive to Lee's comments, but they blamed the phenomenon on fierce competition among local mass media and their audiences' apparent preference for news about disasters, scandals and violence.

Noting the immense influence of the electronic mass media in society and its role as an educational tool, CTC news executive Hu Hsueh-chu said that her department has tried to balance the negative stories by airing four minutes of coverage on the brighter aspects of society in its evening news programs every Monday, Wednesday and Friday.

However, she promised to address Lee's concerns by more carefully screening the newsworthiness of the stories being aired while making some adjustments in the order of appearance. She added that footage of bloodshed, violence and sexual images have already been removed from CTV programs.
TTV news head Ku An-sheng said that TTV will heed Lee's directions and give more emphasis to positive news stories, adding that this is already the long-standing policy of the station.

CTS news head Chou Hsiao-hui echoed Lee's opinions by stating that the rebroadcast of negative local news reports by foreign TV stations has raised questions among international audiences about the state of Taiwan's social security and the safety of living on the island.

Although admitting that the fierce competition among local mass media could force TV news departments to resort to sensationalism in order to boost ratings, Chou promised to do his best to reverse the trend.
Taiwan's fourth TV network, the private-owned Formosa TV, is controlled by members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and was spared from Lee's criticism.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MEETS WITH MALAYSIAN VICE PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Wednesday told visiting Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim that Taiwan is willing to do its best to contribute to the financial and economic stability in Southeast Asia.

Siew said that Taiwan's experience in coping with the financial crisis might be of help to Malaysia and other Asian countries, adding that the sound economic fundamentals and adequate government measures have helped the island weather the financial crisis.

Taiwan maintains close trade and investment relations with the Southeast Asian countries, Siew said, pointing out that Taiwan investment in the region reached US$38 billion last year, while trade between Taiwan and the region totaled some US$27 billion during the same period. In addition, currently over 200,000 laborers, mainly from Thailand and the Philippines, are working in Taiwan, Siew added.

Saying that Taiwan has good reason to be concerned about the economic and financial situations in Southeast Asia, Siew stressed that Taiwan would like to offer assistance in helping restore the region's stability. He also expressed hope that the Southeast Asian countries can maintain more substantial contacts with Taiwan.

Anwar told the ROC premier that although having been hit by the regional financial turmoil erupted in July, Malaysia's economic and financial situations have been stabilized. The Malaysian ringgit is recovering from its record low, while the stock market continues to rally as investors have restored confidence. He said that now is the best time to invest in his country.

After their meeting, ROC government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said that both Siew and Anwar stressed that their meeting was mainly for discussing economic and financial issues, and that there were no political motivations involved.

The Malaysian vice premier arrived in Taipei on Wednesday morning for a short private visit. Before meeting with Siew, he had lunch with Finance Minister Paul Chiu to exchange views on current situation in Malaysia.

Later in the day, Anwar met with Y.D. Sheu, governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC). According to CBC Deputy Governor C.J. Liang, Sheu expressed hope that the Malaysian government will approve more local banks to operate offshore banking units (OBUs) in the Southeast Asian country. OBU approval can provide Taiwan businessmen with loans to facilitate their operations there, Liang said.

He added that the drastic depreciation of the Southeast Asian currencies has promoted many regional countries to raise bank interest rates to protect the value of their currencies, which unavoidably aggravates Taiwan businessmen's financial burdens.

Liang said that the International Commercial Bank of China and United World Chinese Commercial Bank started their OBUs in Malaysia in mid-January, while applications by the First Commercial Bank and the Chinatrust Commercial Bank are pending.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL ARRIVES IN SEOUL

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang, flew in from Taipei Wednesday on a mission to promote Taiwan's ties with South Korea.

Upon his arrival at the Kimpo Airport, Chang told a group of waiting reporters that "we will improve substantial ties with the new administration of South Korean President-elect Kim Dae-jung patiently and gradually."

He was greeted by Soon Se-il, a parliamentarian of South Korea's ruling National Congress for New Politics party and president of the Korean-Taiwan Lawmakers' Friendship Association. Also on hand was Taipei's representative to Seoul, Lin Tsun-hsien, as well as several members of the local Chinese community.

Lin told reporters that a meeting between Chang and Kim Dae-jung was still "under arrangement." His statement seemed to rule out earlier speculation that Kim would meet with Chang "unexpectedly" to avoid possible opposition from Beijing.

Chang is also expected to meet with Kim Jong-pil, the leader of the Korean United Liberal Democrats. However, like his proposed meeting with Kim Dae-jung, that encounter was not listed on Chang's official itinerary released by the Taipei representative office in Seoul.

Chang also told reporters that he had turned down an invitation to visit South Korea during his tenure as ROC foreign minister because his hosts wanted to meet him only in places outside the capital of Seoul.
Chang is slated to return to Taipei on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTHWEST ADDING TAIPEI-OSAKA ROUTE TO PACIFIC SERVICES

TEXT.P: Northwest Airlines, the leading US commercial operator in the Asia-Pacific region, is scheduled to begin daily flights between the Japanese city of Osaka and Taipei on April 5, according to a company spokesman for Northwest Taiwan.

The addition of the Osaka-Taipei flights to Northwest's Asian services will expand the choices of Taiwan passengers bound for either Japan or the United States. The decision was made in consideration of Taiwan's solid economy, which has remained relatively unscathed by the economic crisis in Asia, the spokesman said.
"We have confidence in Taiwan's economy, and project good passenger loads for the new Osaka-Taipei flights," he added.

Starting from April 5, Northwest will operate a daily flight from Seattle to Osaka's Kansei International Airport, with continuing service to Taipei. That flight will depart Osaka at 5:30 p.m. and arrive at Taipei's CKS International Airport at about 7:10 p.m. The same aircraft will leave Taipei at 9:40 the following morning for the return to Osaka, continuing on to Seattle after a short stopover, according to the Northwest plan.

The Osaka-Taipei flights will make Taipei the second Asian city serviced by the US airline from Osaka. Taiwan passengers can use the route to reach other US destinations, including Seattle, Detroit, Minneapolis, Los Angeles and Honolulu.

Several major US airlines have recently moved to increase their service to Japan, taking advantage of a new aviation pact reached between the United States and Japan on Jan. 30. Those airlines, including Northwest, American Airlines, Delta and US Airways, will expand the both number of flights between the US and Japan as well as points beyond.
