DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PHILIPPINE LEGISLATORS TO JOINTLY COMBAT REGIONAL CRIME

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the Republic of China and the Philippines will soon sign a memorandum on joint operations to combat crime in the Asian-Pacific region.

An interparty group from Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, to be headed by Kuomintang Legislator Wang Ling-lin, is leaving for Manila on Friday to sign the memorandum with its Filipino counterpart. It is hoped that by forging the pact the two countries will redouble efforts in eradicating cross-border crime as well as illegal activities in areas beyond.

At a press conference prior to the group's departure for Manila, Wang, a chief executive of the ROC-RP Legislators' Association, said the signing of the memorandum is aimed at initiating joint police operations between the two countries and at making such cooperation a regular and institutionalized program.
Meanwhile, Wang made public a white paper on joint efforts to crack down on crime between Taiwan and the Philippines.

The report, co-authored by five professors from the National Police Academy, said cross-border organized crime is posing new threats to social security and compromising the national interests of Asian Pacific countries. It concluded that law enforcement cooperation between Taiwan and the Philippines will clearly reduce such activity and help improve social order.

The report added that although Taiwan and Philippine authorities have cooperated on individual cases in the past, with more than 40 criminal suspects being exchanged between the two countries, some issues remain difficult to tackle due to the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Manila.

The white paper called for top law enforcement agencies of the two countries to forge a treaty on collaborative action to combat crime, institutionalize bilateral meeting forums and establish channels for swapping case information and police files.

In addition to signing the memorandum, Wang and 12 other legislators, including Wang Tien-ging from the Kuomintang, nonpartisan Chang Chin-cheng and the New Party's Chen Yi-hsin, will also call at the Philippine House of Representatives, Ministry of Justice and National Police Headquarters as well as meet with leaders of the Taiwan business community in the Philippines for discussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTMENTS IN TAIWAN STOCK MARKET SURGE

TEXT.P: Prompted by an overall bullish sentiment in Taiwan's stock market, hot money from foreign investors has continued to pour in since the market reopened on Feb. 2 following the Chinese New Year holiday.
According to the latest Central Bank of China (CBC) statistics, in the seven trading days from that time, the net inflow of foreign funds for stock investment has reached US$691.63 million.

The record influx marks a recovery of overseas confidence in the local market which had been sagging since the outbreak of the Asian regional financial crisis in the middle of last year, the CBC indicated.

From last May to this January, the statistics showed, the outflow of foreign investment from the shares market had outpaced the influx of overseas funds on a month-to-month basis, with the exception of August and December.
In 1997, the island's stock market suffered an overall decline of more than US$1.07 billion in foreign investment, a direct result of the Asian financial storm, the CBC figures showed.

However, the return of outside funds as of the beginning of February is heating up the market once again, the CBC pointed out. It noted that from the first trading day following the Chinese New Year holiday until this past Monday over US$843 million in foreign funds were pumped into stock trading here, while only around US$151 billion in overseas assets were transferred out of the local market during the seven-day trading period.

If the net volume of outside investment keeps its present pace, February will see a new record, breaking the single-month high of US$1.2 billion registered in December 1993, since Taiwan formally opened the local stock market to foreign capital in 1991, the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC OFFICIAL PREDICTS STABLE PRICES THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Recent declines in the global prices of agriculture products and crude oil will help bring down the costs of imported goods and also stabilize domestic prices, Yeh Ming-feng, director of the Council for Economic Planning and Development's Economic Research Department, said on Thursday.

A more solid Taiwan dollar will also contribute to price stability, Yeh said, noting that the real effective exchange rate index of the Taiwan dollar was 91.33 in January, up 0.3 percent from the previous month and continuing to rebound since late last year.

Yeh noted that the price of oil on global markets has shown a modest decline in recent days because supplies are exceeding demands. With the coming of spring and a steady supply of agricultural products worldwide, farm commodity prices will be maintained while the cost of imported goods will drop.

The economics official also said the dramatic 23 percent decline of Taiwan's trade volume in January was not attributable to any major negative factor. Rather, it was the result of fewer working days in January because of the Chinese New Year holidays as well as the implementation of a five-day workweek starting Jan. 1.

In addition, Southeast Asian nations have also tightened control over the exodus of foreign currency in the wake of the financial crisis that hit the region in mid-1997, which has also resulted in a cut in Taiwan's trade surplus with those countries, Yeh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUHARTO SUSPECTS PLOT TO MAKE RUPIAH FALL

TEXT.P: Indonesia's President Suharto on Wednesday said that the downfall of the country's currency, the rupiah, has been engineered by certain parties who want to destroy the nation.

"If the exchange rate falls to 10,000 rupiah to one US dollar, many companies would be ruined and compelled to lay off their workers. Laid-off workers would then be easily stirred (into rioting)," Antara news agency quoted the head of state as saying in an impromptu speech after inaugurating the Texmaco industrial complex in Subang district, West Java Province.
Suharto said he suspects that there is a plot to destroy the country's economic foundation by making the exchange rate fall to as low as 20,000 rupiah to one dollar.
It is not logical for the currency to fall by 1,000 to 2,000 rupiah within a single day, he said.
He further said that irresponsible groups have also circulated rumors on his health.
"I have been reported to be dead, sick or paralyzed," he said with a smile.
Meanwhile, the rupiah opened stronger against the US dollar during Wednesday's trading here in a continuing trend this week that showed no trace of central bank intervention.
The Indonesian currency opened at between 7,300 and 7,500 to the dollar in Jakarta's interbank spot market.
The rupiah on Tuesday strengthened by 2,200 points from Monday's close of 9,600/9,750 to one dollar.
"The selling action by market dealers continued from the morning session to the closing hour. The currency kept strengthening until the end of the session," APEC Research quoted a dealer as saying.

The dealer said the strengthening of the rupiah followed a positive sentiment that had developed among market dealers following reports of government plans to peg the rupiah's exchange rate to a certain level.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIANS WANT SNOWBOARDER TO KEEP OLYMPIC MEDAL

TEXT.P: While a Canadian athlete waited for an appeal decision in Nagano, Japan, Canadians back home from the sports minister and solicitor general down were throwing support behind snowboarder Ross Rebagliati on Wednesday.

Most said he should keep his Olympic gold medal despite testing positive for marijuana. And he remains a hometown hero in Whistler, British Columbia, where a celebration party will be ready for him, no matter what.

Canadian parliamentarians of all stripes said the International Olympic Committee has over-reacted to minute traces of marijuana found in Rebagliati's test specimens after he won the first snowboard gold ever awarded at the Winter Games. In a split decision, the IOC stripped the 26-year-old of his medal, which he claimed he has worked 11 hard years to earn.

"Based on the facts that have been communicated, I think the young man was the best in the world and he did not engage in any activity that would illegally enhance that," Heritage Minister Sheila Copps said.

Copps, whose portfolio covers sports, said, "Canadians are rooting for him." Her comments echoed those of Andy Scott, who as solicitor general is responsible for the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, correctional services, the parole board and CSIS, or intelligence service.
"Every Canadian would love to see him have his medal," Scott said following a Liberal Party caucus meeting.
An independent, three-member tribunal in Nagano, is Rebagliati's last chance of appeal. The panel is to rule Thursday on whether the medal sanction stands.

Reform MP John Reynolds, whose West Vancouver-Sunshine Coast constituency includes Rebagliati's hometown, said the ruling reeks of Olympic political infighting in which members vote in the interests of their own country's medal standing.

"My constituents and a lot of the professional ski people in Whistler are very upset about this," said Reynolds. "They think it's part of the old Olympic (political) game. There's a dispute inside the Olympic group itself," he added.
Conservative Party leader Jean Charest, who has previously served as sports minister, said Rebagliati shouldn't see his gold go up in smoke.
"A warning would be sufficient," said Charest. "The public rebuke is, in itself, a pretty severe penalty for a young man."

It was the Tory cabinet which in 1988 clamped down a severe punishment on Ben Johnson, who tested positive for steroid after winning a world record-breaking gold medal in 100-meter sprint at the Seoul Olympics.
New Democratic Party Leader Alexa McDonough said it is clear that marijuana is not a performance-enhancing drug, and believes the IOC has overstepped its bounds.
"They're supposed to be there to deal with cheaters, not to rule on the morality of individual athletes," said McDonough. "Whatever this guy may have been guilty of, I don't think it's cheating."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN CITY REJECTS PROTESTS OVER DISPLAY OF ROC NAME

TEXT.P: A serious dispute has flared anew between Fairfield City and the mainland Chinese Consulate General in Sydney and pro-Beijing Chinese migrants over the arch hanging in a landmark square of the city because it contains the wording "Republic of China."

Less than three years ago, the mainland Chinese consulate general and its supporters lodged a strong protest when Fairfield, 30 kilometers west of Sydney, signed a sisterhood agreement with Hsinchu City in Taiwan because the agreement contained reference to the Republic of China.

The first dispute was brought to the Australian federal government which told Beijing diplomats that Canberra has no jurisdiction over such matters involving small cities or local governments, including Fairfield.
The latest dispute followed the protests by the mainland's consulate general in Sydney and pro-Beijing Chinese associations, including the Australian Chinese Descendant Mutual Association (ACDMA).

Consulate officials made a phone call to the Fairfield, expressing concern and protest over the city's permission to use the wording "Republic of China" on the arch, while the ACDMA and other associations sent a joint letter to the city demanding that the ROC reference be removed from the arch because it would cause diplomatic row between Australia and mainland China.

The Fairfield municipal authorities agreed to blacken out the wording in question. But the ROC name was restored after a request by a pro-Taiwan organization whose members are mainly overseas Chinese migrants from Indochina.
The organization's leader, Tiao Chen-mao, argued that they had the right to display any title, including the ROC name, because they had donated the money to build the arch.
Tiao said the reference to the ROC is not an offense to Australia because Australia is a democratic country.
He also expressed surprise at the protest from the mainland Chinese consulate general because Beijing always asks foreign countries not to interfere with its internal affairs.
Tiao said Fairfield is a small city with a population of 170,000 and not a major city like Sydney.
But ACDMA and other protesters said Australia adopts a "one China" policy and the use of the ROC name would damage bilateral ties between Australia and mainland China.

In a response to the protests from the mainland Chinese consulate general and pro-Beijing Chinese associations, the Fairfield City Council early this week held an emergency meeting to discuss the issue and later voted nine to five to maintain the wording, stating that the ROC was founded by the late Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who advocated democracy and freedom for all Chinese people when he established the republic.
Members of the city council who voted to maintain the wording said those Indochinese migrants who donated money to build the arch are people who have sought freedom and democracy in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE MANUFACTURERS SEE NO CHANGE IN BUSINESS CLIMATE

TEXT.P: Most manufacturers in Singapore do not expect business conditions in the first half of this year to worsen despite the Asian financial turmoil, according to the latest quarterly survey by the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB).
But, a separate survey by the Singapore Department of Statistics (DOS) shows that the commerce sector is bracing itself for a business slowdown.
In the EDB survey, "Business Expectations of the Manufacturing Sector" conducted between last December and January this year, 384 companies were approached, with 94 percent of them responding.
Fifty-five percent of the industrialists surveyed expected business conditions to remain the same, while 29 percent predicted a weakening. Only 16 percent saw an improvement ahead.
"The caution is largely due to the anticipation of softer overseas demand, especially from the region," the EDB said.
The EDB's business expectation surveys are considered forward-looking indicators relating to the health of the economy.

However, expectations varied from industry to industry within the manufacturing sector. For example, businessmen in the electronics industry -- the central pillar of the manufacturing sector -- varied in their outlook for the six months ending in June.

Manufacturers in the computer, computer peripherals and telecommunications sectors expected more export orders, while semiconductor manufacturers were more conservative because of falling prices of dynamic random access memory chips.
Disk drive makers gave mixed views, with some anticipating good orders and others expecting to be affected by global overcapacity.
In other industries, such as marine products, petroleum refining and pharmaceuticals, most expected business to remain unchanged in the first half of the year.
The transport equipment industry anticipated an improvement, which would be led mainly by the aviation sector, thanks to firm demand for aircraft maintenance.
Notwithstanding the cautious mood, manufacturers said they would continue to invest in plants, machinery and buildings over the next 12 months.
But they will watch out for competitive prices from overseas competitors, which remains the most crucial factor in getting more export orders in the first quarter.
Meanwhile, wholesalers and retailers in Singapore expect lower sales between January and June, according to the DOS Business Expectations Survey conducted last December.
Companies engaged in transport and storage as well as real estate services also predicted a downturn.
Most financial institutions forecast a downward trend.
But catering establishments and hoteliers, which saw higher earnings thanks to the yearend festive season, were optimistic about their businesses in the new year, the DOS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA'S RULING GOLKAR NOMINATES HARMOKO, HABIBIE FOR VP

TEXT.P: The ruling Golkar decided to nominate H. Harmoko and B.J. Habibie for the vice presidency for the 1998-2003 term at its plenary meeting in Jakarta on Wednesday night.

"The Golkar's plenary meeting has decided to nominate Bung Harmoko and Prof. B.J. Habibie (for the vice presidency)," Golkar spokesman Abdul Gafur was quoted by Antara news agency as saying following the meeting.
The plenary meeting, which took place at the Golkar head office here, lasted for nearly two hours.
Gafur, who is also Golkar executive board leader, said the party would soon put forward the name of its vice presidential candidate for discussion at the forum of the Golkar big family.

Meanwhile, a senior military officer said in a meeting in Kopo, West Java, Wednesday that the armed forces (ABRI) do not want to make another mistake by announcing its vice presidential nominee before the general session of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) in March.
"The ABRI does not want to repeat the past event," the ABRI head for social and political affairs, Lt. Gen. Yunus Yosfiah, told participants of the Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI) meeting in Kopo.

In 1993, the then ABRI head for social and political affairs, Lt. Gen. Hersudino Hartas, nominated the then ABRI Chief Gen. Try Sutrisno for the vice presidency in the lead-up to the MPR general session.
Yosfiah said the ABRI wanted to go through a constitutional mechanism in nominating its vice presidential candidate.
Under the 1945 Constitution, the choice of vice presidential candidate shall be discussed with the president-elect so that they can cooperate.
If the ABRI announces its vice presidential candidate ahead of the MPR session, it would appear as if it was steering public attention to the candidate.
"We don't want to dictate to the public," Yosfiah said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN RECEIVES INVITATION FROM MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan has received an invitation from Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad to visit that country at a convenient time, sources close to Lien said on Thursday.

According to the sources, Mahathir's invitation was extended to Lien on Wednesday by Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, who left Taiwan for home Thursday morning after a whirlwind overnight visit to the island.
The sources said Anwar talked with Lien by telephone Wednesday night as the vice president was on a grassroots community outreach tour in southern Taiwan.

During their 30-minute conversation, Anwar was quoted as telling Lien that he admires the Republic of China government's achievements in keeping Taiwan largely unscathed by Asia's regionwide financial turmoil, which has battered several Asia-Pacific countries since last summer.

Anwar, widely regarded as heir apparent to Mahathir, also told Lien that he looks forward to visiting Taiwan again in the near future to look into the development of biotechnology and other high-tech industries here.
For his part, Lien promised to accompany Anwar on a tour of Taiwan's high-tech stronghold -- the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- during his next trip to the island.
Lien further indicated that he may visit Malaysia later this year. Anwar is an old friend of Lien, who visited Malaysia in 1993 when he was the ROC premier.
Lien's aides said the vice president was meeting with Master Hsin Yun, abbot of the Buddhist Fokuangshan Temple in Kaohsiung County, when Anwar telephoned him Wednesday night.

Anwar, who doubles as Malaysia's finance minister, arrived in Taipei Wednesday afternoon to discuss feasible measures with senior ROC officials and entrepreneurs for resolving regional financial woes.

During his brief stay, Anwar met with Premier Vincent Siew, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, Central Bank of China Governor Sheu Yuan-dong and several local business and industry heavyweights, including Jeffrey Koo, chairman of Chinatrust Commercial Bank. In addition to exchanging views on the Asian financial problems, they also discussed concrete measures to promote bilateral economic and financial cooperation.

Anwar was not the first senior Malaysian official to visit Taiwan in recent months. Mahathir made a surprise transit stop on the island last November to discuss Asia's financial woes with Premier Siew. Malaysia recognizes Beijing, but maintains close substantive ties with Taipei. Taiwan is Malaysia's second largest source of foreign capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT BRASSHAT CALLS BEIJING INTERFERENCE 'IRRATIONAL'
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Thursday lashed out at Beijing's request for South Korea to reject economic aid from Taiwan at a time of obvious financial difficulty, calling it politically "irrational."

Chang, who is currently on a four-day private visit in South Korea, noted that, as a sovereign country, South Korea makes its own policy decisions based on considerations of national interest. Its choices can by no means be interfered with by any foreign government, Chang stressed.

Chang made the remarks in response to a Korean newspaper report filed from Beijing which stated that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin met Kim Jong-pil, the leader of the Korean United Liberal Democrats in Beijing last Sunday. During their meeting, Jiang reportedly expressed hope that Seoul would not accept an offer of financial aid from Taiwan aimed at helping South Korea tide over its economic crisis.

The report also said that in the meeting with Kim, who will become South Korea's prime minister after President-elect Kim Dae-jung takes office on Feb. 25, Jiang asked the incoming South Korean administration to stay firm in its promise to recognize Beijing's "one China" policy. Kim, in return, promised that future Seoul-Taipei relations will remain private and unofficial, the report said.

It quoted mainland Chinese authorities as claiming that Taiwan, in a money-diplomacy foray, is seeking to expand its political clout with hard currency, implying that Taiwan's offer of cash loans to South Korea exceeds the bounds of private exchanges.

Chang stressed that his visit here is aimed at gauging South Korea's attitude and its sincerity in improving bilateral ties with Taiwan. Although the two countries maintain no formal diplomatic relations, he said, Taiwan, as a neighbor which is relatively unscathed by the current Asian economic turmoil, is willing to help bail out South Korea from its difficulties.

Chang, who arrived in Seoul on Wednesday, met with KMT officials based in Seoul and overseas Chinese leaders in South Korea on Thursday to convey KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui's greetings to ROC supporters in that country, and exchanged views with them on a wide range of topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.145 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$32.855.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.701 and experienced a high of 32.95.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$353.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA OFFERS AID FOR EXPORT INSURANCE

TEXT.P: In light of the sharp downturn in Taiwan's exports to much of the rest of Asia in recent months, the government has decided to aid local exporters trading with nations in the region through an incentive insurance arrangement.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang revealed on Wednesday that his ministry will inject NT$60 million (US$1.82 million) into the ROC Export-Import Bank, allowing it to offer export insurance services to local businessmen trading with Southeast Asian nations and South Korea, which have been suffering tremendous currency woes since the outbreak of the regional financial crisis.

The decline in trade to those countries, which have little foreign currency and have seen their own units depreciate drastically, has affected Taiwan trade businesses, which have slowed their sales in the region to avoid losses from bounced checks or failed letters of credit.

Wang said the money is expected to provide an entire credit range of approximately NT$1 billion to exporters who wish to reduce their risk in selling goods to those countries, including Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and South Korea.

Between the time the financial storm began in the middle of last year and December, Taiwan exports to South Korea fell 30 percent, followed by a 22 percent plunge in Taiwan goods to Thailand, a 14 percent drop to Indonesia and a 4 percent slide to Malaysia, according to statistics from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOFA).

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND DEMOCRATIC FACTION PROPOSES TO RECOGNIZE ROC'S SOVEREIGNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: A democratic faction in the Chinese mainland is preparing to submit a proposal for recognizing the sovereignty of the Republic of China in Taiwan to the National People's Congress of mainland China, which opens March 5, according to a report in Thursday's edition of Yomiuri Shimbun in Tokyo.

The democratic faction will urge the Beijing authorities to consider the implementation of direct elections in districts on and above the prefectural level, to permit private enterprises to run media operations such as newspapers and TV stations, and to engage in political negotiations with Taipei on an equal basis, the daily said, citing a copy of the proposal it obtained.
In view of mainland China's current monolithic political system, however, the Beijing authorities are unlikely to adopt the proposal, the daily noted.

The proposal, titled "China Must Be Transformed -- Opinions of the Democratic Faction," contains sections pertaining to politics, the economy, foreign affairs, culture and the reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The proposal was written by Fang Jue, 43, a graduate of Beijing University, who was a staff member of the Institute of Political Science of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences and worked under Yen Jiachi, who later on became a theoretician in mainland Chinese democratic movement. Members of the Chinese Communist Party in both the central and local governments also took part in the document's preparation, the news report said.

Concerning the Taiwan issue, the proposal deems that the central governments in Beijing and Taipei are of equal status according to international law. It also declares that Beijing should respect the choice of Taiwan residents, renounce the use of force against the island and proceed with political negotiations with Taipei on an equal basis.

In regard to the issue of Tibet, Beijing should offer the region adequate self-rule, allow the Tibetans to select directly their own administrators, the proposal says, adding that it would be better for the Beijing authorities to discuss the matter with the Dalai Lama.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved 1 percent higher on the Taiwan stock market Thursday, as the greatest flow of capital shifted to financial shares from the technology sector.
According to dealers, investors turned their attention to banking stocks because the mainstream high-tech issues had moved quite high over the past few days.
The weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) surged 86.6 points to close at 8,800.02.
The bourse, which opened at 8,805.16, experienced a high of 8,831.12 and a low of 8,767.5.
Gainers surpassed losers 223 to 188, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 3.22 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$219.28 billion (US$6.64 billion) in the three-hour session.

Financial issues registered the largest gain, at 2.6 percent, followed by a 0.7 percent rise for paper-making shares, 0.6 percent for electrical engineering shares, 0.4 percent for textile stocks and 0.1 percent for plastic and chemical shares.
Cement shares dropped 0.7 percent and construction stocks lost 0.2 percent. Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor, China Development, ACER, Macronix International, Yageo, Pacific Electric Wire, GVC Corporation, Chuntex Electronic and Mitac International.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAPS OUT CONTINGENCY PLANS FOR OVERSEAS CHINESE IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew of the Republic of China said Thursday at a meeting of the Executive Yuan that contingency plans should be mapped out as soon as possible for the safety of overseas Chinese living in Indonesia.

Scattered protests against rising prices on the islands of Java, Sumbawa, and Sulawesi have turned into riots and Chinese shopkeepers have often been attacked in the riots because of their wealth since Saturday.

In the meeting Siew asked the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, and other relevant government agencies to get contingency plans ready for the safety of overseas Chinese living in that country.
Siew also asked the government agencies to monitor the situations there very day.
Taiwan investments in Indonesia have amounted to US$13.2 billion, he pointed out , adding that large numbers of Taiwan tourists are visiting that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-CANADA SCIENCE COOPERATION MEMORANDUM APPROVED

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan Thursday approved a memorandum signed between the National Science Council (NSC) and its Canadian counterpart for cooperation in scientific and technological research and development.
Under the five-year memorandum, the two organizations will exchange information in science and technology, exchange visits by scientists and technologists, and cooperate in researches.

The memorandum was signed in Taipei by officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Canada and the trade office of Canada in Taipei on behalf of the NSC and the national research committee of Canada in October, 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN FOREIGN MINISTER TO GREET WEI JINGSHENG

TEXT.P: Canada's Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy is scheduled to greet exiled mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng at his parliamentary office Thursday.

Wei, who arrived from New York Wednesday night, said he will urge Axworthy to show the Canadian government's concern about human rights and democracy in mainland China. Wei and his American secretary were warmly welcomed at the airport by leaders of several Canadian private organizations.

Organizers of Wei's schedule in Ottawa said he will "probably" be introduced by the House of Commons speaker to the floor when he visits a House session in the afternoon. He is expected to receive a warm welcome at the House, they added.
Wei will then give testimony at a meeting of the parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, during which Members of Parliament of different parties will have a chance to ask him questions.

Following that, Wei will meet with official opposition leader Preston Manning. The Reform Party leader is expected to brief reporters on their discussions. The leader of the ruling Liberal Party and Prime Minister Jean Chretien, however, is said to have declined a meeting with Wei.
In the evening, Wei will give a public lecture at Carleton University.

During his two-day stay in Ottawa, Wei will also be interviewed by major Canadian media. He is scheduled to proceed to Toronto on Saturday, from which he will fly to Vancouver for another two-day visit before concluding his first Canadian tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND SHIPPERS MEET IN BANGKOK

TEXT.P: Shipping tycoons from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are quietly meeting in Bangkok to discuss some practical issues concerning cross-strait shipping services, sources close to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported on Thursday.

Shieh Ming-hui, director of the MOTC's Navigation Department, and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Hu Hanxiang, are also attending the meeting as senior advisers to the Taipei-based Taiwan Strait Shipping Association and the Beijing-based Association for Shipping Across the Taiwan Strait, respectively, the sources said.
Shieh is expected to make a public report on the outcome of the Bangkok conference after he returns to Taipei on Friday, the sources said.

The meeting between senior executives from the two private shipping associations on both sides of the Taiwan Strait was originally scheduled to be held in Hong Kong before the Chinese New Year holiday. The two sides later decided to change the venue to Bangkok because Hong Kong is now under mainland China's rule.

Major topics to be discussed at the meeting include issues related to operations of the offshore cross-strait transshipping services and other practical cross-strait shipping problems, the sources said.

Local shipping companies have complained that mainland China has delayed in allowing major Taiwan shipping firms like Yangming Marine Transport Corp., Uniglory Marine Corp. and Evergreen Marine Corp. to operate scheduled cross-strait shipping services.

"We hope mainland delegates will explain why mainland authorities would not issue operating permits to the three Taiwan firms," an MOTC official said, adding that Taiwan hopes mainland authorities will make public their screening principles.
In addition, the official said, Taiwan delegates will urge mainland China to open more mainland ports for offshore direct cross-strait transshipping services.

Mainland China has only opened two relatively small ports -- Fuzhou and Xiamen -- in its southeastern Fujian Province for direct cross-strait transshipping services. Local shippers have long urged mainland authorities to open its major ports, such as Guangzhou, Shanghai, Dalien, Qingdao and Tianjin, for such services to help increase their shipping volume.

Taiwan still bans direct cross-strait shipping services. All commercial ships are required to make a stopover at a third place before coming to Taiwan from the mainland or vice versa. Nevertheless, Taiwan has opened its Kaohsiung Harbor for offshore direct cross-strait transshipping services, under which mainland goods can be transported to third places via Kaohsiung and vice versa.
In an attempt to pressure Taiwan to open full-fledged direct cross-strait shipping services, mainland China has imposed strict restrictions on offshore cross-strait transshipping services.

Meanwhile, mainland delegates reportedly will ask their Taiwan counterparts to explain Taiwan's regulations governing foreign-registered mainland vessels operating shipping services across the Taiwan Strait via a third place.

The Beijing-based China Ocean Shipping Co. (COSCO) has filed an application with the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau for operating the Kaohsiung-Hong Kong-Shekou-Japan-US West Coast shipping route. The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau has not approved the application because Taiwan still bans mainland-registered ships from entering its ports. The mainland company must file its application in the name of its Hong Kong affiliate, MOTC officials said.

Local press reports said Taiwan may approve COSCO's application in exchange for Beijing's early permission of three Taiwan firms -- Yangming, Uniglory and Evergreen -- to operate cross-strait transshipping services. But the premise is that the mainland firm files its application through its Hong Kong affiliate.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS-INFECTED HEMOPHILIACS ASK FOR NATIONAL COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: A group of local hemophiliacs who have contracted the deadly AIDS virus from injections of contaminated blood products filed applications with the Department of Health (DOH) on Thursday for national compensation.

The victims demanded that the government compensate each of them NT$8 million (US$244,648) for its negligence in handling the case. They blamed National Taiwan University Hospital's hemophilic center for failing to inform them of their infection of the AIDS virus in time and the DOH for delaying in taking precautionary measures.

A total of 53 local hemophiliacs contracted the virus after receiving injections of contaminated Factor Eight blood products between 1983 and 1985. Twenty-two of them already died of the deadly disease.

American authorities in 1983 ordered that all blood products should be heat-treated immediately after encountering the first case of a hemophilia patient becoming infected with AIDS from an injection of blood products. However, the DOH failed to comply with the directive until 1985. The two-year time lapse ultimately victimized the 53 local hemophiliacs.

The victims have decided to ask for national compensation after a major foreign supplier of the contaminated blood products agreed to compensate each of them only NT$1.2 million (US$36,697), far lower than the DOH-proposed NT$2 million.

Most of the tainted blood products were imported from Germany's Bayer Co. A Bayer spokesman said the NT$1.2 million damage award is caculated in accordance with German standards. Some of the contaminated products were supplied by another foreign firm.

Legislator Yeh Chu-lan said the compensation offered by Bayer was too low compared with an equivalent to NT$12 million offered in Japan for similar cases, or US$100,000 in the United States and 100,000 sterling pond in Britain.
DOH officials said late last year the department would help local hemophiliacs negotiate with Bayer for compensating each victim at least NT$2 million.

As the negotiations failed to produce favorable results, the DOH said on Thursday it will consider filing lawsuits against the foreign suppliers of the tainted blood products on behalf of the victims. It also promised to exempt the surviving victims from paying any premium under the National Health Insurance Program and to offer them other services and assistance.
As legal procedures take much time to complete, some observers said the DOH should first offer a sum of money to each victim and then seek compensations from foreign blood products manufacturers.

Legal experts also said it remains uncertain whether the AIDS-contracted hemophiliacs can succeed in obtaining national compensation. They suggested that the victims negotiate with relevant government agencies before seeking compensation through legal procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPELLED DISSIDENT PREDICTS REVOLUTION IN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A prominent mainland Chinese dissident exiled in the United States predicted on Wednesday that a popular revolution will take place in mainland China soon and that an opposition party formed by mainland dissidents scattered around the world will emerge there.

Wang Bingzhang described the Chinese Communist Party as a "big pus-filled boil," and said a revolution led by the people of the mainland will soon break out there. The future leadership of mainland China will not be the communist party or the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang, but an opposition party composed of mainland democracy activists now living throughout the world, he added.
Wang made the remarks at a news conference in Oakland, California, after arriving from Shanghai via Los Angeles.

Wang, 50, a noted dissident who founded the pro-democracy publication "China Spring" and lives in exile in the US, sneaked into mainland China on Jan. 23 under an assumed name. He was expelled by mainland authorities on Monday after being caught in central Anhui province last Friday.

The purpose of his return to mainland China was aimed at forming an opposition political party, he said, adding that most mainland Chinese people only know life under the communist party and that it is very important to forge a new political force there.
Wang said he was able to complete six or seven mission objectives during his mainland visit.

He called on all mainland dissidents residing overseas to work hand-in-hand with democratic forces in the mainland and to provide their mainland counterparts with financial support, warning that otherwise, mainland China's pro-democracy groups based overseas will lose their links with mainland democratic forces at home.
Wang also strongly criticized mainland China's human rights abuses, claiming that his arrest and swift release by mainland authorities was without any legal basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TIMES PUBLISHES SPECIAL REPORT ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Japan Times, the largest English-language newspaper in Japan, published a six-page special report Thursday on Taiwan's economic development
The report, titled "World Eye Report on Taiwan: Little Island, Big Future," was the fruit of 14 weeks of coverage in Taiwan, beginning early last September, by two Japan Times reporters.

The report features interviews with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Republic of China's Council for Economic Planning and Development, and 18 leaders in Taiwan's economic, financial and insurance sectors.

Chiang told the Times that the Southeast Asian currency crisis has had only a limited effect on Taiwan's economy because Taiwan's economic fundamentals are sound, with the world's third-largest foreign reserves and an economic growth rate of about 6.6 percent, the highest among Asia's four "tigers."

Asked about Taiwan's primary economic strengths, Chiang elaborated on four major points: the island's superior geographic location, wealth of human resources, steady and substantial economic growth, and strong industrial foundation and vigorous entrepreneurship.

Referring to Taiwan's weaker areas affecting its economy, Chiang also cited four points: insufficient liberalization and internationalization, insufficient infrastructure and low efficiency of resource allocations, a labor shortage, and low government efficiency.
He noted the ROC government has launched an initiative to promote national development into the next century and enhance the nation's competitiveness.

The plan to develop Taiwan as an Asia-Pacific regional operations center is very important, Chiang stressed. The plan involves setting up six specialized operations centers with the ultimate goal of developing Taiwan into a "science and technology island" and upgrading its international competitiveness, he added.

Also among those interviewed in the special report are George Hsu, president of Evergreen Marine Corp. (Taiwan); Ming Chien, chairman of First International Computer; Michael McKelvie, president of Ford Lio Ho Motor Co.; and Lee Wen-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Cooperative Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERAL COUNTRIES STUDYING S'PORE'S AID-INDONESIA PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: A proposal by Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong to establish a multilateral scheme to kick-start the Indonesian economy through its importers and exporters is being studied by several countries, The Straits Times reported Thursday in a dispatch from Jakarta.

Demonstrating its commitment, the Singapore government has pledged a maximum of US$2.5 billion to underwrite an Indonesian trade finance guarantee facility, according to a proposal paper obtained by The Straits Times.
The Singapore money would come from the US$5 billion it has already offered Jakarta under a US$43 billion aid package supervised by the International Monetary Fund.

The paper -- written by the Indonesia country manager of the ABN-AMRO Bank of the Netherlands, C.J. de Koning, in consultation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) -- was sent to several governments last Saturday, sources said.
The recipient countries included Indonesia's major trading partners -- Japan, the United States, Australia and Canada, the report said.
The Dutch government is considering joining the proposed Group of Governments being assembled by Singapore to underwrite the scheme. Its proposed maximum contribution is US$1 billion.

When Goh announced the initiative in Jakarta last week after meeting Indonesian President Suharto, he said the scheme could provide the Indonesian central bank with up to US$20 billion in foreign counter guarantees to "unlock" its stalled international trade.

With the rupiah's plunge in recent months, international banks have stopped lending to Indonesian banks, making it hard for Indonesian exporters to find foreign banks that would honor their letters of credit from local banks.
Singapore will put forward a plan for Suharto's approval as soon as possible, Goh said, noting it could take some weeks to bring more countries on board.
Sources said Goh met de Koning, a veteran banker with many years' experience in Indonesia who had floated the idea, before meeting Suharto last Tuesday, according to the report.
The Dutch banker, described by an associate as someone who "loves putting together rescue packages," flew into Singapore for consultations with the MAS the next day, the report said.
In a 10-page proposal paper dated Feb. 6, de Koning outlines an implementation plan that offers the required foreign guarantees while offering the underwriting governments some protection:

-- Bank Indonesia (BI) would select 15-20 banks in which requests for opening letters of credit (LCs) as well as pre-export financing would be concentrated until the "current crisis situation is overcome." These trade finance banks (TFBs) could include foreign banks based in Indonesia.
-- The LCs would be confirmed by selected foreign banks, which would also provide pre-export financing to TFBs.
-- BI would add its own guarantee, covering the risk of failure of any TFB to honor its obligations, to all banks taking part in the scheme for each new trade transaction.

-- A Group of Governments would in turn underwrite BI by adding their counter-guarantees, which would be called upon only if BI fails to honor its obligations. Multilateral organizations can also join the group.
-- For each trade transaction, the foreign governments' counter-guarantee would be split pro-rata according to the maximum risk amounts each government would underwrite.
-- In return, the Group of Governments would receive a risk premium of 0.25 percent per transaction, to be paid by participating banks every quarter to a private clearing corporation to be set up.

-- BI would also have to open special International Trade Finance Accounts in US dollars and other convertible currencies with several foreign banks. Foreign governments would have the highest priority to proceeds in the event of defaults.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTERS CLASH WITH POLICE IN JAKARTA

TEXT.P: At least 150 people, including 14 women and two children, were apprehended during a demonstration Wednesday over soaring prices and taken to Jakarta Police headquarters.
They were among 500 protesters who marched to the Attorney General's Office before heading to the Ministry of Manpower, both in South Jakarta.
The protesters, who called themselves the Red and White National Front, arrived at noon in minibuses and other forms of public transportation,
They demanded the Attorney General's Office take proactive measures to follow up on what the group called mismanagement and misconduct among government officials.

A few representatives were ushered into the ministry's office, but hundreds of police and military troops foiled the attempts of other protesters to reach the office, closing the complex's front gate. Some protesters also clashed with police prior to reaching the office.
They were later taken to Jakarta Police headquarters for questioning.

The protesters, believed to be supporters of the ousted leader of the Indonesian Democratic Party, Megawati Soekarnoputri, held a demonstration in front of the central bank building in Central Jakarta on Monday.
Meanwhile, college students in North Sumatra and Central Sulawesi staged massive demonstrations Wednesday demanding the government do more to bring down prices of basic goods.
In Central Sulawesi, hundreds of students took to the streets of the capital Palu, carrying posters and chanting slogans demanding prices be lowered.
They marched to the provincial legislative council offices, where they read out their demands, the Antara news agency reported.
The demonstration prompted many shops in the city to close Wednesday because the owners were worried the protest would turn violent.
In Medan, the capital of North Sumatra, a similar protest took place at the Sumatra Utara University campus.
The students included political reform, abolition of the subversive law, the election of a new president and action against corrupt bureaucrats in their demands.

Demands for lower prices was also the theme of activists at Yogyakarta's Indonesian Islamic University. They urged Armed Forces Commander Gen. Feisal Tanjung to take punitive measures against people hoarding basic commodities.
Business activities in the East Nusa Tenggara town of Ende slowly resumed, although many ethnic Chinese traders who lost their property in Sunday's riot remained in hiding Wednesday.

Police have detained three people on charges of instigating the riot Sunday in which 21 shops were burned to the ground and 71 others damaged. Most of the affected premises were owned by entrepreneurs of Chinese descent.

Lay Ming, 46, who lost her shop and everything else except the clothing she was wearing, called on the authorities to investigate the incident. She said she believed the cause was "more than just the rising prices."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERMEN TO FACE TRIAL IN SOMALIA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan ship's captain and his 27 crewmen, accused of illegal fishing in Somali waters in the Indian Ocean, will face trial by a Somali Islamic court next week, the Republic of China Foreign Ministry said on Thursday.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said that the vessel's owners -- the Far Eastern Shipping Company -- have not contacted the Foreign Ministry to ask for help. The ministry will order its officials stationed in Saudi Arabia to extend the necessary assistance if required, he added.
Wu noted that the company has employed lawyers in Somalia to defend the men.

On Wednesday, AFP reported that the trial will be conducted by a Somali factional Islamic court on Feb. 15, and if found guilty, the crewmen will face penalties ranging from fines to whipping or amputation of a hand.
The trawler with six Taiwan nationals and 22 mainland Chinese fishermen on board was captured on Jan. 12 by three armed Somali speedboats and the crew has been in custody since then.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO DEBATE ITS 'CHINA POLICY'

TEXT.P: The seminar that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party will open Friday on the party's policy on mainland China is attracting widespread interest both here and abroad, political analysts said here Thursday.
The seminar will provide a forum for an open and unprecedented debate on the question of cross-strait relations, they said.

During the three-day seminar, participants will focus on three main themes: the impact of the post-Cold War new world order on Taiwan-mainland China relations, strategic planning for consultations and interaction across the Taiwan Strait, and the development of cross-strait trade and possible changes after both sides formally enter the World Trade Organization.

The participants can be divided roughly into two camps. Hsu Hsing-liang, DPP chairman and the head of the party's Formosa faction, will advocate a "westward expedition," meaning a more daring attitude toward trade with mainland China.
Another group, the non-Formosa faction, will advocate a gradual approach toward the mainland, similar to the government's "no haste, be patient" policy.

The DPP has often been criticized for lacking a clear-cut, concrete policy toward mainland China. Moreover, major DPP factions are far apart on a number of mainland-related issues, including whether the two sides should hold political talks or establish direct trade, transport and postal links, commonly known as the "three links."

In the wake of its landslide win in last November's mayoral and county magistrate elections, the DPP's prospects for becoming Taiwan's ruling party have improved. To prove that the DPP is capable of being a ruling party, participants in the seminar will inevitably debate the biggest issue Taiwan faces today: cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC HEAD DEPARTS FOR INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Y.D. Sheu departed for Indonesia on Thursday to attend the 33rd annual conference of the heads of Southeast Asian central banks.

CBC Deputy Governor Patrick C.J. Liang said the four-day meeting will run until Sunday on the island of Bali, during which Sheu will exchange opinions on the current regional financial situation and regional countries' monetary policies with his Southeast Asian counterparts.

The CBC attaches great importance to the conference, Liang said, adding that his bank hopes to use the meeting to further strengthen relations with the central banks of the other participating countries.
The annual gathering of the heads of Southeast Asian central banks began in 1966 and the CBC joined the grouping in 1992, according to Liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING GUINEA BISSAU PM MEETS WITH PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: Visiting Guinea Bissau Prime Minister Carlos Augusto Correia met with Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday, the third day of his five-day official visit.
Lee welcomed Correia and his entourage, and said he hoped his visit, as well as the cooperation between the two countries, will further consolidate bilateral ties.

Lee told Correia that he is always interested in the development of the ROC's allies, saying that whenever he makes overseas trips, he takes pains to understand the host country's situation through on-site inspections, and then initiates cooperation proposals based on his observations.
Only in this way can the purpose of his overseas trips be fully realized, the president said.
Noting that long-lasting bilateral ties should be based on mutual benefit and prosperity, Lee promised to provide Guinea Bissau with aid, and to encourage Taiwan business people to invest there.
After nearly two decades of struggle for full independence, Correia said that Guinea Bissau now devotes most of its efforts to developing its agriculture while stabilizing its political situation.

In order to attract foreign investment, Correia said, Guinea Bissau has promulgated a set of rules which grant favorable treatment to foreign investors. He welcomed Taiwan businesses wishing to venture into the West African country.

Correia's presidential visit was made in the company of ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Secretary-General of the National Security Council Ding Mou-shih, and Deputy Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Su Chi.
Correia and his ten-member entourage are scheduled to leave Taiwan on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE WANT A CAUTIOUS DPP MAINLAND POLICY: POLL

TEXT.P: Most of the people of Taiwan expect the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to adopt a cautious stance when forging its own policy toward dealing with mainland China, the results of a survey made public on Thursday indicate.

The poll carried out by the mass-circulation China Times daily newspaper shows that 51 percent of the respondents hope the pro-independence DPP will be careful when working out its mainland policy and that the party will adopt a softer and less confrontational position on the issue, compared with 14 percent who voiced support for a stronger stance against mainland China.

The DPP is gearing up for another victorious showing in year-end legislative elections following its resounding win in last year's elections for provincial-level county magistrates and city mayors. However, a daring "go west" mainland policy advocating closer mainland ties which was raised recently by DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang has provoked heated debate among the different factions within the party.
The DPP is scheduled to hold a seminar on Friday to discuss its approach towards mainland China.

Although the DPP's victory in last year's local elections boosted its hopes of becoming the ruling party in the near future, only 26 percent of those polled were aware that the party will debate the stance and course of its mainland policy on Friday, while 43 percent said they knew nothing about such a debate, according to the survey.

When asked about whether they have confidence in the island's leading opposition party if it gains the majority in the legislature, 27 percent said they are worried about such a result, while 27 percent said it makes no difference to them and 19 percent said they would welcome such a development.
According to the survey, the prime reason behind the public's worry about the DPP's ability as a ruling party centers around its ambiguous mainland policy and its pursuit of Taiwan independence.

The survey found that 42 percent of the respondents are concerned that the DPP's pro-independence stance will irritate the Chinese communists, while 26 percent said they think the DPP lacks the experience to be Taiwan's ruling party. Some 9 percent said they think the DPP lacks the talent to rule the country, while 1 percent said they fear the DPP will stir up ethnic confrontation and is a violence-prone party.

On future relations between Taiwan and mainland China, 45 percent are in favor of maintaining the status-quo and about 19 percent hope for eventual unification with the mainland, in contrast to 12 percent who wish independence for the island.
The telephone survey was conducted on Tuesday, sampling 777 people islandwide, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3.6 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: THUMBS-UP FOR BAYER'S SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL EFFORTS

TEXT.P: A fact-finding delegation that recently returned from a visit to the headquarters of the chemical giant Bayer in Dormagen, Germany, on Thursday gave a thumbs-up to the efforts made by the company in implementing measures for industrial safety and environmental protection.

Lin Ming-lin, speaker of the Taichung County Council, said at a press conference attended by eight members of the delegation that they were impressed by the well-managed Bayer factory, adding that the visit has given them a really deep understanding of how Germany endeavors to upgrade industrial safety and environmental protection regulations.

Lin said that he and several other county councilors who were also part of the government-led delegation, made the most of the five-day visit to learn about the safety precautions and operations in the chemical plant because they wish to find out the best options for Taichung County, where Bayer has proposed to build a plant for the production of toluene di-isocyanate (TDI).

Saying he hopes the first-hand and detailed information the delegation brought back from Germany can serve as a reference for Taichung County to decide if it wants the investment project, Lin called on the residents of the Taichung Harbor area to focus on the issues of industrial safety and environmental protection. They should equip themselves with a better understanding of the project before voicing their support or opposition, Lin said.

He also called on the central government and the Bayer Group to be more patient, adding that they should open more channels of communication to give the residents of Taichung Harbor a better understanding of the investment project.

The fact-finding delegation, composed of more than 30 local opinion leaders, academics and government officials, was led by Y.S. Liu, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development. They left for Germany on Feb. 4 and returned to Taiwan on Tuesday.

During the visit, Bayer representatives told the delegation that the company might change its mind and continue with the investment project in Taichung Harbor if the Taiwan Provincial Assembly approves the land lease contract for Bayer by the end of this month. Bayer in December announced it was suspending its first investment project in Taiwan in the face of strong objections from local residents.

As part of efforts to win the support and trust of the residents of Taichung Harbor, the company also made several pledges to local communities if the project is allowed to go ahead, among which are promises to employ local people, to ensure that Bayer executives will live inside the harbor area close to the plant and to ensure the production facilities are built in accordance with German parent company regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRADE MAPS OUT BARGAINS IN KOREA, TAIWAN AND HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The Australian Trade Council (Austrade) is seeking to establish a A$20 million venture capital fund to help Australian investors cash in on bargain-priced Korean assets in the wake of the recent financial crisis.
Austrade officials said it is good timing to invest in strategic industries in Korea so that Australian companies can buy the Korean companies at cheaper prices and penetrate the Korean market.
They said investment in Taiwan and Hong Kong is also good because Taiwan remains buoyant and Hong Kong is on the rebound following the Asian currency crisis.
But they cautioned against investment in mainland China, saying, "We are waiting to see what medium-term effects the crisis will have on China."
They also said the time is not yet ripe for investing in Indonesia and Thailand because recovery will be slow and further economic turmoil could occur in either country.

The Austrade officials also discouraged investment in the Philippines and Malaysia, saying the forthcoming presidential elections in the Philippines could bring uncertainty as it is possible that populist policies will be reintroduced there.

They said Malaysia has taken a "reality check" and the market turmoil has peaked, but there could be more bad news on the corporate front and, as in most of Asia, the outlook for the building and construction sector is particularly gloomy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAUDED FOR HELPING CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN SOUTH AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An American conservationist has praised Taiwan's decision to present a plane to South Africa to help in that country's conservation efforts.
Robert Cleaves, president of the Los Angles-based Wilderness Conservancy, said the move showed Taiwan's commitment to conservation has not been affected by politics.
South African President Nelson Mandela announced in late 1996 that Pretoria would switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing at the end of 1997.

Despite this, the government of the Republic of China on Taiwan announced in 1997 that it would donate US$110,000 for the purchase of a used six-seat plane. The Cessna U206F will be presented to Kruger National Park in June after renovation work on it in the United States is completed in March.
Taiwan also presented a smaller single-engine plane to anti-poaching rangers in Kruger National Park in September 1996.

Cleaves said he had worried that the ROC government might renege on its pledge to send the plane after the severance of the diplomatic ties between Pretoria and Taipei, but that he was not surprised to learn of Taipei's decision.
The move shows the good will of the ROC, he said, adding that he hopes the action is widely publicized so people will know what Taiwan has done.
As when the first plane was donated in 1996, there will be a public presentation ceremony for the Cessna U206F. US news media, including CBS, are planning to cover the donation, according to Cleaves.

The second plane will be used to help transport anti-poaching personnel and to send them needed supplies so that they can remain in the field longer. Kruger National Park is about two-thirds the size of Taiwan.
The Cessna will also fly animal conservation specialists and volunteer doctors and nurses to remote regions in South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF-LED DELEGATION TO VISIT BEIJING NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Lee Ching-ping, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), will lead a Taiwan delegation to visit Beijing on Feb. 16, more than a month after the originally scheduled departure date.

According to SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-you, the SEF-led mission, to be composed of government, political and academic figures in Taiwan, is scheduled to visit Beijing Feb. 16-20 and Shandong Province Feb. 21-24.

Although he described the nature of the visit as "purely scholarly," Shi said Lee and his party "will meet people they should meet," including officials at Taiwan affairs offices and experts at Taiwan research institutes in mainland China.

Shi said the Taiwan delegates will exchange views with their mainland counterparts on a wide range of topics during the visit, which the SEF is describing as a routine exchange of activities across the Taiwan Strait and not something necessarily aimed at negotiations.

Other members of the delegation will include Pao Tsung-ho, a research counselor at the National Unification Council and professor at National Taiwan University; Professor Chou Yu-jen of National Chunghsing University; Professor Yang Nian-tzu of National Sun Yat-sen University; Wu Hsin-hsing, a consultant member of the Mainland Affairs Council; Yen Wan-ching, director of the Chinese Affairs Department of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party; New Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang; and some SEF officials.

The delegation was previously invited by mainland China's National Taiwan Research Association to come to Beijing on Jan. 12. The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, the SEF's counterpart in Beijing, however, suggested that the visit be postponed until after the Lunar New Year holidays, explaining that relevant mainland agencies would be too busy to be hosts to the Taiwan visitors before Chinese New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN OFFICE ACCELERATING SERVICES TO TAIWAN VISITORS

TEXT.P: With direct shipping links between Russia and Taiwan beginning this month and direct aviation links to follow in March, the Russian liaison office in Taipei is taking on more staff to help accelerate visa and other relevant services to people on the island.

Under concerted efforts with the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the Russian liaison office here will soon be capable of issuing visas to Taiwan residents in two working days, according to James Wang, director of the MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs.

About one month after Taipei and Moscow signed a bilateral shipping agreement in Russia on Jan. 9, the first Russian cargo ship reached the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung on Feb. 10, marking a new era of shipping links between Russia and Taiwan.

The maritime transport link allows Taiwan and Russian traders faster and much more economic operations between the two sides, Wang said, noting that it takes only five days for vessels to reach Taiwan from the ice-free port of Vladivostok in eastern Russia.

The new sea route also allows Taiwan shippers to take advantage of Russia's three far eastern seaports, which will allow them access to inner Europe via railways linking Siberia with continental Europe.

It is expected that the new route will help local firms cut their transportation costs and boost trade with Russia and Europe, significantly contributing to economic exchanges between Taiwan and that part of the world, Wang added.
Meanwhile, the first passenger flight between Moscow and Taipei is scheduled for March 31, following the finalization of an ROC-Russian aviation agreement last September.

To mark the landmark aviation link, planes will take off simultaneously from Taipei and Moscow on March 29, with the flight destined for Taipei carrying a Russian delegation that will conduct discussions with relevant ROC authorities on the further promotion of aviation links between the two nations.

Starting March 31, Taipei-based China Airlines will operate two weekly flights to Moscow. The regular flights -- scheduled for every Tuesday and Saturday -- will leave Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 2:25 p.m. and arrive in Moscow at 10:15 p.m. the same day. The aircraft will then take off for a return flight to Taipei after a one-hour stopover, according to Wang.

Taiwan-Russian exchanges in the fields of tourism, trade, the economy, education and culture have surged over the past six years, with both sides committed to enhancing bilateral cooperation in many other sectors.
According to MOFA tallies, two-way trade between Taiwan and Russia reached US$1.2 billion in 1996 and soared to US$1.45 billion the following year, a 17.9 percent increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WON'T DEVALUE YUAN: M'LAND CHINESE VICE PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Vice Premier Li Lanqing has reasserted that Beijing won't devalue the yuan, though he noted that the financial turmoil that has swept most of Asia will inevitably affect mainland China's competitiveness and economic growth.
Li made the remarks here on Wednesday prior to the closure of his three-day visit to Belgium.

Li said at an economic and trade conference here between Brussels and Beijing that the devaluation of the yuan would worsen the Asian monetary crisis and lead to a vicious circle that would bring much more trouble to the Chinese mainland, Asian countries and beyond, according to a report in Thursday's edition of the Free Belgium Times.

Mainland China, which has US$140 billion in foreign exchange, had foreign exports totaling up to US$325 billion last year while enjoying a trade surplus of US$4 billion, he noted, adding that "with all the factors combined, the Chinese yuan faces pressure to appreciate instead of depreciate."

Nevertheless, the daily reported, although mainland China's economy has not yet been hit by the Asian currency crisis, Li confessed that Beijing is waiting and ready for its impact: a loss in the competitiveness of mainland Chinese exports and a decrease in economic growth in particular.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US WTO TALKS 'TOUGH': ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Friday termed the latest talks with the United States on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) as "tough," but vowed to do his utmost to bring the talks to a successful conclusion.

Wang, after speaking by telephone with Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, who is now in the United States for the talks, said negotiations on the service sector and industrial products have been going smoothly, but a wide gap remains over agricultural goods.

Wang, who will leave Saturday for the US for talks with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky, said the WTO consultations were "unfair," adding that demands by WTO contracting parties are always high and the ministry can only do its best to strike the most favorable deal for Taiwan.
But Wang said more delays and additional rounds of talks will only result in fresh demands by the WTO members, which could be even more damaging to Taiwan.
He added that every nonmember of the WTO is anxious to enter into the world trade regulatory body so that they can enjoy the benefits of lower tariffs. Taiwan received WTO observer status in 1992.
The economics minister said the government has to consider the interests of each industry as well as the overall interest of the nation, thus making the talks extremely tough going.
He said the National Pork Producers Council, a powerful lobby group in Washington, has used every channel to influence the US negotiators to exert pressure on Taiwan to pry open its markets.

Sources also said that Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC), chairman of the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee, had sent a message to Stephen Chen, ROC representative in the United States, asking Taiwan to accelerate the pace of its hog imports and to impose a single tariff on imported pork.

Peng Tzuo-kuei, chairman of the ROC Council of Agriculture, said that after days of talks, the two sides have closed the gap on the level of tariffs and quotas for rice and chicken, but the difference on hogs and offal remains wide.
Peng said while Taiwan asked the United States to allow more adjustment time for lowering tariffs on certain agricultural products, the US side has requested reciprocal compensatory proposals.

He said the opening of Taiwan's rice market will be based largely on the "Japanese model," meaning that Taiwan will allow imports in the amount of 4 percent of the local consumption level, or 60,000 tons of US rice annually after its entry into the WTO. Taiwan will allow imports equivalent to 8 percent of domestic consumption, or 130,000 tons of US rice annually, beginning in the 6th year after its WTO accession.

Taiwan has already completed bilateral WTO consolations with 23 contracting parties to the Geneva-based trade body. The United States is one of the three contracting parties that have yet to finalize such talks with Taiwan. The other two are the 15-member European Union and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG ON DEMOCRACY AND HUMAN RIGHTS IN M'LAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Hailed by the Canadian Parliament as "the father of the democratic movement in China," exiled mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng remarked Thursday that democracy and human rights in China as a whole are the best safeguard for the people in Taiwan, Tibet and the mainland.

Wei, who arrived from New York Wednesday night, was warmly welcomed on Thursday by Canada's foreign affairs minister, minister of Asian affairs, members of Parliament and the parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs (CFA). He made the remarks to the CNA correspondent in Ottawa after he gave testimony at a meeting of the CFA.

Wei went a step further in saying that all parties and factions in Taiwan have had contacts with him, and what he hopes most is that he will be "invited jointly by all the parties and factions" in Taiwan. The exact time for such a visit has not been slated, but it will probably come "in the latter half of 1998."
None of the factions and organizations in Taiwan have offered him any material, spiritual or financial support, Wei remarked. He did not say whether he would accept any such support if offered.

Regarding his impression of his contacts with various parties and factions in Taiwan, Wei said that, generally speaking, Chinese on the island of Taiwan want the "ultimate reunification" of China. However, that must be accomplished under the precondition of a political transformation in mainland China. Wei said he personally felt that only under that premise could negotiations for reunification across the Taiwan Strait begin on a sensible footing.
As for the stanch pro-independence stalwarts in Taiwan, Wei observed, they themselves surely know that they can't "pass the point of no return."

Concerning the Tibet issue, Wei said, he basically agrees with the stance of the Dalai Lama, which is to secure human rights for the Tibetans and their right of self-determination in cultural and religious affairs through peaceful dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMIC GROWTH TO SURPASS OTHER WORLD COUNTRIES: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy, which remains relatively unscathed by the economic turmoil in Asia, will post an annual growth this year that will make the world's Top 10 list, an official from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.

If the annual economic growth reaches 6.3 percent this year as widely estimated by local economic think-tanks, the growth will be the second best in the world, behind only mainland China, said Thomas Yeh, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department.

Unaffected by the Asian economic crisis, Taiwan's economy, building on last year's steady performance, is continuing to pick up steam this year, with trade volume booming, its currency stabilized and the drop in the local stock market kept to a minimum, Yeh pointed out.

The CEPD has set the annual growth target for 1998 at 6.7 percent, Yeh noted, adding however that real growth is expected by CEPD researchers to come in at 6.3 percent or above. The discrepancy arises because local commodity prices will remain unpredictable as the fluctuation of the New Taiwan dollar against the US dollar during the rest of 1998 is unclear. The NT dollar-greenback exchange rate will remain the key factor influencing the island's economic stability this year, Yeh added.

By comparison, two local private economic think-tanks -- the Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research and the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research -- predicted that the island's economic growth will top 6.37 percent and 6.25 percent, respectively, this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU TO VISIT SIX AFRICAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu of the Republic of China will leave for six African countries Saturday.

Hu, who visited Senegal, Swaziland, and Malawi earlier this year, will leave Taipei again on Feb. 14 for a week-long trip to Chad, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso.

His trips to the African countries are seen by analysts as a step to enhance Taiwan's relations with those countries after South Africa and the Central African Republic switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in the past few weeks.
President Lee Teng-hui is expected to visit certain African countries in March or April.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S SEMINAR ON POLICY TOWARD MAINLAND CHINA OPENS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opened a three-day seminar on policies toward mainland China Friday in Taipei.
During the seminar, leaders of the party's major factions will participate in three sessions of debates.

The topics of the debates are "the influence of the new international political order on the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China during the post-Cold War era," "strategic planning for bilateral consultations and interaction between Taiwan and mainland China," and "the challenge to and the appropriate policy of a World Trade Organization member country."

Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who is a leader of the opposition party, said Friday that the DPP's platform for Taiwan independence and its position that Taiwan's future shall be decided by the people of Taiwan in a referendum are the mainstream opinions of the party, which will not be changed in any way by the debates in the seminar.

Chen, who is not a participant in the debates, told the press that Taiwan is a sovereign country independent of the People's Republic of China. It is true that there is a country on either side of the Taiwan Strait, he said, adding that "Taiwan is absolutely not a vassal or a part of any other country."

Speaking at the opening ceremony, DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang expressed the hope that the debates may help the ruling and opposition parties of the country reach a consensus on the country's policies towards mainland China.
Some 200 news reporters, government officials, representatives of foreign countries, as well as leaders of other political parties are also attending the seminar as observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: HELMS ASKS TAIWAN TO OPEN ITS PORK MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: American pig farmers have mobilized Sen. Jesse Helms to speak for them in their attempt to get the Republic of China on Taiwan to open its market to their products.

Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, on Thursday sent a letter to Stephen Chen, ROC Representative to the United States, urging Taiwan to speed up the liberalization of its pork market.
