Helms, known as a long-time friend and supporter of the ROC, said in the letter that he will help Taiwan enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) as soon as possible and recommended that the island open its pork market completely.
Taipei and Washington are now engaged in talks on terms for Taiwan to enter the WTO.

The letter also urged Taipei to enact a tariff based on pork market prices instead of maintaining the island's protection policy. He expressed the US farmers' hope that the tariff will be under 15 percent and that the modified taxation will be reduced on a year-to-year basis.

The letter, which was drafted by the US National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) and signed by Helms, expressed the hope that Taiwan will open its market to US pork soon after the completion of the Taipei-Washington WTO negotiations.
The NPPC, which has some 80,000 members nationwide, enjoys close relations with many members of the US Congress. The United States is one of the largest agricultural exporters in the world.

On March 19, 1997, Helms, from North Carolina, the second-largest pork producing US state, wrote Jason Hu, then Taipei's representative to Washington, about his wish that Taiwan liberalize its farm sector.

Hu responded by asking the senator to understand that because a foot-and-mouth disease epidemic forced the slaughter of most of the island's pigs, Taiwan hog farmers were on the edge of bankruptcy and needed the government's protection.
The NPPC, however, was undeterred and mobilized several dozens of members of Congress to push the US government to press for Taiwan opening its market to US pork.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, and Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., have also recently written Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman to say that the United States should take a tough stand on agricultural issues in its bilateral WTO negotiations with Taiwan, mainland China and Russia.

Some 5,000 angry Taiwan farmers on Wednesday pelted Washington's de facto embassy in Taipei with manure and eggs in protest against the US demand that Taiwan remove its import ban on pork bellies and internal organs in exchange for US support for Taiwan's accession to the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRM, SIKORSKY SIGN BUSINESS ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) of the Republic of China and Sikorsky Aircraft Corp. of the United States signed a memorandum of understanding on Thursday calling for further cooperation efforts.
AIDC Chairman Tsai Chuen-huei and Sikorsky CEO Eugene Buckley inked the document on behalf of the their respective firms at Sikorsky's headquarters in Connecticut.
On hand to witness the ceremony was V.C. Chu, director of the Investment and Trade Office of Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States.
The agreement calls for Sikorsky and AIDC to work together to define programs that further the ROC's aviation industry and fulfill Sikorsky's industrial cooperation efforts.
In addition, Sikorsky agreed to encourage its US subcontractor base to work with AIDC and other Taiwan-based industrial firms to develop similar agreements.
AIDC is an international team member of the S-92 Helibus program, which is being led by Sikorsky. The other team members are firms from Japan, Spain, Brazil and mainland China.

The Taiwan firm is responsible for the design and manufacture of the cockpit section of the medium-lift helicopter, including the flight controls, electrical harnesses and hydraulic lines for the five S-92 prototypes being built at Sikorsky's factory.

Sikorsky has a long history with the ROC military. Both the ROC's Air Force and Navy have had Sikorsky S-70 helicopters in their fleets since the mid 1980s. The US firm has recently been awarded contracts to deliver more S-70 helicopters to the ROC military in the coming two years.
On Oct. 13 last year, Sikorsky became the first helicopter manufacturer in the world to sign a Strategic Alliance with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S PROPERTY, FINANCIAL SERVICES GIANT PUTS BRAKES ON ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia's property and financial services giant, Lend Lease Corp. Ltd., has announced it will dramatically curtail its push into Asia for up to five years because of the region's financial meltdown.

Group managing director David Higgins told reporters Thursday that the company was forced to write down the value of its assets in Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand and mainland China by A$25 million (US$17 million) and cut back staff numbers as it waits for the economic turmoil in the region to subside.

The crisis is also affecting other Australian companies, with construction giant Leighton Holdings Ltd. expected to suffer A$5 million in operating losses on its Asian exposure to building contracts when it announces half-year results to Dec. 31, 1997 next week, property sources said.
Higgins said Lend Lease would defer new opportunities in Asia though remaining confident the slowdown would have a minimal effect on the group.
The group was almost fully hedged against foreign exchange losses, he said.
It will take three to five years before conditions in Asia return to normal, Higgins said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOG FARMERS CONSIDER RELOCATING OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: Under formidable pressure triggered by Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), the island's hog farmers are considering relocating their operations to overseas locations, like Canada, to evade increasing competition from foreign imports and rising production costs.

Taiwan hog farmers are facing unprecedented pressure. First came an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease that ravaged the island's hog population last year. Now comes the WTO negotiations with Washington -- wherein Taipei is likely to agree to the imports of American pork chops, bacon and offals -- which is expected to increase competition in the local pork market.

It is estimated that after markets are opened to US pork products, Taiwan will lose about NT$15 billion (US$455 million) a year in the pork market, and some 5 million hogs will be forced to be cut from the annual production charting board.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's foodstuff producers are expected to suffer an enormous shrinkage of their production after the island becomes a WTO member, with annual production cut back some 50 percent from the current 9 million metric tons worth NT$12 billion (US$364 million) annually.

Canada, which has cheaper hog-raising conditions than the United States, will sponsor discussions on hog farming in the near future to provide Taiwan hog raisers with more economical options for relocating operations there.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG RECEIVES STANDING OVATION FROM CANADIAN HOUSE

TEXT.P: Exiled mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng received a standing ovation from the floor of Canada's House of Commons on Thursday.

"Considered to be the father of the democratic movement in China, Wei Jingsheng started the Xidan Democracy Wall movement in 1979 and was subsequently imprisoned for subversion," Liberal Member of Parliament Colleen Beaumier, chair of the Subcommittee on Human Rights and International Development, said while introducing Wei to the House.

Members of Parliament of all party stripes stood and gave Wei, who rose from his seat in the guest gallery, loud applause that lasted almost a minute. At that time, key members of the ruling Liberal Party, including Prime Minister Jean Chretien and Deputy Prime Minister Herb Gray, were not yet in their House seats. They appeared soon afterward.

Earlier in the day, Canada's Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy and Raymond Chan, secretary of state for the Asia-Pacific region, warmly greeted Wei in the Confederation Building. They talked for over an hour, exchanging views on a wide range of topics focusing on the human rights situation in mainland China.
Both ministers went through the back door of the building for the meeting to escape the horde of reporters waiting to shoot the scene of the two shaking hands with mainland China's top dissident.

After testifying at the parliamentary Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and International Trade, Wei was received by Reform Party leader Preston Manning. Bob Mills, the party's foreign affairs critic, said he would not have behaved like Axworthy and Chan if he were the foreign minister of Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.035 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at NT$32.82.
The greenback opened 32.851, and experienced a low of 32.805 and a high of 33.085.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$495 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan stock market moved 1.1 percent lower on Friday, following drops on the Hong Kong and Tokyo bourses.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index plunged 93.56 points to close at the day's low of 8,706.46.
Trading opened at the day's high of 8,920.24.
Losing issues outnumbered gainers 218 to 199, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 3.62 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$224.87 billion (US$6.863 billion) in the three-hour session.

Among eight major stock categories, paper-making issues moved 1.3 percent higher, followed by a 1.1 percent jump in construction stocks. Textile shares climbed 0.7 percent and cement stocks rose slightly by 0.4 percent.
Electrical engineering shares posted the largest decline of 2.4 percent, financial issues lost 1.0 percent, and plastic and chemical stocks both declined 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff shares remained unchanged.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, ADI, Taiwan Semiconductor, China Development, Pacific Electric Wire, Chuntex Electronic, ACER, Chiao Tung Bank, Shingkong Synthetic Fibers and China Trust Commercial Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOPS DAMAGED, HOUSES TORCHED IN W. JAVA RIOT

TEXT.P: Eight shops were damaged and five houses set ablaze on Thursday when hundreds of people ran amok in Jatiwangi, about 90 km east of Bandung, Indonesia, officials said.
The riot that rocked the town mainly involved hundreds of pedicab drivers and blue-collar workers, who have been hard-hit by the worsening economic crisis, they said.
Residents said the violence started at about 10 a.m. after an hour-long protest by a group of 50 pedicab drivers over a 100 percent increase in the price of pedicab and bicycle tires.
They targeted properties of people of Chinese descent.
There was no word of injuries. Police said 19 rioters were arrested for looting pedicab parts and grocery stores along a main street.
The situation was brought under control at about 1 p.m. after hundreds of police officers and soldiers were deployed, the officials said.
Local military commander Col. Oding Mulyadi, who was on the scene, said that the people's patience was wearing thin over the soaring prices of essential goods.
He said the riot began when the protesters were joined by minivan drivers who had been on strike since Monday, also in protest at rising prices of vehicle parts.

Residents said the rioters "freely" pelted shops with stones, looted the contents and set fire to stores until security personnel arrived. Police said dozens of bicycles were burned together with the shops.
Heavy rain helped put out the fires and prompted many of the rioters to disperse.
West Java Governor R. Nurrians expressed his "deep concern" over the violence.
"The Majalengka regents told me the unrest was sparked by the increasing prices of vehicle parts," he was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying in Bandung.
He said that while he could understand the people's plight he denounced the use of violence to express their desperation.
The riot occurred less than a week after hundreds of people ran amok in the town of Ende, where 21 shops were burned to the grounds and 71 others damaged.
Like the one in Jatiwangi, the Ende riot was started by people angered by the soaring prices of essential commodities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA MOVES TOWARD BECOMING REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Australia is moving toward becoming a republic by the year 2000 or 2001 after republicans emerged as the winners of a poll conducted on Thursday night.
Thus, the monarchist system will be dumped after more than two hundred years, since the continent became a British colony in late 18th century.

Following five rounds of voting, a model proposed by the Australian Republican Movement (ARM) emerged as the winner. The plan envisages that the country's future president will be nominated by community representatives and appointed by a two-thirds majority of both houses of the federal Parliament.

The ARM proposal on Thursday won 75 votes out of the 150 delegates to the Constitutional Convention in Canberra. But those opposed to the ARM proposal also received 71 votes with two members absent and four others abstaining.
Only 43 delegates voted in favor of keeping the constitutional monarchy, which, it now appears, will eventually be dumped.
The preferred model by the ARM, however, will be subject to a series of final votes on Friday to test the level of support for a republic because it failed to win a clear majority.
Core elements of the final model are:
* The community, community organizations and the states are to be asked to nominate candidates for the future president of the country;
* Nominations will not be made public by the government;
* Nominations will be screened by a community committee which will recommend a short list to the prime minister;
* The prime minister will move, and the opposition leader will second, a single candidate who will become president on a two-thirds vote of Parliament; and
* The president can be removed by the prime minister, whose decision must be confirmed by a majority of the House of Representatives.

If the prime minister's decision to remove a president is not confirmed, it will be seen as a vote of no confidence in the prime minister, requiring Parliament to pass a vote of confidence in the same or a new prime minister, failing which an election must be called.

The model which finally emerged from the convention on Thursday followed a series of compromises and modifications to the ARM's original proposal because other republicans, who favored direct popular election of the president, opposed the original idea.

Prime Minister John Howard earlier said the convention must produce a "clear view" and a "clear majority" on a preferred model so that he can put it to a referendum next year that will ask Australians whether they want to embrace a republic.
He said he did not believe Thursday night's vote had handed the republicans an unqualified victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PAINTER HONORED BY FRANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A-San Wu, an avant-garde abstract painter from Taiwan, was awarded a knight of the arts medal Thursday by the French government in recognition of his contribution to art and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and France.
David Cameo, an adviser to the French Ministry of Culture, bestowed the medal on Wu during an award ceremony held at Gallery Trianon in the renowned Park Bagatelle in Paris.

Taipei representative in France Kuo Wei-fan, Deputy Mayor of Paris Francois de Panafieu, Cerif Khaznadar, curator of the Home of World Culture, and other Taiwan and French dignitaries were also present to witness the presentation.

At the invitation of the Home of World Culture and the Paris city government, Wu, 56, who received his formal training from National Taiwan Normal University, will begin a one-month solo exhibition on Saturday at Gallery Trianon. On display will be several of his masterpieces and his personal collection of aboriginal artifacts collected from Africa, Oceania, America and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIOTS IN INDONESIA EASE

TEXT.P: The situation in Indonesia has come under control of the military and police, posing no threat to the personal safety and property of ethnic Chinese and Taiwan businessmen in that country, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOEA) said on Friday.

H.J. Tsai, deputy director of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department under the MOEA, said that riots which broke out recently on the island of Flores over food shortages have not spread to the capital city of Jakarta and that ethnic Chinese remain safe in that country. He said that the military and police units are in control of the overall situation in that country in the run-up to presidential elections slated for March 1.

The MOEA, in cooperation with Taiwan businessmen associations and ROC government outposts in Indonesia, has set up a network of communication in case of any emergency, Tsai said, adding that the MOEA also has contacted Indonesian local authorities in the hope that they will fully protect Taiwan people residing there.
He stressed that the MOEA will maintain close contact with the ROC representative office based in Jakarta, and called for the public here not to worry about the situation in Indonesia.

Tsai, citing information dispatched by the office from Jakarta on Wednesday, said unrest which erupted in other provincial towns has not spread to Jakarta and all protests in the vicinity of the capital were peaceful and took place with government permission.

The MOEA voiced grave concern over the safety of ethnic Chinese in Indonesia on Tuesday following media reports over the weekend that shops run by ethnic Chinese were attacked by rioters on the island of Flores in eastern Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: WU'ER KAIXI TALKS ABOUT DPP SEMINAR ON CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese dissident said here Friday that Beijing leaders must be paying close attention to the seminar on Taiwan's future policy toward mainland China, which is being held in Taipei by the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Wu'er Kaixi, one of the well-known student leaders in the 1989 Tiananmen Square incident, told the press after the first morning session of the three-day seminar that the debates in the seminar may have no clear conclusions, but they may be "the beginning of maturing" in democratization.
Beijing leaders may see the debates as very important to the formation of the opposition party's policy toward mainland China, he said. There are three sessions of debates in the seminar.

He regretted that nobody talked anything about the situation on the Chinese mainland. "You have to understand the situation there, if you want to do a research on policies toward mainland China," he said.

Wu'er, who was wanted by mainland authorities in 1989 for his connection with the Tiananmen incident, said Taiwan could be badly hurt, if it decided to open political talks with the mainland in a haste.
He also pointed out that mainland China is now like the Taiwan of the 1970s. The people on Taiwan should not lose their confidence in the democratization of mainland China in the future, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUICIDE RATE AMONG TAIWAN'S ELDERLY UP

TEXT.P: The suicide rate among the elderly in Taiwan has risen once again, the Department of Health (DOH) said on Friday.

DOH officials said the overall suicide rate in Taiwan peaked in 1981 at 0.129 per one thousand people. They attributed that figure to a series of social transformations in Taiwan at that time which had a great impact upon the local population. The rate has since declined gradually.
But in 1996, the rate rebounded again, due in part to a rise in suicides among the island's elderly.

The officials said that senior citizens over the age of 65 have traditionally registered the highest suicide rate among all age groups. The rate had been in decline over recent years, but jumped to three people per thousand in 1996.

Compared with the United States, Germany, Britain, Italy, Japan, Australia, Singapore, South Korea, and mainland China, only Japan and Singapore have registered a higher rate of suicide among the elderly.
Some commentators have suggested that statistic could be interpreted to mean the elderly in Taiwan lead unhappy lives in the twilight of their years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLEANER, MORE-EFFICIENT HYBRID BUS BEGINS TESTING

TEXT.P: Testing on a revolutionary and environmentally-friendly transit bus -- one of the most advanced in the United States -- began Thursday.
Utilizing a combination of battery and propane power, the hybrid electric bus makes use of the newest technologies for greatly improving fuel-economy, lowering emissions and reducing noise.

The new bus is an important step in the push for cleaner air, higher efficiency and high-tech jobs, according to CALSTART, a non-profit advanced transportation technologies organization. In addition to fewer emissions, the bus incorporates a series of other features that transit users will appreciate, including a flat floor for easy ingress, and quieter, smoother operation, it said.

"The recently signed global warming accords at Kyoto really bring home the need and potential for this type of technology," said Michael J. Gage, president of CALSTART. "Increasingly efficient, clean transportation solutions such as this bus -- ready for deployment today -- clearly show the technical realities this growing industry can deliver."

The bus utilizes a new generation hybrid-electric driveline that greatly reduces pollution, vibration and noise. Two electric motors, producing the equivalent of approximately 180 horsepower, power the bus. An advanced nickel-cadmium battery pack fuels the electric motors and can be charged on demand by a propane-fueled, rotary-engine generator.
The hybrid combination allows the bus to operated in three separate modes.

When operating on batteries alone, the bus produces zero emissions and can travel up to 45 miles. If traction requirements can be met by the battery but accessories -- such as air conditioning, lights or windshield wipers -- are needed, the generator operates in a low-power mode. A high-power mode is also available, which further charges the batteries and is capable of extending the vehicles' duty cycle to a total of 230 miles, depending on terrain.
Running full-time, the generator consumers only 2.8 gallons of propane per hour, offering the hope that this vehicle will be the first of a new generation of city buses, CALSTART said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, GOVERNMENT HAVE HIGH REGARD FOR DPP SEMINAR ON CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang and the government of the Republic of China have a high regard for the opinions being presented in the seminar sponsored by the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on its policy toward mainland China.

Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday that the government has a clear and consistent policy toward mainland China, which is based on the opinions of most citizens, and that the opinions of DPP leaders presented in the seminar will also be seriously considered when new strategies are being mapped out.

Huang Li-ching, director of the Cultural Affairs Department of the Kuomintang Central Committee, made similar remarks when asked to comment on the three-day DPP seminar, which opened Friday morning in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND MAINLAND SHIPPING GROUPS FORGE RECIPROCITY PACT

TEXT.P: Representatives from shipping groups in Taiwan and mainland China agreed recently in Bangkok that the authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should handle shipping-related affairs on the basis of reciprocity.

This means that each side will handle applications from the other for such issues as shipping routes and the establishment of branch offices, according to a written report from the Taipei-based Taiwan Strait Shipping Association (TSSA) which was made available to the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) on Friday.

The TSSA said the Bangkok conference with Beijing's Strait Shipping Exchange Association, which began on Wednesday without prior announcement and ended on Friday, was a social gathering of two private groups aimed only at exchanging views on technical shipping issues.

The TSSA voiced the desire of Taiwan shippers for Beijing to open more ports to Taiwan shipping firms and discussed with their mainland counterparts the necessity of both sides lifting a ban on transshipping via Taiwan for cross-strait shipping services.

The association also explained to its mainland counterpart a privatization program under way at Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor which will lead to a cut in stevedoring costs for shipowners, as well as exchanging views on ways of preventing cross-strait shipping from polluting the seas.

The TSSA delegation, led by its president Lin Sheng-shan, included Shieh Ming-hui, director of the MOTC's Navigation Department, while the mainland delegation included Shieh's mainland counterpart, Hu Hanxiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH WILLING TO ASK FOR COMPENSATION FOR AIDS-INFECTED VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Director-General C.H. Chan on Friday demanded that two foreign makers of blood products allocate a total of NT$160 million as compensation for local hemophiliacs who contracted the AIDS virus after receiving transfusions of their tainted products.

Stressing that the DOH is willing to provide moral support and help local victims seek compensation from the two foreign companies, Chan said that he wants Bayer Co. and the other foreign firm to provide NT$2 million for each of the 53 victims within one week, depositing the money with an impartial third party as a way of showing their sincerity in wishing to resolve the problem.
The DOH will prohibit the import of any new medical products from either of the two firms if they refuse to do so, Chan warned.

According to Chan, the victims are dissatisfied with a NT$1.2 million compensation award proposed earlier by Bayer, adding that the DOH also thinks the amount is far lower than the usual level paid to victims in other countries.
He said the DOH, in compliance with the principle of international fair treatment, has set NT$2 million as a baseline figure in this case.

Of the 53 hemophiliacs who contracted the deadly AIDS virus from transfusions of contaminated blood products between 1983 and 1985, 22 have already died of the disease, while 11 others prefer not to be identified.
Meanwhile, officials from Bayer, which enjoys the largest share of blood products in the Taiwan market, said they will make a formal announcement after internal negotiations have been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA URGES GREATER TRADE COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Djoko Mulyanto, chairman of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei, said on Friday that the situation in Indonesia has improved and that Taiwan businesses should continue with their investments there.

Mulyanto said in a fax sent to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) that the overall situation remains good and stable in Indonesia and that the Indonesian government is working quickly to address all its current problems.

Describing many media reports about the recent situation in Indonesia as "untrue," the Taipei-based chief Indonesian trade official said bilateral Taiwan-Indonesia trade and commercial ties have been close and that the two countries should further strengthen two-way cooperation for their mutual benefit.

Mulyanto's statement came on the heels of remarks made by Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang at a news conference on Wednesday calling on Taiwan businesses to temporarily suspend their investment activities in Indonesia amid a wave of unrest against ethnic Chinese there.
The unrest was sparked by massive price increases for basic foodstuffs prompted by the financial crisis which has swept Asia, hitting Indonesia particularly hard.

Wang described the MOEA as very concerned about the problem and said the Jakarta-based ROC representative office, in cooperation with three Taiwan businessmen's associations, has formed a task force to tackle any emergencies there.

He added that the MOEA has asked the Indonesian government to fully protect Taiwan business interests and that the ROC representative office will help Taiwan businessmen to seek damage compensation from local authorities, under the terms of the investment guarantee agreement signed by the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREAT CHINESE COMMONWEALTH PROPOSED BY FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Shih Ming-teh, former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), on Friday proposed a "Great Chinese Commonwealth" scheme to serve as a model for the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Shih said that as the "Great Chinese Commonwealth," Taiwan and mainland China would be international legal entities of equal status, claiming that his design can not only avoid the eruption of cross-strait war but can also safeguard Taiwan's independent sovereignty.

Shih made the remarks after presiding over the morning session of the DPP's "Mainland China Policy" seminar, aimed at providing a forum to debate the party's future policy towards the mainland. Shih expressed dissatisfaction with the morning discussion, saying that he "cannot listen to them any more," and decided to propose his "Great Chinese Commonwealth" scheme.

Saying that his "Great Chinese Commonwealth" is different from the "Great China Commonwealth" or the mainland-proposed "one country, two systems" scheme, he explained that although the commonwealth itself is an incomplete international legal entity, it is composed of members which are internationally recognized legal entities. The character of the relationships between the member countries shall be defined by the members in a contract, he added.

Shih said that Taiwan can propose to the mainland that the two sides conduct unification talks under the principle of a "Great Chinese Commonwealth," a version similar to the British Commonwealth of Nations. Even if the talks fail to lead to the implementation of a "Great Chinese Commonwealth," Taiwan can at least gain a little more time for itself.

According to Shih, four designs can serve as possible models for the reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- mainland China's "one country, two systems," Taiwan's "unification under the Three Principles of the People," the American federalist system and Britain's commonwealth.

The former DPP chairman claimed that the "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" models are actually seeking Taiwan independence, while the "Great Chinese Commonwealth" model can secure Taiwan's independent sovereignty and also avoid the occurrence of cross-strait conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN UNION WORKING ACTIVELY FOR BEIJING'S WTO BID

TEXT.P: European Union Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan has proposed new ideas on the services sector in talks with mainland China's Vice Premier Li Lanqing about Beijing's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), a Geneva newspaper reported on Friday.

"We have had very good discussions both on the political and economic side of China's relations with Europe," Brittan told a joint press conference with Li during a break in their talks in Brussels, the Tribune of Geneva said.
"We are working actively for China's early membership of the WTO," Brittan was quoted as saying.

Li was quoted as saying that he had a "very candid and friendly exchange of views" with Brittan on the early conclusion of WTO negotiations. "We shared the wish that this matter will be resolved as soon as possible."

Mainland China needs the WTO but the WTO also needs mainland China, because without universal representation, it will be very hard for the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body to play its role," Li was quoted as saying.
Brittan said he had put forward some "specific ideas" for the next stage of accession negotiations, involving market access for trade in services, the paper reported.
Brittan said Europe has to understand that mainland China needs time to implement some of the agreed measures for WTO accession.
He said he also outlined to Li a document under preparation in the European Commission that proposes a new EU policy towards mainland China.
Brittan said the document, expected to be issued in April, will set out the EU's agenda for a more active relationship that will do more to recognize mainland China as a global power.

He also said mainland China's present offers for joining the WTO still fall far short of the necessary conditions for membership but added that he nevertheless believes a deal might be clinched this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL IMPRESSED WITH SEOUL'S DESIRE FOR RAPPROCHEMENT

TEXT.P: Hailing his visit to Seoul as an important step toward rapprochement between Seoul and Taipei, John Chang, visiting secretary-general of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said here on Friday that the two countries have reached a consensus on improving ties.

At a press conference called at his hotel, Chang refused to even name the South Korean leaders he met here, on the grounds of an "understanding" with the host country, let alone the contents of their discussions. However, he did say he was impressed with Seoul's determination to mend fences with Taipei.

He dismissed as "untrue" media reports that the KMT has promised to grant South Korea financial aid to tide it over its financial woes, but added: "We are more than willing to help a suffering neighbor state get through the hardship it faces, but any such deal needs in-depth negotiations. Thus far, there is no such deal or promise."

Knowing that reporters from the mainland-China based Xinhua News Agency and The People's Daily were at the news conference, Chang criticized Beijing's attempts to block Seoul from any contact with Taipei as "unwise."

Although Chang didn't mention the names of the Korean leaders he called on, president-elect Kim Dae Jung was definitely not one of them, because he missed an opportunity to met with Kim at the headquarters of Kim's National Congress for New Politics "by chance."

Chang, accompanied by Korean congressman Soon Se Il, arrived at the headquarters for a courtesy call on its acting president, Cho Se Hyung, at 11:10 a.m., ten minutes after Kim left after receiving visiting Australian media mogul Rupert Murdoch.
Chang arrived here on Wednesday for a four-day visit. He is scheduled to return to Taipei on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO STUDY SOUTHEAST ASIAN STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: In order to help the countries of Southeast Asia to weather the current financial turmoil sweeping the region, a delegation from the Southeast Asian holding company jointly invested in by a number of Taiwan enterprises, will on March 15 start a fact-finding mission to four countries in the region.

The delegation will visit Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia, with the aim of gaining a deeper understanding of the current situation of the listed companies in the stock markets of the four countries, with particular emphasis on the high-tech sector.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), on Friday invited local business leaders to discuss ways of contributing to the improvement of financial stability in the region.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Hu Ding-wu, president of the China Development Corp., Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC and several other business executives were among those present.

Koo said that during the meeting, they decided that the holding company will send a delegation to Southeast Asia to study the stock markets there, adding that as Malaysia currently enjoys the most stable political situation among the four countries, future investment will first target that nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL ROC DELEGATION TO WITNESS BISHOP SHAN'S ELEVATION TO CARDINAL

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China has appointed Secretary-General to the President Huang Kun-huei to lead a delegation to the Vatican on Feb. 19 to attend a ceremony for the inauguration of Cardinal Paul Shan on Feb. 21.

Bishop Shan of the Diocese of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan was elevated to cardinal by Pope John Paul II on Jan. 18, 1998, the first ROC national to be made a cardinal in nearly 20 years following the death of the ROC's former Cardinal Yu Bin.

Shan's new position illustrates the importance the Holy See attaches to the democratic policies, freedom of religion and relations between the Vatican and Taiwan. It also indicates that the Holy See recognizes the great contributions to society, in the form of education, medical care and charity activities, made by the Catholic Church in Taiwan.

Shan has in the past held the posts of principal of a church-funded high school, chairman of the board of directors of Fu Jen Catholic University and bishop of the Diocese of Hualien in eastern Taiwan. Throughout his working life, he has dedicated himself to preaching and charity work, as well as to the reform of the human spirit.
Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih will also lead a 20-member group to the Vatican on Feb. 16 to witness the ceremony.
After attending the ceremony, Wu will proceed on a private visit to Amsterdam in the Netherlands and Barcelona in Spain.
Members of Mayor Wu's group will include Bureau of Social Affairs Director Chiang Chi-wen, Department of Information Director Wu Chien-kuo, City Councilor Lee Fu-hsin and several journalists.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S AFRICAN TRIP TO BE ANNOUNCED BY MARCH 2

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu disclosed on the eve of his six-state African trip that a proposed African trip for President Lee Teng-hui will be finalized and announced no later than March 2.
So far, details of the president's visit are still being worked out by the Foreign Ministry and the potential countries to be included in the visit, and no final decision has been made, said Hu.

He brushed aside questions about whether Guinea Bissau will be included in Lee's proposed trip because of an invitation extended to Lee by visiting Guinea Bissau Prime Minister Carlos Augusto Correia, saying that Lee would like to accept the invitation but no decision has yet been made.
Correia arrived in Taipei on Tuesday and was slated to leave on Saturday.
Hu, who is set to depart on Saturday for his own African trip, said that Lee's itinerary is expected to be finalized after his return on Feb. 23, and will be announced before March 2.

This will be Hu's third trip to Africa since assuming the post of foreign minister in October. The journey will take him to Chad, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CANADA STEP UP MARITIME COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Canada and the Republic of China signed a memorandum on maritime cooperation on Friday to further strengthen exchanges of maritime technology and related affairs between the two countries.
The memorandum, the first of its kind, was jointly inked by chief Taipei representative in Canada Fang Chin-yen and Scott Parsons, Canada's acting deputy minister of fisheries and maritime affairs.
The signing of the memorandum was a follow-up action after the ROC's Ministry of Transportation and Communications and Canada's trade office in Taipei forged a draft memorandum in Taipei on Jan. 19.

Under the terms of the memorandum, the two sides agreed to exchange technology and information relating to maritime positioning systems, navigation, seaport management, global ocean risk and security systems, prevention of oceanic oil pollution, and maritime rescue. The two countries will also swap personnel training programs and technological seminars, with Canada increasing the transfer of maritime technology to Taiwan.
It is widely believed that Taiwan will eventually benefit greatly from the new cooperation pact with Canada, an advanced country in terms of maritime science and related technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONALS MAKE MORE THAN 11 MILLION VISITS TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Republic of China nationals have made more than 11 million applications to visit mainland China over the past 10 years, according to statistics released by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Saturday.
The tallies show that ROC nationals made 11.44 million applications to visit the mainland between 1988 and October 1997.

The ROC government began allowing its people to travel across the Taiwan Strait for family reunions in late 1987, and restrictions on mainland-bound visits have been further eased gradually over the past decade.

According to the statistics, Taiwan residents made 1.56 million applications to travel to the mainland in the first 10 months of last year, an increase of 292,000 applications over the same period of 1996.

In compiling the tallies, the MAC referred to data released by mainland authorities concerning the number of Taiwan people who applied for mainland China entry permits in Hong Kong during the ten-year period.
Meanwhile, statistics released by the Bureau of Entry and Exit show that the bureau approved applications by 58,070 ROC passport holders to visit the mainland in 1997, down 253 from the 1996 level.

MAC officials said the huge gap between Taiwan and mainland tallies resulted mainly from different entry/exit regulations. The ROC now offers three-year multiple entry/exit permits for its ordinary citizens. This means that with the exception of ROC intelligence officers, high-ranking government officials and males nearing the conscription age, local residents do not need to apply for a separate permit to visit the mainland every time. Mainland regulations, however, require Taiwan residents to apply for an entry permit for each individual visit.

MAC tallies also show that 42,491 mainland people were allowed to visit Taiwan in 1997 to meet relatives, up 10,315 persons from the 1996 level. Another 3,242 mainland residents were allowed to settle in Taiwan in 1997, 708 fewer than in the preceding year.
Meanwhile, 1,177 illegal mainland immigrants were seized last year, down 472 from 1996. In 1997, Taiwan managed to repatriate a total of 1,216 mainland stowaways detained over the past few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE SUSPECTS ARRESTED IN MICROCHIP ROBBERY

TEXT.P: Five suspects wanted in connection with a robbery earlier this month of SDRAM (synchronous dynamic random access memory) chips, one of the most widely used microchips in the digital industry, have been arrested, police said on Saturday.
Police received a tip-off that a teenager surnamed Lai was involved in the theft, and arrested him at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport on Friday as he was about to leave the country.

Lai admitted that he and four others posed as police and intercepted a truck loaded with SDRAM chips with an estimated value of US$5 million in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, just a few minutes after they were loaded into the truck in front of the United Test Center (UTC) on Feb. 2.
The five ordered Huang Yun-chang, the 25-year-old truck driver, to pull over for a routine security check.
The suspects forced Huang into a sedan that had been following the truck and two of the robbers then took off in the truck.
Police later arrested the four others, all of whom are gang members with previous convictions for robbery, intimidation and burglary.
Vigilant customs officers ensured that none of the stolen chips made it off the island, and police were able to recover them all in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Police are still investigating to find out if anyone masterminded the robbery.
Meanwhile, UTC officials praised the police efforts and said they were happy to recover all the stolen products -- tailor-made for notebook computer makers in Japan and Germany.

They said they suffered no financial losses because the chips were insured, but they expressed hope that the park administration will step up security to avoid a repeat of the incident, saying that it will damage the interests of the businesses in the park, as well as harm Taiwan's international image.

Wang Kung, administrator of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, said that the park will step up security, adding that in the first half of this year, private security guards will be introduced to work hand-in-hand with the police force in the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, JAPANESE EXPERTS TO TIP TAIWAN MAKERS AGAINST DUMPING CHARGES

TEXT.P: American and Japanese officials have been invited to Taipei to tip Taiwan's business and industrial sectors on how to handle dumping charges from foreign governments, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Saturday.

The MOEA's International Trade Commission (ITC) is scheduled to sponsor an international symposium against dumping March 2-3 in Taipei, with the key speakers including Judith Czako, who is in charge of protocol at the World Trade Organization (WTO); Lynn Featherstone, a section chief at the US International Trade Commission; and an official from Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry.

During the symposium, the foreign officials will speak on a number of topics, including the WTO's anti-dumping agreement, anti-dumping cases concerning US high-tech products and know-how, and how the Japanese government helps Japan's high-tech industry evade dumping charges.

The importance of such a symposium has been highlighted by reports that on Friday the US Commerce Department found Taiwan's leading microchip makers -- United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) and Winbond Electronics Corp. -- guilty of dumping SRAMs and ordered that their sales to the United States be hit with prohibitively high anti-dumping duties.
Winbond is reportedly to receive an anti-dumping duty as high as 102.88 percent on its SRAMs into the United States, while UMC will have an anti-dumping duty of 93.87 percent forced on it.

As one of the world's leading exporters of high-tech products, Taiwan should equip its makers and exporters with sufficient industrial and legal knowledge to meet challenges from competitive nations, ITC officials said, adding that the island's manufacturers are often charged with dumping in an effort to cut Taiwan's competitive edge.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIOTS AT TAIWANESE FACTORY IN LESOTHO KILL TWO, INJURE SEVERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By J.S. Chang & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: A riot in a factory owned by Taiwanese businessmen in the Southern African kingdom of Lesotho on Friday has resulted in the death of two workers and the wounding of more than 40 others.

Workers at the Hsieh An textile factory in the town of Ha-Thetsane, southeast of the capital, Maseru, went on strike a week ago to demand higher pay. The strike turned into a riot when around 1,000 striking workers took the plant management hostage on Thursday night and spent the night at the factory.

By Friday morning the situation had deteriorated further as striking workers threw stones at the factory and attacked people of Chinese origin. One mainland Chinese employed as a worker there was killed, while another mainland Chinese who was part of a medical team was injured in the riot.
A nearby textile factory run by the leader of a local Chinese community, Chang Hsi-chia, was also affected.

Police rushed to the Hsieh An factory on Friday morning. After failing to disperse the violent crowd with an eviction order, they opened fire on the rioters, reportedly killing one female worker and injuring more than 40 others. Six of the injured are said to be in critical condition.

Feng Tai, director of Taipei's liaison office in Johannesburg, said on Friday that, fearing the riot might turn into an anti-Chinese demonstration, the office has contacted leaders of the local Chinese community in Lesotho, asking them to urge Taiwanese businessmen to leave the country immediately for their own safety.

Feng pointed out that according to his understanding, more than 90 of the some 100 Taiwanese businessmen living in Lesotho had already fled to South Africa on Friday following the outbreak of rioting at the factory. Most of them are staying with friends and relatives in the town of Ladybrand, not far from the border, he added.

In 1991, a similar riot and anti-Chinese demonstration prompted almost all of the Taiwanese businessmen in Lesotho to leave the country. Most of them settled in Ladybrand, going to Lesotho to take care of business and returning across the border to Ladybrand at night. After the situation in Lesotho was stabilized, a portion of the Taiwanese businessmen returned to live there.
Feng said that if necessary, he and two other officials will go to Ladybrand or Lesotho to offer assistance to their countrymen.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HELP SRAM MAKERS FIGHT DUMPING CHARGES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will assist Taiwan manufacturers of static random access memory (SRAM) chips in fighting US dumping charges, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Saturday.
Wang made the statement prior to his departure for the United States for consultations on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Wang said he will take advantage of his visit to gain a better understanding of the US stance on the SRAM dumping charges.
"Local SRAM manufacturers may still have an opportunity to defeat the US dumping charges," Wang said, adding that the MOEA will offer them all possible assistance.
The US Department of Commerce (DOC) said on Friday it has delivered a final verdict on dumping charges filed by US-based Micron Co. last March against Taiwan and South Korean SRAM makers.

According to the verdict, the US will impose heavy anti-dumping tariffs on SRAMs produced by nearly all major Taiwan chip makers. DOC Assistant Secretary Roberts Larussa has already signed the verdict, but the DOC won't make a formal announcement until next Tuesday.

Wang said the DOC's verdict has been referred to the US International Trade Commission (ITC) for adjudication. The ITC is scheduled to hold a final public hearing on the case on Feb. 18 and will decide by the end of March whether Taiwan makers have hurt Micron's interests. If the ITC upholds the verdict, Taiwan-made SRAMs will be subject to punitive tariff rates starting in April. The punitive rates range from 7.59 percent to 102.88 percent.
Wang said he will do his utmost to help local chip makers fight the charges and will make their stance known to the US government and their American counterparts during his visit to Washington, D.C.
Wang is expected to meet with senior American trade officials, including US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky, on Feb. 17-18 to seek a major breakthrough in bilateral WTO-related talks.

Taiwan and US negotiators started their 17th round of WTO talks last week. Although they have reached consensus on some technical issues, major obstacles still remain. Wang's participation in the negotiations is expected to help push the two sides closer together on some thorny issues, particularly those related to the farming sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALMOST ALL TAIWANESE BUSINESSMEN FLEE LESOTHO: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Friday that 99 percent of the Taiwanese businessmen living in the Southern African Kingdom of Lesotho have fled the country following the outbreak of rioting at a factory run by Taiwanese businessmen.

Hu said at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport prior to his departure for a six-country African mission that the Foreign Ministry is closely monitoring the latest developments in Lesotho and has ordered ROC officials stationed in South Africa to offer the necessary assistance to their countrymen.

According to reports from Johannesburg, the riot at the textile factory in Lesotho has resulted in the death of two workers. On Thursday night, around 1,000 workers who have been on strike for the last week took the management hostage and spent the night at the factory.

By Friday morning the situation deteriorated further as striking workers threw stones at the factory and attacked people of Chinese origin, resulting in the death of one mainland Chinese employed as a worker there. Police rushed to the scene and in the ensuing standoff, police opened fire on the rioters, killing one female worker and injuring more than 40 others.

At the same time, Hu also once again expressed his concern over the ongoing anti-Chinese demonstrations in Indonesia. The foreign minister said that although the Indonesian government has repeatedly given its assurance that the situation is under control, the Foreign Ministry has worked out plans to help Taiwanese businessmen and their families in the Southeast Asian country in case of emergency.

Hu, who visited Senegal, Swaziland and Malawi earlier this year, will visit Chad, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso in his upcoming week-long tour. He will begin the first leg of his trip in Chad on the night of Feb. 15 and is scheduled to return to Taipei on Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG'S ORIENTAL DAILY NEWS CUTS PRICE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-fen) (By Stanley Cheung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: In an announcement on its front page, the daily said that since the financial turmoil still buffeting Asia is bringing hardships on the people of Hong Kong, it had decided to cut its price to show its concern for the community.
At the end of 1995, the Apple Daily of Hong Kong ignited a sales war of retail price cutting, which led to a series of bankruptcies among some small-scale local newspapers.
Some media entrepreneurs are thus concerned that Friday's announcement may prompt another price war among Hong Kong's newspapers in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK HUMAN RIGHTS GROUP DISCLOSES RELIGIOUS PERSECUTION IN M'LAND
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: While three US religious leaders are visiting mainland China to try to gain a first-hand understanding of the extent of religious freedom there, a Hong Kong-based human rights group has disclosed a document that it says details religious persecution in the Chinese mainland.

According to a document marked "secret" that the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China faxed to a New York-based human rights group on Friday, Beijing is using "loyalty to the (Communist) Party and to the Nation" as a criterion to assess the "legality" of religious activity.
Any religious activity that is not deemed as meeting this loyalty test is regarded as illegal and receives harsh treatment, the Information Center said.
The Hong Kong group said the document came from the office of the Party Committee of Wuxian City, Zhejiang Province, and dates from March 1997.

In order to suppress the activities of Christians, the document says, Wuxian established an ad hoc committee headed by the office of the Party Committee and comprising members from the city's public security organizations, united front work department, propaganda department, judicial organizations, department of civil affairs and other relevant groups.

The document lists methods used to suppress religious activities, including monitoring the activities of believers and collecting information on them, sowing discord and attempting to alienate the believers, prohibiting religious gatherings in homes, confiscating religious propaganda, banning juveniles and Party cadres from joining religious activities, closing down churches built by private organizations, and arresting those having contacts with churches abroad.

The counter-religious activities that took place in Wuxian were part of a wide-scale suppression of religion throughout Zhejiang Province and in accordance with the spirit of the Sixth Plenary session of the 14th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, the document says.

The Information Center said that the secret document shows that religious persecution in the Chinese mainland was not limited to Zhejiang Province in the first half of 1997 but was conducted throughout mainland China as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM EMBARKS ON THIRD AFRICAN MISSION

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu left Taipei on Saturday for his third African mission this year, which will take him to Chad, Guinea-Bissau, Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso.

Hu said that with both South Africa and the Central African Republic switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in the past few weeks, ROC officials should make more visits to the Republic of China's diplomatic allies as part of efforts to strengthen bilateral ties.

Hu, who assumed his current post in October, said that his upcoming week-long tour will serve as an indication of Taipei's goodwill and sincerity toward the countries that maintain diplomatic relations with the ROC.

In mid-January, Hu went to Senegal to preside over a meeting related to his ministry's work in African countries. Not long afterward, he journeyed to Swaziland and Malawi. He will begin the first leg of his current trip in Chad on the night of Feb. 15 and is scheduled to return to Taipei on Feb. 23.

Hu stressed that with mainland China currently exploring trade and economic opportunities in Africa, the ROC should not ignore the continent's huge economic potential. Trade and economic officials should be stationed in these African diplomatic allies to promote relations in every field, he added.

The foreign minister expressed the hope that in the future the ROC's best diplomats will be assigned to countries that maintain diplomatic relations with the ROC so as to increase Taipei's "combat ability on the front line" of the international diplomatic arena.
Hu revealed that he plans to visit Central and South America as well as allies in the South Pacific some time this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: US UPHOLDS DUMPING CHARGES AGAINST TAIWAN'S SRAM MAKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US Department of Commerce (DOC) has delivered a final verdict on dumping charges against Taiwan and South Korean manufacturers of static random access memory (SRAM) chips, the department's International Trade Agency (ITA) said on Friday.

ITA officials said DOC Assistant Secretary Robert S. Larussa has signed the verdict and punitive anti-dumping tariff rates for individual Taiwan and Korean SRAM makers, but the DOC won't make a formal announcement until next Tuesday.

Although the verdict is still pending a final adjudication by the federal International Trade Commission (ITC), lawyers commissioned by Taiwan firms to handle the case said they believe the dumping charges will stand.

According to US anti-dumping regulations, the ITC will hold a final public hearing on the dumping charges on Feb. 18 and will decide by the end of March whether Taiwan SRAM makers have really hurt interests of Micron, the US firm which filed the dumping charges in March 1997. If the ITC upholds the DOC's final verdict, Taiwan-made SRAMs will be subject to punitive anti-dumping tariff rates starting in April.

The lawyers said the only good news was that the DOC rejected Micron's demand that Taiwan-made SRAMs set in motherboards be subject to punitive anti-dumping tariffs. "The exclusion of SRAMs built in motherboards will help minimize damage to Taiwan makers," said Chris Corr, a lawyer commissioned by many Taiwan companies to handle the dumping charges.
Taiwan accounts for 60 percent of the annual global motherboard production, and many Taiwan makers inlay SRAMs made by local companies into their motherboards before exporting them to the US.

Another lawyer, Jonny Chiu, said it was discouraging that punitive tariff rates listed in the DOC's final verdict for some Taiwan companies are higher than those proposed in its initial verdict delivered last September.

Chiu said the increases in punitive rates indicate that the ITA didn't accept Taiwan companies' argument that research spending and stocks offered to their employees should be caculated as production costs.

According to the final verdict, the anti-dumping tariff rate for SRAMs produced by Taiwan's Windbond Electronics will reach 102.83 percent, compared to 94.1 percent originally proposed. The punitive tariff rate for another major Taiwan semicroductor producer United Microelectronics Corp. also increases from 63.36 percent to 93.87 percent, while the rate for Alliance Semiconductor Corp. drops from 59.06 percent to 50.58 percent, and that for Hsicheng Co. is lowered to 7.59 percent from 10.96 percent.

The three Taiwan companies which failed to respond to questionnaires sent by the DOC -- Texas-Acer Instruments, Best Integrated Technology and Advanced Microelectronics -- will be subject to an extremely high punitive rate of 113.85 percent.
All other Taiwan SRAM makers will be subject to a punitive rate of 41.98 percent, slightly higher than 41.3 percent proposed in the initial verdict.
Legal experts said the ITC, while delivering its final adjudication, is not expected to change the punitive tariff rates proposed in the DOC's final verdict.

The United States is a major export outlet for Taiwan-made SRAMs, accounting for about half of Taiwan's total SRAM exports. Taiwan exported US$137 million and US$93.4 million worth of SRAMs in 1995 and 1996, respectively. Taiwan accounts for about 9 percent of America's SRAM import market, compared to a 20 percent market share held by South Korea.
Information-technology industry experts said the US anti-dumping verdict will certainly have an adverse impact on Taiwan SRAM makers as the punitive rates are very high.

Most worrisome was that Micron may file dumping charges against Taiwan and Korean makers of dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips following its victory in the SRAM dumping charges. If so, Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturers will be hurt even more drastically because DRAMs account for the lion's share of their exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL MEETS KOREAN PM-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang returned to Taipei on Saturday after a fruitful four-day visit to South Korea.

A spirited Chang said upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that his visit marks an important step toward the rapprochement between the Republic of China and South Korea. Taipei-Seoul relations have reamined at low ebbs since South Korea switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in August 1992.
During his visit, Chang said he was impressed by the desire expressed by Korean politicians to improve ties with Taiwan.
Chang didn't elaborate on details of his itinerary in Seoul. But reports from South Korea said Chang managed to meet with South Korean Prime Minister-designate Kim Jong-pil on Friday.

Kim, who has been named by Korean President-elect Kim Dae-jung as next prime minister, held a closed-door meeting with Chang at the latter's hotel room early Friday morning, according to the reports. Kim was accompanied by one of his close aides during his meeting with Chang.
During their brief meeting, Kim reportedly denied a Korean newspaper report that he had asked mainland China to offer a US$30 billion loan to his country during his recent trip to Beijing.
Kim, who has been friendly toward Taiwan, also expressed his willingness to promote substantive ties with the ROC in the future.
On Friday, Chang also met with Kim Dae-jung's special economic adviser Lew Jong-keun. who has a doctorate in economics from New York State University.
On behalf of Kim, Lew reportedly had exchange views with Chang on how to boost bilateral relations after Kim takes office later this month.

Reliable sources said Kim once sent a personal letter to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, expressing his intention to appoint Lew as a key liaison officer with Taipei in order to further strengthen bilateral ties.
Chang left for Seoul on Wednesday. While there, he had met with top leaders of major South Korean political parties and many business and industry heavyweights.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US REACH CONSENSUS ON SOME WTO ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Negotiators from the Republic of China and the United States have reached consensuses on some trade issues after five days of intensive talks on terms for Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Lin Shiang-nung, vice chairman of the Council of Agriculture and Taiwan's chief farm trade negotiator with the US, said on Friday that the two sides have almost come to terms on the opening of Taiwan's chicken meat market, timetables for farm trade tariff reductions and issues related to wine and tobacco imports.
Nevertheless, Lin said, huge gaps still exist between the two sides concerning issues related to pork, animal intestines and rice trade.
Lin said the US government, under heavy pressure from American hog ranchers, has insisted that Taiwan fully open its pork market following its WTO entry.

The US originally demanded that Taiwan reduce its tariff rates on a number of agricultural products to an average of 12 percent by 2002 from the current 20 percent. But Lin said the US has agreed that Taiwan can lower its tariff rates on some fruits to WTO standards until 2004.
The two sides will continue to discuss agricultural issues on Saturday.

On the tobacco and wine trade, Vice Finance Minister Wu Chia-sheng said Taiwan has agreed to impose zero tariffs on all white spirits starting in 2000 and that smuggled tobaccos and alcholic products seized by customs offices will be auctioned off, donated to suitable organizations or re-exported. At present, all such goods are destroyed. The two sides also reached a consensus on tariff rates on imported cigarettes, but Wu would not reveal details.

ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will arrive in Washington on Monday and is scheduled to meet with senior US trade officials on Feb. 17-18 to discuss some policy issues and seek major breakthroughs in order to finalize bilateral WTO talks as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIAN PM CALLS FOR FLEXIBILITY IN TIES WITH SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Friday that Malaysia and Singapore could resolve many of their bilateral problems if both countries could be flexible and not stick rigidly to their positions, The Straits Times reported on Saturday in a dispatch from Kuala Lumpur.
Both sides must be willing to see each other's point of view, he told The Straits Times in an interview ahead of Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong's visit to Kuala Lumpur on Monday.

"There must be areas for compromise or there is no point talking at all. We are prepared not to be rigid and we expect that both sides must do it... Being flexible is being willing to give up something to gain something," he was quoted as saying.

Mahathir said there was a feeling in Singapore that Malaysia will stop water supplies to Singapore on the expiry of the existing agreement in 2061. This, he said, is not Malaysia's intention, and he is willing to negotiate the issue so long as it is not to Kuala Lumpur's disadvantage, the report said.
Mahathir also said Malaysia has a different interpretation of the Points of Agreement (POA) signed with Singapore in 1990.
The pact spelt out clearly the terms on the development and status of land owned by Malayan Railway (KTM) in Singapore.
Under the agreement, KTM land in Singapore's Tanjong Pagar, Kranji and Woodlands was to be developed jointly by the two countries.
Problems later arose when Mahathir sought to change the agreement, including his proposal to build an electric train track from Singapore to Kuala Lumpur and beyond for a trans-Asian railway.

In a speech to the Singapore parliament in June last year, Goh said the electric train and other changes would require an amendment to the POA. This, he pointed out, could create legal and political difficulties.

Mahathir on Friday said the differences over the POA need not be a stumbling block to better Singapore-Malaysia ties, which become strained over Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew's statements last year about crime in Johor.
Asked if he wanted the POA to be revised totally, he replied: "We'll look at it... We are quite prepared to examine it and to see the other point of view."
Mahathir said bilateral relations now are much better compared to last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: "GREAT CHINESE COMMONWEALTH" PROPOSAL SEEN AS IMPRACTICABLE

TEXT.P: Several leaders of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday that the "Great Chinese Commonwealth" proposal discussed in a seminar on DPP policy toward mainland China Friday is not practicable.

Foreign DPP chairman Shih Ming-teh proposed in the seminar that mainland China and Taiwan hold talks on the establishment of a "Great Chinese Commonwealth" in order to resolve the problem of national unification.
The three-day seminar is sponsored by the DPP as a forum for debates on DPP's future policy toward mainland China. There are three sessions of debates in the agenda.

DPP Legislator Chou Po-lun said that the proposal is not practicable because a commonwealth is an organization of friendly sovereign countries and mainland China does not see Taiwan as a sovereign country. It is impossible to talk about it at a time when communist China is still threatening to use military force if Taiwan formally declares independence, he added.
Shen Fu-hsiung, a factional leader of the DPP, said the proposal is contingent on Beijing's consent. If Beijing doesn't like it, it is impossible to hold talks on it.

Yen Wan-ching, director of the Mainland Chinese Affairs Department of the DPP, said the proposal is a "too distant expectation," because communist China may not become a friendly country and recognize Taiwan as a sovereign country in the short term. But he said that the ruling Kuomintang has commissioned certain scholars to study a similar idea, and that the DPP had better continue to pay attention to it.
Yen Ching-fu, another factional leader of the DPP, said it is possible to talk about a great Chinese commonwealth for economic and trade promotional purposes, but not for political purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: REP. BROWN INTRODUCES RESOLUTION URGING WHO MEMBERSHIP FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U. S. Congressman Sherrod Brown (Ohio-D) introduced Thursday a resolution calling for Taiwan's admission to the World Health Organization (WHO), and urging the U. S. government to support it.

An official of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington said Friday that the resolution, endorsed by eight other members of the House of Representatives, is highly appreciated, and that it is too early to predict its outcome at the present time.

Resolutions calling for Taiwan's admission to world trade organizations have been introduced in U.S. Congress in the past few years, while Brown's resolution is the first of its kind that says Taiwan should be admitted to an organization of the United Nations.

Brown, senior member of the House Health and Environment Subcommittee, said in a statement inserted into the Congressional Record on Feb. 12 that a lofty goal of the WHO is to enable people of the world to enjoy good health, but the 21 million people on Taiwan are now unable to receive the latest medical knowledge and technology from the world health organization, and Taiwan is unable to contribute its rich resources and technology to the organization.
The children on Taiwan will benefit from WHO service, and the world health organization can benefit from Taiwan's membership, Brown said.
Brown pointed out that political intervention by mainland China has prevented Taiwan from making financial and technological contributions to WHO-sponsored activities in recent years.

Continued denial of Taiwan's request to join the WHO is a violation of the basic rights of the people on Taiwan without any reason, and is an incomprehensible act of overlooking the benefit Taiwan's WHO membership cab bring to Taiwan and the whole world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP KMT AIDE DENIES MEETING WITH KIM

TEXT.P: Secretary-General John Chang of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Sunday denied local newspaper reports that he met South Korea's President-elect Kim Dae-jung during a recent visit to there and that he brought back a letter from Kim for President Lee Teng-hui.

Responding to questions from reporters following an appearance at a prayer ceremony at a temple in downtown Taipei, Chang denied the rumors and said that the four-day trip had met exceptions set prior to his departure.

Describing his recent South Korean visit as fruitful, Chang said he met leaders from a broad social spectrum there and discussed issues of mutual concern with them. He said South Korea has high appraisals of Taiwan's performance in the recent financial crisis plaguing the Asian region and called on the people of Taiwan to support government policies.
Chang said he will propose measures to increase bilateral ties with South Korea to pave the way for a warming of two-way relations.
Relations between the two countries have remained at a low ebb since Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1992.

Speaking of the coming elections in Taiwan, the top KMT aide said his party will work out a series of regulations in late March to govern its preliminary elections in order to field appropriate candidates.
He also called for an early resumption of cross-strait talks and said that all issues which are beneficial to peaceful development on both Taiwan and mainland China can be discussed.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSING FOR FOREIGN DIPLOMATIC MISSIONS COMPLETED

TEXT.P: Construction of offices and a residential compound built by the National Property Bureau (NPB) to house foreign diplomatic missions based here has been completed, NPB Director-General Liu Chin-pioa said on Sunday.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will make a final decision on which countries can move diplomats and their families into the 16-story office building and 10-story residential building after electricity, air conditioning and other facilities are fully installed, according to Liu.
Liu said the purpose of constructing the two buildings was aimed at enticing allies of the Republic of China to open consular offices here.
Construction on the project, occupying a 4,378-square-meter compound in Tienmu, suburban Taipei, by Chief Construction Corp. began in March 1995 and was completed last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE CAN EMERGE FROM CRISIS STRONGER: LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 15 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Conrad Lu)

TEXT.P: Singapore, Feb. 15 Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Saturday night that Singapore will emerge stronger if it handles the current financial crisis correctly and if the people learn from the experience.
Speaking at a Lunar New Year and Hari Raya dinner at his constituency, he pointed out that the regional economic crisis is also a serious social and political crisis for the region.
If there are mis-steps or mishaps and unexpected events occur, then the recovery will be more complicated.
Singapore must do whatever it can to help its neighbors restore their prosperity. And that is why Singapore has been active in diplomacy, he said.
Lee cited two factors which could affect the region and Singapore severely.
First, although mainland China has not been affected by the turbulence so far, the devaluation of regional currencies and the Korean won could affect its export competitiveness.
If mainland China comes under pressure, the exchange rate will go down, and that could start the fires all over again, he warned.
Second, the outcome of the Indonesian presidential election in March could also be a significant factor.

If Indonesia continues to face economic problems and the reform measures take a long time to work, or if they fail outright, that country's problems would affect the region generally and Singapore specifically, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEACEN URGED TO FOCUS ON MACROECONOMIC STABILITY

TEXT.P: Bank Indonesia Governor Sudradjat Djiwandono has underlined the need for member countries of the Southeast Asian Central Banks Association (SEACEN) to focus their attention on macroeconomic stability.

This can be achieved by bolstering regional cooperation in maintaining economic and monetary stability, Sudradjat was quoted by Antara news agency as saying at the conclusion of the 33rd Conference of Asian Central Bank Governors in Nusa Dua, Bali, on Saturday night.

The SEACEN conference in Bali was attended by 41 delegates from ten central banks, including Taiwan's Central Bank of China, Bank Negara Malaysia, Bank of Korea, Bank of Thailand, Central Bank of Myanmar, Nepal Rastra Bank, Monetary Authority of Singapore, Central Bank of Sri Lanka, and the host Bank Indonesia.
Also present were observers from the National Bank of Cambodia, Reserve Bank of Fiji and the Reserve Bank of Tonga.
Dhiwandono said the forum plays a crucial role in facilitating an active cooperation policy and joint supervision to promote stability within a freer capital market scheme.
He said the problems faced by a particular country in an increasingly integrated international environment are not isolated.
Meanwhile, Thai Central Bank Governor Chaiyawat Wibulswasdi pointed out that the task of a central bank is to restore credibility and confidence.

To that end, he said, clear-cut and sustainable actions and a strong determination are needed. While the process for doing this might be very difficult and painful, and demands great sacrifice, Chaiyawat said he was optimistic that his country would overcome the adverse effects of its monetary crisis.

Meanwhile, Bank for International Settlements Managing Director Andrew Crockett said in his address on monetary stability and international capital movement that even countries with strong economic fundamentals could fall victim to a sudden loss of public confidence.
He also said that a country with a sound macro policy would need to adjust to a constantly changing environment.
"Those who fail in making such adjustments on time will get serious consequences," he said.

He also suggested that liberalization in a domestic monetary system and openness to the international capital market have to be matched with more reliable and firmer policies as well as better control.
The SEACEN conference is an annual meeting of Asian central bank governors held on a rotating basis in the member countries. South Korea is expected to host next year's 34th SEACEN conference.

SEACEN is a consultative and regional cooperation forum of central banks and monetary authorities in the Southeast Asian region. It is aimed at promoting matters of common interest, particularly in the economic, monetary and banking sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FINANCIER SOROS DENIES PLANS TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By Jane Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: World-renown investment expert George Soros has no plans to visit Taiwan in the near future, a spokesman for the billionaire American financier said here Saturday.

He did not deny, however, that investment managers from the Quantum Group of Funds, the forward player of the Soros Fund Management corporation, have made a series of visits to that island to call on locally listed companies.

The spokesman made the remarks in response to questions from CNA over recent reports that a large amount of money from the Quantum Fund N.V., the oldest and largest fund with the group, has recently poured into the Taiwan stock market, especially in the high-tech sectors.
