Confidence in the Taiwan Stock Exchange has gradually rallied in the past several weeks following a decline resulting from Asia's regional financial troubles.

Nevertheless, the spokesman refused to reveal whether the group's funds will make their way into the emerging market. Nor would he comment on its assessment of the prospects for Taiwan technology shares, citing confidential business strategy.

The spokesman merely stated that his boss has devoted his attention to charitable causes over the past eight years while leaving the burden of his business operations on the shoulders of managing executives. Thus, he said, Soros himself rarely makes "inspection tours" of potential investment markets.

Soros Fund Management, employing 21 elite investment consultants and more than 100 support personnel, currently possesses total assets valued at over US$18 billion. Its Quantum Fund is generally recognized as having the best performance record of any investment fund in the world since its founding in 1969.
Other funds under the Quantum Group include the Qussar International Fund N.V., Quantum Emerging Growth Fund N.V. and Quata Fund N.V., according to the company.

Soros has been a controversial figure in the world's financial markets. Criticism of the tycoon's role in Asian monetary and stock markets, which suffered severe damage from last year's financial turmoil, has increased following his assistance to South Korea in helping that country avoid bankruptcy.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEBEC PREMIER CLAIMS OTTAWA CREATING POLITICAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard warned Saturday that Ottawa is creating a political crisis by going ahead with its plan to ask the Supreme Court of Canada for an opinion on the legality of unilateral declaration of independence by Quebec.

Bouchard wants the Supreme Court to "refuse to hear the case," claiming the matter is a political, not legal, issue. His central argument is that Quebec's political future should be decided by the people, not by the court.

If the Supreme Court goes ahead, as requested by Jean Chretien's Liberal government, there will be "political consequences" -- suffering a blow to its credibility as well as creating new tensions, Bouchard said. The court is to begin hearing the case on Monday.
It will "exacerbate the political tensions and, of course, it will add up to the political crisis," he warned.

Besides boycotting the court proceedings, Quebec sovereigntists will bring their case to foreign envoys stationed in Ottawa. Bouchard said they plan to tell the foreign ambassadors that most Quebecers do not want the court to interfere in their future.
"I think that the foreign countries' ambassadors have to know not all people in Quebec and in Canada share the distorted view of democracy of the federal government," Bouchard added.

The Chretien government has asked the Supreme Court to answer three questions: Can Quebec unilaterally secede under the Canadian constitution? Does it have the right under international law? In a conflict between domestic and international law, which takes precedence?

For all intents and purposes, these are questions involving the rule of law and ones which anyone professing to be a democrat must deal with. But Quebec's sovereigntists, knowing they will almost certainly lose the case in the court, have refused to participate in the court debate.

Instead, they shifted the focus from the legal to the political aspect, claiming those are questions for the people to decide, and not the nine judges in the court. Canada's "unity minister," Stephane Dion, conceded he has a "major challenge" in countering the argument of the Bouchard camp.

As this is the first time such a sensitive case has been brought up to the Supreme Court, nobody has dared to predict what will happen. Analysts are unsure whether or not the court will answer these questions. Most are confident, though, that a court decision will not come soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH TO SEEK NEW BASIS FOR CLOSER LINKS WITH MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said on Saturday he will try to find a "new base" to forge closer cooperation between Singapore and Malaysia during upcoming talks with Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad in Kuala Lumpur.

Asked what issues will be brought up during the two-day meeting in Kuala Lumpur beginning on Monday, he was quoted as saying: "I would not want to approach it on an issues basis. It's generally to see whether we can find a new base for us to forge closer cooperation.
"So I go up with a positive outlook. Not to think there are problems to be solved, but how we can work together."
Still, the regional economic crisis will be top of the agenda.

"There's a crisis going on, and we've got to try and see how we can help resolve the regional crisis. That's the main rationale for my going up. But beyond that, it's always good between neighbors to see one another from time to time," he was quoted as saying.
The two leaders have already met twice so far this year.
On Jan. 20, they met in Johor, Malaysia, at the Sebana golf resort. During the 90-minute meeting, they discussed the regional currency crisis and bilateral relations.
They continued these discussions when they met again in Singapore on Feb. 7.
Monday's meeting will be Goh's first official visit to the Malaysian capital since 1994.
The Straits Times reported earlier that Mahathir had said that he was open to negotiating a new water-supply agreement with Singapore, one which must not put Malaysia at a disadvantage.
He had also said that Malaysia would not turn off the water supply to Singapore when the current agreement ends in 2061.
Asked about the water issue on Saturday, Goh was quoted as saying: "I read this in the paper, that we would discuss water. There are other issues which we will discuss as well."
The prime minister was speaking to reporters during a community event at his Marine Parade constituency.

Meanwhile, according to a report from Malaysia's Bernama news agency on Saturday, Mahathir said he would discuss with Goh about "better relations" between the two countries when they meet in Kuala Lumpur.
"We just want to discuss how to get over all these problems we have and to have better relations," he was quoted as telling reporters who had asked him about the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY SINGAPOREAN BUSINESSES BADLY HIT BY REGIONAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: More than half of the members of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) polled in a recent survey said they were reeling from the fallout of the regional currency crisis.
Most of the members also blamed government levies for pushing up their costs of doing business in Singapore, according to the survey.
These were the findings of a survey of 268 SCCCI members conducted by the chamber last week.
Just over half of them, or 145, said they were badly affected. Another 115, or 43 percent, said they were only slightly affected by the regional downturn.
Just eight members, or 3 percent, said the regional crisis has not had any effect on their business.
Among those surveyed, 148 said that the foreign worker levy and industrial and commercial rents were too high.
Members polled in the survey also expressed dissatisfaction with local banks and financial institutions.
These institutions were overly cautious in giving credit, said 24.3 percent of those polled.
The SCCCI members urged the government to offer rebates or defer various tax payments to help them ride out the financial crisis.
They also suggested setting up a Business Costs Supervisory Committee to coordinate and review the fee hikes of various government bodies.
They also called for a cut in Central Provident Fund contributions to help them tide over the financial storm, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING IN FINAL STATE BEFORE JOINING WTO

TEXT.P: The deputy director-general of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) said that Beijing is in its final stage before joining the WTO," according to reports of the world trade body on Saturday.
"I believe we can say that the process has entered its final phase," Kim Chul-su was quoted by the WTO report as saying.

"The process of (mainland) Chinese accession that began more than 10 years ago has recently gathered momentum and direction. There has been renewed determination on all sides to secure China's entry into the WTO as soon as possible on commercially viable terms."
Kim, a former South Korean minister of trade, industry and energy, said that conditions for mainland China had improved with its market opening initiatives.
He said Beijing and WTO members are now engaged in intensive and focused bilateral market-access negotiations.
"My impression is that we are very close to the successful conclusion of the negotiations," Kim was quoted as saying.
Kim also said Taiwan would immediately follow as a member of the organization should mainland China join, the WTO report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAVYWEIGHT PROPOSES 'CHINESE FINANCIAL GROUP'

TEXT.P: A heavyweight member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Sunday proposed the establishment of a Chinese financial organization, grouping Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and Singapore.

DPP Legislator Chang Chun-hung said during a debate on the party's policy toward mainand China that the financial crisis which has embroiled most of the countries in Southeast Asia is turning worse and that it is poised to become a "disaster" for all nations in the region within three to six months.

He suggested the four Chinese economies -- Taiwan, the mainland, Hong Kong and Singapore -- which so far have suffered only a slight impact from the economic turmoil, hold a joint conference for the purpose of establishing a formal "Chinese Financial Group" in order to weather the turbulence.
Beijing's refusal to join the group would only expose its hegemonic manner, Chang said.
However, the proposal by Chang, who represents the DPP's mainstream Formosa group, was rebutted by delegates from the party's other factions.

Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung called the suggestion an "admirable but unfeasible political concept" which sees cross-strait trade as a bargaining chip with mainland China but ignores Taiwan's security.
Legislator Chai Trong R. said that Taiwan's joining such a group would be tantamount to "surrendering" to Beijing because it would undermine Taiwan's sovereignty.
The three-day session, aimed at forging a consensus among the DPP factions on the party's policy toward the mainland, drew to an end in the afternoon.
Former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh on the sideline of the forum proposed on Friday the formation of a "Greater Chinese Commonwealth" to normalize relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

According to Prof. Yang Kai-huang of Soochow University, Beijing should take serious note of the DPP forum and map out strategies for dealing with the opposition party, which is growing in strength and stands poised to challenge the Kuomintang as Taiwan's ruling party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROVINCIAL COUNCIL SET TO REVIEW BAYER CASE

TEXT.P: The NT$50 billion investment plan by the Germany-based Bayer Group to set up a production plant for toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) in central Taichung Harbor is expected to gain a new lease of life, as the Taiwan Provincial Assembly is set to review the matter during its next session.

Sources familiar with the case said that discussion on the land lease contract by Bayer is expected to be put on the agenda of the provincial council's 14th temporary session, which will begin on Monday and run through Feb. 27, as most provincial councilors have shown support for the project.

The sources said they are optimistic about eventual passage of the land lease contract for Bayer, which will give the group a legal basis to start construction of relevant facilities on a site owned by the Taiwan Provincial Assembly near Taichung Harbor in central Taichung County.

The chemical giant announced in December that it was relocating the long-delayed TDI investment plan to the United States, as the project had encountered strong opposition from local residents over fears that it would cause environmental pollution.

However, Bayer showed a willingness to return to Taiwan last week after a fact-finding delegation composed of Republic of China officials, local experts and opinion leaders from Taichung County visited its headquarters in Dormagen, Germany.

The German firm told the delegation that it is willing to retain the plan in Taiwan as long as the Taiwan Provincial Assembly approves its land lease contract by the end of this month to pave the way for construction of its production facilities in Taichung Harbor by September.

In an effort to woo back Bayer, the central government has been actively coordinating with the provincial council in the hope that it will call a temporary session in the middle of this month to review the Bayer case.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), will hold a seminar in Taichung City on Monday to explain Bayer's plan to the public, underscoring the importance attached by the central government to the project.

According to the CEPD, the Bayer's TDI plant, the first foreign investment plan presented to the ROC government in line with its bid to build Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific operations hub, will bring considerable economic gain to local communities.

Its first-phase, NT$11.5 billion investment alone will create NT$126 billion in economic benefits over 20 years, in addition to the profits created by the following two phases, the CEPD said. The council added that Bayer has also promised to hire local workers and register the company with the Taichung County government in order to pay taxes directly to the local authorities.

Currently, there are only eight companies in the world capable of producing TDI, a material essential for the production of the high-end PU, and Bayer holds the largest stake of 27 percent in the global market.

As annual demand for TDI in Asia has been estimated at 350,000 metric tons for the year 2000, Bayer has set the first-phase annual output for its Taichung production plant at 100,000 metric tons, which industry sources said will pave the way for Bayer to become the region's leading supplier of TDI.

Nevertheless, a public opinion survey released recently by the Taichung County government showed that 47 percent of the local residents are opposed to the Bayer investment plan, while 26 percent are in favor of the project. But more than 50 percent of the people do not know what type of product Bayer will manufacture at its Taichung plant.

The central government has repeatedly said that it will do its best to push for the passage of the project, as it will play a vital role in Taiwan's continued economic development and carry great symbolic importance for other foreign companies planning to invest in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY MISSION VISITS MAINLAND CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland China will open its arms for a visit by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a high-ranking Beijing official in charge of cross-strait affairs was quoted as saying.

Chen Yunlin, director of the mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, made the remarks in Beijing on Friday during a meeting with a visiting delegation from Taiwan's opposition New Party.

Chen told the 25-member group from Taiwan's third largest political party that he hopes the Taipei-Beijing talks will be resumed as soon as possible under the "one China" principle. He added that bilateral dialogue on matters of substance can begin following the opening of political negotiations, according to the delegation's press release on the meeting issued Sunday.

In response to Taiwan's urging that cross-strait talks should be "re-opened from where they left off," which implies that technical issues between the two sides should be the major agenda item of resumed negotiations, Chen said there is no need to confine the dialogue because "things are always changing."
Cross-strait talks were unilaterally suspended by Beijing in 1995 in protest at Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June that year.

As for recent personnel shifts in the SEF, the mainland official made no detailed comment, merely expressing reserved optimism and hope that Shi Hwei-you, new SEF secretary-general and vice chairman who will be the top negotiator for Taiwan in future talks, will contribute to lessening the current state of antagonism between the two sides.
The SEF is a semi-official intermediary body founded by ROC authorities in 1991 to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official dialogue channels.

The New Party delegation departed Taipei on Monday for an eight-day visit to the mainland under the first invitation ever extended by the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to a Taiwan political party since the release of mainland President Jiang Zemin's "eight-point statement" in January 1995.

On Saturday, the group, which has described itself as "the voice of the Taiwan people," called on ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei in Beijing, who expressed "cautious optimism" over the resumption of cross-strait talks, according to another news release issued by the New Party delegation from Shanghai, where they arrived on Saturday.

It said Tang called on the two sides to engage in more frequent communications and to greater better efforts in advancing mutual understanding. He said that concerns expressed by the Taiwan side could be included on the agenda of the first round of discussions in order to reduce its doubts over the mainland's demand that political negotiations be conducted under the "one China" principle, which is defined by Beijing as the People's Republic of China being the sole legal government of China, with Taiwan being a province of China.

Taiwan is governed by the Republic of China, which recognizes that China has been divided since 1949 and is currently ruled by two separate governments, whereby two equitable political entities coexist under the concept of "one China."
Based on this concept, the Taiwan side has demanded equal treatment in the handling of cross-strait political issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MUM ON REPORTED US VISIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Monday denied reports that arrangements are being made for a US visit and a private meeting with Vice President Al Gore.
Chen, however, said he would like to visit Washington if given an opportunity.

Chen was answering reporters' questions about a Japanese newspaper report on Sunday that the Taipei mayor is planning to visit the United States in mid-March, during which time he would meet with ranking US government and political leaders, including Vice President Gore.

In a report filed from Taipei, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun said Chen, widely expected to be the candidate for Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the next presidential election, will use the trip to exchange views with US officials and politicians on mainland Chinese and Taiwan affairs. A meeting with Gore is also being arranged, the paper said.
The report noted that the DPP, with its political clout on the rise, is seen by Washington as likely to play an important role in future relations between Taiwan and mainland China.
The Japanese daily, however, pointed out that tension across the Taiwan Strait may escalate in the event the pro-independence DPP wins the presidential election or becomes the ruling party on Taiwan.

Ma Yung-cheng, a Taipei City Government spokesman, denied on Sunday evening that Chen had mentioned either a March visit to the United States or a possible meeting with Gore during an interview he gave with the Nihon Keizai Shimbun last week.

Ma admitted that Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), had extended an invitation to Chen during a recent visit to the Taipei City Hall. The AIT represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Washington.
Ma said although the mayor had verbally accepted Bush's invitation to visit the United States, relevant arrangements are still under planning and nothing is finalized yet.

He pointed out that the DPP is scheduled to hold intraparty primaries in March to choose candidates for mayoral races in Taipei and Kaohsiung, city council seats in the two metropolitan areas as well as national-level legislative elections, further lowering the possibility of Chen's departure in mid-March for the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1.1 MILLION MAINLAND RAILWAY WORKERS TO BE LAID OFF

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Ministry of Railways will lay off 1.1 million workers in various sections under its administration within the next three years, in order to cut a huge deficit in its operations.
The deficit incurred by mainland Chinese railway operations has accumulated to 22 billion Chinese yuan, according to the Sunday edition of the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Bao.

In addition, the newspaper added that a new trend is looming which could deal a further blow to the development of the railway system in mainland China. That is the fact that highway and air transportation is gradually replacing railroads as the backbone of mainland China's internal transportation network.

During the traditional busy season of the Lunar New Year holidays, official statistics show that the total passenger load on the mainland's transportation systems increased 4.8 percent in 1997 over that of 1996; however, passengers on the nation's railways decreased 1.5 percent in the same period.

Personnel costs account for one-third of the total expenditures of mainland railway operations, which makes the impending layoffs appear to be the only effective approach to raising the competitiveness of the rail system, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISITORS PREVENTED FROM VIEWING MRT AT NEW HONG KONG AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A Taiwan group intending to make a tour of the expressway project at Hong Kong's new airport this week was forced to cancel the trip Monday after its members were unable to obtain visas from Hong Kong authorities.

According to sources from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), the 13-member Taipei delegation, headed by Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Chen Shih-chi, was effectively barred from entering Hong Kong without any explanation from officials there.

Chen and his team, which also included Deputy Taiwan Governor Wu Jung-ming, President Group Chairman Kao Chin-yen, and several officials from the MOTC's High Speed Rail Bureau, are members of a screening committee for work on a proposed mass rapid transport (MRT) system linking Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and the Taipei MRT system.

They were scheduled to depart for Hong Kong on Monday for a fact-finding tour of the new Chek Lap Kok airport where they hoped to familiarize themselves with advanced rail and expressway systems at the airport complex which link that facility with the existing Kai Tak international airport in Kowloon.

High Speed Rail Bureau officials explained that the visit was arranged because some of the engineering proposals offered by bidders on the CKS Airport-Taipei Railway Station MRT Project are the same as those being incorporated into the Hong Kong new airport.

However, the officials said that since visas were not issued in time by Hong Kong authorities, the visit by the screening committee members would be canceled and that there are no plans to reschedule the trip.

The US$20.3 billion Chek Lap Kok airport, the world's largest infrastructure project, is due to be completed by April this year. Designed to replace the outmoded Kai Tak international airport, Chek Lap Kok will be able to handle 35 million passengers and 3 million tons of air cargo annually, according to Hong Kong transportation authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO PARTIALLY OPEN FARMING MARKET BEFORE WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will partially open its agricultural market as a "down payment" for entry to the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO), the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) confirmed on Monday.

"We'll allow limited imports of some agricultural products before we are formally admitted to the world trade regulatory body," COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan said, adding that the move is aimed at finalizing bilateral WTO talks with Taiwan's most important trade partner, the United States, as soon as possible.
The WTO does not set detailed terms for "down payments" by any membership applicant, but such offers can help narrow differences in the entry terms negotiation process, Lee explained.
Nevertheless, Lee would not reveal the list of agricultural products or the quota for those items Taiwan plans to allow for import ahead of its WTO accession.
"Negotiations with the US are still going on. Nobody knows the outcome at the moment," Lee said. "We'll remain flexible and prudent in the procedures."

Government sources said the COA had discussed various "down payment" proposals with local agricultural and husbandry associations before the current round of Taiwan-US WTO talks opened in Washington, D.C. last week.

The COA has drafted import quotas and tariff rates for such sensitive products as pork, chicken meat and animal intestines, but which items will ultimately be selected for pre-WTO entry market opening, annual import quotas and tariff rates remains uncertain, the sources said.
Taiwan currently bans imports of chicken meat, intestines of chickens and pigs as well as pork bellies, but allow imports of top-quality pork, which is subject to a tariff rate of 15 percent.

Agricultural issues have been the crux of Taiwan-US WTO talks. Reports from Washington said the two sides have almost come to terms on insurance and service industry topics, but are still divided on farm trade and compact car import issues after six days of intensive consultations.

According to the reports, the US side has demanded that Taiwan lower the local-content rate for compact cars from the current 50 percent to 40 percent before its WTO accession and cancel preferential commodity tax rates for locally developed engines, chassises and auto designs. The United States has also asked Taiwan to speed up its tariff reduction timetables for some other industrial products. The two sides will continue negotiating compact car issues as well as pork, animal intestine and rice import matters in the next few days.
Meanwhile, ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang arrived in Washington on Sunday in preparation to seek major breakthroughs in the difficult WTO talks.

Wang is scheduled to meet with US Deputy Trade Representative Richard Fisher on Tuesday for talks on some policy issues related to Taiwan's WTO entry terms. US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky will join the bilateral policy talks on Wednesday.
Taiwan has so far held 17 rounds of WTO-related talks with the United States. Both sides hope the current round will resolve all thorny issues and put an end to the lengthy negotiations.
