DOC.HEADLINE: GOOD GOVERNANCE IS THE ONLY REAL PROTECTION

TEXT.P: "Good governance is the only real protection" in any financial crisis, according to Thomas L. Friedman, a noted financial analyst.

Contributing an article to the Paris-based mass-circulation International Herald Tribune, Friedman pointed out: "Of those Asian nations which were fully plugged into the market, those with the most noncorrupt, transparent and accountable financial systems -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore -- have been hurt the least. Those that had democratic, but corrupt, systems -- Thailand and South Korea -- were hurt the second worst, but at least have been able to respond quickly by voting in better governance."
"The country that is going to melt down is Indonesia. Its corrupt, authoritarian regime can't adapt," Friedman said.

"If your domestic institutions are strong, then you don't need very strong global institutions. If domestic institutions inside countries are weak, it won't matter how strong your global institutions are. They will not be effective," Friedman quoted Bob Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, as saying in his article.
"Democracy does not guarantee that you will never have an economic crisis. We know that. Markets overshoot. Investors take crazy risks," Friedman said.

"But the more democratic, accountable and open your governance, especially as an emerging market, the less likely it is that your financial system will be exposed to surprises, the easier it will be for you to improve and adapt when it is, and the more legitimacy your government will have to share the pain when change is required," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEIGHBORS URGE FREE AND FAIR ELECTIONS IN CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: Pressures from the international community have started to mount on Cambodia to hold a fair, credible and free election in July of this year or face possible sanctions.

Philippine Foreign Affairs Secretary Domingo Siazon, in a press conference at the Manila Hotel, said that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the Friends of Cambodia (FOC) resolved that the scheduled elections in Cambodia on July 26 are crucial to its international standing as a nation.

Siazon, chairman of the ASEAN Standing Committee, held a three-hour consultative meeting with Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas and Thai Foreign Minister Surin Pitsuwan, the so-called "ASEAN Troika," with representatives from the 12-member FOC at the Manila Hotel on Sunday to discuss the Cambodian issue.

The foreign secretary stated that all countries present during the meeting, had urged that free, fair and credible elections be held in July in order that the standing of Phnom Penh as a member of the world community will not be unduly affected.
Pitsuwan said in an interview that members of the FOC have expressed the possibility of cutting aid, financial or otherwise, if Cambodia fails to hold credible elections this year.

"The Friends of Cambodia expressed their desire to see the election take place as scheduled (because) the elections are a vital step in the restoration of peace and political stability in Cambodia and that the key issue for the credibility of the electoral process is that of participation. If the issue of participation is not resolved, the Friends of Cambodia would have to individually review their continuing assistance for the electoral process," the FOC said in a statement.

The ASEAN Troika, tasked to assist Cambodia to achieve a stable government in lieu of its membership in ASEAN, is in close coordination with the members of the FOC to discuss pressing developments in that country.

Cambodia was supposed to join ASEAN in July last year together with Myanmar and Laos when Second Prime Minister Hun Sen, alleging acts of treason, launched a coup that deposed the First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh, son of Cambodia's head of state, King Norodom Sihanouk.

In a consensus decision, ASEAN decided to defer Cambodia's membership, pending efforts to normalize the situation in the country and enable Phnom Penh to meet certain prescribed requirements, one of which was the holding of elections, before it can be allowed to formally enter the international organization as a full member.

Among the FOC members which took part in the meeting were Austria, Canada, mainland China, France, Germany, Japan, Korea, New Zealand, Russia, the United Kingdom and the United States. UN Representative to Cambodia Lakhan Mehrota also attended the meeting.
Siazon explained that the FOC is an informal group which is directly interested in developments in Cambodia based on its member countries' various ties with Phnom Penh.
The group is scheduled to meet again in the Philippines on March 6 to review developments relating to the assessments made at Sunday's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRESH RIOTS HIT WEST JAVA SUBDISTRICT

TEXT.P: A riot triggered by price hikes hit the West Java subdistrict of Kadipaten in Majalenka regency, 10 kilometers east of Bandung, on Sunday, as other towns remained tense.
Dozens of people began to take to the streets at midday, attacking shops and settling them ablaze. At least 15 shops were damaged, with six of them -- plus several motorcycles -- being set on fire.
Security authorities quickly restored order and arrested two men suspected of sparking the unrest. There was no report of injuries during the 40-minute police clampdown, the Jakarta Post reported.

In Cerebon, minor rioting erupted in Karansembung village just hours before Governor R. Nuriana toured the town to inspect the village after rioting on Friday. The latest outbreak left two houses burned.
Nuriana visited people in Ceribon's riot-hit areas of Lemah Abang, Pasar Gebang, Losari and Cileduk who were clearing remnants of buildings attacked by angry rioters over the past few days.

The coastal town had yet to return to normal on Sunday, with many shops staying closed and major bus terminals witnessing a sharp decline of passengers leaving the town. Instead, people seemingly preferred to travel by train as evidenced by increased numbers of travelers at the railway station.
Violence also spilled over into Purwokerto in Central Java on Sunday when several people stoned buses heading for the coastal areas of Banyumas, Pemalang, Brebes and Cilacap, all in Central Java.

Antara news agency reported that the attack caused buses and other forms of public transportation to suspend services out of fears that riots would resume. Hundreds of residents were left stranded for hours due to the absence of transportation.

Tension also reigned in the Central Java town of Purbalingga as hundreds of people pelted shops which sell basic commodities because their owners refused to open. But the military and police managed to immediately thwart any potential rioting. They made no arrests, only ordering the angry people to return home.
Bandung was calmer on Sunday, despite rumors that strikes and riots were about to erupt. The rumors affected public transportation, forcing groups of people to wait for hours for public minibuses.
More troops were seen patrolling the town despite heavy rain throughout the day.
Governor Nuriana called on entrepreneurs and public transportation drivers to resume their business activities as usual to prevent public anxiety from worsening.
"Most riots were triggered by a lack of public transportation. People tend to gather. And once this happens, they can be easily driven to rioting," Nuriana said.
Earlier, Central Java Governor Soewardi accused a certain group based in Jakarta of organizing the riots that had rocked the province and other town across Java.
"We found that some people we arrested for allegedly inciting riots came from Jakarta. They arrived here along with the exodus of Idul Fitri revelers," Suwardi said over the weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES SET TO BACK HABIBIE AS INDONESIAN VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Indonesia's armed forces (ABRI) look set to support Research and Technology Minister B.J. Habibie as the country's next vice president, The Straits Times reported Monday in a dispatch from Jakarta.

Military sources in Jakarta told the Singapore-based daily that the armed forces was leaning towards Habibie after a consensus was reached among various ABRI factions at a three-day annual meeting of commanders last week.
"We have agreed to back Dr. Habibie because that is what Pak Harto wants," a senior ABRI officer involved in the deliberations was quoted as saying in reference to Indonesian President Suharto.
"We have also agreed if the president changes his mind and appoints someone else at the eleventh hour, we will support his choice."

The deputy speaker of parliament and ABRI parliamentary faction head, Lt. Gen. Syarwan Hamid, also alluded to this possibility on Saturday, saying that the military had named only one person as its vice presidential candidate, the report said.
Asked if this was Habibie, he replied: "You may be right. There will be no changes in the armed forces' decision."

The comments of these high-ranking officers take place against a background of growing support for the 61-year-old German-trained engineer and close confidant of Suharto, who had given the broadest hint that Habibie was his choice after presenting a list of criteria which a vice president must possess, the report said.
That message seems to have permeated downwards, the report noted.
The ruling Golkar party said last week that it was backing Habibie along with parliamentary speaker Harmoko for the vice presidency.
Habibie has also received backing from the Muslim-based United Development Party and the Indonesian Democratic Party, the report said.
Conventional thinking in Jakarta has been that ABRI would be more comfortable with a military figure in the No. 2 post, with some backing incumbent Gen. Try Sutrisno as its candidate, it said.

Many younger officers have been resentful of Habibie's efforts to take away strategic industries and procurement decisions from them, with the result that he now has a bigger say in what equipment is purchased and from where, the report said.

Indeed, it pointed out, in the run-up to the 1993 People's Consultative Assembly, observers said that the military took the unusual step of supporting Try as its vice presidential candidate, fearing that Suharto would nominate Habibie or even retain then Vice President Sudharmono for another term.

Sources said that the military was unlikely to pull off a similar stunt, the report said. Noted a senior officer: "It is wishful thinking for us to go against the president's wishes. The ABRI of 1993 is very different from today's ABRI."

Habibie's fortunes appeared to have taken a temporary dip last week with the replacement of his close ally, military chief Feisal Tanjung, by Gen. Wiranto, who is known to distance himself from Islamic forces and from supporting Golkar outright, the report said.

But military insiders said that Habibie's star was still shining given countervailing support for him from other key military figures, including Suharto's son-in-law, Maj. Gen. Prabowo Subianto, who was promoted recently from head of the Special Forces to lead the Army Strategic Reserve Command, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN SEEN TO PROVIDE BOOST FOR ROC-AUSSIE TIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan business migrants are expected to play an active role in forming bilateral ties between the Republic of China and Australia, analysts say.

The Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in Australia (TCCA) held its inaugural meeting and party at the Sydney Townhall on Friday in which 450 guests, including former opposition leader John Hewson, Australian Labor Party members of Parliament and businessmen from Taiwan and Australia took part.
The TCCA comprises Taiwan businessmen based in Queensland, Victoria, New South Wales, Western and Southern Australia and currently has more than 80 members.

Australian analysts said they believe the TCCA will serve as a bridge in improving the already good ties between Australia and Taiwan, not only in trade and investment, but also in cultural and educational, sports and other fields.

"We believe TCCA will play an active role in the improvement of trade and investment between Australia and Taiwan. It will also help increase other ties. Therefore, the establishment of TCCA is significant because it will have a far-reaching impact in boosting bilateral ties between the two countries," one analyst said.
Liu Po-lun, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canberra, gave his blessing to the establishment of the TCCA and wished the chamber success in its endeavors.
Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Australia totaled about A$6 billion in 1997, up slightly from the previous year. Investment between the two countries, however, has lagged behind the trade figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PRAISES DPP DEBATE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday hailed the party's three-day debate on mainland policy, saying consensus reached on the issue will help the DPP take a big step towards coming to power in the central government.

Chen, who did not attend the debate, said he appreciated DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang's adjustment and compromise in his "go west" policy, which he said made it possible for different factions within the party to reach consensus on its mainland policy.
The pro-independence DPP has long been criticized for lacking a clear policy toward mainland China, especially if it hopes to become Taiwan's ruling party.
Chen also expressed delight that the debate drew a great deal of attention from society and that it served to show that the DPP is a democratic, progressive, flexible and responsible political party.
However, Chen stressed that the result will not affect the DPP's basic stance of advocating a public referendum to decide the future of Taiwan.

Hsu said on Sunday at a news conference following the close of the three-day gathering that the debate has enhanced solidarity within the DPP and that the agreements reached in the debate will be submitted to the central standing committee as references for the party's future policymaking on mainland China.

Hsu expressed the belief that the DPP will gain greater support in the year-end mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities if the party can work out a practical policy for dealing with mainland China.
Despite the fact that a number of differences remain among the various party factions, DPP Secretary-General Chiou I-jen lined out the major agreements as follows:
-- Taiwan and mainland China should conduct negotiations.
-- the DPP stands firm on its principle of Taiwan's sovereignty, and the issue cannot be used as a bargaining chip in negotiations with the mainland.
-- to adopt a comprehensive and flexible strategy in negotiations with mainland China, which can include trade and commercial ties and technical issues.
-- to upgrade Taiwan's industrial sector and engage cautiously with mainland China on the economic front.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES EDGE UP

TEXT.P: Share prices edged up on Monday, with the weighted price index, the key barometer of the Taiwan stock exchange (TAIEX), rising 1.83 to close at 8,708.29.

The bourse opened low at 8,673.82 after electrical engineering shares fell in the wake of the US Department of Commerce's verdict on dumping charges against Taiwan and South manufacturers of static random access memory (SRAM) chip over the weekend.
The bourse edged up higher after experiencing a high of 8,729.7 and a low of 8,628.36.
Losers outnumbered gainers 218 to 207, with 54 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.53 billion shares changes hands on a market turnover of NT$151.08 billion (US$4.57 billion) in the three-hour session.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3,000-YEAR-OLD SARCOPHAGUS UNEARTHED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The largest sarcophagus ever found in Taiwan was unearthed in Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan over the weekend, according to a local researcher.

Liu Yi-chang, a researcher at the Institute of History and Philology of Taiwan's highest-level academic institution, Academia Sinica, said he and his team found the 216cm-long and 60cm-wide stone coffin in Wanshan, Tungshan Village.

The largest sarcophagus ever discovered previously in Taiwan was found in Peinan Village, in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County, which had a length of 210 cm. Sarcophagi normally found in Taiwan have a length of between 160 and 180 cm.
Liu estimated that the stone coffin could be as much as 3,100 years old, which should classify it as belonging to the neo-stone age.

Three years ago, archeologists unearthed stone axes, stone bracelets and rings at the same site. Among these artifacts, zoo-anthropomorphic (animal-shaped) jade earrings were deemed the most precious. The finds were dated as belonging to the late neo-stone age period.

The site is located in a 1,000-ping (one ping is about 3.3 square meters) lot owned by Lee Cheng-fu, the chairman of Changfu Enterprise, who recently applied to build a tower on the land for storing the ashes of the deceased.

To try to save possible additional prehistoric treasures from being ruined by the bulldozers, Liu led a team to the site early this month. In the past few days, to the delight of Liu and his team members, they excavated other neo-stone age artifacts, including potsherds, lug handles, net sinkers, stone rings and stone axes.
Liu said his team will continue to excavate about 40 pits over the next three or four weeks to try to unearth more artifacts.
Landowner Lee said that he is willing to postpone construction of the tower to allow Liu and his team more time to continue their excavation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY AND DPP TO HOLD M'LAND CHINA POLICY SYMPOSIUM IN APRIL

TEXT.P: Taiwan opposition New Party Legislator Yao Li-ming, said on Sunday that a symposium on mainland China policy will be held in early April between the New Party and the main opposition pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), as a first step in forging a consensus on the question of policies relating to mainland China.

Yao made the announcement after attending a three-day DPP mainland China Policy Symposium which concluded on Sunday. The symposium was held to try to establish consensus among the various DPP factions on mainland China policymaking.
According to an agreement reached between the mainland affairs sections of both the New Party and the DPP, the two sides have decided to hold a cross-party discussion on mainland relations.

Yao praised the DPP's three-day conference as a first step towards integrating opinions among its factions, and he said he hopes the DPP will take this another step further by contributing to the forging of a consensus among the various political parties in the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO EVACUATE ROC EXPATRIATES FROM INDONESIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has no plans to evacuate its nationals from Indonesia at the moment because the situation there remains under control, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Monday.
Wu made the statement after a series of riots and anti-Chinese demonstrations were reported in several remote Indonesian townships in recent weeks.
Although some Taiwan-owned stores in those areas were ransacked or looted, there have been no casualty reports involving Taiwan businesspeople.

Wu said most ROC expatriates live in major Indonesian cities where public order remains fully intact. There are also no safety problems for students at the Taipei schools in Jakarta and Surabaya because they are closed for winter vacation.

Wu pointed out that even though Indonesia is currently encountering some economic, financial, social and political difficulties, society is not breaking down. "It's too early to talk about evacuation of our expatriates there," he noted.

Nevertheless, Wu reminded local travel agencies to remain cautious and prudent in organizing tour groups to Indonesia. Individual travelers should also heighten their vigilance when visiting that country, he said.

According to statistics released by Indonesian authorities, Taiwan invested a total of US$13.28 billion for 600 projects in Indonesia between 1967 and 1997, making it the sixth largest investor in that Southeast Asian country after Japan, Britain, Hong Kong, Singapore and the United States.

Following the outbreak of Asian financial crisis, Taiwan businesspeople have slowed their investment activities in Indonesia and other Southeast Asian countries and some Taiwan investors in the region have encountered difficulties obtaining loans or export financing. Taiwan's exports to Indonesia also suffered a 51.6 percent year-on-year decline in January.
Minister Chiao Jen-ho of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) said the commission has set up a special fund to offer emergency loans to overseas Chinese businesspeople.
"Taiwan-funded companies in Indonesia can apply for such loans if they encounter difficulties due to current anti-Chinese riots in that country," Chiao said.
Indonesia has some 8 million ethnic Chinese, but few of them are ROC passport holders. "All ethnic Chinese attacked in the recent riots are Indonesian nationals, not ROC expatriates," Chiao noted.

Meanwhile, OCAC Vice Minister Ko Wei-shin said wealthy ethnic Chinese businessmen in Indonesia are not facing imminent dangers because they mostly live in large cities. Many of them have donated sugar, cooking oil, rice and other daily necessities for distribution to needy people in rural Indonesia through military and police authorities or Islamic mosques and other religious groups as part of efforts to improve relations with local people.

Ko further said most ethnic Chinese living in remote or small Indonesian townships operate groceries or small shops. "Although they are not rich, many of them offer discount prices for various consumer products for poor Indonesians," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO FORGE "SUPRAPARTY" MAINLAND POLICY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh said on Monday that the MAC is actively working out a "supraparty" policy toward mainland China as a way of forging national consensus in future negotiations with the mainland.
As the government's mainland policy plays a vital role in Taiwan's security, Chang said the policy itself should not be a focus of disputes between the nation's different political parties.

As a matter of fact, Chang said, one of the 36 agreements reached in the nonpartisan National Development Conference held in late 1996 was to forge national consensus on the government's policy toward the mainland and that the government would collect different opinions from different political camps on the issue.

However, Chang fell short of elaborating on what is a supraparty mainland policy, but stressed that such a policy should take into account national security, benefits to the people of Taiwan, and the future of all Chinese people.

Y.H. Lin, deputy director-general of the Department of Policy Research under the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said consensus reached by the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Sunday following a three-day debate on its mainland policy is similar to the KMT's current mainland policy.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the Vanguard Foundation, Lin hailed the DPP's debate on the issue as enhancing the general public's concern over cross-strait affairs, but said that the major agreements reached in the debate coincide with the KMT's present dealings with mainland China, which are based on maintaining the status-quo with the mainland.

Lin said the KMT has always been supportive of across-the-board dealings with mainland China, even prior to the suspension of cross-strait talks between the two sides, despite its understanding that bilateral political negotiations will be difficult at present. He was referring to one of the DPP's final agreements which urges a stronger Taiwan industrial sector while cautiously engaging with the mainland on the economic front.

Meanwhile, opposition New Party Legislator Yao Li-ming said his party and the DPP have reached a tentative agreement to hold a joint seminar on mainland China affairs in early April as a first step towards forging national consensus in Taiwan's policy toward the mainland.

Yao, who was present at the DPP's three-day debate, also gave a high appraisal of the DPP's seriousness towards the issue and the democratic manner in which it held the debate. He said it will also help the New Party understand the differences among the various DPP factions and can serve as a reference for the New Party when it forms its own relevant policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ERSO DIRECTOR TO DEFEND TAIWAN AT ANTI-DUMPING HEARING

TEXT.P: Genda Hu, president of the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA), left for the United States on Monday to fight US dumping charges leveled against the island's manufacturers of static random access memory (SRAM) chips.

Hu, concurrently director-general of the Electronics Research and Service Organization (ERSO) under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), said prior to his departure that he will try his utmost to fight for Taiwan's SRAM makers during a final public hearing to be held by the federal International Trade Commission (ITC) on Feb. 18.
The US Department of Commerce (DOC) last week delivered its final verdict on dumping charges against Taiwan and South Korean SRAM manufacturers.

ITC officials said DOC Assistant Secretary Robert S. Larussa has already signed the verdict which will allow for punitive anti-dumping tariffs on individual Taiwan and Korean SRAM makers, but the DOC won't make a formal announcement until Tuesday.

According to US anti-dumping regulations, the ITC will hold a final public hearing on Feb. 18, and will decide by the end of March whether Taiwan SRAM makers have really hurt the interests of Micron, the US firm which filed the dumping charges in March 1997. If the ITC upholds the DOC's final verdict, Taiwan-made SRAM chips will be subject to punitive anti-dumping tariff rates starting in April.

The Feb. 18 public hearing therefore will be the last chance for Taiwan SRAM makers to defeat the charges said Hu, who was accompanied by Chang Ching-chu, vice president of Winbond Electronics, which was slapped with an anti-dumping tariff rate of 102.83 percent as a result of the DOC verdict.

Hu said the good news about the verdict is that Taiwan-made SRAMs built into motherboards are not subject to the anti-dumping tariffs, which will help minimize the impact on Taiwan makers. About three-quarters of Taiwan-made SRAMs bound for the US are built into motherboards.

The bad news, he said, is that the anti-dumping tariff rates listed in the DOC's final verdict, some of which are much higher than those proposed in its initial verdict delivered last September, are so high that it will be difficult for the defendants to convince ITC officials during the Feb. 18 hearing that Taiwan SRAMs are not damaging the US industry.

Despite the slim chance of being able to overturn the verdict, Hu said Taiwan makers will still try their utmost to defend themselves against the anti-dumping charges because the case may set a precedent for future cases which are likely to be numerous, since Taiwan has become a major supplier of semiconductor chips like SRAMs, DRAMs, and others.

According to the DOC's final verdict, the anti-dumping tariff rate for SRAMs produced by Taiwan's Winbond Electronics will reach 102.83 percent, compared to the 94.1 percent originally proposed. The punitive tariff rate for another major Taiwan semiconductor producer, United Microelectronics Corp., has also been increased from 63.36 percent to 93.87 percent, while the rate for Alliance Semiconductor Corp. has been dropped from 59.06 percent to 50.58 percent, and that for Hsicheng Co. has been lowered to 7.59 percent from 10.96 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S DECEMBER FOREX RESERVES TOTAL US$74.7 BILLION

TEXT.P: Despite the spread of the regional currency crisis throughout Southeast Asia since July 1997, Singapore's foreign exchange reserves still kept increasing, totaling S$119.62 billion (about US$74.7 billion) by the end of last year.

According to figures released by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), by December 31, 1997, Singapore had accumulated foreign exchange reserves amounting to S$119.62 billion, an increase of S$980 million over last November's S$118.64 billion.

However, the growth of customer credit loans from local banks declined to 12.8 percent last December, down from 13.7 percent the previous month, showing that business operations of Singapore's manufacturing and commerce sectors, as well as non-bank financial institutions, slowed down during the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DEFENDS CANBERRA'S SUPPORT FOR US-LED STRIKE ON IRAQ

TEXT.P: Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has defended Canberra's support for A US-led war against Iraq and warned that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is concealing enough chemical weapons to poison the entire world.

He said that although a peaceful settlement was always preferable to military action, the Iraqi government is no closer to proposing an acceptable solution to the eight-year impasse over UN weapons inspections.

In response to criticism from the Australian Labor Party and Islamic groups for Australia's support of the US, Downer said Iraq has enough VX nerve gas to kill everyone on the planet, while a mere ounce of anthrax spores passed through the air-conditioning system of a sports stadium could kill 70,000 people.
He said UN investigations have revealed that Iraq is unable to account for 600 tons of raw materials that could be used to make around 200 tons of VX nerve gas.
Releasing a Department of Foreign Affairs briefing paper detailing the extent of Iraq's chemical weapon's arsenal on Sunday, Downer ruled out criticism that a military strike was unnecessary.
"Saddam Hussein has form. People who say he'd never use these weapons are wrong because Saddam Hussein has used chemical weapons against Iran, he's used (them) against his own people," he said.
"Any leader who will use chemical weapons against his own people would be prepared to use chemical weapons against anybody," he said.
Downer denied that any military action was aimed at toppling Saddam Hussein, saying it is for the Iraqi people to choose their own leader.
"If it comes to a military strike, the aim will be to destroy the chemical and biological weapon capabilities of Iraq and also some of its missile capabilities," he added.
Australia has offered to send nearly an entire squadron of Special Air Service group troops for rescue missions for downed allied pilots and two Boeing 707s for air-to-air refueling.
In 1991, Australia sent two warships to the Middle East during the Gulf War.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.038 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at NT$32.858.
The greenback opened 32.861 and was traded between 32.825 and 32.972.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$335 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-FUNDED FIRMS IN LESOTHO URGED TO SUSPEND OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has asked all Taiwan-invested companies in the southern African Kingdom of Lesotho to suspend operations, ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Monday.

"We have kept close contact with our representative offices in South Africa since a riot erupted at a Taiwan-funded textile factory in Lesotho last Thursday, which resulted in the death of two workers and the injury of more than 40 others," Wu told a press conference.

In addition to immediately asking ROC nationals to close their shops or factories in Lesotho and evacuate their families, the ROC representative offices in Johannesburg and Durban have also managed to push South African authorities to issue 14-day temporary visas to ROC expatriates fleeing Lesotho.

To date, Wu said, nearly all the Taiwan businesspeople residing in Lesotho have already fled to South Africa. Most of them are staying with friends or relatives in the town of Ladybrand, not far from the border between the two countries.

Wu said the ministry has ordered the representative offices in Johannesburg and Durban to extend the ROC government's concern for the well-being of the refugees and to offer them all necessary assistance.

"The representative offices have also asked South African diplomats stationed in Lesotho to convey to the kingdom the ROC government's concern about the incident and its demand for better protection, both physical and material, of its nationals there," Wu said, adding that the ROC earnestly hopes Lesotho will help resolve the labor-management dispute at the Taiwan-owned factory as soon as possible so that Taiwan investors can return to continue their business operations.

Although the ROC cut diplomatic ties with Lesotho in 1994 after the African kingdom switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing, sources said there are still some 300 ROC expatriates residing in the country, nearly half of whom come from Putze, a small township in the southern Taiwan county of Chiayi.
According to the sources, the ROC representative offices in South Africa have also maintained good relations with Lesotho's military and police authorities.

Reports from Johannesburg said workers at the Hsieh An Textile Co. in the twon of Ha-Thetsane, southeast of the capital, Maseru, went on strike a week ago to demand higherpay. The strike turned into a riot when about 1,000 striking workers took the plant management hostage Thursday night and spent the night at the factory. By Friday morning the situation had deteriorated further as striking workers threw stones at the factory and attacked people of Chinese origin. One mainland Chinese worker was killed. A nearby factory, run by a local Chinese community leader, was also affected. The riot ended only after police opened fire on the rioters.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSSIBLE DOMESTIC NUCLEAR DUMP SITES TO BE UNVEILED

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) said on Monday it will send a list of possible sites for construction of a dump for permanent disposal of low-grade nuclear waste to the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC) for screening before the end of this month.

Taipower, a state-run enterprise, said there are several suitable sites. "In addition to the five sites previously unveiled, several new sites on remote islets controlled by the military will also be included in the list," said Lin Ming-hsiung, a Taipower department chief.

The five previously proposed sites are Wan-an in the offshore Penghu County, Ta-jen and Chinfeng in the eastern Taitung County, Mutan in the southern county of Pingtung and Chukwang on the offshore defense outpost of Matsu.
Because of strong opposition from local residents, Taipower has delayed in deciding a site for construction of a low-grade nuclear waste dump.
Press reports said Taipower has negotiated with military authorities for several months for striking a deal on the nuclear dump construction project.
According to the reports, several military-controlled islets, including Wuchiu, Tungchu and Pengchiayu, are among the most likely sites to accommodate the proposed nulcear waste dump.

Taipower said Taiwan currently has 172,550 barrels of low-grade nuclear waste. About 97,000 barrels have been stored on the Orchid Island off the southeastern Taiwan coast, while the rest are placed at Taipower's three existing nuclear power plants and a national nuclear power research institute.
Taipower said it needs only a piece of land of one square kilometer to build a dump for permanent disposal of all the low-grade nuclear waste.
Studies by local nulcear energy experts and geologists show that there are several sites in Taiwan or its offshore islands suitable for nuclear waste permanent disposal.

The Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said it will carefully select a final site after receiving the Taipower-proposed list of possible locations. The council is expected to unveil its choice in three months.

Taipower plans to spend NT$100 million conducting geological and environmental impact study at the AEC-approved site starting in June. Taipower said it hopes construction of the nuclear dump can be completed by 2004.

The company has launched a series of publicity campaign to enlist popular support for its nuclear dump construction project. It has also promised to give NT$3 billion (US$91.46 million) to the township where the dump will be located. Of the amount, 70 percent will be directly given to the township government for improving welfare services to its residents, and the remaining 30 percent will be appropriated to the county government for community development projects. If the site is under military control, Taipower will give the money to military authorities.

An AEC official said Taiwan has manpower, technology and financial resources to dispose of low-grade nuclear dump. "What we lack is only a dump," the official said, adding that the AEC will strictly supervise the construction and future management of the dump in order to ensure safety and zero accident.

Taipower once struck a deal with North Korea to ship up to 60,000 barrels of low-grade nuclear waste to that country for permanent disposal. But the contract has not been implemented because of complex political reasons, including opposition from the international community and North Korea's lack of funds for building a dump.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRPLANE CRASHES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A China Airline A-300 aircraft crashed near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan Monday evening with many casualties, said airport sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOHN CHANG, S. KOREAN PM-DESIGNATE MEET: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Kuomintang official on Monday confirmed that KMT Secretary-General John Chang met with South Korean Prime Minister-designate Kim Jong-pil during his trip to Seoul last week.
The official, who asked not to be named, said that Chang had a two-hour talk with Kim on the development of relations between Taiwan and South Korea.
The official said he would not disclose details of the Chang-Kim discussions in compliance with an agreement reached between the two.
"The talks have opened a new channel of communications between Taipei and Seoul, thus contributing greatly to increasing bilateral ties," he stressed.

Chang paid a four-day visit to Seoul Feb. 11-14, making him the highest-ranking official of the Republic of China's ruling party to visit South Korea since the two nations severed diplomatic ties in 1992. Taipei-Seoul relations have remained distant since that year.
Chang was forced to cancel a planned meeting with South Korean President Kim Dae-jung due to interference from Beijing, the official said.

Kim, however, had one of his close aides extend an apology to Chang over the aborted meeting and asked the KMT secretary-general to forward a personal letter from him to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, the official said.
According to a CNA dispatch from Seoul, Chang also met with Lew Jong-keun, Kim Dae-jung's special economic adviser.
Lew reportedly will be tipped by Kim Dae-jung to become one of Seoul's key liaison officers with Taipei after Kim is sworn in later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF PRAISES DPP'S CONSENSUS ON M'LAND POLICY

TEXT.P: The government's top mainland affairs official on Monday praised the consensus the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has reached on the party's policy toward mainland China.

Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that the DPP's statement is in the same spirit as the existing mainland policy of the government, which proposes enhancing cross-strait relations step by step.
Chang made the remarks in an interview with CNA.

The DPP, the island's largest opposition party, announced at the conclusion of a recent three-day party symposium that it will adopt a "comprehensive" strategy in negotiations with Beijing, promote the upgrade of Taiwan's industrial sector and engage cautiously with the mainland on the economic front.

The MAC head stressed that the government has long hoped that Taiwan and mainland China will replace their current antagonism with harmonious relations and that the two sides will develop mutually-beneficial trade and economic exchanges.

The current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait -- with Beijing yet to renounce the use of force against Taiwan -- must be taken into consideration amid Taiwan businesses' pursuit of mainland markets, which, given mainland China's huge population and abundant resources, is seen as a potential gold mine, Chang said.

He reiterated the government's call for local enterprises that wish to expand their businesses in the mainland to ensure their roots on the island are deep, which he pointed out would reduce the political and economic risks involved in mainland investment.

Regarding cross-strait negotiations, Chang revealed that his ministry is working on a "sur-factional" mainland policy based on the consensus reached at the 1996 National Development Conference, saying opinions from different political parties -- including the DPP -- will also be included.

The MAC official did not reveal specifics of the "sur-factional" policy but merely stressed that a good mainland China policy should take the nation's safety, people's welfare and the future of all of China into serious consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR FEARED DEAD IN AIRPLANE CRASH

TEXT.P: Sheu Yuan-dong, governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC), has been confirmed to have been aboard a passenger airplane that crashed Monday evening at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Also on board were Sheu's wife and three CBC officials-- Director General of the Foreign Exchange Department Chen Huang, Director General of the Economic Research Department Chien Chimim and Director General of the Department of Secretariat Lin Rong-tien-- according to director General of the Civil Aeronautics Administration Tsai Tuei, who rushed to the scene after the tragedy to direct the rescue operation.
Sheu and his entourage were returning from a conference of the Association of the Southeast Asian Central Bank governors at Bali island in Indonesia.

The ill-fated China Airlines A-300 , bound from Bali to Taipei with 182 passengers and 14 crew aboard, crashed on a highway near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan Monday evening after hitting a building. The only person found alive at the scene so far was a boy about ten years old.
The boy, who might not have been a passenger, was pronounced dead after being sent to a nearby hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU MEETS CHAD PRESIDENT, PM
DOC.DATELINE: N'djamena, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Ling-ju Yen and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Monday called on Chadian President Idriss Deby and Prime Minister Nassour Ouado for discussions on ways to promote bilateral relations between the Republic of China and Chad.
Hu arrived here in Chad's capital on Sunday on the first leg of his week-long, six-nation trip that will also take him to Guinea-Bissau, the Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe and Burkina Faso.
The ROC resumed diplomatic ties with Chad in August last year after a 25-year hiatus. Deby visited Taipei two months later.

Taiwan has sent a medical team to the African country, which has been ravaged by a 30-year civil war, and has helped dig five wells to increase the drinking water supply there. A Taiwan mission composed of agricultural experts will arrive here in March to help develop the nation's economy.
After being honored by President Deby at a luncheon, Hu left N'djamena for Guinea-Bissau.
Hu went to Senegal in mid-January to preside over a meeting of Taiwan's diplomatic personnel stationed in African countries. Not long afterward, he journeyed to Swaziland and Malawi.

Hu's frequent African visits are part of the ROC's efforts to consolidate ties with its African allies after South Africa and the Central African Republic switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL AIRLINER CRASHES NEAR CKS AIRPORT, KILLS 196

TEXT.P: A China Airlines (CAL) Airbus A-300 passenger plane with 196 on board crashed near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan Monday evening, a CAL spokesman said Monday.

The ill fated airliner, which took off from the Indonesian resort of Bali in the afternoon, was to have landed at the airport in the evening. It was ordered to take a "go around" after a failed landing attempt due to poor visibility at the airport caused by heavy fog.
The plane then first hit the airport fence before it crashed into a residential area on the Western Coastal Highway.

A 10-year boy was rescued and rushed to a nearby hospital for treatment. But he died before reaching the hospital. Four others, including two from the destroyed residences and two others from cars on the highway, were confirmed dead.
Airport officials said that because the plane burst into flame, the chances that any of the 182 and passengers or 14 crew members survived are very slim.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECISION ON BAYER'S LAND-LEASE CONTRACT DELAYED AGAIN

TEXT.P: As more than 1,000 opponents of a proposed toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) plant in central Taiwan's Taichung County protested outside the Taiwan Provincial Assembly on Monday, an assembly panel inside again voted to delay their decision on the plant's land-lease contract, dealing another blow to the German chemical giant Bayer.

Because the ruling Kuomintang, however, has called on its members to support the proposed NT$49.2 billion (US$1.5 billion) Bayer TDI plant as a showcase for the government's plan to make the island a regional operational hub, there is still a chance that the land-lease contract will be approved Tuesday when it reaches the transportation committee Tuesday and later on Feb. 26 when it is sent to the floor of the Assembly, where the ruling party enjoys a comfortable majority.

Monday's debate on the contract, which would allow Bayer to lease a plot of Taiwan Province-owned land near Taichung Harbor for the site of its billion-dollar plus chemical plant, reopened Monday morning at a panel while a group of protesters rallied outside the conference site.

The protesters, led by You Pi-ling, the female head of Wuchi township, came from four rural towns around the site of the proposed plant. They shouted anti-Bayer slogans and waved signs calling for a local plebiscite to decide the fate of the project.

They clashed with riot police when they tried to storm into the conference site and scuffled with a handful of project supporters. One of the supporters, who emerged from the conference site after presenting a petition with 15,000 signature in favor of the Bayer plant, was beaten by a number of the protesters.

Under a local assemblywoman's mediation, 50 opponents were allowed to entered the site to monitor the debate of the ad hoc panel, which, after three hours of discussion, voted to postpone any decision on the grounds that there are still fears of the project's safety among local residents.
The panel, caught between the strong pressure from local anti-Bayer groups and the central government's urge for approval, also delayed the same decision on Dec. 18.

At that time, the German giant announced in disappointment that it would scrap its TDI project. The central government, however, asked Bayer to hold off the decision until the project's fate was formally determined.

In an attempt to allay the public's fear of the proposed plant, the central government organized a fact-finding team comprising local assembly delegates and industrial experts to visit Bayer's headquarters in Dormagen, Germany earlier this month.
The team members were favorably impressed by Bayer's environmental protection measures and its safety record in handling phosgene, the poisonous chemical needed in the production of TDI.
Bayer promised not to abandon the project that it began two years ago until the end of February when the Taiwan Provincial Assembly is scheduled to debate it on the Assembly floor.

Despite Monday's setback, Yang Wen-hsing, vice speaker of the Assembly and a KMT member, said that the Assembly will debate the issue on Feb. 26 as scheduled if it is approved by the Transportation Committee on Tuesday.

In order to shepherd the project successfully through the Assembly, Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development P.K. Chaing, the Cabinet member in charge of the Bayer project, threw a luncheon Monday for the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, but only a few of the 73 members showed up.

At a press conference ahead of the luncheon, Chiang lauded Bayer, noting that it boasts of 19 TDI plants around the globe, is one of five firms in the world that engage in TDI production, and has accumulated the equivalent of about 400 years of production experience per plant in total without any accident.
The press conference also featured a display of the form of Styrofoam through the reaction of TDI and resin that Chiang said demonstrates the safety of the proposed Bayer plant.
Horst Mueck, chairman of the Bayer Taiwan Co., regretted on Monday that the protesters used violence. He said that in a free society, Bayer's supporters are entitled to express their opinion.

Chen Chia-chung, a spokesman for the company, said that Bayer will stick to its timetable for the resumption of its Taiwan TDI project, which requires the approval of the land-lease contract by the end of February and ground to be broken before September.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIO OF CBC GOVERNOR SHEU YUAN-DONG

TEXT.P: Governor of the Central Bank of China Sheu Yuan-dong, who is believed to have died in an airplane crash Monday evening in Taoyuan, was a career financial official with broad experience in the field of finance.

He has served as director of the Department of Monetary Affairs under the Ministry of Finance from 1982 to 1984, chairman of the Land Bank of Taiwan from 1984 to 1990, and chairman of the Bank of Taiwan from 1990 to 1995 before being tapped to be CBC governor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO ASK JAKARTA FOR RIOT COMPENSATION FOR ROC NATIONALS

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Monday that the ministry will ask Jakarta authorities to compensate any ROC nationals who suffered losses in the upheavals that have rocked Indonesia recently.
Roy Wu said that Taipei would convey its demands through its representative office to Jakarta because of the absence of diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Indonesia.

Chinese businessman, including those from Taiwan, were singled out as targets in the rioting, as mobs in several locations in Indonesia ran amok in protest against rocketing prices in the wake of that country's financial woes.

Wu said the priority of the ministry for the time being is to ask the Jakarta authorities to take effective measures to uphold law and social order as well as to maintain the stability of the economic situation in Indonesia.
The ministry is also keeping in close contact with the Chinese community in Indonesia and will try to protect their property and lives in case of emergency.
Because of the lack of diplomatic ties, Taipei so far has only expressed concerns to Jakarta authorities over the Chinese community's safety rather than any demands, said Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC MAKES LOAN OFFER FOR SOUTHEAST ASIAN BUSINESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to promote its "go South" policy to open Southeast Asian markets despite the regional financial turmoil and will also provide loans to Taiwan businesses and people of Chinese origin in that area, according to Y.D. Sheu, governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC).
Sheu was cited by his deputy Hsu Chia-tung at a press conference here on Monday. Hsu said the governor hopes the loan project can help Taiwan's Southeast Asian trade partners' economic recoveries.

The CBC will deposit a total of US$1.22 billion of its foreign exchange reserve in 61 overseas branch offices of local banks to supply the loan applicants, Hsu said, adding if there is more demand than expected, his bank will add more money to support the needs of Taiwan's business community.
The CBC governor, who was taking part in the annual conference of Southeast Asian central bank governors in Indonesia, has expressed Taiwan's willingness to join in regional financial cooperation.

He urged countries that have suffered in the region's financial storm to devote themselves to the formation of correct macro-economic policies to strengthen their financial structures, saying this would allow the region to enjoy financial stability.

Sheu and his wife, along with three other CBC officials, were on the list of passengers aboard the China Airlines A-300 Airbus plane that crashed Monday evening near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan, causing many casualties and heavy damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONCLUSION OF DPP DEBATES SEEN AS SIMILAR TO KMT POLICY

TEXT.P: The conclusions of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party's just-completed debates on policy toward mainland China are basically similar to the policy of the ruling Kuomintang, although not so comprehensive, a high-ranking official of the ruling party said Monday.

Chang Jung-kung, director general of the Mainland Operations Department of the Kuomintang Central Committee, said at a high-level meeting of the party that the three-day debates have however shown that the DPP is now more able to keep up with cross-strait relations than in April, 1993 when it protested against the first round of high-level unofficial talks between Taiwan and mainland China in Singapore.

During the debates held Feb. 13-15 in Taipei, factional leaders of the opposition party reached a consensus that Taiwan should strengthen its base and deal with the west side of the Taiwan Strait with care. The consensus is very similar to President Lee Teng-hui's "be patient, no haste" policy toward communist China, Chang said.
Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, also made similar remarks Monday.
Several other participants in the meeting told the press they believed that the DPP debates have little substance, although they have generated good publicity for the opposition party.
John Chang, secretary general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, is expected to explain the mainland policy of the ruling party and his views on the DPP debates Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAULT LINES IN JAPAN, MAINLAND CHINA AND US SEEN THREATENING GLOBAL ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Should fault lines in Japan, mainland China and Wall Street occur, the global economy will be threatened with a chain-reaction, the first casualty of which will be the destruction of the fragile "fire-walls" which the International Monetary Fund has erected around the Asian financial crisis.

Writing on the front page of the mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald on Monday, economic writer Max Walsh said Japan will come under pressure when the Tokyo government unveils its latest plan to revive the economy, because Asian leaders expect Japan to take decisive action to kickstart its economy with a strong package of fiscal stimuli that will provide an economic anchor for the region.
The Japanese banking system is deeply integrated with the global banking system and any failure will send ripples through world markets -- ripples that could turn into large waves.
The Asian region takes some 40 percent of Japan's exports, the lion's share of which are capital goods, which the Asian economies no longer can afford.

With Asian markets contracting, Japan will become an even more aggressive exporter to the advanced economies. If Japanese banks cannot or will not roll over loans to the beleaguered Asian economies, then they will experience further turmoil and recession.
That will inevitably increase concern about the impact these developments will have on mainland China.

He said mainland China has embarked on enormous structural change that was always fraught with risk, but which has become much more difficult because of what has happened in the Asian region over the past six months.
Though mainland China has so far come through this financial crisis relatively unscathed, it is still being buffeted by the adverse economic winds blowing across the region.
Many mainland Chinese exports such as clothing, footwear, cheap electronics and light industrial products compete with the output of the now heavily depreciated currencies of Thailand and Indonesia.
Mainland China has been moving its exports further up the value-added chain, but here it has to compete with both Taiwan and South Korea.
Strong export growth is essential for mainland China if it is to move successfully through the next stage of its structural reform without political upheaval.

This has raised fears that mainland China will devalue its currency to make it more competitive. He said mainland China's structural-cum-financial problems are similar to those which have brought South Korea to its knees.
Its banking system has extended excessive credits to industrial enterprises and state-owned enterprises which have operated without being disciplined by bottom-line considerations.
Where mainland China is different is that its banks are state-owned and they have not borrowed from abroad. Being state-owned, their capital base, in effect, is the national tax base.
The same back-stop, access to consolidated revenue, means depositors remain confident that they are viable.

In fact, they are not. While nobody knows the exact problem loan situation of the mainland Chinese banks, the US ratings agency S&P puts it at 60 percent of its gross domestic product, which would make the situation twice as bad as that in Korea, Walsh said.
Investment capital flown to mainland China from Taiwan and Hong Kong is in decline because the two places are grappling with their own problems.

Mainland Chinese leaders have repeatedly said Beijing will not devalue its currency, yet they could reverse their policy next year if the country cannot compete with other Asian exporters in the world market.

A higher proportion of US household wealth is now held in equities than ever before. The long bull run on Wall Street has underwritten consumer confidence and spending. So far, Wall Street has shrugged off the Asian crisis, moving to new record levels. In fact, part of its latest success is because of what is happening in Asia, because many investors in Asia have pulled out their money and channeled the money into the US, Walsh said.
The last year has seen a sharp increase in the flow of capital from Japan, Hong Kong and Europe into US equities and bond markets.
But should this capital flow stop or move into reverse -- a development which would be on the cards should Japan move into an extended recession -- then Wall Street will be hurt, Walsh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL AIRLINER CRASHES NEAR CKS AIRPORT, KILLS OVER 200

TEXT.P: A China Airlines (CAL) Airbus A-300 passenger plane with 196 on board crashed near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan Monday evening, a CAL spokesman said Monday.

The ill fated airliner, which took off from the Indonesian resort of Bali in the afternoon, was to have landed at the airport at 8:20 in the evening. It was ordered to take a "go around" after a failed landing attempt due to poor visibility at the airport caused by heavy fog.
The plane then first hit the airport fence before it crashed into a residential area along the Western Coastal Highway at 8:07.
Civil Aeronautics Administration Deputy Director General Chang Kuo-cheng said that all the 196 passengers and crew were feared dead as no survivors had been found so far.

A 10-year boy was rescued and rushed to a nearby hospital for treatment. But he died before reaching the hospital. Seven others, including two from the destroyed flats and five from cars on the highway, were confirmed dead. A baby from one of the ruined houses was found alive and was rushed to a hospital.
Chang would not confirm whether Bank of China (CBC) Governor Sheu Yuan-dong and his wife were among the victims, although they and three other CBC officials were on the passenger manifest.
Sheu and the CBC officials were returning from a trip to Bali, where they attended the annual conference of the governors of the Central Bank of Southeast Asia.
Airport officials said that because the plane burst into flame, the chances that any of the 182 passengers or 14 crew members survived are very slim.
Witnesses said that bodies of the victims were scattered over an area of two square kilometers.
Premier Vincent Siew, upon being informed of the accident, expressed his sorrow and regret and he extended his condolences to the families of the victims.
Siew asked the Ministry of Transportation and Communication to investigate the cause of the accident and handle the follow-up.
President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan also expressed their regret over the tragedy.
This was the second major accident for CAL in less than four years. A CAL A-300 airbus plane crashed at Nagoya airport in Japan on April 26, 1994, killing 264 of the 271 on board.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK PEOPLE AGAINST USE OF FORCE TO QUASH TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE BID
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 17 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Most Hong Kong people are against a mainland Chinese invasion of Taiwan, even if the island were to declare outright independence, according to a public opinion poll released on Tuesday.

The telephone poll of 1,000 adult Hong Kong residents, conducted in January by the Hong Kong-based Cross-Strait Relations Research Center, found that 73 percent of the respondents opposed the proposal that Beijing attack Taiwan should the island announce de jure independence, with only 8.8 percent of those polled supporting such an overture.

Survey results also show that 49.8 percent of those interviewed do not think that the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" scheme is applicable to Taiwan, while 23.7 percent said they believe Beijing can successfully use this formula to unify Taiwan with the mainland.
Asked about whether they support permanent separation of Taiwan from the Chinese mainland, 59.7 percent responded negatively, while only 17.8 percent gave a thumbs-up.
Meanwhile, 42.2 percent said they are pessimistic about the prospects for peaceful reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, compared to 32.9 percent who sounded a positive note.

The survey further found that 75.8 percent of the respondents think Hong Kong and Taiwan should exchange official representative offices to boost bilateral relations, while 13.6 percent oppose the proposal.

About 53 percent said they believe Hong Kong's reversion to mainland Chinese rule has weakened the territory's role in promoting relations across the Taiwan Strait, but 29.4 percent said held a contrary opinion.

Nearly 44 percent said they feel Taiwan-Hong Kong relations have remained unchanged following Hong Kong's handover on July 1, 1997; 35.2 percent said they think post-handover Taiwan-Hong Kong ties have worsened; but 9.3 percent said they feel bilateral relations have improved over the past half-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
