DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST WASTE CATALYST RECYCLING CENTER TO BE ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: A local business on Monday signed an agreement with a Japanese company to construct Taiwan's first waste catalyst recycling center.
Representatives from Taiwan's Lunghwa Engineering Services and Japan's Toyo Gijutsu Koheki signed the agreement at the Taipei Hilton Hotel.
Under the agreement, both sides will initially invest NT$350 million (US$10.73 million) to establish a recycling plant for waste catalyst in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.
The Japanese side also promised to transfer the catalyst recycling technology to its Taiwan partner unconditionally.
Tzou Shih-chao, deputy director-general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center of the Republic of China Ministry of Economic Affairs, witnessed the ceremony.

Tzou expressed hope that the agreement will help the technology for recycling catalysts quickly take root in Taiwan to help ease pollution problems in the oil refining, petrochemical, metallurgy, and electronics industries.

The center will be located at the Haihu Industrial Park in Luchu Village, Taoyuan County, and will recycle 6,000 tons of catalyst annually, or about two-thirds of the domestic catalyst industry's current output.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU ARRIVES IN GUINEA-BISSAU FOR BRIEF VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Bissau, Guinea-Bissau, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Yen Ling-ju and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu arrived in Guinea-Bissau on Monday following a whirlwind visit to Chad.
This is the second leg of Hu's current six-country African shuttle visit aimed at shoring up the Republic of China's relations with its African allies.

During his brief stay in the Portuguese-speaking West African state, Hu will donate two fire engines to Guinea-Bissau's Interior Ministry and two ambulances to its public health department on behalf of the ROC government. He will also take a look at the country's new international airport and parliamentary building construction projects.

Hu will meet with Guinea-Bissau's acting President Malam Bacai Sanha, acting Prime Minister Samba Lamine Mane and acting Foreign Minister Engo Joao Cardoso on Tuesday morning to discuss ways for further boosting bilateral exchanges and cooperation in various fields.

Guinea-Bissau President Joao Bernardo Vieira is currently on a visit to France, while Premier Carlos Correia and Foreign Minister Fernando Delfim Da Silva are visiting Portugal following their just-concluded trip to Taiwan.
Hu will leave for the Gambia on Tuesday afternoon to continue his diplomatic swing, which will also take him to Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe as well as Burkina Faso.
During his visit to Chad, Hu met with Chadian President Idriss Deby and Prime Minister Nassour Ouado for an exchange of views on matters of mutual concern.

This is Hu's third visit to Africa since he assumed office late last year. He went to Senegal in mid-January to chair a meeting of ROC diplomats stationed in African countries. Not long afterward, he visited Swaziland and Malawi.

Hu's frequent African visits are part of Taiwan's efforts to cement ties with its allies on that continent after South Africa and the Central African Republic switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE TROOPS LEAVE FOR GULF TO BACK US-LED STRIKE AGAINST IRAQ

TEXT.P: Australian elite troops and two Boeing 707 aircraft are leaving Tuesday for the Persian Gulf in support of a US-led force in the case a military strike against Iraq is inevitable, Prime Minister John Howard said.
In a statement, Howard said the National Security Committee of the federal Cabinet has authorized the deployment of elements of the Australian Defense Force to the Gulf.

Howard traveled to Perth on Tuesday morning to bid farewell to about 190 troops, including 110 Special Air Service soldiers and two Boeing 707s for air-to-air refueling purposes during the military action.
Howard also said the New Zealand prime minister contacted him on Monday and indicated his country would send elite troops to the Gulf as well in support of the US-led action against Iraq.
"Every effort will be made for cooperation between the Australian and New Zealand forces should military action become necessary," he said.

"I want to emphasize that the contribution that Australia is making demonstrates our desire to make it plain to Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi leadership that a growing number of the states of the civilized world will not tolerate or agree to his continued possession of and capacity to deliver weapons of mass destruction. That does represent a threat not only to the immediate region, but also in the long run to the security of nations around the world," he said.
The Australian troops and the aircraft will be based in Kuwait.

Howard on Monday said: "The government continues to hope that force will not be needed. We strongly support diplomatic efforts to persuade Iraq to comply fully with UN Security Council resolutions requiring it to dismantle its chemical and biological weapons programs and allow inspections. There is still time for Iraq to reconsider," he said.
This will be the second time for Australia to support its Western allies in the Middle East. In 1991, Australia sent two warships to the Gulf to provide the Allies a naval blockade against Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRESH RIOTS HIT TOWNS IN JAVA, SUMATRA

TEXT.P: Fresh rioting hit the West Java town of Pangalengan on Monday while unrest continued in the South Sumatra subdistrict of Pangaralam.
In Pangalengan, police arrested three people on charges of inciting the riot in which eight shops were attacked and looted before the situation was brought under control.
The riot coincided with a mass strike by bus drivers protesting against spiraling prices of essential commodities and auto parts.

An eyewitness was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying people were seen loitering around in several places waiting for buses. They turned violent after being provoked to riot by another group of people.
The mob threw stones at shops and houses. Dozens of security officers quickly moved in to disperse the approximately 200 rioters.
Rumors of an imminent riot abounded in Bandung, but came to nothing. Security officers were visible in strategic areas of that city.
Meanwhile, the South Sumatra town of Pagaralam, 200 kilometers south of the capital Palembang, remained tense Monday after being rocked with violent protests over price increases on Sunday.
It was reported that a mob damaged three shops belonging to entrepreneurs of Chinese descent.
Security was tight and shops remained closed throughout Monday, the report said.
In Ende, East Nusa Tengara, police said 56 people have been arrested in connection with riots on Feb. 8, in which dozens of shops were set on fire.
In East Java, the police warned that they would not hesitate to shoot rioters "who pose a great danger to others."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA ON TRACK TO BETTER TIES, SAYS GOH

TEXT.P: Singapore and Malaysia are on track to achieving better bilateral ties, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said Monday in Kuala Lumpur after a meeting with Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, The Straits Times reported Tuesday.

In a dispatch from Kuala Lumpur, the Singapore-based paper also quoted Goh as saying that he and Mahathir had instructed their respective officials to step up efforts to resolve outstanding issues between the two countries.

"There will always be problems and some issues will remain unresolved. But you can't expect issues that have been there for years to be solved in one meeting," he was quoted as telling reporters after touring the Kuala Lumpur City Center.
"But what is important is that we are progressing," he said. "Certainly relations today are better than last year."
Ties between the two neighbors took a sudden turn for the worse last March, following comments by Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew's about crime in the Malaysian city of Johor.
Goh also disclosed Monday that Mahathir had agreed to supply water to Singapore beyond 2061, when the existing water supply agreement expires, "on terms and conditions to be agreed upon."
He declined to give details, noting that officials were still working to come up with wording for the text of the agreement which will be acceptable to both sides, the report said.

Goh, who is in Kuala Lumpur on a two-day working visit, had earlier held a "four-eyes" meeting with the Malaysian leader, which lasted more than an hour. This was followed by a 45-minute closed-door meeting with ministers and officials from both sides, including Singapore Foreign Minister S. Jayakumar.
Briefing the press later, Malaysian Foreign Minister Abdullah Badawi said that relations were "back to normal," the report said.
He said he was very positive and even "bullish" about bilateral ties.

The two leaders had discussed the regional currency crisis, as well as bilateral issues, such as plans to develop Malayan Railway (KTM) land in Singapore, Malaysia's claim to the Singapore-held island of Pedra Branca, as well as the long-term supply of water to Singapore.
Talks on these issues, which have been stalled for about two years, are set to resume, Badawi said.
He also told reporters that both sides planned to work out a mechanism to prevent ties from being unsettled in the future by "pin pricks and irritants," the report said.
These, he added, should be settled by officials and ministers, without waiting for the two prime ministers to meet to thrash them out, the report added.
Goh and his delegation will return to Singapore Tuesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARMOKO YIELDS TO HABIBIE FOR INDONESIAN VICE PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Harmoko, chairman of the ruling Golkar's Functional Group Board of Executives, said he has proudly stepped aside to make way for B.J. Habibie as the party's only nominee for the vice presidency.

"This means Golkar will only propose one nominee, B.J. Habibie, for vice president. President Suharto, in his capacity as the party's patron, has instructed that the decision should be constitutionally processed in the upcoming People's Consultative Assembly," he was quoted by Antara news agency as saying Monday.
Harmoko said he "gave way" for the sake of the party and the nation. He added that he will concentrate on his position as speaker of parliament.
Harmoko spoke to the press following a second plenary meeting of Golkar, held specifically to discuss the vice presidential nominee.
During that meeting, Golkar instructed the Gokar Faction to fight in the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) to win the position for Habibie for the 1998-2003 term.

He said Golkar has received additional input from a meeting involving the ruling party's three divisions, A (Armed Forces), B (bureaucracy) and G (Functional Group). After the meeting, the results were related to the head of state in his capacity as Golkar's patron.
Harmoko did not mention the words "withdraw from the nomination" but said he "give way for Habibie to become the vice presidential nominee."
Therefore, he said, Golkar's decision regarding its next vice presidential nominee is final.

Harmoko added that in the board's first meeting on Feb. 11, the board had two nominees, himself and Habibie. Later, through an internal mechanism, he said, the group's divisions were consulted about the two nominees.
In his meeting with Golkar's patron, Indonesian President Suharto, Harmoko said he gave way for Habibie and would concentrate on his present responsibilities.

Asked whether the party's decision could reduce the exchange rate against the US dollar and the high cost of staple commodities, Harmoko said the decision had nothing to do with the exchange rate or other issues.

"This is Golkar's full responsibility as the largest sociopolitical organization which has agreed to nominate Mohammad Suharto for the next president and B.J. Habibie as his vice president," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR CRASH VICTIMS INCLUDE 7 FOREIGN NATIONALS

TEXT.P: Seven foreign nationals were among the 203 victims killed in Monday's China Airlines (CAL) plane crash near Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, some 30 kilometers southwest of Taipei, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported on Tuesday.

"The foreign nationals include five Americans, an Indonesian and a French passport holder," MOFA spokesman Roy Wu told a news conference, adding that the ministry has informed the three countries' representative offices here of the tragic news.
Wu also extended condolences to the families of the seven foreign
passengers on behalf of ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu and the ministry staff. Hu is currently on a six-country African diplomatic tour.

Wu said the MOFA has ordered its overseas offices to offer all necessary assistance to families of the foreign victims in handling related affairs, such as expediting the issuance of visas to facilitate their trips to Taiwan.
The name list of the seven foreigners follows:
-- Laurence Smith, male, American passport number 152563712;
-- Christopher Cory, male, American passport number 084557069;
-- Kenneth Cowan, male, American passport number 101820963;
-- Jacques Augustin, gender not specified, American passport holder, number not given;
-- Tom Hadel, male, American passport number 27194133;
-- Sukadarma Nyoman, gender not specified, Indonesian passport number E191938;
-- Rachel Liu, gender not specified, French passport number 130190002794.

Among the victims killed in Monday's crash, 196 were aboard the ill-fated CAL Airbus A-300 jetliner, including 182 passengers and 14 crew members. The remaining seven were killed on the ground when the plane ploughed into a row of a dozen houses in dense night fog in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODY IDENTIFICATION SLOW, BLACK BOXES RETRIEVED

TEXT.P: Relatives have identified 78 bodies of those killed in the crash of a China Airlines (CAL) A-300 Airbus plane as of Tuesday morning.
With most of the bodies burned beyond recognition, the identification work proceeded slowly amid the wailing sounds of grieving relatives in the temporary morgue set up by CAL near the crash site.
Coroners were conducting DNA tests throughout the afternoon to help anxious relatives identify their loved ones.

Among the remains that have been identified so far is the body of Central Bank of China Governor Sheu Yuan-dong, who was aboard the ill-fated plane on his return from Bali, Indonesia, where he attended the annual conference of the Governors of the Central Banks of Southeast Asia.

The CAL plane left the resort island of Bali for Taipei in the afternoon, and was due to arrive at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 8:20 p.m. After one aborted landing, the aircraft circled around for a second attempt before it went down short of the runway, crashing into a residential area on the northern side of the airport along the Western Coast Highway at 8:07 p.m.
All 196 passengers and crew members aboard the plane were killed. Two persons died when the aircraft struck their houses and five occupants in a passing car also perished in the tragic crash.

A recording of conversations between the pilots and the control tower prior to the crash was made public Tuesday morning. The situation seemed normal before two ringing sounds were heard immediately before the plane went down.

CAL officials said the French-made A-300 Airbus was only seven years and two months old, had 20,193 flying hours and had made 8,828 landings and takeoffs. It had a good maintenance record and the pilots were experienced.
The officials said they will have to wait for the results of an analysis of the "black box," the cockpit voice and flight data recorders, which were retrieved around 10:00 p.m. Monday.
Airbus officials from France are scheduled to arrive here Tuesday afternoon to help determine the cause of the crash.
CAL officials said the airline has nine other A-300 Airbus planes operating in its fleet.

This was the second major accident for CAL in less than four years. The same model of CAL aircraft crashed at Nagoya Airport in Japan on April 26, 1994, killing 264 of the 271 passengers and crew aboard.
Because of the latest incident, CAL canceled two flights on Tuesday -- flight CI-607 from Taipei to Hong Kong in the morning and flight CI-608 from Hong Kong to Taipei in the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HELPS COSTA RICA PROMOTE TECHNICAL EDUCATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Costa Rica Monday entered into an agreement for cooperation in the promotion of technical professional education.

The agreement was signed by ROC Ambassador Mao Kao-wen and Costa Rican Education Minister Eduardo Doryan Garron on behalf of their government. The ceremony was witnessed by Costa Rican President Jose Maria Figueres, ROC Vice Education Minister Lee Chien-shing, and other dignitaries.

Under the two-year agreement, the ROC will provide US$7 million for establishing electronics, mechanic, and computer professional training centers in Costa Rica. Some of the centers will educate engineers and professional training teachers.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC TO INCREASE FINANCIAL AID TO OVERSEAS CHINESE BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission will gradually increase the fund for guaranteeing business loans to overseas Chinese businessmen, OCAC Minister Chiao Jen-ho said here Tuesday.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the 18th International Trade Study Class for overseas Chinese businessmen in Taipei, Chiao said the OCAC will make it easier for overseas Chinese businessmen to apply for business loans from commercial banks by increasing the fund gradually.
The OCAC will also try to make services of overseas Chinese commercial banks available in more places in the world for the convenience of overseas Chinese businessmen, he said.
President Lee Teng-hui has hoped that where there are overseas Chinese there are overseas Chinese commercial banks, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS HITS MAJOR AUSTRALIAN CASINOS

TEXT.P: The Asian currency crisis has brought casinos throughout Australia falling revenues and forced expansions to be put on hold due to the declining number of gamblers coming to the country from Asia.

In its latest survey, The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business daily, reported that Melbourne's Crown Casino Ltd. has been forced to completely abandon its plans to build a second hotel tower because the Asian economic crisis has taken a toll on its international operations.
Elsewhere, the South Australian government has been forced to cancel the sale of a casino in Adelaide because of a lack of interest from Asian investors.
In Perth, the Burswood Casino has indicated that its revenue from Asian high rollers has been cut substantially as they have been staying at home during the currency turmoil.
The Jupiter Casino in Gold Coast in Queensland has had the same luck, with a report of a worse than expected 40 percent slump in interim net profits to A$12.1 million (US$8.1 million).
The Sydney Harbor Casino has already conceded that occupancy rates at the Star City's hotel are running well below expectations at about 40 percent because Asian tourists have been staying away.
Casino operators are unsure when the current slump will turn around and Asian high rollers will return to Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAMOS WELCOMES JAPANESE ROYALTY TO PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Philippine President Fidel Ramos said on Monday that the current five-day visit here of Prince and Princess Akishino of Japan would further strengthen Philippine-Japanese relations, particularly in cultural exchanges and cooperation.

In welcoming the Japanese imperial couple to Malacanang Monday afternoon, Ramos expressed appreciation for Japan's participation in the centennial celebration of the independence of the Philippines, saying their presence at centennial rites adds honor and prestige to the event.
First lady Amelita Ramos was with the president in welcoming the couple.
Prince and Princess Akishino will grace the opening ceremony of the Philippine-Japan Festival '98 on Tuesday.
The festival will run until April 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE LAUNCHES NEW INT'L FRANCHISE ENTERPRISE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) launched the new International Franchise Enterprise Program (IFEP) Tuesday to provide a higher level of support to Singapore companies in their development and marketing of their franchise concepts.
This is part of the TDB's continuing efforts to promote franchising services overseas and develop Singapore into an international franchise hub with total support capabilities, the TDB said Tuesday.
It pointed out that the IFEP provides an integrated package of assistance and facilitation for three targeted groups:
-- Singapore Franchise Enterprise: Indigenous franchise concepts from Singapore that are expanding overseas;
-- Regional Franchise Enterprise: Singapore enterprises that are acquiring regional master franchise licenses; and
-- Franchise Brand Owners: Singapore enterprises that are acquiring the ownership of international franchises.

The TDB said that Singapore companies with franchise business activities, who fall into any of the three categories, can enjoy the TDB's support and assistance in the acquisition, adaptation and marketing of franchise concepts.
Companies under the Singapore Franchise Enterprise group will receive the following support:
-- Financial assistance up to a maximum of 70 percent of eligible expenses;
-- Support for marketing activities such as marketing trips, fairs and missions; and
-- Support for advertising activities for initial franchise launches overseas.

Companies under the Regional Franchise Enterprise group will receive financial support to acquire the master franchise rights to a foreign franchise for a territory including Singapore and beyond, and sub-franchise parts of this territory to other parties.

The TDB's assistance to this group will be through a combination of grants and tax incentives, providing assistance in acquisition feasibility studies of foreign franchises, support for master franchisees in the adaptation of acquired franchises and help in overseas marketing activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL GIVEN POOR FLIGHT SAFETY RATING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's flagship carrier, ranks among the 29 international air passenger companies with substandard flight safety records, according to a rating compiled by the private US Air Travelers Association.

The rating was based on flight safety records of the world's 260 commercial airliners over the past 10 years. The association gave "perfect" or "near perfect" ratings to 210 carriers. CAL and 28 other carriers were given "flunking" scores.
Besides Monday's crash, CAL had been involved in 11 major flight accidents over the past 30 years, resulting in the death of 411 Taiwan and foreign passengers and crew members.

In the 10-year period alone, running to the end of 1997, CAL recorded four major accidents, including the crash of an Airbus A-300 jet in Nagoya, Japan on April 26, 1994, which killed a total of 322 passengers and crew members onboard.

On Monday, another CAL Airbus A-300 jet crashed near Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, some 30 kilometers southwest of Taipei, in dense night fog and light rain, killing all 196 persons aboard and seven others on the ground.

CAL has embarked on an extensive safety campaign since the 1994 Nagoya crash. It is also actively preparing to increase the number of flights and destinations in the United States, cashing in on the newly signed Taiwan-US open-skies agreement and the US Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) upgrade of Taiwan's rating for flight safety supervision and management.
Under the terms of the open-skies accord, Taiwan carriers can cooperate with their American counterparts in operating many new air routes based on a code-sharing scheme.

The FAA once evaluated Taiwan's civil aviation management and supervision system in 1996. It claimed that Taiwan failed to meet the world requirements for commercial airlines supervision, and thus rated Taiwan's flight safety control system as "second grade."

Through concerted strenuous efforts of Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration and airline companies, the FAA finally agreed to upgrade Taiwan's flight safety control and management system to the "first grade" in April 1997 after several rounds of inspection.
Airline sources said Monday's crash may hinder CAL's plans to expand its global flight services at least in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL CRITICIZED FOR WORST AVIATION DISASTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tsay Jaw-yang, minister of Transportation and Communications, said on Tuesday that his ministry won't be able to announce the reason a China Airlines (CAL) plane crashed Monday evening, killing all 196 on board, until the craft's cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder have been analyzed.
The black boxes of the ill-fated aircraft were retrived Monday night and will be analysed soon.
CAL has nine other A-300 Airbus planes operating in its fleet.
Meanwhile, the former national flag carrier drew flak over the accident, Taiwan's worst aviation disaster.

Chen Hung-ki, whip of the ruling Kuomintang, said in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday that the accident -- CAL's second major disaster in less than four years -- not only revealed the airline's poor flight safety but also has damaged the nation's image.
Another CAL A-300 Airbus crashed at Nagoya Airport in Japan on April 26, 1994, killing 264 of the 271 abroad. Most of the compensation claims have yet to be settled.

Hau Lung-ping, the opposition New Party's whip, said that Tsay should take political responsibility, and that CAL should submit plans to the Legislative Yuan for rigorous training of the airline's pilots.
Chang Chun-hsiung, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's whip, demanded that Tsay ground all CAL planes immediately and resign to take responsibility for the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT BAYER CASE

TEXT.P: Ranking central government officials are still optimistic about the fate of a NT$50 billion (US$1.5 billion) investment plan by the Germany-based Bayer Group to set up a toluene-di-isocyanate (TDI) plant in central Taiwan's Taichung Harbor, despite the Taiwan Provincial Assembly's decision on Monday to delay reviewing the case amid violent protests from more than 1,000 opponents outside the building.

Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang, who chaired a seminar on Monday in Taichung to sell the project, was optimistic after the event. "We will overcome the obstacles step by step," he said.

Although Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party has insisted on holding a public referendum to decide the fate of the Bayer project, Chiang reiterated that such practices lack a legal basis in Taiwan. He called Bayer's case an economic and technical issue and said that the CEPD hopes to resolve the matter through communication with local residents.
Chiang said the government will provide the Taiwan Provincial Assembly with detailed information on Bayer's preventive measures against earthquakes and typhoons to help assuage the people's concern.

Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen said the government supports Bayer setting up the TDI plant near Taichung Harbor in Taichung County, taking into consideration the country's and the area's long-term development.

After more than two years of arrangements and negotiations, Bayer announced in December that it was relocating the project to the United States as a result of strong opposition from local residents over fears that the TDI plant would cause environmental pollution.

But the chemical giant told a visiting fact-finding delegation composed of more than 30 local experts and opinion leaders and ROC government officials early this month that it wouldn't cancel the investment plan in Taiwan should the Taiwan Provincial Assembly pass the land lease contract by the end of this month to facilitate construction on the TDI production plant by September.

CEPD Vice Chairman Y.S. Liu, leader of the delegation, said he and the others were very impressed by Bayer's environmental protection and safety measures, adding that the company has already spent NT$1.5 billion in foundation work at the construction site and that earthquakes and typhoons should not be a cause for the public to worry.

Other delegates voiced regrets for not having enough time to report their recent trip to Bayer's headquarters in Dormagen, central Germany, to the public. They said that Taiwan would lose a significant chance of upgrading its industrial sector if Bayer's plans fail to materialize here.

Despite the central government's efforts to push for the Bayer plant, it remains to be seen whether the Taiwan Provincial Assembly will approve Bayer's land lease contract by the end of this month, the deadline set by Bayer.

Meanwhile, the results of a public opinion survey made public on Monday by the Taichung County Government showed that 39 percent of the total county population are in favor of Bayer's project, while 21 percent support the plan conditionally. Only 24 percent are opposed to the plan.

The results are significantly different than those of an earlier poll of people living in the four townships near Taichung Harbor, which showed 40 percent of the public opposed to the investment plan, while only 26 percent backed the project.
The Taichung County Government has said that the fate of the Bayer plant will be decided by the residents of the four townships near the harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF WOULD GIVE OFFICIAL RESPONSE TO FORMAL REACTION FROM ARATS: MAC

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), remarked on Monday that should Beijing respond formally to a proposal that the head of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) visit mainland China, the SEF would respond in kind.
The SEF has written twice to its Beijing-based counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), proposing that SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu visit mainland China, he noted.

Chang was responding to reports that ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei recently told a delegation from Taiwan's New Party that was visiting mainland China that ARATS is taking the SEF's proposal of a visit by Koo "seriously."

According to an agreement reached in 1993 between Koo and his mainland counterpart, ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, the two sides should conduct regular high-level exchanges, Chang noted, adding that the SEF has not received a formal reply to its twice-issued proposal that Koo travel to mainland China.
He stressed that ARATS should respond formally to the proposed visit. He went on to say that the SEF's fax machine is always on, and that a faxed letter from ARATS could resolve the situation.

Koo has said that he would be willing to visit the mainland and meet relevant officials so that a "warmer atmosphere can be created" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chang noted. If there is a difference of opinion, the MAC official added, "we hope the mainland could tell us formally by sending us a letter."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS PLANS TO WITHDRAW AGRICULTURAL TEAMS FROM INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan may withdraw its two agricultural technical teams from Indonesia, if their safety is threatened by riots.
Scattered protests against price hikes have turned into riots, in which overseas Chinese shopkeepers in that country have been attacked in recent weeks.

An official of the International Cooperation Development Fund, which keeps frequent contacts with the two teams, said Tuesday that authorities in Taipei are very concerned about the riots and the safety of overseas Chinese in that country.

The two countries entered into agricultural technical cooperation agreement in 1976. There are 12 Taiwan agricultural experts working at Jogjakarta in central Java and Sprabaja in eastern Java. Leaders of the two teams have been told to get contingency plans ready for prompt withdrawal from that country in case of need, the official said.
But he said the contingency plans will be used only as a last resort. The local Indonesians are unlikely to attack the agricultural teams from Taiwan, because they enjoy cordial friendship, he added.
In addition to Indonesia, Taiwan has agricultural technical teams working in such Asian Pacific countries as Thailand, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Nauru.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR, SHARE PRICES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar finished at 32.926 against the US dollar in the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, down NT$0.068 from Wednesday.
After opening at 32.851, the greenback had a high of 32.949 and a low of 32.85.
Interbank transactions totaled US$240 million.
Meanwhile, share prices in the Taiwan stock market opened lower but ended higher, with the weighted index, the local bourse's major indicator, surging by 73.8 points to close at 8,782.09.

Electrical engineering issues posted the largest increase of 3 percent, while construction shares contracted the largest drop of 1 percent. Losers outnumbered gainers 248 to 187, with 45 issues remaining stable.
A total of NT$2.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turn of NT$185.3 billion in the three-hour session.
Among the 10 most heavily traded issues were Taiwan Semiconductor, United Micro Electronic, Chuntex Electronic, Acer, Mitac International, and China Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SHIFT IN CBC'S MONETARY POLICY: ACTING GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) funneled NT$15.4 billion (US$466.67 million) into the domestic monetary market on Tuesday in an effort to maintain financial stability in the wake of the death of the bank's governor and four other senior officials in a tragic plane crash on Monday.

CBC Deputy Governor Liang Cheng-chin told a news conference that the central bank has made proper arrangements to cope with the unexpected situation and maintain normal operations of the domestic capital markets.

Liang said as Taiwan's economic fundamentals have been healthy, the domestic foreign exchange market, securities market and call-loan market are not expected to fluctuate too drastically simply because of the abrupt death of the central bank's elite members.

CBC Governor Sheu Yuan-dong, his wife and four other bank officials were killed in Monday's plane crash near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, some 30 kilometers southwest of Taipei, together with 190 other persons aboard the China Airline Airbus A-300 jetliner and seven others on ground. Sheu and his colleagues were flying home from the Indonesian island of Bali after attending a meeting of central bank governors from 10 Southeast Asian countries.

Liang, who has been appointed by Premier Vincent Siew to serve as the central bank's acting governor, said a CBC board meeting originally scheduled for Feb. 26 will be postponed due to the tragic incident.
At the moment, Liang said, the central bank will continue implementing the Sheu-crafted "measured" easy credity policy in order to meet the local business community's normal cash demand.

Liang recalled that Sheu had telepohoned him shortly before leaving Bali for home. "Sheu told me that he had exchanged views with his counterparts from 10 Southeast Asian countries on ways to resolve the region's financial woes, maintain regional financial stability and help Taiwan-owned companies in the region tide over their current difficulties," he said.
Liang said Sheu was particularly concerned about the difficulties faced by Taiwan companies in the beleaguered Southeast Asian economies.

"He asked me to notify the three local banks which all have several branches in Southeast Asian countries to draft respective packages of measures to help Taiwan-funded firms in the region," Liang said.

The three banks -- the First Commercial Bank, the International Commercial Bank of China and the Export-Import Bank of the Republic of China -- have all submitted comprehensive packages to the central bank. "We'll unveil them at an appropriate time," Liang said.

Sheu, 71, once said the central bank would deposit some of its huge foreign exchange reserves at overseas branches of Taiwan banks to help them offer loans or short-term export financing to Taiwan-owned companies abroad, particularly those in troubled Southeast Asian countries.

With the CBC's capital infusion, the short-term interest rates in the local monetary market reamined stable on Tuesday. Trading on the foreign exchange market also remained normal, with the New Taiwan dollar edging down marginally to close at NT$32.9 against US$1. The local stock market opened lower in a bearish mood, but rallied after mid-session and closed higher than Monday's finish.

The four other CBC officials died in the plane crash were Chen Huang, director-general of the Foreign Exchange Department; Chien Chi-min, director-general of the Economic Research Department; Lin Rong-tien, director-general of the Department of Secretariat; and Lin Li-wen, a specialist with the Foreign Exchange Department.
Premier Siew paid a visit to the central bank Tuesday morning to boost morale of the CBC staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD KEEP HELPING ASIA: DAILY

TEXT.P: "Americans have more than a humanitarian interest in mitigating Asia's pain," the International Herald Tribune said on Monday.

So far, the economic impact on the United States has been, if anything, beneficial, as Asia's crisis dampens inflationary pressure in America, the influential mass-circulation international daily pointed out.

In the coming months, however, the impact is likely to be less positive, as competitive pressures will threaten some American jobs, it said, adding that if the economic crisis worsens and provokes ethnic riots in Indonesia and social instability elsewhere, this could have a terrible impact on the United States.

The financial situation remains precarious, especially in Indonesia, the daily noted. But other economies in the region -- including those not yet infected or barely infected by the Asian "contagion" -- remain vulnerable to shifts in fickle and sometimes irrational international financial flows, it said.
Any one of these developing nations, or all of them, could be tripped up by a US congressional refusal to support the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the daily said.
It would help the Clinton administration's position and the IMF's if both were seen to be hard at work to prevent the next crisis, the International Herald Tribune opined.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM URGED TO RAISE MAINLAND CHINA'S CHEMICAL WEAPONS PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard has been urged to raise mainland China's chemical and biological weapons programs when he meets with mainland China's Defense Minister General Chi Haotian in Canberra later this week.

Chi is visiting Australian military bases in Cairns, Queensland, and is expected to meet Howard, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, and Defense Minister Ian McLachlan, among other senior officials. Chi is the highest-ranking military officer from mainland China to visit Australia.
The Australian Financial Review on Tuesday reported that the US Pentagon, in its latest report, claimed that mainland China has chemical and biological weapons.

The report says: "In the near future, China is likely to achieve the necessary expertise and delivery capability to integrate chemical weapons successfully into overall military operations. China's current inventory of chemical agents includes the full range of traditional agents and China is conducting research into more advanced agents. It has a wide variety of delivery systems for chemical agents, including tube artillery, rockets, mortars, landmines, aerial bombs, sprayers and short-range ballistic missiles."

The daily reported that the Pentagon appears to place little trust in the fact that mainland China ratified the Chemical Weapons Convention last April -- about the same time as the US. It is even less convinced by mainland China's ratification of the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention in 1984, according to the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: 9 CAL AIRBUS PLANES GROUNDED FOR SAFETY CHECK

TEXT.P: In the wake of Taiwan's worst air accident, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications on Tuesday ordered all Airbus planes belonging to China Airlines (CAL) to be grounded for safety checks.

"The ministry has ordered that all Taiwan-bound CAL A300-600 Airbus planes be grounded for thorough safety checks upon their return to Taiwan airports, and that they will not be allowed to take off again until they are confirmed to be meeting safety standards," a CAL spokesman said.

A CAL A-300 aircraft crashed into a building Monday evening, minutes before it was scheduled to land at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, killing 203, including 182 passengers, 14 crew members, two people residing near the airport and five others who were in passing cars.

CAL, the Republic of China's former national flag carrier, now has nine Airbus aircraft in its fleet and has plans to order three more from France as part of its expansion project, according to Liu Kuo-chien, CAL's deputy director of public affairs.
Liu said six CAL flights were suspended Monday and that each of the next four to five days will see the suspension of two flights.
He said he could not say for the moment whether CAL would drop its plan to purchase new Airbus aircraft.
Monday's accident was the second for CAL in less than four years. Another CAL Airbus A-300 airliner crashed at Japan's Nagoya airport on April 26, 1994, killing 264 of the 271 aboard.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE IN INDONESIA SAID SEEKING REFUGE IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Ethnic Chinese Indonesians, alarmed by rioting in several places, are trying to seek refuge in Australia in the wake of rising violence against Chinese targets as a result of growing food prices and unemployment in the world's biggest Islamic nation.

In a dispatch from Jakarta Tuesday, the mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald reported inquiries about resident visas to Australia by ethnic Chinese Indonesians have jumped at least 100 percent in recent weeks as Muslim food riots hit Chinese shops, temples, churches and houses.

The daily reported ethnic Chinese have become the scapegoats for Indonesia's economic crisis because they dominate trade and business although their number makes up only 3 percent of the total population of more than 200 million.

The daily quoted an unnamed immigration agent in Jakarta as revealing that the recent riots were the worst violence against Indonesia's ethnic Chinese since the bloodshed of 1965, when some 500,000 people were killed.
"All the ethnic Chinese are worried -- if you are on the street when a riot breaks out, you don't know what will happen to you," the agent said.
"It is already happening, but not yet in Jakarta," he added.
Many of those inquiring about Australian visas are middle-class professionals or small-business owners who have sufficient capital to be accepted as business migrants, the agent told the daily.
The wealthier Chinese, who could qualify more easily, could afford private security and are less at risk, the agent said.
"So immigration is not necessarily a solution, either. The ones at the greatest risk are the least likely to get a visa," he said.
The Australian Embassy in Jakarta reported 132 business migration approvals for December for Chinese Indonesians, compared with 30 to 40 in previous months.
Many Chinese Indonesians settle in Perth, which is less than four hours by air from Jakarta.

The daily quoted one Chinese businessman as saying, "We know that if there is a riot in Jakarta ... there will be blood spilled." The riots made him very angry, but he said he could understand the frustration of those Indonesians who were suffering from the economic crisis.

The daily also quoted Jakarta-based economist Michael Backman as saying: "The Chinese minority are under pressure at the best of times in Indonesia; now you have an intolerable amount of anger directed against them.

"If there was a complete meltdown in Indonesia and they started coming to Australia, they may have a reasonable claim for refugee status because they could demonstrate that the State of Indonesia has laws constraining Chinese culture and beliefs, and now you have the physical danger element with the rioting and the property damage," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS FORCES ETHNIC CHINESE FAMILY CONGLOMERATES TO CHANGE

TEXT.P: The Asian economic crisis, globalization and brand values are forcing many ethnic Chinese family conglomerates in Asia to change the way they do business in order to survive.

In an article published in the mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Tuesday, the daily's Asia business editor Geoff Hiscock noted that as the Asian economic crisis continues to unfold, the old "buy and hoard" mentality that dominates the thinking of Chinese family conglomerates in key business centers such as Bangkok, Jakarta, Manila, Taipei, Hong Kong and Singapore is giving way to a new focus: protect the core business.
He said the 60 million ethnic Chinese who live outside mainland China have been among the key drivers of rapid economic growth in Southeast Asia for the past three decades.

Their easy cross-border access to capital, their commercial intelligence networks, their willingness to work hard in trying conditions, their emphasis on family solidarity and the often iron discipline of a patriarch have brought them fortune and fame.

He said: "...The key Chinese business leaders today are the sons and daughters of the huaqiao, the `sojourners' who left southern China's Fujian and Guangdong provinces in the 19th and 20th centuries to establish commercial footholds in rice, rubber, tobacco, sugar, timber and palm oil plantations in the rich `south sea' lands of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Indochina."

He said the success in agribusiness and commodity trading encouraged these entrepreneurial families to expand into shipping ventures, banking, property development, manufacturing, distribution and later, media and telecommunications.

In the postwar era, the men who are now the most influential figures in the ethnic Chinese business networks of Southeast Asia -- billionaires like Robert Kuok, Liem Sioe Liong, Quek Leng Chan, Alfonso Yuchengco, Dhanin Chearavanont and Chatri Sophonpanich -- did deals together and forged networks built on shared origins of clan, guild, village or dialect.

For some members of the Chinese business elite, political and military patronage in Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines, enshrined their commercial primacy, even if the downside was a life often lived in fear of violent ethnic envy.

But a business model built on guanxi (connections), cronyism and opaque finances, while it worked in earlier decades, is not necessarily the best approach in the late 1990s, when globalization, brand values and the economic crisis that began to pound Southeast Asia last July have put the spotlight on lax lending, speculation, corruption and mutual backscratching, Hiscock said.

He said ethnic Chinese families who once grew their businesses in a price-driven acquisitive fashion, with no thought of Western buzzwords like synergy, are now looking to rationalize their portfolios. For some it is a matter of necessity; for others it is a chance to free up cash that can be used to snap up assets that better dovetail with their core businesses, Hiscock said.

The Asian crisis is offering these families the chance to buy shaky conglomerates in South Korea, and the asset-rich but confidence-poor Japanese -- along with Australian, European and US multinationals looking to cherry-pick some cheap assets from the rubble.
He said cashed-up Taiwanese families, led by prominent bankers such as Jeffrey Koo of Chinatrust Commercial Bank in Taipei, are also on the acquisition trail.

In a marketing sense, Japan and Korea have shown it can be done with Toyota, Sony, Samsung and Hyundai, while Taiwan has worked hard to get Acer into the world's consciousness. But outside of a few luxury boutique names and some food brands, the ethnic Chinese entrepreneurs have been singularly unsuccessful.

The other challenge for the Chinese networks is globalization. The founders' Western-educated children, armed with MBAs from Harvard, Wharton and other famous schools, will have to carry the fight because their parents have no idea how to do so, he said.
Hiscock said the new Asian focus on core business and the more competitive globalized world will severely test what until now has been a highly successful business model.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH COLUMBIA PREMIER MEETS MAINLAND CHINA DISSIDENT

TEXT.P: Exiled dissident Wei Jingsheng of mainland China visited British Columbia on Monday to talk about human rights in his communist-controlled country. But he admitted there isn't much one province can do.
"Western countries need to work out a scheme of economic blackmail to force China to respect human rights," the Canadian Press quoted Wei as saying during a meeting with B.C. Premier Glen Clark.
"The Chinese Communist Party employs trade as a means to influence foreign powers to do their bidding," he said through an interpreter.

The West's refusal to pressure the mainland about human rights abuses has encouraged the Beijing leadership, he said on the last stop of a Canadian visit. He visited Ottawa and Toronto before coming to Vancouver.

Clark didn't make any promises, saying economic sanctions aren't the only solution and trade and reform in mainland China "are not mutually exclusive." That's exactly the same tune pitched by Canada's federal leaders.
Wei wants Canada to speak out when the United Nations Human Rights Commission discusses mainland China's human rights record in April.
The Globe and Mail on Tuesday printed a question-and-answer session with Wei in Toronto. In the discussions, Wei was quoted as saying: "Communist governments never bow to logic, only pressure."
He urged Western countries not to be afraid of "retaliation" by mainland China if they sponsor a UN resolution to denounce mainland China's human rights record.

"Last year, when Denmark sponsored the resolution criticizing China, China threatened to cancel Danish contracts. But if you look at the record over the past year, Chinese trade with Denmark has increased. The Chinese economy is still underdeveloped, and they cannot afford to discontinue trade with Western nations," he told the newspaper.

What are the five things Wei would do if he were president of mainland China? He said: "First, eliminate corruption. Two, go after the money that has been stashed away overseas because of corruption. Three, reform the military to make it a defense force instead of a tool of repression. Four, allow freedom of expression so that people can openly discuss national issues. Fifth, improve our relationships with the democratic and freedom-loving countries of the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PHILIPPINE LAWMAKERS INK MEMORANDUM ON FIGHTING SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: A group of visiting lawmakers from the Republic of China signed a memorandum here on Tuesday with their Philippine counterparts on fighting crimes.

The memorandum, which focuses on the battle against trafficking in drugs and firearms between the Philippines and Taiwan, calls for lawmakers from both Manila and Taipei to work in concert to prod their governments to crack down on the rampant smuggling between the two sides.

The memorandum also calls for exchanges of information on suspected smugglers, on the enactment of measures concerning trafficking in arms and drugs, and on the capture and punishment of those involved in smuggling, as well as for cooperation in tracking down smugglers.

All 11 members of the ROC delegation, led by Wang Ling-lin, signed the memorandum with a group of five Philippine congressmen led by Senator Antonio Cuenco, with ROC representative to Manila H.C. Chan on hand.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LEADERS EXTEND CONDOLENCES OVER TAIWAN AIR ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: The leaders of several foreign nations have extended their regrets and condolences to Taiwan over Monday's air crash that killed 203 people, according to the Foreign Affairs Ministry of the Republic of China.

Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez, Saint Christopher and Nevis Governor-General Cuthbert Sebastian and Prime Minister Denzil Douglas, and Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto have extended their condolences to Taiwan through various channels, ministry spokesman Roy Y.Y. Wu said.

Meanwhile, Chairman W. Abdul Razak Ramil of the senior officials' conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, currently being held in Penang, Malaysia, also expressed his regrets at the opening of Tuesday's session.

Senior officials from Canada, Singapore, Thailand and the Philippines also extended their condolences to the ROC delegate attending the meeting, Director Hsia Li-yen of the Foreign Ministry's International Organization Affairs.
Speaking on behalf of the ROC government, Hsia later thanked the APEC partners for their expressions of concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSURANCE PAYOUTS FOR AIR CRASH TO SET RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Insurance indemnity for the destruction caused by the crash of China Airlines flight 676 in Taoyuan on Monday night, estimated at about NT$1.44 billion (US$43.63 million) looks set to be a record high in Taiwan, according to the Insurance Department under the Ministry of Financial Affairs.

The insurance coverage for the ill-fated airplane itself, an Airbus 300, is US$71.5 million, underwritten jointly by three local property insurance firms, in addition to uncapped liability insurance covering injury to people, damage to cargo, and property both aboard and on the ground, according to documents released on Tuesday by the Insurance Department.

Under the Warsaw Convention which provides guidelines for compensation for aviation passengers, the maximum indemnity is NT$1.5 million (US$45,454) per victim. However, there is no ceiling on damages claimed for lives, houses and automobiles lost on the ground, said officials at the department.

Of the 196 victims on board, 127 were traveling on a package tour which was protected by group travel insurance provided by travel agencies with a maximum compensation of NT$2 million (US$60,606) per capita.

Four victims from one family paid their flight fares via Diner credit card and automatically enjoy flight insurance of NT$16 million per capita provided by the credit company's insurer. Another 12 paid their fares with other credit cards offering coverage varying from NT$4.5 million to NT$12 million (US$136,363 to US$363,636).
The 196 victims had taken out a total of 266 life insurance policies with combined coverage of NT$983.3 million (US$29.79 million) , according to the Insurance Department.
The largest number of policies provided by a single company -- 59, by Cathay Life Insurance -- had a total coverage of NT$185.7 million (US$5.62 million).

Six Central Bank of China (CBC) officials killed in the crash, including Governor Sheu Yuan-dong, were covered automatically by group insurance providing a maximum of NT$3 million (US$90,909) for any government employee killed on a business trip and an extra NT$3 million (US$90,909) for those killed in an air crash.
The underwriters, the government-run Central Trust of China, has already delivered the payments, totaling NT$36 million (US$1,090,909), to the CBC.

As for the five victims traveling in an automobile which was hit by the crashed plane, the four passengers are each covered by NT$1.2 million (US$36,363) compensation under the newly-enacted compulsory automobile insurance program, while the next-of-kin of the driver are entitled to claim unspecified damages from the driver's insurance company.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA TO RESTORE REGIONAL CURRENCY STABILITY

TEXT.P: Singapore and Malaysia will cooperate with one another and with their Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) partners to restore stability to regional currencies.
This is one of the major points of a joint communique issued in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday after a meeting between Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong.

The two prime ministers met in Kuala Lumpur on Monday and had "productive discussions on a wide range of bilateral, regional and international issues," said the joint communique. Goh was in Kuala Lumpur on a two-day working visit.
Mahathir and Goh agreed that they will "work towards realizing the full potential" in relations between the two countries, based on the principle of "prosper thy neighbor," the communique said.
"The two prime ministers also recognized that the regional financial crisis has further underscored the need for both countries to cooperate closely in all possible areas," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER RECEIVES GUESTS FROM SOUTH KOREA AND PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew told visiting South Korean lawmakers Soon Se-il and Sul Hoon on Tuesday that he is guardedly optimistic about the prospects for reopening air links between Taipei and Seoul if the two sides can engage in serious negotiations.

In a meeting at his office with the two congressmen who arrived in Taipei on Monday for a three-day visit, Siew expressed regret that the bilateral economic ties established during his term as economics minister were disrupted abruptly because of Seoul switching diplomatic recognition to Beijing in 1992.
He said he believes economic cooperation is still the first step towards rapprochement between the two countries, cooperation which includes the resumption of air services.
Also on Tuesday, the premier received a group of visiting congressmen from Paraguay, in South America.
The six-member group, led by Paraguayan Senator Carlos Albert Gonzalez, Chairman of the Commission of Foreign Relations, arrived in Taipei on Saturday for an eight-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-WASHINGTON WTO TALKS BOTTLENECKED OVER RICE TRADE

TEXT.P: The 17th round of Taipei-Washington talks on Taiwan's bid for World Trade Organization (WTO) membership, which opened in Washington last Monday, have stalled on thorny issues relating to rice import quotas, with negotiators from both sides reluctant to yield to demands from the other, according to the Council of Agriculture, (AOA)

Rice, a staple food of most of the people of Taiwan, has long been provided by some 300,000 local farmers who continue the ancestral industry which is commonly seen as having been the basis of Taiwan's economic development.

In order to preserve the industry and farmers' livelihoods, the domestic rice market is closed to free trade, but Taiwan can no longer neglect outsiders' demands for an opening of this market if the nation wants to join in the largest trade and economic organization in the world and enjoy the profitable opportunities this will bring, COA officials said.
During a series of WTO negotiations with the US, an influential WTO member and one of the world's largest agricultural producers, Taiwan has often found itself on the horns of a dilemma.
American negotiators' are demanding a free rice trade without official interference, but Taiwan's agriculture officials can only promise "limited imports" based on the Japan model.
Like Taiwan, Japan is also a nation of rice consumers which had to fight for its rice interests during its own WTO entry talks. It eventually won a "yielded program."

According to the COA's open schedule for opening the rice market, in order to reduce the impact of imported rice, 90 percent of imported rice should be controlled by the government, while the other 10 percent is opened to private importers.

COA has also proposed that, based on the Japanese model, Taiwan will open 4 percent of its annual domestic consumption to foreign import in the first year after WTO accession, the figure increasing 0.8 percent per year until it reaches 8 percent.

However, Washington rejects this arrangement, declaring that the 4 percent opening level for Japan was enacted in 1995, when it started to open its rice market, and that based on the 0.8 percentage increase, it's 1998 import quota will be 6.4 percent. According to Washington officials, Taiwan's first-year rice import quota should be the same as Japan's current quota -- 6.4 percent, assuming Taiwan is granted entry this year.

Agricultural officials on the island told the CNA on Tuesday that no consensus on the current talks will be reached if the two sides fail to submit a compromise program for the rice issue over the next few days.
The US is one of the four remaining WTO contracting parties which have not concluded discussions with Taipei on membership requirements. The others are Canada, Switzerland and the European Union.
Taiwan, under the name "The Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu," in 1990 applied to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which was succeeded by the WTO in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBIA PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Banjul, the Gambia, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Yen Ling-ju and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Gambian President Yahya A. J. J. Jammeh on Wednesday reaffirmed his firm commitment to the Republic of China, saying he will continue to speak for the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations during his tenure.
Jammeh made the remarks while meeting with ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu, who arrived in the Gambia for a brief visit on Tuesday.

Jammeh said ROC President Lee Teng-hui is welcome to visit the Gambia at any time of his convenience. President Lee is scheduled to embark on an African diplomatic tour later this year. His itinerary is expected to include Senegal, Guinea-Bissau, the Gambia and Burkina Fasso.

Senior Gambian officials confirmed that the two countries have drafted plans for Lee's Gambia visit. "We'll make public Lee's itinerary in the Gambia after it is formally finalized," Gambian Vice President Zsatou Njie-Saidy said.
Hu attended a cocktail reception in celebration the Gambia's National Day shortly after his arrival in the West African state for a whirlwind visit.

This is the third leg of Hu's current six-country African diplomatic swing aimed at shoring up the ROC's relations with his allies in the region in the wake of the switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing by South Africa and the Central African Republic earlier this year.

Hu already visited Chad and Guinea-Bissau. He will also travel to Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe as well as Burkina Faso before his return to Taipei next Monday. His two previous African trips in recent months took him to Senegal, Swazilandand Malawi.

Hu said he plans to visit all of the ROC's African allies in the possible shortest period of time and will then come up with a comprehensive report on feasible measures to further expand exchanges and cooperation with those countries.
