DOC.HEADLINE: CPG TO MAKE INROADS INTO JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-min & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Core Pacific Group (CPG), one of Taiwan's largest brokerage and fund investment companies, has revealed its plan to enter the Japanese market.
CPG Chairman Sheen Ching-jing said in a press conference here on Tuesday that he expects to cooperate with Japanese enterprises, creating joint opportunities for potential profits.

The Core Pacific Group has so far built 69 affiliates since Sheen set up his first business company in October 1974. In 1996, the group, with around 9,500 employees, processed total assets of some NT$150 billion (US$4.57 billion), making it the 17th largest conglomerate in Taiwan.

At the middle of last December, CPG bought Yamaichi International (Hong Kong) Ltd., the Hong Kong operation of Japan's collapsed Yamaichi Securities Company. With the addition of Yamaichi Hong Kong (now renamed Core Pacific-Yamaichi Hong Kong), Sheen said that his firm is fully ready to make inroads into Japan.
CPG's business interests extend to stock brokerages and real estate.

Sheen told the local press that his group hopes to forge cooperation with competitive Japanese enterprises. The elite stock speculator also noted that he expects trade opportunities will follow the financial liberalization that Japan will institute on April 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL PONDERING INVESTING IN MALAYSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC) is reconsidering making an investment in Malaysia to materialize its plans on expanding operations overseas.

CSC, which has successfully transformed itself from a state-run enterprise over the past two years, is reexamining a plan from several years ago to move part of its Taiwan operations to Malaysia, prompted by that country's offer of new investment incentives.

The industrial giant's overseas investment plans have not gone smoothly in the past. First, its go-Malaysia plan was halted because of opposition by some legislators. Later, its plan to establish a steel refinery in Paraguay was aborted for undisclosed reasons. Most recently, while CSC officials were discussing plans to invest in Vietnam, ranking Malaysian officials visited Taipei bearing investment incentives, reigniting the steel company's interest in setting up some of its operations in Malaysia.
CSC, with annual transactions exceeding NT$100 billion (US$3 billion), has a production capacity of 8 million metric tons of crude steel a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Prompted by optimistic sentiment on the potential profitability of the high-tech sector, share prices climbed 0.6 percent on the Taiwan stock market on Wednesday.
The weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX), the market's key indicator, rose 55.25 points to close at 8,837.34.
Trading opened at 8,868.68.
Advancing issues outnumbered those falling 283 to 128, with 71 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 3.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$213.38 billion (US$6.51 billion) in the three-hour session.

Foodstuff shares jumped 2.1 percent, followed by a 1.2 percent growth in electronic engineering stocks, 1.0 percent in plastic and chemical shares, 0.7 percent in both paper-making and construction stocks, 0.6 percent in textile issues and 0.2 percent in cement stocks.
Financial shares dropped 0.6 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were ACER, Winbond Electronics, United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, ADI, China Development, Yageo, Chuntex Electronic, Kinpo Electronics and Liton Electronic.

DOC.HEADLINE: GULF TENSION MAY DRIVE UP OIL PRICES

TEXT.P: Tensions appear to be building in the Persian Gulf with the United States expressing its intention to attack Iraq if it continues to block weapons inspections, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Wednesday.

The MOEA's Research and Development Commission said an outbreak of military confrontation in the Gulf region is not expected to affect Taiwan's crude oil supply because the country has successfully diversified its import sources.

Nevertheless, the commission said, military actions in the Gulf region could trigger a rally of the US dollar in the international monetary markets. "A rise in the greenback's value would add our crude import costs," said a commission official.

The official said if the US-Iraq tensions over weapons inspections can be eased soon, international crude oil price will maintain at the current levels, ranging between US$16 and US$17 per barrel. But if the situation continues to worsen, oil price may rise to US$18 per barrel.
As Taiwan's oil supplies are based on long-term contracts, the official said, moderate price fluctuation in the international crude market will not result in a drastic rise in domestic oil prices.
Despite escalating tensions in the Gulf region, international crude oil prices have so far remained stable because of a continued glut in the market, the official said.
Thanks to successful diversification of import sources, Taiwan has lowered its dependence on the Middle East for the supply of crude oil in recent years.

Taiwan used to import up to 84 percent of its annual oil demand from Middle East countries, but the rate has dropped to 59 percent by now. Among Middle East countries, Saudi Arabia accounts for 28 percent of Taiwan's total annual crude oil imports; Kuwait, 10 percent; Iran, 7 percent; the United Arab Emirates, 7 percent; and Oman, 3 percent. Taiwan doesn't import crude oil from Iraq.
Meanwhile, Chinese Petroelum Corp. (CPC), a state monopoly, has consistently maintained a crude oil stockpile enough for 60 to 90 days of domestic consumption.
Even if the Persian Gulf comes under a blockade because of military confrontation, the official said, Taiwan can take delivery of contracted crude oil from Red Sea ports.
Against this background, the official said, domestic oil supply will not be affected by a Gulf war.
However, he said, the eruption of a war in the region may spark appreciation of the US dollar, which will lead to increases in CPC's oil import costs.
According to CPC estimates, the company's oil import costs will increase NT$500 million to NT$600 million per month if the local currency depreciates NT$1 against the greenback.
The official said the Economics Ministry will keep a close watch on the developments in the Gulf region and will adopt timely measures to cope with any emergency situation.
The ministry has also allowed the CPC to implement a floating pricing system to let market mechanism determine domestic oil prices, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES LAUNCHES OFFER FOR CSC

TEXT.P: Chinese computer software tycoon Charles Wang's Computer Associates International has commenced a cash tender offer of US$108 per share for all the outstanding common stock of Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC), according to a news release from the company Tuesday.

The news release said CSC has approximately 85 million shares outstanding on a fully diluted basis, and approximately US$700 million of indebtedness, giving the transaction a total value of approximately US$9.8 billion. Credit Suisse First Boston arranged financing for the acquisition through Bank of America, the Chase Manhattan Bank and Nations Bank.
In addition, Computer Associates announced Tuesday that it has commenced legal action designed to compel CSC's Board of Directors to take steps to permit CSC's shareholders to consider the offer.

Computer Associates, with headquarters in Islandia, N.Y., is the world leader in mission-critical business software. The company develops, licenses and supports more than 500 integrated products, including enterprise computing, information management, application development, manufacturing and financial applications. The firm has over 11,000 people in 160 offices in 43 countries and had revenue of US$4.5 billion in calendar year 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA RULES OUT INTEREST RATE CUTS IN FACE OF ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has ruled out bank interest rate cuts due to its concerns about the impact of the Asian financial crisis on the local currency and economic growth rate.
In its quarterly economic report, the RBA warned that the Asian crisis will slow the Australian economic growth rate despite the fact that Australia has so far avoided the worst of the Asian crisis.
The RBA said its immediate tactical priority is to insulate Australia from the financial turmoil that has engulfed other economies in the Asian region.
"Monetary policy will be directed toward the continuance of the low-inflation expansion that the economy has experienced since the early 1990s," the RBA said.

"In the period ahead, the pursuit of these medium-term objectives will require policy to place a good deal of importance on fostering financial market stability. Australia has done well to avoid the worst of the financial turmoil that has characterized our region over the past 12 months -- continuing to do so must be a high priority," it said.

The RBA statement, released Tuesday, has killed growing financial expectations of another interest rate cut, fueled by recent figures showing signs of weakness in the economy, continued low inflation and slow wage growth.
The RBA reduced interest rates five times between July 1996 and July 1997, reducing the official rate to 5 percent from 7.5 percent.
The RBA statement helped the Australian dollar to become stable, closing slightly higher at 66.75 US cents from Monday's closing level of 66.55 US cents.
The All Ordinaries Index also closed 35.8 points higher to finish at 2657 on Tuesday.

Ted Evans, secretary of the Federal Treasury, also warned that the Australian economy would slow this year because of the Asian economic crisis, which is slowing demand for imports from Australia and elsewhere.
"The Asian crisis will slow the growth that otherwise would have been obtainable in Australia and, as forecast, put pressure on our current account," he said.
Treasurer Peter Costello said Australia's strong domestic economy would counteract the downturn on the external front caused by the Asian crisis.
But economists said he was too optimistic, saying the Asian crisis would cut Australia's gross domestic product growth by about one percentage point this year.
Australia's GDP was earlier set to grow more than 4 percent before the Asian crisis. But the growth rate now has to be set at around 3 percent, the economists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK MARKET DISRUPTING BEIJING'S PROMISE NOT TO DEVALUE YUAN

TEXT.P: The black market in foreign currency is alive and well in mainland China and is disrupting Beijing's promise not to devalue its yuan so as not to deepen the Asian currency crisis.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business daily, reported on Wednesday that black marketeers' calls of "Change money, US dollars?" are rampant again in mainland China and that the exchange rate between the yuan and the US dollar has approached nine yuan to one US dollar, compared to the official selling price of 8.29 yuan to one greenback.
The black market is trading billions of US dollars a day, according to the daily, which quoted the Business Weekly edition of the China Daily.

The Review reported most analysts think that for now Beijing will stand behind the yuan's steady rate of the last three years -- around 8.2 to US$1.00 -- for a host of economic and political reasons that are most unlikely to be derailed, at least in 1998.
The Review even quoted mainland Chinese Vice Premier Zhu Rongji as saying, "I can solemnly swear the Chinese currency will not be devalued." Zhu will replace Li Peng as premier next month.

The Review reported, however, that the black market is proving hard to kill off. It has been revived by recent rumors of depreciation as other Asian currencies have collapsed, recalling the profits made by the massive devaluation of 1994 when dual foreign exchange systems in the mainland were merged and succored by the limited official convertibility of the yuan and mainland China's much increased contacts with the wider world.
The daily reported some mainland Chinese people use the black market to launder illegally earned money and some use it to speculate for profit taking.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAST ASIAN 'MIRACLE' WAS REAL: WORLD BANK OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The East Asian "miracle" was real, and its economic transformation of East Asia has been one of the most remarkable accomplishments in history, said Joseph Stiglitz, vice president and chief economist of the World Bank.

In an article he contributed to the Wall Street Journal, Stiglitz pointed out that the dramatic surge in gross domestic product that East Asian countries brought about is reflected in higher standards of living for hundreds of million of Asians, including longer life expectancy and better health and education, and that millions of others have rescued themselves from poverty and now lead more hopeful lives.
"These achievements are real and will be far more permanent than the present turmoil," he said.

The East Asian miracle's impact on poverty is probably one of its most striking features. In 1975, six out of 10 Asians lived on less than US$1 a day. In Indonesia, the absolute poverty rate was even higher. Today, two out of 10 East Asians are living in absolute poverty. South Korea, Malaysia and Thailand have eliminated absolute poverty, and Indonesia is within striking distance of that goal. The United States and other Western countries, which have also seen solid growth over the past 20 years but little reduction in their poverty rates, could well learn from the East Asian experience, Stiglitz said.

Once held up as models for other developing countries, today legions of critics are condemning the East Asian countries for their unworkable economic systems that they say were always bound to collapse into crisis. This dramatic swing in public opinion, matching the dramatic changes in the markets, has gone further than is justified by the fundamentals, he said, pointing out that no other economic system has delivered so much, to so many, in so short a span of time.

Stiglitz reminded his readers that financial and currency crises have occurred elsewhere in the world, most recently in Scandinavian countries such as Norway, Sweden and Finland. The fact that these countries had highly transparent economic systems and advanced institutional frameworks demonstrates that transparency is not enough to underpin robust financial systems, he said.
Although the lack of transparency in the East Asian economies contributed to the problems, it is probably not responsible for the crisis itself, he said.

At the same time, the crisis in the East Asian countries is very different from crisis experienced by many developing countries in the past, Stiglitz noted. The East Asian countries have all run budget surpluses or minimal budget deficits in recent years.

Stiglitz asserted that the financial crisis in East Asia can be understood as the result of a number of factors that have made these economies especially vulnerable to a sudden withdrawal of confidence. The problems -- including misallocation of investment, maturity/currency mismatch of assets and liabilities, and, in the case of South Korea, very high debt-equity ratios -- are rooted in private-sector financial decisions, he said.
Stiglitz stressed that "restoring growth in East Asia requires restoring confidence."
"This is as much a matter of perception as of reality, including the perception of the fundamental strengths of the East Asian economies and their resolve to address their weaknesses," he said.

"At the same time," he continued, "governments and international institutions, including the World Bank, have the responsibility for ensuring that the poor and vulnerable suffer as little as possible in the process of adjustment."

DOC.HEADLINE: HAZE COULD RETURN TO S'PORE BY MARCH IF FIRES CONTINUE

TEXT.P: The haze could return to Singapore as early as next month or April if forest fires continue to burn in Indonesia.
The Singapore Meteorological Service said that as wind direction becomes unpredictable in those two inter-monsoon months, Singapore could experience haze on several days.
How thick it gets will depend on the extent of the fires in Indonesia.

With a week to go to till ASEAN environment ministers meet in Kuching, East Malaysia, to discuss a regional plan to prevent a repeat of last year's haze, the Indonesian authorities are reporting widespread fires in Kalimantan.
Antara, the Indonesian national news agency, reported there were 895 fires in East Kalimantan as of Sunday night, compared with 618 a day earlier.

On the prospect of the smoke haze reaching Singapore, a Meteorological Service official was quoted as saying, "Assuming the fires go on burning, we could get slight haze in March or April over Singapore."
He explained that the current northeast monsoon is expected to weaken over the next week or two.
Before the southwest monsoon starts in May, there is what is called the inter-monsoon period, when wind direction is quite unpredictable.
He said that even in normal non-El Nino years, Singapore did experience slight haze too, but that it varied year to year.
Looking further ahead, he said there was a high chance of normal weather conditions returning by June, when the El Nino phenomenon tails off.
El Nino results from a warming of the Pacific Ocean off South America. It brings heavy rainfall and flooding to some parts of the world and extreme drought to others.
The southwest monsoon usually blows from June to October and coincides with Indonesia's dry season. But last year was exceptionally dry, worsening the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIONAL BALANCE OF POWER SEEN MOVING TOWARD M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Asian crisis will not only hit defense budgets in Asian countries but also shift the regional balance of power toward mainland China, according to Australian experts.

They said they believe there will be massive cuts in the Asian military budgets and the likelihood of increased instability in the region. Nearly all Southeast Asian nations, except Singapore, are suddenly facing defense budget cuts of up to 20 percent, straining cooperative defense relations and placing constraints on what other countries are able to do militarily.
Australian defense officials said, "The cuts in defense budgets in countries in our region mean we'll have to work harder to retain bilateral relations."
They said that mainland China, which has been little affected by the Asian economic crisis so far, would become stronger militarily as other Asian countries become weaker due to defense budget cuts.

Professor Paul Dibb of the Australian National University in Canberra said: "The relative weakening of the Malaysian and Thai economies is not a good thing given that China is rising and showing leadership. Therefore the regional balance of power could move toward China."

Other experts noted the Asian crisis has forced an urgent reassessment of Australia's latest strategic defense review because the instability of the Asian region is expected to increase due to such massive cuts in defense budgets.
Australia's senior defense officials believe the region will return to robust levels of economic growth only in the medium to long term.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO SEND HOME BALINESE VICTIM'S BODY

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) has said it will do all it can to recover and repatriate the body of Nyoman Sukada, 26, a Balinese passenger on the CAL Airbus 300 that crashed near Taipei's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport (CKS) Monday, the Antara news agency reported from Denpasar.

Antara quoted I Gede, a local CAL officer, as saying Tuesday that the CAL branch office in Denpasar was in constant contact with its head office in Taipei about when Sukada's remains will be returned to Indonesia.
The airline had also contacted Sukada's family in Tengkudak village, 25 km south of Denpasar, he said.

According to I Gede, the Airbus 300 crash would not affect the frequency of CAL's flights from Bali's Ngurah Rai International Airport to CKS, Taiwan's main international terminal, a short drive south of Taipei.
CAL maintains five flights a week from Bali to Taipei.
On Tuesday, a CAL plane departed Ngurah Rai airport for Taipei with 260 passengers on board, while there were 200 passengers on the boarding list for Wednesday, I Gede said.
CAL's flight 676 crashed Monday evening just outside CKS, killing all 196 people on board and several others on the ground.
Part of the ill-fated airliner slammed into a residential area near the airport, setting a number of houses ablaze and killing several people.

DOC.HEADLINE: HABIBIE MOVES CLOSER TO BECOMING INDONESIA'S VP

TEXT.P: B.J. Habibie only needs the Indonesian armed forces' nod to make his vice presidential nomination a forgone conclusion in the wake of Indonesia's 27 governors lining up behind him Tuesday.
The regional leaders' endorsement means that Habibie, the state minister of research and technology, has secured the backing of four of the five factions in the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR).
The governors form the regional representatives faction in the Assembly, Indonesia's highest law-making body, which elects the president and vice president.
The Moslem-oriented United Development Party, the dominant Golkar and the minority Indonesian Democratic Party have all fielded the technology tsar as their sole candidate.
"Our decision on Habibie's nomination is final," Minister of Home Affairs Moch. Yogie S.M. was quoted by the Antara news agency as saying after chairing the governors' meeting.

Yogie, who supervises the MPR's regional representatives faction and Golkar's bureaucrats, said Habibie's vice presidential nomination was decided by the three elements that form the backbone of Golkar: the armed forces, the bureaucracy and mass organizations affiliated to the political grouping.
"Originally, the bureaucrats had two names for the vice presidency -- Harmoko and Habibie," he said, "but then Harmoko withdrew his (decision to accept the) nomination."
Yogie said that the result of the meeting had also been reported to the chairman of Golkar's board of patrons, President Suharto.
"The president asked the regional representatives faction to formally nominate Habibie in the MPR," he said.
Habibie said all the MPR factions' support for him was "really an honor."
"It'll be an honor for me to assist the elected president," he told reporters after accompanying Suharto at a state function at the State Palace Tuesday.
Speaking about senior economist Emil Salim's bid for the vice presidency, Yogie said the former minister was free to go on with his campaign.
"But our candidate is only one, Habibie," he said.

On Monday, noted figures Herawan Diah, Nelly Adam Malki and Saparinah Sadli -- on behalf of 128 scholars and public figures seeking Emil's nomination -- presented their petition to the MPR regional representatives faction.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ADJUSTS GROWTH DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: Affected by the Asian financial turmoil that has challenged global economies over the past few months, Taiwan's economy will grow slower this year than previously expected, down from the originally-estimated 6.5 percent to 6.2 percent, the government's statistics agency reported Monday.

According to Wei Duan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), Taiwan's economy will continue to expand steadily this year and will feature "moderate growth, with a low unemployment rate and inflation well-controlled."
1998 will also reveal whether Taiwan's economy is crisis-proof, Wei said, citing the Chinese proverb that declares that a horse's strength is known only when the way is long.

With the downgrading of Taiwan's economic growth rate come readjustments in other figures, Wei noted. Inflation is now expected to grow at 3.10 percent this year, down slightly from previous estimates of 3.12 percent, while the wholesale price index is expected to rise by 5.7 percent, up from the originally-forecast 5.3 percent, he said.

DGBAS researchers also cut back substantially the estimated gross national product (GNP) for this year, down to US$273.4 billion from last year's US$285.3 billion, and targeted the per capita GNP at US$12,586 in 1998, as compared with the US$13,245 forecast previously and the US$13,233 Taiwan posted in 1997.

Wei attributed the downward readjustment to slowing exports on the part of Taiwan and the regionwide recession. Asia suffered economic stagnation in the first half of last year and a financial crisis in the second half.

The Asian economic turbulence, which has challenged world economies, has prompted leading economic forecast institutes to make major downward readjustments of global growth. For example, Wei said, the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association forecast recently that Japan's economy will grow a mere 0.8 percent this year, while that of the United States will score a growth of 2.5 percent and South Korea's will drop 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE MADE OVER 140,000 VISITS TO CANADA LAST YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan people made 143,000 visits to Canada in 1997, up 5.8 percent from 1996, according to Canadian tourism officials.

In contrast, other major sources have recorded marked decreases, most notably Hong Kong and Japan, where the drops were 27 and 13 percent respectively in 1997 from the previous year's levels, they said.

Taiwan was Canada's eighth largest source of foreign tourists (excluding the United States), following Britain, Japan, France, Germany, Australia, South Korea and Hong Kong. The Netherlands and Italy rounded out the top 10.
The tourism officials said that 17.6 million tourists visited Canada last year, up 1.6 percent from the previous year, with US citizens comprising 13.3 million of the total.

The fluctuation of world currencies and the economic crisis in Asia have affected the tourism market, they said, noting that Canada's tourist arrivals from Japan, Germany, France and other European countries have decreased comparatively and that all of those countries' currencies have depreciated against the US dollar.
Asian countries' attempts to persuade their nationals not to take overseas trips to save foreign currency have also contributed to the reduction in tourists to Canada, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH EXPERTS INSPECT PLANE CRASH

TEXT.P: Experts on Wednesday went to the crash site of China Airlines flight 676, Taiwan's worst aviation disaster which killed all 196 on board as well as six others on the ground.

Officials from Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), representatives from the French Airbus Industrie, maker of the doomed Airbus A-300, as well as experts from France's Bureau Enquetes Accidents which helps investigate aviation accidents, arrived on Wednesday afternoon at the crash site in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.
After two consecutive days of rain, the wreckage scattered around the scene of the accident seemed in even more tragic disarray.
They scrutinized the crash site, took notes, videotaped and photographed of the debris. They sifted through the wreckage to gather every possible clue to help find out the cause of the crash.
The wreckage of the plane was scattered over a wide area after the plane aborted a landing in fog and then veered off course to crash into a residential area.
The experts heard a briefing by CAA officials in the morning at the CAA building, where they first observed a minute's silence in memory of the victims.

CAA officials provided the weather forecast, the recording of the conversation between the pilots and the control tower at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport before the crash, a map of the wreckage of the plane, and a history of the plane's regular repair and maintenance records.
The officials also reported that autopsies already carried out on the bodies of Kang Lung-lin and Chiang Teh-shen, the pilot and co-pilot, found no trace of alcohol or drugs in their systems.

The French experts said they will give a three-week intensive safety course to CAL's Airbus pilots in the near future, while the CAA on Tuesday ordered all CAL's Airbus planes to be grounded for safety checks.
They also expressed the hope that the aircraft's "black box," the cockpit voice recorder and digital flight data recorders, will be sent overseas for analysis as soon as possible.
They refused to comment further on the accident, saying only that the present information could not confirm the cause of the crash.

Meanwhile, CAL officials said two ringing sounds heard during the conversation between the pilots and the control tower just before the plane went down at 8:07 p.m. could indicate that the pilots were trying to switch from auto pilot to manual control, which they said is normal procedure.
Whether the timing for switching off the auto pilot was appropriate will not be clear until the black box information has been analyzed, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSTS TRADE DEFICIT IN FIRST WEEKS OF NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two-way trade amounted to US$24.75 billion in the first six weeks of this year, down 4 percent, or US$1.04 billion, from the year-earlier level, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Wednesday.

Between Jan. 1 and Feb. 14, Taiwan posted accumulated exports of US$12.086 billion and imports of US$12.661 billion, leaving the country with a deficit of US$575 million during the period, officials from the MOF's Department of Statistics said.
MOF officials attributed the deficit increase to considerable imports of aircraft by both the private and military sectors, as well as increased imports of crude oil by the Chinese Petroleum Corp.

However, the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar in the latter part of 1997 means that two-way trade recorded in the Jan. 1-Feb. 14 period was much larger than that posted in the same period of 1997 if calculated in local currency, the officials pointed out.
During the 45-day period, the island's two-way trade amounted to NT$821.39 billion, up 16 percent, or NT$113.33 billion, over the figure posted in the same period of the previous year, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dropped NT$0.039 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.887.
The greenback opened 32.916 and was traded between 32.875 and 32.97.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$339.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 9TH NATIONAL PEOPLE'S CONGRESS TO SEE QUIAO SHI'S INFLUENCE DIMINISHED

TEXT.P: Qiao Shi, Standing Committee chairman of mainland China's 8th National People's Congress, has long been considered to be mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's sole potential rival, but his influence in the political and legal fields will soon be swept away.

According to the Hong Kong-based Ming-Pao Daily News, Luo Gan, Secretary-General of mainland China's State Council and a crony of Premier Li Peng, is set to replace Qiao's crony Ren Jianxin as secretary of the Central Commission of Political Science and Law of the Communist Party of China (CPC) in the 9th National People's Congress which will be held in March. Meanwhile, Jiang, who is also CPC General Secretary, is demanding a counter-corruption movement to be conducted against judicial organizations.

In view of the above developments, political analysts have observed, Qiao's influence in the fields of political science and law, which was established during his membership in the CPC's Central Commission of Political Science and Law, will diminish.

After former deputy secretary Luo Gan assumes his post as secretary of the Central Commission of Political Science and Law, Qiao's faction, such as Ren, who concurrently serves as president of the Supreme People's Court, and Procurator-General of the Supreme People's Procuratorate Zhang Siqing, will all retreat to the second line of the hierarchy.

Furthermore, in a break with tradition, they will not be allocated posts as members of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress; instead, they will be made standing members of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

According to informed sources, Luo's new appointment bears evidence that after Li Peng takes the chair of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, he will use the congress to expand his own influence on mainland Chinese political affairs and consolidate his power in the fields of politics and law, just as Qiao did before.

Other sources have remarked that the Beijing authorities have accelerated their appeal on the counter-corruption movement against judicial organizations since the end of last year, pointing out that this is also aimed at cutting Qiao's influence on the mainland's political and legal systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL ADJUSTS FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: China Airlines on Wednesday announced that it was canceling seven domestic flights between southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung and the capital, Taipei, as well as 10 international flights, after Taiwan's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) demanded that all of the company's Airbus A-300/600R planes must be grounded for safety checks.

The demand came after a CAL A-300 aircraft crashed on Monday evening while approaching Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, claiming 203 lives including that of Central Bank of China Governor Sheu Yuan-dong. The crash marked the nation's worst-ever air disaster.

In light of the fact that the plane is the same type as the CAL plane which crashed at Japan's Nagoya airport on April 26, 1994, killing 264 of the 271 aboard, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has ordered a ban on all flights by Airbus planes until complete checks can be carried out to confirm their complete safety.

At present, there are nine Airbus planes in Taiwan, all of which belong to CAL, the former national flag carrier. CAL officials said that in accordance with the ban, they will suspend another seven flights between Taiwan and Southeast Asia scheduled for Thursday.

They said the company's Boeing 737, Boeing 747 and MD-11 aircraft are shouldering the flight services originally provided by the A-300 planes, while the B-737s, which ply mainly domestic routes, will now cover regional flights.
The flights to be suspended on Thursday are CI604, CI605, CI609, CI610, CI615, CI616, CI623, CI624, CI655, CI656, CI665, CI666, CI673 and CI674, according to CAL.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER MEETS DEPUTY US TRADE REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang met with Deputy US Trade Representative Richard Fisher on Tuesday for discussions on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Wang said after his 30-minute talks with Fisher that both sides have a strong desire to end bilateral WTO consultations as soon as possible. "However, we remain far divided on several critical issues," he noted, adding that as both sides face heavy pressure at home, further negotiations are needed to work out mutually acceptable terms.

Negotiations have proceeded slowly because American negotiators have to consult frequently with relevant US agricultural or industrial associations on various Taiwan-proposed market opening or tariff reduction measures, Wang said.
The 17th round of Taiwan-US WTO talks began more than a week ago, but the two sides have still failed to reach consensus on some thorny issues, particularly those related to trade in pork and rice.
Wang said the US negotiators want Taiwan to make larger cuts on tariff rates for certain sensitive agricultural products and to increase annual import quotas.

As the US demands go far beyond Taiwan's bottom line, Wang said, the current round of talks may have to be extended for one or two days. "If no compromise can be worked out, we do not rule out the possibility of ending the meeting and leaving those issues open for future consultations," the minister said.

This is the first time the Taiwan delegation has explicitly said it is prepared for the worst. Taiwan sent a large-scale delegation to this round of talks with the strong intention of settling all remaining unsolved issues.

"As huge gaps still exist between the two sides, we may have to end this round and meet again at an appropriate time," Wang said, adding: "We can't make unconditional concessions simply for concluding the negotiations."

Wang arrived in Washington, D.C. on Sunday with the aim of seeking major breakthroughs in the difficult WTO talks. He is scheduled to meet with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Wednesday to exchange views on related issues.

On Tuesday, Wang also met with Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, for discussions on a range of economic and financial topics of mutual concern. Bush is the top American liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Wang told Bush that the Republic of China government is willing to assist in addressing the current Southeast Asian financial crisis. "We do not have any political motivation in making such offers," Wang said, adding that Taiwan has consistently maintained close trade and economic ties with many Southeast Asian countries. "We have invested heavily in the region and do not want to see it plagued by financial and economic woes."

The economic minister also expressed Taiwan's intention to take part in a US-sponsored meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors from 22 major economies around the world. The US has invited several Asian economies to the meeting, tentatively set for mid-April, but Taiwan has not been included.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 PRIVATE INVESTMENT ESTIMATED TO GROW BY 17 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) estimated on Wednesday that fixed domestic private sector investment will grow by 16.6 percent to hit NT$1 trillion in 1998.

The DGBAS said growth in 1997 stood at 15.6 percent, predicting that this year's growth rate will be higher as a result of robust investment from the private sector in large-scale construction projects such as power plants, the new high-speed rail system, warehousing centers, commercial-industrial compounds, high-tech industrial parks and recreational resorts.
Domestic demand will be the major force behind Taiwan's economic growth this year, it added.

A survey of the manufacturing sector carried out by the DGBAS in January showed that investment in the sector is expected to increase by 20 percent this year, with the textile, paper making and electronic engineering industries showing the greatest growth potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: US COMMERCE SECRETARY TO VISIT SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: United States Secretary of Commerce William Daley will arrive on Thursday morning in Singapore from Seoul for a two-day visit, wrapping up a three-country fact-finding trip which began in Japan.

While in Singapore, Daley will meet with Singaporean government leaders including Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew, as well as representatives of the US and Singapore business communities, to discuss the current Asian financial crisis and ways to increase US trade with the region.

He will also meet with a group of US ambassadors from countries throughout the Southeast Asian region, including Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam and Hong Kong, according to the US Embassy in Singapore.
Daley will make a speech at a luncheon of the American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore on Friday, before his meetings with Goh and Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH RANKED 7TH HIGHEST GLOBALLY LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth for 1997 reached 6.8 percent, the seventh highest in the world, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Wednesday.

DGBAS Director-General Wei Duan said the economic growth for the first half of 1997 registered at 6.6 percent, while the rate for the second half climbed to 7 percent, despite the financial turmoil that has swept most of the countries of Southeast Asia since last July.
The 6.8 percent overall economic growth rate is the highest recorded in Taiwan in the last six years.
The growth rate for the fourth quarter of last year reached 7.1 percent, the highest since the third quarter of 1992.
Meanwhile, the consumer price index rose 0.9 percent for 1997, the lowest level since 1988.
The high economic growth and low inflation rate for 1997 signified the sound economic fundamentals the island still enjoys, Wei stressed.
The gross national product (GNP) for 1997 broke the NT$8 trillion mark to reach NT$8.18 trillion (US$285.3 billion), bringing the 1997 per capita GNP to US$13,233.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN BUSINESSES IN LESOTHO RESUME OPERATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Chang Jer-shioung)

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan-invested factories and shops in Lesotho have resumed operations after suspending operations for four days due to violent strikes by local laborers last week, according to sources from Lesotho's capital of Maseru.
However, production at the two Taiwan textile plants which bore the brunt of the strike has yet to return to normal, the sources said.

Local laborers at the Hsieh An Textiles factory in the town of Ha-Thetsane, southeast of Maseru, went on strike and held hostage the managers of the factory last Thursday after failing to secure a satisfactory pay raise in negotiations with the management.

The strike turned violent the next day as the 1,000 workers threw stones at the factory and attacked people of Chinese origin, killing a mainland Chinese worker at the plant and injuring a medical team member, also from the mainland.
A nearby textile plant run by a local Chinese businessman was also affected.
Police rushed to the Hsieh An factory and opened fire to disperse the striking workers, killing one and injuring some 40 others.

In addition to demonstrating its resolve to maintain social order, the Lesotho government also stressed that it will hold national elections as scheduled in May, so as not to give opposition parties any excuse to fan new waves of labor unrest.
The sources said that the two textiles plants have dismissed their entire workforces, numbering nearly 1,000 and 3,000 laborers respectively, and are now recruiting new personnel.

Wu Sung-po, a local Chinese leader who serves as the local agent of both Japan's Nissan Motor and Italy's Fiat Motor, said the situation in Lesotho has calmed down and is expected to gradually return to normal.
The 60 Taiwan businesses in Lesotho provide nearly 10,000 jobs for the local people and contribute significantly to the economic development of that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE POPULATION IN CANADA TOPS 920,000
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Feb. 17 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The number of ethnic Chinese in Canada stood at 920,000 as of the end of 1996, comprising 26.9 percent of the country's 3.2 million "nonwhite minorities," the largest group in that category, according to a demographic survey released by the Canadian government on Tuesday.

According to the statistics, other major nonwhite ethnic groups living in Canada include South Asians, blacks, West Asians and Arabians, and Filipinos. Japanese and Koreans totaled around 68,000 and 65,000, respectively.

Most of the Chinese population resides in the greater Toronto, Vancouver and Montreal areas, according to the tallies. There are some 335,000 ethnic Chinese in Toronto, or about one quarter of the city's total minority population, while the figure in Vancouver is around 270,900, making up nearly half of that city's minorities. Another 46,000 Chinese reside in Montreal, accounting for 11.5 percent of its minority population.

By province, there are 1,400 ethnic Chinese in Newfoundland, some 5,600 in Quebec, 423,000 in Ontario, 98,000 in Alberta, and 312,000 in British Columbia. The rest are scattered across other parts of the country.
Chinese is the third most spoken language in Canada, after English and French.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAIL PELTS CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A rare hailstorm hit central Taiwan Wednesday morning, damaging crops, killing poultry and disrupting air traffic.
The sudden burst of hail, caused by a cold front which has brought heavy rain storms to central Taiwan since Tuesday night, fell in the areas of Chiayi and Changhua at about 5:00 a.m.

The pellets of ice, some measuring about 4 cm in diameter, rattled the roofs of buildings and awakened sleeping residents. Several windows of houses and automobiles were shattered. Hundreds of geese at a poultry farm in Liouchao village and the crops at an exclusive vegetable-producing zone in Tungshih village, both in Chiayi County, were destroyed by the sudden downpour, with the damage estimated at about NT$100 million (US$3.03 million).

Although the hail lasted for only about twenty minutes, drenching rains along with heavy gusts of wind continued until midmorning, force the airports in Taichung and Chiayi to close from 8:00 a.m. until noon.
However, as air traffic at the facilities is usually light on Wednesdays, only a few travelers were affected by the closures.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE ACCEPTS FINANCIAL LIBERALIZATION PROPOSALS

TEXT.P: The Singapore government said Wednesday it has accepted nearly all the recommendations made by a finance subcommittee designed to liberalize Singapore's financial sector.

The Finance and Banking Subcommittee under the Singapore Competitiveness Study Committee (CSC) released its report on Feb. 2, in which it made 55 recommendations, covering fund management, treasury/risk management, equities markets, general debt issuance, corporate finance and venture capital, insurance and re-insurance, and cross-border electronic banking.
Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who chairs a general committee on finance, announced the government's response to the recommendations on Wednesday.
It said the government has accepted nearly all the subcommittee's recommendations, other than those dealing with tax matters.

"The thrust of these recommendations is to liberalize the financial sector while maintaining high standards of integrity and supervision, to allow the private sector to play a greater role in deciding what products to offer, and to let the public decide for themselves what they want to invest in, and what risks to accept," it said.
This coincides with the approach the government has taken in its review of the financial sector, it added.
Where further study is necessary, it pointed out, "we have indicated our agreement in principle or otherwise, so that the industry is clear on the direction to be taken and the follow-up necessary."

The response does not cover the government's decisions on recommendations which involve tax matters except in cases where the answer is a clear rejection. The government will study the other tax issues and announce its decisions in due course, it added.

Underlying the subcommittee's recommendations, though not explicitly stated, is the sentiment that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) should play a more active promotional role, and champion the industry's needs with relevant government agencies, e.g. the ministries of finance and law, which administer relevant areas, and the Internal Revenues Administration of Singapore (IRAS) for tax matters.

MAS plans to set up a financial sector promotion department, separate from the departments responsible for supervising the industry. It will work closely with the industry to help bring in new products, technologies and activities, the announcement said.
Since Jan. 1 this year, Deputy Prime Minister Lee has also taken the chairmanship of the MAS, Singapore's de facto central bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPATHY POURS IN AFTER AIR CRASH

TEXT.P: Foreign leaders are extending their sympathy to Taiwan and its people following Monday night's crash of China Airlines flight 676 near Taipei.

Messages of condolence have been received from Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel, Swaziland Prime Minister S.B. Dlamini, Senegal President Abdou Diouf and Prime Minister Labib Thiam, Chad Prime Minister Nassour Guelengdouksia Ouaidou, Nicaragua President Arnoldo Aleman, Malawi President Bakili Muluzi, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Governor-General Charles J. Antrobus, and others, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Wednesday.

Many heads of foreign representative offices responsible for Taiwan affairs have also sent condolences to their Taiwan counterparts, including Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, and Leijiru Hattori, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, said the Foreign Ministry.
The air crash, the worst ever in Taiwan, claimed the lives of 196 passengers and crew members as well as six persons on the ground. The cause of the accident is under investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND BANK OFFICIAL RULES OUT DEVALUATION OF YUAN

TEXT.P: A visiting mainland Chinese central bank official told Japan's Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi on Tuesday that Beijing will not cut the value of its currency.
Bank of China Chairman Wang Xuebing said that Beijing's policy is to maintain the exchange rate of the yuan at near-current levels for the foreseeable future.

He cited the stability of the mainland Chinese economy, the surplus of its international balance of payments and the sound structure of its foreign debt as three reasons why the yuan is unlikely to lose its value.
Obuchi, who recounted Wang's remarks after their meeting, emphasized to the local press that a stable yuan is a vital factor in keeping the lid on Asia's financial woes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN FIRMS WOO TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR MAKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the potential to become the third country in the world to feature high-end 12-inch wafer plants, after the United States and Japan, overseas industry sources said on Wednesday.

T.S. Chen, managing director of the US-based PRI Corp., said Taiwan has the potential to leap ahead of South Korea and become only the third country to produce sophisticated 12-inch wafers, as Taiwan semiconductor makers are actively engaged in expansion plans while South Korean firms have stopped such efforts.

Chen made the remarks after his company and three Japanese firms -- Daifuku, Shinko and Murata -- held a joint seminar at the Science-based Industrial Park in northern Hsinchu to tout their automation facilities to Taiwan firms.

Chen said the event drew enthusiastic response from more than 100 representatives of local integrated circuitry firms, revealing that a number of them had shown keen interest in purchasing his company's equipment to manufacture semiconductors.

Chen expressed confidence that the first 12-inch wafer plant will be soon set up in Taiwan, following in the steps of similar facilities in the United States and Japan. He said that the first 12-inch wafer plants in those two countries will be completed by 1999.

According to the estimates by the Industrial Technology Research Institute, construction of a 12-inch wafer plant requires at least US$3 billion in capital, while that for an eight-inch wafer needs an investment of US$1 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE EXPRESSES CONDOLENCES FOR CRASH VICTIMS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as the chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, on Wednesday expressed his deep condolences over those who perished in Monday night's China Airlines (CAL) crash.
Lee said in a routine meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee that his concern is also with the families of the victims and residents living near the crash site.

The CAL Airbus A-300 crashed near the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, killing all 196 passengers and crew members onboard as well as six others on the ground. Part of the ill-fated aircraft slammed into a residential area, setting a number of houses afire and claiming the lives of the six and injuring several others.

At the beginning of the meeting, Lee asked the committee members to observe one minute of silence in memory of the victims who died in Taiwan's ever-worst aviation disaster. Central Bank of China Governor Sheu Yuan-dong and three other high-ranking financial officials who were aboard the airplane on their return from an international meeting on the resort island of Bali were among the victims.

While stating that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) and the CAL should make every effort to properly handle the incident, Lee added that the CAL should offer the families of the victims reasonable compensation and help them with funeral arrangements.

Lee also instructed the MOTC to set up a special task fore to determine the cause of the crash. He said the MOTC and the CAA should take the responsibility for strengthening aviation safety standards to protect the lives of air passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATIZATION OF CAL SHOULD BE ACCELERATED SAYS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: After the worst-ever aviation disaster in Taiwan on Monday night, the privatization of China Airlines (CAL) is seen as more urgent than ever in order to salvage both the airline's reputation and its operations.

Hsu Lih-teh, former vice premier and currently chairman of the government-controlled CAL Foundation, on Wednesday called on the government to accelerate the privatization process of the CAL, whose Airbus A-300 en route to Taipei from the resort island of Bali crashed near the CKS International Airport on Monday night, killing all 196 passengers and crew onboard as well as six persons on the ground.

Hsu said that the CAL Foundation, though holding a 70 percent stake of the CAL, actually assumes no responsibility for monitoring operations of the airline, adding that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) should resolve itself to step up efforts to privatize the company.

The status of the CAL is neither official nor private, Hsu said, pointing out that this brings immense difficulties in the operation as well as the transformation of the airline. Hsu, who assumed his post last July, described the CAL as a "company without management," and even called it "an orphan that no one cares about."

Monday's disaster was the CAL's second crash in four years. On April 26, 1994, the same model of Airbus A-300 crashed at Japan's Nagoya airport, killing 264 of the 271 persons onboard. The airline's poor flight safety record is drawing severe criticism from the public.
Hsu admitted that the CAL needs improvement in many areas, but said there is no reason to dissolve the company, as some legislators have demanded in the wake of the latest accident.

Hsu claimed that Taiwan residents have strong feelings of loyalty toward the CAL. In addition, due to considerations of national interest as well as the legal aspect, the CAL should not be disbanded, he argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE KICKS OFF TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL BOOK FAIR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui kicked off the Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) on Thursday, with a wish that the Asia's largest book fair will help make Taipei the pivot of the regional publishing industry and the global center of Chinese-language reading material.

Lee said he hopes that by sponsoring the TIBE, Taipei will evolve into an international copyright exchange hub. He also anticipated that the book fair will help Taiwan residents develop better reading habits and thus broaden their horizons.
Meanwhile, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said the Taipei book fair will be institutionalized as an annual event for book exchanges between Taiwan and the world community.

The TIBE, the sixth of its kind since 1988, boasts of being the fourth largest book fair in the world. It will feature books offered by 673 publishers from 40 countries and areas around the world displayed in 1,409 booths at the Taipei World Trade Center.
In an unprecedented attraction, a German theme pavilion at this year's TIBE is presenting a glimpse of the Frankfurt Book Fair, the world's biggest such exhibition with a 250-year tradition.

On display at the pavilion will be an array of 1,500 German publications, a collection of original illustrated books by 15 German artists, an authentic 15th-century Gutenberg press -- believed to be the world's first movable-type machine, and a collection of some of the smallest books in existence -- prayer books in seven languages.

Peter Weidhaas, chairman of the Frankfurt Book Fair, and Roland Ulmer, chairman of the Frankfurt Book Expo Co., were among the guests at a cocktail party marking the opening of the 1998 TIBE on Wednesday. ROC Premier Vincent Siew also attended the party to welcome and extend greetings to participating exhibitors from around the world.
In addition to books, on display in the TIBE will be stationery, CD-ROMs, Internet systems and other electronic reading materials.
The six-day event will run through next Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SRAM DUMPING CHARGES TAKE DRAMATIC TURN (PART I)

TEXT.P: Dumping charges against Taiwan and South Korean manufacturers involving static random access memory (SRAM) chips took a dramatic turn during Wednesday's final public hearing at the US International Trade Commission (ITC), with the largest American SRAM maker Motorola Corp. voicing opposition to imposing punitive anti-dumping tariffs on Taiwan and Korean exporters.

Motorola, which produces US$520 million worth of SRAMs annually, said at the ITC public hearing that since the final verdict delivered by the Commerce of Department (DOC) last week exempted South Korea's Samsung Co. from punitive tariffs, the anti-dumping charges filed by Micron Co. have become meaningless.

Motorola claimed that Samsung is the strongest foreign competitor that has caused "real harm" to American SRAM makers, while other Korean and Taiwan makers to be subject to the DOC-proposed punitive anti-dumping tariffs do not pose a real threat because their combined American market share falls below 10 percent.

Motorola asked the ITC to reconsider the DOC verdict, which it said would only serve to make Samsung the real beneficiary. "Samsung would become even more competitive in the US market once other Korean and Taiwan SRAM makers are subject to punitive tariff rates," it asserted.
Speaking on the same occasion, Micron lawyers, however, said that Taiwan makers took the lead in selling their SRAMs below fair market prices and that Samsung was forced to follow suit.

Even though the aggregate market share controlled by Taiwan and other Korean makers is limited, Micron said, their "low price" strategy would eventually force their American counterparts to cut prices or completely withdraw from the market. "So they should be subject to punitive tariffs," a Micron lawyer asserted.

According to market tallies, Samsung accounts for 13 percent of the US SRAM import market; Taiwan makers, including Windbond, Microelectronics, Alliance and Integrated Silicon Solution (Taiwan) Inc. (ISSI), jointly control a 5 percent market share; and other Korean firms on the dumping list, including Hyundai and Lucky-Gold Star Group, jointly command a 3 percent share.

Lawyers representing Korean makers stressed that their SRAM exports would not cause any harm to American firms because the quantity is limited. Moreover, they said, their products are different from Taiwan's. Taiwan mainly produces high-speed SRAMs.

Lawyers hired by Taiwan companies said two of the charged Taiwan firms -- ISSI and Alliance -- are owned by Americans and that the remaining Taiwan firms actually account for less than 3 percent of the US SRAM import market.
For all these arguments, observers said the chances that the ITC would overrule the DOC's dumping charges against Taiwan and Korean makers are slim.

Genda Hu, secretary-general of the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association who came to Washington on Monday to appeal for Taiwan firms, said there is a 50-50 probability that the ITC will make a decision favorable to Taiwan makers.

Under US anti-dumping procedures, both the plaintiffs and defendants can still furnish the ITC with relevant data or documents before Feb. 26 and present written responses or arguments based new data offered by the rival side before March 23. The ITC is expected to deliver a final adjudication on the DOC's anti-dumping verdict by the end of March. If the ITC upholds the verdict, Taiwan SRAM makers will be subject to punitive anti-dumping tariff rates starting in early April.

According to the DOC final verdict, Windbond-produced SRAM chips will be subject to a punitive tariff rate of 102.83 percent; the rate for United Microelectronics reaches 93.87 percent; the rates for Alliance and ISSI are set at 50.58 percent and 7.59 percent, respectively.

The three Taiwan companies which failed to respond to questionnaires sent by the DOC -- Texas-Acer Instruments, Best Integrated Technology and Advanced Microelectronics -- will be subject to an extremely high rate of 113.85 percent. And the rate for all other Taiwan SRAM makers is set at 41.98 percent. (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu) (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: SRAM DUMPING CHARGES (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Industry sources said even if the ITC upholds the verdict, it may not critically hurt Taiwan firms because SRAMs built in motherboards, which form the bulk of Taiwan's SRAM exports to the US market, won't be subject to punitive rates.

Nevertheless, Taiwan makers worry that Micron may file dumping charges against their dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips following its victory in the SRAM case. DRAM chips account for the lion's share of export items of many Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers.

Micron spokesperson Julie Nash, however, told CNA that Micron has no plans to file such a charge because Taiwan makers command only a modest 5 percent share of the US DRAM import market. "The prospects for us to win such a case are slim," she noted.
