DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN COUNTY MAGISTRATE STUDIES CITY PLANNING, ENVIRONMENT IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-chen and a six-member group are on a study tour in Australia to look into city planning, environmental, water and electric facilities.
Liu and his delegation on Wednesday visited Canberra, where they were briefed by the National Capital Authority officials on the city planning of the Australian capital.
This is the first visit by the Ilan County government magistrate and county officials to Australia.
The group also received another briefing from the Australian Capital Territory Electric and Water Department on the water supply and power facilities in Canberra.

Canberra is the second leg of Liu's visit. He and his group went to Sydney on Feb. 16 and 17 where they visited Sydney's Deputy Lord Mayor Henry Tseng and observed the city planning of Australia's biggest metropolitan area.
The group left Canberra on Thursday for Melbourne, continuing its tour to the second biggest city of Australia.
Liu and his delegation will wind up their tour to Australia and return to Taiwan on Feb.21 from Brisbane.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHEMICAL INDUSTRY TO MAKE INROADS INTO NORTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: In an effort to open markets in neighboring Japan and South Korea, a delegation from Taiwan's chemical sector is planning an April trip to Seoul, Tokyo and Osaka, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Thursday.

A spokesman for CETRA, a nonprofit organization funded by the government to promote market expansion, said the Northeast Asian visit will present excellent opportunities to increase trade and develop cooperative relations there.

CETRA suggested that the capital investment and technology fields in Japan and Korea are well suited for launching strategic cooperation, while forging mutual licensing agreements with local companies there is also a good way to penetrate regional markets and at the same time to acquire new technologies, the spokesman said.

He added that the present time is the best juncture for local chemical businesses to develop the Korean market, as that country is facing a period of supply and demand readjustment after entering the "IMF era" -- a reference to attempts by the International Monetary Fund to guide Korea's torn economy out of financial chaos.

According to CETRA, a sponsor of the April visit, the delegation will be composed of representatives from the member-enterprises of industry associations for dyestuffs, synthetic resin and plastic raw materials, as well as executives of the Taipei Import-Export Association.

The CETRA official indicated that in addition to the two Northeast Asian countries, his council has also mapped out programs for making inroads into Southeast Asia's chemical industry markets, and for exploring opportunities in those sectors in India and southern Europe. (Elizabeth Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MALES TO BE ALLOWED TO GO OVERSEAS FOR TOURISM

TEXT.P: Taiwan males who have yet to serve their military conscription duty will be allowed to go overseas for tourism, if a plan by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) goes through.
The plan will benefit mainly those who are enrolled in schools and have yet to serve in the armed forces as well as those who quit school and are awaiting their conscription notifications.

Under current regulations, Taiwan males who reach the age of 19 must serve in the military if they are no longer pursuing academic studies. Furthermore, until they have fulfilled their obligation of military service, they are barred from going overseas.
Those who have yet to fulfill their mandatory military duty must apply for permission if they wish to travel abroad, with such applications reviewed on a case-by-case basis.

But the Council of Grand Justices late last year said in its interpretation of the ROC Constitution that the practice runs counter to the spirit of the Constitution, which guarantees the people freedom of movement.

The officials said that in response to the decision, the MOI will revise its regulations to allow those males who have yet to serve in the military to go overseas for tourism. However, it will continue to prohibit them from going overseas to study, except for short-term courses.
Taiwan males affected by the proposed regulations will thus be able to travel overseas by June 25 at the latest if the revisions are adopted, they said.

Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen said the MOI is obligated to give priority to the rights of people who wish to go overseas for tourism, rather than attempting to prevent the male from going aboard for fear of they may be dodging military service.
Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Ministry of Defense said it will have to confer with the MOI before making any comment on the proposed regulations.
The ministries of defense, education and the interior are due to meet next week to discuss related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: US BLASTS AUSSIE TRADE PROTECTIONISM

TEXT.P: The United States has warned that Australia's alleged use of quarantine issues as protection barriers could harm its push for bigger export to America and elsewhere.

The warning was made by US Ambassador to Australia Genta Hawkins Holmes, who said other important trading partners such as Canada, New Zealand, Thailand and the European Union have supported the US view.

The US envoy's remarks about Australia's quarantine decisions echo criticisms in January by the Canadian high commissioner and follow quarantine decisions to ban imports of fresh salmon and cooked chicken meat for most purposes.
"Too often ... Australia seems to be using technical restrictions in order to provide protection for inefficient sections of agriculture," she said.

"Concern about this and the possible negative effects on Australian exports have been expressed by many in this room. We remain very concerned over the potential to move backwards on access requests that have been around for as long as 10 years or more, such as table grapes, Florida citrus, and should I mention salmon and chicken?" she added.

Earlier Australia's Prime Minister John Howard blasted Washington for using its export guarantee funding to help American farmers provide necessary credit to cash-strapped Asian countries such as South Korea and Indonesia for imports of US commodities because the Asian countries are facing economic crises and are short of funds to import agricultural produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN TO BUY WEST JAVA COFFEE

TEXT.P: Taiwan and South Korean businessmen interested in purchasing robusta and arabica coffee from Central Java are expected to visit the province's coffee-production areas next month.

Hartono Chandra, chairman of the foreign division of the Indonesian Association of Coffee Exporters (AEKI), Central Java chapter, was quoted by Antara news agency as saying in Semarang on Tuesday that the potential customers will visit Semarang, Klaten, Magelang and Wonosobo districts.
He said businessmen from Taiwan and South Korea are interested in buying coffee from Central Java because of its high quality.
In Central Java, he said, coffee is grown on some 40,000 hectares of land, with the robusta variety occupying 38,000 hectares and the arabica variety occupying 2,000 hectares.
The province's monthly coffee production averages 4,000 tons of robusta and 300 tons of arabica, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN UNION LOSES HORMONES CASE

TEXT.P: Members of the World Trade Organization (WTO) formally endorsed WTO panel and appeal body rulings against the European Union's ban on hormone-treated beef which was found not to be based on scientific evidence, according to reports from the world trade body on Wednesday.

The EU has until the next meeting of the WTO's dispute settlement body on March 13 to explain how it plans to implement the rulings, but EU officials have already said they intend to carry out another scientific risk study to support keeping the ban. The United States and Canada, which brought the WTO challenge, said the ban should be lifted immediately, the WTO report said.
Meanwhile, Washington also rejected India's claim that it needed until at least mid-June 1999 to implement panel and appeal body rulings upholding a US complaint against India's patent regime.

The ruling said India had failed to institute a satisfactory "mailbox" system for pharmaceutical and agrochemical patent applications, pending the introduction of full patent protection in 2005, and to grant exclusive marketing rights as required by WTO rules.
The two sides have until March 2 to agree on a time period for implementation, failing which the WTO will appoint an arbitrator, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA TO HOLD INTERNATIONAL AIR SHOW

TEXT.P: An international air show will be staged at Waterkloof Air Base near Pretoria from April 28 to May 2.
The show organizer Peter Piggot said Wednesday that the event, dubbed "Aerospace Africa '98," would feature aerial displays by several exotic military and civilian aircraft.
There will be at least 150 international exhibitors from 20 countries, including the United States, Britain, France, Italy, Germany, Russia and Poland, Piggot said.

He said the show, jointly organized by the Commercial Aviation Association of Southern Africa and the South African Aerospace, Maritime and Defense-related Industries Association, would cover all aspects of the aviation and aerospace industry.

Piggot pointed out that African countries are under pressure to update their air traffic control systems in view of an international outcry about the dangers of flying over the continent. "On show will be state-of-the-art navigation and advanced ground control equipment," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA STUDYING ENTRY OF FOREIGN CAPITAL INTO PUBLIC UTILITIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is studying proposed revisions to relevant statutes in order to allow foreign investment in state-owned enterprises during the process of privatization.

Under a program to sell shares of leading state-run enterprises, including Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), Chunghwa Telecom, and Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC), ownership of those companies will be gradually transferred to private investors, MOEA officials said.
For example, they said, CPC, one of the oldest and most lucrative state-run enterprises in Taiwan, will be privatized in three stages, with the first stage having already begun.
Some 10 percent to 15 percent of CPC stakes will be sold to private investors and CPC employees in the first stage, scheduled to conclude in fiscal year 1998.

Another 15 percent to 20 percent of the CPC shares, set to be released in fiscal 1999, will be opened to foreign strategic investors through the Taiwan Stock Exchange and to other overseas investors in the form of global depository receipts (GDR).
In the final stage, scheduled to be launched before the end of 1999, 25 percent to 30 percent of CPC stakes will be released to eligible ROC citizens, the officials noted.
Meanwhile, the privatization of Taipower will also be implemented in three stages, starting in early 1999.

In the first stage, 10 percent of Taipower stakes, or about 3 billion shares, will be sold to private investors through public bidding and offered to Taipower employees. The process is expected to be implemented before June 1999.

Another 10 percent of the Taipower shares, set to be released before June 2000, will be opened to local strategic investors through the Taiwan Stock Exchange and to overseas investors in the form of GDRs.
In the third stage, scheduled to be launched before June 2001, 20 percent to 30 percent of Taipower stakes will be released to eligible ROC citizens, the officials said.
There will be flexibility in proceeding with the second and third stages, depending on the market reaction, they noted.

If the Taipower shares prove to be highly sought after in the initial offer, the third phase selloff may be moved up to June 2000, with the original second phase being pushed back to June 2001, the officials added.
In addition, they said, special annual reward rates will be offered as incentives for long-term investors who hold the Taipower shares for at least two years.

AIDC, formerly the military-run Aero-Industry Development Center, which built Taiwan's locally designed Indigenous Defense Fighters, is scheduled to go private in two stages between June this year and December 1999, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENSIONS ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT RISE: JAPAN DEFENSE AGENCY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Tensions across the Taiwan Strait are on the rise, according to a report published on Thursday by the Defense Institute of the Japan Defense Agency, which has made a study on the strategic environment of countries around Japan.
The report titled "A Strategic Overview of East Asia, 1997-1998" pointed out that crisis management involving the Taiwan Strait is becoming more difficult.

Compared with the report published last year, which did not rule out the possibility of mainland China launching a "peace offensive" toward Taiwan, the outlook for 1998 is gloomier, pointing out that "mainland China does not expect (ROC President) Lee Teng-hui's administration to be a force for improving cross-strait relations."
The buildup of the air forces on both sides and Taiwan's resumption of live-fire military exercises point to an increase of instability factors across the strait, the recently concluded report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND SWITZERLAND CONCLUDE GOVERNMENT PROCUREMENT AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Lee Chien-chung, vice chairman of the Public Construction Commission of the ROC Executive Yuan, announced Wednesday that bilateral consultations between Switzerland and the Republic of China for accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) Government Procurement Agreement have concluded.

Lee noted that similar bilateral consultations between the ROC and the United States were concluded last December in Washington. He presumed that the pending bilaterals with Canada, the European Union and South Korea, as well as the ongoing accession process can be finalized soon so to facilitate Taipei's accession to the Agreement after becoming a member of the WTO.

Lee led a three-member delegation to attend the committee meeting on Feb. 16-18. He told the committee that the draft of his government's procurement law has gone through the intercommittee review by the Legislature and completed the interparty negotiations among legislators from different political parties, and is now standing for the second and third readings by the Legislature at its plenary session in Taipei.
"A new session of the Legislature is to be commenced this week. We do hope to have the law passed soon."

DOC.HEADLINE: HK GOV'T TO RESOLVE COIN SHORTAGE IN MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's current change shortage is due to coin collectors and ordinary Hong Kong citizens, who have put aside almost all of Hong Kong's commemorative coins minted in 1997 and those bearing the portrait of the British queen, said an official with the government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

When questioned at the Provisional Legislative Council about the coin shortage in the market, Xu Shiren, head of the trade and economic affairs bureau of the Hong Kong government, pointed out that the government issued 800 million new coins in 1997 to replace the 800 million coins with the bust of Queen Elizabeth II it expected would be put aside by Hong Kong residents and collectors.
Worry over the coin shortage, however, has caused people to hoard coins even more, further worsening the situation, he said.

Xu offered three approaches to resolve the problem: the continuous minting of new coins, accelerating the circulation of coins in the market and expanding the use of electronically read cards in public transportation.

The Hong Kong government issued 206 million coins in the first six weeks of this year, with that figure expected to reach 1.4 billion coins by the end of September, or some 156 million additional coins per month.
The Hong Kong government is encouraging bus companies to adopt the use of transportation cards. A total of 3.8 million such cards have been sold to date.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN OFFERS CONDOLENCES TO CAL CRASH VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Vatican's secretary of state, Cardinal Angelo Sodano, sent condolences from the Holy See to families of the 202 people killed when a China Airlines (CAL) Airbus A300-600R crashed on Monday in Taipei.
In his message to Archbishop Joseph Ti-Kang of Taipei, Sodano relayed Pope John Paul II's concerns over Taiwan's worst air disaster.
The full text of the wire reads:

Deeply saddened by the loss of life in the airline accident at Taipei Airport, the Holy Father asks you to express his condolences to the families of those who died. He joins the Church in Taiwan in praying for the victims and invokes divine strength and comfort upon all affected by this tragedy. He asks God to send his comforting gifts upon all who are in mourning and to bless them with his peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKES MAJOR CONCESSION ON RICE TRADE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan has agreed to a major concession on the opening of its rice market in exchange for US support of its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang said here on Wednesday that Taiwan has promised to follow the Japanese formula in opening its rice market after its WTO accession as demanded by the US side.

This means that if Taiwan enters the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body this year, it must immediately open its rice market, with an import quota equivalent to 6.4 percent of its total rice consumption between 1990 and 1992. And if its entry is postponed to next year, the import quota will increase to 7.2 percent of its 1990-92 rice consumption.
Taiwan originally offered an import quota of 4 percent of its 1990-92 rice consumption, with the quota increasing by 0.8 percent annually to 8 percent in five years.
According to the new terms, Taiwan will be required to allow annual imports of about 96,000 tons of rice if it joins the WTO in 1999, far higher than the previously proposed 60,000 tons.
Wang said he hopes Taiwan's concession in rice trade will help finalize the WTO-related bilateral talks with the United States soon.
Wang said the two sides have agreed to extend the current round of WTO talks for one day to Thursday in order to seek breakthroughs on some unsolved thorny issues.

Wang met with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Wednesday afternoon to discuss policy issues. During their talks, Wang urged the US side to be more flexible in dealing with topics related to pork and animal intestine trade so that bilateral WTO talks can be concluded at an early date.

For her part, Barshefsky expressed the US hopes that Taiwan complies with an EVSL market liberalization plan proposed by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum and supports the Clinton administration's proposals for zero-tariff electronics trade.

Barshefsky also expressed concern about America's widening trade deficit with Taiwan. According to US tallies, the US incurred a trade deficit of more than US$12 billion with Taiwan in 1997, the highest in eight years. However, ROC tallies put Taiwan's trade surplus with the US at only US$6.3 billion.
Wang arrived in Washington on Sunday for high-level consultations with senior US officials on terms for Taiwan's WTO entry.

Wang said it remains uncertain whether the two sides can finalize all WTO-related issues on Thursday. If no compromise on several sensitive issues can be worked out, he said, the two sides will hold another round of talks in the future.

Taiwan has so far held 17 rounds of WTO talks with the US. The current round began last week and the two sides have managed to come to terms on several topics, including the opening of Taiwan's chicken meat market and service markets, timetables for farm trade tariff reductions and issues related to wine and tobacco imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN EXPERTS WARY OF HEPATITIS CURE CLAIM

TEXT.P: Canadians, battling the spread of hepatitis resulting from a tainted-blood scandal, are wary of claims Wednesday that scientists in the United States and Hungary have found a cure for the B and C types of the disease.

The US and Hungarian researchers said they had found a naturally occurring virus that wipes out the disease. They also said the cure has no side effects and costs just a fraction of what is currently spent. The Hepatitis C Society of Canada said the claims seem exaggerated.
Tim McClemont, executive director of the society, said it would ask Health Canada's Health Protection Branch to check the researchers' claims.
McClemont said while the news is encouraging, experts are entitled to be skeptical about claims of an outright cure because progress in treatment has been slow.
The number of Hepatitis B cases has been reduced through vaccination programs, but Hepatitis C is now recognized as a major public health problem worldwide.

In Canada, the number of cases is estimated at 300,000 or 1 percent of the population. That includes the thousands who were infected by tainted blood products in the 1980s and are now demanding government compensation.
The blood-borne disease show such symptoms as chronic fatigue, nausea and vomiting and jaundice. Both strains attack the liver and can lead to liver cancer or cirrhosis.

Results of tests using a naturally occurring virus developed by Laszlo Csatary of the United Cancer Research Institute in Alexandria, Va., are to be published in the March edition of the international journal Anticancer Research.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESPOND FORMALLY TO SEF'S PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Beijing should respond formally to the proposal that C.F. Koo, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), visit mainland China, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Thursday.
Chang made the remarks while attending a seminar on the direction of mainland China's development since last September's 15th Communist Party Congress.
Chang pointed out that Koo has said since November that he hopes to lead a delegation to visit the mainland and meet there with his mainland counterpart.
The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the SEF's mainland counterpart, has yet to respond to the proposal, he noted.

Chang stressed that the resumption of talks between the SEF and ARATS, the two intermediately bodies set up by Taipei and Beijing respectively to deal with exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal ties, could be the starting point for normal exchanges between the two sides.

Chang said he is optimistic about the prospects for improved cross-strait relations. He predicted that after the conclusion of Beijing's National People's Congress and Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference in March, mainland China will start to address cross-strait relations seriously.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT INTERESTED IN GAINING SHARE OF CAL, SAYS LIU TAI-YING

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang would be extremely interested in buying a piece of China Airlines (CAL) if the disaster-stricken company goes public, Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the KMT Business Management Committee (KBMC), said on Thursday.
Liu said the ruling party's business arm would like to pitch in to help bail out the trouble-ridden company, as well as to help raise CAL's standards of service.

He said the KMT is experienced in airline operations and that the KBMC would have no problem joining with CAL's operations, citing that the China Development Corp., a KMT business offshoot, is a partner in Far East Air Transport.
Since the KBMC couldn't and wouldn't want to secure all of CAL alone, the KMT would welcome others to jump on the wagon with it if CAL shares are opened to private investors, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATION INTO AIR CRASH CONTINUES

TEXT.P: The investigation by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) and Airbus Industrie into Monday's airplane disaster that claimed 202 lives continued Thursday at the crash site.

The leader of the investigation, CAA Deputy Director Chang Kuo-cheng, said the investigative teams will not remove the wreckage or otherwise disturb the crash site until the reason is found for the accident, the worst in Taiwan's aviation history.

The CAL A300-600R passenger aircraft, bound from the Indonesian resort of Bali, crashed on Monday evening while attempting to land at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, killing all 196 persons on board and six others on the ground.

Chang indicated that the work ahead will be difficult, noting that investigators not only have to reassemble the pieces of the plane as best they can but also analyze the location of individual pieces for clues to the cause of the accident.

Questioned about a statement from Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, France, that blamed the crash on bad weather and human error, the CAA official expressed his disagreement, noting that both before and after the crash there were many successful landings and take-offs, which he said shows the weather was not responsible.
"It's improper for Airbus to make such statements before all the evidence is in," Chang said.

In order to gain in-depth knowledge of the likely condition of the plane before the accident, the CAA has asked relevant departments and CAL to provide numbered, detailed information on the aircraft's parts and components, as well as its repair records.

Precise weather data recorded by advanced Doppler radar were also acquired to check whether wind shear or sudden air currents appeared when the A-300 plane was preparing for landing, said Chang, who added that his team is also investigating allegations that CAL falsified its pilots' flight-hour records.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.141 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at NT$32.746.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.705 and had a high of 32.8.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$453.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SKYROCKET ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices jumped 1.6 percent on the local stock market Thursday, spurred on by a rally on Wall Street.
The weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX), the market's key indicator, rose 141.17 points to close at 8,978.51, its highest level this year.
Trading opened at 8,958.34, with the bourse experiencing a low of 8,942.72 and a high of 9,010.12.
Gainers overwhelmed losers 336 to 95, with 59 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 3.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$243.55 billion (US$7.43 billion) in the three-hour session.

Seven of the eight major categories of shares registered gains, with electrical engineering stocks surging 2.5 percent, followed by a 2.4 percent gain in construction issues, 2.1 percent in paper-making shares, 1.4 percent in foodstuff stocks, 1.2 percent in cement issues, 0.7 percent in textile shares and 0.4 percent in plastic and chemical stocks.
Financial shares were the only category to experience a fall, dropping 0.8 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were Winbond Electronics, United Micro Electronics, ACER, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, China Airlines, Mosel-Vitelic, Macronix International Computer, ADI, GVC Corp. and Microelectronics Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF TAIWAN'S MOBILE PHONE SECTOR TO REACH US$9.14 B.

TEXT.P: The annual production value of Taiwan's mobile telephone sector will reach NT$300 billion (US$9.14 billion) in five years, according to a white paper on telecommunications policy unveiled on Thursday.

In releasing the white paper, officials with the Directorate General of Telecommunications under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said that since the opening of four telecommunications services between January and May 1996 to private telecommunications operators, there have been abundant business opportunities in that sector.

The officials said that the annual production value of the four services -- covering mobile telephones, radio paging, mobile data communication and trunk radio -- combined with the revenue of peripheral industries is expected to reach NT$300 billion five years from now.
They noted that with only five out of every hundred people in Taiwan equipped with a mobile phone, the island lags far behind many nations in the Asia-Pacific region.
In view of Taiwan's per capita income, the island could see 25 mobile phone users per 100 people in five years, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TRAINER CRASHES OFF TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: A training airplane of the ROC Air Force crashed on Thursday into Paisha Bay off the coast of northern Taipei County after developing engine problems during a routine training mission, according to air force general headquarters.
A spokesman said the plane was totally destroyed but the pilot escaped with his life. Squadron Leader C.M. Tsai, pilot of the No. 748 Chunghsing trainer, swam ashore after ejecting safely.
The air force is investigating the cause of the accident, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE MAY BE FIRST IN ASIA TO JOIN US FIGHTER PROJECT

TEXT.P: Singapore is poised to become the first Asian country to join the United States in a program to develop the next generation of multi-role strike fighter aircraft.

A memorandum of understanding is under discussion that could pave the way for Singapore's Ministry of Defense to join the Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) program as an "informed customer," The Straits Times reported Thursday, quoting the weekly aerospace news magazine Flight International.
The arrangement is another indication of the close relationship between the governments of the two countries and the good defense ties they have been cultivating, the report said.

The JSF program is aimed at developing and fielding an affordable family of next-generation multi-role strike fighter aircraft for the US Navy, Air Force (USAF), Marine Corps and its allies, the magazine said.

As an informed customer, the Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) would be given access to 90 percent of the data on the program. This would allow it to evaluate the JSF against future requirements, it said.
However, Singapore's observer status would not give it key information on radar-evading stealth technology or allow it to influence the fighter's design, according to the magazine.
Denmark, the Netherlands and Norway have already become informed customers of the JSF program. Italy is holding talks on joining the program, and Australia has been briefed on it.
Commenting on getting involved in the JSF program, the Feb. 18-24 issue of Flight International quoted Lt. Gen. Bey Soo Khiang, Singapore's defense chief, as saying:
"I think that we would be interested in doing that, but the entrance fee is still quite big to us ... so it is something to ponder on.
"From an operational viewpoint, with the JSF being a possible replacement for the F-16s in the long-term, it is something we should be interested in."
No details on the cost were available, the report said.
Lockheed F-16s are among the fighters the RSAF operates.
The JSF project is already partially through a 51-month concept demonstration phase that will culminate in the final selection by early 2001 of a winning design, the report said.
Boeing and Lockheed Martin were short-listed in November 1996 for each to produce two demonstrators.
The US and Singapore governments enjoy a close relationship, and many of Singapore's defense purchases are US-made products.
The USAF has made available its bases in the United States for training of RSAF F-16 pilots, giving them the needed air-space Singapore lacks.
The USAF rotates F-16 deployments through Singapore, and recently Singapore announced that US Navy carriers would be given access to its new Changi Naval Base.
The involvement in the JSF program is another indication of the close ties the two countries have been building. There is also prestige involved in being part of the program, the report said.
Flight International said that the JSF admission "would elevate the status of Singapore head and shoulders above that of its Southeast Asian neighbors."

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST SQUADRON OF 2ND IDF WING FORMED AT TAINAN AIRBASE

TEXT.P: The first squadron of the second wing of the locally built indigenous defense fighters (IDFs) was formed at an air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan on Thursday.
Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Huang Hsien-yung presided over a ceremony marking the formation of the new squadron.

Huang said he is delighted to see that the Tainan airbase has completed installation and initial personnel training of the squadron in just 11 months, indicating that the system for aircraft replacement and personnel training established by the air force is sound.

Huang reviewed all 18 of the IDFs, also known as Ching-kuo fighters in memory of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, their pilots and maintenance personnel, and presented citations to those who contributed to the installation and training work.

At the moment, the squadron has only preliminary combat capability and will require further professional training before it can be formally commissioned, Huang said, adding that he hopes the airbase staff will continue working hand-in-hand to complete all necessary training programs as scheduled.

The first IDF wing, comprising 70 IDFs, was commissioned last April at the Ching Chuan Kang airbase in central Taiwan. The second wing, which will consist of 60 IDFs in three squadrons, is scheduled to be formally commissioned at the Tainan airbase in 1999.

The air force had originally planned to purchase 150 of the locally developed IDFs, but cut the number to 130 after striking separate deals with the United States and France for purchasing 150 F-16 and 60 Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters, respectively.
The three types of advanced fighters will form the backbone of Taiwan's fleet of second-generation warplanes.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LIEN TALKS ABOUT ISSUE OF TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan of the Republic of China said here Thursday that the issue of Taiwan Strait can be resolved through friendly exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China.
He made the remark at an international conference on the People's Republic of China after the 15th Party Congress, which opened in Beijing on Sept. 12, 1997.

He said Taiwan and mainland China will eventually be able to reach their common goal of national unification under the principles of freedom, democracy, and equal distribution of wealth, if the two sides can sit down to resume their talks without setting preconditions and excluding any particular issues.

Lien said he recently set forth "three nos and three yeses" as an applicable approach to the Taiwan Strait issue. The three nos are no Taiwan independence, no hurry to unify with the Chinese mainland, and no antagonism.

He explained that the Republic of China has been a sovereign state for 87 years. "We do not need to once again declare independence or change the name of our nation." He said Taiwan is in no hurry to unite with the Chinese mainland, because conditions for unification are not yet ripe. He also said that the two sides should not provoke or exclude each other. They should not deliberately incite antagonism or hostility and thereby cause instability.
The "three yeses" Lien proposed are yes to peace, yes to friendly exchanges, and yes to a "win-win" situation for both sides.
The three yeses and one "no to antagonism" will provide the best condition for promoting friendly exchanges and moving toward eventual reunification, he said.

Continuous exchanges would enhance mutual understanding and reduce hostilities, and thus prevent conflicts between the two sides. "Indeed, proceeding with gradual and sequential exchanges between the two sides is the ideal method for maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait," he said.

Through dialogue and exchanges in the past ten years, the two sides have laid a foundation for bilateral relations. From 1991 to October 1997, Taiwan entrepreneurs invested a total of US$8.17 billion in mainland China. Since 1990, an average of one million visits by Taiwan residents to the mainland have been made per year, he pointed out.
However, he said that a latent antagonistic atmosphere still lingers, "which we are very concerned about."

Lien said Beijing, which wants to wipe the Republic of China off the face of the earth, is now hoping to annex Taiwan "in name." Beijing's efforts to suppress Taiwan's foreign relations will only intensify the ill will the residents of Taiwan feel for the Chinese communist regime. "This is clearly detrimental to the development of cross-strait relations and national reunification," he added.

The Vice President said the two sides must respect each other's international presence, cooperate, and help each other. "We must march hand in hand toward a new era of cooperation," he said, adding that "I believe exchanges to be the most effective and feasible method for resolving the Taiwan Strait issue."

He said the differences between Taiwan and mainland China are often called "Taiwan issues," but it is better to call them "Taiwan Strait issues," because the latter can better indicate the complexity of all factors involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU URGES BEIJING TO OPEN SERVICE SECTOR TO FOREIGN FIRMS

TEXT.P: The European Union is urging Beijing to allow foreign companies to operate nationwide and to offer a full range of services there as part of communist China's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to reports from the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body on Thursday.

Mainland China's current WTO offer obliges most foreign companies offering services to set up only through joint venture agreements. Foreign companies should be able to operate nationwide, but Beijing's current offer limits the areas where foreign companies can operate.

Key services such as telecommunications, transport, financial services and distribution should be available in a mature economy, but mainland China has made no offer on basic telecommunications, the WTO report said.

An EU team led by Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan went recently to mainland China, where it presented Beijing with a list of eight principles that it should follow in its offer to the WTO on market access for the services sector and a memorandum setting out these eight principles was released by the European Commission in Brussels.
The memorandum said foreign companies should be allowed to choose whether or not to set up branches, subsidiaries, wholly-owned companies, or joint ventures.

It also called for transparency in mainland China laws and regulations and for a sound and neutral regulatory regime. It also urged mainland China to review its laws on the establishment of foreign companies, pointing out that many restrictive conditions apply to foreign firms, but not to domestic ones.
Brittan announced in Beijing that mainland China has promised to submit detailed tariff cuts to the WTO in Geneva next month, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER CONTINUES AFRICAN TOUR
DOC.DATELINE: Monrovia, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By L.J. Yen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Thursday departed for the island nation of Sao Tome and Principe, off the coast of central Africa, after concluding a brief one-day visit to the West African country of Liberia.

Before leaving the Liberian capital of Monrovia, Hu visited Liberian President Charles Taylor and Parliament President Nyudeh Morkonmana in the morning and was hosted by Foreign Minister Monie R. Captan at noon.

Hu and Captan signed a memorandum of understanding with the aim of boosting bilateral cooperation. Liberia very much hopes that the ROC will help it with its reconstruction after a bitter four-year civil war.

Hu, who arrived here on Wednesday from Gambia on the fourth leg of his current six-country African tour to drum up support from ROC diplomatic allies in the region, said he was hoping to find ways of strengthening two-way relations between the ROC and Liberia. He has already visited Chad and Guinea-Bissau.
Local newspapers all printed reports on Hu's visit on their front pages and carried extensive stories on the ROC on inside pages.
The foreign minister is scheduled to proceed to Burkina Faso from Sao Tome and Principe before returning to Taipei on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL FUND ESTABLSIHED TO HELP CONVICTED MURDERER

TEXT.P: A special fund was founded in Taipei on Thursday to help Tzuo Ming-hsin, a Republic of China national who was convicted of first-degree murder in the US state of Alaska seven years ago and is now serving a 198-year prison term there.

Tzuo Tzu-cheng, son of the convicted murderer, announced the establishment of the fund at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan in the company of former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou, Legislator Chien Hsi-kun (DPP-ex officio) and Lin Shen-fen, a senior journalist.

Ma, now a professor at National Chengchi University (NCU), called on local people to donate money to the fund in order to hire qualified lawyers to appeal for a retrial of Tzuo's case. The fund's postal savings account number is 19148901.

Ma, a Harvard-trained legal expert, said seeking a retrial of the Tzuo case requires professional legal expertise and a large sum of money. "We hope local people will pool resources to support Tzuo's cause," he added.
Ma said the fund will also help other ROC nationals or overseas Chinese who have faced unfair trials abroad.

Speaking on the same occasion, Tzuo Tzu-cheng, an NCU student, said he appreciates all those who have assisted him in setting up the fund. "I'll carefully record all donations and repay donors after I graduate from the university and start to work."
Tzu-cheng paid a visit to his father at an Alaska prison during the Chinese New Year holiday. He held a news conference there to enlist support for his father's cause.

Tzuo left Taiwan for Alaska in the 1980s to work as a cook. He was arrested on charges of murdering a Chinese man and the man's daughter in 1989. A jury found him guilty in 1991 of first-degree murder and sentenced him to 198 years in prison.

Tzuo was convicted simply on the basis of a tape recording, without having physical evidence such as the murder weapon, fingerprint samples or blood stains. Moreover, he never had an opportunity to testify for himself. Tzuo has gone on a long-term hunger strike to protest his conviction. He has consistently insisted on his innocence over the past seven years.

Several American lawyers who were present at the news conference given by Tzu-cheng in the US earlier this month said there were many faults in investigation and trial of Tzuo's case. Some of them have promised to help Tzuo get another chance at justice.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said it has ordered its officials stationed in the US to seek assistance of American legal experts or advisory groups to help Tzuo's cause. "We'll also ask US authorities to ensure that Tzuo is given reasonable, humanitarian treatment in jail," said a minsitry official.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER TO MAKE HUMANITARIAN PAYMENTS TO HEMOPHILIAC AIDS VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Germany's Bayer Group on Thursday agreed to provide humanitarian payments to ROC hemophilia patients infected with HIV from tainted blood products produced by the chemical giant, according to a statement issued by Bayer Taiwan.

The statement said that Bayer, together with Baxter Laboratories, another manufacturer of tainted coagulants derived from blood plasma, will set aside NT$106 million in the form of a bank guarantee to help the 53 local hemophilia patients who contracted HIV from injections of contaminated coagulants. The two manufacturers will negotiate directly with the patients or their representatives to reach agreement on the amount of each payment.
It said that a representative from Bayer headquarters will arrive in Taiwan on Monday to commence the negotiations.

However, the statement stressed that the company does not share responsibility for HIV infections caused by blood plasma products distributed in the early 1980s, on the grounds that the tragedy was "unforeseeable and unavoidable" at that time. The Bayer subsidiary, Cutter Laboratories in the US, has always manufactured strictly in accordance with the latest scientific knowledge, it claimed.
As Bayer is in full agreement that the patients and their families are in need of financial support, the company is willing to provide them with humanitarian payments, the statement said.

Bayer's statement is a positive response to a call made by the Department of Health (DOH) last week, when DOH Director-General Chan Chi-hsien demanded that Bayer offer a NT$2 million guarantee to each of the 53 hemophilia patients as a way of showing a sincere desire to solve the dispute.

Between 1983 and 1985, 53 hemophilia patients in the ROC contracted the AIDS virus from injections of contaminated coagulants made by Cutter Laboratories and Baxter Laboratories. Twenty-two of the original patients have already died of the deadly disease.

The representatives of the patients in recent years have been asking the DOH to assist them in seeking compensation from the foreign suppliers of the tainted products. In addition, they have filed suit against the DOH to demand "national compensation" -- NT$8 million each -- as they believe the DOH should shoulder the blame for failing to ensure the safety of the imported blood products.

Due to limited knowledge about the AIDS virus in the early 1980s, the government didn't demand that all coagulants be heat-treated -- an effective method of eliminating the potential AIDS virus -- until 1985.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER VOWS TO SHOULDER POLITICAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR CAL AIR CRASH

TEXT.P: Tsay Jaw-yang, minister of transportation and communications, promised on Thursday to shoulder political responsibility for the tragic crash of China Airlines (CAL) flight 676, one day after he boasted about his ministry's "good" performance during the rescue operation.

Tsay told a group of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) leaders at an inner party meeting that the administration, especially the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will definitely assume political responsibility for the crash which claimed the lives of 202 people on Monday.
He refused to elaborate on how he will take responsibility, saying that Premier Vincent Siew has ordered him to "explain his plans in detail" to the Legislature on Friday.

Tsay's statement came one day after public outrage over his boast on Wednesday about the ministry's performance in handling events following the crash, which, he claimed, was "no less than the performance of the Japanese authorities" in their efficient and well-organized management of the 1993 CAL air crash in Nagoya which killed 264.

He shrugged off reporters' inquiries about the possibility of his resigning when he emerged from a meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee on Wednesday , saying that the KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who also serves as the country's president, was rather positive about his performance in the crisis and that he has no intention whatsoever of quitting because of the tragedy,

Tsay's claims drew fire from opposition lawmakers as well as from families of the victims. They criticized Tsay's "arrogance" and the government's alleged laxness in enforcing aviation safety rules which they said contributed to the disaster.

Admitting that the public view of his ministry's job performance differs widely to his own, Tsay said on Thursday that his praise on Wednesday for the rescue operation referred only to the 1,500-strong rescue crew, and admitted that there are certainly some shortcomings which need to be improved in the MOTC's crisis management.

At a Cabinet meeting earlier on Thursday, Siew criticized government agencies' amateurism in dealing with the rescue, and the less-than-thoughtful way the search, identification and release of the victims' bodies was carried out.

Fighting back tears, Siew said his personal sorrow for the tragedy could not be relieved by weeping. Noting that 774 lives in Taiwan have been lost in 20 air crashes in the last two decades, the premier called on his Cabinet members to do their utmost to ensure aviation safety and prevent a repeat of the tragedy.

Siew's criticism stemmed partly from complaints by some of the victim's families on Wednesday that prosecutors had refused to release the bodies of their beloved pending DNA confirmation of their identities.
The prosecutors eventually backed down and agreed to let the families claim the bodies after the families promised not to cremate the victims before the test results are released.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA AIRLINES PILOTS SENTENCED TO HEAVIER JAIL TERMS

TEXT.P: Two Formosa Airlines pilots were resentenced to heavier jail terms on Thursday by the Kinmen District Court for their roles in an April, 1996 air crash which claimed the lives of five passengers and injured another seven.
Pilot C. C. Miao was sentenced to three years, and co-pilot C. Y. Chang received one year in prison on charges of involuntary manslaughter.

The earlier sentences, delivered in April 1977, saw Miao receiving a two-and-a-half year jail term, while Chang was given a sentence of eight months suspended for three years by the Kinmen District Court.

Judge Y.S. Shen, who announced the second verdicts, said Miao and Chang were given heavier punishment because police investigations proved that the two had displayed serious negligence in their duties.

According to the judge, Miao, the senior officer on board, made a serious mistake immediately following the crash by failing to try to rescue any of the passengers of the ill-fated plane, opting instead to save his own life. In accordance with ROC law, Miao and Chang can appeal to the supreme court within 10 days of receiving the verdict, he added.

The Formosa Airlines Dornier 228 plane crashed into the sea on April 5, 1996 while attempting to land on the offshore island of Matsu near the coast of mainland China's Fujien Province. The accident killed five people and injured seven more. A six-year-old girl remains missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERIA SEES NO CONFLICT BETWEEN ENGAGEMENT WITH TAIPEI AND BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Monrovia, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By L.J. Yen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Although sticking to the Republic of China's "one China" policy, Liberia doesn't think its diplomatic ties with Taiwan should exclude it from seeking friendship with Beijing, Liberian President Charles Taylor said on Thursday.

In an interview with a group of Taiwan reporters accompanying ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu on a one-day visit to the West African country, Taylor said his country is committed to Taiwan's "one China policy," but this policy doesn't preclude the country's possible engagement with Beijing.

"If Beijing asks to open an embassy here, we would grant it. We would like to forge close ties with Beijing too," said Taylor, adding that engagement with Taipei and Beijing should not conflict with each other.

Liberia has switched recognition between Taipei and Beijing several times since 1957. The last switch occurred in 1997, when Taylor assumed the presidency in August of that year and broke off ties with Beijing.

Meanwhile on Thursday, Hu signed a memorandum of understanding with his Liberian counterpart Monie Captan on an aid package of US$3 million to help demobilize part of the country's 70,000-strong armed forces now that a bitter four-year civil war in the impoverished country has come to an end.

Hu arrived in Monrovia on Wednesday morning on the fourth leg of a six-country African trip. He called on Taylor later that day, when he was awarded the Knight Grand Commander of The Human Order of African Redonptm in honor of his contribution to improved mutual ties.
He left Monrovia on Thursday afternoon for the island nation of Sao Tome and Principe off the coast of Central Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILLING TO HOLD TALKS WITH DPP SHOULD DPP IN POWER

TEXT.P: Tang Shubei, vice chairman of mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), said on Thursday that the mainland authorities are willing to hold talks with the Republic of China's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) once the opposition party takes up the reins of power, according to a high-ranking DPP official who is currently visiting Beijing.

Yin Wang-chin, director of the DPP's China Affairs Department and a member of a delegation headed by Lee Ching-ping, deputy secretary-general of ARATS counterpart, the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said that Tang made the remarks while meeting with the delegation.

Yin said that during the meeting, they exchanged views on issues surrounding the name and form of future cross-strait talks. According to Yin, his proposal that cross-strait talks could be conducted in the name of a "cross-strait forum" was echoed by Tang.

The "cross-strait forum," a model reached at Taiwan's National Development Conference in December 1996, would provide an occasion for representatives from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to exchange views on a comprehensive range of issues, without preconceived stances on those issues. The representatives would attend the forum in their private capacities.

All the participants at the meeting agreed that before there can be a resumption of cross-strait talks, unilaterally suspended by mainland China in the summer of 1995, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should strengthen other channels of communication and dialogue.

When Tang said that cross-strait talks should be conducted under the "one China" principle, Yin replied firmly that the DPP will not accept this, stressing that the talks should be resumed under the framework set by the "Koo-Wang" talks which took place in Singapore in 1993.

The delegation, composed of law scholars from the three major parties in Taiwan -- the ruling Kuomintang, the DPP and the New Party, arrived in Beijing on Monday for a week-long visit at the invitation of the mainland's "National Taiwan Research Institute."
The visit is being seen as an important step forward in enhancing the mutual understanding of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION ON 12-INCH WAFER PLANT TO KICK OFF IN 2ND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Construction on Taiwan's first 12-inch silicon wafer plant will kick off in the second quarter of this year, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) announced on Friday.
The world's largest memory chip foundry service said it will invest more than US$2 billion in building the new plant as part of its effort to maintain market niches.

TSMC Chairman Morris Chang said the plant, scheduled for completion by the end of next year, will make Taiwan the world's third country to have a 12-inch wafer production facility, after Japan and the United States.

According to Chang, TSMC has drawn an ambitious plan to build a total of five 12-inch wafer plants by 2006. The world's first such plant is expected to come on line either late this year or early next year in Japan.

"We'll continue to expand our production capacity and upgrade technology," Chang said, adding that he is convinced that the company will be able to catch up with industrial giants like Intel and IBM in semiconductor production technology and capacity by the year 2000.

Even though the global semiconductor market saw a slowdown last year, Chang said his company still managed to post gains in chip foundry services. TSMC earned NT$17.4 billion (US$527.27 million) on a turnover of NT$43.9 billion in 1997, making it the best performing local memory chip maker.

To sustain its competitiveness, TSMC has invested heavily in expanding production facilities in recent years. Its fourth and fifth wafer plants in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park became operational last year and construction on its sixth wafer plant has begun at the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan. The company now can produce 1.19 million units of 8-inch wafers annually.

TSMC officials said the global demand for semiconductors will continue to grow because of swift expansion of low-price computer markets around the world. The OEM (original equipment manufacturing) orders for specially designed integrated circuits (ICs) have also been growing steadily, accounting for about 10 percent of the world's total semiconductor production.
TSMC forecast that the global IC foundry service market will reach US$8 billion this year, with an annual growth rate of more than 23 percent.
