DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ENVOY LEAVES FOR VATICAN TO ATTEND ELEVATION CEREMONY

TEXT.P: Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to the president of the Republic of China, left for the Vatican Thursday evening to attend a ceremony on Saturday at the Holy See during which Archbishop Paul K.H. Shan of Kaohsiung will be elevated to the post of cardinal by Pope John Paul II.

Huang took with him a personal letter from President Lee Teng-hui to the pope, in which Lee sent greetings from the government and people of the ROC to the world's highest Roman Catholic spiritual leader.

Prior to his departure, Huang said he attaches great importance to his visit to Vatican City, the only state in Europe maintaining diplomatic relations with the ROC. He said Shan's appointment by the pope was seen by Taipei as indicative of the importance the Vatican attaches to Taiwan's political democratization and religious freedom, as well as to the long-lasting relations between the two sides.
Nearly 20 heads of states and government leaders from around the world will take part in the ceremony marking the elevation of 22 new cardinals.

Shan was appointed a cardinal by the Pope on Jan. 18, making him the first clergyman in Taiwan to hold that title since the death of Cardinal Yu Pin in 1978. Yu was raised to the cardinalship in Nanjing on the Chinese mainland before the ROC government relocated its seat to Taiwan in 1949.

Shan, 74, who is still active in his work of promoting catholicism, had requested retirement last year but was asked to stay on by the Holy See. He said his appointment is an affirmation of all 300,000 Catholics and church workers in Taiwan.

In the Roman Catholic hierarchy, cardinals hold a status second only to that of the pontiff. Collectively known as the College of Cardinals, they are authorized to elect a new pope when the position becomes vacant. However, several of those members have already passed their 80th birthday, making them ineligible to participate in the next papal election.

With Shan's appointment, there will be three cardinals from the world's Chinese communities, including Cardinal Hu Chen-chung in Hong Kong and Cardinal Kung Ping-mei in mainland China. Kung, however, will not be eligible to vote for a new pope in the event of John Paul Pope II's death or resignation because he is over 80 years of age.

The Vatican, as the spiritual center of the 1.1 billion Catholics worldwide, exercises an enormous religious, ethical and moral influence worldwide. Despite its small size, the Holy See maintains formal diplomatic relations with more than 170 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAY FREEZE FOR SINGAPORE MINISTERS, TOP CIVIL SERVANTS

TEXT.P: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced in Parliament on Thursday that salaries for government ministers and top civil servants will be frozen this year, to set the tone for the private sector in the wake of the Asian regional financial crisis.
"The tone should be restraint and caution. We must take the crisis seriously, but in our stride," he said.

In line with this, the government would freeze salaries for its Staff 1 officers, who include ministers and top civil servants. This means they would forgo an 8.1 percent rise that they would have been paid starting on July 1 this year.
Superscale G officers will face a 0.4 percent cut in pay, while salaries for other grades will be adjusted accordingly.
"In effect, salaries of all grades will be frozen or very slightly reduced this year," Lee said.
Promotions and normal increments will continue and if there is a National Wages Council (NWC) adjustment later this year, it will apply to all officers, including ministers, he said.
The situation will be reviewed next year when the government has the figures from the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) on last year's earnings, he added.

The deputy prime minister disclosed this in a speech in response to a motion by Non-Constituency MP J.B. Jeyaretnam for ministers and MPs to take a voluntary 25 percent pay cut to show that they identify with those who have been hit by the regional financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM WORRIED ABOUT CIVIL STRIFE AND DISORDER IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard is worried about possible civil strife and social disorder in Indonesia and has warned President Suharto that Jakarta must strictly adhere to the economic reforms demanded by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
"The Indonesian economy is taking a fearful hammering and there has been a huge reduction in the wealth of that country almost overnight," Howard said.
"I worry about the potential for internal trouble ... I worry about the potential for social disorder," he added.

In a detailed statement on financial aid to crisis-hit Indonesia, Australia's Federal Treasury warned that the aid package for Indonesia from the IMF and Australia was conditional on the implementation of tough IMF reforms.

But the reforms demanded by the IMF have sparked a number of riots across Indonesia in recent weeks. More trouble was expected overnight after an estimated 6,000 people stoned shops and other businesses Thursday in the latest outbreak of unrest over rising prices.
Australia has pledged about US$1 billion in financial aid to Indonesia under the IMF scheme.

The IMF has threatened to withdraw its US$43 billion in aid to Indonesia if Jakarta does not adhere to its requirements, including the cancellation of Indonesia's plan to peg the rupiah to the US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANBERRA, BEIJING AGREE ON ELIMINATING WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Australia and mainland China have agreed on the importance of eliminating weapons of mass destruction and the need for Iraq to comply with UN Security Council resolutions as well as the desirability of a peaceful resolution to the Gulf crisis.
The agreement was reached between Australia's Defense Minister Ian McLachlan and mainland Chinese Defense Minister Chi Haotian during a meeting in Canberra on Thursday.
Chi is visiting Australia, becoming the most senior military official to visit this country from the mainland since the June 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

In a press release Thursday, McLachlan said: "The visit of General Chi raises the defense relationship to a new level. It provided the opportunity to discuss a whole range of important issues which are the common concern of both Australia and China."
But defense sources said Chi disagreed with McLachlan on Australia's dispatch of 190 elite troops to Kuwait in support of the U.S.-led war against Iraq.

In reviewing bilateral defense relations, both ministers agreed that the three priorities for further developments between the two countries would be regular meetings between defense ministers and military commanders, enhanced dialogue on strategic developments and defense policies, and continued exchanges at middle and junior officer levels.

McLachlan has accepted an invitation to visit mainland China soon and other Australian military brasshats -- Gen. John Sanderson, the chief of the Australian Army, and Maj. Gen. Jim Connolly, commander of the Australian Theater, will also travel to the mainland later this year.
The statement also mentioned that an unnamed senior mainland Chinese officer will visit Australia for a second round of defense talks.

In a speech to about 100 students of the Australian College of Defense and Strategic Studies in Canberra on Tuesday, Chi said Beijing pursues a national defense policy which is defensive in nature and its defense construction neither is directed against nor poses a threat to any other country.

"The basic goals of China's defense policy are to consolidate national defense, resist foreign aggression, defend the nation's sovereignty over its territorial land, sea and airspace as well as its maritime rights and interests and safeguard national unity and security," he said. Chi has met Prime Minister John Howard, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and other senior Australian officials during his visit in Canberra and other cities.

But Chi's visit to Australia is marked by secret meetings with Australian leaders because he is worried about possible demonstrations by Chinese dissidents or Tibetans because he was involved in the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, analysts here said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE REVIEWING RESTRICTIONS ON USE OF LOCAL CURRENCY

TEXT.P: The Singapore government is reviewing some of the specific restrictions on the use of the Singapore dollar, although it will stick largely by its current policy of not encouraging its internationalization, Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in Parliament on Thursday.
"The basic rationale for not encouraging the internationalization of the Singapore dollar remains valid," he said.

"If the Singapore dollar is widely held and used internationally, our influence over the exchange rate would diminish, making the currency more vulnerable in a speculative attack even though our sound fundamentals make it unlikely that such attacks will eventually succeed."
Lee pointed out that a lack of market demand was the primary reason why the Singapore dollar had not become internationalized.

Indeed, he noted, if there had been market demand for Singapore dollars, the government's policy against the extension of credit in the local currency to nonresidents could not have prevented it from being internationalized.

"However, within this framework, we are reviewing some of the specific restrictions on the use of the Singapore dollar with a view to making adjustments that can help to further develop the financial sector particularly in the area of capital markets," he said.
Earlier, Lee said the government had not received any specific proposal to use the Singapore dollar as a common trading currency among the ASEAN countries, in response to a legislator's question.

He said that the Singapore dollar did not have the prerequisites for being used in that way, adding that the local currency did not qualify for the role as the size of the economy was too small and the amount of the currency in international circulation was not substantial.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN CITY HIT BY 3RD DAY OF RIOTING

TEXT.P: Rioting erupted again Thursday in Kendari, capital of Indonesia's Southeast Sulawesi Province, following similar unrest in that city over the previous two days.
Hundreds of people, enraged by soaring prices of basic commodities, went on the rampage, damaging and looting dozens of stores.

High school and university students, workers and local residents took part in the frenzy at shopping centers for about three hours in midday, forcing troops to fire repeated warning shots. Scores of protesters were later arrested.

Security personnel were later deployed to areas where protesters were gathered and dispersed them. At about the same time, three people representing residents met with Brig. Gen. R. Ampi Tanujiwa, the local army commander, explaining that people were frustrated because prices of some commodities increased almost hourly.
"We have tried to visit local legislators, but they refused to meet us," the Jakarta Post quoted one as saying.
Ampi said the military in the region was on full alert and would, if necessary, shoot rioters on the spot.

On Wednesday, hundreds of public transportation drivers in the North Sumatra town of Rantau Prapat, frustrated over soaring prices of spare automobile parts, ran amok damaging dozens of stores and houses.
The situation was back to normal Thursday with numerous security personnel patrolling the town, according to North Sumatra military spokesman Lt. Col. Agus Ramadhan.
"The situation is under control now," he said, without further elaboration on the violence in the Labuhan Ratu regency town, 400 kilometers southeast of Medan.

North Sumatra police spokesman Lt. Col. Amrin Karim, when contacted in Medan on Thursday, refused to disclose how many stores and houses had been damaged. Antara news agency said no one was arrested and no casualties were reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAST BY MAINLAND CHINESE DEMOCRACY ACTIVISTS GOES INTO 4TH DAY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: A fast initiated by exiled mainland Chinese democracy activists in front of the United Nations headquarters in New York headed into its fourth day on Thursday.

The demonstration, in which participants have taken turns fasting, is aimed at securing the release of Wang Tingjin and all other dissidents from mainland Chinese jails. The demonstrators are gaining increasing support.

The protest against the Beijing authorities started at noon on Feb. 16. Each day one activist stages a sit-in in front of the U.N. headquarters and fasts for 24 hours before being relieved by another colleague. The relay was taken up on Thursday by Wei Guomin, a senior activist who was one of the leaders of the democratic movement in Shanghai in 1979.

The fasting activities during the first three days were conducted by Wang Bingzhang, who slipped into mainland China in early February under a pseudonym only to be expelled after his arrest by mainland Chinese police; Zhang Lin, a dissident from Anhui Province; and Bao Gu, a member of the national committee of the mainland-based Human Rights Call.

Fu Shunqi, spokesman for the overseas preparatory section of the Chinese Justice Party, who acted as a coordinator for the relay fast activity, said that World Chinese United Entity representative Hua Xiazhi, who was originally scheduled to take up the fast on Friday, would be replaced by another activist as he has not felt well recently. Hua will join the protest next week.
According to the present schedule, a representative of the China Liberal Democratic Party will fast on Feb. 21 and democratic movement veteran Chen Jun will join the relay on Feb. 22.

In addition, overseas Chinese organizations such as the Institute of China Strategy, Alliance for Democratic China, China Democratic Front, and Alliance for a Democratic China, all are considering whether to assign representatives to join the demonstration.

In addition to urging Beijing to release Wang Tingjin and all other dissidents, Fu stressed, the activity is also aimed at convincing the United Nations Committee on Human Rights to pay more attention to mainland China's human rights conditions.

Wang, a teacher from China's Anhui Province was sentenced to two years in prison for his involvement in the Democracy Wall Movement in 1979. Following a meeting with Wang Bingzhan on Feb. 6, both men were seized in the city of Bengbu, Anhui Province. Mainland Chinese public security police have not given the reasons for Wang Tingjin's arrest, and visits by his relatives have been prohibited.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL PILOTS RECEIVE RETRAINING COURSES

TEXT.P: The pilots of China Airlines (CAL) A300-600F aircraft have started a series of retraining courses, while CAL crew members report a sharp increase in leave-taking, Yang Cheng, a spokesman for the airline, said on Friday.

Yang said that all 107 CAL pilots are taking the 24-hour retraining courses, including a four-hour flight simulation. Airbus Industrie, maker of the A300-600F, has sent officials to help conduct the courses, which are expected to be completed in three weeks.

The retraining directive followed the Civil Aeronautics Administration's decision to ground the CAL's fleet of nine A300-600F aircraft after the same type of plane crashed near CKS International Airport in Taoyuan County Monday night, killing all 196 persons onboard and six others on the ground after it slammed into a residential area.
Taiwan's worst-ever air disaster has also dealt a heavy blow to the morale of CAL employees.

Yang reported that the number of CAL crew members requesting leaves of absence has increased sharply to nearly 7 percent after the crash, compared with between 3 percent to 5 percent before the tragedy.
But he denied anyone has tendered his or her resignation after the CAL crash.
On behalf of CAL's 8,000 employees, Yang also said that they have the right to earn a living, and that the fate of the company should not be dictated by legislators.
He was responding to calls by some lawmakers for the dissolution of CAL because of a series of aviation accidents in recent years.

Meanwhile, Taoyuan District Court Chief Prosecutor Tien Ping-lin reported that his office has issued death certificates for 106 of the crash victims. But to avoid any mistakes, he said, it has ordered that those bodies which have already been identified not be cremated before the completion of DNA sampling, expected to be finished later this week.

As of Friday morning, 90 victims out of the 196 who perished in the air disaster have yet to be identified by their relatives. The National Dentist Association has sent a team to facilitate the identification process by means of dental records.
Meanwhile, the two "black box" data recorders from the ill-fated CAL A-300 Airbus were taken to Australia for analysis Thursday night.
A five-man team of CAL and Civil Aeronautics Administration officials as well as prosecutors, escorted the plane's cockpit voice recorder and its digital flight data recorder to Australia.
The team is scheduled to return to Taipei in a week after the analyses of the black boxes are completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINTAINING ECONOMIC STABILITY TOPS ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS: SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday unveiled his seven-point administrative guidelines for the upcoming year on opening day of the new Legislative Yuan session, giving top priority to maintaining the country's economic stability.

Siew said 1998 is a key year for the ROC in attempting to carry on the achievements the nation has made in the past and in paving a new course for the future, especially as global competitiveness is becoming increasingly keen.

At such a crucial juncture, Siew said, seven administrative guidelines must be implemented in the coming year so as to ensure that the ROC continues to enjoy political democracy, economic prosperity and social stability.
The seven guidelines are:
-- Maintaining economic soundness and seeking sustainable growth;
-- Bettering social order and rebuilding social morality;
-- Elevating quality of living and improving public security and environmental protection;
-- Realizing educational reform and accelerating cultural renaissance;
-- Promoting cross-strait dialogue and improving relations with mainland China;
-- Expanding pragmatic diplomacy and re-enforcing national security;
-- Accelerating governmental reform and consolidating relations between central and local administrative systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS DEMAND FOOD SECURITY, REFORM

TEXT.P: Around 2,000 University of Indonesia students marched around their campus in Depok, West Java on Thursday, demanding food security, employment and political reform.
The students also delivered a scathing attack on the New Order government which they claimed has failed to keep the people's mandate.
"The government should, in full awareness and peacefully, resign," the Jakarta Post quoted the students as saying in a statement signed by seven leaders.
After demanding the government step down, however, the students demanded it should provide people with basic commodities at affordable prices, and immediately address soaring unemployment.
"We demand political reform as a prerequisite for total reform." the students said.
The students also demanded a change of the national leadership and that the government stand accountable for the nation's current social, economic and political crises.

"The country is bankrupt because of the various mistakes committed by the government. Corruption is rampant, as is nepotism, while capital is concentrated only in a small group, (aggravated by) legal uncertainty and repression of people's political rights," the statement said.
They also called on fellow students across the country to press for the same reform agenda.
Student sources said the demonstration might well be followed by similar events at universities in several other towns.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP

TEXT.P: Share prices rose on the local stock exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the barometer of the market, ending at 9,037.48, up 58.97 from Thursday.
This was the first time the index broke the threshold of 9,000 in nearly five months.
Trading opened at the day's high at 9,095.37. The bourse experienced a low of 9,021.85.
Gainers outnumbered losers 292 to 139, with 58 stocks remaining unchanged.
A total of 3.88 billion shares changes hands on a market turnover of NT$247.36 billion (US$7.56 billion) in the three-hour session.

Six of the eight major categories of shares registered gains, with foodstuff stocks surging 2.0 percent, followed by 1. 7 percent gain of paper-making shares, 1.4 percent increase of cement stocks, 1.7 percent in electrical engineering stocks, 0.5 percent in plastics and chemical stocks, and 0.1 percent in construction stocks. Financial stocks remained unchanged while textile stocks fell 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW HOLDS OUT OLIVE BRANCH TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew held out an olive branch to mainland China again on Friday as he delivered an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan's first plenary session of the year.

Siew called for the holding of a second "Koo-Wang meeting" as early as possible in accordance with an agreement reached between Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) in May 1995.

"By convening the long-stalled Koo-Wang meeting, the two sides can discuss any topic that is helpful to the peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and to China's eventual reunification under freedom and democracy," Siew noted.

The premier pointed out that the Republic of China government has spared no effort to promote bilateral exchanges and consultations with a view to maintaining cross-strait harmony, peace and stability.

Noting that the National Unification Guidelines have been a basic tenet of Taiwan's mainland policy, Siew reaffirmed that promoting China's eventual reunification based on the principles of freedom, democracy and prosperity is the ROC's unswerving ultimate goal.

Siew went on to say that mainland China's political and economic development has been moving in a clearer, more definite direction since Hong Kong's handover last July and the smooth conclusion of the 15th national congress of the Chinese Communist Party in September 1997. Mainland authorities have also since shown a more positive attitude toward the resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

"All these developments have catapulted cross-strait relations into a new stage," Siew said, adding that, at this critical juncture, the two sides should treasure the results of their previous negotiations.

In 1992, the two sides reached a consensus that each could uphold its own definition of the "one China" principle. In April 1993, SEF Chairman C.F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan held their first meeting in Singapore, laying a framework for regular dialogue and consultations on issues of mutual concern. In May 1995, SEF and ARATS officials met to discuss technical and procedural issues related to the convening of a second Koo-Wang meeting. The two sides already agreed to begin negotiations on a broad range of topics during the 1995 meeting.

However, Beijing unilaterally suspended the institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue in mid-1995 to vent its anger at ROC President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States in June that year as it interpreted Lee's trip as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence.

Siew said Taiwan has consistently abided by all previous cross-strait agreements and points of consensus over the past two years and eight months. "We firmly believe that only when both sides can uphold their promises or agreements can they gradually forge mutual trust and lay a solid foundation for future bilateral talks on a broad range of issues, including political consultations," Siew claimed.

He stressed that Taiwan has consistently adopted a positive, active and optimistic attitude toward the development of cross-strait relations. "We have also incessantly explained our basic concepts and attitudes to mainland authorities via various channels and means," the premier said, adding that Taiwan has always kept its doors open for cross-strait dialogue and has repeatedly urged Beijing to resume long-stalled institutionalized consultations.
Siew said he is pleased to see that mainland authorities have shown willingness to resume dialogue with Taiwan in their recent talks. "We welcome this development."

So long as mainland China agrees to hold a second Koo-Wang meeting, Siew said, Taiwan is willing to discuss "in a gradual manner" any topic helpful to peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and to China's reunification under a democratic system, particularly certain practical issues that have arisen from cross-strait civilian exchanges.

The two sides previously agreed to jointly work out measures to resolve cross-strait fishing disputes and crack down on smuggling of firearms and other contraband goods across the Taiwan Strait. "As these issues have critical impact on rights and interests of people on both sides, we should give them top priority," Siew said.

He also reaffirmed Taiwan's sincerity and good will in promoting cross-strait engagement and rapprochement. "We'll work to reduce animosity through communications and replace confrontation with negotiations," he pledged, adding that Taiwan will also boost bilateral exchanges based on the principles of equality, reciprocity and mutual respect.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF, ARATS HEADS MET SECRETLY IN JANUARY: HK ECONOMIC JOURNAL
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: High level officials from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait met secretly in Tokyo in January and reached an agreement pertaining to principles of the cross-strait relationship, according to the Friday edition of the Hong Kong Economic Journal.

The journal identified the officials as Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), and his Taiwan counterpart, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

According to the journal, both sides agreed to accept that "one China" refers to neither the People's Republic of China nor the Republic of China, but called for a new status of cross-strait relations to be confirmed under the "one China" framework, with Taiwan regarded as an "independent" part of "one China."

The representatives of the two sides accepted the above agreement in principle, the journal reported, adding that they also agreed to have other officials discuss details of the understanding in Hong Kong or some other third location.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLASH ERUPTS AT SCREENING FOR BAYER LAND-LEASE CONTRACT

TEXT.P: A heated confrontation broke out on Friday at a joint meeting of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly to screen the land-lease contract which would allow German chemical giant Bayer to build a plant in central Taiwan's Taichung County.

A bitter war of words erupted after Assemblyman Wang Shih-hsun accused Tseng Tsai Mei-tzou, convenor of the Transportation Committee under the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, of receiving money from Bayer.
Tseng Tsai Mei-tzou, cursing Wang and pounding the table, angrily denied that she has received anything from the company.
Because of the bitter outburst, the joint meeting had to adjourn at noon, and the two groups ultimately decided to do their screening separately.
The Transportation Committee and an ad hoc team were originally set to present the results of the screening for discussion on the floor of assembly by Feb. 26.

Horst Mueck, chairman of Bayer Taiwan Co., and Chen Chia-chung, a spokesman for the company, both went to the provincial assembly in central Taiwan to express their concern about the screening process by the teams from the assembly.
They denied having delivered any form of payment to facilitate the establishment of the toluene di-isocyantate (TDI) plant in Taichung Harbor.
They denied having given money to secure the US$1.5 billion investment project. Nor have promises been made to allow any company to undertake the construction work, they said.
As Bayer has not even decided to build the plant in Taiwan, how could there be promises on construction work or payments, they asked.

Mueck said that Taiwan is a respectable nation, and that so far no one has asked for any benefits from Bayer in connection with the project. The company would rather construct the plant elsewhere than resort to bribery in order to secure the project, he added.

Mueck then greeted a group of onlookers who had gathered in support of the project. He also tried to approach a group which was opposed to the project, but had to give up the attempt as police kept the two camps separated.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS CALL FOR IMPROVEMENT OF CAL'S MANAGING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Legislators of the nation's three major political parties said Friday that the managing system of the China Airlines (CAL) must be improved in order to ensure its flight safety.

In the "Forum on National Affairs" of the Legislative Yuan, legislators of the ruling Kuomintang and the two major opposition parties, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the New Party (NP), made the same demand.

Leaders of the DPP and NP caucuses in the Legislative Yuan also said that Tsai Chao-yang, minister of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, should resign immediately to take responsibility for the tragic crash of a CAL A-300 Airbus Monday at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in suburban Taipei.

A total of 202 people were killed in the accident. Another CAL A-300 Airbus crashed at Nagoya Airport in Japan, killing 264 people, less than four years ago. There were 12 crashes of CAL jetliners in the past 20 years.
Two legislators of the ruling Kuomintang said however that it is inappropriate to demand the resignation of government officials before the cause of the air accident is found out.

Leaders of the DPP caucus also said the China Aviation Development Foundation, which controls 71 percent of the airlines' shares and is responsible for its operations and management, should be reorganized immediately. Some other legislators of the opposition party said that all of the airlines' shares should be sold to private investors as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew said Friday at the Legislative Yuan that it would be better to sell CAL shares after the airlines' operations and its share prices return to a normal level. CAL shares have dropped dramatically in the stock market since Tuesday because of the air accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ANTI-HIV DRUG TO BE TESTED, MARKETED IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Australia's first anti-HIV drug will be tested and marketed in mainland China because the developer here was unable to get sufficient funding for research from the Australian government.
John Majewski, chief executive officer of Narhex Operations, told reporters the anti-HIV drug his company developed will be given trials in mainland China and manufactured there.

Narhex Operations signed a letter of intent Thursday with mainland China's largest pharmaceutical maker -- the North China Pharmaceutical Company -- for the trial and sales of its anti-HIV drug in the mainland.

Thirty HIV-infected people will begin the three-month trial "as early as possible," Majewski said, adding that if it is successful, the two companies will form a joint venture to develop a commercial product for sale in mainland China and possibly elsewhere.
Majewski said he originally planned to have his anti-HIV drug tested in Australia and then manufactured here, but that a lack of funding for research prevented him from doing so.
"I have been very disappointed with the federal government's support. Several times we applied for grants, and it was felt that we wouldn't be successful, so we did not get the grants," he said.
This is the first time Western synthesized medicine for HIV-infected people will be given a trial on humans in mainland China, he said.
Narhex Operations is known for a range of skin treatments that use cross-linked elastin.

The drug to be tested in mainland China is called Nar DG-35 and was first developed in Australia. It was first subjected to trials in Melbourne in 1995, and new trials will be conducted in April in Australia, mainland China and possibly Brazil, Majewski said.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE'S TOTAL TRADE EXPANDED 3.2 PERCENT IN JAN.

TEXT.P: On a three-month moving average basis, Singapore's total trade at current prices expanded by 3.2 percent last month, while on a monthly basis, it dropped by 7.7 percent as compared to that in January of last year, the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) said Friday.
During the month, exports and imports grew by 5.5 percent and 1.1 percent respectively.

The total value of external trade last month amounted to S$28.48 billion (US$17.37 billion), lower than the total of S$34.29 billion registered in December 1997, according to figures released by the TDB.

Non-oil domestic exports increased by 7.8 percent to reach S$7.3 billion last month. Non-oil domestic exports to the United States and the European Union remained strong, expanding by 12.5 percent and 16.0 percent respectively on the back of strong economic growth in these two economies. Nevertheless, non-oil domestic exports to Malaysia and Japan declined by 5.7 percent and 7.6 percent respectively, the TDB said.
Domestic exports of oil continued to be weak last month, declining by 16.3 percent due mainly to lower shipments of oil to the Asian region, it said.

Non-oil reexports increased by 7.7 percent to reach S$6.1 billion last month, due mainly to increases in reexports of integrated circuits, computer parts and peripherals, disk drives, transistors, semiconductors, parts of aircraft, parts of VCRs, printers and unwrought gold.
It said Singapore's non-oil imports grew by 2.4 percent to reach a level of S$12.6 billion last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES PARAGUAYAN SENATE LEADERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China received a group of Paraguayan senators led by Carlos Alberto Gonzalez, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Friday at the Presidential Office.
During the visit, President Lee cordially welcomed the Paraguayan legislative leaders and expressed deep appreciation for Paraguayan support for the Republic of China.
Gonzalez expressed gratitude for the assistance Taiwan has given to his country. He also expressed the hope that cooperation between the two countries will be further strengthened.
Members of the group include Diogenes Martinez, vice chairman of the committee, and four senators.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 TRADE SURPLUS EXPECTED TO SLIDE

TEXT.P: The Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs estimated on Friday that Taiwan's trade surplus will slide to US$7.5 billion in 1998 as a result of a reduced world trade volume.

The department, citing data compiled by the Washington Economic Forecast Association, said the world trade volume is expected to fall by 7 percent, and that the world's annual economic growth rate will average at about 2.6 percent.

It forecast that major developed countries will post an average economic growth rate of 2.4 percent this year, while Pacific-rim countries, affected by last year's financial woes plaguing the Asian region, will see their average economic growth rate drop to 0.4 percent in 1998 from the 4.9 percent registered in 1997. It will take some Asian countries two years to recover from the current morass, the department added.

Despite the outbreak of a foot-and-mouth disease epidemic at hog farms island-wide and the resulting ban on Taiwan's pork exports last year, Taiwan's exports still increased by 5.3 percent for the whole of 1997, while imports grew by 11.8 percent as a result of a recovering domestic market, leaving Taiwan with a trade surplus of US$7.64 billion, down 43.7 percent from the previous year.

Meanwhile, private-sector consumption, boosted by the partial implementation of the five-day work week in the government sector, the mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities and an islandwide legislative election, will grow by 6.8 percent this year, the department predicted, adding that on the other hand, investment by the government in public construction projects will rise by 3.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW ORDERS FORMATION OF AVIATION SAFETY COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday he has ordered the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to set up a special commission to oversee aircraft safety and investigate flight accidents.

Siew made the remarks while reporting on Monday's crash of a China Airlines Airbus A300-600F jetliner at a Legislative Yuan plenary meeting. The crash resulted in the death of 202 people, including Central Bank of China Governor Sheu Yuan-dong, his wife and four other senior central bank officials.

The premier said the MOTC's Civil Aeronautics Administration is responsible for supervising operations of airline companies. "The ministry should set up a separate commission to inspect all commercial aircraft and investigate flight accidents in order to improve aviation safety controls.

Siew said he was saddened by the latest air disaster, asking the bereaved families of all crash victims to accept his condolences on the death of their loved ones. "We'll do our utmost to handle the aftermath to comfort the souls of the deceased," he pledged, adding that the government will also step up aviation safety controls to avoid similar accidents in future.

Siew told the lawmakers that the Executive Yuan has formed a special task force to organize a memorial service for the deceased and to study measures to help their bereaved families resolve difficulties they may face in future daily lives and education.

The premier further said the government will push China Airlines (CAL), the Republic of China's flagship carrier, to overhaul its leadership and management team, hiring outstanding civil aviation managers to draft and implement a comprehensive restructuing plan.

Siew expressed his hope that the carrier's largest shareholder, the China Aviation Development Foundation which controls 70 percent of CAl' stake, will use its funds to help upgrade flight safety controls of all of Taiwan's commercial carriers.

"We also expect the foundation to gradually sell its CAL stock holdings to qualified private investors after the carrier's business returns to normal," Siew said. "We believe privatization will be the best way to improve CAL's corporate image and upgrade its management and competitiveness."

The premier went on to say that the country should not feel complacent about the first-grade rating given by the US Federal Aviation Administration last year to Taiwan's flight safety control measures. "We should make continued efforts to improve civil aviation safety and cannot allow any flight accidents to happen again."
Siew said the Cabinet has directed the MOTC to adopt several measures to ensure flight safety:
-- Encouraging local carriers to use larger planes to replace smaller ones to improve traffic to remote areas or offshore islands;

-- Demanding the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) to conduct across-the-board inspection of flight safety control systems at all commercial carriers, with China Airlines as the first target; to require all carriers to faithfully implement a cockpit crew and resources management system; and to upgrade professionalism of all CAA inspectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW: U.S. DID NOT PRESS TAIWAN TO TALK WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The United States government did not pressure Taiwan to hold talks with communist China, Premier Vincent Siew said Friday at the Legislative Yuan.

Siew made the remark in reply to a question by Legislator Parris H. Chang of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party. Siew made an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan Friday, the first day of the current legislative session, and answered questions.

Siew said the U.S. government did not express hope for the talks either. What the American government is concerned about are "the relations between the U.S. government and us, and the peace and stability in this region," he added.
He said however that some American scholars doing researches on mainland China and the Asian Pacific region have expressed hope for early talks between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW: U.S. DID NOT PRESS TAIWAN TO TALK WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The United States government did not pressure Taiwan to hold talks with communist China, Premier Vincent Siew said Friday at the Legislative Yuan.

Siew made the remark in reply to a question by Legislator Parris H. Chang of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party. Siew made an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan Friday, the first day of the current legislative session, and answered questions.

Siew said the U.S. government did not express hope for the talks either. What the American government is concerned about are "the relations between the U.S. government and us, and the peace and stability in this region," he added.
He said however that some American scholars doing researches on mainland China and the Asian Pacific region have expressed hope for early talks between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE POLICY TO RESTRICT MIGRANTS' BENEFITS RECEIVES BLOW

TEXT.P: Australia's new immigration policy to prevent migrants from claiming welfare benefits for two years after their arrival received a severe blow when two couples successfully challenged the waiting period, the Australian Department of Immigration said.
The department identified the first couple as from Russia and the second one as from Bangladesh.

Both couples were given permanent Australian residency as skilled migrants but became poverty-stricken due to circumstances beyond their control. They appealed to the Welfare Rights centers in Sydney and Adelaide for financial help and were awarded welfare benefits of A$290 (US$192) per fortnight.

Australian diplomatic offices across eastern Europe and Asia -- including offices in Poland, Russia, Sri Lanka, India, Thailand and Bangladesh -- have been criticized for allegedly failing to properly address migrant concerns and for their poor language skills in communicating with migrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SMES TO SEEK PARTNERSHIPS WITH GERMAN COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: A group of some 30 company executives with Taiwan-based small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will visit Hamburg, Germany in late May to seek partnerships with their German counterparts, according to sources at the Taipei Trade Office in Hamburg.

The trade mission, organized by Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council, will attend a seminar on May 28 in Hamburg on business partnerships. Members of the group are also scheduled to hold individual business discussions with German firms during their visit.

SMEs play important roles in both Taiwan and Germany. In recent years, the business sectors in both places have endeavored to promote more cooperation in joint ventures and technology transfers among SMEs.
A group of German entrepreneurs visited Taiwan in November 1997 and was impressed by the flexibility and highly competitive performance of the island's SMEs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO SEND MISSION TO US TO STUDY CWC IMPACT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will send a delegation of trade officials and chemical experts to the United States in late March to seek feasible measures to cope with the possible impact on Taiwan's chemical industry of the United Nations-initiated Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC).

The convention, which regulates global trade in some chemical products that could be used to produce chemical weapons, already took effect on April 29, 1997. A total of 166 countries around the world have signed the convention aimed at maintaining world peace.
As the Republic of China has been shut out of the UN since 1971, it's not easy for the ROC to become a CWC signatory.
According to the convention, non-signatory countries or those who fail to abide by its provisions will be subject to trade sanctions.
Taiwan is the world's 11th largest chemical products manufacturing country. Its trade in CWC-regulated chemical products could be adversely affected in the future.

According to MOEA tallies, Taiwan's pesticide, dyeing, pharmaceutical industries and even electric bulb and leatherware industries may be hit hardest. The annual production of these products amounts to NT$15 million (US$454,546).

CWC-regulated products account for a large share of annual Taiwan-US chemical trade. The MOEA delegation will discuss with relevant American officials on how to regulate bilateral trade in those products in accordance with the UN convention in the future.
MOEA officials said the ministry has set up a 16-member task force to mull strategy to address the convention's possible adverse impact and to control the flow of CWC-regulated chemical products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR WANTS TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Friday that he would like to serve as a pioneer for an eventual visit to mainland China by President Lee Teng-hui.

"How can Lee, as the head of state, pay a trip to the mainland if a local government head like me is barred from going there?" asked Chen at a Taipei seminar co-sponsored by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the National Policy Research Institute. The mayor has maintained high approval ratings in public polls and is widely considered to be the DPP's best choice to challenge the presidency in the 2000 election.
President Lee declared in his inaugural speech in May, 1996 that he would like to make a "journey of peace" to the mainland as part of the Republic of China's efforts to promote China's unification.

Chen said he is pessimistic about the prospects for a mainland China visit by Lee before cross-strait tension is substantially eased. "I would therefore like to take the initiative by visiting the mainland first to pave the way for Lee's trip there," he announced.
Vigorously promoting the DPP's policy of seeking Taiwan independence, Chen said the opposition has not changed its stance regarding the pursuit of independence for the island.

The outspoken mayor pointed out that during his party's three-day debate on its policy towards mainland China on Feb. 13-15, none of the delegates from any of the major DPP factions questioned the credibility of the "Taiwan independence" article in its party platform.
"This demonstrates that the DPP maintains the pursuit of Taiwan independence as its top guideline in policy towards the other side of the Taiwan Strait," Chen said.
He said that the so-called "Taiwan issue" is an international issue rather than "an issue of the Taiwan Strait" as defined by Vice President Lien Chan at a Thursday session of the same seminar.
However, Chen was also critical of the consensus reached by his comrades at the DPP policy debate, which calls for "comprehensive negotiations" between Taiwan and the mainland.

"How can there be comprehensive talks between the two sides before deeper and wider contacts are forged?" Chen asked. He instead suggested a step-by-step approach of "contacts, dialogue and negotiations" in handling such exchanges.

He said he would like to invite the mayors of Beijing and Shanghai to the World Capitals' Forum to be held in Taipei in May if the mainland authorities are interested in the event. More than 50 capital city mayors from all over the world are expected to take part in the forum, which will be hosted by Taipei for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG FUND MANGERS UPBEAT ABOUT TAIWAN BOURSE
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The German business weekly "Wirtschaftswoche" (Economic Weekly) has reported in its latest issue that Hong Kong-based fund managers are upbeat about the outlook of the Taiwan bourse.
The magazine said that the financial markets of Shanghai\Shenzhen, Hong Kong and Taipei are the three major playgrounds of German China funds.

Citing three China funds -- Atlas Chine, ABN China Equity Fund and TGS China Fund -- as examples, the weekly said that their investments in Hong Kong usually made up 65 percent of their total investments in ethnic Chinese areas worldwide, followed by their investments in Shanghai\Shenzhen. The Taiwan bourse accounted for about 10 percent of their total investments.

However, the recent steep plunge in the prices of real estate and stock in Hong Kong and Shanghai have made Taiwan a relatively safe haven for investment, which has forced fund managers to review their portfolios, the report said.
Among the 1,030 mutual funds listed in Germany, China-related funds posted the best showing over the last week, with Atlas China, ABN China Equity Fund and TGS China Fund ranked among the top-five.

At the bottom of the list were funds exclusively for investment in non-Chinese areas of Asia, with Dresdner Th. Korea, GT Korean Growth, Fidelity Thailand, Fidelity Korea and Barings Korea showing the poorest performances.

DOC.HEADLINE: US COMMERCE SECRETARY STRESSES US COMMITMENT TO ASIA

TEXT.P: US Secretary of Commerce William Daley stressed here on Friday that the United States has a strong and long-standing commitment to Asia as a whole.

In his address to the American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore, Daley said that his meetings with government and business leaders in Japan, South Korea and Singapore during his current trip have provided enormous insight into the region's economic situation.
"I come away convinced that this crisis is a defining moment for Southeast Asia, perhaps the most important period in ASEAN's economic 30-year history," he said.
The decisions made now, in the face of this crisis regarding economic reform and trade liberalization, "will determine the ASEAN economy for the next thirty years," he added.
Daley said he was "proud to say American firms are in the region for the long haul." This continued US commercial engagement is important for not only ASEAN but also the United States, he stressed.

Noting that he was impressed by the plans of many US companies, he pointed out that they not only want to continue their operations in the region but to expand them. "This reflects their confidence that the region will rebound -- and it will create exports and jobs in the United States, as well," he said.

The countries in Southeast Asia have great underlying strengths, he noted, citing their high savings rates, firm commitments to education and strong work ethic. With a sustained commitment to the necessary reforms, they are well-positioned to re-establish strong economic growth and sound currencies, he added.
US companies will be an integral part of the resurgent growth in Southeast Asia, Daley asserted.

He also announced Friday that US ambassadors and senior commercial officers in ASEAN have developed a commercial strategy initiative intended to energize US government attention toward business opportunities in the ASEAN region during this time of significant economic change.

"We will identify and help US businesses to take advantage of new export and investment opportunities -- despite current economic conditions -- because we believe in this market's long-term potential," he said.

Daley, who flew into Singapore Thursday morning from Seoul for a two-day visit, called on Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew Friday afternoon after holding a meeting with Trade and Industry Minister Lee Yock Suan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PRESIDENT OFFERS CONDOLENCES OVER CAL AIR DISASTER

TEXT.P: Daryl Johnson, director-general of the Taipei office of the Washington-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), on Friday conveyed US President Bill Clinton's condolences over the recent air crash of Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) flight 676 to ROC President Lee Teng-hui.

In addition to expressing sorrow and commiseration to the families of the 202 victims, Johnson, on behalf of Clinton, also thanked Lee for the assistance and handling of the aftermath of the tragedy by the relevant Taiwan authorities, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and CAL.
For his part, Lee voiced his deep regret and sorrow for the accident, and asked Johnson to convey his appreciation for Clinton's concern over the tragedy.
The crash of the CAL Airbus A300-600 on Monday at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan killed all 196 people on board and six on the ground.
Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Y.D. Sheu, five other ranking CBC officials, and five American passengers were among the dead.

Meanwhile, condolences from a number of foreign heads of state, governments and opinion leaders from all over the world are still pouring into the ROC Foreign Ministry in Taipei in the wake of the country's worst-ever air disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: 114 VICTIMS OF CAL FLIGHT 676 IDENTIFIED

TEXT.P: Twelve of the victims of the ill-fated China Airlines (CAL) flight 676 which crashed on Monday have now been identified by DNA testing, bringing the total number of identified bodies to 114 out of 202, an official with the Ministry of the Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Friday.

Vice Transport Minister Chen Shih-chi said that since it takes 14 hours to complete DNA analysis of a single blood sample, three to five more days are needed to complete DNA matching of the blood samples taken from relatives and the victims' remains.

A total of 500 blood samples have been collected, including over 100 from direct family members -- parents or children -- of the victims. DNA testing is the last hope for these families to identify the remains of their loved ones.
However, in some cases where all the members of a family died in the crash, no blood samples from direct relatives were available, so the identification process will be longer.

The remains of the six foreigners -- five Americans and an Indonesian -- who were passengers on the ill-fated airplane en route to Taipei from the resort island of Bali, have not yet been identified, Chen added.

He said that a number of relatives have identified sets of remains by appearance or through other evidence, such as dental records, which means the possibility of wrong identification exists. For this reason, Chen asked those relatives who have claimed the remains of their loved ones not to cremate the bodies until the identification process is complete.

Early on Friday morning, eight large refrigerated shipping containers were taken to the Panchiao morgue in Taipei County, where the remains of the victims of Taiwan's worst-ever air disaster are being kept. As no more room is available in the freezer of the Panchiao morgue, the containers will serve as emergency cold storage units.

For days, the remains of the unidentified victims, covered in golden-yellow sheets, have been kept in thin caskets and left lying on the wet and sometimes rain-flooded ground. By 4:00 a.m., the 121 caskets with remains were loaded into six of the containers, while another 56 caskets containing only charred remnants were placed in the other two.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY REBUTS US NEWSPAPER REPORT ON LEE'S 1995 VISIT

TEXT.P: The Foreign Ministry of the Republic of China on Friday rebutted a recent report by the Los Angeles Times, saying that the ROC enjoys widespread support in the US Congress and that ROC President Lee Teng-hui's historic US visit in 1995 was not the result of a financial deal.

Ministry spokesman Roy Wu stressed that the ROC has strong support from a majority of both Republican and Democratic Congressmen and that Lee's 1995 visit was favorably backed by the US Congress and leading media.

Denouncing the Wednesday report by the Los Angeles Times as "false," Wu said the nonpartisan support enjoyed by the ROC in the US Congress is reflected in its voting patterns, speeches and resolution records at both the Senate and the House of Representatives.
Wu also categorically denied the newspaper's report that the ROC government used an "inappropriate approach" to win US popular support for Lee's trip.

He said the House passed a unanimous resolution at the time, welcoming Lee's visit to the US by a vote of 396 to zero, while the Senate approved a similar resolution by a vote of 97 to one. Major US newspapers such as the Washington Post and the New York Times also printed editorials voicing support for Lee's visit, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BRAZILIAN REPRESENTATIVE TO TAIPEI ASSUMES POST

TEXT.P: Brazil's new representative to the Republic of China, Paulo Antonio Pereira Pinto, arrived in Taipei on Wednesday and took over from his predecessor on Thursday.

Pinto, 50, is a professional diplomat who has been stationed in Asia and Africa. Between 1982 and 1985, he was stationed at the Brazilian embassy in Beijing, where he was responsible for promoting trade ties between his country and mainland China.
Before being given his new assignment, Pinto served at the Brazil Presidential Office, where he was in charge of strategic cooperation affairs involving mainland China.

Pinto replaces former Brazilian representative Jose Soares, who took up the position in July, 1995. Soares' mother died a few days ago and her funeral was held on Friday, attended by newly appointed ROC representative to Brazil Ho Ping-fu. Ho will go to Brazil to assume his new post in mid March.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER REGRETS POLITICIZING OF TAIWAN INVESTMENT PROJECT
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for Bayer's German headquarters on Friday refused to comment on the raucous debate in a Taiwan local legislature over the firm's multi-billion investment project in Taiwan, but said he regrets that the whole issue has been politicized.

The spokesman told CNA in a telephone interview from Dormagen, western Germany, that he didn't know the project pitted supporters against opponents in a fierce confrontation outside the Taiwan Provincial Assembly on Friday morning, when a land-lease contract for the project was being debated by a committee of the assembly.

However, he had heard about a similar scuffle between the opponents and supporters which took place on Monday, when an ad hoc panel of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly decided to postpone any decision on the contract. The fistfight, caught by TV cameras, was broadcast worldwide.

Recounting the two Taiwan fact-finding delegations which visited Bayer headquarters recently to see the measures the company has taken to ensure plant safety, the spokesman said that although Bayer has done its best to convince Taiwan residents that its proposed chemical plant in Taiwan is technically safe, the controversy surrounding the issue has been politicized.

A Bayer executive for East Asia said his firm has dropped plans to launch a publicity campaign for its project at Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan, and will instead resign the fate of the project to the authorities and people of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Liu Yu-shan, a vice chairman of Taiwan's Council for Economic Planning and Development, who headed a fact-finding delegation to Bayer's German headquarters earlier this month, said on Friday in Taipei that his council will organize a televised public hearing on the issue and conduct opinion polls as the Taiwan Provincial Assembly has suggested.
The results of the polls will be used as an important reference for the assembly members when they vote to veto or endorse the project on Feb. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DENIES MEETING BETWEEN MAC, ARATS HEADS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday denied that its chairman, Chang King-yuh, met secretly with Beijing's point man in dealing with Taiwan in January.

In a statement, the MAC said that Chang went to Tokyo in January to attend an academic seminar which was scheduled about six months ago and coincided by chance with a trip to Japan by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), the mainland China body charged with dealing with affairs related to Taiwan.
They both stayed in the same Tokyo hotel at the same time, but engaged in completely unrelated activities.

The Hong Kong-based Chinese-language daily the "Economic Journal" carried an unsubstantiated report on Friday that Chang met with Wang secretly on that occasion and that an understanding on bilateral issues was worked out.

The newspaper claimed that the main point of their alleged agreement includes the fact that the "one China" policy, which both sides believe should be the cornerstone of bilateral ties and a principle to which Taipei and Beijing both claim to be committed, should refer neither to the People's Republic of China nor the Republic of China.

On his return from Tokyo on Jan. 12, Chang denied that he had met with Wang, but didn't explain why he called a press conference at the same hotel and at about the same time as Wang met the Japanese press.
The MAC said in its statement that it has asked the Hong Kong Economic Journal to correct its false report.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, TAIWAN REACH AGREEMENT ON AGRICULTURAL CONCESSIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo & Herman Pan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan negotiators concluded bilateral trade consultations with their counterparts from the United States on Friday, agreeing to make major concessions on Taiwan's market-opening to US agricultural exports.

The agreement marked a big step forward towards Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), said Taipei officials who participated in the marathon bilateral negotiations which began in Washington, D.C. on Feb. 9.

On one of the major sticking points, rice, Taiwan agreed to follow the current Japanese model for rice imports under the WTO framework, promising to open its rice market to US imports upon WTO accession, with an import quota equivalent to 6.4 percent of its total rice consumption between 1990 and 1992.

If Taiwan's entry to the WTO is postponed until next year, this quota will increase to 7.2 percent of the island's 1990-92 rice consumption, gradually increasing to 8 percent in 2000, a total of about 144,720 metric tons, according to the agreement.

A portion of this quota will be allocated to the private sector trade in rice, increasing from 21 percent to 35 percent in 2000 under a "mark-up" system. The rest of the rice quota will be imported by central authorities with conditions that will facilitate its release for table use in Taiwan.
Taiwan originally offered an import quota of 4 percent of its 1990-1992 rice consumption, with the quota increasing by 0.8 percent annually to 8 percent in five years.

With regard to the pork market, Taiwan will lift its remaining bans on selected pork cuts and variety meats immediately. Taiwan has agreed to an immediate market opening of 5,000 tons of these currently-banned pork cuts and 7,500 tons for pork variety meats from the United States.
Taiwan agreed to fully open its market for these pork products and will establish a tariff rate quota (TRQ) system that will gradually increase access until the market is completely open by 2005.

Upon accession, Taiwan will fully open its market to many banned pork cuts and establish a TRQ for the remaining restricted pork cuts, bellies, and spare ribs and for pork variety meats. The quota for pork bellies will be 6,610 tons, at 15 percent tariff, increasing to 15,400 tons at 12.5 percent tariff in 2004, before the market is completely opened on Jan. 1, 2005. The quota for pork variety meats will be 10,000 tons at 25 percent tariff, increasing to 27,500 tons at 15 percent tariff in 2004.
In the poultry market, Taiwan agreed to an immediate market opening of 10,000 tons for US chicken meat at a tariff rate of 25 percent.

Upon accession, Taiwan will establish a TRQ for chicken meat of 19,163 tons, growing to 45,990 tons by 2004 before the market is completely opened on Jan. 1, 2005. The in-quota tariff rate for chicken meat will be 25 percent upon accession, falling to 20 percent by 2004.

On beef and beef variety meats, Taiwan will provide immediate market opening of 5,000 tons for US beef variety meats annually at current tariff rates, with the unused amounts in any year to be carried over to the next year.

In addition, Taiwan agreed to completely open its market to imports of beef variety meats upon accession at a tariff rate of 25 percent. Taiwan also has agreed to reduce the specific tariff for beef from current rates to the equivalent of 14 US cents/pound (NT$10/kilogram) by 2005. Current rates are NT$22.1/kilogram for special quality beef and NT$30/kilogram for all other beef.

During the talks on agricultural products, Taiwan agreed to complete tariff-cut measures by 2002, but also won approval from the US side on delayed schedules for 74 agricultural products until 2004, the officials said.
As compensation, Taiwan also agreed to lower import tariffs on 33 other agricultural items before or by 2000, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER CONCLUDES VISIT TO SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE
DOC.DATELINE: Sao Tome, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Yen Ling-ju & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Friday concluded a one-day visit to this Central African island state and left for the landlocked West African nation of Burkina Faso.
Speaking to an accompanying group of Taipei-based reporters before leaving Sao Tome, Hu hailed his visit here as a success.

The foreign minister said it was a great pleasure for him to have met with President Miguel A.C.L. Trovoada and Prime Minister Raul W. Braganca Neto. The meetings have deepened his understanding of the tiny state's situations and needs, he said.

Noting that Sao Tome and Taiwan are similar with respect to their deficiency of natural resources, Hu said Taiwan would like to share its development experience over the last four decades with Sao Tome.

Sao Tome switched diplomatic recognition from Beijing to Taipei in May, 1997. Before closing its embassy in Sao Tome in August, an angry Beijing asked the island state to pay back loans of US$17.2 million within three months, a demand Sao Tome has not been able to meet until now.
Sao Tome is the fifth leg of Hu's six-state African trip which has already brought him to Chad, Guinea-Bissau, The Gambia, and Liberia, and will end on Sunday in Burkina Faso.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK ECONOMIC JOURNAL PUBLISHES MAC CLARIFICATION LETTER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong Economic Journal in its Saturday edition published a letter of clarification by Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Republic of China's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), in which he denied a report carried in Friday's edition of the journal that he met secretly with Wang Daohan, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) chairman, at a Tokyo hotel in January.

Chang said that he was in Tokyo to attend an international meeting sponsored by the Institute of World Peace, and that while Wang was staying at the same hotel at the same time, he was engaged in entirely different activities and they did not meet with each other at all.

The Hong Kong-based economic daily carried an unsubstantiated report on Friday that Chang met with Wang secretly on that occasion and that they reached an agreement pertaining to the principles of the cross-strait relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, US REACH WTO AGREEMENT ON OPENING SERVICE SECTOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the United States on Friday concluded talks in Washington, D.C. on the ROC's terms for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

In the 17th and final round of bilateral WTO talks, both sides reached agreement on opening Taiwan's market to a number of service industries after its accession to the WTO, including professional services (architects, accountants, engineers, lawyers), audiovisual services, express delivery services, advertising, computer services, construction, wholesale and retail distribution, financing, and environmental services.

In the financial services sector -- banking, insurance and securities -- Taiwan will guarantee full market access and national treatment for US companies. With these commitments, US banks, insurance companies, and mutual funds will have greater freedom of access to consumers in Taiwan, and greater freedom of choice in conducting their commercial operations.
US banks will now be able to provide new services to Taiwan depositors, while US insurance companies will have more leeway to write policies, extend new coverage and establish operations in Taiwan.
Taiwan's state-owned Chunghwa Telecom Company has also agreed to lower interconnection fees significantly by Oct. 1, 1998, from about US$0.06 per minute to US$0.035 per minute.
The rate will be no higher than rates charged in major developed countries (currently less than US$0.02) after Chunghwa is privatized in 2001, according to the agreement.
Taiwan has also agreed for the first time that US and other foreign companies can hold a controlling interest of up to 60 percent in Taiwan's telecom companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US INITIAL BILATERAL WTO ACCORD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan took a historic step forward with its bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday by concluding difficult and lengthy negotiations with its largest trade partner, the United States, on its WTO entry terms.

Following 17 rounds of intensive talks spanning more than five years, Taiwan and American negotiators have finally come to terms on all the thorny WTO-related issues, with Taiwan agreeing to lower trade barriers and offer greater market access to US agricultural products, services, industrial goods, wine and tobacco.

Stephen Chen, de facto ROC ambassador to the US, and American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush, initialed a comprehensive WTO agreement on behalf of the two governments at the conclusion of the marathon talks. Bush is the top US liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky also attended the ceremony as witnesses to the historic occasion. Scores of ROC officials and their counterparts from the US departments of state, agriculture, treasury and transportation took part in the final two-week round of talks in Washington, D.C.
Both Barshefsky and US Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman hailed the newly signed agreement as a major victory for American producers. Taiwan is America's seventh-largest trading partner.
"This comprehensive agreement will dramatically open Taiwan's markets to US agricultural products, services and industrial goods," Barshefsky told reporters.

Glickman hailed the ground-breaking accord as a boon for American agriculture, saying it will open up new export opportunities for a wide range of farm and food products. "Taiwan, which is already one of our largest export markets, has agreed to provide new access for US poultry, pork and beef variety meats," he said.

ROC Minister Wang said he is pleased to see a smooth conclusion of the WTO talks with the US. In the process, Wang said, the American negotiators have made many tough demands, but "through the concerted efforts of our negotiators, we have managed to forge certain very favorable terms," he noted.

Teng Chen-chung, economic division chief at the ROC representative office in the US, said the conclusion of the talks with the US is absolutely a plus to Taiwan's overall national interests and marks a new milestone in bilateral trade and economic relations.

Teng said both sides have made concessions in order to work out a "win-win" agreement for both sides. For instance, the US originally demanded that Taiwan adopt a single tariff rate for all pork products and that the rate be lowered to 7.5 percent over a six-year period. As a result of the difficult negotiations, Teng said, the US finally agreed to the Taiwan-proposed tariff rate quota (TRQ) system that will gradually increase access until the market is completely open by 2005.

ROC Representative to the ROC Stephen Chen said the new agreement will benefit both countries. "For the ROC, it marks a giant step forward towards its goal of entering the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body," he noted.

AIT Chairman Bush said the pact is probably the most important agreement ever signed by Taiwan and the US in recent years. "It signifies that the deep and mutually beneficial relationship between the people of the United States and the people of Taiwan is strong and growing," he explained.
Wang left for home shortly after the signing of the agreement, which is scheduled to take effect on March 10 after the two sides complete certain domestic formalities.

Wang said prior to his departure that Taiwan will hold separate WTO talks with Switzerland and the 15-member European Union next week. They are the two remaining trade partners which have yet to finalize bilateral trade consultations with Taiwan.
"We hope to conclude all bilateral talks before the end of March in order to speed up our accession to the WTO," Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PORK PRODUCERS CALL WTO ACCORD A 'HOME RUN'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo & Herman Pan)

TEXT.P: The president of the US National Pork Producers Council, Jerry King, called the agreement reached Friday between Taiwan and US negotiators on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) a "home run" for US pork producers.

"Our trade negotiators have hit a home run for us in Taiwan," King said upon learning that Taiwan has agreed to lift its ban on the import of US pork parts and set a quota of 12,500 tons of bellies, cuts and variety meats worth US$18 million.

Taiwan has also agreed to fully open its pork market for these US pork products and will establish a tariff rate quota system that will gradually increase access until the market is completely open by 2005.
In his written statement, King said the latest agreement with Taiwan will have an immediate and direct impact on American hog farmers, who have been suffering through a prolonged price slump.

According to a formal statement released by the office of the US Trade Representative in the wake of the bilateral consultations concerning Taiwan's accession to the WTO, Taiwan's market opening for pork products provides immediate market opportunities for US farmers of almost US$18 million. In the first year after accession, Taiwan's pork import opportunities will increase by an additional US$22.5 million.

According to the release, the agreement on rice provides US farmers with a new market opportunity worth almost US$60 million in the first year of implementation. Private traders will have direct access to an increasingly large share of the quota (through a license allocation system), which will allow US exporters to establish long-standing relationships to promote the sale of US labeled rice in Taiwan.

For US poultry farmers, the immediate market opening will provide sales opportunities for them of almost US$10 million annually. Trade in the first year of the tariff rate quota will reach US$18 million, increasing to about US$43 million in 2004.

For US beef producers, the immediate market access will provide them market opportunities worth US$8.3 million. As Taiwan is currently the seventh largest foreign market for US beef exports, the lower tariffs should make US beef even more price competitive on the island, the statement indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA SAID TO VISIT TAIWAN AGAIN

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, will make a second visit to Taiwan in mid-August to preach Tibetan Buddhism, reliable Tibetan sources said here on Saturday.
The sources said that as before, the Dalai Lama will come at the invitation of the Chinese Buddhist Association here.
To avoid unnecessary troubles during his 10-day stay on the island, the Dalai Lama's visit will not include official or political activities.
The exiled Tibetan spiritual leader is also planning to preach in the United States in March and hold a historic meeting with Taiwan's respected Buddhist Master Shih Sheng Yen in New York.
The Dalai Lama made his first visit to Taiwan in March 1997. His message and personal charisma attracted large crowds islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS RELEASE OF CONTROLLING STAKE IN CAL

TEXT.P: In an attempt to reorganize the disaster-stricken national carrier, China Airlines (CAL), after it lost a passenger plane in a crash near Taipei on Monday, Premier Vincent Siew told the government-financed China Aviation Development Fund (CADF) to reduce its stake in CAL to less than 51 percent.

In a meeting with CADF Chairman Hsu Li-teh and Tsay Jaw-yang, head of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), Siew asked the two to cooperate with each other to settle the issues related to the air crash and to reorganize the airline.
Siew said the CADF should comply with the orders of the government, including the MOTC, or the CADF's board would be dismissed en masse.
Although the CADF is technically a private group, its board members are government appointed.
Siew also told the fund to release its CAL stocks until it owns less than a controlling stake in the carrier.

The CADF, which owns the most shares in CAL, and the MOTC have blamed each other publicly after the crash. The MOTC lambasted the CADF for resisting its order to reorganize, while the CADF shot back that the MOTC shouldn't meddle in the fund's affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER OF JUSTICE WORRIES MOST ABOUT FIREARMS, DRUGS AND ECONOMIC CRIMES

TEXT.P: Firearms, drugs and economic crime are the problems which have most undermined Taiwan's social fiber, Minister of Justice Liao Cheng-hao said on Saturday.

In a speech at a local college, Liao pointed out that political, economic, and social development in recent years has frayed the old value system, especially the prevailing attitude that "I can do anything I want to," which tends to justify even illegal behavior and seriously distorts the meaning of freedom.
The unraveling of social order has contributed to the island's bad name as "a land cash-rich but value-poor," "an island of greed," and "an island of filth," said Liao.
The bad name might be exaggerated to some extent, but it should still remind Taiwan's people of the importance of setting up and maintaining a new system of social values, said Liao.

Citing an example, Liao referred to notorious kidnapper and murderer Cheng Chin-hsing, whose daring hostage-taking of a South African diplomat and his family to demand the release of his wife and accomplices in November was televised live islandwide. Cheng was portrayed as a hero by the media, which seriously damaged social values.
Liao encouraged his audience to learn how to use their freedom without losing their direction. In other words, they should learn to play the game according to the rules.
