Democracy is a lifestyle which relies on order, emphasized Liao.

Noting that a law-abiding citizenry is a vital factor in enhancing a nation's competitiveness and that apart from family, school is the social organization that most people are first exposed to, Liao urged his student audience to prepare themselves for the more complicated adult social life by learning how to meet their responsibilities while enjoying their schooldays.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME ISN'T RIPE FOR SEF TO SET UP CROSS-STRAIT FORUM: MAC

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of Taipei's cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Friday that although setting up a cross-strait forum under the framework of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) would not likely result in structural "overlap," the time isn't ripe for carrying out that idea.

Chang's remark was in response to a report that the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) has set up an organization named the Cross-Strait Relationship Research Center and that it hopes the SEF will establish a corresponding cross-strait forum in Taiwan.

ARATS set up the center to serve as another channel for consultations between the two sides, according to the report. It will be chaired by Tang Shubei, with Mu Huaigo as its deputy-chief and Xing Kuishan, who is currently the research bureau director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, as an advisor.

Beijing hopes the SEF will set up a corresponding organization so that the new channel can serve as a more effective means for reflecting the views held by both sides and thus be conducive to greater interaction between Taipei and Beijing, according to the report.

Chang told reporters that according to the consensus reached at the National Development Conference at the end of 1996, there was a suggestion of setting up a non-official cross-strait forum; however, he added, the time for the implementation of that idea is not ripe yet.

Although a forum set up under the framework of the SEF wouldn't necessarily result in "overlap," its status and function would hinge on how the two sides of the Taiwan Strait chose to regard it, Chang observed.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE JOLTS INDONESIAN PROVINCIAL CAPITAL

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 6.0 on the Richter scale shook Ambon, capital of Indonesia's Maluku province, and its surroundings at 11:14 p.m. on Thursday, but there was no immediate report of casualties or damage.
A spokesman for the Ambon Geophysical Office said on Friday that the quake's epicenter was located at 4.45 degrees south and 129.25 degrees east, 33 km beneath the sea.

Earlier that same day, at 4:20 p.m., Ambon was hit by another earthquake, this one measuring 4.8 on the Richter scale. The quake was located 3.4 degrees south and 128.24 degrees east, 30.77 km beneath the sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US WTO AGREEMENT ON INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTS (I)

TEXT.P: At their 17th and final round of talks on Taiwan's terms for entry into the World Trade Organization (TWO), Taiwan and the United Stated finally reached agreement on terms for Taiwan's entry into the world trade regulatory body. Following are details of part of agreement on industrial products:
1. Industrial Tariffs
Taiwan has committed to reducing its average tariff for industrial products from 6.5 percent to 4.9 percent by year 2002 and to further reduce it to 4.7 percent by 2004.

Taiwan will participate in all Uruguay Round (UR) zero-for-zero sectoral initiatives. These initiatives include chemical harmonization and the elimination of tariffs on medical equipment, furniture, toys, steel, paper, construction equipment, agricultural equipment, civil aircraft and distilled spirits. Apart from a few categories where Taiwan will eliminate duties in 2004, Taiwan has offered to completely eliminate duties in these sectors by 2002. Taiwan is also participating in the zero-for-zero Information Technology Agreement, and is an active participant in ITA II.

Taiwan has agreed to actively support all of the APEC sectoral initiatives and, when an agreement is reached in APEC on the sectoral initiatives, Taiwan will include it in its WTO schedule. The immediate APEC initiatives include energy, equipment and services, environmental goods and services, forest products, toys, chemicals, medical equipment, fish and fish products, gems and jewelry and the telecommunications mutual recognition agreements.
2. Motor Vehicles

The tariff on motor vehicle imports will be reduced from 30 percent to 20 percent over a reasonable period. In addition, Taiwan will replace its current system of three commodity tax levels based on engine displacement with a two-level system. At 2000cc and below, the tax remains at 25 percent. Vehicles at 2001cc and above, however, will be taxed at 35 percent upon accession, and further lowered to 30 percent five years after accession.
Currently, Taiwan taxes passenger cars at 2000cc and below at 25 percent, cars between 2001cc and 3600 at 35 percent, and the 3600cc and above category at 60 percent.

A tariff-rate quota (TRQ) will be in place for ten years after accession. The quota that the United States enjoys will be double the amount of their highest level of imports between 1990 and 1993. Tariffs on motor vehicles outside the quota will be phased down from 60 percent to 20 percent over the ten-year TRQ period after which the TRQ will be entirely eliminated.

The Taiwan market for motor vehicles is expected to be approximately 500,000 units in 1998. The US quota allocation will be approximately 160,000 vehicles on accession, or potentially 32 percent of the market, and will grow by 20 percent in each of the following ten years.
Taiwan has agreed to eliminate the privilege that locally made engines, bodies, and chassis can each offset a 3 percent commodity tax from January 1, 2001.

Taiwan has also agreed to eliminate the local content requirements of Taiwan-made motor vehicles, a regulation which runs counter to WTO rules, immediately upon accession. Before being admitted to the WTO, Taiwan will reduce the local content rate of Taiwan-made motor vehicles from 50 percent to 40 percent after January 1, 1999. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US WTO AGREEMENT ON INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTS (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: 3.Other Industrial Products

Chemicals and Pharmaceuticals: Taiwan has agreed to fully participate in the Uruguay Round Chemical Harmonization Tariff Agreement by 2002 with limited exceptions to 2004. This agreement provides for very low tariffs -- zero percent for raw materials and pharmaceuticals, 5.5 percent for intermediates, and 6.5 percent for manufactured chemicals.
Medical Equipment and Supplies: Taiwan has agreed to completely eliminate tariffs for all medical equipment and supplies by 2002 with some tariffs reaching zero percent immediately upon accession.
Wood: Taiwan has agreed to completely eliminate tariffs on all wood products except a few plywood items, by 2002.

Paper: Taiwan has agreed to completely eliminate import duties on paper and paperboard products by 2002, and will completely eliminate tariffs on several key paper products, such as newsprint, by 2000.

Furniture: Taiwan tariffs on certain furniture products will be reduced to zero immediately upon accession and tariffs on all other furniture items will be reduced to zero by January, 2002. Current tariffs on furniture range from 1.25 percent to 10 percent for products from the United States.

Steel: Taiwan has agreed to completely eliminate its tariffs on steel mill products and certain fabricated steel mill products by January 1, 2004. The current tariffs on certain key US steel exports range up to 10 percent.
4. Privatization of Taiwan's Monopoly Board

Taiwan has committed to carrying on the privatization of the state-run Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau. It has agreed that the changes resulting from this privatization will eliminate discriminatory treatment of foreign beer, wine, distilled spirits, and tobacco.

In addition, Taiwan has agreed to completely eliminate tariffs on both brown and white spirits (e.g. bourbon, whiskey, gin and vodka) by 2000. Tariffs on beer will be completely eliminated by 2005. Tariffs on wine will go down to 10 percent by 2002.
5. Civil Aircraft

Although WTO agreement on trade in civil aircraft is not compulsory to the WTO signatories, Taiwan has agreed to join the agreement under which it will eliminate tariffs on civil aircraft and parts, whether for use by manufacturers or for maintenance or repair.
6. Dolls, Toys and Games

Taiwan tariffs on certain toys will be reduced to zero immediately upon accession. Tariffs on all other dolls, toys, and games will be reduced to zero by January 1, 2002. Current tariffs on dolls, toys, and games range from 5 to 10 percent for products from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.02 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at NT$32.826.
The greenback opened at 32.751 and was traded between 32.751 and 32.830.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$70.50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday reaffirmed the necessity of resuming dialogue across the Taiwan Strait, saying consultations can help foster mutual trust, avoid misunderstanding, reduce the risk of misjudgments and maintain peace in the region.

Lee made the remarks while meeting with a group of foreign scholars and experts here to attend a seminar on mainland China's political and economic developments in the wake of the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.
Lee refuted speculation in some quarters that Taiwan does not really want to resume talks with the mainland.

"Such speculation is erroneous," the president asserted, adding that Taiwan is more than willing to resume dialogue with the mainland because contacts and consultations can increase mutual understanding, forge rapprochement, and, more importantly, reduce misunderstanding and misjudgments.

Lee said he has consistently attached great importance to cross-strait relations, adding that during his tenure, the Republic of China government has declared the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion and abolished the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.

"These moves were aimed at replacing previous cross-strait military confrontation with peaceful exchanges and negotiations," Lee explained, adding that maintaining cross-strait peace and safeguarding physical safety and property rights of the general public have been his top concern.

Noting that mainland China's situation has a critical bearing on stability across the Taiwan Strait and even the entire Asia-Pacific region, Lee said he earnestly hopes that other countries, while engaging in trade and economic exchanges with the mainland, can simultaneously help push for its peaceful evolution in order to sustain regional peace, stability and prosperity.

Lee further said he will be delighted to see mainland China's peaceful evolution proceed in a gradual manner instead of as a result of radical changes because the country encompasses such a large area. "Gradual changes will be more suitable than a radical revolution," he noted.
Lee also expressed his regret over Beijing's failure to make any formal response to Taiwan's calls for resumption of bilateral dialogue since mid-1995.

Since Beijing unilaterally suspended institutionalized cross-strait consultations in June 1995, Lee said he and other senior ROC officials have repeatedly urged the mainland to resume such contacts. "Regrettably, mainland China has so far failed to make any formal written reply to our appeal."

Touching on the establishment of a new world order, Lee said the ROC is an independent sovereign state with an 87-year history. "We have never disappeared from the international community," Lee noted, adding that the ROC maintains unofficial ties with more than 140 countries around the world, in addition to maintaining formal diplomatic relations with some 30 countries.

For its own survival and development, Lee said, the ROC must step boldly and firmly into the world arena in a pragmatic manner. "More importantly, we have the resources to pay back the world community for what it has given to us in the process of our development."

As an East Asian country, Lee said, the ROC cannot sit idly by and adopt a hands-off policy while its Southeast Asian neighbors are beset by financial woes. "We'll share our experience and expertise with those battered Southeast Asian countries and help them to weather their current difficulties."

DOC.HEADLINE: US WELCOMES WTO AGREEMENT WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US government officials responsible for trade, commerce and agriculture have welcomed an agreement reached on Friday aimed at further opening Taiwan's market to US products.
US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky said the comprehensive agreement will "dramatically open Taiwan's market" to US agricultural products, services and industrial goods.

"US farmers will see new markets for pork, chicken and other meat products that have never been open to any foreign imports," she said. "US exporters of industrial products will achieve levels of market access comparable to those available in other developed countries. And Taiwan will provide broad access to a full range of services, including financial and telecommunications services."

Commenting on the agreement initialed in Washington, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said he is "particularly pleased that this agreement addresses issues of key concern to America's export industries, from autos to major infrastructure projects."
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman called the accord "a ground-breaking agreement for American agriculture."
Glickman said: "Taiwan, which is already one of our largest export markets, has agreed to provide new access for US poultry and pork and beef variety meats."

The agreement came as negotiators from the two countries concluded their 17th round of talks in five years over terms for Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO). With the conclusion of this agreement, only two of the 26 WTO members with which Taiwan has held bilateral talks require further consultations.

Taiwan is currently the seventh-largest export market for US products and imported about US$2.6 billion-worth of US farm goods in 1996/97, although it has maintained a ban on livestock and rice imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUNDED CAL AIRBUS PLANE CLEARED TO FLY

TEXT.P: As of Saturday morning, six of the nine China Airlines (CAL) A300-600R Airbus planes have completed safety inspection, and one of them has been cleared to fly again, CAL officials said on Saturday.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) grounded all nine of CAL's Airbus planes on Tuesday after the tenth one crashed near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Monday night, killing all 196 people on board and six on the ground in the worst air disaster on the island.

Because of the grounding order and the retraining that CAL's airbus pilots are currently undergoing, CAL has decided to suspend seven flights to Hong Kong, Manila and Jakarta and seven flights between Taipei and Kaohsiung on Sunday.

Meanwhile, CAL officials said that a public memorial service has been tentatively set for Feb. 26 but that the final date will hinge on the completion of the DNA sampling of those who died in the crash and on the wishes of the families of the victims.
Officials said that unidentifiable remains of the victims will be cremated en masse and that a monument will be erected at the crash site to commemorate the tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA CALM BUT TENSE

TEXT.P: The newly appointed chief of Indonesia's Army Strategic Reserve Command, Lt. Gen. Prabowo Subianto, expressed concern on Friday over the continuing social unrest, as many areas remained tense.

No fresh riots were reported that day, but the situations in the Southeast Sulawesi capital of Kendari and the North Sumatra town of Rantau Prapat, the scene of major unrest on Thursday, were tense, officials said.

Bus drivers in several cities in Java remained on strike to emphasize their demands that the government should lower prices of auto parts and increase bus fares in line with the price hikes in the Southeast Asian country which has been hard-hit by the financial crisis sweeping the region.
Prabowo said he was aware that the riots, which have mostly targeted properties owned by ethnic Chinese entrepreneurs, have endangered the nation's unity.
Prabowo, a son-in-law of President Suharto, reiterated his stance that the army remains committed to safeguarding security across the country.

"We will do our best to ensure the safety of all citizens regardless of their ethnic and religious backgrounds. I think the Armed Forces (ABRI) will not fail the people," Prabowo was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying.
Thousands of people enraged by soaring prices of essential commodities have run amok in several cities in Java, Sumatra and Sulawesi this week.
The angry mobs smashed shops and property owned by ethnic Chinese traders, who dominate Indonesia's retail sector.
In Rantau Prapat, about 400 km southeast of Medan, the authorities said 10 people were caught looting stores and houses on Wednesday and Thursday were still being questioned.
Kendari was calm but tense after the military threatened to carry out shoot-on-sight orders if protests turned violent.
In Yogyakarta, hundreds of students from 10 universities held three different demonstrations, demanding the government guarantee adequate supplies of basic commodities at affordable prices.
The rally was part of a two-day demonstration by students calling themselves the Association of Yogyakarta Youth Struggle.

Meanwhile, food shortages are threatening thousands of people in several subdistricts in Central Sulawesi, North Maluku and East Kalimantan as the economic situation continues to deteriorate, media reports said on Friday.
At the same time, legal aid and pro-democracy groups said they have recorded 14 abductions, 13 shootings and 921 arrests across Indonesia in the past few weeks.

"According to our data, 14 people were kidnapped," said a joint statement issued by the Indonesian Legal Aid Foundation, the Independent Committee on Election Monitoring and the Institute for Study and People's Advocacy.
Troops and police have shot 13 people during the recent spate of riots in a dozen cities and towns across the country that have occurred in protest against the soaring prices, said the statement.
The shots, fired during separate incidents in the Central Java district of Brebes and West Java towns of Cirebon and Bekasi, left three dead and ten injured, it added.

However, the figure does not include two other people who died from gunshot wounds during a riot on the eastern island of Lombok. The groups recorded that 921 people were arrested by police and troops during the riots and demonstrations in at least 23 cities and towns.

Army Chief Gen. Soebagio on Thursday warned that severe action would be taken against demonstrators and marchers who could trigger disturbances and violence ahead of and during the upcoming presidential and vice presidential elections.
Jakarta Military Commander Maj. Gen. Sjafrie Sjamsoedin had earlier banned demonstrations in the capital.
East Java military authorities have threatened to shoot demonstrators who spark rioting in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS SIGN AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL PLEA

TEXT.P: To mark the 50th anniversary of the International Declaration of Human Rights, many legislators on Saturday signed a plea from Amnesty International for the earlier full implementation of the declaration.

The "Get Up and Sign Up" campaign, which Amnesty International launched in December, has already gotten the endorsement of President Lee Teng-hui. After the legislators sign the plea, the international human rights group will collect signatures among the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices rose on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 51.33 points to finish at 9088.81.
The bourse opened at 9,132.79 and experienced a high of 9,138.81 and a low of 9069.1.
Gainers outnumbered losers 329 to 112, with 48 remaining unchanged. In all, 3.18 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$183.82 billion (US$5.60 billion).
Textile shares rose the most at 1.9 percent, followed by plastic and chemical stocks at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent and paper and pulp stocks at 1.1 percent.
Construction shares increased 0.9 percent, foodstuff stocks rose 0.3 percent, and electronic and engineering shares edged up 0.2 percent.
Financial shares remained unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRASHED CAL AIRBUS BLACK BOX, VOICE RECORDER SENT TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A five-man team from Taiwan has arrived in Canberra with the black box and cockpit voice recorder of crashed China Airlines (CAL) flight 676 to be analyzed at the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) so that the cause of the tragic crash near Taipei's International Airport that killed 202 people on Monday can be determined.

The group, led by Spencer Long, a safety inspector from the Civil Aeronautics Administration under Taiwan's Ministry of Transport and Communications, two CAL officials and two attorneys, arrived in Canberra on Friday.

Long and his group were not available for comment on the details of the analysis because they were busy helping the BASI officials to analyze the black box and voice recorder recovered from the wreckage of the Airbus 300-600.
But an Australian aviation source in Canberra said it would take a few days to finish the analysis.

The crash is Taiwan's worst aviation disaster, and many Australian government officials, members of parliament, academics and businessmen have expressed their sympathies and condolences to the bereaved families and the Republic of China government.
BASI has modern facilities for analyzing black boxes and voice recorders, and has so far helped many countries in Asia and elsewhere to do similar analyses, according to the same source.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US AGREEMENT ON MARKET OPENING DEEMED 'WIN-WIN OUTCOME'

TEXT.P: The agreement signed Friday between the Republic of China and the United States at the conclusion of their bilateral negotiations over Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) has been termed by both countries' representatives as a "win-win outcome" for the US and Taiwan economies.

The comprehensive agreement, which opens Taiwan's market to US agricultural products, services and industrial goods, was signed by Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the United States, and Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), at the end of an 11-day round of negotiations between ROC and US officials on Taiwan's accession to the WTO.

Asked to comment on the outcome of the negotiations, Chen, who heads the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) in Washington, said the agreement is mutually beneficial and that it represents "another big step" toward Taiwan's accession to the WTO.

"We look forward to the days when we will conclude similar bilateral negotiations with the European Union and Switzerland so that we can join the World Trade Organization in the near future," Chen said, noting that the WTO is extremely important to Taiwan's existence and development.

In a statement issued after the signing ceremony, Bush termed the agreement "a great achievement." He said the comprehensive pact is "probably the most important agreement" signed between AIT and TECRO -- formerly known as the Coordination Council for North American Affairs -- since their establishment 19 years ago.
"It signifies that the deep and mutually beneficial relationship between the people of the United States and the people on Taiwan is strong and growing," Bush said.

In his view, the agreement is good for both sides because US companies, exporters and farmers will have new opportunities in Taiwan, the 14th largest economy in the world. On the other hand, consumers in Taiwan will benefit as tariffs on imported goods decline over the next few years.
He expressed confidence that as Taiwan companies are exposed more to global economic forces, they will become even more competitive and successful than they already are.

Taiwan and the United States conducted 17 rounds of bilateral negotiations on Taiwan's accession to the WTO over the past five years. The latest round of negotiations in Washington began on Feb. 9. The ROC delegation was headed by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and the US side by US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU TO HOLD WTO TALKS WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By P. C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The 15-member European Union (EU) will hold a new round of talks with Taiwan on the terms for the island's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
EU officials in charge of WTO affairs already left for Taipei in preparation for the Feb. 23-25 trade consultations with their Taiwan counterparts, EU sources said on Friday.

Taiwan officials stationed in Brussels said there are not major disputes between Taiwan and the EU over the island's WTO entry terms. The unsolved issues are mainly related to Taiwan's tariff reduction plan for compact car imports and the reform of its decades-old wine and tobacco monopoly system.

Taiwan has promised to replace its wine and tobacco monopoly system with a new taxation system following its accession to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body. "Only some technical details in this regard need further discussion," said an official with Taiwan's representative office here.
Nevertheless, the official said, the EU may demanded Taiwan to further lower its tariff rates for compact car imports.

EU officials once agreed to Taiwan's proposal to lower its tariff rate for compact cars to 25 percent from the current 30 percent over a resonable period of time. However, the EU now intends to push Taiwan to make larger tariff cuts and lower the rate to below 25 percent following its WTO entry.

Taiwan managed to conclude bilateral WTO talks with its largest trading partner, the United States, on Friday after 17 rounds of marathon talks spanning more than five years. As a result, the EU and Switzerland are the only two trading partners that have yet to finalize bilateral WTO talks with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ACCORD PANICS TAIWAN HOG FARMERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan hog farmers have panicked over the results of the latest US-Taiwan bilateral trade consultations on terms for Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), in which Taipei agreed to open the island's pork market to US exports to the tune of 12,500 tons of pork products immediately upon accession.

According to an estimate by Fang Ching-chuan, secretary-general of the Taiwan Hog Raisers Association, the US imports will cause locals to sacrifice 1 million head of swine worth NT$15 billion (US$455 million) in the first year of the accession.

Although Taipei officials have expressed satisfaction that the gradually enlargement of the annual quota on US pork products will allow local hog farmers a period of "adjustment," Fang said that the "down payment" that Taiwan has promised to make in exchange for the quota system is too high.

In addition, Taipei's promise to fully open Taiwan's meat markets by the year 2005 is "rubbing salt into the wound" of the island's hog farmers, he said, noting that many of them have barely recovered from the catastrophic damage that a foot-and-mouth disease epidemic had on the hog population islandwide.

Last week, some 5,000 angry hog farmers took to the streets of Taipei to protest the market liberalization demand from the US side, pelting Washington's de facto embassy here with eggs and pig manure.

Fang, on behalf of the island's hog farmers and pork producers, made an eight-point appeal to the government, asking the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. to forsake its hog raising business once and for all, demanding the extension of salvation loans to farms that were ravaged by the foot-and-mouth disease outbreak and calling for government measures to digest stocks of frozen pork products.
The hog farmers also demanded a government-facilitated fund to be established to aid the development of domestic hog farming and help farmers who become victims of the foreign imports.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's top agricultural official urged the farmers to throw their support behind the government's policy, saying WTO membership will eventually help restructure Taiwan's agricultural and industrial sectors and raise the island's international competitiveness.

Peng Tzuo-kuei, chairman of the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said he is pleased that Taipei finally concluded its WTO talks with the United States. The negotiations ended on Feb. 20 in Washington, D.C. after 17 rounds of talks over the last five years.
Peng said seeking accession to the WTO has been Taipei's established policy, and that during the last round of talks both sides demonstrated commendable sincerity and flexibility.

While Taipei agreed to make a number of concessions for the WTO accession, the new foreign imports will not necessarily threaten the survival of the Taiwan's agricultural sector, Peng said, citing the fact that many Taiwan agricultural products and their production technologies can competitively match the standards of industrially-advanced countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TO BE DUTY-FREE

TEXT.P: Satellite and flat television screens could soon join the list of information technologies that are due to cross borders free of customs duties by 2000, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Friday.

The Information Technology Agreement (ITA) signed in Geneva in December 1996 by the world's biggest information technology traders covers six main categories, including computers, semiconductors and software, as well as other goods such as calculators and cash registers.
Trade in such equipment rings up more than US$600 billion a year in sales.
A WTO committee has been charged with expanding coverage of the agreement. The deadline for a final decision on new additions is June 30.
However, a number of countries expressed misgivings at a recent meeting of the committee in Geneva, the WTO report said.

South Korea, backed up by India, voiced concern that some of the proposed products were not directly linked to information technology and asked for an explanation of the relationship, the report said.
Panama and Latvia are expected to join the ITA soon, bringing the total number of participants to 45, counting the European Union as 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE KUAN YEW ASKS EU TO HELP ASIA TO SPEEDIER RECOVERY

TEXT.P: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew on Friday called on the European Union (EU) to play a more active role in helping Asia to a speedier recovery from its economic ills.
He made the call in a keynote speech to the first Europe-Asia Forum currently being held in Singapore.
He said Europe and the United States should support Japan in its efforts to help countries in the region out of the present crisis.
Europe, he pointed out, has missed earlier opportunities to show concern for Indonesia and Thailand.
It came late in Korea with direct contributions to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) package, and did not give directly to Thailand and Indonesia except through its IMF membership.

Apart from German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's recent expression of support for Indonesia's President Suharto, the perception in Asia is that the EU "has been passive" in this crisis of confidence, he said.
"If it is to play a global role, the EU must be more active in helping to restore confidence in Asia's currencies and financial markets," he stressed.

As European banks exposed to Asia have potential losses of well over US$15 billion, it is in their interest to help contain a crisis which they, like the other industrialized nations, have abetted with some careless investments and loans, he said.
The two-day forum brings together more than 60 European and Asian political, business and opinion leaders for dialogue on the theme, "Two Views, One Vision."

In his speech, Lee gave a detailed analysis of the currency turmoil's origins. He noted that some East Asian economies, which grew 7 to 9 percent a year for 15 years, had reached full capacity by the early 1990s, so new investments went into doubtful projects.
Yet, no international body "raised the red flag," with the World Bank and global ratings agency Fitch IBCA now admitting they were too optimistic on the region.
Amid the euphoria, cheap and easy credit led to asset bubbles and overbuilt property markets. Banks gave loans for personal and political connections. Investors went in recklessly.
Lenders were aware, but accepted it as a way of business. Some saw politically connected business partners as implicit government guarantees for loans.

In 1996, an export slowdown and widening current account deficits in these countries spooked financial markets. "What had begun as a classic market mania as funds flowed exuberantly into East Asia to enjoy higher rates of return, became a classic market panic as foreign investors stampeded towards the door to get out with their money," he noted.
Turning to how East Asian governments could respond, Lee said they should:
-- Reject cronyism and have a professional civil service, effective central bank, and sound banks and companies, to restore confidence.

Policies should be in accordance with benchmark IMF programs, to convince their people and global fund managers that their economies are on the mend. "In spite of criticism, there is no viable alternative to the IMF for now."
ASEAN countries should also endorse the OECD convention of last December to make receiving bribes a criminal act.

-- Improve information flow and disclosure, and be more transparent -- the best way to avoid market reactions to rumors. With such data, foreign investors can distinguish between East Asian economies and foresee potential problems.
-- Continue to open up their economies, including sectors previously closed, and encourage capital inflow.

Summing up at the end of the day, Prof. Tommy Koh, executive director of the Asia-Europe Foundation, one of the sponsors of the forum, said that the consensus that emerged from the discussion was that "Asian economies will get back on track in two to four years," and commitment was expressed by both Europe and Asia to help each other continue to globalize.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA, NZ SEEK JOINT FORCE FOR GULF WAR

TEXT.P: Australia and New Zealand are working to form a united force in support of the US-led war against Iraq in case last-ditch efforts by UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan fail to persuade Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to comply with the UN Security Council resolutions to dismantle Iraqi chemical and biological weapons.
In a meeting in Sydney Friday, Australian Prime Minister John Howard and his New Zealand counterpart, Jenny Shipley, discussed the joint force.

Both countries have dispatched special forces troops to the Gulf. Australia has sent 190 personnel, including 110 Special Air Service (SAS) troops, while New Zealand has sent 20 SAS soldiers and 40 air force personnel.
In a joint press conference, Howard and Shipley said arrangements were being discussed to form the units into an Australian-New Zealand (ANZAC) force.
"The goal would be for the closest possible cooperation between the two countries in the ANZAC tradition," Howard said.
"The practicalities of that, of course, are things that need to be fully worked out and resolved by ourselves and in discussion with the United States," he added.
Shipley said they would know within several days if the arrangement would be possible.

"While New Zealand is a small country, it is one that has always sought to do its share, and the recent decision to deploy troops to Iraq is something that has been important to New Zealand," she said.
"It is our hope that we will be able to work as an ANZAC force. New Zealanders and Australians have had a great history of success," she added.

Australian and New Zealand troops used to cooperate closely on battlefields in many countries in support of the British armed forces in World War I, World War II and other wars, such as those in Korea and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE BACKS UN EFFORTS TO RESOLVE IRAQI CRISIS

TEXT.P: Concerned with the situation in Iraq, Singapore fully supports the efforts of the United Nations to resolve the crisis there, the Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement issued on Friday night.
Singapore is pleased that UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan is visiting Iraq to try and resolve the crisis, it added.
"We have consistently supported the role of the UN Security Council in bringing about peace and stability to the Gulf region," the statement added.
It pointed out that it is the responsibility of all members of the UN, including Iraq, to comply with UN Security Council (UNSC) resolutions and respect the authority of the world body.

"Singapore would like to see a peaceful diplomatic solution to this crisis. This will require the government of Iraq to fulfill the requirements of all the relevant UNSC resolutions regarding UN inspection by the UN Special Commission."
The statement added that the government of Iraq "has to bear responsibility for any consequence if it fails to implement these resolutions."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO COMPLETELY OPEN TOBACCO, LIQUOR MARKETS IN THREE YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will phase out its monopoly system on tobacco and liquor and open its market completely to foreign tobacco and liquor in three years, according to a high-ranking financial official.

Vice Finance Minister Wu Chai-shen, who returned on Saturday morning from the Taiwan-US talks on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, said that according to the agreement reached with US officials, three years after Taiwan's monopoly system on tobacco and liquor is lifted -- an action expected this year -- the island's tobacco and liquor markets will be totally liberalized.

Four years after the monopoly system is dismantled and replaced with a taxation system, the production of liquor will be open to local and foreign investors, Wu noted, adding that as tobacco is hazardous to human health, the government has no plans to open the manufacture of tobacco products to the private sector.

Wu said that the Legislative Yuan is expected to pass the law governing the taxation of tobacco and liquor and another law governing the production and sale of those products in this session, providing a legal framework for the taxation system to replace the monopoly on tobacco and liquor.

On tobacco or liquor smuggled into Taiwan and then seized, Wu said that the US officials have agreed that when Taiwan adopts the taxation system, confiscated tobacco or liquor won't have to be destroyed but can be disposed of in other ways, including auctioning, donation or resale.

The taxation of rice wine was a key issue in the trade talks. According to Wu, the US side, which had demanded that the rice wine be taxed the same as distilled spirits, has agreed to give it a five-year adjustment period. This means that the taxation for rice wine will be raised gradually over five years once the new system is launched. Beginning in the sixth year, rice wine will be taxed the same as distilled spirits.
Currently the taxation for rice wine is NT$22 (US$0.67) per liter, compared with NT$170 per liter for distilled spirits.

Wu said that in the agreement, Taiwan has agreed to completely eliminate tariffs on both brown and white spirits (e.g. bourbon, whiskey, gin and vodka) by 2000. Tariffs on beer will be completely eliminated by 2005. Tariffs on wine will go down to 10 percent by 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW SATISFIED WITH WTO AGREEMENT WITH US

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday he is satisfied with the outcome of negotiations with the United States over terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

"Even though Taiwan has made concessions in consultative process, the outcome complies with our economic liberalization policy," Siew noted, adding that the government has drawn up measures to minimize the possible adverse impact on domestic agriculture or industries of the newly signed Taiwan-US WTO agreement.

Taiwan and American negotiators finally came to terms on all the thorny WTO-related issues on Friday after 17 rounds of intensive talks spanning more than five years, with Taiwan agreeing to lower trade barriers and offer greater market access to US agricultural products, services and industrial goods.

According to the agreement initialed on Friday in Washington, D.C., Taiwan agreed to imports of limited quantities of pork, chicken meat and intestines from the US before its WTO entry. Taiwan also made concessions on some other trade fields in exchange for US support for its WTO bid.

Siew said accession to the WTO will benefit Taiwan's overall economic development. "We fully understand that market-opening measures will affect certain industries, particularly the agricultural sector. We'll adopt effective measures to protect rights and interests of local farmers," he added.

Meanwhile, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Peng Tzuo-kuei said the government has managed to stand firm on its stance in negotiating with the US. Noting that negotiation is a given-and-take process, Peng said even though Taiwan made some concessions, it has managed to get some favorable terms to protect its farmers.

Taiwan has agreed to offer market access to 5,000 tons of pork cuts, 10,000 tons of chicken meat and 7,500 tons of intestines from the US. "This doesn't mean that foreign pork will be able to successfully make inroads into our market," Peng said, adding that local farmers should have confidence in the competitiveness of locally produced pork.

With the conclusion of WTO talks with the US, Taiwan will now focus on negotiations with the 15-member European Union (EU) and Switzerland, the only two trade partners that have yet to finalize bilateral talks with Taiwan.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Saturday that Taiwan expects to conclude bilateral WTO talks with the EU and Switzerland before the end of March.
If all goes smoothly, the ministry said, Taiwan will begin multilateral talks with the WTO working party in charge of Taiwan's membership application in Geneva in April.

"The conclusion of WTO talks with the US marks a big step forward toward our goal to join the important world trade regulatory body," government spokesman Chen Chien-jen, adding the agreement with the US will help speed up Taiwan's WTO accession.

Twenty-six WTO contracting parties expressed intentions to hold bilateral talks with Taiwan. To date, 24 of them have finalized such talks with Taiwan, and 18 of them have signed agreements on entry terms. Six other members -- Hungary, Argentina, Thailand, Hong Kong, Mexico and Canada -- have yet to ink formal accords. The pact with the US will take effect on March 10.

Reports from Washington quoted US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky as saying that the US has consistently handled Taiwan's WTO application separately from mainland China's WTO bid. The US has no intention to stimilate or provoke Beijing by concluding talks with Taipei ahead of its negotiations with Bejing, she added. Washington's WTO talks with Beijing are still stalled by some sensitive trade issues.

Beijing applied for joining the WTO's predecessor, the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs (GATT), in 1986, while Taiwan filed its application in 1990. The WTO superceded the GATT in January 1995. Both Taiwan and mainland China are now WTO observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANS TO DISRUPT INDONESIA'S ASSEMBLY UNCOVERED: JAKARTA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: City Police Chief Maj. Gen. Hamami Nata said Friday that documentary evidence had been found of plans to disrupt next month's General Session of the Indonesian People's Consultative Assembly.
He said the documents indicated a group calling itself the Democratic Order planned to wreck havoc on the General Session.

"The group apparently does not only plan to cause trouble before the session starts, but also during the session and after the session ends," the two-star general was quoted by the Jakarta Post as saying.
He refused to provide further details about the documents or the group.
Meanwhile, a plan to provide free staple food for needy residents is aimed at deterring people from staging street demonstrations, a city official said Friday.
Hari Sandjojo, head of Jakarta's Regional Economic Bureau, said many people would be comforted to know the municipality was ready to help them if there were an "emergency" situation.
One of the mass food packages from the country's businesspeople was handed over to the municipality Thursday.
The 100,000 packages of foodstuffs, worth Rp 27 billion (US$2.9 million), were handed over by tycoons Sudomo Salim and Sukandani Sahid Gitosardjono and a group of other businesspeople.
Each package contains five kilograms of rice, 40 packets of instant noodles, a liter of cooking oil and 20 sachets of soy sauce.
Hundreds of stores and supermarkets in Tangerang, a town on the capital's outskirts, closed early Friday morning after the area was rocked by rumors of a massive riot.
The gossip also prompted residents to abruptly leave the streets and stay at home or in their offices.
The authorities' announcement that the rumors were totally baseless apparently failed to persuade the store owners, most of whom are ethnic Chinese, to reopen.
By late Friday afternoon, a few stores had tentatively begun trading again, but only after the authorities deployed police and military personnel onto the streets.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST S'PORE FIRMS HIT BY ECONOMIC TURMOIL: SCI SURVEY

TEXT.P: Eight out of 10 small and medium-size businesses in Singapore expect their profits this year to be reduced by the regional economic turmoil, and 30 percent are braced for earnings to plunge more than 40 percent.

This was disclosed in a survey conducted by the Singapore Confederation of Industries (SCI), which on Friday urged the government to review and reduce all business costs to help the firms cope with the crisis.

The fallout from the economic crisis will hit the domestic sales of 85 percent of these firms, while another 83 percent will experience a decline in revenue from exports, according to the SCI survey conducted early this month.
Business prospects have been hurt mainly by lower selling prices and currency exchange losses incurred, SCI members said.
The SCI called on the government to reduce business costs such as all fees and taxes, as well as land and factory rents.

It also asked for a postponement of the implementation of the electronic road pricing scheme and a one percentage point reduction in the goods and services tax, as well as for greater government assistance to tap unexplored overseas markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARGIN FOR SHORT SELLING TO BE LOWERED: FINANCE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul Chiu on Saturday announced that margin for short selling is to be lowered from 90 percent to 70 percent of each stock transaction value, effective next Monday.
The announcement came when the Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index rose 51.33 points to 9088.81, the highest level this year, amid optimism over the market's outlook.
The minimum requirement for margin buying remains at 50 percent of each stock transaction value, Chiu added.
While saying that the stock market has returned to normal, Chiu stressed that he believes the ministry's latest move won't bring any negative effect on the stock market.

The Finance Ministry raised the margin for short selling from 50 percent to 90 percent of each stock transaction value on October 20 as part of efforts to revive the local bourse which had suffered serious setback for weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FARM EXPORTS TO TAIWAN DROP IN 1997
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The total value of US agricultural products purchased by Taiwan in 1997 dropped 12 percent from the year-earlier level, marking the first decline in the trade in five years, according to statistics from the US Department of Agriculture (DOA).
The statistics show that Taiwan bought US$2.69 billion worth of American agricultural products last year, down US$352 million in comparison with the 1996 volume.
However, in terms of total value, Taiwan remained Washington's fifth largest overseas agricultural market, following Japan, Canada, Mexico and South Korea, the department said.

By category, the tallies showed, the main farm items that Taiwan purchased from American producers last year were cereal grain, soybean, leather, fresh fruit and wheat. The United States is the island's largest trade partner.

In 1997, the United States sold US$698 million worth of cereal grain to Taiwan, down sharply by 28.8 percent from the previous year, while US$1.62 billion worth of American wheat was exported to the island, down 25.3 percent. The US$6.49 billion of soybean exports to Taiwan represented a 16.4 percent fall, according to the DOA statistics.

The figures also indicated that Taiwan's protection of its rice market resulted in only a small amount of US-produced rice, valued at US$485,000, being exported to the island last year. Nevertheless, that represented a 164 percent jump from the year-earlier level.

American exports of rice to Taiwan, where the commodity is a staple in the diet of most residents, are expected to see a significant rise after Taipei promised on Friday to fully open its rice market to US producers as part of a deal to gain World Trade Organization membership.

According to the DOA, Washington exported a total of US$57.137 billion worth of farm products last year, down 5.3 percent from a year ago. Japan was the largest buyer of American agricultural goods, followed in order by Canada, Mexico, South Korea, Taiwan, Holland, Hong Kong, mainland China, Germany and Britain, the department said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE VISITS POPE

TEXT.P: Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, on Saturday visited Pope John Paul II and conveyed Lee's personal greetings to the world's highest Roman Catholic spiritual leader.

Accompanied by Raymond R.M. Tai, ROC ambassador to the Holy See, Cardinal Paul K. H. Shan from Taiwan, and Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, Huang, on behalf of Lee, asked the pope to pray for peace around the world and across the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Huang told the pope that President Lee is actively promoting spiritual reforms to achieve social justice and peace in Taiwan, which, he noted, are also values pursued by the Catholic Church. He expressed the belief that Cardinal Shan, in cooperation with other religious leaders, will continue to work for upgrading the spiritual dimension of the people of Taiwan.

Huang and Wu were the leaders of an ROC delegation here to attend the elevation ceremony of Kaohsiung Archbishop Shan and 21 other prelates from around the world. The ceremony was held earlier Saturday at St. Peter's Square.

Speaking at a news conference after the ceremony, Shan thanked Pope John Paul II for his concern for the Chinese people and the development of the Catholic Church in Taiwan and mainland China. He vowed to engage in welfare activities to assist other countries and serve as a bridge in communication with the Catholic Church in the mainland, saying that the mission of the Catholic Church is to serve society, humanity and help carry out spiritual reforms.

The Catholic Church played an important role in the fields of education, medical care and assisting the poor in the early days after its founding in Taiwan, while its mission nowadays focuses on taking care of the elderly and mentally retarded children and setting up halfway homes for women, Shan pointed out.

The cardinal said that the Taiwan Catholic Church not only cares for the people of Taiwan but also is very willing to assist poor people in other countries, adding that it has a worked out a long-term program to carry out its international aid mission.
Tai said the elevation of Shan, the only Asian among the 22 prelates named to the cardinalship on Saturday, will help boost peace and justice in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT SENDS CONDOLENCES OVER CAL CRASH

TEXT.P: -- Philippine President Fidel V. Ramos Saturday sent his condolences, on behalf of the Filipino people, to relatives of the victims in the crash of a China Airlines (CAL) A-300 jetliner last Monday.
The disaster killed all 196 passengers and crew members onboard and six other persons on the ground.
At the same time, Ramos reiterated his call for a thorough investigation of the recent Cebu Pacific Flight 387 crash which, he said, has become more urgent following the Taiwan air accident.

"The investigation to pinpoint responsibility should likewise be carried out with similar thoroughness for the sake of aviation safety by way of immediate corrective, punitive and preventive actions whenever necessary," Ramos said.

In a letter of condolences to Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, the Philippine president said: "The Filipino nation, which still mourns the tragic loss of 104 previous lives in the crash of the ill-fated Cebu Pacific Flight 387 in Northern Mindanao (on Feb. 2, 1998), is too well aware of the pain and anguish being felt by your people.
"Mrs. Ramos and I join you and your people in praying that the families and loved ones of the victims be given the strength and courage to recover from the tragedy," he added.
The CAL jetliner was returning from the Indonesian resort of Bali when it slammed into a row of houses near Taipei's international airport and burst into flames.
Among those who perished in the crash were Taiwan's central bank governor and other finance officials returning from a conference in Bali.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BENEFIT GREATLY FROM WTO MEMBERSHIP: WANG

TEXT.P: Taiwan's long-awaited membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO) is expected to bring multifaceted benefits to the island's economy, Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang said Sunday.

Taiwan concluded bilateral talks with the United States on terms for its entry into the WTO in Washington on Friday, marking a great step forward in its bid for membership in the world trade regulatory body.
Wang, Taiwan's chief negotiator in the talks, said that Taiwan's gross domestic product will increase by US$33 billion after it joins the WTO.

The WTO membership will also bring Taiwan an additional US$23.7 billion in domestic consumption, US$25.9 billion in exports, US$26.3 billion in imports and US$3.9 billion in investment, along with 376,000 more job opportunities, he said.

Besides, the economics minister said, membership will entitle Taiwan to most-favored-nation status and treatment as a national entity under the global trade system, as well as ensure the right to participate in the framing of international trade laws and to seek WTO arbitration in trade disputes with other nations.
Wang described the just-concluded talks with the United States as the most difficult in the five-year, 17-round negotiation process.

He said that while the US side had "nothing to lose" and had increased its demands every time upon returning to the negotiating table, Taiwan could do nothing but adopt a strategy of "giving the less, the better."

Wang echoed the comment by Richard Bush, chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, who said the Washington talks have created a "win-win" situation for both sides as each gained what it wanted.

But Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lin Shiang-nung said that WTO membership will also inevitably bring certain negative impacts on the island's farm sector and that the government will take necessary relief measures for those affected.

Taiwan applied to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the predecessor of the WTO, in 1990 under the name "Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu," and was granted observer status in that body the following year.

With the conclusion of talks with the United States, Taiwan has completed its negotiations with 24 of the 26 WTO contracting parties who have expressed concerns over Taiwan's trade regime, and has signed pacts with 17 of them.
Taiwan is expected to gain entry into the WTO in May, after completing talks with the European Union later this month and with Switzerland in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN OFFICIAL APPOINTED TO HEAD WTO GENERAL COUNCIL

TEXT.P: A Canadian official has been appointed as chair of the general council of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

John Weekes, 54, has been Canada's ambassador and permanent representative to the Office of the General Council of the WTO since September 1995. He was chair of the WTO committee on regional trade agreements.
Before working at the WTO, Weekes was Canada's chief negotiator for NAFTA between 1991 and 1994, and ambassador to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva.
Canada's International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi said the election of Weekes "reflects Canada's continued leadership in the multilateral trading system."
Canada was one of the original signatories of the WTO, founded in 1994 to develop and enforce multilateral trade rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TRADE CHIEF ACCEPTS INVITATION TO VISIT

TEXT.P: US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky has accepted an invitation from Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang of the Republic of China to visit Taiwan, Chen Ruey-long, chief of the Board of Foreign Trade, revealed here Sunday.

Chen quoted Barshefsky as saying she believes high-level official exchanges between Taipei and Washington can help improve links between the two countries and, accordingly, she plans to travel to Taiwan at Wang's invitation.

Wang and Barshefsky were the chief negotiators for their respective governments in bilateral talks on Taiwan's bid for World Trade Organization (WTO) membership. The negotiations ended in what was called a "win-win" situation on Friday when the two sides forged an agreement after 17 rounds of marathon sessions spanning several years.

The United States has been Taiwan's largest trade partner. After winning Washington's agreement, the island sees no more major obstacles to its joining the world trade regulatory body later this year.

Chen pointed out that Barshefsky had expressed the observation that Taipei-Washington trade relations always seem to show signs of improvement following her meetings with Wang and in the aftermath of each round of discussions on the WTO issue.
Accordingly, she hopes the two countries can continue to follow the pattern of such exchanges in order to enhance mutual ties, Chen noted.

When Washington switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, all ministerial-level contacts between Taiwan and the United States came to a halt. Although vigorous trade activity between the two sides has continued, only one senior US trade official has come to Taiwan since formal ties were severed.

Former US Trade Representative Carla Hills toured the island in 1992 in a private capacity, marking a significant step forward in Taiwan-US relations at the time. Such progress is expected to advance once again if Barshefsky goes ahead with her stated intention to visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS HITS US AND JAPANESE TRADE

TEXT.P: United States and Japanese trade statistics have provided further indications of the widening shockwave from Asia's economic crisis.

Japan's exports to the rest of Asia plunged in January, and the country recorded its first trade deficit with the region in eight years. In the United States, a higher-than-expected December trade deficit pushed up the annual deficit to its highest level since 1988, according to a report of the Financial Times.
News of the drop in Japan's exports to Asia highlights the degree to which the financial turmoil in the region is suppressing demand and making Japanese goods less competitive in those markets.
It also provides one of the first concrete signs of the degree to which Southeast Asia's problems are threatening, on the eve of the latest economic stimulus package, to hurt Japan's own economy.

Analysts forecast the US trade deficit would worsen in 1998 as imports increase from Asian countries that have devalued their currencies. The US deficit increased 24.3 percent in December to US$10.79 billion compared with forecasts of US$8.7 billion.

That meant the annual deficit in goods and services last year was US$113.75 billion, a 2.4 percent increase compared with 1996. The biggest import losses were in manufactured goods -- totaling US$172.6 billion for the year. However, the impact was mitigated by the growth in services, which turned in a record US$85.2 billion surplus. Services exports reached US$254 billion for the year. Imports were US$168.8 billion.
Japan's sales to Asia were 9.4 percent lower in January, measured on an annual basis -- the sharpest monthly drop recorded since 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: 21ST CENTURY WILL STILL BELONG TO THE UNITED STATES, SAYS HURD

TEXT.P: The 21st century will be the American century, not the Asian century or the European century, former British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd predicted Saturday.

In an interview at the first Europe Asia Forum held here, he said: "The United States will remain the only superpower in the world in the next century. The United States is already far ahead in its use of technology, and its general management of its economy, and this will continue."
It will continue to maintain its preeminent position in technology, in economics and in security arrangements, he added.

Asian powers, such as Japan and mainland China, will grow rapidly in population and gross domestic product (GDP) output, but would not be able to rival America's status, said Hurd, who was Britain's foreign secretary from 1989 to 1995, according to a report in The Straits Times on Sunday.

In any case, mainland China is not an "evangelical" power trying to spread its values to the world, and it is only the United States that aspires to that role. Europe and Asia, on their part, must get themselves organized and united to be "valid partners" with Washington, he said, adding that this was his main message to the forum.
Hurd is one of more than 60 decision-makers who were participating in the first Europe Asia Forum held in Singapore on Feb. 20-21.
Explaining his concept of "valid" partnership, he said this did not mean Europe and Asia would be "satellites" of America.

Rather, each region should get itself organized to present a united voice with which the United States can engage. Citing European responses to the Iraqi crisis, in which individual European countries have adopted different stances, Hurd said Europe has not been able to present itself as a "valid partner."
Asked for his assessment of the Asian economic crisis, Hurd said one of the positive outcomes was that it has sparked sharp interest in Europe about Asia.

While some people have put forward the "domino theory" that the Southeast Asian financial crisis will drag down Hong Kong, Japan and mainland China, he said this is unlikely to happen because the economic fundamentals in Asia remain strong.
The crisis in Asia rose in part from problems of perceptions. This is one area the second Asia-Europe meeting, which will be held in London in April, can correct, Hurd said.

European governments can play a part in spreading the message to their people that the Asian crisis will affect Europe, while telling investors that fundamentals in Asia remain strong. Asian countries like mainland China and Japan can use the meeting as a platform to reinforce these arguments convincingly.
On the expertise Europe can offer Asia, he said the European institutions can help strengthen financial institutions in Asia.
Strengthening systems of regulation and supervision, and making use of sophisticated financial products, can all help reduce future shocks to the financial system, Hurd said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPRAPARTY MAINLAND POLICY URGED

TEXT.P: Local academics and mainland experts at a seminar on Sunday urged the government and opposition political parties to soon forge consensus on a "supraparty" mainland policy as a common basis for future political negotiations with Beijing.

J.K. Chang, director of the Department of Mainland Operations under the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), said Premier Vincent Siew's recent policy report at the Legislative Yuan reflected the government's intention to adopt a more flexible and active policy in its dealings with mainland China.
According to Chang, Siew made reference to cross-strait negotiations on 10 occasions during his report, without differentiating between "technical" or "political" talks.

Chang also alluded to remarks by Siew last week that "any topics which are beneficial to the peaceful development on the two sides of Taiwan Strait and the nation's democratization and unification can be discussed step by step in cross-strait talks," saying that such topics include a wide range of issues, including technical matters such as fishery disputes and political themes such as the "one China" issue.

Dismissing a belief by the outside world that Siew's recent remarks on cross-strait talks, which are seen as "more flexible than before," have come in reaction to a widely praised mainland policy seminar held by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Chang said there is no connection between the two developments.

The decision made by the DPP at the gathering to advocate a cautious "go west" approach in economic exchanges with the mainland has long been the KMT's set policy in cross-strait relations, he noted, adding that the pro-independence DPP has moved a step closer to the KMT position following the seminar in this regard.

Both Y.C. Liu, a research fellow at Academia Sinica, and C.S. Chao, international relations professor at National Chengchi University, hailed the DPP's transparent and democratic manner in forging consensus on its own mainland policy. But the most important task for the DPP now is to gain wide support from the various factions within the party as a way of working out a "suprafactional" mainland policy, they pointed out.
Liu also called on all political parties in Taiwan to set aside their disputes on the issue as a first step toward forging a supraparty mainland policy.
P.C. Chen, economics professor at National Taiwan University, however, was more reserved about cross-strait economic exchanges.

Although many people are in favor of gradually enhancing ties with the mainland on the economic front, he warned, history has proved that the smaller part eventually will be swallowed up by the larger part.

Taiwan can neither be overly arrogant nor grant too many concessions in cross-strait negotiations, and it should negotiate with the mainland only after the Chinese Communists first show signs of sincerity, he said, urging the government not to give way to Beijing's threats.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S LEE EXPLAINS WHY ASIAN CRISIS SPREAD SO FAST

TEXT.P: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said technology is moving so fast that people's emotional and cultural makeup cannot keep up with the changes in the world, and this is one underlying reasons why the Asian crisis spread so quickly.

Leaders in East Asia, for example, did not understand the speed and power of the international financial market, and thus made some decisions early on in the crisis which eroded investors' confidence in the region, he said.

European leaders could help by taking measures that would help Asian leaders "get in tune" with the new realities, Lee said during a 20-minute dialogue with participants of the first Europe Asia Forum in Singapore on Friday night, The Straits Times reported Sunday.

The two-day forum for over 60 European and Asian politicians, business executives, financiers and academics was organized by the German BMW Foundation, the Singapore-based Asia-Europe Foundation (ASEF) and the Institute of Policy Studies.

Responding to a question from Luxembourg banker Edmond Israel, who sits on the ASEF's board of governors, on what his greatest concern was for Asia's future, Lee said: "My greatest concern is the inability of the emotional and cultural makeup of a man to catch up with the technological changes that have been brought upon us, and are coming. There is a time lag and this creates a dangerous gap."

So, for example, the lure of loans at low interest rates enticed people to borrow cheap, and to borrow short-term for long-term investments. But they forgot the power and speed at which money could move out of stock and money markets.
There was thus this time lag between developments of modern systems and people's ability to understand their implications. This created a big problem, he said.

Making a similar point in response to another question on what, how and how much Germany could do to help alleviate the Asian crisis, Lee said that beyond financial contributions, European leaders such as German Chancellor Helmut Kohl could play a part in helping Asian leaders come to terms with the nature of today's financial markets.
Because of the lack of understanding of the rapidity and volatility of the financial markets, missteps were taken at the beginning of the crisis, which eroded confidence in the region, he said.

Giving a frank assessment of the situation, Lee said: "What I think has been the greatest lesson of the Asian crisis is that many in the region did not understand, or did not realize, the nature of today's financial markets. We are not in the 1960s, we're in the 1990s."

He said it was not until the crisis broke and he started reading market reports two, three times a day, that he understood "just how swift, how comprehensive, how thorough, every move that the government makes during the crisis is analyzed, assessed," with the consequences spelt out and offered to customers at the touch of a button.

"So whether it's Bangkok, Manila, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Jakarta or Seoul, every move that the government makes or does not make, has been analyzed, by Saloman Brothers, or ABN-AMRO -- two, three pages of careful analysis, disseminated, and influencing opinion in London, New York, Frankfurt, Paris, Tokyo.
"It is necessary to get people updated on these things. That's part of the job of leaders in the developed world."
Whether people like it or not, they live in one globalized world, he said.
Lee recounted an exchange he had as a young man with a Japanese prime minister, who argued that everyone was traveling in the same boat.
He said he had retorted then that the prime minister traveled first class, whereas he traveled in the deck, to which the premier had replied: "You will reach the lifeboats first."
The point of the tale? If the ship sinks, everyone goes down with it.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP LAWMAKERS AIR '1 CHINA, 2 CHINESE STATES' FORMULA

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the opposition New Party (NP) on Sunday proposed a formula for "one China, two Chinese states" as means to break the existing stalemate in relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Under the formula, initiated by Prof. Chang Ya-chung of National Chengchi University, national sovereignty will be shared by all Chinese in Taiwan as well as the mainland. Thus China will not be completely divided, and both the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China will be sovereign entities with jurisdiction over their own territory.

Endorsed by the heads of the NP caucuses in the National Assembly, Legislative Yuan and Taipei City Council, the formula calls for Taipei and Beijing to sign a document similar to the one inked by then West and East Germany in 1972, declaring that neither the ROC nor the PRC will seek to separate China and making clear their determination to pursue national unification.
Under this system, the ROC and the PRC will treat each other as "brother nations" but both are entitled to the status of independent nations internationally.

Yao Li-ming, NP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that compared with the ruling Kuomintang's ambiguous "one China" concept, which only refers to Chinese blood, culture, and history, the new approach is clearer and more capable of easing cross-strait tension.

The formula will stress there is one China legally and politically, but that China doesn't exist substantially at the moment because of its state of national division. China's future revival, however, is possible, Yao said.
Chu Chao-hsiang, NP National Assembly whip, said the approach must be fully discussed and approved by NP members before it becomes official party policy toward the mainland.

The Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan's main opposition party, after a three-day internal debate on mainland policy earlier this month, forged a consensus calling for "consolidating the base (Taiwan) with gradual engagement with the mainland."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERAL INJURED IN CLASHES OVER INCINERATOR

TEXT.P: About 20 policemen and six local residents were injured early Sunday morning after more than 2,000 policemen and over 200 people clashed over the building of an incinerator in Hsichou township in central Changhua County.

Clashes between the public and police first broke out around 3:00 a.m., after Legislator Wong Chin-chu of the Democratic Progressive Party failed in her negotiations with local police station head Chen Chih-jon to convince police to postpone construction of the incinerator until Chunghua County Magistrate Juan Kang-meng returns from an overseas trip.
Chen refused Wong's request and claimed that it was his responsibility to help remove barriers to construction of the incinerator, as the project has been blocked for more than three years.

But the more than 200 protesters from local Hsichou township and Hsilou township of neighboring Yunlin County, who were already staging a sit-in protest outside the construction site, began to attack the policemen by throwing rocks, excrement, bricks and poles after those manning the frontline of their ranks were forcibly removed by the officers.
The second round of clashes erupted around 4:25 a.m. after police failed again in efforts to convince the protesters to drop their weapons and resolve the conflict peacefully.
Police then decided to disperse the crowd by force, and six protesters and nearly 20 policemen were wounded as the two sides exchanged blows with poles and riot shields.
Under heavy police escort, trucks were able to drive into the construction site at around 4:30 a.m., while some protesters continued to roam about the vicinity.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ATTENDS MEMORIAL CEREMONY FOR AIR CRASH VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Sunday attended a joint service to mourn the victims from southern Taiwan's main city of Kaohsiung who perished in last week's tragic air crash at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, extending his condolences to the victims' family members.

Siew, accompanied by Minister Without Portfolio Lin Feng-cheng and several other officials, arrived at the Kaohsiung Municipal Funeral Parlor, where the service took place, on Sunday morning. He paid homage to the dead by spreading incense around the parlor.

Appearing reluctant to answer questions from members of the press concerning governmental steps in handling the worst accident in Taiwan's aviation history, an obviously grieving premier said only that he has instructed Lin to form a task force to carry out necessary work in the aftermath of the crash, which took lives of 202 people.

A China Airlines Airbus A-300 plane, en route from the Indonesian resort of Bali, crashed during an attempt to land at the airport in northern Taiwan on Feb. 16, killing all 196 persons onboard and six others on the ground.
Among the dead were Sheu Yuan-dong, governor of the Central Bank of China, and two other senior financial officials, as well as seven foreign nationals.

Lin told reporters at the memorial service that the premier is highly concerned over the accident and has held two meetings to give instructions for dealing with the aftermath, including the identification of remains and compensation payments for victims' families.

Siew has also directed that a nationwide memorial ceremony be held after all immediate matters related to the crash have been properly concluded, the minister said, adding that the premier hopes the tragedy will be taken as a lesson by all related institutions that aviation safety can never be neglected.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIDE GAP REMAINS OVER LIQUOR TAXES IN TAIWAN-EU WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will begin a new round of talks with the European Union (EU) on Tuesday to discuss the island's bid for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Jean-Pierre de Laet, deputy head of the EU unit in charge of WTO talks with Taiwan, and Chen Ruey-lung, director general of the ROC Board of Foreign Trade, will lead the delegations for their respective sides.
Officials noted that the two sides remain far apart on Taiwan's monopoly taxes on imported liquors from European countries.

ROC Vice Minister of Economics Lin Yi-fu said earlier that after more than four years of talks with the EU on terms for Taiwan's entry into the world trade regulatory body, 90 percent of the contentious issues have been resolved.
But there is still a wide difference on imports into Taiwan of whiskey and brandy from EU members, which is the most thorny issue of the talks, Lin added.

With the steep depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar and the inroads made by Japanese whiskey imports into the local market during the past year, the market share for Scotch whisky and French cognac in Taiwan has fallen dramatically.

Against this background, the Taipei-based European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT), British Trade and Cultural Office, and the Scotch Whisky Association recently called on the officials from the Ministry of Finance to complain about the loss of competitiveness by their nations and to seek redress for what they called "unfair treatment."

The ECCT said that if Taiwan fails to satisfactorily address the problem, it will seek to put the issue on the table during the upcoming talks. In addition, it will not rule out the possibility of suggesting that the EU impose heavy tariffs on imported goods from Taiwan.

Taiwan currently imposes a monopoly tax of NT$1,000 (US$30.48) per liter of French cognac, compared with NT$500 for per liter of brandy from other nations. Taiwan also imposes a monopoly tax of NT$440 for per liter of Scotch whisky, compared with NT$198 for per liter of whiskey from other countries.
European liquor manufacturers said the tax is discriminatory toward their products.

The Scotch Whisky Association said sales of scotch in Taiwan have been cut by 10 million pounds due to the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar and the influx of Japanese whiskey imports since last year.
Taiwan has so far completed talks with 24 of 26 WTO members who requested bilateral negotiations with Taiwan on its bid to enter the WTO.
