With the conclusion of such talks with the United States over the weekend, Taiwan is hoping to quickly conclude negotiations with the two remaining WTO signatories, the 15-member EU and Switzerland, and to clear up all outstanding bilateral consultations by early March.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LIEN CHAN LEAVES FOR JORDAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan left for Jordan on Monday for a private visit aimed at boosting bilateral friendship and cooperation.
Lien will make a transit stop in Bangkok and is scheduled to arrive in Amman at around 5:00 p.m. (Taipei time).
Reliable sources said Lien will receive an honorary doctorate from Jordan University on Tuesday. He is also expected to meet with Jordanian officials during his stay there.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, Jordan has long been friendly toward the Republic of China. Jordan recognizes Beijing, but allows the Taipei representative office in Amman to bear the ROC's official national title. ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a private visit to Jordan in 1995.
Lien will travel to Lebanon and Bahrain following his Jordan visit, the sources said. The two Middle East states also do not maintain official ties with the ROC.
Bahrain is a major Middle East oil exporter and an important base for the US Navy Fifth Fleet. Lien will be the first senior ROC official to visit the Persian Gulf emirate in recent years.
This is Lien's second trip abroad so far this year. He traveled to Singapore in January.

Following his Middle East journey, Lien is also expected to make a stopover in Kuala Lumpur to meet with senior Malaysian officials, including Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, to discuss effective measures to cope with the current Asian financial woes. Anwar made a brief private visit to Taipei earlier this month.

The government is tight-lipped on Lien's current overseas visit to avoid affecting his itinerary. Premature exposure caused some troubles for the vice president during his visit to Singapore early this year.

Mainland China has been waging an extensive campaign against the ROC's diplomatic activities in an attempt to isolate Taiwan in the international community. Against this backdrop, senior ROC officials often keep their overseas travel plans secret or low-profile. Previous experience has that protests from Beijing can force changes in such plans.

It remains unclear whether Lien will travel to Europe following his Middle East tour. He had planned to visit Spain to receive an honorary doctorate degree from Madrid University last year, but he was forced to give up the trip because of Beijing's protests.

Despite Beijing's pressure, Lien still had managed to visit several major countries which do not maintain formal diploamtic ties with the ROC in the past few years, including the Czech Republic, Austria, Ukraine, Iceland and Ireland.

On his Middle East visit, Lien is being accompanied by his wife and several senior government officials and close aides, including Minister Without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi. Lien is scheduled to return to Taipei on March 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO PRESIDE OVER CONFAB ON ABORIGINAL POLICY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui will personally preside over a high-level meeting to examine governmental policies aimed at improving the livelihood of Taiwan's aboriginal peoples, sources from the Presidential Office said on Monday.

After a trip to an Atayal tribal village in Fuhsing, in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, on Sunday, Lee said he realized more than ever that the welfare of Taiwan's aborigines has been neglected for too long.
He said policies on aborigines' living rights, sustainable development of their cultures, education and employment rights should be comprehensively overhauled.

The visit to the Atayal village in Fuhsing was the third of its kind undertaken by Lee since the beginning of this year in an effort to better understand the aboriginal people's way of life. Earlier in the day, Lee also visited an aboriginal village under the Sanying Bridge in Taipei County.

Last month, Lee visited an aboriginal village in Hsichih, suburban Taipei, where some 500 indigenous people originally from eastern Taiwan's Hualien and Taitung counties reside in shacks without electricity or running water.

Lee said justice and righteousness are two vital ingredients for the sustainable development of a society or nation. Thus, he added, securing the social rights of Taiwan's aboriginal people, women and children, as well as the island's less-privileged groups, has become a priority task for the government.
Accompanying Lee during the trip to Fuhsing was Legislator Kao Yang-sheng, an Atayal lawmaker representing the ruling Kuomintang in the Legislative Yuan.
Kao elaborated upon the plight of aborigines around the island, numbering roughly 360,000 and representing nine tribes, to the president.

Citing unfair land policy as one of the major complaints of the island's poorest ethnic group, he said some areas in Alishan, Heping, Fuhsing and Wusheh have been unreasonably restricted from use by the aborigines, the original inhabitants of those areas, so that their immediate livelihood has been threatened.
Kao urged the government to return parts of the land to the aborigines, help them in employment opportunities, and financially assist in the preservation of their diverse yet endangered cultures.
About one-tenth of the island's aborigines now live in outlying areas of greater Taipei. Most of them are poor and have little hope of leading better lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC PLANE SKIDS OFF RUNWAY, NO CASUALTIES REPORTED

TEXT.P: No injures or casualties were reported when a Far East Air Transport Corp. plane skidded off the end of the runway upon landing at Taipei's Sungshan domestic airport on Monday, airline officials here said.
The Boeing 757 plane took off at 11:05 a.m. from Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, and landed at the Sungshan airport at 11:55 a.m. when the incident took place.
Far East officials suggested the mishap may have been caused by slippery conditions on the runway due to steady rains over the past several days, and said they are trying to learn more details.
The Civil Aeronautic Administration has also sent a team to investigate the incident.
The runway mishap caused a scare among passengers as it came in the wake of a China Airlines plane crash last Monday that killed all 196 persons onboard in Taiwan's worst-ever air disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS SECRETARY-GENERAL ON CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: If Taipei agrees to engage in political negotiations, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) is ready to immediately begin talks, ARATS Secretary-General Zhang Jincheng said over the weekend.

He added that ARATS is also willing to expand contacts and strengthen cross-strait communications channels prior to the start of procedural discussions for political negotiations and the resumption of economic and protocol-related talks.

Zhang made the remarks on Saturday when he attended a seminar sponsored by the California-based Alliance for China Reunification, China Council for Promoting Peaceful Reunification, and the Institute of China Political Strategy.

Cross-strait political negotiations, Zhang said, should address all issues that create tension between Taipei and Beijing, including matters pertaining to the termination of cross-strait hostility and the political questions which concern Taiwan.

Zhang said that ARATS will continue to actively promote political negotiations with its Taipei-based counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation, in order to establish suitable conditions for the improvement and further development of cross-strait relations.

He said: "The political negotiations we advocate are divided into several phases, and will be carried out step by step. Firstly, we must talk about putting an end to hostility between the two sides, and that means not talking about the issue of reunification immediately. It is evident that we have paid adequate consideration to the present realities and to Taiwan's doubts and concerns about relations across the strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO MEMBERSHIP IRRELEVANT TO 'THREE DIRECT LINKS': MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not be forced into opening direct trade, postal and transportation links with mainland China even if the two archrivals are both allowed to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), a spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday.

Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the MAC, Taiwan's top agency in charge of mainland Chinese affairs, noted that the timing of Taiwan's and mainland China's entry into the WTO remains up in the air. But even if both sides gain membership, Taiwan will not be obliged to open the so-called "three direct links" with the mainland. he said.

The existing WTO protocol does not require members of the world trade regulatory body to directly engage in transportation or investment exchanges, therefore Taiwan will not necessarily alter its current policies regarding such links with mainland China after the WTO accession, Sheu noted.
Taiwan, however, will inevitably liberalize parts of its trade regime upon admission to the WTO so as to comply with the organization's rules and its spirit of free trade, Sheu added.
Those issues, including the liberalization of some areas of the island's trade and financial sectors, will be the responsibility of relevant government agencies to tackle, Sheu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENSIONS BETWEEN AUSTRALIA AND JAPAN OVER TUNA CATCH INTENSIFY

TEXT.P: Tensions between Australia and Japan over tuna fishing intensified after Tokyo announced it would increase the catch of the endangered southern bluefin tuna to 8,000 tons a year from the current quota of 6,000 tons.

Australian Resources and Energy Minister Warwick Parer said his department is arranging an emergency meeting with its Japanese counterpart in order to avert the collapse of the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna in Australia's territorial waters.
He said Australia could not accept Japan's plan to increase the tuna catch because the stock of the fish is depleting.
"Australia cannot accept Japan's position. Our fisheries scientists believe that the stock is severely depleted and that the proposed catch increase is unsustainable," he told reporters Sunday.
Australia and Japan annually hold talks to set the quota of tuna catch. Japanese fishing vessels must be licensed to operate in Australia's exclusive economic zone, Parer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND GDP GROWTH SACRIFICED FOR CURRENCY RATE

TEXT.P: Mainland China's pledge to maintain its currency at the present level is expected to cost its economic growth rate by three percentage points, according to Beijing's vice minister for foreign trade and economic cooperation, Long Yongtu.

Long, currently on a visit to Australia, told a conference at the Australian National University in Canberra that Beijing would not devalue its currency to boost trade competitiveness because this would set off a new round of destabilization in the Asian region.

He said, however, that the Asian economic crisis would cause mainland China's gross domestic product growth to slow from the 10 percent to 11 percent seen over the past few years to about 8 percent in 1998.
He said the growth would be achieved only because of the US$750 billion infrastructure program unveiled by mainland Chinese officials at the recent World Economic Forum in Davos, the Philippines.
He said Beijing would push ahead with reforms to its banking and finance sector to insulate the mainland economy from the effects of the Asian crisis.
Long said mainland China was ready to accept slower export growth and considerably more imports in order to play its part in overcoming the problems now facing Asia.
He said Beijing would resist the pressure to devalue its currency.
"A devaluation of the yuan would also trigger a new round of competitiveness devaluations in the region," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE SCIENTISTS DEVELOP 'ELECTRONIC BIRD' TO PROSPECT COOPER, GOLD AND OTHER METALS

TEXT.P: Australian scientists have developed a revolutionary "electronic bird" that will make possible prospecting for buried copper, gold, lead, zinc, nickel and even diamond deposits from the sky.
The bird resembles a two-meter-long torpedo and is towed by aircraft flying just 100 meters above the ground. It is expected to open up vast areas of Australia for mineral exploration.

The new device was developed by scientists of the Cooperative Research Center for Australian Minerals Explorations Technologies of Macquarie University in New South Wales following a six-year research project, according to mass-circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald.

Instead of the costly and laborious process of drilling through rock, the bird utilizes the fact that all minerals -- and the types of ground they are buried in -- conduct electricity to varying degrees.

Electrical bursts are sent along a wire wrapped around the bird's tow plane at intervals of up to 500 times per second, creating a magnetic field. This causes weak electric currents to flow through the earth, producing tell-tale magnetic fields which in turn are monitored by the device, according to Dr. Brian Spies, director of the research center at Macquarie University.
He said the buried minerals can be identified by analyzing variations in the man-made magnetic fields.
He said the electronic bird was developed from work begun in Scandinavia and Canada in the late 1940s.
"Australia is now recognized as a world leader in this technology," he said. "With the sensitivity we have developed we can now get a 3-D (dimension) image of the ground."
He said he believes the new device will be widely used in exploring for large mineral deposits in Australia as well as abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS TALK ABOUT RELATIONS WITH MAINLAND CHINA (1)

TEXT.P: Government officials and leaders of political parties in Taiwan have recently talked about policies toward mainland China, with most of them saying that friendly exchanges and talks are important to the improvement of the relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

Premier Vincent Siew of the Republic of China showed a gesture of goodwill to mainland China Friday when he delivered an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan on the first day of the current legislative session.

When talking about dialogues between Taiwan and mainland China, Siew said all subjects that may contribute to peaceful development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and relate to democratic unification of the nation may be put forth step by step for discussion.

Last month, Beijing repeated its calls for holding political talks with Taiwan under the principle of "one China." The calls are believed by people here to be Beijing's attempt to annex Taiwan "in name."

Talks between the heads of the two sides' semi-official intermediary organizations, Koo Chen-fu of the Taipei-based Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Wang Daohan of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) were held for the first time in Singapore in April, 1993. Their consultations, focused mainly on problems arising from the increasing civilian exchanges, are usually called "technical" talks, or Koo-Wang talks.

The preparations for the second round of Koo-Wang talks were unilaterally disrupted by Beijing in June, 1995 soon after President Lee Teng-hui's private visit to the United States angered Beijing leaders.

Beijing has since insisted that the technical talks won't be resumed unless Taiwan agrees to hold political talks on unification under the principle of "one China," which is communist China. Beijing has also insisted on its "one country, two system" formula for unification with Taiwan.

Premier Siew's remark is believed to be a gesture of goodwill to Beijing by analysts in Taipei, because it implies that political issues, if they are conducive to peaceful development and democratic unification, may also be put forth for talks between the two sides.

He said those technical issues which are directly related to the interests of the people on Taiwan and the Chinese mainland and have formerly been selected for consultations in the second round of Koo-Wang talks should be given priority.
Siew stressed that new talks should start from the agenda of the second round of Koo-Wang talks, which has been postponed since June, 1995.

Siew said the government will persistently carry out its policy of "eliminating hostility through communications and replacing confrontation with consultations" with sincerity and goodwill. The government is trying to promote cross-strait exchanges and discussions under the principles of mutual respect, equality, and mutual benefit to create a "win-win" situation for both sides, he added.

He expressed the hope that Beijing will agree to resume Koo-Wang talks and reopen the channel of communications established in the first round of the talks as soon as possible for the prosperity and peaceful development of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"The door of cross-strait discussions is always open, and the government is holding positive and pragmatic attitudes toward cross-strait relations," he added. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS TALK ABOUT RELATIONS WITH MAINLAND CHINA (2)

TEXT.P: Meanwhile, Vice President Lien Chan recently set forth "three nos and three yeses" as an approach to improvement of cross-strait relations.

The three "nos" are no declaration of independence, no hurry to unify with the Chinese mainland, and no antagonism, and the three "yeses" are yes to peace, yes to friendly exchanges, and yes to a "win-win" situation for both sides. There is no need to declare independence, because the country has been a sovereign state since its establishment in 1912, he explained.

The approach will provide the best condition for promoting friendly exchanges and moving toward eventual reunification of the Chinese nation, he said, adding that continuous exchanges would enhance mutual understanding and reduce hostilities, and thus prevent conflicts between the two sides.
Lien pointed out that a "latent antagonistic atmosphere" still lingers. Beijing is now hoping to annex Taiwan "in name," he said.

He said Taiwan and mainland China will eventually be able to reach their common goal of national unification under the principles of freedom, democracy, and equal distribution of wealth, if the two sides can sit down "to resume their talks without setting preconditions and excluding any particular issues."

Analysts here believe that Beijing is very unlikely to give up such preconditions as the "one China" principle and the "one China, two system" formula for unification. Beijing also dislikes the rhetoric of "unification under the principles of freedom, democracy, and equal distribution of wealth," because its ultimate goal is to put Taiwan under communist rule.

They also believe that Beijing would hate to talk with Taipei about human rights, private property, freedom of the press, multi-party political system, free economy, and many other values of the free world.
Lien made the remarks on Feb. 19 in an international conference on "The People's Republic of China after the 15th Party Congress," which was held in Beijing in September, 1997.
Some 30 factional leaders of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) debated policies toward mainland China in a seminar sponsored by the party on Feb. 13-15 in Taipei.

In the beginning of the three-day seminar, Hsu Hsin-liang, DPP chairman and leader of the Formosa Faction, stressed that Taiwan should "boldly deal with the west side of the Taiwan Strait" for economic and trade reasons. His position was strongly criticized by leaders of other factions. At the end of the meeting, the DPP leaders reached the consensus that Taiwan should "strengthen its base and deal with the west side."
John Chang, secretary general of the ruling Kuomintang, said Saturday that the consensus "clearly endorses" the ruling party's long-standing policy toward mainland China.
At the seminar, the DPP leaders also declared that Taiwan is a sovereign state, whose sovereignty will never be negotiated , and that Taiwan can hold "all-dimension talks" with mainland China.
By "all-dimension talks," they mean that Taiwan can talk with mainland China on all kinds of subjects, so that talks can go on and on without ending.
The DPP participants in the seminar were criticized by some analysts as being too naive and ignorant of Beijing's strategy and ambition to annex Taiwan.

Chang Jung-kung, director general of the Mainland Operations Department of the Kuomintang Central Committee, said last week that the debate made the DPP look more able to keep up with cross-strait situations now than it was in April, 1993 when it sent representatives to Singapore to protest against the first round of Koo-Wang talks being held there.

Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who is a DPP leader but did not participate in the debate, said last week that the opposition party's pro-Taiwan independence platform is the "mainstream position" of the party, which had not been changed by the debate in any way.

The platform says that Taiwan is a sovereign state independent of the People's Republic of China. There is one country on either side of the Taiwan Strait. "Taiwan is not a part or a vassal of China," Chen said. The position is in sharp contrast with that of communist China.

Vice President Lien pointed out in the international conference on mainland China that one of the factors underlying the post-1995 stalemate in cross-strait relations is the big difference in political development between mainland China and Taiwan. The mainland is governed by a Leninist, one-party dictatorship, while Taiwan is ruled by a democratic government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNEMPLOYMENT DROPS TO 22-MONTH LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped to 2.35 percent in January, marking a 22-month low since April 1996, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Monday.
According to DGBAS tallies, the January unemployment rate was 2.35 percent, down 0.1 percentage points from December's figure, and 0.33 percentage points less than the year-earlier level.
The DGBAS attributed January's relatively lower unemployment to increased employment in the service sector, which saw an increase of 26,000 employees over December.

In January, 224,000 of Taiwan's workforce were reportedly jobless, down some 10,000 from the previous month, while the number of people who lost their jobs due to workplace closures or downsizing declined 18,000 in comparison with the same month of last year.
The number of first-time job seekers and the number of those who quit because of dissatisfaction with their jobs also declined 28,000 in January from the year-earlier level, the DGBAS reported.

Average periods of unemployment in January, however, were found to be getting longer, with the tallies showing an average wait of 25 weeks before an unemployed person finds a new job, one week longer than in the previous month.
First-time job seekers, meanwhile, stayed idle for an average of 27 weeks before finding a job, one week longer than the period reported in December, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN EXPERTS ANALYZING CAL BLACK BOX

TEXT.P: Experts from Australia's Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) are giving top priority to analyzing the data contained in the flight data and cockpit voice recorders taken from the China Airlines (CAL) Airbus 300-600R which crashed on Feb. 16, killing 202 people in Taiwan's worst-ever air disaster.

In an interview with the CNA on Monday, Spencer Long, leader of the five-man investigating team from Taiwan, said the Australian experts have worked long and hard with his team to help analyze the data.
"We are very grateful and satisfied with the assistance they are giving us. The analysis of the data is quite satisfactory," Long said.

"From our preliminary analysis, the data contained in the black box and voice recorder are almost complete," Long said. But he declined to give details because he said the investigation results are only one of 15 items which will be evaluated to determine the main cause of the crash.
He said the Civil Aviation Administration (CAA) of Taiwan's Ministry of Transport and Communications will collate the rest of the information before drawing any conclusions.

"I cannot say anything about the data recovered from the black box and voice recorder because it serves only as partial evidence of the factors behind the crash," he said, adding that the analysis will take several weeks to complete.
The team is expected to return to Taipei soon to make an initial report to the CAA about its preliminary findings, Long said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU CONCLUDES SIX-COUNTRY AFRICAN DIPLOMATIC TOUR

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu returned to Taipei on Monday after winding up a six-country African visit aimed at shoring up the ROC's diplomatic ties with its allies in the region.
Hu described his 10-day diplomatic tour as "fruitful and significant," saying that the visit has attracted extensive media coverage in Africa and created a "Taiwan whirlwind" there.

Hu's trip took him to Chad, Guinea-Bissau, The Gambia, Liberia, Sao Tome and Principe, and Burkina Faso. "I received warm welcomes in all these countries," the foreign minister said, adding that the six countries have all expressed a strong desire to reinforce bilateral relationships and expand cooperation with the ROC.

Hu went on to say that many of the senior officials he met told him that the main purpose of their engagement with the ROC is to learn from the `Taiwan Experience' to help boost their own economic development.

Against this background, Hu said, the government and the private sector should join forces to introduce Taiwan's experience in economic development and business management to the country's African allies to help cement bilateral ties.

"We should work even harder to assist our allies in development in various fields, so that they will feel it a glory to maintain diplomatic relations with the ROC," Hu said. "This will help create a `lighthouse effect,' shining a beacon that will attract more countries to forge ties with us."

The ROC has dispatched agricultural, medical, handicraft and engineering missions to many other developing countries over the past several decades to help them implement economic development and infrastructure construction projects, Hu said.
However, he stressed that these efforts should not be interpreted as "checkbook diplomacy." Compared with other countries, Hu said, the ROC's financial aid to its allies remains limited.

For instance, France alone offers US$140 million in aid to Burkina Faso annually, and the annual aid from the European Union to the French-speaking West African country also reaches US$130 million. Many other advanced countries, including the United States, Canada, Denmark and Spain, also offer far more aid to that country than the ROC.

Hu pointed out that the ROC's annual budget for foreign aid accounts for less than 0.1 percent of its Gross National Product (GNP), far lower than the 0.7 percent level set by the United Nations for advanced countries. "I hope the government will increase the foreign aid budget to 0.175 percent of our GNP to enable more of our allies to share the Taiwan Experience," he said.

During his visit, Hu also discussed with relevant African officials the itinerary of President Lee Teng-hui's planned visit to several African countries in late March. The itinerary will be formally announced either late this month or in early March.

In related news, Hu touched on Vice President Lien Chan's ongoing Middle East visit, which he described as part of the ROC's "outreach" efforts to counter Beijing's extensive campaign to isolate Taiwan in the international community.

"We must walk out boldly and firmly into the world arena," Hu said, adding that the ROC should not let Beijing feel it can succeed in depriving Taiwan of all opportunities to forge ties abroad. "To walk out is critical to our survival," he emphasized.

Hu said he earnestly hopes the mainland Chinese authorities will understand that they cannot and need not block the ROC's international activities. "Based on this understanding, relations across the Taiwan Strait will be able to move forward even more smoothly and swiftly," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.026 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at NT$32.852.
The greenback opened at the day's low of 32.823 and had a high of 32.93.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$248 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved up 0.6 percent on the Taiwan stock exchange on Monday, with the weighted price index, the market's key indicator, rising 58.19 points to close at 9,147, the highest level of this year.
Dealers said a confident sentiment prompted retail investors to engage in brisk trade as positive market information emerged.
The bourse opened at 9,126.5, and experienced a high of 9,169.84 and a low of 9,074.62.
Advancing stocks outnumbered those dropping 319 to 136, with 36 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 4.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$226.73 billion (US$6.91 billion) in the three-hour trading session, up from the 3.18 billion issues valued at NT$183.82 billion (US$5.6 billion) which were traded in the previous session.

Cement stocks jumped the highest, at 4.2 percent, followed by construction issues, which surged 4.0 percent, paper-making shares, which rose 3.5 percent, textile stocks, which climbed 2.9 percent, plastic and chemical issues, which increased 1.2 percent, and financial issues, which moved up 0.7 percent.
Electrical engineering stocks dropped 0.9 percent and foodstuff issues declined 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRONIC LEADERS AGREE ON ENCRYPTION TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: Five leading computer and commercial electronics companies have agreed on a plan to use encryption technology to prevent users making illegal copies of digital movies, software and other digital recordings, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Monday.

Intel of the US and Hitachi, Matsushita, Sony and Toshiba of Japan have jointly developed the encoding method, which could be used to protect copyright materials transmitted via the Internet, over TV cable systems or between home electronics systems, the WTO report said.

The technology would prevent piracy of digital recordings such as compact discs (CDs) and the latest digital video discs (DVDs). It could also be used to block copying of "pay per view" TV transmissions.
High definition TV sets, personal computers, DVD players, digital audio cassette recorders and TV set-up boxes could be equipped with the encryption technology, the WTO report said.
The system would require a password to be entered before copyrighted material could be transferred from one device to another.

There has been widespread concern within the entertainment industry about the potential for illicit copying of digital recordings, because without encryption, it would be possible for users to make perfect copies of music, movies or software at little cost.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT LIEN LEAVES BANGKOK FOR JORDAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan left Bangkok for the Middle Eastern country of Jordan on Monday afternoon following a brief transit stop here.
Speaking to reporters at Bangkok airport, Lien said he hopes to keep his Middle East visit at a low profile, since excessive media hype may affect his itinerary.
In addition to Jordan, Lien is also expected to visit Lebanon and Bahrain. None of the three countries maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.
Lien is scheduled to arrive in Amman, capital of Jordan, at around midnight (local time).
This is Lien's second trip abroad so far this year. He visited Singapore in January.
Reliable sources said Lien will receive an honorary doctorate from Jordan University on Tuesday. He is also expected to meet with Jordanian officials during his stay there.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, Jordan has long been friendly toward the Republic of China. Jordan recognizes Beijing, but allows the Taipei representative office in Amman to bear the ROC's official national title. ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a private visit to Jordan in 1995.
Lien will travel to Lebanon and Bahrain following his Jordan visit, the sources said.
Bahrain is a major Middle East oil exporter and an important base for the US Navy Fifth Fleet. Lien will be the first senior ROC official to visit the Persian Gulf emirate in recent years.

Following his Middle East journey, Lien is also expected to make a stopover in Kuala Lumpur to meet with senior Malaysian officials, including Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, to discuss effective measures to cope with the current Asian financial woes. Anwar made a brief private visit to Taipei earlier this month.

The government is tight-lipped on Lien's current overseas visit to avoid affecting his itinerary. Premature exposure caused some troubles for the vice president during his visit to Singapore early this year.

Mainland China has been waging an extensive campaign against the ROC's diplomatic activities in an attempt to isolate Taiwan in the international community. Against this backdrop, senior ROC officials often keep their overseas travel plans secret or low-profile. Previous experience has that protests from Beijing can force changes in such plans.

It remains unclear whether Lien will travel to Europe following his Middle East tour. He had planned to visit Spain to receive an honorary doctorate degree from Madrid University last year, but he was forced to give up the trip because of Beijing's protests.

Despite Beijing's pressure, Lien still had managed to visit several major countries which do not maintain formal diploamtic ties with the ROC in the past few years, including the Czech Republic, Austria, Ukraine, Iceland and Ireland.

On his Middle East visit, Lien is being accompanied by his wife and several senior government officials and close aides, including Minister Without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi. Lien is scheduled to return to Taipei on March 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIXTH LAFAYETTE FRIGATE TO ARRIVE IN ROC SOON

TEXT.P: The last of six Lafayette-class frigates that Taiwan has ordered from France will arrive in Taiwan soon, Republic of China military sources said on Monday.
ROC naval officers and crew who took delivery of the frigate at a shipyard at the French port of Lorient on Jan. 16, are sailing the frigate to Taiwan.

After a 40-day, 24,000-kilometer voyage, the frigate, to be christened "Cheng Teh," will arrive at a southern Taiwan marine base, where high ranking central government officials will be invited to a ceremony to review the new vessel together with the five others that have already been delivered.
The new frigate will be commissioned in March, after which it will undergo a series of test-and-training operations before it is put into active service two months later.
Taiwan placed an order with France in 1991 for the six advanced frigates, for a total cost of US$2.3 billion.
In order to avoid possible protests or a boycott from mainland China, Taiwan and France kept the deal very low-profile. The first two ships were delivered in 1996 and the next three in 1997.
Taiwan naval personnel have been undergoing training in Lorient to learn how to operate and maintain the advanced frigates.

With a displacement of 3,500 tons and a top speed of 25 knots, the frigates' outer hull is clad with a special composite material which makes them less visible to radar and has earned them the nickname of "stealth frigate."

Upon arrival in Taiwan, the new frigate will be armed with the Phalanx air defense system, Sea Chaparral surface-to-surface missiles, domestically produced Hsiung-Feng anti-ship missiles and an anti-submarine helicopter.
The five other Lafayette frigates have been christened "Kang Ting," "Hsi Ning," "Kun Ming," "Ti Hua," and "Wu Chang."

The six new vessels, along with the six Knox-class ships Taiwan has on lease from the United States and eight locally-made Perry-class warships, will form the backbone of Taiwan's naval fleet, allowing it to phase out its fleet of aging destroyers.

As part of its overall military modernization program, Taiwan has also purchased 150 US-made F-16 fighter jets and 60 French-built Mirage 2000-5s, as well as 130 locally produced Indigenous Defense Fighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA MAGNATE GIVES PRIVATE MOVIE SCREENING FOR MAINLAND CHINESE LEADERS

TEXT.P: Media magnate Rupert Murdoch and his company, News Corp., have succeeded in winning the favor of mainland China's leaders and have strengthened their position to make inroads into the mainland market.

In a dispatch from Beijing, mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald's correspondent David Lague said Murdoch has won a tribute from mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, and his ministers and senior cadres, because he used a special screening of the multimillion dollar blockbuster "Titanic" to entertain them.

The News Corp.'s diplomacy seems to be paying off for the media giant as it recovers from Murdoch's damaging 1993 threat that satellite television was "an unambiguous threat to totalitarian regimes everywhere."

The daily quoted Bruce Dover, vice president of News Corp. in China, as saying that he organized the private viewing in the Chinese capital for Jiang and his ministers and senior cadres and that they liked the movie.
Dover has been coordinating News Corp.'s low-key recovery in mainland China through a series of joint venture business partnerships with mainland Chinese companies.
Media industry analysts report that the company is now in a strong position, as its major rivals, including Disney and Sony, have angered Beijing with films about Chinese repression in Tibet.

News Corp.'s businesses are already making headway in the tightly restricted mainland market. Through a 45 percent stake in the satellite Phoenix Channel, News Corp.'s Hong Kong-based Star TV claims it has an audience of about 36 million viewers in mainland China and has won approval to collect advertising fees from foreign companies in Guangdong Province, the daily reported.

In addition, News Corp.'s Internet service, PDN Xinren Information Technology Company, a joint venture with the Chinese Communist Party's official mouthpiece the People's Daily, now has the most popular Website in mainland China, the daily reported.
In order to win even more favors from Beijing, Murdoch is attempting to censor harsh criticism of the mainland leadership contained in a new book by former Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten.
Murdoch has told senior managers at his Harper Collins publishing company to ensure that observations about the mainland leadership are toned down, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO BUDGET NT$80 BILLION FOR ASSISTING FARMERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will form a task force to help local farmers tide over the difficulties they will face following the Republic of China's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), a senior official said on Monday.

"As far as the agriculture is concerned, the ROC has completed bilateral negotiations with all of the 26 WTO members which have expressed intentions to hold bilateral talks the ROC on terms for its WTO accesion," said COA Chairman Peng Tzuo-kuei.

In exchange for their support of the ROC's WTO bid, Taiwan has agreed to offer them greater market access to their agricultural products, services, industrial goods, wine and tobacco. Among them, the agricultural sector is expected to be hit hardest by tariff cuts and market-opening measures promised by the ROC in consultative procedures.

Peng said the COA's main task now is to help local farmers adapt themselves to the new market situation. "The COA will form a task force to draw up a comprehensive package of measures to cope with anticipated increasing competition from foreign suppliers of various agricultural products."
The task force, to be headed by COA Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung, will comprise government officials, academics and senior executives of major agricultural and relevant industrial associations.

Five panels will be established under the task force to study the current states of five agricultural sectors -- rice, vegetables and fruits, hog, poultry and fishery -- and work out strategies to address the possible adverse impact on all those sectors.

Peng said the government will set aside a budget of NT$86.9 billion (US$2.63 billion) over the next six years to help local farmers adjust production and marketing strategies and upgrade competitiveness. Part of the money will be used to help those who would not continue their agricultural or husbandry operations to switch to other professions.

Peng said the COA will spend about NT$48.2 billion helping local hog and poultry farmers adjust their production and marketing systems, and will also spend some NT$38.7 billion helping rice growers streamline production structure.

"Our top policy guideline is to assist those who want to stay in the agricultural sector to upgrade production and marketing strategies while helping those who want to swtich to other sectors succeed in their bids," Peng stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW MEETS WITH HERITAGE FOUNDATION PRESIDENT FUELNER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew of the Republic of China Monday received Heritage Foundation President Edwin J. Fuelner, Jr. in his office.
During the meeting, they talked about Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

When talking about cross-strait relations , Siew said Taiwan would be glad to talk step by step with mainland China on all subjects that may contribute to the peaceful development of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and relate to democratic unification of the nation.
He expressed the hope that American leaders may understand Taiwan's sincerity to improve the atmosphere for further talks between Taiwan and mainland China.
The Heritage Foundation is a prestigious conservative think-tank headquartered in Washington.
Siew said his government is optimistic about its bid to join the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC TO IMPROVE SERVICE TO OVERSEAS CHINESE

TEXT.P: Chiao Jen-ho, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in Taipei, said Monday that his commission will step up its efforts to serve overseas Chinese in the whole world.
Chiao made the remark when he met with representatives of overseas Chinese organizations in South Africa.
He said the government always tries to improve its service to overseas Chinese while promoting substantive relations with other countries.
He also expressed his gratitude to overseas Chinese leaders in South Africa for their help to Taiwan businessmen in South Africa and Lesotho in recent months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE WAGE ROSE SIGNIFICANTLY IN DECEMBER

TEXT.P: The average monthly wage in Taiwan was NT$38,600 (US$1,177) last year, up 4.07 percent from the year-earlier-level (adjusted for inflation), the highest rise in the past few years, according to official statistics.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Monday released new figures on wages and productivity on the island that showed an average wage of NT$38,800 (US$1,183) last December, up 12.02 percent from the previous month.
The December surge, higher than that of other months, was mainly due to many local companies distributing year-end bonuses and job-performance awards, the DGBAS said.

According to the DGBAS tallies, prompted by recovering economic development, over 5.52 million people were employed in the island's industrial and service sectors in 1997, up 0.95 percent from the level of the year before.
The industrial sector enjoyed an employment growth of 0.45 percent, with manufacturing scoring a 1.03 percent gain, the largest in this sector.

Employment in the service sector grew 0.75 percent, with the financial insurance and housing subsector showing demand for human forces by posting a 6.7 percent gain in employment, the statistics showed.

The service sector is emerging as the major creator of job opportunities on the island, the bureau said, citing that in 1997, the number of employees in the service sector had grown to reach 47.68 percent of the total in the industrial sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO VISIT FOUR AFRICAN COUNTRIES SOON

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China will visit four countries in Africa in late March and early April.
He is tentatively scheduled to arrive at Ouagadougou, capital of Burkina Faso, on March 30 for an official visit, and then visit Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, and Senegal in that order.
The itinerary of his 7-day trip to Africa will be announced in a few days, an informed source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET PUBLISHERS OF ILLEGAL DRUG MANUFACTURING INFORMATION TO FACE PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: A Taipei prosecutor said on Monday that people using the Internet to disseminate information in Taiwan on how to manufacture illegal drugs will face punishment under the present Republic of China Criminal Code.

Chin Cheng-hsiang, a public prosecutor of the Taipei Prosecutor's Office, was responding to news that the dissemination via cyberspace of pornography, and information on arms and drugs, is increasingly becoming a problem.

Chin noted that most of the website addresses tend to be located overseas, preventing effective investigation by local law enforcement authorities, although he added that the authorities are maintaining contact with their overseas counterparts to cooperate in the crackdown on cybercrime.

He said he believes that Internet discussions on the manufacture of illegal drugs have not yet reached the stage of actual manufacture, trafficking and distribution of drugs, and therefore may not be subject to the ROC's strict anti-drug regulations, whereby offenders face punishment of death or life in prison.

He added that under the current Penal Code, those found guilty of disseminating information on illegal drug manufacture can only be prosecuted for violation of public order, a crime which carries a relatively light punishment of up to two years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH FINE PREVENTS TAIWAN CREWMEN FROM RETURNING FROM SOMALIA

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese ship's captain and his 27 crewmen, accused of illegal fishing in Somali waters in the Indian Ocean, may not be returning to Taiwan soon as the ship's owner has said it is unable to pay the high fine to have them released.

The Shun Bin Fishing Company, owner of the fishing boat, said Monday that a court in Somalia sentenced the crew members to pay more than NT$48 million (US$1.5 million) in fines for poaching in Somali waters or face jail terms in excess of 10 years.

The Taiwanese fishing boat "Shun Kuo No. 11" -- with six Taiwan and 22 mainland Chinese fishermen on board -- was captured on Jan. 12 by three armed Somali speedboats. The crew has been in custody since then.
Shun Bin said that no local fishing company could afford such a high fine. It has commissioned the Far Eastern Shipping Company to handle the incident for it and to ensure the crew's safety.

On Feb. 16, the day after the captain and crew's trial, AFP reported that the prosecutor in the Somali Islamic court had demanded that the captain have his right hand and left foot amputated. The prosecutor also called for the vessel's 27 crewmen to be fined US$10,000 each, the report said.
Shun Bin said that it believes no one will have to face amputation over the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEES OPPORTUNITY FOR COOPERATION IN AEROSPACE DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Several international aerospace giants have shown interest in exploring the possibility of industrial cooperation with Taiwan's aerospace industry in the manufacture of regional aircraft, passenger aircraft, helicopters and engines, according to the Economics Ministry.

The Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development (CASID) under the Economics Ministry said Monday that Bell Helicopter Textron Inc., Dassault Aviation Concern, Sikorsky Corp. and Pratt-Whitney Corp. have written to the committee, asking to discuss the possibility of industrial cooperation during the Singapore Aviation Show, to kick off on Tuesday.

The Singapore Aviation Show is the largest of its kind in the Asia-Pacific area. Over 600 aerospace companies from 31 countries around the world are scheduled to take part in it this year. Nine Taiwanese companies, including Aerospace Industrial Development Corp., will present their latest developments in aerospace technology in the exhibition. This year's booth for the Taiwanese companies is three times the size of that of last year.

The Taiwanese aerospace industry will exhibit a Boeing 717 composite horizontal stabilizer, S-92 helicopter cockpit, CT-7 engine for the S-92 helicopter, AE-270 passenger airplanes, 16G passenger seats and airplane light fixtures.

The CASID said that with South Korea's, Indonesia's and Malaysia's plans to develop their aerospace industries adversely affected by the region's financial turmoil, Taiwan has a good chance to win industrial cooperation with international aerospace giants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-EU WTO TALKS TO OPEN TUESDAY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: On Tuesday, Taiwan will start its bilateral negotiations with the European Union (EU) as a whole on the island's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), the world's trade regulatory body, an economics official revealed here Monday.

Chen Ruey-long, chief of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, told the press the planned three days of talks will be held at the BOFT's Taipei headquarters and will cover issues including tobacco and wine, financial services, automobiles and industrial products.

According to the BOFT, the first day's agenda will include the issues of the taxation of industrial production and the opening of Taiwan's service market, while government procurement policies will be the major topic on the second day of talks.
Scheduled for the last day is the thorny problem of the island's opening to such European products as tobacco, wine, automobiles and diesel engines for cars.

Chen, who has been appointed Taiwan's top negotiator, said that he hopes the two sides can resolve all their differences at the Thursday meeting and thus conclude the penultimate talks over the island's accession to the WTO.
The only other economy that has not yet finished negotiations with Taipei over Taiwan's WTO membership is Switzerland.
Taiwan completed its WTO negotiations with the United States, its largest trade partner, last week.

In order to realize its goal of Taiwan joining the WTO in May, the government has mapped out that all required bilateral negotiations should be completed in March to facilitate the organization's review of Taiwan's membership application.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAIN, HAIL CAUSE OVER US$32 M. IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES
DOC.DATELINE: Chungshing New Village in Nantou, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: As of Monday, the heavy downpours and hail that have pummeled Taiwan for one week had caused over NT$1.05 billion (US$32.01 million) in agricultural losses on the island, the Taiwan Provincial Government's Department of Agriculture and Forestry said.
The department reported the figure included NT$1.04 billion in crop damage, NT$6.54 million in losses to fishing firms and NT$5.49 million in livestock losses.
So far, five cities and counties have already submitted the documentation necessary to apply for disaster relief funds, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH AND COMPENSATION SET STAGE FOR CUSTODY BATTLE

TEXT.P: An 18 year-old girl still grieving from the death of her father, stepmother and two half brothers in a recent airplane crash is facing troubles she says are due to the US$1.74 million she is to gain in compensation over the accident.

The girl, who identified herself only by the nickname of Hsiao Hsuan, made public her story in a press conference on Monday. She accused her natural mother of seeking to gain custody of her following the death of her father out of greed for the compensation she is to receive.

Huang Shun-fa, his wife, their two sons and his parents-in-law were passengers on the ill-fated China Airlines flight 676, which killed all 196 passengers and crew on board as well as six people on the ground when it crashed Feb. 16.

Huang had used his Diner's Club card to purchase the tickets for the family. Because of a Diner's Club policy, Hsiao Hsuan, the only survivor of the family, is entitled to US$580,000 for the deaths of her father and two brothers, a total of US$1.74 million.

Hsiao Hsuan, who wore sunglasses and used a hat to help cover her face in the press conference, said that she could not but question her natural mother's motives in seeking to gain custody of her now, asserting that ever since her parents got divorced when she was six years old, her mother seldom showed any concern for her.

She said that if her mother, Lan Tsai-yeh, really cares about her safety as she said in a press conference held on Saturday, she should agree to have her placed in the custody of the Social Department of the Kaohsiung Government.

Hsiao Hsuan also called her father a good father and a good husband, describing him as a man with a sense of responsibility and integrity. She said she hopes her mother will stop insulting her father.

Hsiao Hsuan said that the media exposure of the confrontation between her and her mother over the compensation issue has hurt her deeply and that she hasn't dared to stay at home for days but has had to live with friends of her father.
She also said that she has already made a will, and that if something happens to her, all the money she has will be used to establish a foundation in memory of her father.

Lan said on Saturday in a press conference that she seeks the custody of her daughter because she is concerned about her safety. She also said that she divorced Huang because he often beat her and had affairs with other women.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NAVAL MONTHLY CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT COOP. OVER SPRATLY ISSUE

TEXT.P: A Beijing military publication has called for cooperation between Taiwan and mainland China in handling the Spratly dispute.

Modern Vessels, a monthly published by the mainland Chinese navy, said that the Spratly issue could be the "starting point" of the process of China's unification since both sides have the "fewest conflicts" and "most mutual benefit" with regard to their stances on the Spratlys.

The Spratly Islands, consisting of around 100 islets and atolls in the South China Sea, reportedly sit on rich crude oil reserves. They are claimed in whole or in part by Taiwan, mainland China, the Philippines, Malaysia, Vietnam and Brunei.
Currently, Taiwan controls Taiping, the largest island in the chain, while mainland China and the Philippines each have eight islets, Vietnam 25, and Malaysia three.
"Taipei and Beijing adhere to the same position that the Spratly Islands are traditionally Chinese territory, a point that could serve as the basis of cross-strait cooperation," the monthly said.

"Concerted Taiwan-mainland action on the Spratly issue could shift long-time cross-strait confrontation into cooperation, thus increasing the cohesiveness of the Chinese and helping create a favorable climate for national unification," it added.

This is the first time that Beijing's military has openly called on Taiwan and the mainland to join hands to defend traditionally Chinese territory since mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, in his eight-point stance on policy toward Taiwan issued more than three years ago, urged both sides to jointly safeguard Chinese sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND ASEAN MINISTERIAL MEETING ON HAZE TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) environment ministers will hold the Second Ministerial Meeting on Haze in Kuching, Sarawak, Malaysia on Feb. 25 to review the progress of the Regional Haze Action Plan in the face of a new outbreak of forest fires in Indonesia early this month.

The objective of the meeting is to review the progress of the action plan, particularly the areas of the plan in which Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia are spearheading preventive measures, monitoring measures and the strengthening of fire fighting capabilities, the Singapore Ministry of the Environment said on Monday.
Environment Minister and Health Minister Yeo Cheow Tong will lead a four-member Singapore delegation participating in the meeting.

While in Kuching, Yeo will also attend a high-level segment of the Fourth Meeting of the Conference of Parties of the Basel Convention on Feb. 26. The Basel Convention deals with the transboundary movement of hazardous waste and toxic chemicals, the ministry said.

Under the Regional Haze Action Plan adopted by the ASEAN environment ministers in December last year, Singapore is to spearhead measures to monitor land and forest fires. Singapore monitors closely the development of land and forest fires through the use of satellite imaging.

Meanwhile, the Singapore Environment Ministry will convene a meeting of Singapore's Inter-Ministry Haze Task Force on Feb. 25, when the task force will reaffirm the action plans of the various ministries and government agencies to ameliorate the impact of smoke haze on the health and well-being of the public.

In 1994, this task force formulated a Smoke Haze Action Plan (HAP) to coordinate the overall approaches and action for minimizing the adverse impact of smoke haze. The HAP was reviewed and updated last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP KMT EXECUTIVE TO ATTEND KOREAN PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang, left for Seoul on Tuesday to attend the inauguration ceremony for South Korean President-elect Kim Dae-jung.
KMT sources said Chang will occupy a very conspicuous seat at Wednesday's ceremony, in an indication of the great importance South Korea attaches to its ties with Taiwan.

This is Chang's second trip to South Korea so far this month. He headed a high-level KMT delegation to Seoul on Feb. 11-14. During that visit, Chang met with South Korean Prime Minister-designate Kim Jong-pil, Parliamentarians Soon Se-il and Lew Sing-soo and several other influential figures of various political stripes.

However, Chang failed to meet South Korean President-elect Kim because of strong pressure from Beijing. Kim later apologized for the cancellation of their scheduled meeting through one of his close aides. The aide also asked Chang to forward a personal letter from Kim to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman.

Chang, a career diplomat, had been minister of foreign affairs before assuming his current post late last year. Chang once said he will actively promote the KMT's relations with major political parties of other countries as part of Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy drive.

Taiwan-South Korean relations have been at a low ebb since the two countries cut diplomatic ties in August 1992. Senior officials of both countries have expressed a desire to improve bilateral relations after the inauguration of the new Korean president.
