DOC.HEADLINE: WIFE OF TANG SHUBEI LEADS M'LAND ARTS DELEGATION TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Liang Wenfeng, wife of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Vice Chairman Tang Shubei, led a 29-member delegation of young artists from the mainland's China Central Television to Taiwan on Monday.
The delegation, the first of its kind to visit Taiwan, is composed of members of a professional group dedicated to cultivating young talent.
The current islandwide performance activity, sponsored by the China Youth Mainland Cultural and Educational Research Foundation, is aimed at promoting arts exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

The foundation provides training for children with talent in such areas as dancing, singing, playing musical instruments and performing Chinese opera. After becoming adults, many of the artists will work as performers for China Central Television.

Mrs. Tang is an adviser to the foundation and was chosen to lead the delegation to Taiwan. A press conference was held on Tuesday morning in Taipei to introduce the members of the group, all of whom are under 12 years of age.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOD PRICES DOWN IN SEVERAL INDONESIAN TOWNS

TEXT.P: The Indonesian government's efforts to lower the prices of basic commodities by selling directly to the public has shown positive results, a media report said Monday.
The government's "market operation" has brought about encouraging results in Semarang and Yogyakarta, two major Javanese cities.
In the traditional markets of Kotagede, Sentul and Prawirotaman in Yogyakarta, prices of all basic foodstuffs except rice dropped significantly, Antara news agency reported.
The price of cooking oil, for instance, steadily decreased over the last four days from 5,000 rupiah (71 US cents) per liter to 3,200 rupiah per liter, Antara quoted several traders as saying.
It reported that the price of wheat flour dropped from 1,000 rupiah per kilogram to 700 rupiah per kilogram, tapioca flour from 2,000 to 1,700 rupiah and sugar from 1,800 to 1,600 rupiah.
High-priced essential commodities had sparked rioting in several parts of the country over the past month. Rioters targeted mainly shops and property owned by entrepreneurs of Chinese descent.
Traders said the latest development in price levels was due to the government's market operation which enabled people to buy goods at prices lower than market rates.
Smooth delivery and easy terms of payment for cooking oil by distributors also attributed to the lower prices of essential commodities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN MILITARY CHIEF SAYS SOME PARTIES SEEK RADICAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The newly appointed chief of the Indonesian Armed Forces (ABRI), Gen. Wiranto, has said it is obvious that certain parties want radical political and economic reforms to occur in the country.

"Their secondary goal is to disrupt the upcoming general session of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR), but their primary goal is to institute total political and economic reforms, if necessary through radical means," Antara news agency quoted Wiranto as saying when handing over his former post as chief-of-staff of the Indonesian Army to his successor, Gen. Subagyo, at army headquarters in Jakarta on Monday.
He claimed that certain parties have attempted to incite the people to "act savagely" while the government is making an all-out effort to overcome the nation's monetary crisis.
The people should thus be vigilant of rumors that are aimed at provoking them to act and create instability in the country, he said.

He urged the military, particularly the army, to be prepared to fight off threats to the country's unity and stability, and to make efforts to strengthen the good relationship between the people and the military.
Wiranto also stated that the upcoming general session of the MPR is a channel by which the people's hopes and aspirations for a more democratic country will be addressed.
"That is why we have to ensure that the MPR session runs smoothly," he said.

The ceremony was also attended by Information Minister and former Army Chief of Staff Hartono, who was dressed in his military uniform, Coordinating Minister for People's Welfare Azwar Anas, five-star Gen. (Ret.) A.H. Nasution, and other senior military officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO NEWSLETTER TO BOOST CANADIAN UNDERSTANDING OF TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Many Canadians are not aware of the substantive relationship between their country and Taiwan. Taiwan's representative office in Canada is publishing a newsletter to change that.

In the first issue of the TECO Newsletter, which has just come out, Dr. Chin-yen Fang of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office said the publication aims to "contribute to a broader understanding within Canada of the importance of the bilateral economic and cultural relationship" between that country and Taiwan.

TECO was set up seven years ago to facilitate and promote the continued growth of the many business and cultural linkages that exist between Canada and Taiwan. TECO performs a function similar to the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT), which was set up in 1986.

The "substantive relationship" that the TECO representative was trying to make Canadians more aware of includes bilateral trade which exceeded 5 billion Canadian dollars in 1997. In fact, Fang noted, Taiwan is now Canada's eighth largest trading partner.

In addition to trade, "we are forming important personal linkages too," Fang pointed out. He explained that Canada is one of the preferred destinations for Taiwan tourists, thousands of Taiwan students are enrolled in Canadian universities, and Canada has become a target for many Taiwan business and investor immigrants.

He went on to say that one unanticipated result of Taiwan tourists visiting Banff and Niagara Falls is that "high quality Canadian specialties like maple syrup and ice wine have become popular products" in Taiwan. "Of course, Canadian gold coins have long been a favorite of Taiwanese collectors," he added.

The newsletter, to be published quarterly, will provide "factual information" to Canadians so they will have a better understanding of the nature of the Canada-Taiwan ties and the "many facets" of the relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN AEROSPACE SHOW '98 OPENS IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The Asian Aerospace Show '98, the largest and most prestigious aerospace event in the Asia-Pacific region, officially opened in Singapore on Monday night.

The opening ceremony was held at the Singapore International Convention and Exhibition Center in downtown Singapore. The show itself will open at the Changi Exhibition Center adjacent to the Changi Airport for a week from Tuesday through March 1.

Singapore Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Tan Keng Yam, the guest of honor at the opening ceremony, pointed out in his speech that with the rapid growth of air traffic in the Asian Pacific, Singapore is well-positioned to play a catalytic role to spur further growth of the aerospace industry in the region.
He cited three reasons for his assertion:

First, Singapore is a strong supporter of open skies policy. The adoption of an open skies policy by governments in the region, coupled with greater deregulation and liberalization, will help to build a more competitive aviation industry.

Second, in terms of aviation standards, Singapore promotes strict safety standards in the aerospace and air travel industry through high standards of engineering maintenance and repair, and stringent security at airports.
Third, Singapore is well-poised to act as an aerospace hub in the Asian Pacific from which companies can venture into the region.

Multinational aerospace companies are welcome to establish their operations in Singapore as a value-added location to capture new markets, expand in the region through further investments, and serve the growing needs of the Asian Pacific, he said.

Capitalizing on the growing markets, Singapore's aerospace industry has been expanding at a record pace. In 1997, the industry registered a healthy 17 percent growth in output to reach 1.84 billion Singapore dollars, he said. About 35 percent of the output was for the United States and Europe markets, while 65 percent was for the Asian markets, he added.

He stressed that Singapore is prepared to commit its resources, both personnel and money, in good times and bad, to develop the necessary capabilities for the Singapore Air Force (SAF) to fulfill its missions effectively to ensure the security of Singapore.
One such capability is attack helicopters, which he said, fits in well with the development of the SAF into a modern and balanced force.

The SAFE will proceed to acquire a small number of attack helicopters and will be calling tenders in the coming months, he told the audience, which mostly included representatives from several of the world's leading military and commercial aircraft manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL LEAVES FOR SEOUL TO ATTEND PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang, left for Seoul on Tuesday to attend the inauguration ceremony for South Korean President-elect Kim Dae-jung.
KMT sources said Chang will occupy a very conspicuous seat at Wednesday's ceremony, in an indication of the great importance South Korea attaches to its ties with Taiwan.

This is Chang's second trip to South Korea so far this month. He headed a high-level KMT delegation to Seoul on Feb. 11-14. During that visit, Chang met with South Korean Prime Minister-designate Kim Jong-pil, Parliamentarians Soon Se-il and Lew Sing-soo and several other influential figures of various political stripes.

However, Chang failed to meet South Korean President-elect Kim because of strong pressure from Beijing. Kim later apologized for the cancellation of their scheduled meeting through one of his close aides. The aide also asked Chang to forward a personal letter from Kim to ROC President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently serves as KMT chairman.

Chang, a career diplomat, had been minister of foreign affairs before assuming his current post late last year. Chang once said he will actively promote the KMT's relations with major political parties of other countries as part of Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy drive.

Taiwan-South Korean relations have been at a low ebb since the two countries cut diplomatic ties in August 1992. Senior officials of both countries have expressed a desire to improve bilateral relations after the inauguration of the new Korean president.

Chang said prior to his departure that the two countries should work hand in hand to improve bilateral ties based on the principles of equality and reciprocity. "With sincerity and good will, I believe many problems can be resolved smoothly and satisfactorily," he added.

South Korea has called for resumption of direct flight services between the two countries, which have been suspended since the break of bilateral diplomatic ties. ROC Foreign Ministry officials said the airlinks can be resumed only on a reciprocal basis.
Chang is scheduled to return to Taipei on Wednesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAR EAST PILOT SUSPENDED AFTER ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: The pilot of a Far East Air Transport plane which skidded off the runway at Taipei's domestic airport was suspended from duty for one month, airline officials said on Tuesday.

The Boeing 757, carrying 126 passengers, took off from Taiwan's southern city of Kaohsiung at 11:05 a.m. and landed at the Sungshan Airport in Taipei at 11:55 a.m., when the mishap happened. No one was injured in the incident.

Although the mishap could be partially attributed to slippery conditions on the runway due to steady rainfall over the past few days, investigators from the Civil Aeronautics Administration said pilot Hung Kuei-chih failed to follow standard procedure by slowing down the plane sufficiently after it touched down.

Far East officials said that Hung will be demoted to co-pilot for six months, effective Tuesday. He will be reinstated in his former position after six months only if he satisfactorily completes a series of tests.
The Boeing 757, which was slightly damaged in the accident, has been grounded for maintenance and repair work.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN FIRM ROBBED OF NT$1 BILLION WORTH OF MEMORY CHIPS

TEXT.P: A semiconductor manufacturing company in Taoyuan County, some 30 kilometers south of Taipei, was robbed of more than 3 million computer memory chips late Monday night, police said on Tuesday.
A spokesman for Expeditors Co. in Taoyuan's Luchu township said the stolen memory chips were valued an estimated NT$1 billion (US$30.3 million).

The spokesman said three armed men, donning raincoats and wearing gloves, broke into the company's offices at around 11:20 p.m. The robbers attacked Ho Yu-tang, an Expeditors department chief, cutting him with hunting knives and forcing him to open a guarded warehouse. They soon made away with more than 3 million memory chips.

During the attack, Ho sustained injuries to his chin and ears. In addition, the assailants tied his limbs with ropes before fleeing. Ho reported the case to police authorities Tuesday morning, immediately after he managed to break free.
Ho told police the intruders spoke in the Taiwanese dialect. But, as he was traumatized during the ordeal, Ho was unable to give an accurate physical description of the three men.
Police have formed a special task force to investigate the incident. A senior officer said he is confident the case can be broken as all the missing chips were marked with a model or batch number.

This was the second theft of memory chips reported here in less than a month. On Feb. 2, United Test Center in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan was also robbed of US$5 million worth of synchronous dynamic random access memory (SDRAM) chips. At least eight suspects involved in the case have been arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO HOLD FIRST MEETING OF 9TH NATIONAL PEOPLE'S CONGRESS

TEXT.P: The first meeting of mainland China's 9th National People's Congress is to open on March 5 in Beijing, with preparatory work proceeding as scheduled.

The last meeting of the Standing Committee of the 8th National People's Congress, slated to be held on Feb. 27-28, will put the final touches on the agenda and list of representatives for the 9th Congress.
The 8th National People's Congress convened a session on Monday, according to the mainland-based China News Service (CNS), which was presided over by Congress Chairman Qiao Shi.
Cao Zhi, secretary-general of the 8th Congress, gave a report at that gathering about the draft agenda for the 30th meeting of the 8th Congress, to be held at the end of this month, CNS reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S AFRICAN TRIP SAID NOT FINALIZED

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that President Lee Teng-hui's planned visit to Africa next month is still under assessment.
He was responding to an interpellation by Legislator Chen Hung-ki of the ruling Kuomintang in the Legislative Yuan when Chen asked if reports that Lee will delay his African trip were correct.

Siew said that, according to diplomatic protocol and procedures, visits by heads of state are announced only after the foreign affairs ministries from the relevant countries have confirmed all details regarding the trips.
The premier indicated that President Lee's trip is still on the drawing board and has yet to be finalized.

He also said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is still assessing whether the president will visit all nine African nations that currently maintain diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, or only some of those countries.

Officials from the Presidential Office said on Tuesday that Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who returned from a whirlwind six-nation trip to Africa on Monday, has yet to report to Lee, and that the president's own visit to that continent will not be finalized until he discusses relevant matters with the foreign minister.
Hu was unable to attend the legislative meeting due to a high fever.

According to the original itinerary, Lee was set to take a chartered plane to Burkina Faso via Europe in late March, with subsequent visits to Gambia, Guinea-Bissau and Senegal during a week-long trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S INFLATION UP 1.2 PERCENT IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Singapore's inflation rate rose 1.2 percent last month compared with the same month of last year, but it was 0.6 percent lower than in December 1997.
Health care costs jumped the most, by 5.9 percent, followed by housing costs, up 3.4 percent, and education and stationery, up 2.2 percent, according to the Singapore Bureau of Statistics.
On the downtrend were prices of clothing, transport and communication, as well as miscellaneous items.
Prices for transport and communication slid 2.1 percent on a year-on-year basis, while clothing was 1.7 percent lower and miscellaneous items fell a marginal 0.2 percent, the figures showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM SKEPTICAL ABOUT UN-IRAQI AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard, who has echoed the United States' cautious skepticism to the Middle East peace agreement signed between the United Nations and Iraq, has said Australia will keep its elite troops in the Persian Gulf region on standby.
Howard said Monday night that until details of the agreement were known and Saddam Hussein's intentions had been tested, he would support a continued allied military presence in the Gulf region.
The agreement has described been as a diplomatic breakthrough because it allows UN inspectors to unconditionally resume the search for Iraq's biological and chemical weapons.

Howard urged the United Nations to carry out inspections to the fullest extent as soon as possible and said Australian Special Air Service (SAS) troops would remain beyond the initial deployment period of three months if necessary.
"I think if we have got an agreement which allows inspections, I think that agreement should be tested to the fullest extent possible, as soon as possible," he said.

"It is only then we'll be satisfied, and I would never rely on Saddam Hussein's word until we do that. I would imagine that if it is everything that people are suggesting it is, then it would be tested by a full-scale inspection very soon, and unless -- and until -- that inspection is successfully carried out, there should be no withdrawal of forces," he said.
Howard said he expected the same kind of conditions on the length of the Australian military deployment would also apply to the US and British deployments.

The Australian National Security Committee is expected to hold a meeting Tuesday to consider the results of UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan's mission to Baghdad and to confirm the continuing presence of the 110 SAS troops and two Boeing 707 air refueling aircraft and their crews in the Gulf.

Defense sources here said the decision to leave troops in place was influenced by fears that Iraq may once again try to frustrate the weapons inspection work of the UN Special Commission if the threat of military retaliation is removed.
Howard said if war were avoided, "it will forever be to the credit of the United States and her allies, such as Australia and Britain."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SET TO IMPOSE ANTI-DUMPING LAWS AGAINST ASIAN PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Australia is set to impose anti-dumping laws to stem any financially stricken Asian countries from dumping their products into the local market in the wake of economic crisis.
Customs Minister Warren Truss is developing detailed proposals for the Cabinet in preparation for a statement on dumping later this month or early next month.

Truss is expected to implement the central findings of the 1996 report by businessman Lawrie Willett, who suggested that the government speed up dumping laws to prevent other countries from dumping their products into the Australian market.
The Industry Anti-dumping Task Force said the organization has been advised that the government was "about to move" on anti-dumping reform.
The task force's chairman, Bruce McAllen, said, "We are very concerned that Asian businesses will respond to the drying-up of domestic demand by exporting goods at variable cost."
He claimed that if the government refused to take action, it could cost Australia about 100,000 jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIFE OF TANG SHUBEI HOPES DELEGATION'S VISIT IS BENEFICIAL

TEXT.P: Although cross-strait talks have not yet resumed, cultural exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have begun.

Liang Wenfeng -- wife of Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- arrived in Taiwan on Monday at the head of the Milky Way Young Artists Delegation, a 29-member delegation of artists from the mainland's China Central Television.
Liang said that she hopes that through such cultural exchanges, people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can gain a better understanding of each other.

Ho King-wen, manager of the public relations department of the Ding Hsing Enterprise Company, which is one of the sponsors of the current activity, disclosed that the visit is likely the result of a journey to Beijing by Taiwan's Lan-Yang Artists delegation. When the Lan-Yang Artists were in Beijing, Tang suggested they perform together with the Milky Way Young Artists and that young mainland artists be invited to perform in Taiwan.

The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation will hold a banquet in Liang's honor Tuesday night. Furthermore, Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih has offered the southern Taiwan city's hospitality to Liang and the young artists when they perform there.
Liang said that her first impression of Taiwan is good, noting the island's prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF WELCOMES ARATS RESPONSE TO ITS PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) sent a letter to its Taiwan counterpart on Tuesday, saying it welcomes a visit to mainland China by Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland at an "appropriate time."
The ARATS said in its letter that C. F. Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) is welcome to visit the mainland at a proper time for political talks.

It further said appropriate-level officials of the two intermediary bodies can exchange visits to discuss technical details or procedural issues related to the opening of cross-strait political talks.

This was the first time the ARATS has made a formal response to the SEF proposal that its chairman visit the mainland to restart institutionalized technical talks broken off by Beijing in mid-1995. SEF had twice informed ARATS of such a proposal.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies founded by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow said he has transferred the ARATS letter to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which supervises SEF operations.

"Basically, we welcome ARATS' formal response to our proposal for Koo's visit to the mainland," Shi said, adding that Taiwan has consistently upheld that cross-strait dialogue should be resumed under the framework laid out in the first meeting SEF Chairman C. F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan held in Singapore in 1993.
Meanwhile, the MAC also expressed welcome to the long-overdue ARATS response the Taiwan-proposed visit to the mainland by SEF Chairman Koo.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.1 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$32.752.
The greenback opened at 32.803 and was traded between 32.751 and 32.81.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$285 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices declined 0.9 percent on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Tuesday on profit-taking.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the market's key indicator, dropped 80.54 points to close at 9,066.46.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 9,324.54 and experienced a low of 9,032.79.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 354 to 98, with 41 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 4.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$255.5 billion (US$7.79 billion) in the three-hour session.
Technology issues registered the only gain among the eight major stock categories, with a modest rise of 0.1 percent.

Paper-making shares plunged the most, at 4.5 percent, followed by cement stocks, which fell 3 percent; construction issues, 2.8 percent; textile shares, 2.6 percent; plastic and chemical stocks, 1.8 percent; foodstuff shares, 1.1 percent; and banking issues, 0.1 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, United Micro Electronics, ACER, Winbond Electronics, Mitac International, Kinpo Electronics, Tatung, Tycoons Group Enterprise, Orient Semiconductor Electronics and Mosel-Vitelic.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND PLEDGES TO IMPORT MORE GOODS

TEXT.P: Mainland China has assured Australia that it will reduce its huge trade surplus with its trading partners and buy more products from Australia and elsewhere.

Mainland Chinese Vice Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Long Yongtu, who is now visiting Canberra, said mainland China wants to reduce its US$26.5 billion world trade surplus through slashing its exports and buying more imported products.
Long said bilateral trade between mainland China and Australia trade will remain unaffected by the Asian economic crisis despite a slowing in growth in both economies.
"We are two countries both immune from this contagious disease, and we are lucky that your currency and our currency are both strong," he said.

Long, who has been closely associated with mainland China's economic reform and is Beijing's chief negotiator for mainland China's accession to the World Trade Organization, said Beijing is determined to maintain the value of the yuan.
"It's not an easy decision, because we know we have to pay some price, that is, to reduce our competitiveness and slow down our exports," he said.
But he said maintaining the value of the yuan is in mainland China's interest.
"We are not trying to be a leader in any way because the Chinese economy is still weak, but we are happy to play a part," Long said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST NEW MIGRANTS DON'T KNOW AUSTRALIA HAS 2-YEAR BAN ON DOLE

TEXT.P: Three out of every four newly arrived migrants do not know that the Australian government bans them from claiming welfare benefits for two years, according to a new survey.
The survey shows nearly 60 percent of new migrants said they had no knowledge of the government's two-year waiting period for migrants until they actually arrived in Australia.
Another 15 percent did not discover they had no right to welfare until they visited a social security office, according to the survey by the New South Wales Ethnic Communities Council in Sydney.
The study, which interviewed 95 new migrants from 22 different cultural backgrounds, found only 24 percent knew of the two-year waiting period before they arrived in Australia.

Lawyers, welfare workers, academics and ethnic community leaders gathered together in a meeting in Sydney on Monday to outline strategies for a campaign to pressure the Australian government to amend the controversial migrant welfare legislation introduced in March 1997.

The measure was introduced in order to stem new migrants from claiming social welfare because the government, which is trying to reduce its budget deficit and cut down Australia's US$146 billion foreign debt, is under financial constraints.

The Australian government has criticized its overseas embassies for providing misleading and incomplete information to migrants on critical matters such as job prospects, welfare payments and cost of living.
The Welfare Rights Center in Sydney said the refusal to grant new migrants access to special benefits -- a payment of A$290 (US$192) each fortnight for a destitute adult -- was particularly harsh.
"This government is making people face destitution when they arrive in Australia," a center spokeswoman said.
In 1997-98, the Australian government will sharply reduce its immigration quota to about 68,000, down from nearly 100,000 in 1996-97.

Most migrants coming to Australia from Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong and South Korea are business migrants, bringing lots of money. But those coming from Eastern Europe, Vietnam, mainland China, the Philippines and Indochina are more often either skilled workers or relatives for family reunions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORDERS RECEIVED BY TAIWAN EXPORTERS DOWN IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: The value of orders received by Taiwan exporters in January totaled US$8,460 million, a drop of 14.28 percent from a year earlier, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The statistics showed that the value of January orders from the United States totaled US$2,850 million, an increase of 4.05 percent, while the value of orders from Hong Kong in the month dropped 30.21 percent to US$1,260 million. The value of orders from Japan and Europe also plunged 28.92 percent and 1.83 percent respectively from January, 1997.
The value of orders received in January for transportation, information and communications equipment was higher than a year earlier, the statistics showed.

The number of working days in last month was five less than a year ago, because the Chinese New Year fell in January this year. This may be attributable to the reduction in the value of export orders received last month, an official of the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LIEN RECEIVES HONORARY DOCTORATE FROM UNI. OF JORDAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan of the Republic of China received Tuesday an honorary doctorate from the University of Jordan in Amman, an official of the Vice President's office said.
Lien, who met with some 30 overseas Chinese businessmen in the city earlier in the day, arrived in Amman Monday evening for an informal 4-day visit.
He will also visit Lebanon and Bahrain, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA DENIES DECLARING RCA PREMISES PERMANENTLY CONTAMINATED

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Tuesday denied a local news report that a parcel of land in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, that was previously the site of an RCA electronics plant has been declared permanently contaminated.
The EPA released a statement that it had never made any such announcement, saying that a program to decontaminate the water below the site of the deserted RCA factory is still in progress.

It said that the final determination on the effectiveness of the program launched by the US-based General Electric (GE) Co. and French-based Thomson Corp. to rid the underground water of toxic substances is scheduled to be made in June.

If the clean-up is unsuccessful and the land is declared permanently contaminated, this would be the first case of its kind in Taiwan. Permanently contaminated land cannot be put to residential or business use.

The EPA said that it has received the report submitted by the GE and Thomson work team regarding the results of the six-month clean-up program. The EPA is reviewing the report and studying several possible remedies to the pollution problem.

RCA established a production center for the manufacture of electronics and electric home appliances on the 23.71 acres of land in Taoyuan in 1970. GE took over the plant's operations in 1986. Two years later, the operation went to Thomson.
The land currently belongs to two local companies -- Hong Yi and Chang Chung, which purchased it for some NT$1.6 billion (US$48.8 million) several years ago.

The two Taiwan companies applied to rezone the industrial land for business and residential use not long before the land purchase. But the application was put on hold in 1994 when reports emerged that RCA had dumped toxic waste into wells on the land for nearly 20 years, seriously contaminating the area.

The United Daily News reported in its Tuesday edition that according to the report submitted by the GE and Thomson team, the EPA has decided that the clean-up program was futile and that the area should be declared permanently contaminated. It quoted Chang Ching-feng, a high-ranking official at the EPA's Water Quality Protection Bureau, as saying that the clean-up program was a failure.

The report also said that the two local companies have filed suits against GE and Thomson in New York and Paris, respectively, accusing the two giants of tricking them into buying the land by not informing them of the contamination.

According to the mass-circulation newspaper, Professor Yeh Hong-teh of National Chiao Tung University said that an EPA survey made in 1994 showed that the water below the RCA premises contained 930 parts per billion (ppb) of trichloro-ethylene, compared with 5 ppb allowable in drinking water. The latest survey, conducted after the completion of a six-month clean-up program, showed samples of the underground water containing an even higher level of trichloro-ethylene than in the previous study.
Professor Chen Chai-hsun of National Central University said that trichloro-ethylene and tetrachloro-ethylene are both considered "DNAPL," meaning that the toxicants are difficult to get rid of.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VINCENT SIEW WELCOMES ARATS MESSAGE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday he welcomed a letter from mainland China concerning the resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait and exchanges of visits by officials of the two cross-strait intermediary bodies, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Siew made the remarks in response to an interpellation by Legislator Lee You-chi of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) about a letter from the ARATS saying it would welcome a visit at the appropriate time by SEF Chairman C. F. Koo.

The letter, which was sent to the SEF, said the ARATS would welcome a visit by Koo for political talks. It also proposed working-level exchange visits by SEF and ARATS officials to discuss procedural issues related to the opening of political talks, as well as the resumption of consultations on economic and administrative issues.
Siew said he welcomed the ARATS' positive response to a Taiwan-proposed resumption of regular cross-strait dialogue and exchanges of visits by officials of the two intermediary bodies.

Nevertheless, Siew said, the agenda proposed by the ARATS still differs from the SEF-proposed one on certain points. "We need further study to understand the ARATS' true intention and stance," Siew said, adding he has asked the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the SEF to address the issue. The MAC supervises SEF operations.
Siew also echoed the ARATS' call for exchanges of visits by SEF and ARATS officials at the appropriate level. "I hope the SEF will draw up detailed plans for boosting such exchanges."
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies founded by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

The SEF sent letters to the ARATS on Nov. 7 and Jan. 19, suggesting that SEF Chairman Koo visit the mainland to restart institutionalized technical talks broken off by Beijing in mid-1995. The ARATS didn't formally respond to the proposal until Tuesday.

While Taiwan does not oppose talks on any topic that can contribute to harmonious development and the eventual reunification of China under freedom and democracy, it has stressed that cross-strait talks on practical issues should be resumed first under the framework laid out in the first meeting between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Singapore in 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO'S GROUP TAKES OVER 50 PERCENT STAKE OF THAI SECURITIES CO
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Haungjee Sae-Chia & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Koo's Group will become the first Taiwan group to purchase a Thailand's financial organization since the financial turmoil that has swept the Southeastern Asian countries erupted in last July.

Thailand's largest securities company -- Securities One Plc. (S-One) announced on Tuesday that the board of the directors has decided in a meeting on Monday to sell nearly 50 percent stake of the company to KG Investment Co., affiliated to Koo's Group.

The S-One will sell 4.2 million shares to KG Investment at 5 baht per share, a price that is nearly four-fold lower than the market price. At the close of the Thai stock market on Monday, each S-One share was worth 19.5 baht.
S-One is in the process of increasing its capital, aimed at raising the current capital from 1.47 billion baht to 8.47 billion baht.

Due to the financial crisis, the S-One lost 5.2 billion baht in its assets last year. The depreciation of Thai currency further made the company lose 789 billion baht. The company also lost 2.9 billion baht in its investment in stock market and 569 million baht in margin trade loans which were unable to retrieve.

KG Investment is a multinational consists of Taiwan's Koo's Group, Japan's Nippon Life Insurance, South Korea's Tong Yang Group, Singapore's Lee Kim Yem Ltd., Indonesia's Salim Group, the Philippines' Yuchengoo Group and mainland China's Citic Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI: TAIWAN IS MODEL FOR ALL CHINA

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui told a group of overseas Chinese from Japan on Tuesday that Taiwan's economic and democratic achievements have created a model for the whole of China.
He also reiterated that the Republic of China, a sovereign nation with an 87-year history, has no need to declare its independence.

Lee said that the existence and achievements of the Republic of China on Taiwan is the result of the efforts made by people of Taiwan and ethnic Chinese abroad. "We pride ourselves on this and cherish it," said Lee.

"Although Beijing takes pains to isolate the island, and doesn't rule out the use of force against Taiwan, Taiwan will not abandon its pursuit of national unification under the principles of freedom, democracy, and equal distribution of wealth," said the president.

Addressing concerns among the overseas Chinese visitors over Taiwan's economy, Lee emphasized that the island's dynamic and sound economic system has enabled the island to weather the current regional economic woes.

The group of overseas Chinese from Tokyo was accompanied at the meeting by the newly inaugurated Minister of Overseas Chinese Affairs Chiao Jen-ho, and Deputy Secretary-General to the Presidential Office Huang Cheng-hsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC TO SUPPLY BOEING

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC) has recently won a contract to supply the Boeing Company, one of world's largest commercial aircraft makers, marking a significant step forward for Taiwan's bid to enter the international aviation market.
AIDC Chairman Tsai Chun-hui made the announcement on Tuesday at the Singapore Aviation Show, which kicked off here that day.

Tsai told the press that his company has been contracted to manufacture nine different parts and components for Boeing B-777 aircraft. The multi-million US dollar contract makes AIDC the first Taiwan supplier of the giant company, he said.
He added that AIDC will begin production of the Boeing order prior to a formal contract signing ceremony between April and May.

AIDC, which has its headquarters in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, originated as a military-run institute that built Taiwan's locally designed Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs).

Currently in the process of privatization, AIDC now produces not only the IDFs, also known as "Ching Kuo" fighters after the late ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, but also commercial aircraft, including MD-95 tail assemblies and S-92 helicopters for McDonnell Douglas and Sikorsky Aircraft, respectively, of the United States.

The Singapore Aviation Show is the largest of its kind in the Asia-Pacific region. Over 600 aerospace companies from 31 countries around the globe are taking part in the exhibition, including nine companies from Taiwan which are presenting their latest developments in aerospace technology.
The Taiwan booth at the 1998 World Aviation Fair is three times the size of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: THIS STORY IS TO REPLACE CEP0026.
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Haungjee Sae-Chia & Lin Wen-fen)
DOC.TEXT:
Multinational conglomerate KG Investment Co., in which Taiwan's Koo Group is a major player, is to purchase shares in a Thai financial organization which has hit dire straits since the eruption last July of the financial turmoil that has swept the countries of Southeast Asia.
Thailand's largest securities company -- Securities One Plc. (S-One) announced on Tuesday that its board of directors decided in a meeting on Monday to sell nearly 50 percent of the company to KG Investment.
The S-One will sell 420 million shares to KG Investment at 5 baht per share, a price that is nearly four times lower than the market price. At the close of the Thai stock market on Monday, S-One shares were worth 19.5 baht each.
The move is part of S-One's efforts to increase its capital from the current level of 1.47 billion baht to 8.47 billion baht.
The financial crisis caused S-One to lose 5.2 billion baht-worth of assets last year, while the depreciation of Thailand's currency cost the company another 789 million baht. The company also lost 2.9 billion baht in its stock market investments and 569 million baht in marginal trade loans which it has been unable to retrieve.
KG Investment is a multinational conglomerate comprising Taiwan's Koo Group, Japan's Nippon Life Insurance, South Korea's Tong Yang Group, Singapore's Lee Kim Yem Ltd., Indonesia's Salim Group, the Philippines' Yuchengoo Group and mainland China's Citic Group.
Koo Chung-yun, president of KG Investment said that investment in the Thailand's largest securities company will help the multinational conglomerate to expand its stock business in Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS, PHARMACISTS HIT STREETS AGAIN ON RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Some 5,000 medical practitioners and pharmacists from around the island protested in front of the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday to voice their concerns over their rights to prescribe and dispense medicine.
The doctors, dressed in their professional whites, were demanding the return of their dispensation rights which they have been deprived of since about one year ago.
They demanded the legislature to revise the Pharmacy Law so as to allow the Taiwan public the choice of obtaining medicine either from medical institutions and clinics or from pharmacies.
The current law, revised last year, gives doctors the right to prescribe medicine but not to dispense it.

The doctors said their demonstration will continue for three days, and they did not exclude the possibility of dropping out of the National Health Insurance program en masse if their demands are not met.
Meanwhile, pharmacists were also asking for the return of their prescription rights, since they claimed there are still many doctors who refuse to release prescriptions to patients.
The pharmacists accused some doctors of prescribing low-cost medicines in order to reap illegal profits, which they allege infringes upon patients' rights.
They argued that one major advantage of obtaining medicine from pharmacies is that pharmacists may double check to see if doctors' prescriptions are adequate.

Commenting on the confrontation between medical practitioners and pharmacists, Taiwan's top health official, Chan Chi-hsien, urged the two opposition camps to keep in mind that the interests of the public should be the only ultimate goal of their services.
Chan, director-general of the Department of Health, said any party who threatens to cease their operations because their demands are not met will be duly dealt with.
He stressed that while interests can be negotiated, policies can be reviewed and laws can be revised, patients' rights are not negotiable.
The separation of prescribing and dispensing is the law and an established policy, Chan noted, adding that the government will not sit idly by and watch patients' rights be infringed upon.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TRAINER CRASHES, PILOTS RESCUED

TEXT.P: An ROC Air Force training jet developed engine problems off the coast of Tungho, in eastern Taitung County on Tuesday afternoon, causing both pilots to eject into the sea, where they were later rescued, according to the Ministry of Defense.
The two-seater T38 jet, with one instructor and one trainee aboard, was ditched into the sea at about 5:05 p.m., when a fire broke out in one of its two engines during a routine training flight.

The trainee, Lt. Capt. Liang Chih-hung and instructor Lt. Col. Huang Chi-hung, ejected from the plane and parachuted into the sea. They were airlifted to safety by rescue helicopters some seven miles off the coast and sent to a nearby military hospital, where Huang was later listed in serious condition and Liang was reported as being stable.
It was the second air force crash in one week. Last Thursday, a Chunghsing training jet crashed into the sea off the coast of Taipei County. Its pilot also ejected safely.

DOC.HEADLINE: III REFUTES US PIRACY ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: The government-funded Institute for Information Industry (III) on Tuesday refuted a US allegation that Taiwan has not done enough to eliminate commercial piracy.

The US-based International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA) has asked the Office of the US Trade Representative (USTR) to put Taiwan on a Special 301 "watch list" again because it has regressed in intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and in crackdown on computer software piracy.

"The IIPA allegation is unfair," Chen Chia-chun, director of the III's legal service center, said, adding that Taiwan's law-enforcement officers have broken more than 200 computer software piracy cases and destroyed more than 100,000 pirated CD-ROMs and video game software over the past year.

Chen said Taiwan has done its utmost to crack down on software piracy. Nevertheless, he admitted that Taiwan should still intensify publicity campaign to help its people understand the importance of IPR protection.

Chen pointed out that Taiwan's software industry has not grown as fast as its hardware industry partly because of rampant piracy. "We should teach our people the importance to respect and protect intellectual property rights in order to boost scientific and technological development."

Reports from Washington said the IIPA claimed that Taiwan remains a pivot in entertainment software piracy in the three Chinese economies -- Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China. It further said pirated CD-ROMs, CDs and music recordings remain rampant in Taiwan.

The IIPA, composed of 1,350 US-based movie, music and computer software companies, claimed that American companies lost an estimated US$237.2 million in software sales last year due to counterfeiting by Taiwan firms. The amount marked a 5.4 percent decline from the 1996 level.

The USTR has made an annual review on how US copyrights, patents and trademarks are being protected around the world since 1989 in accordance the Special 301 provisions of the Omnibus US Trade Act. It has consistently unveiled lists of countries for different degrees of US moniotring to imporve IPR protection at the end of April annually.

Taiwan was placed on the "priority watch list" in 1989; on the "watch list" in 1990 and 1991; on the most threatening "priority foreign countries" in 1992; on the "priority watch list" in 1993; on the "watch list" in 1994-5; and on the least-threatening "special mention" list in 1996. Due to its progress in IPR protection and nationwide crackdown on commercial piracy, Taiwan has managed to graduate from any "Special 301" watch list since November 1996.

Economics Ministry officials said the ministry will intensify cooperation with law-enforcement authorities to wipe out IPR infringement in order to protect national image and reduce trade frictions with major trade partners, particularly the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, EU REACH CONSENSUS ON OPENING OF SERVICE MARKETS

TEXT.P: Negotiators from Taiwan and the 15-member European Union (EU) started a new round of talks in Taipei on Tuesday on terms for the island's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The two sides first discussed issues related to Taiwan's service market opening measures and have reached consensus on almost all major problems, said Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Schive said Taiwan has agreed to allow foreign nationals to set up wholly-owned air cargo forwarding companies in Taiwan on a reciprocal basis following its WTO entry. At present, foreign nationals can only hold a maximum 50 percent stake in such a company in Taiwan.
Taiwan also promised to review in three years its current regulation that a foreign lawyer must have five years of professional experience before he or she will be allowed to practice in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Taiwan promised to allow foreign investors to invest up to 60 percent in local telecommunications companies after it is firmally admitted to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.
Schive also explained to EU officials that Taiwan will no longer issue operating permits for any new trust investment companies.

The two sides will discuss topics related to Taiwan's tariff reduction plans for automobiles, tobacco, alchol and other industrial goods as well as liberalization of its government procurement system in the next two days.
The EU delegation to the current round of talks is headed by Jean-Pierre de Laet, deputy head of the EU unit in charge of WTO negotiations with Taiwan.
The EU is one of the two remaining trade partners that have yet to finalize bilateral WTO talks with Taiwan. The other trade partner is Switzerland.

Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, said Taiwan hopes to finalize all bilateral talks with its major trade partners before the end of March in order to speed up its WTO accession.
If all goes smoothly, the WTO working party in charge of Taiwan's membership application will begin to draft Taiwan's entry protocol and screen all relevant documents in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA DEVELOPMENT CO. TO MAKE INROADS TO SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: China Development Corp. (CDC), a business arm of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), has decided to establish an investment and trust fund in South Korea aimed at investing directly in the East Asian country.

The fund, initially to be valued at 10 billion Korean won (US$6.02 million), will share investment from CDC and a number of Korean businesses and banking companies, with CDC contributing 70 percent of the paid-in investment and the Korean companies responsible for the remaining 30 percent, said Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the KMT Business Management Committee.

Liu said CDC decided to pitch into South Korea's business and industrial sectors because the company has found that Korean attitudes toward foreign investment have changed remarkably in the wake of the Asian financial turmoil which has affected South Korea particularly badly and the intervention of the International Monetary Fund to bail the nation out from possible economic disaster.
According to Liu, he and CDC President Hu Ting-wu visited South Korea many times to tap the feasibility of investing in that country before making the decision.

The CDC-initiated fund will initially target South Korea's high-technology industries, including personal computer, software and precision machinery manufacturing. The investment foray could also include the financial and banking sectors if assessments find these sectors viable, Liu noted.
Hu is leaving for Seoul on Wednesday to meet Korean business and industrial leaders for discussions on possible investment projects.
However, the widely-reported possible CDC investment in Korean-Asian Airlines is now history because the airlines' financial situation is too difficult to tackle, said Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TRAINER CRASHES, INSTRUCTOR KILLED

TEXT.P: An ROC Air Force training jet developed engine problems off the coast of Tungho, in eastern Taitung County on Tuesday afternoon, causing an instructor and his trainee to eject into the sea. The injured men were rescued and taken to hospital, where the instructor later died, according to the Ministry of Defense.
The two-seater T38 jet, with one instructor and one trainee aboard, was ditched into the sea at about 5:05 p.m., when a fire broke out in one of its two engines during a routine training flight.

The trainee, Lt. Capt. Liang Chih-hung and instructor Lt. Col. Huang Chi-hung, ejected from the plane and parachuted into the sea. They were airlifted to safety by rescue helicopters some seven miles off the coast and sent to a nearby military hospital, where Huang was later pronounced dead and Liang was reported as being stable.
It was the second air force crash in one week. Last Thursday, a Chunghsing training jet crashed into the sea off the coast of Taipei County. Its pilot also ejected safely.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN PREPARING FOR 2000 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday made public his intention of running in the Republic of China's next presidential election, slated for 2000.
"I am preparing for 2000," Hsu said in response to a question raised after he delivered a speech at the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT) in Taipei.
The questioner had asked what Hsu intends to do after he resigns as DPP chairman.

In his speech entitled "DPP Policies on Taiwan's Economic Development and Relations with China," Hsu painted a picture of the Taiwan of tomorrow as an island with a more open economy, a more mature and stable democracy, and improved relations with mainland China.
He stressed the need for a thorough internationalization and liberalization of Taiwan's economy and wider opening of its financial sector.
The DPP chairman said that although his party represents the interests of Taiwan, it should also comply with international political and economic order while pursuing its goals.

He also explained to his audience the DPP consensus of "consolidating the base (Taiwan) first and engaging gradually with the mainland," which was reached at a recent inner-party debate on policy towards mainland China.
He said that his party will not seek to declare Taiwan independence since Taiwan is already a sovereign independent country.

"Our foremost priority is to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait, and as long as the status quo serves the interests of regional peace and stability, we will not initiate any declaration. We believe that in this way our security is guaranteed, for the international community would not tolerate China's unprovoked aggression against Taiwan," he said.
Hsu agreed with calls made by the international community that now is the right time for Taiwan and the mainland to resume talks which have been suspended since 1995.

"Besides the issue of sovereignty, we are willing to enter into comprehensive talks with China to address issues of mutual concern. We also want to encourage cultural and economic exchanges to enhance cross-strait peace and understanding."

Hsu, who was recently forced to drop his earlier advocacy of "boldly marching towards the west" mainland policy after being criticized by his comrades, said that he is still personally in favor of lifting government regulations and limitations on trade with the mainland to increase cross-strait trade links.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA, GE ESTABLISH JOINT-VENTURE FOR AIRPLANE MAINTENANCE

TEXT.P: EVA Airways Corporation of Taiwan and General Electric Aircraft Engines (GE) of the United States on Tuesday formally signed a NT$2.5 billion (US$76.22 million) joint venture for aircraft maintenance and repair.
A contract signing ceremony was held at an EVA engine facility at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport in Taoyuan, some 40 km west of the Taiwan capital of Taipei.

The joint venture, which will have its headquarters near the airport, will build various maintenance and engine overhaul facilities, an EVA spokesman said, noting that the deal will enable Taiwan to provide a complete maintenance center for carriers with fleets in the Asia-Pacific region.

The newly formed Evergreen Aviation Technologies Corporation, 80 percent owned by EVA and 20 percent owned by GE, will operate an already completed turbine test facility which can test jet engines generating up to 120,000 pounds of thrust, as well as conducting engine overhauls, said the spokesman.

He added that besides the company's mission of improving the island's capability in aircraft and engine repair and maintenance, the joint-venture is also committed to engage in the development and manufacture of engine products, leading EVA into the field of aviation manufacture.
In view of this commitment, GE will contribute technology transfers to the joint-venture, which could be ready to begin production of aircraft spares after five years, according to EVA.
The Evergreen Group, the Taiwan-based shipping giant, began business in the aviation services sector in 1994 through the establishment of EVA Airways, which now possesses a 32-plane fleet.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCHANGES BETWEEN SEF AND ARATS SHOULD BE PRIORITY

TEXT.P: If Beijing really wants to resume contact with Taipei, it should start with exchanges between the two front agencies set up by each side to deal with the other, said Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Tuesday.

In response to questions from an opposition legislator, Chang said at the Legislative Yuan that exchanges of visits between personnel of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), should take place prior to any visit to mainland China by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu or formal negotiations between the two agencies.

Chang lauded ARATS' letter to the SEF which arrived on Tuesday in which it suggested a reopening of dialogue with the SEF as a positive response to Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew's friendly gesture toward Beijing made in a statement to the Legislature on the administration's agenda last Friday.
In his analysis, Chang said the ARATS intended to contact its Taiwan counterpart on economic, working, and procedural issues pending a mandate from the Beijing authorities.

This, he said, can be seen from the first paragraph of the letter, which says the two agencies could restart negotiations on economic and working-level issues as well as on the procedure for political talks, once they are given the go-ahead to do so.
The second paragraph of the letter, urging exchanges between the SEF and the ARATS, is an echo of what Taipei has always called for, said Chang.

The third paragraph, which says the ARATS would welcome a visit by Koo to mainland China "when the time is appropriate," is a reply to a suggestion made by Taipei earlier this year that Koo make such a visit, according to Chang.
Hailing the letter as a welcome movement on the part of the ARATS, Chang emphasized the importance of order and prudence in cross-strait exchanges.

Although Siew pledged in his agenda statement on Friday that his administration would like to negotiate with Beijing on anything which might help cross-strait relations and contribute to the democratic unification of the two sides, Chang said that priority should be given to issues concerning the exchanges themselves, on which consensus already exists.
In a related development on Tuesday, Koo said he also welcomed the ARATS suggestion for expanded dialogue with the SEF, calling it a positive response to Siew's friendly gesture toward Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENTIAL AIDE MEETS VATICAN SECRETARY OF STATE

TEXT.P: The Holy See fully supports the peaceful resolution to differences between the archrivals across the Taiwan Strait, the Vatican's secretary of state, Cardinal Angelo Sodano, said on Tuesday.

Sodano, who met on Tuesday with Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China, for an hour-long discussion, said he greatly admires Lee for his promotion of "spiritual reform" in Taiwan.

Sodano said that while Europe, even the entire world, is sinking in the materialist quicksand in which spiritual values are bankrupt, spiritual reform like that inspired by Lee is highly commendable, since it is in line with what the Pope has called for in terms of ethics and moral values.

Huang for his part told Sodano that the ROC government is always willing to pitch in to help international charities and to provide aid to refugees around the world. These gestures of goodwill, however, have often been barred because of political interference, he lamented.

Sodano, on behalf of the Vatican, expressed hope that the spiritual center of the 1.1 billion Roman Catholics worldwide should work closely with Taiwan in international aid efforts on a politics-free and borderless basis.
Huang meanwhile expressed Taiwan's gratitude to the Pope for elevating Archbishop Paul K.H. Shan of Kaohsiung as one of 22 new cardinals from around the world.

Huang arrived in the Vatican on Saturday to witness the elevation ceremony. During his stay in Vatican City, he was granted an audience with the Pope, when he conveyed President Lee's greetings to the leader of the world's Roman Catholics.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AEROSPACE FIRMS PARTICIPATE IN ASIAN AEROSPACE '98

TEXT.P: Nine Republic of China aerospace and aviation industry companies and institutions are taking part in the week-long Asian Aerospace Show '98 currently being held in Singapore.

They are: the Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation, Chen-Tech Taiwan Industries Corp., Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology, Hiwin Technologies Corp., the Industrial Technology Research Institute Center for Aviation and Space Technology, Masbe Corp., the National Aerospace Fasteners Corp., Super Precision Heat Treatment Co. and Ta Yih Industrial Co.

They are sponsored and headed at the show by the ROC Economic Affairs Ministry's Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development. However, its title at the ROC exhibition compartment was registered in the name of the Council for External Trade Development (CETRA).

Singapore Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Tan Keng Yam and Minister for Communication Mah Bow Tan officiated at a ribbon-cutting ceremony at the exhibition site, Changi Exhibition Center, near Changi Airport early on Tuesday morning. They also toured the exhibition halls before they opened to traders.

A total of 590 aerospace and aviation industrial manufacturers and companies from all over the world, including 70 of the world's top 100 aerospace and aviation industrial manufacturers, are participating in the exhibition.

A spectacular air display took place over the exhibition site at 12:30 p.m. Joining in the 75-minute display were Russian Sukhoi Su-27 fighters, French Dassault Rafale-B fighters and Dassault Mirage 2000 fighters, US F-16C Fighting Falcons and Singapore's A4-SU Super Skyhawk fighters, as well as helicopters and transport planes.
The exhibition will last for six days and is expected to attract some 25,000 traders and 50,000 members of the public, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAA TO OPEN KAOHSIUNG-OKINAWA FLIGHT

TEXT.P: Eyeing mushrooming travel opportunities emerging from the five-day workweek that Taiwan began at the start of this year, Japan Asia Airways (JAA) in Taipei will open passenger flights between Kaohsiung and Okinawa, according to the Japanese company.
JAA said that it will inaugurate two regular round-trip flight services per week between the Japanese island resort, southwest of Japan's Kyushu, and Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan, in April.

The chartered flight services will be on a trial basis until October, when the carrier will decide whether or not to maintain the new route based on market demand, a JAA executive stationed in Kaohsiung revealed Wednesday.

The executive noted the new flight project was prompted by the facts that most of their flight services bound to Japan enjoyed high passenger carrying rates during this year's winter-holiday season and that some 40 percent of their customers were from southern Taiwan.

He stressed the direct flight between Kaohsiung and Okinawa, which will take only half of the time of a flight through northern Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, is expected to help enhance the airline's competitiveness in Taiwan's emerging tourism sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOLEN INTEL MEMORY CHIPS FOUND IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A batch of computer memory chips that have been in police custody since early this month have been identified as stolen from Intel's manufacturing plant in Malaysia, Kaohsiung police said on Wednesday.
The 11,530 chips, packaged in four cartons, arrived at Kaohsiung International Airport from Malaysia in early February, marked as being for Kaohsiung resident Su Yi-jen, 30.

The Kaohsiung Customs Bureau became suspicious about the chips because although they were labeled as being from Intel, they bore no model or batch numbers. The bureau seized the chips for further investigation.

After some two weeks of contacts with Intel's Taiwan operations and relevant investigations, the bureau was informed that the same amount of memory chips was stolen from the Intel plant in Malaysia about one month ago.

Questioned by Kaohsiung airport police, Su, the consignee of the chips, said that he bought the chips from an overseas Chinese surnamed Ma in Malaysia at 30 US cents apiece. Su said he intended to extract the gold in the chips and that he didn't know they had been stolen.
The police later found that Su operates a small IC plant in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WANTS SHI-TANG DIALOGUE FIRST
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Soong Bin-chong and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Beijing would prefer to have those on both sides of the Taiwan Strait responsible for the day-to-day workings of the bodies related to cross-strait affairs resume their dialogue before higher-level officials resume theirs, according to mainland officials related to Taiwan affairs.

In other words, Beijing would like to hold a meeting between Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his counterpart Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), prior to SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's visit to Beijing.

In a letter it faxed to the SEF on Tuesday, ARATS said it hopes to further expand exchanges between both sides in advance of discussions on procedural matters related to the holding of cross-strait political negotiations, adding that it is open to discussions on the level and issues of these exchanges.

The mainland welcomes Koo's visit, said a related Taiwan affairs official who insisted on remaining anonymous. Since the visit, however, will inevitably involve the issue of resuming the talks between Koo and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, contact between the SEF and ARATS at an "appropriate level" is necessary, he added.

Asked what is regarded as appropriate, the official remarked that ARATS wrote the SEF on Nov. 6, 1997, inviting Chiao Jen-ho, then vice chairman and secretary-general of the SEF, to the mainland. Taipei, however, rejected that invitation.
