DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR NOT TO RUN FOR DPP CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian announced on Wednesday that he will not run for chairmanship of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Taiwan's largest opposition party.

Chen told a news conference that he will continue to concentrate on performing his mayoral duties. "I'll dedicate myself to playing the role the people of Taiwan expect of me," said the charismatic mayor of Taiwan's largest city.

The pro-independence party is scheduled to elect a new chairman in May. Incumbent DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang has said he will not seek reelection. Some DPP politicians originally expected Chen to run for the post in order to lead the opposition party to power.
Chen said he had made extensive consultations and had given the matter careful consideration before making his decision.

Noting that the 10-year-old DPP is now at a critical juncture in its bid to become the country's ruling power, Chen said that what the DPP badly needs at the moment is a sense of esprit de corps and humility, not "personal heroism" or individualism.

During the course of his consultations, Chen said he found that many of his DPP colleagues and friends have high expectations of him. "I think at the moment I should modestly shelve my own personal career plan and devote all of my energy to upgrading municipal administrative work in order to make the Taipei City Government a shining beacon that will attract more popular confidence in and support of the DPP."

Chen didn't formally announce his bid to seek reelection as Taipei City mayor, saying only that he will "certainly go to the DPP's Taipei office to pick up application forms for joining a primary election for selecting the party's candidate for the year-end mayoral election." The DPP will accept registrations from March 2 through March 6 for the primaries to select candidates for the next Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections and for the Legislative Yuan elections scheduled for later this year.

Chen was accompanied at the news conference by his mentor, Professor Lee Hung-hsi of National Taiwan University, and leaders of the major DPP factions, all of whom threw their support behind Chen's decision to stay out of the DPP chairman election.

Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung, head of the DPP's Welfare State faction, lauded Chen's decision as "wise and correct." He further pointed out that the most important thing for Chen at the moment is to win reelection as mayor of Taipei. "Whether Chen can be reelected Taipei mayor will be an important indicator to gauge whether the DPP will be able to come to power in the early years of the next century," he said.

As the next DPP chairman will have to lead the party through this year's three elections and the 2000 presidential election, Chang said he hopes the major factions will jointly recommend a mutually acceptable candidate to run in the chairmanship election. According to DPP regulations, the party's chairman should be elected by all of its members.

Chang denied that he will seek the party's leadership post as Chen's surrogate. "Such a rumor is an insult to both me and Chen," he asserted, adding that he has yet to decide whether to join the race for the party chairmanship.
To date, only Lin Yi-hsiung, a former Taiwan Provincial Assembly deputy, and Legislator Yen Chin-fu, have explicitly expressed their intentions to run for the top DPP post.

Incumbent DPP Secretary-General Chiou Yi-jen said Chen's decision to stay out of the race has made the prospects for the chairmanship election even more uncertain. Chen is widely believed to be the strongest competitor for the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY IS ALIVE AND WELL: YALE PROF.

TEXT.P: "Taiwan's economy is alive and well. This has important lessons for its neighbors," said Frank Altschul, professor of International Economics at Yale University.

Contributing an article to the Financial Times, Altschul pointed out that in the midst of all the discussion of Asia's financial crisis, there has been very little mention of one place: Taiwan. Although historically it has been considered a virtually identical twin of South Korea, Taiwan has been little affected, he noted.

Taiwan has been relatively untouched by the contagion that has spread to almost all emerging countries, including those as far away as Brazil and Russia, he said, noting that the island's growth rate has remained fairly steady at more than 6 percent, inflation in 1997 was less than 1 percent, its currency has fallen by only 12 percent over the past three months and its stock market actually rose by 8 percent in 1997, though it has fallen back somewhat in the first weeks of this year.
The Taiwan economy has continued to perform remarkably well and confidence has remained high even though there has been no International Monetary Fund presence.

"In Taiwan, as in Hong Kong and to some extent Singapore, high rates of growth have been achieved. In thinking about how to rebuild in Asia, the Taiwanese example might be a good place to start," Altschul added.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND CHINA STRUGGLING WITH NUMEROUS ECONOMIC PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Although spared the currency panics that spread from Thailand to South Korea last year, mainland China now faces the collapse of its real estate boom, the specter of widespread bank failures, rampant deflation and a sharp slowdown in its growth rate, reported the San Francisco Chronicle.
A tumbling mainland Chinese economy would take the rest of Asia down with it and hurt the United States by crimping its exports, the Chronicle warned in an analysis by Jonathan Marshall.

Other than a series of economic problems from falling real estate prices, debt burdens, loss of state enterprises and bad bank loans, the report said, mainland China now faces growing competition in world markets from its neighbors.

Beijing estimates that a fifth of mainland China's exports compete directly with products from Southeast Asia and South Korea, which suffered attacks on their currencies last summer and fall. In addition, mainland China sells about 40 percent of its exports to Asia, where demand is plummeting.
The big question now is whether mainland China will respond by devaluing its currency to stay competitive against its neighbors, the Chronicle said.

Aware of the tremendous negative impact and danger a devaluation would have, Beijing has pledged not to cut the value of the yuan, the report said, adding that many experts take Beijing at its word. "There is absolutely no chance of a devaluation," Gregory Chow of Princeton University was quoted as saying. "They'll lose too much credibility if they do."

Citing the US$140 billion foreign exchange reserve and more than US$14 billion current account surplus last year, economists observed that although mainland China is not likely to slip into a financial crisis similar to Southeast Asia's, its economy can no longer afford policy errors.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE COMPANIES' PROFITS SLUMP DUE TO ASIAN ECONOMIC CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis is not only hitting Australia's economic growth rate but also its companies' profits, the Bureau of Australian Statistics (ABS) said Wednesday.

Figures from the ABS show company profits -- before tax, interest and depreciation -- plunged 4.5 percent in seasonally adjusted terms in the last quarter of 1997, compared to a revised rise of 3.2 percent in corporate profits in the third quarter of the same year.

The ABS said the big fall in profits in the October-December period of 1997 was driven by unusually large foreign exchange and asset write-down losses by companies in the mining, transport and service sectors in Australia.
The mining sector has now suffered profit declines in three of the last four quarters as a result of poor metal prices and declining exports to Asia, the ABS said.

Economists said the unexpected fall in company profits follows an earlier forecast of a one percentage point decline in Australia's gross domestic product in fiscal 1997-98, falling to some 3 percent from the original forecast of over 4 percent.
Colonial State Bank chief economist Craig James said, "The Asian crisis has hit Australian firms at a time when profitability is vulnerable."

Federal Opposition Treasurer Gareth Evans, who was formerly foreign minister under the Labor Party government, said, "These poor profit figures are highly worrying as they suggest that Australian companies are not as well placed to withstand the economic fallout from Asia when it hits with full force later this year."

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.201 against the New Taiwan dollar on the foreign exchange market here on Wednesday, closing at NT$32.551.
The greenback opened at the day's high of 32.73 and has a low of 32.55.
Interbank trading reached US$458.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN FOUNDER CALLS FOR SPEEDY DEVELOPMENT OF SHIPPING
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, northern Taiwan, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Because Taiwan is an island, it should make progress in shipping its top priority and have an advanced maritime sector, Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa said on Wednesday.

Chang, who founded Evergreen Marine Corp. with one second-hand vessel in 1968 and steered the company into becoming the world's largest container ship operator 17 years later, said he succeeded because he dared to stretch out, however modestly.

Chang was awarded an honorary doctorate degree in maritime management Wednesday by National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) in recognition of his contribution to Taiwan's shipping sector, making him the recipient of the first honorary degree ever given by the university in its nearly four-decade history.
Although he has received honorary doctorates from two foreign universities, Chang said he felt particularly proud to be cited by a university in his own country.

In his speech during the degree-presentation ceremony at NTOU, Chang lamented that even though Taiwan is an island, the government here, like its predecessor in mainland China, knows only "mountain" but nothing about "ocean."

Noting that the island-based Japan has become an advanced country, he laid the blame for Taiwan not achieving similar results on the government, which he said has not adequately recognized the importance of maritime development and has not sufficiently encouraged relevant sectors.
Under Chang's leadership, in 1989 Evergreen expanded its operations to aviation by establishing EVA Airways, Taiwan's second airline to maintain international flights.

Chang said that in a soul-searching session one week after the island's worst air crash -- in which 202 persons killed when a China Airlines Airbus 300 exploded near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- he decided that the root cause of Taiwan's relatively high rate of air accidents is that there is no aviation school on the island.

Lacking an aviation institute where pilots and relevant airlines personnel can be nurtured systematically, Taiwan's airlines have sought pilots and training from abroad, he pointed out. This practice not only has been a major waste for Taiwan but also has contributed nothing to efforts to nurture the island's own aviation service sector, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF INSTRUCTED TO ARRANGE RECIPROCAL CROSS-STRAIT VISITS

TEXT.P: Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman and spokesman of the Taipei-based Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Tuesday that his organization will ask the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to proceed immediately with the necessary arrangements regarding Beijing's response to Taipei's proposal to restart reciprocal visits across the Taiwan Strait.

The MAC welcomed the mainland's positive response to the issue of reopening cross-strait talks and to Taipei's proposal to promote reciprocal visits between SEF and ARATS officials, Sheu told reporters at the MAC office on Tuesday afternoon.

Sheu's statements were in response to a proposal offered by the ARATS in a message faxed on Tuesday suggesting that reciprocal visits by officials at the "appropriate level" of both the SEF and the ARATS could take place.

The SEF and the ARATS are the semi-official organizations on either side of the Taiwan Strait set up to deal with cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties, while the MAC is a Cabinet-level body charged with forming Taiwan's mainland China policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVALUATION OF YUAN SEEN WOULD CAUSE GLOBAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: If mainland China were to devalue its currency, a global economic crisis could result, with Southeast Asian countries suffering the most, according to one of the world's biggest funds managers, Fidelity Institutional Asset Management (FIAM).
FIAM chief investment officer Richard Horlick, currently on a visit to Sydney, warned that the world's economic growth remains critically poised on a devaluation of the yuan.

Many analysts have speculated that US government representatives have sought to ensure the stability of the Southeast Asian economy by unofficially asking mainland China not to devalue the yuan in exchange for Washington not pressuring Beijing on human rights.

"Life would become extraordinarily difficult for most Southeast Asian countries, as their goods became uncompetitive in world markets," Horlick said in an interview with the mass circulation newspaper The Australian on Tuesday.
He said the recovery of Southeast Asian markets was also critically dependent on inflation staying low, allowing global interest rates to remain on a stable and downward path.

"Interest rates rising and world growth slowing down would make it impossible for Southeast Asian companies to export and find a way out of their problems," he said, adding, "People look at Asia as another Mexico, where there was a relatively good recovery, but in our analysis Asia will be much worse."
FIAM now manages US$650 billion in institutional funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFTER BALANCING BUDGET, CANADA WAGES WAR ON DEBT

TEXT.P: Canada's finance minister declared the government's chronic deficit dead Tuesday and went on to wage a war on the nearly C$600 billion (US$397 billion) in federal debt.

Paul Martin told Parliament he will be starting the assault with a leg up because C$13 billion will have been paid off in the first nine months of the current fiscal year thanks to a healthy economy, growing revenues and low interest rates.

Canada is the first G-7 country to declare a budget surplus, squeaking by the United States by five months. This year's federal ledger will balance at exactly zero, the first time in 28 years that Ottawa has brought down a budget without a deficit, Martin said.
That compares with a deficit of C$8.9 billion last year and C$42 billion when the Liberal Party took power in 1993.
Ottawa also forecast the next two budgets will be balanced. That would mark the first time in over 50 years Canada has balanced its budget for three consecutive years.

With those numbers, Martin pronounced, the next chapter of the country's fiscal history has begun. "Canada's remaining fiscal challenge is to significantly lower the government's debt burden," he stated.

At C$583.2 billion this year, the federal debt will stand at 68.1 percent of the gross domestic product. That's down from 71.1 percent the previous year, and Martin forecast the ratio will fall to 62.9 percent by 2000.
Still, the ratio is far worse than the G-7 average, estimated to be 46.7 percent this year. In fact, only Italy is expected to exceed Canada this year in this ratio with 107.3 percent.

In fiscal 1997-98, which ends on March 31, about 30 cents of each revenue dollar will be used to pay interest on the public debt, double the amount paid in the mid-1970s and a big drain on the government's spending power.
Analysts said despite all the progress on the deficit, debt rating agencies will not return Canada to a top credit rating until its debt-GDP ratio falls near 50 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC TO FORGE COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH US SIMULATOR MAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Chi Chin-ling & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC) will forge cooperation links with Reflectone, an American maker of technology training systems, to jointly open Taiwan's simulator market, which is estimated to create US$15 million-worth of business opportunities per year.

AIDC Chairman Tsai Chun-hui revealed the cooperation project at the Asian Aerospace Show '98, which opened in Singapore on Tuesday for a week-long exhibition of advanced aeronautic products from around the world.

Tsai said his company is scheduled to sign a letter of intent on cooperation with Reflectone on Thursday. The deal means AIDC will be granted technology transfers from the US' leading simulator maker, the chairman noted.
Reflectone, which has its headquarters in the US state of Florida, enjoys a reputation as one of the world's pioneers in high technology military and commercial aviation training systems.

Prompted by the lure of profits in the Asia-Pacific region, Reflectone Vice Chairman S. Anthony Brancato told the CNA that they expect Taiwan will become a stronghold for the company's push into the Asian market, pointing out that there is around US$15 million-worth of trade prospects for Reflectone products, including simulators for the entertainment sector and for civil aviation services, in Taiwan alone.

An AIDC executive in charge of the cooperation project also stressed that besides domestic demand, his company is especially eyeing the large regional market, in which so far only Japan possesses the technology to produce various types of simulator.
Meanwhile, AIDC could also take over Reflectone's maintenance and repair operation for Reflectone-produced military simulation and training systems on the island, the official noted.

AIDC, which has its headquarters in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, originated as a military-run institute that built Taiwan's locally designed Indigenous Defense Fighters. The government-funded company is now undergoing privatization.

Reflectone, founded in 1939 and now 52.7 percent owned by British Aerospace, is the US' second-largest military simulation system producers, which offers military simulators for C130 aircraft. It is currently working on designing a full flight simulation and training system for the C130J transport aircraft of Britain's Royal Air Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved down 0.4 percent on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Tuesday due to adjustments in the wake of heavy turnover in the previous session.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key indicator, dropped 39.36 points to close at 9,027.1. Dealers described the decline as "healthy adjustment" since the index had been climbed upwards dramatically in previous sessions.
The bourse opened at 9,111.87 and experienced a high of 9,131.42 and a low of 9,013.7.
Falling stocks outnumbered gainers 257 to 178, with 61 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$175.59 billion (US$5.35 billion), down from the 4.1 billion issues valued at NT$255.5 billion (US$7.79 billion) which changed hands in the Tuesday session.

Cement stocks fell the most, at 1.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues, which posted a 0.9 percent drop; electrical engineering shares, which declined 0.8 percent; financial issues, down 0.6 percent; and plastic and chemical stocks, down 0.5 percent.
Construction issues surged 1.1 percent and foodstuff shares rose 0.9 percent. Textile stocks remained unchanged.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were: United Micro Electronics; ACER; Mitac International; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; Holtek Microelectronics; Winbond Electronics; Chuntex Electronic; Hwang Dih Lon Textile; Kwong Fong Industries; and Mosel-Vitelic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SMALLEST-EVER SURVIVING PREMATURE BABY GOES HOME

TEXT.P: The smallest premature baby ever born in Taiwan's pediatric history was released from hospital on Wednesday and taken home by her happy parents.

"Hsintzu," the "palm-sized" baby girl who was born prematurely at the China Medical College Hospital in Taichung, central Taiwan in late September, weighed just 530 grams at birth. She was nursed in an incubator for five months while her weight increased steadily to her present weight of 2,400 grams.

The baby girl, who smashed Taiwan's previous premature birth record by surviving for five months, is basically healthy and suffers from none of the complications that usually plague prematurely born babies, such as retinopathy and cerebral palsy, although she had to spend 110 days on a ventilator and her weight at one point dropped to a critical 400 grams, according to her doctors.
The hospital threw a party on Wednesday to mark her "formal birth," five months after her accidental birth, which her mother at first mistook for a miscarriage.

DOC.HEADLINE: MECHANICAL FAILURE MAY BE CAUSE OF TRAINER CRASH: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said on Wednesday that mechanical failure might have been the cause of Tuesday's crash of an air force T-38 trainer off the southeastern coast of Taiwan which resulted in the death of a flight instructor and the injury of a trainee.

Preliminary investigations show that the trainer's exhaust was emitting fire immediately prior to the accident during a routine training flight over Tungho, a small township in the eastern county of Taitung, Chiang said, emphasizing that further investigation will be needed before the real cause can be established.
"The air force has formed a special task force to investigate the case, and we'll announce the true reason after the investigation is completed," he said.

According to Chiang, the pilot of the lead aircraft, upon spotting the flames coming from his wingman, had taken emergency action and immediately instructed the instructor and trainee aboard the stricken plane to eject.

Both the flight instructor, Huang Chi-hung, and the trainee, Liang Chih-hung, were picked up by rescue helicopters some seven miles off the coast and airlifted to a nearby military hospital, where Huang was later pronounced dead while Liang's condition was reported as stable.

Chiang said the ill-fated trainer was leased from the United States. The air force was originally scheduled to return the jet to the US at the end of June. "We'll handle the compensation issue carefully in accordance with the leasing contract with the US," the defense minister said.

He expressed sadness over Huang's death, describing him as a brilliant pilot, one of an elite group of instructors who in 1994 received training in the US and returned to Taiwan to pass his knowledge on to others.
It was the second air force crash in one week. Last Thursday, a Chunghsing training jet crashed into the sea off the coast of Taipei County, but its pilot ejected safely.
Chiang said the air force is reviewing its flight safety measures and will take the necessary steps to prevent a recurrence of flight accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA WOULD BE SET BACK DECADES IF IT EXPELS CHINESE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Indonesia's economy would be set back 30 to 50 years if Jakarta expels the country's six million ethnic Chinese, a leading intellectual in the world's biggest Moslem country has warned.

The warning was made by Yusuf Wanandi, director of Indonesian President Suharto's Golkar Party, in an interview in Jakarta with Peter Hartcher of The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business newspaper.

Wanandi, himself a Chinese Indonesian, said most ethnic Chinese have become or will become scapegoats because they have been singled out every time when there have been economic problems or difficulties in Indonesia.
At some six million, Indonesia's ethnic Chinese account for only about 3 percent of Indonesia's total population, but they control 70 percent of the country's economic power.

"The Chinese are very afraid, especially in the regions, because they don't know what to expect and nobody is protecting them any more," said Wanandi, chairman of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Jakarta and a key figure in Indonesia's informal diplomacy abroad.
He said that ethnic Chinese are increasingly becoming the first target of Indonesian protesters and mobs because the country's economy continues to deteriorate.
He said there are three factors contributing to this situation.
First, ethnic Chinese have been accused of earning their fortunes in Indonesia but then sending the profits abroad, undermining the rupiah and precipitating the crisis, he said.

"The second reason is that the relation between Indonesians and Chinese has been one of the fault lines of our political stability. Whenever anything goes wrong, it is always the Chinese who are blamed," Wanandi said.

"The Chinese were used as compradors by the Dutch and the Japanese colonial powers. And in the New Order (of Indonesia), they have been confined to business, and they are most exposed now. So whenever there's anything to do with the economy, the Chinese get picked up," he said.
"The third reason is irresponsible statements made by some officials. They have accused us of being outlaws," he added.
He warned that the persecution of ethnic Chinese would cost Indonesia dearly. "If they want the Chinese out, it will set the country back 30 to 50 years," he said.
He said some of big Chinese tycoons have already left Indonesia under the guise of going abroad on business.

Wanandi said ethnic Chinese should not be singled out just because they send their money out of Indonesia because the little people, the ordinary people and the middle class of Indonesians have also done the same thing by parking their money abroad.
He said these Indonesians do not trust the rupiah, especially in time of difficulty.
He said the Indonesian government did not prepare the people for the price increases.
The result is that the masses blame the merchants, and the majority of the merchants in Indonesia are ethnic Chinese, Wanandi said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JORDAN'S CROWN PRINCE HASSAN ENTERTAINS ROC VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan of the Republic of China was honored at a banquet on Tuesday night hosted by Jordanian Crown Prince Al Hassan Bin Talal.
Reliable sources close to the Jordanian royal family said that King Hussein Bin Talal was later expected to receive Lien at the palace.
Earlier in the day, Lien received an honorary doctorate in social science from the University of Jordan in Amman.

This is Lien's first visit to Jordan. Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, Jordan has a long and friendly relationship with the Republic of China. ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a private visit to Jordan in 1995.
Lien arrived in Amman on Monday evening at the invitation of the University of Jordan. After concluding the unofficial four-day visit, he will proceed to Lebanon and Bahrain.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ENTRY TO GIVE TAIWAN LONG-TERM BENEFITS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday that joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) will bring long-term benefits for the nation.

Wang made the remarks in an address to the Kuomintang (KMT) caucus in the Legislative Yuan on the progress of Taiwan's bid to enter the world trade regulatory body and on the just-concluded WTO consultations between Taiwan and the United States.

He noted that Taiwan is an export-oriented nation which has recorded booming imports and exports in recent years. However, because Taiwan is not a WTO member, it cannot join other nations in working out norms of world trade and is excluded from multilateral trade talks. Even when Taiwan is being unfairly treated or discriminated against in terms of trade, it is unable to resolve related problems through normal channels.

He said that the WTO has wide and far-reaching implications over every aspect of world trade activity. If Taiwan cannot join the organization, it will be unable to continue to maintain its stature in the world economy.

Speaking of Taiwan's progress in its bid to enter the WTO, Wang said eight years have passed since Taiwan applied for membership of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the WTO's forerunner. During this period, Wang said, Taiwan has concluded talks with 24 of the 26 WTO signatory parties that requested bilateral talks with Taiwan on its terms for accession. The two yet to conclude talks are the 15-member European Union and Switzerland.

He added that the US, which has requested Taiwan to make the most concessions and most extensive market opening out of the 26 WTO signatory parties, finally initialed a WTO agreement with Taiwan over the weekend, taking Taiwan's bid for entry into the final stages.

To cope with the possible impact of WTO membership on Taiwan's industrial, agricultural and service sectors, Wang said the government has worked out substantial measures to ease this impact by upgrading the long-term competitiveness of these industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CBC GOVERNOR APPOINTED

TEXT.P: Peng Fai-nan, chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), has been appointed governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC), according to an announcement by the Republic of China Presidential Office on Wednesday.

Peng will officially assume his new post on Thursday, filling the vacancy left by former governor Sheu Yuan-dong, who died tragically in Taiwan's worst-ever air disaster on Feb. 16 while he was returning from a financial meeting in Bali, Indonesia.

Talking about his new appointment, Peng said the CBC will try to establish a system to provide correct information to the media and will seek to provide them with as much information as possible about the bank's operations.

Peng, 59, who received a Masters degree from the University of Minnesota, has served as director of the CBC's Economic Research Department, director of the Foreign Exchange Department, deputy governor of the CBC, and chairman of the Central Trust of China.
Peng has served as ICBC chairman for the past eight months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LOWER MONOPOLY TAXES ON EUROPEAN LIQUORS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has agreed to lower monopoly taxes for liquors from European Union (EU) countries in exchange for the trade bloc's support of its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), a senior official said on Wednesday.
Chang Shiu-lien, director of the Department of National Treasury under the Finance Ministry, made the statement after concluding wine and tobacco trade issues with EU negotiators.

EU countries have long complained about Taiwan's discriminatroy monopoly tax rates on their liquors. Taiwan currently imposes a monopoly tax of NT$1,000 (US$30.48) per liter for French cognac, compared to NT$500 for brandy from other countries. Meanwhile, the monopoly tax for Scotch whisky, compared to NT$198 for whisky from other nations.
Chang said the government has decided to flexibly lower monopoly taxes for liquor imports from EU countries even before Taiwan's WTO entry.

Chang said the chief EU negotiator, Jean-Pierre de Laet, has tentatively agreed to Taiwan-proposed new monopoly tax rates for liquors from EU countries. The new rates will be implemented after the EU's executive arm, the European Commission, endorses the proposal.

Chang would not reveal the new monopoly tax rates for EU liquors. She just said the government has referred to import prices of EU liquors and tariff rates to be imposed under a new taxation system in working out those rates.

After the new rates take effect, market sources said local consumers will benefit because prices for liquors from EU countries, including French cognac and Scotch whisky, will drop in the local retail market. The new rates may take effect in March and prices for EU liquors may drop by NT$100 to NT$300 per bottle, the sources said.

Chang said Taiwan has decided to replace its decades-old wine and tobacco monopoly system with a new taxation system. For years, Taiwan levies "monopoly profits" on tobacco and alcohol sales under a monopoly system. After the system is phased out, Taiwan will impose tariffs, wine and tobacco taxes and commodity taxes on imported and locally produced tobacco and alcoholic products. The new system will be implemented after Taiwan is formally admitted into the WTO.

Taiwan and the EU began a new round of WTO-related talks on Tuesday. The two sides have resolved many contentious issues. They will discuss some remaining issues concerning Taiwan's tariff reduction plan for automobiles and other industrial products as well as libearlization of government procurement measures on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JANUARY FOREIGN RESERVES STAND AT US$84 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign reserves rose for the third consecutive month in January to reach US$84.03 billion, an increase of US$528 million over the same period of one year ago, according to statistics released on Wednesday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).

However, the figure is still down from last June's US$90.02 billion, as the CBC had to use some of it to defend the value of the local currency during the financial crisis that has swept the region since last July.
The island's foreign reserves dipped to US$82.92 billion in October, before climbing back to this January's level.
Taiwan's foreign reserves still rank third in the world, behind the Japan's US$219.6 billion and mainland China's US$139.9 billion, according to data compiled by the International Monetary Fund.

However, Hong Kong, ranked fourth with US$75.3 billion in foreign currency, will overtake Taiwan if the figure takes into account the government's US$17.5 billion in proceeds from sales of government-owned land, which is counted by Hong Kong's Monetary Authority among its foreign reserves of US$92.8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG FEI PROMOTED TO CHIEF OF GENERAL STAFF

TEXT.P: Tang Fei, vice chief of the General Staff (Executive) of the Ministry of National Defense, will be promoted to chief of the General Staff, according to an announcement from the Presidential Office Wednesday.
Tang, who was also promoted to the rank of four-star general, will take over the post from Gen. Lo Pen-li, who has been removed from his post for another appointment.
Tang, 66, has served as superintendent of the Air Force Academy and Air Force commander-in-chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT TO BAN VISIT BY INDEPENDENCE ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: Chairman Kao Koong-lian of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission said on Wednesday the government will not ban visits here by Tibetan, Mongolian and Turkistan independence activists.

Kao was responding to questions regarding the expected arrival in Taiwan by Thubten Jigme Norbu, the eldest brother of the Dalai Lama, and a group of Tibetan, Mongolian and Turkistan independence activists.

The delegation was invited by several local political bodies seeking Taiwan's independence, including the World Federation of Taiwanese Association, the World United Formosans for Independence, the Green Party and the Taiwan Independence Party.

The group, scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Wednesday evening, will call on Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan and Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian as well as attend a series of symposiums on Tibet's future before leaving for Japan on March 9.

Other members of the group include Tashi Jamyangling, former interior minister of the Tibetan government-in-exile; Katie Murphy, deputy director of the International Tibet Independence Movement; Johnghar Bache, vice chairman of the Inner Mongolian People's Party; Anwar Yusuf, founder of the East Turkistan Freedom Center; and, Erkin Apptekin, a representative of the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization.
Kao said that the Republic of China government still considers Tibet part of the national territory in accordance with both the provisions of the ROC Constitution and historical factors.

The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan spiritual leader, has made it clear on several occasions that he and his exiled government pursue the autonomy of Tibet, rather than its independence -- a declaration which Kao said does not come into conflict with the Constitution, which stipulates that the government should safeguard Tibet's autonomous system.
Since the government treats the Tibetan people as ROC citizens, it is in no position to ban them from advocating Tibet's independence, as Taiwan is an open and democratic society, Kao stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENOWNED DOCTOR KIDNAPPED AND MURDERED

TEXT.P: A renowned gynecologist in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, was shot to death and immolated several hours after he was kidnapped by two gunmen at his clinic on Tuesday morning, police said.

They said the charred remains of Hsieh Cheng-hsien, 42, were found abandoned in a remote mountainous area of Kaohsiung County, south of Tainan, on Wednesday afternoon. He is believed to have been shot to death before his body was set aflame, the police said. An apparent gunshot to the victim's left temple exited through the right side of his head, they said, adding that it appears the doctor had been bound with ropes.
The body was identified by Hsieh's family from dental records and physical features on Wednesday morning. But police said that DNA testing is also in process to confirm the identity.

Hsieh was apprehended by two masked men armed with knives and guns at 9:12 a.m. Tuesday at his clinic in Tainan City. Attempting to resist, Hsieh was beaten by the assailants and then bundled into to a red car, where a third kidnapper was waiting to drive away.

The kidnappers made several phone calls to Hsieh's family between Tuesday afternoon and early Wednesday morning, demanding a ransom of NT$30 million (US$923,000) in exchange for the doctor's release. The amount was eventually reduced to NT$5 million after bargaining. Although the kidnappers gave several sets of instructions as to where the ransom payment could be dropped off -- variously in Tainan County, Tainan City and Kaohsiung county -- they never showed up.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME TO RESUME TAIPEI-SEOUL AIR LINKS SAID RIPE
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Y. C. Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, said on Wednesday that "time is ripe" for South Korea to send a delegation to Taiwan to discuss the resumption of direct air links between the two nations.
Chang, who was here to attend the inauguration of Kim Dae-jung as South Korea's new president on Wednesday, said that Seoul and Taipei should discuss the matter as soon as possible.
Chang said that during his short stay in Seoul, some South Korean friends had brought up the issue with him.
He said "there is no timetable" for the resumption of air links, but there will no doubt be progress so long as both sides discuss the matter based on mutual respect and common interests.

South Korean lawmaker Sohn Sae-il, who accompanied Chang in the press conference, said improved relations, including air links, was the wish of the people of both nations, and that all democratic nations must respect the popular will.

Sohn, who returned from a visit to Taiwan last week, said that legislators from both sides will also help their governments to promote bilateral relations. He predicted that the new government of Kim Dae-jung will initiate ministerial and vice-ministerial talks with counterparts from Taiwan.
After Seoul switched diplomatic relations from Taipei to Beijing in 1992, Taiwan retaliated by cutting off direct air links between Taipei and the South Korean capital.
Chang and seven legislators from Taiwan are scheduled to return to Taipei on Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE SURPLUS DECLINED IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Amid shrinking overall foreign trade and fewer exports, Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$140 million in January, a decline of 86.7 percent compared to the same period of last year.

Statistics prepared by the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that Taiwan exported US$7.63 billion worth of goods last month, a decline of 26.3 percent from January 1997, while importing goods worth US$7.49 billion, a 19.4 percent decline.

The island's trade surplus with its traditional major trading partner, the United States, declined by 24 percent to US$390 million, resulting from US$2.03 billion worth of exports and US$1.65 billion worth of imports.

Meanwhile local exports to Japan declined by 39.8 percent to US$650 million, while imports from that country declined by 22.1 percent to US$1.75 billion, representing a negative balance of US$1.1 billion.

Taiwan's exports to Hong Kong dropped by 28.1 percent to US$1.6 billion in January, while imports from the territory were trimmed by 18.8 percent to US$150 million, accounting for a surplus of US$1.45 billion.

Taiwan's exports and imports with members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations both registered in at US$850 million, for an even balance sheet, but declined by 38.3 percent and 21 percent, respectively, from January 1997 levels.

Compared with the same period of last year, Taiwan's exports to Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines saw substantial drops of 51.6 percent, 42.6 percent, 41.9 percent and 34.9 percent, respectively, largely because of the financial woes which swept through the region.
Taiwan posted a slim trade surplus of US$20 million with European countries, with its exports to that continent listed at US$1.38 billion and imports at US$1.36 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN CARDINAL SHARES HIS HONOR WITH COMPATRIOTS

TEXT.P: Paul K.J. Shan, the newly appointed cardinal from Kaohsiung, Taiwan, shared his honor with his compatriots Wednesday upon his return from the Vatican.

At a press conference hosted by the Government Information Office, Shan pointed out that he was the only Chinese and the only Asian among 20 cardinals elevated by Pope John Paul II in a consistory at the Vatican on Saturday, which he said reflects the importance the Holy See attaches to Roman Catholicism in the Republic of China.

The pope's concern for the Chinese people, Shan added, is also indicated by the fact that there are now four ethnic Chinese cardinals worldwide, including the 94-year-old Cardinal of Shanghai Kung Pinmei, who currently lives in the United States, Cardinal Hu Chen-chung in Hong Kong, Shan himself and an undisclosed cardinal in mainland China.

That number is significant in light of the relative few Roman Catholics among the Chinese, Shan said, noting that there are only three cardinals in the Philippines among almost 60 million Catholic followers in that country, and three cardinals among 10 million believers in India.
Shan said Pope John Paul II had expressed his personal hope that the Chinese people will make outstanding contributions to world peace in next century.
Earlier Wednesday, Shan called on Premier Vincent Siew at the Executive Yuan.

Siew hailed Shan's elevation as an honor for the Roman Catholic faithful in Taiwan as well as all residents of the island. It also signified pope's approval of Taiwan's campaign for democracy and human rights protection, the premier said.
Siew said the pope has put his own stamp on the church through his choice of the new cardinals.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO ATTEND ROC-SWAZILAND ECONOMIC MEETING

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will lead a delegation to attend the fourth economic and cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and Swaziland, to be held in the Southern African country on March 3-4.

An economics official said that with the severance of diplomatic relations between the ROC and South Africa on Jan. 1, 1998, the upcoming meeting in Swaziland carries added significance. The ROC government has the intention to help Taiwanese businessmen in South Africa to relocate in Swaziland, he added.

Wang will leave for Swaziland on March 1. During his stay there, the economics minister will meet with Swaziland's King Mswati III. He will also attend the opening ceremony for a textile factory established by Taiwan's Tuntex Group.
King Mswati III will preside over the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL RETURNS FROM PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION IN SEOUL

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang returned from Seoul Wednesday night after attending the inauguration ceremony of new South Korean President Kim Dae-jung.

Upon his return at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Chang told reporters he decided to accept an invitation to the ceremony only after receiving assurances that he would be seated on the podium alongside other foreign dignitaries.
The prominent seat given to him was taken as a reflection of the importance which Seoul attaches to its relations with Taipei, Chang said.
Chang left Taipei for Seoul on Tuesday to attend Kim's inauguration ceremony. During his stay there, he also held meetings with several South Korean political leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO POLICY ON DUTY-FREE TRADE VIA THE INTERNET

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) gave support to a US proposal that electronic commerce should be discussed in the global trade regulator body, but stopped short of endorsing a plan to keep the Internet duty-free.

Washington is hoping for a quick WTO decision on duty-free Internet trade, which would apply only to products delivered by electronic means, but seems likely to be disappointed, according to reports from the organization on Wednesday.

Launching his electronic commerce initiative last July, US President Bill Clinton said he was aiming for a WTO accord within a year, and Rita Hayes, US ambassador to the WTO, said that the United States would like some results by the time of the WTO's ministerial meeting in Geneva, on May 20, 1998.

However, it was clear from the initial discussion at the WTO's ruling General Council that many countries are reluctant to make a binding commitment in the WTO without a broader look at the implication for trade and taxation of the expected explosion in electronic commerce over the next few years, the WTO report said.

Washington argues that no country currently treats electronic transmissions across borders as imports subject to customs duties, any more than they levy tariffs on international telephone calls or fax messages. Hayes said the United States was simply proposing that WTO members agree to maintain current practice "to give business certainty for the future."

The duty-free proposal applied only to products supplied electronically and would not affect tariffs on goods ordered through the Internet and delivered physically across national frontiers, she said. Nor did the proposal affect or set a precedent for domestic taxes or regulation of electronic commerce.

However, most WTO members said they needed more time to study the issues and the European Commission, which has just produced its own proposals for global governance of the Internet, said it planned to also submit some ideas to the WTO, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE ECONOMY GREW BY 7.8 PERCENT IN 1997

TEXT.P: Singapore's economic growth hit a remarkable 7.8 percent last year, nearly 1 percent higher than 1996's 6.9 percent rise, but it is expected to slow significantly this year, the Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) said Wednesday.

The government's earlier official forecast of economic growth for 1998 was set at between 5 percent and 7 percent. However, the MTI had to readjust its growth forecast down to between 2.5 and 4.5 percent, taking into account the adverse effects of the regional economic crisis and financial turmoil which have swept through Southeast Asian countries since last July, an MTI spokesman said.
He pointed out that the construction sector, boosted by public works projects, scored a remarkably high growth rate of 13 percent last year, leading all economic sectors on the growth path.
The financial sector, which also achieved a high 11 percent growth rate in 1997, also contributed a great deal to the Singapore economy, he added.

Due to the recovery of the world's electronics industry in the latter half of last year, Singapore's manufacturing sector, with electronics being its major pillar, also achieved an impressive growth of 8.6 percent last year, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM ONE: ROC VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER IN LONDON FOR WTO TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo & C.L. Ou)

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-fu, vice economic affairs Minister of the Republic of China, arrived in London on Wednesday at the head of an ROC government mission to take part in a Taiwan-Britain bilateral economic and trade consultation slated to kick off on Thursday.

Lin and British Trade and Industry Minister Tony Hutton will lead their respective delegations into the talks, during which the two sides will exchange views on Taiwan's monopoly tax on whiskey imports from Britain, and finance, insurance and law firm operations.

Talks over Taiwan's monopoly tax on Scotch whisky will be the centerpiece of the consultation as Taiwan has recently agreed in principle to cut the tax on spirits from the European Union (EU). Taiwan made the concession on Wednesday in the second day of the 12th round of ROC-EU talks on terms for Taipei's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Britain has been so successful at marketing Scotch whisky in Taiwan during the last several years that it is now the second largest British export item to the island.

Scotch whisky, however, has been unable to compete with Japanese whiskey in Taiwan because the liquors from Europe are hit with much higher taxes than similar products from other regions, British trade sources complained.

Under Taiwan's tobacco and alcohol monopoly system, a tax of NT$440 (US$13.4) per liter is levied on whiskey from Scotland and Ireland, while the rate for whiskey from other regions is set at NT$198 (US$6).
The Scot Whisky Association called the taxation schedule discriminatory and said it is responsible for the decreased market share of European liquors.

Scotch whisky accounted for 38.49 percent of total liquor imports in the first 10 months of last year, down from 44.64 percent in 1996, while the market share of Japanese whiskey rose from 6.78 percent to 22.21 percent over the same period, according to Taiwan customs sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TWO: FORMER US NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER LAKE TO VISIT TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Tony Lake, a former US national security adviser, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on March 4 for a four-day visit.
During his stay in Taipei, Lake will deliver a speech on the US role in Asia-Pacific regional security and meet with senior Republic of China officials for wide-ranging talks.

Lake, who left his former post just over a year ago, served as the top security adviser to President Bill Clinton during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis. His speech is expected to provide a glimpse into the thinking of Washington's inner circles regarding Asia-Pacific security issues.

Stephen Chen, Taiwan's de facto ambassador to the United States, said Lake is well aware of the twists and turns in ROC-US relations. "We believe his visit will help boost mutual understanding between the two countries."
Chen hosted a luncheon in honor of Lake on Wednesday, wishing him a good trip to Taipei.
Lake, now a professor at Georgetown University, told reporters after the luncheon that he has long planned to visit Taiwan. "I'm delighted that this plan will be realized soon."

Lake's Taipei visit is organized by the Central Daily News. In addition to delivering a series of speeches, he will meet with ROC officials in charge of diplomatic, mainland and national security affairs. He is also expected to meet with President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew.
Lake served as Clinton's top national security adviser from January 1993 through the end of 1996. Clinton once named Lake as director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

After three days of tedious and often embarrassing congressional questioning about his personal finances during the confirmation process, Lake issued a statement saying he would rather give up the appointment than endure further insults. He later decided to take up a teaching post at Georgetown University. Lake holds a doctorate in public and international affairs from Princeton University.
Earlier this year, former US Defense Secretary William Perry also headed a high-profile delegation of former American officials to visit mainland China and Taiwan.

Members of Perry's delegation, which focused on relations across the Taiwan Strait, included John Shalikashvili, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Brent Scowcroft, a former national security adviser.

The prestigious Washington Post reported recently that Perry's mission was part of a delicate attempt by the US government to open an informal back channel of communications with both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The paper said US officials, frustrated by not-very-productive official dialogue with mainland China on Taiwan-related issues and the US government ban on travel to Taiwan by senior American officials since Washington switched recognition to Beijing in 1979, have encouraged the formation of what they call a "track 2" dialogue with Taipei and Beijing with the aim of decreasing tension between the two rivals.

However, Clinton administration officials have clarified the Washington Post report, saying that the Perry mission's visits to both sides of the Taiwan Strait were private in nature and that the opinions expressed by the delegation members did not represent the administration's official stance.

Political observers said even though opinions expressed by those former US security officials do not necessarily represent official US positions, the visits to Taipei by the Perry delegation and Lake will help the people of Taiwan better understand the basic US stance on cross-strait relations and the role the US wants to play in the Asia-Pacific region.
