DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM FOUR: WTO ENTRY BY YEAR'S END SAID POSSIBLE

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Thursday that Taiwan may have the chance to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) by the end of the year.

Wang made the remarks when he and Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Peng Tzuo-kuei, along with COA Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung, called on the opposition New Party caucus at the Legislative Yuan.

Asked when Taiwan could expect gain membership in the world trade regulatory body, Wang said Taiwan has so far concluded negotiations with 24 of the 26 WTO signatory parties that requested bilateral talks, thus the accession bid is entering the final stage.
Taiwan is now wrapping up talks with the 15-member European Union (EU), and will soon hold another round of discussions with Switzerland, Wang said.
He said the WTO working party screening Taiwan's membership application is expected to hold a meeting in April for multilateral talks on the matter.
The WTO Secretariat has prepared a report on Taiwan's application and a draft protocol on terms for its accession, which are expected to be discussed at the WTO working party in its April meeting.
Wang said it is likely that Taiwan can join the WTO by the end of the year, although he cannot be sure of the timetable.

On concerns about the adverse impact of compliance with WTO liberalization measures upon Taiwan's chicken and hog industries, Peng said the COA will set up a NT$3 billion (US$92.3 million), six-year program to help the poultry industry adjust.

Peng said hog farmers will eventually have to reduce the islandwide hog population by 2 million head from the current 8 million. The COA will also devise counseling programs and rescue packages as well as improve distribution networks to keep industry losses to a minimum.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM FIVE: PLANS FOR LEE'S AFRICAN TOUR UNDECIDED, SAYS SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen on Thursday kept mum about whether President Lee Teng-hui's planned trip to Africa will be canceled or postponed, saying only that everything is yet to be decided.

Chen, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), declined to comment on recent local newspaper reports that Lee's African tour, scheduled to take place between late March and early April, will be postponed or canceled outright because of concerns over flight security, weather conditions, the availability of telecommunication facilities and medical factors.
He said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Presidential Office are in close consultation over the proposed visits to ROC allies in Africa, but nothing is finalized at the moment.

Meanwhile, Chen was also tight-lipped about Vice President Lien Chan's current trip to the Middle East. He admitted that he could not say anything about Lien's itinerary, except to confirm a visit to Jordan, in order to avoid interference from Beijing that could jeopardize the remainder of his tour.

Chen said that with Beijing stepping up efforts to suppress Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy initiatives, arrangements for high-level officials to travel abroad, particularly to countries maintaining no formal ties with the ROC, have become increasingly difficult.
Relevant sources disclosed that Lien's plans to fly to Lebanon and Bahrain following his Feb. 23-25 visit to Jordan may be altered due to objections from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM SIX: S'PORE ECONOMIC SECTORAL GROWTH RATES IN 1997

TEXT.P: Singapore scored a better-than-expected economic growth of 7.8 percent in 1997, almost one percentage point higher than the 6.9 percent growth in 1996.

By sector, construction rose the most in 1997 at 13.3 percent, followed by financial and business services at 11.0 percent, transport and communications at 9.2 percent, commerce at 5.8 percent, manufacturing at 4.3 percent and others at 7.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM SEVEN: PREMIER CONDEMNS "IRRATIONAL" OPPOSITION TO BAYER PROJECT

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday condemned the violence that erupted earlier this month in a public hearing on a plan by German chemical giant Bayer to set up a plant in central Taiwan's Taichung County.
Siew said that Bayer's US$1.5 billion investment project has been under assessment over the past four years, but noted that the public still has misgivings about the plan.
He said, however, that such concerns should be expressed through normal channels, adding that the silent majority will not condone the use of violence.

Commenting on repeated clashes between local people and police units during the Taiwan Provincial Assembly's screening process for the project, Siew also said that relevant government agencies should act to prevent illegal or irregular activities associated with the controversial project, less they have a detrimental influence on public safety and social stability.
Siew's words came during a screening meeting on the land-leasing agreement with Bayer in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly on Thursday.
The meeting was delayed for nearly 90 minutes as legislators from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) discussed strategies behind closed doors.

But soon after the screening began at 10:55 a.m., DPP Assemblyman Yu Cheng-dao accused his colleague Lin Chin-chun of the KMT of having dinner with officials from land development companies during the Chinese New Year holiday to discuss possible allocation of construction work for the project after Bayer's proposal cleared the provincial assembly.
Lin, saying that Yu has insulted him, demanded evidence to substantiate the accusation. He also asked for an independent investigation of the matter.
Several KMT assemblymen echoed his demands and asked Yu to renounce his right of legislative immunity in order to undergo an investigation. But Yu refused and a bitter war of words erupted.
Yang Wen-hsin, deputy speaker of Provincial Assembly, had to adjourn the screening meeting until the afternoon due to the chaotic situation.
Meanwhile, nearly 1,000 people opposed to the Bayer project again gathered in front of the Provincial Assembly building, waving banners and making speeches to voice their opposition to the plan.

But supporters of the project were not present this time. One official from the pro-Bayer camp said his alliance did not mobilize the public in the interest of maintaining local harmony and because they had already clearly expressed their views.
A police force of 1,500 was deployed to maintain order.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM EIGHT: INTERNATIONAL DRUG RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: After more than a year of effort, law-enforcement officers managed to break a Hong Kong-based drug trafficking ring and seize 100 kilograms of mainalnd China-originated heroin and amphetamine Wednesday evening, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) reported on Thursday.
Three key suspects involved in the illegal narcotics trade, including a former Hong Kong police officer, were also arrested in Keelung, a port city some 30 kilometers north of Taipei.

The mastermind of the ring, identified as Cheung Po Ming, once served as a unit leader in the Hong Kong police department, MJIB officials said. He left his post a few years ago and had since used his professional expertise to smuggle contraband drugs into Taiwan.

As Cheung was familiar with criminal investigative tactics, he used various anti-shadowing techniques to counter local investigators' monitoring activities. The special task force, composed of MJIB agents, prosecutors and military police officers, has devoted much energy and resources to probe the ring's activities over the past year.

The task force had kept on high alert after it found that the ring might have smuggled a new batch of drugs from mainland China during the Lunar New Year holiday. MJIB agents had closely shadowed Cheung upon his arrival in Taipei on Monday.

Cheung and his accomplice, Ng Tim Ka, also a Hong Kong resident, were caught red-handed on Wednesday as they were taking delivery of 16 heroin bricks, with a street value of about NT$250 million (US$7.69 million), and 37 bags of amphetamine, worth some NT$150 million, from a refrigerated warehouse in suburban Keelung and loading them into an automobile.

MJIB officers said the drugs were shipped from the mainland via a fishing boat operated by Hsu Kun, who was also arrested on Wednesday. The drugs were hidden in five of the 400 cartons of jellyfish smuggled from the mainland.

Cheung's ring allegedly was also involved in the smuggling of two batches of heroin from the mainland into Taiwan, which were seized by law-enforcement officers on Dec. 4 and Dec. 14, 1996, respectively. The ring had managed to set up a warehouse and an islandwide distribution network in Taiwan over the past year.
MJIB Director-General Wang Jung-chou lauded local investigators for their professional sills and patience in probing the case.

Wang said about 50 percent of heroin and 70 percent of amphetamine confiscated here were originated in mainland China. "We hope mainland authorities will closely cooperate with us to crack down on drug trafficking," he added.

Peng Kun-yeh, a chief prosecutor with the Taipei Prosecutor's Office, said the busting of Cheung's ring was of great significance because it was a major source of contraband drugs circulating here. "As Cheung usually stayed in Hong Kong and only made brief stops here to arrange for drug sales, it was a tough task to arrest him," he added.
MJIB officials said the special task force will continue to investigate whether there are other accomplices and the ring's middle- and down-stream distribution channels here.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM NINE: NZ SEEKS AUSSIE EXPERTISE TO RESTORE POWER IN AUCKLAND

TEXT.P: New Zealand has urgently asked for Australian expertise and resources to help restore power after a serious blackout in its biggest city of Auckland, which has curtailed commercial and other activities in the past few days.

Mercury Energy of Australia, which has been requested to help restore the power in Auckland, is sending seven power generators and cable jointers to help repair the damaged lines that caused the blackout in Auckland's central commercial district.

A Mercury spokesman said that the repair process, estimated to cost about A$1.5 million, will begin immediately and that Auckland will have 40 percent of the lost power restored by next week. But full power may return until March 15.
The blackout in Auckland was the first serious such incident in a decade. And New Zealand has no necessary expertise to grapple with the blackout because it has no cable jointers.

Auckland is the biggest city in New Zealand with a population of over 1 million, including tens of thousands of migrants from Taiwan, Hong Kong, mainland China, Japan, South Korea, Vietnam and the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TEN: MIGRANTS SAID HELPING BOOST JOB PROSPECTS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Immigrants do not rob jobs from Australians, but instead help boost job prospects for the unemployed people in this country, according to a new survey by the Australian National University in Canberra.

The survey, conducted by economists Prof. Bruce Chapman and Dr. Deborah Cobb-Clark, shows many Australians fail to recognize that while immigrants add to the competition for jobs, they also increase employment by spending savings brought into this country.
They said the benefits flowing to the unemployed from immigration are higher during periods of economic recession than at other times.

"The conclusion drawn from the exercise is precisely the opposite of that promoted in populist discussion: Specifically, chances of an unemployed resident gaining employment, immigration is more likely to achieve this the more recessed the labor market," they said.

Chapman said the conclusion is justified from "the overwhelming weight of evidence from the United States, Canada and Australia that higher levels of immigration have not been associated with higher levels of unemployment."
Under the current coalition government, the immigration intake for fiscal 1997-98 is set at 68,000, down sharply from nearly 100,000 in 1996-97.

The lower quota is the result of economic downturn, which keeps Australia's unemployment rate quite high at more than 8 percent with about 750,000 unemployed, and the criticism of Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, who said higher intake of immigrants, especially from Asia, has cost Australians jobs.
The Australian government is now alarmed by the Asian economic crisis, which could slow employment and increase unemployment rates in this country.
Market economists have predicted the unemployment rate could rise to 9 percent, with more than 800,000 jobless later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM ELEVEN: SINGAPORE 1998 GROWTH FORECAST CUT TO 2.5%-4.5%

TEXT.P: The Singapore government on Wednesday sharply downgraded its economic growth forecast for 1998 to between 2.5 percent and 4.5 percent due to the Asian financial turmoil, but it ruled out for now any fears of a recession.
The forecast is a drop from the 5 percent to 7 percent growth predicted by the Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) last November, and is the lowest projection since the 1985 recession.
It is also a hefty fall against last year's better-than-expected growth of 7.8 percent, announced in Singapore's annual economic survey report released Wednesday.

The 1997 growth, buoyed by a revised third-quarter figure and a resilient fourth quarter, was an increase on the 7.6 percent Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong announced in his New Year Message. It was, in fact, higher than the 6.9 percent growth in 1996.
Singapore's economic growth peaked at 10.5 percent in 1994, before slowing down to 8.7 percent in 1995.
A spokesman for MTI said on Wednesday that at this point, "We are not expecting a recession, but obviously we are making our forecast against a very volatile background."
He noted that when the MTI issued its preliminary 1998 forecast last November, the Indonesian rupiah was trading at 3,300 to the US dollar. The current rate is about 9,380:1.
The slowdown caused by the regional turmoil would be offset by continued growth in the United States and European countries, he said.
The impact of the regional turmoil began to filter through to industries with a high reliance on regional demand only in the fourth quarter.

"But overall, the diversified nature of our economy helped to overcome the initial impact of the regional financial turmoil, and except for the construction and commerce sectors, all sectors grew faster in 1997," the spokesman said.
Fourth-quarter growth was a respectable 7.6 percent. The third quarter was revised to 10.7 percent from 10.1.
Growth in the current year is likely to be driven by the manufacturing and construction sectors, which grew 4.3 percent and 13.3 percent, respectively, last year.
The transport and communications sector will also pull its weight, although growth there is expected to moderate from last year's 9.2 percent.
Likely underperformers will be companies in the finance and commerce sectors as the regional economic slowdown begins to bite.

Commerce is expected to take a hit as entrepot trade with the region slows and regional tourist arrivals fall. The retail trade in Singapore will also feel the pinch amid lower tourist numbers and weak domestic demand.
In 1997, commerce grew 5.8 percent compared to 1996's 6.2 percent.

Financial and business services, which expanded 11 percent in 1997, are also likely to experience slower growth this year amid a drop in regional lending activity in the Singapore-based Asian dollar market, which is basically an offshore banking system.
Despite the MTI's growth scale-back, the Straits Times Industrials Index closed 21.47 points higher at 1,583.22 on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TWELEVE: FLIGHT SIMULATOR GIANTS LINK UP WITH TAIWAN PARTNERS

TEXT.P: The Asia-Pacific market potential for flight simulators and related products has prompted two of world's leading simulation systems creators to seek partners in the region for business expansion.

Reflectone of the United States will sign a cooperative agreement with Taiwan's state-run Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation (AIDC) at the Asian Aerospace Show here on Thursday, designed to set up a regional manufacturing, maintenance and repair center for simulators with both aeronautical and entertainment applications, by merging the capital resources and technical know-how of the two companies.
The deal is estimated to generate US$15 million worth of business annually. It will also allow AIDC to receive technology transfers from the leading US simulator maker.

Canada's CAE Inc., which controls a 70 percent stake of the global civil flight simulator market, will also forge a strategic alliance with the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) of Taiwan on Thursday at the aerospace exhibition in Singapore.
CAE, headquartered in Toronto and operating several facilities worldwide, is a technology leader known for the design and manufacture of flight simulation equipment.

Company representatives said CAE expects Asia to be the most rapidly expanding market for the global flight simulator sector over the next 20 years due to its obviously urgent need for advanced aviation management systems and expertise.

What prompts the CAE to develop cooperative links with Taiwan is its assessment that the island's consumer power and human resources make it the best stronghold for advancing into the huge Asia-Pacific market, they said.

The representatives added that the CIST's successful development of a simulation system for fighter squadrons and Taiwan's large market for military simulation systems and training devices were also encouraging.

The CIST is the military-run technology research unit that designed and built Taiwan's first locally developed Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF), also known as the "Ching Kuo" fighter, after the late Republic of China President Chiang Ching-kuo.

A CIST spokesman said during the exhibition that its new fighter squadron simulator is entirely "made in Taiwan," the joint creation of the CIST and other six domestic enterprises in the information, chemical and electronic sectors.

With its available expertise and technologies, as well as the imminent alliance with CAE, the spokesman said, the CIST hopes to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific regional hub for the manufacture, maintenance and repair of civil and military flight simulators.
The AIDC and CIST are among nine Taiwan aerospace and aviation industry companies and insititutes taking part in the week-long 1998 Asian Aerospace Show.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM THIRTEEN: NT DOLLAR RISES

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar surged to NT$32.2 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday.
The local currency enjoyed a significant growth of NT$0.351 at the market after the inauguration of Peng Huai-nan, new governor for the Taipei-based Central Bank of China.
The NT dollar opened at 32.551 and was traded in a range between 32.2 and 32.64.
Interbank trading reached US$564.5 million.
Peng, 59, was sworn in as the governor of Taiwan's central bank, a position left by Sheu Yuan-dong who died in the February 16 China Airlines air crash.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM FOURTEEN: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH VISITING BELIZE MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui met here on Thursday with Alfredo Martinez, Belize's minister of industry and commerce, and Martinez's wife, extending them a warm welcome to Taiwan.

Lee told the foreign guests that the Republic of China is glad to further enhance links with Belize and also hopes that exchanges and cooperation between the two nations can be expanded in the very near future.

He also noted that he talked with Belize Prime Minister Manuel Esquivel about matters related to Taipei-Belmopan exchanges in fields including trade, economy and culture during the 1997 Central American summit in El Salvador.
Lee attended the summit during a visit to Latin America aimed at cementing Taipei's ties with its diplomatic allies in the region.
Martinez echoed Lee's hopes, adding that the government and people of his country thank the ROC for its help in Belize's development.
Belize and the ROC forged diplomatic relations in October 1989. The two allies signed agreements on agricultural cooperation two years later.
Taiwan sent an agricultural mission to Belize in 1991 and has been helping the Central American nation develop self-supporting agricultural businesses ever since.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM FIFTEEN: S'PORE'S GDP TOPPED US$86 B. IN 1997

TEXT.P: Singapore's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) amounted to S$143.0 billion (US$86.1 billion) in 1997, some S$12 billion more than 1996's S$130.8 billion, according to the Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry.
By the end of 1997, Singapore had accumulated official foreign exchange reserves totaling S$119.6 billion, it said.
The unemployment rate fell from 2.0 percent in 1996 to 1.8 percent in 1997, while Singapore's current account balance rose from S$20.6 billion to S$21.7 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM SIXTEEN: ANOTHER SUSPECT IN HONG KONG-BASED DRUG RING ARRESTED

TEXT.P: Another suspect involved in a Hong Kong-based drug trafficking ring, which allegedly had sumggled NT$400 million (US$12.3 million) worth of heroin and amphetamine from mainland China into Taiwan recently, was arrested in the northern Taiwan port city of Keelung on Thursday.

The suspect, identified as Lam Kay Man, a Hong Kong passport holder, was arrested early Thursday morning at a bowling alley in downtown Keelung, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said. Lam has taken residence in Taiwan for several years. He was allegedly responsible for taking delivery of contraband drugs sent by the ring from abroad.
After more than a year of effort, three other key suspects wanted in connection with illegal narcotics trade, including a former Hong Kong police officer, were arrested on Wednesday.
MJIB agents also managed to confiscate 100 kilograms of mainland China-originated heroin and amphetamine, with a street value of NT$400 million, in Wednesday's raid.

The mastermind of the ring, identified as Cheung Po Ming, once served as a unit leader in the Hong Kong police department, MJIB officials said. He left his post a few years ago and had since used his professional expertise to smuggle contraband drugs into Taiwan.

As Cheung was familiar with criminal investigative tactics, he used various anti-shadowing techniques to counter local investigators' monitoring activities. The special task force, composed of MJIB agents, prosecutors and military police officers, has devoted much energy and resources to probe the ring's activities over the past year.

The task force had kept on high alert after it found that the ring might have smuggled a new batch of drugs from mainland China during the Lunar New Year holiday. MJIB agents had closely shadowed Cheung upon his arrival in Taipei on Monday.

Cheung and his accomplice, Ng Tim Ka, also a Hong Kong resident, were caught red-handed on Wednesday as they were taking delivery of 16 heroin bricks, with a street value of about NT$250 million (US$7.69 million), and 37 bags of amphetamine, worth some NT$150 million, from a refrigerated warehouse in suburban Keelung and loading them into an automobile.

MJIB officers said the drugs were shipped from the mainland via a fishing boat operated by Hsu Kun, who was also arrested on Wednesday. The drugs were hidden in five of the 400 cartons of jellyfish smuggled from the mainland.

Cheung's ring allegedly was also involved in the smuggling of two batches of heroin from the mainland into Taiwan, which were seized by law-enforcement officers on Dec. 4 and Dec. 14, 1996, respectively. The ring had managed to set up a warehouse and an islandwide distribution network in Taiwan over the past year.
MJIB Director-General Wang Jung-chou lauded local investigators for their professional sills and patience in probing the case.

Wang said about 50 percent of heroin and 70 percent of amphetamine confiscated here were originated in mainland China. "We hope mainland authorities will closely cooperate with us to crack down on drug trafficking," he added.

Peng Kun-yeh, a chief prosecutor with the Taipei Prosecutor's Office, said the busting of Cheung's ring was of great significance because it was a major source of contraband drugs circulating here. "As Cheung usually stayed in Hong Kong and only made brief stops here to arrange for drug sales, it was a tough task to arrest him," he added.
MJIB officials said the special task force will continue to investigate whether there are other accomplices as well as the ring's middle- and down-stream distribution channels here.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM SEVENTEEN: REGIONAL TURMOIL TO HAVE WIDE-RANGING IMPACT ON S'PORE

TEXT.P: The regional financial turmoil will have a wide-ranging impact on the Singapore economy, with both domestic and external demand for goods and services being hit hard, according to the Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI).
One bright spot is that demand from the United States and Europe will help lift exports, the ministry said in a study on the impact of the regional financial turmoil on the Singapore economy.

"Given our diversified export market, exports of goods are likely to be sustained by healthy demand from the United States and European Union, while services exports are expected to be more severely hit by the regional economic slowdown," it said.
The demand for Singapore-made goods and services by neighboring countries is likely to be hit harder in view of Singapore's close links with the region, it noted.

Sweetening the picture for domestic investment spending will be the fillip provided by expenditure on infrastructure such as the construction of Singapore's Northeast MRT line and Housing Development Board upgrading projects.
But the impact of the regional slowdown on consumption expenditure is likely to be fairly significant, the MTI said.

Slower economic activity and a negative wealth effect following sharp declines in the Singapore and Malaysian stock markets -- which fell by 36 percent and 47 percent respectively between July last year and January this year -- is likely to reduce domestic consumption spending.
At the same time, the strength of the Singapore dollar in relation to regional currencies will result in Singaporeans spending more overseas, it said.

Between 1991 and 1997, Singaporeans' overseas trips by air rose by an average of 13 percent every year. Increased visits to neighboring countries will particularly have an impact on retailers of daily provisions in Singapore, the ministry said.

Businesses are expected to hold back investing in new machinery and equipment amid the weaker demand and greater uncertainty. Moreover, poor sentiment in the property market is likely to limit the buying of homes and commercial buildings.

The study noted that with the new alignment of the regional currencies, Singapore -- with its relatively strong dollar -- is likely to face greater regional competition for investment from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. "The challenge is for Singapore to continue upgrading our capabilities to stay one step ahead," it said.

The appreciation of the local dollar will also affect Singapore's exports to the region, it pointed out. Exports meant for local consumption in the region will be hit badly, but exports used as intermediate inputs and reexported to developed countries are "likely to remain relatively healthy."

The MTI said it expects a significant impact on the exports of services like air and sea cargo as they are destined largely for the region. Singapore serves as an important hub for the movement of people and goods.
Air and sea cargo movement to the region slowed significantly in the second half of last year.

The study noted that tourism earnings are also likely to be adversely affected as there will be fewer visitors from the region due to the fall in disposable income and a more expensive Singapore dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM EIGHTEEN: SHARE PRICES LEAP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices jumped 2.2 percent on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday, encouraged by an overnight rally on Wall Street.

The overall bullish sentiment contributed to by the gains in New York and the inauguration of Taiwan's new central bank governor prompted institutional investors to release capital for stocks, especially high-tech and semiconductor issues, dealers said.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the market's key indicator, surged 202.09 points to close at 9,229.19.
The bourse opened at 9,144.26, with the index fluctuating between 9,229.19 and 9,126.56.
Advancing stocks overwhelmed those falling 358 to 78, with 51 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 3.29 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$209.61 billion (US$6.51 billion), rising from the 2.77 billion issues valued at NT$175.3 billion that changed hands in the previous session.
Electrical engineering shares posted the largest gain among eight major stock categories, at 3.6 percent.

Both cement and foodstuff issues followed with 2.1 percent rises. Financial stocks surged 1.8 percent. Plastic and chemical issues and textile shares registered 1.3 percent growths, while construction stocks climbed 0.9 percent and paper-making issues moved up 0.8 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, ACER, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Winbond Electronics, Macronix International, Holtek Microelectronics, Mitac International, Mosel-Vitelic, China Petrochemical and First International Computer.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM NINETEEN: DPP SAYS LOCAL PARTY LEADERS' VISIT TO PRC IS PRIVATE

TEXT.P: No body can visit the Chinese mainland on behalf of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the present time, Yen Wan-ching, director of the Mainland Chinese Affairs Department of the party, said here Thursday.

Yen made the remark when asked to comment on a recent mainland Chinese radio news report by the "Voice of Taiwan Straits" that a 16-member delegation of DPP's county and city party committees visited the mainland earlier this month.
Yen said the week-long visit was organized by (DPP county and city party committee) "Chairmen's Association," which is a private organization. The visit ended on Feb. 22.

He said that there is no party-to-party exchanges between the DPP and mainland China, and that the DPP "neither encourages nor prohibits" its party members from making private exchanges with the mainland.
The Voice of Taiwan Strait said in the report that the visit "marked a good beginning." The DPP's mainland Chinese policy makers may benefit from the visit, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TWENTY: FUNDS FOR GUARANTEEING LOANS TO OVERSEAS CHINESE TO BE INCREASED

TEXT.P: The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission of the Executive Yuan in Taipei will increase the funds for guaranteeing business loans to overseas Chinese to NT$1,070 million (US$33.5 million), an OCAC official said Thursday.

He quoted OCAC minister Chiao Jen-ho as saying earlier this month at the 18th International Trade Study Class for overseas Chinese businessmen that the funds will be increased gradually for the convenience of overseas Chinese who need bank loans to do business.

The Bank of Taiwan, the First Commercial Bank, the Changhua Commercial Bank, and the Huanan Commercial Bank have agreed to contribute to the funds, the OCAC official said. But he did not disclose the current amount of the funds.

Chiao said the OCAC will try to make services of overseas Chinese commercial banks available in more places in the world. President Lee Teng-hui has hoped that where there are overseas Chinese there are overseas Chinese banks, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TWENTY-ONE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT CANCELS TRIP TO LEBANON
DOC.DATELINE: Beirut, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Yang I-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan has canceled a planned trip to the Middle East state of Lebanon because of strong pressure from the ROC's archrival, mainland China.
Lien may return to Taipei via Bahrain, but it is possible that his itinerary might be subject to further change.

Hotel sources said Lien had canceled reservations for three rooms in Beirut's Commodore Hotel. He was originally expected to arrive here on Thursday for a groundbreaking visit, but did not appear to have been aboard either of Thursday's two scheduled flights from Jordan to Lebanon.

Local diplomatic sources said mainland Chinese embassies in the region had pressured various Middle East countries to revoke visas already issued to Lien after the itinerary of his trip was reported by the media.

The sources pointed out that Lebanon is particularly sensitive to pressure from Beijing as mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen promised late last year to offer US$6 million in aid to Lebanon to help it rebuild its war-torn infrastructure.

Other sources said the ROC has maintained regular contacts with Lebanon in recent years. However, as the two sides have yet to come to terms on some critical issues, no major breakthrough in bilateral relations has been achieved so far. The ROC originally had hoped that Lien's visit could help push forward the long-stalled bilateral ties.

Lien left Taipei for Jordan on Monday for a private visit to receive an honorary doctorate from the University of Jordan. Previous press reports had said Lien then would travel to Lebanon and Bahrain. None of the three Middle East states maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.

He was also reportedly scheduled to make a stopover in the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur on his way home to discuss with senior Malaysian officials feasible ccoperative measures to address the current Asian financial turmoil.

However, Beijing's sabotage has now caused Lien's itinerary following his Jordan visit to become uncertain. Beijing has been waging an extensive campaign against the ROC's diplomatic activities in an attempt to isolate Taiwan in the international community. Against his backdrop, senior ROC officials often have to keep their overseas travel plans secret.

Despite Beijing's pressure, Lien still had managed to visit several major countries which do not maintain formal diploamtic ties with the ROC in the past few years, including the Czech Republic, Austria, Ukraine, Iceland and Ireland. The current Middle East visit is Lien second trip abroad so far this year. He visited Singapore in January.

On his Middle East visit, Lien is being accompanied by his wife and several senior government officials and close aides, including Minister Without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi. Lien is scheduled to return to Taipei on March 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TWENTY-TWO: MAC WELCOMES ARATS RESPONSE TO SEF PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh issued a statement on Thursday welcoming a response from the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to its Taiwan counterpart the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) saying that it would welcome a visit to mainland China by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu at an "appropriate time."
Chang expressed delight over the ARATS message and said the MAC has instructed the SEF to maintain further contact with the ARATS to make the necessary arrangements for such a visit.

Citing a policy address by Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday, Chang said Taiwan's stance on cross-strait talks is that any issues which are beneficial to the interests of both sides of the Taiwan Strait can be discussed under the framework set by previous SEF-ARATS talks and that negotiations on matters which are vital to the interests of the people on the two sides should be discussed first.

Taiwan has maintained a firm stance in this regard over the past two years and eight months, and has been seeking to create a favorable climate for the resumption of cross-strait talks, which were unilaterally suspended by Beijing in July, 1995 after a visit to the United States by President Lee Teng-hui, the MAC head said.
Welcoming the ARATS response to the SEF proposal, he expressed the hope that the current low ebb in cross-strait exchanges will soon warm up.

The SEF and the ARATS are the quasi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing respectively to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TWENTY-THREE: VISITOR ARRIVALS IN S'PORE PLUNGE FOR FOURTH MONTH

TEXT.P: The number of visitors coming to Singapore dropped for the fourth month in a row in January as a result of the regional currency turmoil and economic slowdown.

However, the Chinese New Year holidays brought a ray of sunshine to the gloomy Singapore tourism industry with a sharp rise in visitors from Hong Kong, Taiwan and mainland China, the Singapore Tourism Board said Wednesday.
Only 509,752 tourists came to Singapore in January, a 16.7 percent plunge over the same month last year, it reported.
This is the steepest drop since October last year, when visitor arrival figures started plummeting for the first time in 14 years.
Last October, visitor arrivals plunged 17.6 percent against the figure for October 1996 as a result of the regional financial crisis and the smoke haze.
In November, the figure was 10.7 percent lower and in December, 15 percent.
Singapore's top three tourist markets -- Indonesia, Japan and Malaysia -- all showed double-digit declines in January.
The number of ASEAN visitors went down almost 15 percent.
The market that shrank the most was Japan. Holiday visitors fell by 40 percent, while business visitors went down almost 35 percent.
The Chinese New Year holidays, however, brought more visitors from Hong Kong, Taiwan and mainland China, the tourism board said.
The number of Hong Kong visitors climbed almost 45 percent, while visitors from Taiwan rose 13 percent and from mainland China by 10 percent, it added.
The regional economic crisis has also resulted in a marginal fall of 0.4 percent in the average standard room rate in hotels to S$148 (US$89) a night, the tourism board said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITEM TWENTY-FOUR: S'POREANS SPEND MORE ON TRIPS ABROAD

TEXT.P: Singaporeans' spending on overseas trips amounted to S$6.3 billion (US$3.8 billion) last year, compared to S$5.7 billion in 1996, according to figures from the Singapore Department of Statistics.

Despite any effect the regional financial crisis might have at home, they spent 11 percent more in 1997 on overseas trips, which were mainly in the turmoil-hit regional countries where the Singapore dollar's buying power stretched further.
As a share of Singapore's overall consumption at S$49.5 billion in 1997, 12.6 percent was due to overseas spending, up from 12.2 percent in 1996 and 11.5 percent in 1992.
Regional currency crisis or not, Singaporeans certainly were not on an austerity drive last year.
They spent 6.7 percent more year-on-year on food, clothing, rent, utilities, furnishing, medical bills, transport, recreation and education, according to the figures.

The figures also showed that Singaporeans spent S$7.6 billion or 1.3 percent more on food and beverages, 5.7 percent more on rent and utilities (S$6.6 billion), 5.9 percent more on furniture and household equipment (S$4.4 billion) and 1.1 percent more on recreation and education (S$7.7 billion).
But transport and communications spending dipped 1.8 percent to S$7.9 billion.

The strength of the Singapore dollar vis-a-vis regional currencies is likely to result in increases in Singaporeans' expenditures abroad, noted the Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry in its economic survey report.
The Singapore dollar gained 4.1 percent against a trade-weighted basket of currencies -- including the Malaysian ringgit, Thai baht and South Korean won -- from last July to the end of last year.
But the Indonesian rupiah had fallen nearly 70 percent against the Singapore dollar since last July 1, while the ringgit, baht and the Philippine peso were down by between 20 percent and 30 percent.
The number of outbound trips Singaporeans made by air rose an average of 13 percent annually between 1991 and 1997.
For the first 10 months of last year, Singaporeans made 1.8 million overseas trips by air, compared to 2.2 million trips in the whole of 1996 and 2 million in 1995.

Besides losing Singaporean customers, the double-whammy for Singapore retailers is that tourists visiting Singapore spent just S$8.2 billion here last year -- 11 percent less than their 1996 shopping bill of S$9.2 billion, the report said, adding that was already 4.8 percent lower than tourist spending here in 1995.
Tourist spending was just 16.5 percent of overall consumption in 1997, down from 19.8 percent in 1996 and 22.3 percent in 1995, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY GOVERNMENT UNABLE TO PAY EMPLOYEES

TEXT.P: Government employees, including teachers, in central Taiwan's Nantou County, will not receive their pay checks for March, the head of the county announced on Thursday.

Peng Pai-shien, who took over leadership of the agricultural county in January following the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)'s victory in December elections, said that as the county coffers are emptying, he has decided that pay for nearly 8,000 public servants in the county will be suspended.

The DPP magistrate said that he has reported the county's financial plight to the central government, stressing that if the central government fails to offer substantial assistance, the suspension will continue indefinitely.

Peng said that the annual revenue of Nantou County stood at just NT$2.1 billion approximately, but payroll spending for local government employees costs NT$420 million per month, a total of NT$5 billion per year. This spending deficit means the county government always has to rely on grants from the central government, he said.

Describing his decision as being made "unwillingly," Peng called on local government employees to support his decision. However, he added that the local government might use a NT$200 million educational subsidy to make up part of the payroll, which would mean that the employees will at least get half of their pay for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH CUSTOMS CHIEF VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The customs chiefs of the Republic of China and the Czech Republic met here on Thursday, exchanging views on customs affairs and cooperation between their two countries.

Czech Customs Chief Miroslav Karnik arrived in Taipei on Wednesday for a six-day visit. He met with his ROC equivalent, Jan De-ho, at the Directorate General of Customs in downtown Taipei on Thursday.
During the meeting, the two talked about matters related to customs operations, including the clearing of cargo, people and mail, and the computerization of customs procedures.

The Czech visitor expressed an interest in Taiwan's customs system and its modernization, while Jan urged the forging of a mutually-beneficial accord between the ROC and the Czech Republic on the temporary admission of professional equipment, commercial samples and advertising material.
The two supervisors are scheduled to sign a letter of intent on Taipei-Prague customs cooperation next Monday to generate the two nation's links in that sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUSHES FOR RECOGNITION OF MAINLAND DEGREES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) of the Republic of China is aggressively pushing for recognition of academic degrees conferred by academic institutions in mainland China, paving the way for Taiwan students to legally seek higher education in mainland China.
The initiative is scheduled to take effect at the end of June after being approved by the Executive Yuan, MOE officials said.

With the approval of the mutual-recognition initiative, local high school students interested in studying in mainland China should feel more confident, as academic degrees from 73 colleges and universities on the other side of the Taiwan Strait will be recognized by Taiwan authorities from this year onwards, according to the MOE.

Most of these mainland degrees will require only a screening of the relevant document by the MOE. Graduates of mainland Chinese institutes' programs in medicine, dentistry and traditional Chinese medicine, however, will be required to pass another scholastic test in addition to the MOE screening, ministry officials said.
Degrees held by mainland Chinese people who have settled in Taiwan will also be recognized by Taiwan authorities after the holders pass a scholastic test plus an MOE screening, the officials noted.

As for degrees obtained by Taiwan residents in mainland China between Sept. 17, 1992 -- when the ROC government promulgated the Regulations Governing Relations Between the People of Taiwan and Mainland China -- and Oct. 22, 1997, the officials said, equivalent certificates from the MOE will be issued after the degree holders pass a scholastic test prepared by the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT CONCLUDES SMOOTH VISIT TO JORDAN
DOC.DATELINE: Amman, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By C. S. Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Lien Chan said on Wednesday that he had met with all the very important persons (VIPs) he intended to meet during his stay in the Jordanian capital of Amman.
Lien made the statement when he arrived at a Jordanian industrial park, located some 40 kilometers southeast of Amman, at around 11 a.m.

Lien would not elaborate on his meetings with Jordanian VIPs. Sources said Lien might have made a stopover at an undisclosed destination on his way to the industrial park to meet with Jordanian officials.
The sources further said King Hussein Bil Talal and Prime Minister Dr. Abdul Salem Majali are among the Jordanian VIPs Lien wanted to meet.
During his tour of the industrial park, Lien visited a Taiwan-owned textile company in the park.
On Wednesday afternoon, Lien left Amman for the ancient city of Petra in southern Jordan for a sightseeing journey.

Petra, an ancient city carved in the stone, was once the stronghold of an Arab tribes, known as the Nabataeans. It is now a tourist attraction noted for its massive architecture and the ingenuity of its pools, dams and water channels.
Lien toured the Dead Sea and Mt. Madaba, where prophet Moses reportedly disappeared, and several other historic relics in the region.
Lien and his entoruage are scheduled to return to Amman on Thursday and will leave Jordan for an undisclosed destination Friday morning.

Accompanied by his wife and several ROC officials, Lien arrived in Amman on Monday for a private visit. He received an honorary doctoral degree in social sciences from the University of Jordan on Tuesday. On that evening, Jordanian Crown Prince Al Hassan Bin Talal hosted a dinner in honor of Lien and his entoruage.

This is Lien's first visit to Jordan. Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, Jordan has been friendly toward the ROC. ROC President Lee teng-hui made a private visit to Jordan in 1995.

Previous press reports had said Lien would travel to Lebanon and Bahrain after concluding his visit to Jordan. But the latest reports from Beirut said Lien has canceled his planned trip to Lebanon because of strong pressure from mainland China.

Lien was also reportedly scheduled to make a stopover in the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur on his way home to discuss with senior Malaysian officials feasible cooperative measures to address the current Asian financial turmoil. However, Beijing's sabotage has now caused Lien's itinerary following his Jordan visit to become uncertain.

Beijing has been waging an extensive campaign against Taipei's diplomatic activities in an attempt to isolate the ROC in the international community. Against his backdrop, senior ROC officials often have to keep their overseas travel plans secret.

Despite Beijing's pressure, Lien still had managed to visit several major countries which do not maintain formal diploamtic ties with the ROC in the past few years, including the Czech Republic, Austria, Ukraine, Iceland and Ireland. The current Middle East visit is Lien second trip abroad so far this year. He visited Singapore in January.

On his Middle East visit, Lien is being accompanied by his wife and several senior government officials and close aides, including Minister Without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Su Chi. Lien is scheduled to return to Taipei on March 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS TOLD TO BE PREPARED FOR HAZE

TEXT.P: Singaporeans should be prepared for severe haze, as forest fires in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, have reached a serious level, Singapore Environment Minister Yeo Cheow Tong said on Wednesday at the end of an ASEAN Environment Ministers' Meeting on the Haze held in Kuching, Indonesia.

Malaysia and Indonesia have been urged by ASEAN to activate a bilateral plan that could see Malaysian firefighters and equipment being sent to Indonesia, The Straits Times reported on Thursday in a dispatch from Kuching.
ASEAN also welcomed immediate international help in fire-fighting efforts, the report said.
Yeo said that Singapore will offer equipment if necessary.

Although the current situation in East Kalimantan is still not as bad as last year, Indonesian Environment Minister Sarwono Kusumaatmadja said that only extensive rains can put the fires out completely, as help will only mitigate the situation, the report said.
He said that cloud seeding was starting in East Kalimantan on Thursday to help bring rain to the region, which has seen only scant rainfall in recent months.
"We have had some success in ground and airborne operations, but the fires in the damaged forests are hard to control," Sarwono was quoted as saying.
On the situation in Sarawak, Malaysia's Science, Technology and Environment Minister Law Hieng Ding said that the fires there were already under control, the report said.
About 200 firefighters, together with water-bombing aircraft and helicopter surveillance, were being used, he said.

Turning to what still needs to be done, Yeo said that aside from containing the present fires and fighting them at source, enforcement against illegal burning must be stepped up to ensure that no new man-made fires are created, the report said.

At the same time, Malaysia and Indonesia can press on with bilateral efforts to fight the fires and identify what additional resources are needed, from the region as well as internationally, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY SAID MUST WAIT FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Beijing won't oppose Taipei's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) as long as it doesn't gain membership first, according to reports from the Geneva-based world trade body on Thursday.

"Beijing is firmly opposed to Taipei's entry into the WTO ahead of them," the WTO report said. WTO members had previously agreed that Taiwan can accede only after Beijing puts together its own successful bid. "The Beijing question should be settled first," the WTO report said.

Taiwan's bid to enter the WTO got a boost last Friday after the US agreed to support Taiwan's application. Washington's decision followed market-opening concessions on the part of Taiwan that will lead to more imports of US products.

Entry to the WTO -- and the international recognition membership would bestow -- is a coveted prize for Taiwan. Mainland China has tried to isolate the island by refusing to recognize countries that maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUND CAMPAIGNS TO SAVE ENDANGERED TIGERS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A campaign to save endangered tigers in northeastern mainland China was launched here on Thursday by a Taiwan-based foundation.

The Hope Fund, founded by former Olympic silver medalist Chi Cheng, said at a press conference that there are only about 5,000 wild tigers left in the world, while the population of mainland China's indigenous northeastern Chinese tiger has been reduced to only about 300 and is listed as an endangered animal by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES).

The northeastern Chinese tiger, the biggest of all tigers, weighs on average between about 180 kg to 300 kg, although some can grow to more than 400 kg. An adult tiger consumes 6 kg to 12 kg of food per day.
In order to conserve the northeastern Chinese tiger, which is high on Beijing's list of protected animals, the fund launched a campaign in Taiwan to "adopt" tiger cubs at NT$1,200 apiece.
The money will go to the tiger conservation center in mainland China's "tiger city," Hailin, in Heilongjiang Province, in the mainland's northeast.
In order to allow the tigers to keep their ability to hunt and eventually live on their own in the wild, the conservation center feeds the tigers with beef and chickens only once a week.
It costs the center about NT$120,000 (US$3,750) per year to take care of one northeastern Chinese tiger, according to the foundation.

"Conservation of the tiger will allow our descendants to one day see these magnificent creatures in their wild habitat, rather than only in books or on the screen," said the foundation's press release.
The foundation also maintains a website on the Internet. Point your browser at www.hopenet.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROVINCIAL ASSEMBLY AGAIN DELAYS DECISION ON BAYER LAND LEASE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly on Thursday decided to once again delay their decision on a land lease contract which would allow German chemical giant Bayer to build a plant in central Taiwan's Taichung County.
Assembly speaker Liu Ping-wei announced at 6:40 p.m. that discussion of the land lease contract will be delayed until March 6, following hours of heated confrontation on the floor of the assembly.

During the meeting, nearly 1,000 protesters gathered outside the assembly, waving banners and making speeches to voice their strong opposition to the proposed toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) plant near Taichung Harbor.

A 1,500-strong police force was deployed outside the assembly building to maintain order, but as the pro-Bayer investment group didn't mobilize their supporters on this occasion, the protest was described as peaceful. Serious clashes between anti-Bayer protesters and police units have broken out during previous meetings relating to the project.

The assembly meeting began at 10:55 a.m., nearly 90 minutes later than scheduled, as assemblymen from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) first discussed their strategies behind closed doors. The meeting was presided over by Deputy Speaker Yang Wen-hsin.

A bitter war of words erupted soon after DPP Assemblyman Yu Cheng-dao accused his colleague Lin Chin-chun of the KMT of having dinner with officials from land development companies during the Chinese New Year holidays to discuss the possible allocation of construction work for the project after Bayer's proposal cleared the provincial assembly. Although he described Yu's accusation as an insult, Lin stressed that if there is evidence to substantiate the accusation, he would be willing to quit the post.

Because of the bitter outburst, Yang had to adjourn the meeting, which was reconvened at 3:35 p.m. The chaotic situation deteriorated even further in the afternoon session, this time presided over by Assembly Speaker Liu Ping-wei.

Accusations of bribes paid by Bayer, allegedly NT$5 million for one vote in exchange for support of the land lease contract, were once again mentioned on the assembly floor. Serious clashes erupted between KMT Assemblyman Chou Hsi-wei and his party colleague Yen Ching-Piao when Chou pounded the table and demanded the discussion should not be suspended, which prompted Yen to dash over to where Chou was standing, with the apparent intention of attacking him.

It is the second time in less than two weeks that the Taiwan Provincial Assembly has decided to delay the decision on whether or not to grant the land lease to the international chemical giant for its proposed NT$50 billion project. As Bayer has set a February deadline for a decision on the investment project that it began two years ago, the delay is being seen as a heavy blow to the prospects of the project going ahead. The government is anxious to secure the deal as a showcase for the plan to establish the island as a regional operational hub.

A spokesman for Bayer Taiwan said on Thursday night that the result of the assembly meeting has been reported to company headquarters in Germany. Whether or not Bayer is willing to extend its deadline until March 6 has yet to be decided by the headquarters, he added.

Chen Chia-chung said that the company headquarters will convene a meeting to make a decision on its first investment project in Taiwan. The response of the Bayer's headquarters to the assembly's decision can be expected on Friday at the soonest, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNOR SOONG POLLED AS BEST CANDIDATE FOR PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey show that Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong is the most popular candidate for Taiwan's next presidency.

The telephone survey carried out by the Taipei-based CommonWealth Magazine in its March edition points out that Soong has an average 47.9 percent support from residents islandwide, far ahead of Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian's 22 percent, Vice President Lien Chan's 5.5 percent and Premier Vincent Siew's 3.6 percent.

The survey results, which sampled 1,144 residents in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan on Feb.7-8, indicate that Soong enjoys widespread backing among the people of Taiwan, regardless of which region or ethnic group they belong to.

Although Chen has long sought to build his image in northern Taiwan, the survey found that he enjoys only 18.3 percent support in the region, while Soong wins nearly 50 percent from each of the four regions.
The survey also discovered that the people of Taiwan are more concerned with public security, household and educational issues than with political and foreign policy matters.

The household category is listed for the first time as one of the public's top three issues of major concern, a reflection that the island's residents are increasingly worried about their personal safety and family lives amid deteriorating public order, the devaluation of the New Taiwan dollar resulting from the recent financial crisis plaguing the Asian region, and the widening gap between rich and poor.
About 50 percent of the respondents think it is safe to live in Taiwan, while 27 percent have the opposite opinion, according to the poll.

Meanwhile, nearly 70 percent of the people said they think the gap between rich and poor will continue to increase, and they are afraid their incomes will be swallowed up by the get-rich-quick schemes which are now so popular on the island.

Of the four members of the greater Chinese economic sphere -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, and mainland China -- 65 percent of the people of Taiwan have the impression that Singapore is the best of the four, ahead of 22 percent which chose Taiwan. Some 7 percent and 2 percent said they have the impression that Hong Kong and mainland China, respectively, are the best of the four areas.

Citing analyses made by academics, the monthly magazine said the worsening social order, money politics, dirty environment, and the lack of moral values are the prime reasons behind the local peoples' admiration for Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CBC GOVERNOR VOWS TO KEEP PRICES AND EXCHANGE RATES STABLE

TEXT.P: Vowing to maintain the stability of both prices and local currency, the new Governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC), Peng Huai-nan, was sworn in on Thursday, filling the vacancy left by the tragic death on Feb. 16 of former Governor Sheu Yuan-dong in Taiwan's worst-ever air crash.
However, the governor excluded energy and vegetable prices from the "Core Inflation Index" which he pledged to defend.

At the swearing-in ceremony, Peng noted the time lapse between the implementation of monetary policies and the time when their effects are felt, and pledged to monitor leading indicators such as the import prices and labor unit and capacity factor costs, which are closely related to prices, and to adjust monetary policies accordingly.
With regard to maintaining currency stability, Peng said this does not mean fixing the exchange rate of the New Taiwan dollar, but rather keeping it within reasonable bounds.
In order to shield the currency from short-haul fluctuations caused by speculation, Peng said the CBC will provide the financial markets with accurate information in a timely manner.
Emphasizing his respect for market forces, the new CBC governor said that the bank will intervene in the financial market only in case of seasonal or occasional imbalances between demand and supply.
He also promised to cooperate with the Ministry of Financial Affairs to tighten up financial discipline and improve the health of the nation's banking system.
Peng said the CBC would also like to stimulate the development of the economy but only to the extent compatible with the aforementioned goals.
He said that the bank will bring more outside scholars and experts onto its boards of directors and supervisors to promote the transparency of its policymaking process.
Peng, chairman of the International Commercial Bank of China and a former CBC deputy governor, is renowned for his hardline attitude against speculative international money dealers.
Meanwhile, responding to Peng's appointment, the NT dollar surged against the greenback on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENDS LATEST ROUND OF WTO TALKS WITH EU

TEXT.P: The latest round of talks between Taiwan and the European Union (EU) on the island's terms for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) ended here on Thursday evening with a partial consensus having been reached.
After three days of negotiations, delegates of the two sides have forged agreements on the opening of Taiwan's service sector, and a timetable for cutting tariffs and commodity taxes.

The two sides will officially ink the minute book to confirm the points they have agreed upon, according to Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade and Taiwan's chief negotiator.
Chen said that a formal accord is expected to be signed after all 15 EU member countries give their individual endorsements of the result of the Taipei talks.
Further rounds of talks will be necessary if any of the EU members disagree on the content of the agreements.
The delegates at the Taipei talks, however, failed to resolve their differences on the "monopoly benefit" (charges) on European alcohol and custom tariffs on cars.

Taiwan has completed talks with 24 of the 26 WTO contracting parties which expressed concern over Taiwan's trade regime. Besides the European Union, the only nation that Taiwan has yet to conclude WTO talks is Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PYONGYANG THREATENS TO SUE TAIPOWER IF NUCLEAR DEAL STALLS

TEXT.P: North Korea has threatened to file a complaint with the International Court if Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) fails to fulfill the contract it signed with Pyongyang in January 1997.

Pyongyang has on several occasions expressed its concern to Taipower's Nuclear Backend Management Department over the implementation of the contract, under which Taipower will ship 60,000 barrels of low-grade radioactive waste to North Korea over a two-year period for permanent storage.

As no action has been taken by Taipower during the past year, Pyongyang is becoming increasingly concerned over the stalled deal, and has threatened to sue Taipower for nonfulfillment of the contract.
Taipower authorities, however, argue that the company has been carrying out its end of the agreement step by step over the past year.

The contract is still valid even though not a single barrel of the company's nuclear waste has been sent northward to date, Taipower officials said, adding that the approval process for an export license has been delayed by the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC).
The Ministry of Economic Affairs has recently asked the AEC, the supervisory body for nuclear-related affairs, to speed up the handling of relevant matters for which it is responsible.
According to the Taipower-Pyongyang agreement, Taipower will begin to ship the waste once Taipower obtains an export license and the Pyongyang company receives an import permit.
Pyongyang first contacted Taipower in 1996, offering a parcel of land near a North Korean seaport to Taipower for use as a nuke waste receptacle.

The North Korean offer was viewed favorably by Taipower for the reasonable price, not-too-distant location and the convenience of not needing to pass through a third country for the shipment, Taipower officials noted.
The Taipower-Pyongyang deal, however, has sparked a storm of protest from South Korea, whose objections might account for the AEC's slowdown of the permit screening process.
Meanwhile, Taipower's plans to store low-radioactive toxins in Russia, mainland China and the Marshall Islands have also hit snags because of a wide variety of problems.
Against that backdrop, Taipower has refocussed its search on domestic locations.

The company on Thursday presented its latest proposal to the AEC, identifying sites it considers suitable for receptacles. Six initial locations were selected in order of preference: Hsiaowuchiu in Kinmen County; Hsiaolanyu, an offshore islet near Taitung in eastern Taiwan, Nantien Village in Taitung County; Tungchiyu in Penghu; Pengchiayu, off Keelung in northern Taiwan; and Hsuhai Village in coastal Pingtung County.
Hsiaowuchiu, the first choice on Taipower's list, will be awarded NT$2.1 billion (US$64.6 million) as compensation if the nuclear waste dumping plan is implemented, according to Taipower officials.
Another NT$900 million (US$27.6 million) will be presented to the Kinmen County government, the administrative authority for Hsiaowuchiu, as a goodwill gesture.

Taipower's proposal, however, will remain on the drawing board for the time being, according to AEC officials. No concrete moves will be taken before public safety investigations and environmental assessments have been conducted, they added.

Meanwhile, indignant over Taipower's designation of Hsiaowuchiu as its choice site for the nuclear storage plan, Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ching-pao, a representative from Kinmen, staged another protest Friday at the Legislative Yuan, his third in the past week.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKERS URGE THAILAND TO OPEN DOOR TO TAIWAN BANKS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan banking executives have urged Thailand to open its doors to private Taiwan banks, a move they say could help the country rid itself of the onslaught by the recent financial storm.

Representatives from Taipei-based banks, including the International Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), Chinatrust Commercial Bank and First Commercial Bank (FCB), sounded the call during a conference sponsored by a Thai-language economic newspaper in Bangkok on Thursday.

The banking executives said Thailand's opening for the establishment of branch units by foreign banks would contribute to more efficient financial and monetary services in the country. They indicated that Taiwan's expertise and up-to-date technologies in financial management could help rescue local businesses as well as Taiwan companies operating in Thailand from difficulties caused by the regionwide economic volatility.

An ICBC manager stationed here further suggested that the Thai financial sector should set up a joint credit information center to provide a complete paper credit database for reference by all Thai and foreign banking institutions which are willing to provide loans for companies in need of financial aid.
The information center could also reduce the risk of bounced checks, which is seen as one of the major culprits in the financial turmoil afflicting the Southeast Asian nation, he said.

A Chinatrust representative said a more liberalized financial sector is the only road to take Thailand out of its recession. He also pointed out that there are more private and foreign banks in Taiwan than in Thailand, which allows for a greater diversity of services and more benefitial competition.
The banking executive cited Taiwan's sound financial structure as being the main factor behind the island's success in emerging relatively unscathed from the regional financial attack.

In Taiwan, there are currently nine state-run banks and 37 private banks, while a total of 45 foreign banks have opened representative and branch offices on the island, according to the Chinatrust executive.

At present, five state-run banks, 15 private institutions and 21 foreign concerns operate in Thailand, which continues to ban foreign banks from opening more than one branch office in the country, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR KILLED IN KAOHSIUNG GAS EXPLOSION
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An explosion touched off by a liquefied natural gas (LNG) spill in Kaohsiung killed four people and injured 40 others on Friday morning.

A driver had just filled his tanker truck with LNG when he attempted to drive away before disconnecting the supply lines, triggering a blast at around 8:40 a.m. that caused the worst public nuisance in Taiwan so far this year.

The blast at the Linyuan petrochemical industrial complex caused a blaze that engulfed the LNG supply reservoir and sent a fireball 10 stories into the air, with debris flying 150 meters from the truck.
The explosion was so powerful that it devoured a nearby auto repair garage, resulting in four fatalities and leaving 40 others injured.
The unidentified tanker driver, however, escaped unharmed.

The blaze wasn't put out until noon. Dozens of firefighters continued working at the scene, building a water wall around the area to prevent four other LNG reservoirs in the immediate area from exploding.

DOC.HEADLINE: US LAUDS ROC'S ANTI-DRUG DRIVE, BUT STILL LISTS IT AS TRANSIT POINT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration has lauded the Republic of China on Taiwan for an aggressive anti-drug campaign in its 1998 international narcotics control report, but it still lists Taiwan as a transit point for contraband drugs.

Taiwan, like Hong Kong and mainland China, ranks among the 22 major illicit drug producing and/or transit countries/dependent territories that "have cooperated fully with the United States, or have taken adequate steps on their own, to achieve full compliance with the goals and objectives of the 1988 United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances," according to the report released by the White House on Friday.
Meanwhile, the US Department of State also issued a statement explaining why it has continued to identify Taiwan as a significant transit point for drug trafficking.
The statement said, "Given trafficking patterns in the region and Taiwan's role as a shipping center, the US believes Taiwan remains a transit point for drugs significantly affecting it."
While Taiwan authorities dispute this assessment, the statement argued, there is no disagreement that individuals from Taiwan continue to be involved in international narcotics trafficking.
The statement pointed out that some 67 percent of all drugs smuggled into Taiwan are believed to come from mainland China.

It went on to say that, whatever their belief about Taiwan's transit role, Taiwan authorities continue to mount an aggressive counternarcotics campaign that involves both social rehabilitation programs and harsh sentences for narco-trafficking.

"Although Taiwan is not a UN member and cannot be a signatory to the 1988 UN Drug Convention, it tries to meet Convention goals regarding precursor chemicals via an active program to control the products of its large chemical industry," the statement noted.

In addition, the statement said, Taiwan has come to recognize that money laundering is a growing problem. "In 1997, a Money Laundering Prevention Center was established under the auspices of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB)."

The statement further said cooperation between American and Taiwan law enforcement agencies continued to expand in 1997. Officials with the US Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and Financial Crimes Enforcement Network have led training seminars for their Taiwan counterparts and have broadened their range of contacts within Taiwan's law enforcement community.

It recognized that Taiwan has generally responded positively and constructively to US requests on counternarcotics issues. With the opening of its Money Laundering Prevention Center, it said, Taiwan has started sharing with American law enforcement officials Taiwan-originated information related to money laundering cases where the flow of money leads to the United States. In addition, Taiwan's MJIB officers assisted DEA agents with a case involving a shipment of drugs to Guam.

The statement also said Taiwan's anti-drug crackdown led to a 19.1 percent increase in drug convictions in the first 10 months of 1997 over all of 1996. Drug seizures also increased. The Money Laundering Prevention Center pursued investigations in all 360 cases of reported suspicious transactions. In the past year, the statement said, Taiwan has also continued to prosecute cases of public corruption. "There are, however, no known cases of official involvement in narcotics trafficking," it noted.

According to the US Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, the White House is required to submit a report to Congress on major illicit drug producing and/or transit countries annually. Countries or areas which are certified as "failing to meet the standards" set forth in section 490 (b) of the 1961 Act will be deprived of any US aid. Such countries listed in the 1998 report include Afghanistan, Burma, Iran and Nigeria.

Drug producing and/or transit countries which are regarded as "having cooperated with the US in fighting illicit trafficking" are still eligible to receive US aid. The three Chinese economies -- Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China -- are all included in this category in the 1998 report.
Observers said even though Taiwan doesn't need US aid, its inclusion in any such list is a minus to Taiwan's international image.
