DOC.HEADLINE: NAVAL SHIP COLLIDES WITH FISHING BOAT OFF PENGHU

TEXT.P: An ROC naval vessel collided with a private fishing boat off the coast of Penghu County on Thursday night, but there were no reports of injuries, the Navy General Headquarters (NGH) said on Friday.

The destroyer No. 909 collided with the Taipei County-based Chuan Sheng No. 36 fishing boat in waters some 20 nautical miles north of Penghu's Hsiyu township at around 9:35 p.m. when it was on a routine patrol mission, the NHG said in a press release.

None of the crew members aboard either the warship or the fishing boat was injured, the statement said, adding that the fishing boat already arrived at a military wharf in Penghu County, located off Taiwan's southwestern coast, under the escort of a naval rescue ship early Friday morning for repair and damage assessment.
Initial investigations show that two ribs of the naval ship were damaged in the collision, while the fishing boat sustained damage to its bow, naval officials said.

The officials said bad weather and poor visibility might have contributed to the accident. Nevertheless, they admitted that further investigations are needed to find out the cause and determine which party, if any, should be held responsible for the collision.
The military and other relevant government agencies will form a joint task force to investigate the case.
Seven crew members, including five from mainland China, were aboard the fishing boat when the accident occurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, EU REACH CONSENSUS ON MOST ISSUES

TEXT.P: The European Council of Commerce and Trade said on Friday that though minor differences remain between Taiwan and the European Union (EU) on the terms for the island's accession into the World Trade Organization (WTO), both sides greatly narrowed the gap between their positions during the latest round of talks.
EU officials noted that although the two sides did not resolve all their differences in the most recent round of talks, the 12th, Taiwan and the EU spoke fully on all outstanding issues.

On Thursday, Chen Ruey-lung, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), and EU negotiator Jean-Pierre de Laet reached a consensus on the opening of Taiwan's service sector and a timetable on cutting the island's tariffs and commodity taxes.
But both sides have yet to agree on the tariffs on imported vehicles and the monopoly tax on imported whiskey.
During the three-day talks, Taiwan agreed to reduce its average tariff for industrial products to 4.7 percent by 2004.

In the service sector, foreign investors in Taiwan's banks will receive national treatment according to the related law, which is that a shareholder cannot hold more than 5 percent of a domestic bank. Foreign companies, however, will be able to set up wholly-owned commercial banks.
Both sides also agreed that the ceiling of foreign investment in air cargo forwarding services will be lifted fully from the present 50 percent on reciprocal principles.
On marine services, Taiwan agreed that foreign companies can set up subsidiaries or affiliates. They are presently limited to branches.
The EU expressed its understanding that foreign investment in the island's telecommunications sector should not exceed 20 percent after Taiwan's entry into the WTO.
Taiwan also explained that it no longer issues operation licenses for trust investment companies.

Taiwan has agreed that upon its entry into the WTO, it will review its regulations concerning foreign lawyers practicing on the island and will study partnership relations between foreign and local lawyers three years after gaining WTO membership.
Both sides, however, still disagree on the cutting of monopoly taxes on European liquors and tariff cuts on imported automobiles.
Taiwan agreed that it will cut its monopoly tax on brandy to less than NT$750 (US$23) but has yet to agree on how much its tariff on whiskey will be reduced.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.1 against the New Taiwan dollar in the local foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at the day high of NT$32.1.
The greenback opened at 32, and experience a low of 31.75.
Interbank trading reached US$514 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved down 0.3 percent on the local stock market Friday after an active surge in the previous session.
Profit-taking by institutional investors pulled the weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX), the market's key indicator, down 26.63 points to close at 9,202.56.
The bourse opened at 9,363.39, with the index fluctuating between 9,378.52 and 9,194.51.
Losers outnumbered gainers 251 to 178, with 67 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 4.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$273.1 billion (US$8.4 billion).

Construction shares posted the largest fall at 1.1 percent, followed by paper and paper stocks, which dropped 0.9 percent; electrical engineering issues, 0.6 percent; cement shares, 0.5 percent; textile stocks, 0.3 percent; and financial shares, 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff issues climbed 0.4 percent, and plastic and chemical shares rose 0.3 percent.

The 10 companies with the largest turnovers were United Micro Electronics, ACER, Mosel-Vitelic, Macronix International, Winbond Electronics, Mitac International, Holtek Microelectronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Taiwan Mask and China Petrochemical.

In related news, the latest official statistics show that bullish sentiment on the market has pushed the volume of market trading up to NT$4.87 trillion (US$149.75 billion) this month, as of Thursday.

This figure averages to NT$220.2 billion (US$6.78 billion) per day during the 22-trading day period, the highest level since Taiwan opened stock trading, according to the statistics from the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
An MOF official pointed out that with the 0.03 percent tax on stock transactions, the government is expected to earn around NT$14.6 billion (US$449.23 million) from this month's vigorous trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA USES LOTTERY SYSTEM FOR TICKETS TO 2000 OLYMPICS

TEXT.P: Australia launched a lottery-style campaign Friday to sell more than eight million tickets to Australian households so that all citizens will have an equal chance to see the events of their choice.

The campaign's organizers said the scheme is being unveiled through a blanket newspaper advertising campaign. Each household will also receive a packet informing them of the dates, times and likely demand for each event.
Households will be asked to list their choices in order of preference, and requests for events that are over-subscribed will go into a national ballot.
Events expected to fall into this category include swimming and athletics finals and the opening and closing ceremonies.

Organizers said the eight million tickets account for 70 percent of the total tickets to be made available. The remaining 30 percent will be distributed worldwide through various channels, including media, sponsors, Olympic committee members and associates.
The organizing committee of the Olympic Games in Sydney will issue a total of about 11 million tickets.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS BEGIN TO THAW (1)

TEXT.P: A positive response from Beijing on Tuesday to an appeal from Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew is being seen as a signal that frosty relations across the Taiwan Strait have begun to thaw.

During his administrative report to the opening session of the Legislature last week, Siew called for "collaborative cultivation" of bilateral relations between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland. On Tuesday, Taipei received what it termed a "positive" proposal from Beijing, suggesting that preparations begin for political dialogue and the restoration of negotiations on cross-strait technical issues. Thus a warming of cross-strait relations, which have been frozen in place for more than 30 months, appears near.

More than 40 years of hostility between Taipei and Peking gave way to an era of exchange and communication after the ROC government in November 1987 began to allow people residing in the Taiwan area to visit relatives on the Chinese mainland. This decision moved cross-strait relations out of a state of complete estrangement and opened the door for private-level exchanges.

During the past 11 years, a rapid growth in economic, cultural and social exchanges has been witnessed between the two sides. However, due to differences in living conditions and social values between Taiwan and the mainland, as well as the vastly disparate political systems existing on the two sides, mutual relations have hobbled forward along a rocky road.

If the interaction among high-level leaders can serve as a criterion for evaluating the state of two-way exchanges, it may well be said that cross-strait amity reached a peak in the spring of 1995. It was on the eve of the lunar new year in January 1995, that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin presented an "eight-point proposal," while ROC President Lee Teng-hui responded by announcing his "six-point statement" on April 8, 1995.

However, on June 16, 1995, Beijing suspended a second meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), after Lee made a private but high-profile visit to the United States. Thus cross-strait relations returned to the freezing point.
As it now appears that an improved atmosphere is once again emerging, a better understanding of the reasoning on both sides can be gained by examining the highlights of the cross-strait dialogue.

On June 10, 1995, President Lee delivered a speech at Cornell University, calling on Beijing to abandon confrontation and commit itself to peaceful competition. The spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, responded on June 16 by indefinitely postponing the second scheduled "Koo-Wang meeting," the first having taken place in Singapore in April 1993.

Between July 21, 1995, and late November of that year, Beijing conducted four separate series of military exercises, extending from the East China Sea and Qingdao, Shandong Province, in the north, to the shores of Fujian Province in the south.

President Lee declared on July 22, 1995, that the Republic of China must be afforded its due status in the international community, and called on the Beijing authorities to renounce ideological confrontation in favor of a new era of peaceful competition among all Chinese around the world.
Nevertheless, Lee's speech at Cornell was harshly criticized by mainland commentators in four articles published by the Xinhua News Agency and the People's Daily between July 23-26.

On Sept. 1, 1995, Lee told The New York Times that as soon as the situation on the Chinese mainland stabilized, and after the conclusion of presidential elections on Taiwan, the two sides could consider rescheduling a high-level meeting.

Jiang responded to Lee's remarks during an interview with the US media during which he welcomed the ROC president to visit Beijing. Asked whether he would visit Taipei if invited, Jiang added, "I would like to." (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS BEGIN TO THAW (2)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Chang Lung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: On Feb. 11, 1996, Lee remarked at his presidential campaign headquarters in Taipei, that terminating enmity and establishing peace across the Taiwan Strait would be the top priority of the next president.
Lee told the press at his Chinese New Year news conference shortly thereafter that the first step toward alleviating tensions between the two sides would be the signing of a peace accord.

During the period before the March 23 presidential election, however, the mainland news media poured out a massive number of articles extremely hostile to Lee. In addition, Beijing held missile exercises off the northeast and southwest coasts of Taiwan March 8-25, pushing cross-strait relations to a nadir.

After the vote, in all his meetings with foreign visitors and members of the international media, President-elect Lee reasserted that the door for cross-strait negotiations is always open, adding that while Taipei insists that there is only one China, the government views this as post-unification China and not the People's Republic of China. China has been divided and is under separate rule, he consistently pointed out.

Lee noted in his inaugural address on May 20, 1996 that Taipei and Beijing should work seriously to end cross-strait hostility. He went a step further by saying that he would like to make a "journey of peace" to the Chinese mainland. The spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council responded by citing Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's "Eight-point Proposal" that the two sides could negotiate and reach an agreement on the termination of cross-strait enmity under the premise of One-China.

Jiang also responded on June 26, 1996, during a visit to Spain, that he would welcome reciprocal visits by the leaders of both sides of the Taiwan Strait. He reiterated this stance when he met with Le Figaro, a French daily, in September 1996.

In a report to the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China on Sept. 12, 1997, Jiang urged the Taipei authorities to "formally end hostilities under the principle of one-China" and to reach an agreement with Beijing. Under the premise of one-China, he said, everything can be discussed.

At an administrative meeting of the Executive Yuan on Oct. 2, 1997, ROC Premier Vincent Siew welcomed the mainland's stance and asked the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the nation's top agency in charge of mainland policy, to map out the resumption of talks between the SEF and ARATS, the semi-official organizations on either side of the Taiwan Strait that were set up to deal with cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.

On Nov. 6, 1997, ARATS invited Chiao Jen-ho, then the vice chairman and secretary-general of the SEF, to attend a seminar on cross-strait economic relations scheduled to be held in December in Xiamen, mainland China. The SEF responded with a suggestion that SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu lead the delegation instead. ARATS replied on Nov. 11 with a counter-proposal for a meeting between Chiao and ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei.
On Jan. 19, 1998, the SEF faxed a letter to ARATS for the second time about Koo's visit; ARATS answered that its letter dated Nov. 11, still held good, meaning that ARATS had not changed its stance.
Siew remarked in his administrative report to the legislature on Feb. 20 that the ROC government is "willing to eliminate enmity through dialogue and replace confrontation with negotiation."

"I think if we start from the second Koo-Wang talks, any agenda that will help peaceful development across the strait and the country's democratic unification can be proposed gradually in order to start up communication and dialogue," he said.

In the wake of Siew's strategic speech, ARATS faxed a letter on Tuesday saying: "We welcome Mr. Koo Chen-fu to visit at an appropriate time. Officials of an appropriate level can make the necessary preparations for that through an exchange of visits."

DOC.HEADLINE: A DOMESTIC AIRPORT TO BE BUILT AT HUWEI, YUNLIN COUNTY

TEXT.P: A domestic airport will be built at Huwei, Yunlin County in central Taiwan to provide 10 flight services to and fro Taipei each day during the first stage of development of the airport.

A professor of the aviation department of National Cheng Kung University, which was commissioned by the Yunlin County Government to map out the plan for the airport, said Friday that it will be located in the middle of the county, where weather conditions are good and transportation to nearby cities is convenient.

The airport will occupy 40 hectares of land, which will probably be purchased from the Taiwan Sugar Company. Flight services to and fro Kaohsiung, Hualien, Taitung, Kinmen, Matsu, and other cities will be added step by step in the future, an official of the county government said.

The Yunlin County Government and certain domestic airlines are planning to apply for central government subsidies for the construction of the airport, which carries a price tag of NT$900 million (US$28.1 million), the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ISN'T RULING OUT RUNNING A WOMAN IN TAIPEI MAYORAL RACE

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang is not ruling out the possibility of nominating a woman to run for Taipei mayor, KMT Secretary-General John Chang said on Friday.
Chang said that high-ranking KMT officials have exchanged views on fielding a woman in the race and have taken several possible candidates into consideration.
Chang, however, also said the KMT has yet to decide on a nominee and that the list of potential candidates isn't confined to women.

Incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian announced earlier in the week that he will seek a second term. Observers here believe he has a good chance of winning, given his high ratings in opinion polls, and that an electoral victory would pave the way for him to enter the next presidential race.
Chang has often been asked how the KMT could field a candidate formidable enough to overcome Chen's popularity.
"The KMT will not rule out any woman who has an outstanding performance record and a very strong chance of winning the race," he said Friday.
On which women the KMT is considering, Chang said that he will only discuss the candidate when the time is ripe.
He stressed the KMT will carefully screen all possible candidates and select the best person.

Observers believe candidates under consideration include KMT Vice Secretary-General Yeh Chin-feng, Taipei City Councilman Chin Huei-chu and Lee Chi-chu, chairman of the National Youth Commission under the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOTLINES ESTABLISHED TO HELP WOMEN ABUSED BY HUMAN SMUGGLERS

TEXT.P: A Taipei-based anti-child prostitution association on Friday announced special telephone lines to help women forced into prostitution by human smuggling rings.

The association said human smuggling rings in Taiwan, mainland China, Japan and Southeast Asian countries have joined forces to engage in cross-border sex trade operations. "They have grown into a terribly strong force in human smuggling and sex trade operations in the region," it noted.
The association called on local people and social groups to pool their resources to help the victims escape and return to their home countries to rebuild their lives.
The association also unveiled for the first time the three major routes used by regional criminal rings for the smuggling of women into sexual servitude.

It said the rings would first smuggle women from Burma and Laos into Thailand, where they would be forced to work as prostitutes; three to six months later, the same women would be sent on to either Singapore, Taiwan or Japan to continue their sexual services.
The rings also smuggle women from mainland China into Thailand via Burma and Laos; some of these women would then be sent to Taiwan, either directly from Thailand or via Hong Kong.
In some cases, Southeast Asian women are lured to Malaysia first, before being sent on to either Singapore or the Philippines; some of them also eventually end up in Taiwan.

The association said the rings usually place advertisements in newspapers pretending to recruit women to work as waitresses, family helpers, dancers or singers. Such ads usually stress that the work is easy, does not need experience, and offers lucrative rewards.

Sometimes, the association said, human smuggling rings disguise themselves as matchmaking agencies to trick women into marrying abroad. The victims soon come to understand that the men they are supposed to marry are drivers or bodyguards hired by brothels and other sex joints.
The association pointed out that some travel agencies and document forgery rings have colluded with the human smuggling rings, providing travel papers and false passports.

As immigration authorities have tightened inspection of passports and travel documents, the criminal rings now seldom send women to Taiwan by air. Instead, they smuggle the women into Taiwan via sea, using small fishing boats or even jet skis to land on the island.
The association also alleged that many taxi drivers collaborate with brothels and sex joints to control the abused women, providing transport or monitoring services.

In most cases, the association said, the women have little opportunity to escape because they have often been conned into signing huge debt receipts and their passports are often confiscated by the criminal rings. In addition, the rings often use drugs and bodyguards to control their charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLIND MAN BECOMES NATIONAL EXAM'S TOP SCORER

TEXT.P: The first blind person ever allowed to take the National Professionals and Technologists Examination has become this year's top scorer.
Lan Chieh-chou, 25, outperformed more than 3,000 other contestants in this year's exam, earning a score of 65.23, well above the 50 points required to pass and become a certified sociologist.
Lan's examination rivals even included a number of university professors of sociology who wished to obtain a national license to be a sociologist.
John Kuan, vice president of the Examination Yuan, visited Lan Friday upon the announcement of the national examination results to offer his congratulations.
Although overjoyed by the triumph, Lan, a native of Tainan, said words cannot describe his sad and difficult ordeal over the last 25 years.
His fate took a turn for the worse, however, when he was 16 and hit by retinopathy, which made him totally blind.
Lan was sent to a school for the blind in Taichung, some 120 kilometers from his hometown.
He was brave and persistent at his new school and managed to pass the national college entrance examination. He entered National Chunghsing University (NCU) at the age of 19.

After graduating from NCU, Lan passed the national examination for the handicapped and became a government employee at the Supervisory Board for the Civil Servant Pension Fund, an agency under the Ministry of Examination, where he was noticed by Lin Chi-yuan, chairman of the Civil Service Protection and Training Commission.

Prompted by Lan's hard work and diligence, Lin pushed for blind people to be allowed sit in the national examination for professionals and technologists. Lin's efforts succeeded, and this year Lan was allowed to join the test takers.
In addition to being an outstanding sociology expert, Lan is an Internet devotee. He's enthusiastic about the World Wide Web and even met his girlfriend there.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO CHIEF SPEAKS POSITIVELY ON TAIWAN'S MEMBERSHIP BID
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The director-general of the World Trade Organization (WTO) said here on Thursday that Taiwan's membership bid has proceeded smoothly.
Renato Ruggiiero further said Taiwan's WTO bid has nothing to do with mainalnd China's membership application.
This was the first time that Ruggiiero has given such a clear-cut positive review of Taiwan's WTO bid.

Ruggiiero's latest remarks were seen yet another positive development in Taiwan's WTO bid following the conclusion of its lengthy, difficult bilateral talks with the United States on terms for its entry into the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.
Ruggiiero, a former Italian foreign minister, is currently in San Jose, California to attend a seminar on the current global trading system.

Asked whether mainland China would request for joining the WTO ahead of Taiwan, Ruggiiero didn't make an explicit, direct reply. He instead said Taiwan's WTO-related negotiations have been proceeding smoothly and that its prospects of entering the organization are rosy.

The top manager of WTO's day-to-day affairs further siad he is convinced that Taiwan will be able to resolve all WTO-related problems within a reasonable period of time. By then, Ruggiiero said, any other factor or pressure will disappear.

Ruggiiero said the conclusion of negotiations with the United States is a very important development in Taiwan's WTO bid. Nevertheless, he said, Taiwan still has to finalize talks with other WTO contracting parties. He declined to predict when Taiwan will be formally admitted to the WTO.
Teng Chen-chung, a division chief in charge of economic affairs at Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C., has expressed welcome to Ruggiiero's remarks on progress in Taiwan's WTO bid.

Teng said the US has upheld its principle in separating Taiwan's WTO application from mainland China's. "We hope the WTO will follow suit and consider our membership bid purely from economic viewpoints," he urged, adding that he hopes Taiwan's WTO bid will not be hindered by any political interferences.

Taiwan applied to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1990 as an independent customs territory, while mainland China filed a similar application in 1986. The GATT was superceded by the WTO in January 1995.

Taiwan has completed bilateral WTO talks with 24 of the 26 contracting parties which have expressed intentions for such consultations. It is scheudled to finalize simialr talks with the 15-member European Union and Switzerland before the end of March to speed up its WTO accession.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY FLASHED 'YELLOW-BLUE' IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy flashed a "yellow-blue" light in a governmental rating system in January, the first time in 14 months that the signal has moved downward out of the "green" range of steady growth, according to the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Declaring that January's indicator is not a warning of an economic recession, a CEPD senior official attributed the lower level signal mainly to the fact that there were fewer workdays that month than usual due to the Chinese New Year holidays.
This January had only 18 workdays, 21.7 percent fewer than the 23-day level of the same month last year.
Domestic activities were hard-hit by last month's scarcity of workdays, said Thomas M.F. Yeh, the CEPD's head of economic research.

In the CEPD-devised five-color rating system, a "yellow-blue" light signals an economic slowdown, while a "blue" light represents a recession; "red" means the economy is overheated; "yellow-red" refers to an economy that is heating up; and "green" reflects steady growth.

In applying the system, the CEPD measures nine major areas of economic activity: industrial production, manufacturing-sector inventories, non-agricultural employment, export orders, export value, the check default rate, M1B money supply, bank lending and the stock index.
The decreased number of workdays pulled down the measuring indices in industrial production, manufacturing-sector inventories, export orders and export value, according to the CEPD.
Yeh said that according to anlayses of his council, the island's economy is continuing stable development, and he urged people not to be concerned by the "seasonal" rating result.

The economic expert also revealed that the CEPD's recent survey showed 23 percent of local manufacturing businesses predict Taiwan's economy will be flourishing in three months, up from 19 percent in the previous survey, marking most domestic enterprises are optimistic about the country's economic future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DIVORCE RATE CONTINUES RISING

TEXT.P: The number of newly-wed couples in Taiwan edged down 0.22 percent in 1997, while the number of couples that got divorced increased 8.67 percent during the same period, according to the statistics made public by the Ministry of Interior.

The statistics showed that 166,217 couples married last year, for a marriage rate of 0.768 percent, down 0.22 percent from the same period of the year-earlier level. The marriage rate is calculated as the number of newly-wed couples as a percentage of the total population.

During the same period, 38,986 couples divorced, for a divorce rate of 0.18 percent, up 8.67 percent from a year ago. The divorce rate is the number of divorced couples as a percentage of the total population.
The statistics could be translated into that per 3.2 minute, one couple got married in Taiwan, while per 13.5 minute, one couple ended their unhappy marriage.
The Kaohsiung City recorded the highest divorce rate at 0.217 percent, followed by the Taipei City at 0.205 percent. The divorce rate in Taiwan Province stood at 0.174 percent.

Taiwan's divorce rate continues rising for the past 10 years. The divorce rate stood at 0.126 percent and 0.125 percent in 1988 and 1989, respectively. The ratio then rose to 0.135 percent in 1990, 0.138 percent in 1991, 0.141 percent in 1992, 0.145 percent in 1993, 0.151 percent in 1994, 0.157 percent in 1995, and 0.167 percent in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANGUAGE FIGHT IN MONTREAL CHINATOWN OVER -- FOR NOW

TEXT.P: The widely reported language fight between Quebec's "tongue troopers" and businesspeople in Montreal's Chinatown came to a halt after the former were ordered on Wednesday to back off.
Quebec has for now suspended plans to crack down on a lack of French on commercial signs in Chinatown, the minister in charge of the province's language policy said.

Louise Beaudoin said she is convinced the apprehensions expressed by business leaders in Chinatown were based on "misunderstanding and a lack of communication" and that Quebec is ready to go a lot slower in its approach to the issue.

Her language inspectors were to crack down on shop owners who do not put up signs with French "predominant" over other languages. Ethnic Chinese businesspeople complained they were being "harassed" and that changing the signs would be costly.

Beaudoin did not say the issue was closed, indicating instead that she was waiting for a report from a deputy minister who has been meeting Chinese community leaders to find a compromise. She expected the report sometime in March.

Reaction from the community has been cautiously optimistic. "It's OK for now," said Bill Wong, a restaurant owner and vice president of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. "I won't be happy about anything until everything is dropped."
He noted that "they are just suspending it," and reported that his chamber's objective is that "it will not come back again."

The controversy erupted last fall after the Commission de Protection de la Langue Francaise targeted Chinatown in response to complaints that signs there were in Chinese only or that the French letters were not twice the size of Chinese characters.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-AUSSIE LEADER SEES ASIAN CRISIS TAKING DECADES TO RESOLVE

TEXT.P: John Hewson, former leader of Australia's Liberal Party, predicted it will take one or two decades to resolve the Asian economic crisis, saying that governments in the region and their cronies will resist reforms and that the current bailouts by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will only cure short-term economic problems in the region.

In an article published in the Australian Financial Review on Friday, Hewson, who lost the prime minister's post to Paul Keating in 1993, said he was surprised to see that many countries and leaders regard the Asian problem as just a currency crisis that is relatively short-term or cyclical.

In fact, he said, the key structural weakness of many of the affected Asian economies is the close, incestuous relationship between government, business and the financial sector. This has not only economic but also substantial political and social significance, he added.
"At its worst, it is corruption, cronyism and nepotism. At best, banking is just an extension of government industry policy," Hewson said.
He said the solution to the Asian crisis is not just economic.

"The underlying power structure (in the region's countries) will have to be broken down. The corruption and cronyism will need to be eradicated. Political processes will eventually become more democratic. Social structures will have to become more equal," he said.
He cited Japan as an example. Japan's bubble burst back in 1990.

"Yet today, eight years on, we still don't even know the full extent of the debt problems, particularly of the banks, with the 'Big Bang' deregulation of the financial sector due on April 1," he said.

"Consumer and business confidence (in Japan) are shattered. The near-term danger is yet another recession. The worst elements of Japan Inc. have had to be exposed of corrupt practices, favors and cronyism," he said.
"Korea is very much a mini-Japan -- eight years later -- but with apparently bigger debt problems and less transparent business, government and banking practices," he said.
"Indonesia is several stages further behind and its political and social upheaval will be far more significant," he said.
"The IMF bailouts only buy time -- in the long term they only work if the correct and necessary reforms are put in place," he noted.

"Throughout this process, despite repeated commitments to the IMF and the international community, (Asian) governments and their cronies will resist change. They will fight to keep their privilege, their power and to protect their vested interests," he said.
"While there will be many false summers, as things seem to look better for a time, the whole process will ultimately take a decade or two," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: THIS ITEM IS TO REPLACE CEP0019.
DOC.TEXT:
