The statistics show that 166,217 couples married last year, representing a marriage rate of 0.768 percent, down 0.22 percent from the same period of 1996. The marriage rate is calculated as the number of newly-wed couples as a percentage of the total population.
During the same period, 38,986 couples divorced, a rate of 0.18 percent, up 8.67 percent from last year. The divorce rate is calculated as the number of divorced couples as a percentage of the total population.
According to the statistics, therefore, one couple got married in Taiwan every 3.2 minutes last year, while one couple ended their marriage every 13.5 minutes.
Kaohsiung City recorded the highest divorce rate at 0.217 percent, followed by Taipei City at 0.205 percent. The divorce rate in Taiwan Province stood at 0.174 percent.
Taiwan's divorce rate has continued to rise for the past 10 years, from 0.126 percent and 0.125 percent in 1988 and 1989, respectively, to 0.135 percent in 1990, 0.138 percent in 1991, 0.141 percent in 1992, 0.145 percent in 1993, 0.151 percent in 1994, 0.157 percent in 1995, and 0.167 percent in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE LAWMAKER FROM VIETNAM DENIES ORDERING MURDER OF AUSTRALIAN MP

TEXT.P: Australian councilor Phuong Ngo, an ethnic Chinese from Vietnam, has denied ordering the murder of Member of Parliament John Newman in September 1994.
When interviewed by New South Wales police, Ngo said he did not arrange for three employees of Cabramatta's Mekong Club to kill Newman on September 5, 1994.
Newman was killed in front of his house in Cabramatta, a city near Sydney, and the case remains unsolved.

Ngo is one of the councilors from the town of Fairfield who promoted a sisterhood agreement about three years ago between the Taiwan city of Hsinchu and Fairfield, a small town with a population of about 170,000, the majority of whom come from Vietnam.
Police say they have information that Ngo arranged the murder of Newman, but Ngo denied any knowledge of the killing and said he was not involved in the shooting in any way.
Police are continuing with their investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TRIES TO MAKE 2000 OLYMPIC GAMES CLEAN AND FAIR

TEXT.P: The doping scandal surrounding a mainland China swim team at the 8th World Championship in January in Perth, Australia, not only puts mainland China's credibility in doubt, but also raises the prospect of tougher crackdowns on more than 12,000 athletes expected to attend the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, leading to the hope that the event will be remembered not only as a great sporting event, but also a clean and fair one, organizers said.

They said the seizure of human growth hormones from mainland China swimmer Yuan Yuan, and the positive drug tests of four other mainland China swimmers, has illustrated the seriousness of the problem, not only in swimming competitions, but also in other sports.

Yuan and the other four swimmers were banned from competing in the World Swimming Championship in Perth, and the organizers said they hoped the doping scandal would serve as a serious warning not only for mainland China, but also for other countries.

But Terry Gathercole, president of the Australian Swimming Association, turned up the heat on mainland China this week during a World Cup meeting in Beijing, reiterating the call for mainland China to withdraw from international competition for a year -- not just in swimming but in all sports.
Gathercole has the backing of nearly all of the 19 other participating swimming countries in the Beijing competition.
Three Australian swimmers boycotted the Word Cup competition in Beijing on Wednesday and Thursday as a protest against the host country.
They were followed by New Zealand, who did not send any swimmers after competing in the Hong Kong leg of the World Cup last weekend.
Sweden has stayed away, while the United States and Canada are also absent.

Australian swimmers said they had to boycott the Beijing competition because if they took part, it would be tantamount to supporting mainland China in light of their 29 positive drug results in the past seven years -- more than all other swimming nations combined.

Gathercole was not only applying more heat on the Chinese on Tuesday, he also said the recently announced 11-point anti-drugs plan devised by a FINA delegation and the Chinese Swimming Association (CSA) five days ago has not yet been formally adopted.

The plan, which calls for a life ban, punishment of coaches, suspension of Chinese clubs for a year if they have two positive steroid or hormone cases within a 12-month period and monies won by athletes to be put into trust accounts, is supposed to be backdated to January 1, 1998.
Gathercole said the plan could just be window-dressing.

"The first proof will be if CSA adopts the FINA recommendations but if they reject any, or the whole thing, then they are not being as sincere as they should be and their credibility will be shot," he said.

The organizers of the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney said the recent doping scandal in Perth should serve as a serious warning for mainland China and a good reminder that Beijing must clean house in all sports to avoid a repeat of a similar scandal in September 2000, when the Olympic Games take place in Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1997 TRADE WITH MAINLAND CHINA HIT RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Trade between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1997 totaled US$24.44 billion, creating a new record high for bilateral trade, according to statistics released on Friday by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

Taiwan exported a total of US$20.53 billion-worth of goods to mainland China while importing a total of US$3.91 billion-worth from mainland China last year, representing a trade surplus of US$16.62 billion in Taiwan's favor, also a new record high, the statistics show.

BOFT officials said that in the face of the steady growth of ROC exports to mainland China and the substantial increase of its imports from mainland China, two-way cross-strait trade enjoyed an increase of 10.1 percent over the previous year.
Taiwan goods exported to mainland China last year included mainly electrical equipment and components, machine tools and parts, plastics and plastic goods.

The bulk of the items imported from mainland China in 1997 were agricultural and industrial raw materials, accounting for 74.5 percent of the total, while capital equipment and consumer goods accounted for 14.4 percent and 11.1 percent, respectively, of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER STILL ASSESSING INVESTMENT IN TAICHUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Germany-based Bayer Group on Friday fell short of clarifying its decision over the fate of its controversial proposal for a production plant for toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) in Taichung Harbor, central Taiwan, saying only that the company is still assessing the case.

A Bayer executive in charge of international and Asia-Pacific affairs said the company has not made a final decision over the TDI investment project in Taiwan which on Thursday provoked clashes between Taiwan Provincial Assembly deputies of the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party over a proposed land lease contract for the chemical giant.
The Taiwan Provincial Assembly announced on Thursday afternoon that it will postpone the final vote over the land lease contract until its next session, scheduled for March 6.

It is understood that Bayer headquarters may make a final announcement next week on whether or not it will withdraw the case from Taiwan, one week later than a deadline of late February set earlier by Bayer.

After more than two years of arrangement and effort, the Bayer Group announced in December that it was relocating its TDI investment project from near Taichung Harbor to Texas as a result of strong opposition from local residents over fears that the plant will pollute the environment.

But Bayer told a Taiwan delegation which visited the parent company earlier this month that it is willing to keep the project in Taiwan if the land lease contract can be approved by the end of this month in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.

Meanwhile, a survey made public by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development shows that a total of 64.8 percent of the respondents (including 21.3 percent of those who agree with the plan if safety measures can be fully implemented) are in favor of Bayer's TDI investment in Taichung Harbor, while a similar level of respondents think the residents of the four townships near the proposed site should be entitled to decide the fate of the project.

Another signal worth noting is that although most of the respondents have confidence in Bayer's record in environmental protection, they lack such faith in the ROC government's supervisory capabilities.

According to the poll, 61.1 percent of the respondents believe that Bayer will fully implement safety and environmental protection measures here, while at the same time, 53.5 percent said they do not have confidence in the government's supervisory role, with 59.1 percent saying that they are still worried that the TDI plant will cause pollution in the nearby communities.
The telephone survey, carried out by the TVBS cable television company on Feb. 24, sampled 1,678 people over the age of 20 islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU RONGJI TO BE NAMED NEW PRC PREMIER: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Wu Shean-shen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Zhu Rongji, vice premier of the People's Republic of China, is to be named premier, while the current Premier Li Peng will be reassigned as chairman of the National People's Congress, with formal approval being given at the 9th National People's Congress which opens on Thursday, according to Hong Kong's South China Morning Post newspaper.
The newspaper said in its Friday edition that the reshuffle of state leaders passed through the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China in Beijing on Thursday.

A reformed-minded economist, Zhu has been at the country's economic helm for five years, and will face the challenge of boosting domestic demand and halting deflation while avoiding stagflation, all against the background of the regional economic crisis.

Vice Premier Qian Qichen, who has been in charge of the country's foreign affairs for a decade, is expected to remain in office for at least another year, said the newspaper, noting that he has presided over the handover of Hong Kong in July, President Jiang Zemin's US visit in October and the recent rapprochement with the European Union and pointing out that no one in Beijing's senior hierarchy has yet been groomed to take his place.

Meanwhile, the Chinese-language Minpao newspaper, also Hong Kong-based, said that Hu Jintao, the No.4 member of the CPC Political Bureau, is expected to be named a vice president, while Wen Jiabao, a member of the Political Bureau, and Wu Yi, minister of foreign trade and economic cooperation, have been tipped to become new vice premiers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE GOVERNMENT UNVEILS 1998 BUDGET

TEXT.P: The Singapore Government Friday unveiled its budget for fiscal 1998, with revenue collection estimated at S$29.9 billion and operating and development expenditures budgeted at S$27.2 billion.
The operating surplus for the period is expected to be S$2.7 billion or about 1.7 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
As a percentage of GDP, the surplus is much lower than the 3.8 percent average of 1996 and 1997.
The budget was presented in nearly two hours by Singapore Finance Minister Hu Tsu Dow at a parliament session on Friday afternoon.
Apart from the direct impact caused by the regional financial turmoil, there are two other reasons for the smaller surplus, Hu explained.

One is a general slowdown in the growth of revenue collection due to the cumulative effects of tax cuts introduced over the past 12 years. The other is the substantial rise in development expenditures in recent years.
Notwithstanding the slower increase in revenues, Singapore's revenue base remains robust and a deficit budget is not envisaged, he said.

Total government expenditure in fiscal 1998 is expected to increase by 15 percent to S$27.2 billion, more than double the expected nominal GDP growth rate, which will provide some fiscal stimulus to the domestic economy, he said.
Defense spending, education, infrastructure, economic development, and communications will take up the lion's share of government spending, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT BAHRAIN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan, currently in Jordan for a private visit, will fly later on Friday from the Jordanian capital of Amman to Bahrain, according to officials from his Taipei office.
Lien, who arrived in Jordan with his wife Lien Fang Yu on Tuesday for an unannounced visit, remained tight-lipped on his destination following his three-day stay in Amman.

He had originally planned to visit Lebanon, which, like Jordan, doesn't recognize Taiwan diplomatically, but was forced to cancel after his schedule was exposed by Taiwan's mass media, stirring up protests to the Lebanese government by mainland authorities in Beijing.
During his stay in Jordan, Lien received a honorary doctoral degree from Jordan University and met with various Jordanian leaders, ,according to the officials.
Lien and his entourage are expected to visit Kuala Lumpur on March 4 to return a February 11 visit to Taipei by Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.
No date for his return to Taipei has yet been announced.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO BECOME ASIA'S PRIME FUND MANAGEMENT HUB

TEXT.P: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said on Friday that the government will develop Singapore into Asia's premier fund management hub over the next five to 10 years.

Addressing a seminar organized by the Investment Management Association of Singapore (IMAS), he pointed out that "we start with well-known advantages -- our reputation as a safe haven, our record of political stability and macro-economic soundness, our well-established airlinks, telecommunications network, and IT (information technology) infrastructure."
But, he added, Singapore also faces some natural constraints: a small domestic market, and long geographic distances from the major investment markets of America and Europe.

"Our target is therefore twofold," he said. "First, to become a center for managing the Asian investment portfolios of both Asian and Western clients. And second, to manage global investments of clients in Asia. The industry is already developing in this direction."
He pointed out that Singapore's strategies for developing the fund management industry focus on the following areas:
First, to improve and streamline the regulatory structure for fund managers and unit trusts.
Singapore's financial criteria for obtaining an Investment Adviser's (IA) license are set too high. This has kept smaller but well-managed fund management companies of good repute out of Singapore.

Lee, who is also chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), said that MAS will reduce the minimum shareholders' funds required for an IA license from S$500 million to S$100 million, and lower the minimum amount of global funds that the parent company must manage from S$5 billion to S$1 billion. However, the admission criteria in terms of track record, management expertise, and licensing status will remain.
Second, to place substantially more GIC funds with private fund managers based in Singapore.
Since 1994, the GIC has been placing more funds with private fund managers with offices in Singapore. So far, it has placed out a total of S$10 billion.

In the next three years, Lee said, the GIC will increase the amount placed with fund managers with Singapore offices from S$10 billion to S$35 billion. This will comprise both global and regional mandates.
Third, to further liberalize the CPF (Central Provident Fund) Unit Trust Scheme, and encourage CPF members to invest their savings in CPF-approved unit trusts.
Fourth, to enhance distribution channels for unit trusts.

Improving distribution channels will give investors a wider choice of unit trusts. It will promote competition among financial institutions, and drive fees lower. The MAS will therefore permit foreign fund managers in Singapore to market their products to Singapore investors through local financial institutions.
Fifth, to develop a broad range of domestic investible instruments.
Singapore is currently studying ways to develop its equity and debt capital markets so as to make it the leading corporate funding center in the region.
Finally, to encourage a strong private sector role in promoting the fund management industry.
Lee pointed out that one strategy he had not touched upon was "to use tax incentives to promote fund management."
"We already have various tax incentives for this purpose, but they can be further improved and enhanced," he said. "When we decide on any changes, we will announce them."

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTS ARRESTED IN DOCTOR'S KIDNAP AND MURDER

TEXT.P: Taiwan police said on Friday that they have arrested nine suspects wanted for the kidnap and murder of renowned gynecologist Hsieh Cheng-hsien in southern Taiwan's Tainan city, but warned that the man believed to be the mastermind behind the case remains at large.

Police said they arrested Chiu Sheng-lung late on Thursday night, while another suspect, Chen Kuo-hsung, turned himself in early on Friday morning. Their confessions helped the police to apprehend another seven suspects, but the alleged mastermind, Tsai Cheng-hsien, was not nabbed.

Chen Kuo-hsung told police that in 1990, for unknown reasons, Tsai and a group of gangsters vandalized Hsieh's Tainan City clinic. Tsai was later listed as a hooligan by the police, partly because of Hsieh's identification. A few days ago, Tsai accompanied his pregnant wife to Hsieh's clinic, where he asked Hsieh to deliver their baby. Upon recognizing Tsai, Hsieh refused to offer his services, whereupon Tsai became enraged and decided to kidnap the doctor.

Chen said that on Tuesday morning, he and Tsai, masked and armed with knives and guns, apprehended Hsieh at his clinic. They beat the doctor, who attempted to resist, before bundling him into a waiting car driven by the third suspect, Chiu Sheng-lung.

They made several phone calls to Hsieh's family between Tuesday afternoon and early Wednesday morning, demanding a ransom of NT$30 million in exchange for the doctor's release. The amount was eventually reduced to NT$5 million after bargaining but in fact by that time, Hsieh had already been shot to death and his body burned.

Chen said they took Hsieh to a remote mountainous area in Kaohsiung County, where, despite their strong objections, Tsai shot the doctor in the left temple and set the body aflame. According to Chen, Tsai even told them: "It's no big deal to kill a person."
Chen told the police that regretted getting involved in the kidnap, stressing that he didn't know that Tsai intended to kill the doctor.
The other five suspects were arrested on charges of helping the assailants rent the car used in the kidnapping and assisting them in making their getaway.

The kidnappers fates were sealed when one of Hsieh's nurses caught a glimpse of the license plate of the rental car as it Made off with Hsieh inside. Although the plate had been tampered with, the police were able to locate the store that owns the rented car, and from there were able to identify the suspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKED AS HONG KONG'S 7TH-LARGEST MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked as Hong Kong's 7th-largest export market in the first eleven months of 1997, according to statistics released by the Hong Kong government on Friday.
Taiwan absorbed US$4.35 billion-worth of Hong Kong exports out of a total of US$170 billion, representing a growth of 10 percent and 4 percent respectively, compared to the same period of a year ago.

Mainland China remained Hong Kong's biggest export market, accounting for US$59.8 billion-worth of Hong Kong's exports, followed by the United States, at US$37.76 billion, and Japan, at US$10.59 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY MEMBER PROPOSES NEW IDEA FOR CROSS-STRAIT POLICY

TEXT.P: Jaw Shau-kong, a heavyweight with the opposition New Party, on Friday proposed his own unique version of a cross-strait policy, the goal of which he termed as: "Make a fortune together and discuss reunification some other time."

Jaw, a founding member of the pro-reunification New Party, said that Taiwan and mainland China can establish "constructive strategic partnership," similar to the one between the United States and mainland China.

In a press conference which will be held for three consecutive days in order for Jaw to express his thoughts on national issues, he said that only through increasing contacts and exchanges of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will Taiwan have the chance to export democracy to the mainland.

To show goodwill to Beijing as part of efforts to improve cross-strait relations, Jaw suggested that the government of the Republic of China announce that it will stick to its "one China" policy, that it won't seek Taiwan independence, and that it won't seek membership in the United Nations.

While saying that a "one China, two countries" scheme which was proposed a few days ago by some New Party members runs counter to the party's official mainland policy, Jaw said that this doesn't mean that the party members cannot have other opinions on mainland policy. The most important question after a new mainland policy is approved by the party will be whether the New Party followers will support the policy, he added.
After his failure in a bid to win the Taipei mayoral election three years ago, Jaw has gradually withdrawn from the political arena and currently runs a local radio station.
Asked if the holding of the press conference means that he intends to return to political arena, Jaw replied that the answer will be known within the next two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU, TAIWAN SIGN CONFERENCE RECORDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Chen Ruey-long and European Union delegate Jean-Pierre de Laet on Friday signed a copy of the minutes of their discussions on Taiwan's terms for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) following the close of three days of bilateral negotiations.
Chen, chief negotiator of the ROC delegation, said the EU will respond formally to the document within two weeks, following approval by the 15 individual EU member states.

The Brussels-based Executive Commission under the EU will report the contents to the 15 members and the terms reached in the bilateral negotiations will become a formal accord, so long as none of the 15 nations voices opposition, Chen added.

Although minor differences remain in the issues of customs duties on imports of EU automobiles and parts and on tariffs for wines and spirits, Taiwan and the EU reached major agreement on the opening up of the Taiwan's service and industrial sectors, removing the principal barriers to successful bilateral consultations for Taiwan's WTO membership.

Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said he is generally satisfied with the results of the talks, while Chen said he is very optimistic that Taiwan will soon be able to sign a formal accord with the EU.
Taiwan and the EU have held 12 rounds of bilateral negotiations over the past five years on the island's terms for WTO entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: WUCHIU STRONGLY OPPOSES STORAGE OF TAIPOWER NUCLEAR WASTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company's (Taipower's) plan to shortlist one of Taiwan's offshore island groups near the coast of mainland China for a possible site for storage of nuclear waste has aroused strong opposition from the island's residents.

Lee Yi-chiang, chief of the island township, about 70 nautical miles northeast of Kinmen, indicated that the people of the island do not enjoy the convenience of electricity generated by Taipower, and said the decision by Taipower to store nuclear waste on the tiny islands will never gain the support of the islanders.
He said that he plans to lead a group of people from Wuchiu within the next few days to the headquarters of Taipower in Taipei to protest the company's plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAP BETWEEN TAIWAN, BRITISH TRADE OFFICIALS NARROWED

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan and British officials have not resolved all their differences, Republic of China Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu said here on Friday that both sides have greatly narrowed the gap between their positions during their latest round of annual trade talks.

Lin, who arrived in London on Wednesday at the head of an ROC government mission to take part in a Taiwan-Britain bilateral economic and trade consultation, told the CNA that Taiwan's monopoly tax on whisky imports from Britain remains a thorny issue which needs to be tackled further.

Britain has expressed full support for Taiwan's bid to join the WTO, and is very interested in forging agreements on intellectual property rights protection and double-tax exemption with Taiwan, Lin noted.

During the one-and-a-half-day meeting, the two sides also discussed ways to accelerate commercial and investment exchanges between the two countries, and the opening of international and regional trade organizations, commodity and service markets.

Lin said he fully understands Britain's concern over Taiwan's disproportionately high monopoly tax on Scotch whisky compared to similar products from other regions, and promised to convey this concern to the relevant ROC government agencies so that it can be resolved as soon as possible.

Under Taiwan's tobacco and alcohol monopoly system, which basically imposes liquor and wine taxes based on the products' prices, a tax of NT$440 (US$13.4) per liter is levied on whisky from Scotland and Ireland, while the rate for whiskey from other regions is set at NT$198 (US$6).
The Scotch Whisky Association called the taxation discriminatory, and said it is responsible for the decreased market share of European liquors in Taiwan.

Scotch whisky accounted for 38.49 percent of total liquor imports in Taiwan in the first 10 months of last year, down from 44.64 percent in 1996, while the market share of Japanese whiskey rose from 6.78 percent to 22.21 percent over the same period, according to Taiwan customs sources.
Britain has been so successful at marketing Scotch whisky in Taiwan during the last several years that it is now the second-largest British export item to the island.
Britain is currently Taiwan's third-largest trading partner in Europe. Two-way trade between the two countries reached US$4.6 billion in 1997.
Before arriving in London, Lin and his party visited Israel and the northern African country of Tunisia.

In Israel, the officials were warmly received by their official counterparts, and the two sides exchanged views on cooperation in the aerospace industry, and the biological technology and electronics sectors, paving the way for the signing of agreements on bilateral cooperation in the near future, according to Lin.

Following his Tunisian visit, Lin concluded that the country's textile industry may be an excellent choice for Taiwan investors, given that the market can serve as a quota-free gateway to the European Union and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRADE MISSION TO VISIT FOUR EAST EUROPEAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Saturday that it will organize a trade mission to explore emerging markets in central and eastern Europe.

The delegation of trade officials and business executives is scheduled to visit Lithuania, Latvia, Finland and Russia between May 23 and June 11 to seek trade and investment opportunities and promote bilateral economic cooperation, BOFT officials said.

In addition to meeting with trade and economics officials of the four countries, the delegation will sponsor trade forums in their major cities, tour industrial parks and export processing zones, and visit major trade promotion organizations.

According to BOFT tallies, Taiwan's aggregate trade with central and eastern European countries amounted to US$910 million in 1997, accounting for a mere 2.3 percent of its total trade with Europe as a whole.
Of this amount, Taiwan exports to those countries comprised US$530 million, up 15.3 percent from the year-earlier level.

BOFT officials said there is still ample room for trade with central and eastern European countries. Many nations in the region, such as Russia, Latvia and Lithuania, have been undertaking extensive market reforms and are enjoying brisk economic growth.
Noting that trade with Russia has grown rapidly in recent years, the officials said Russia is eager to buy computer peripherals, textiles and consumer electronics.

The officials further said Latvia and Lithuania have been actively pushing for economic reforms since they declared independence in the early 1990s. The officials suggested that local manufacturers set up production facilities in the two countries to facilitate their forays into the region.

Finland shares a common border with Russia and is a member of the European Union. "Given its special geographic location, Finland can act as a bridgehead to explore emerging markets in the region," said a BOFT official.

Because of the geographic distances involved, and the special trade practices in the region, the official said local traders had better pool their resources in tapping those emerging markets. "Previous experience has shown that joint efforts are far more effective than individual promotional activities in making inroads into eastern European markets," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGLIGENCE BLAMED FOR MAJOR WORKPLACE ACCIDENTS

TEXT.P: Serious accidents in the workplace are often the result of negligence on the part of employers and employees, according to a Republic of China Council of Labor Affairs (COA) report released on Saturday.

COA officials made the report after the latest such accident which occurred in the Linyuan industrial zone in southern Kaohsiung county, when a gas explosion on Friday killed four and injured scores of others.
The report defined "serious accidents" as incidents in the workplace which cause the death of more than one worker or injuries of morth than three workers.

It further revealed that investigations into the causes of serious accidents found that between 1982 and 1996, 2,499 cases, or 40.14 percent, were caused by violations of safety codes, while 1,522 cases, or 25.06 percent, took place because of insufficient safety facilities.
This indicates that the majority of serious accidents are caused by human factors, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL PLIGHT OF NANTOU COUNTY RELIEVED TEMPORARILY

TEXT.P: Government employees including teachers in central Taiwan's Nantou County, felt relieved on Friday when they heard that they will receive their pay checks for March and for the rest of this year, thanks to assistance from the provincial and central governments.

Premier Vincent Siew on Friday said that he has instructed the provincial government to subsidize NT$240 million to make up the shortfall of the March payroll for local government employees in Nantou County.

Siew also said that the Taiwan Bank will provide a NT$1.5 billion loan to the agricultural county to help relieve the financial plight the Nantou county government is facing in meeting payments to its employees.

Peng Pai-shien, who took over leadership of the county in late December following the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)'s victory in November elections, announced on Thursday that as the county coffers are fast approaching empty, he had decided that pay for nearly 8,000 public servants in the county would be suspended.

Peng said that as of the end of last year, the local government deficit has accumulated to NT$2.2 billion, adding that if the provincial or central governments failed to offer substantial assistance, the suspension would continue indefinitely.

However, Peng, a former DPP legislator, said that a NT$200 million educational subsidy might be used to pay part of the payroll, which would mean that employees would still get half of their pay for March.

According to Peng, the annual disposable revenue of the Nantou County government stands at just NT$2.1 billion approximately, but payroll spending for local government employees costs NT$420 million per month, a total of NT$5 billion per year.

Peng's move was seen as part of efforts to draw the central government's attention to the financial problems faced by the cash-strapped county, and to win greater discretion over the disposal of the revenue collected in the county. Under the current political system, revenue collected in a county or city is allocated among the central government, the provincial government and the local government.

In 1995, the total revenue collected in Nantou county stood at NT$8.6 billion, of which only some NT$2 billion was at the disposal of the county government. The annual expenditure listed in the county's budget for that year, however, reached NT$12.1 billion, meaning that even if the total revenue collected in the county had been at the disposal of the local government, there would still have been a shortfall in funds for development.

Peng said he hopes that in addition to an overhaul of the revenue allocation law, the central government will institute laws governing subsidies to government employee payroll spending and to the welfare policies of the nation's poorer counties and cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESUMING TALKS TOPS ALL CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES: CHANG

TEXT.P: Resuming talks between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), is the top priority of all efforts concerning cross-strait relations, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Saturday.

Only by guiding the SEF-ARATS communication onto the right track will a meeting between the heads of the two intermediary bodies become possible, and talks on resolutions to other differences across the Taiwan Strait be a natural progression, Chang noted.
During a speech to a symposium hosted by National Chengchi University, Chang expressed welcome to the latest ARATS response to Taipei's calls for a resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

Although differences exist and controversies take time to solve, Chang said the common goal of seeking peaceful rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait and the eventual unification of China remain unchanged.
He called for both sides to demonstrate sincerity in a rational and practical manner during the testing process.

Meanwhile, at the same symposium, Chang Jung-kung, director of the ruling Kuomintang's Department of Mainland Affairs, again urged Beijing to face the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are two distinct political entities existing on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
The best idea for both sides, or any other parties in the world, to handle cross-Taiwan Strait relations, is to treat the issue from the point of view of a divided nation, Chang noted.

He also predicted that the second meeting between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan will be held this year, after a hiatus of five years since their last history-making and ice-breaking rendezvous in Singapore in April 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESIDENTS NEAR CAL CRASH SITE DEMAND REDRESS

TEXT.P: Residents near the site of the worst-ever air crash in Taiwan's history on Saturday demanded that China Airlines (CAL) shoulder the responsibility of dealing with the issue of property damaged by the crash as soon as possible.

Several houses were destroyed or seriously damaged when a CAL A300-600R airbus crashed on approach to the Chiang Kai Shek International Airport Feb. 16, killing all 196 on board and six on the ground.

Over 100 protesters from 30 or 40 households, waving large banners which said "homeland turning into graveyard," "ghosts crying in the night," and "bodies strewn over the fields," gathered near the crash site to protest against CAL for not handling compensation for damage to their houses in a timely enough manner.

They complained that after days of heavy rain, their damaged houses have developed cracked walls and leaking roofs. They voiced concern that their houses could collapse in the event of an earthquake, a fairly common occurrence in Taiwan.
CAL has evacuated residents from five houses that were completely destroyed, and the occupants of four other houses that were severely damaged, resettling them elsewhere.
But residents who said their houses were also damaged by the impact of the plane crash expressed hope that CAL will purchase their houses and land so that they can move to other places soon.

Meanwhile, work to identify all the crash victims has been continuing around the clock. The Taoyuan Prosecutors' Office has issued 152 death certificates so far, but it will wait for CAL to work out a solution with the families of the victims whose bodies were burned beyond recognition.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER CALLS FOR COMPASSION TO HEAL 2-28 SCARS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Saturday called for compassion and tolerance to heal the wounds and divisions left by the tragic February 28 Incident of 1947.

Siew made the appeal during a memorial service marking the 51st anniversary of the incident, which was sparked by the arrest and beating of an elderly female street vendor selling untaxed cigarettes. Subsequent islandwide rioting and anti-Kuomintang (KMT) protests followed by a brutal military crackdown caused the death of thousands of innocent people all over Taiwan.

Noting that the tragic incident has touched many families here, Siew said that Feb. 28 is a day of sadness, but added: "In recent years, the government has shown it has the courage and sincerity to face historical facts and has adopted many measures to heal the wounds and scars left by the episode."

In remembrance of those lost in the unrest and its aftermath, Siew said he hopes the nation will learn a lesson from the tragic events of the past to avoid the recurrence of similar tragedies in the future.
"Let us break from the pathos of the past, walk away from old resentments and demonstrate our power to create a more harmonious, brighter future," Siew urged.

He further encouraged his fellow countrymen to pause for reflection at this critical juncture in the nation's development. "We can draw inspiration from the incident," Siew said. "Let us forgive and forget."

The premier also called for unity and social harmony, saying that all Taiwan's residents, regardless of whether they moved from the Chinese mainland centuries ago or after the ROC government moved its seat to Taiwan from the mainland in 1949, should stand united and work from the grassroots to cope with the numerous challenges and tests that lie ahead in the completion of the country's many construction and reform projects in preparation for the new millennium.

The memorial service at the 2-28 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei was jointly presided over by Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian and Minister-without-Portfolio Chao Shou-po, who concurrently serves as chairman of the 2-28 Memorial Foundation.

Chao said the foundation has commissioned local academics to draw up concrete measures to restore the reputations of many innocent people who were convicted and executed in connection with the 2-28 Incident. The scholars are studying some foreign practices and will come up with a comprehensive package of measures before the end of June.
"In memory of all the victims, we should transform sadness into strength and work hand-in-hand to create a more just and harmonious society with a sense of common destiny," Chao added.

Speaking on the same occasion, Mayor Chen said President Lee Teng-hui has publicly apologized for the tragic incident on behalf of the government. "This indicates that the government has the sincerity to face its past mistakes. I hope the relevant government agencies will hereafter handle various 2-28 Incident-related issues in a more broadminded manner and make public all related historic archives and documents."

Professor Lin Chun-yi, whose father was executed without trial in the incident, urged the families of all the 2-28 victims to forgive and forget the historic wounds and dedicate themselves to pushing for continued democratic reforms and cultural, economic and social development in Taiwan.

An inscription featuring 642 Chinese characters on a facet of the globe-shaped sculpture, which forms part of the 2-28 Monument in Taipei's 2-28 Peace Memorial Park was destroyed by unidentified persons a few hours after it was unveiled on Feb. 28, 1997. Some families of the victims were dissatisfied with the content of the destroyed inscription.
Lin said he hopes a new inscription featuring an accurate account of the incident will be installed on the mounment in the near future.
Similar commemorative activities were also held in other major cities around the island to mark the occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO UPGRADE INDIGENOUS PORK TO COUNTER ASSAULT OF FOREIGN PORK

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Saturday that it will upgrade the competitive edge of local pork to counter the expected onslaught from foreign pork in Taiwan's market after its accession into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Hog farmers have expressed serious concern that US pork will undercut local pork prices in the Taiwan market since Taiwan last week initialed an agreement with the US on the island's terms for WTO entry, especially as Taiwan has promised to allow an immediate market opening for 5,000 tons of currently-banned pork cuts and 7,500 tons of pork variety meats from the US.
To cope with the situation, COA is planning to cut the island's hog population from the current 8.5 million head to 6 million in the future.
Chen Pao-ki, director of the COA's Animal Industry Department, said that it is cheaper to produce pork and chicken in the US, which gives the US an edge if it exports these products to Taiwan.

But he also pointed out that Japan's market was not affected by the entry of US pork after Tokyo joined the WTO, adding that Taiwan pork still accounted for 50 percent of the Japanese market, up until a ban imposed as a result of an epidemic of foot and mouth disease which ravaged Taiwan in March last year. Chen described this as proof that the taste of Taiwan pork is indeed better than that produced in the US.

To increase the competitive edge of Taiwan pork, Chen said that the COA has mapped out a plan which will include the establishment of a sperm bank for semen taken from top quality stud hogs, the use of imported stock to develop a new generation of high-yield indigenous pork with superior flavor, together with integrated management of hog farms and the promotion of joint purchasing to lower the costs of hog farming.

Chen said that US pork cuts and bellies may lose some of their flavor after long hours of transportation, and said they will be more likely to be processed into pork products, instead of going directly to the consumer market.
The COA will also step up the quality control and inspection systems for local pork, as well as promoting a sound distribution system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPPOSES APEC EARLY VOLUNTARY LIBERALIZATION PLAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan, along with Japan, South Korea and mainland China, has recently expressed opposition to an APEC initiative to voluntarily liberalize the fishing and fishery products sector at an early date, in sharp contrast to the positions of some other APEC nations, including Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the United States.

According to Huang Chin-jong, director of the Council of Agriculture's Economics and Planning Department, who took part in an APEC senior officials meeting in Penang, Malaysia in mid-February, the representatives from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea and mainland China are all opposed to an APEC initiative to include the fishing and fishing products sector in the APEC Early Voluntary System of Liberalization (EVSL).
Taiwan's position is that by gradually lowering its import tariffs on fishery products, the island is already contributing to the APEC principle of upholding the spirit of free trade, Huang said.
Like the officials from Japan, South Korea and mainland China, the Taiwan representatives do not think adding the fishing and fishery products sector to the EVSL is viable, he added.
Taiwan has agreed to cut its tariff rates for imported fishery products in line with its effort to become a member of the World Trade Organization, Huang said.
Senior officials from 18 APEC economies have discussed an accord for EVSL in 15 sectors, nine of which have to be ready by next year.

APEC trade ministers have only until this June to finalize "detailed targets and timelines" for these nine fast-track sectors: chemicals, energy, environmental goods and services, fish and fish products, forest products, gems and jewelry, medical equipment, telecommunications and toys.

DOC.HEADLINE: HU JINTAO REPORTED TO BE HEIR APPARENT TO JIANG ZEMIN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Victor Lai and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The two-day Second Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC), which concluded on Thursday, adopted a list of candidates for leading positions in the government, including Hu Jintao for vice president of mainland China, the Tokyo-based Yomiuri Shimbum reported from Beijing on Saturday.
Hu, 55, is currently a member of the Standing Committee of the Politburo of the CPC Central Committee.

The daily said that if its sources are correct and Hu has indeed been recommended to become vice president, this would be a de facto nomination for him to be the heir apparent to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

Whether the personnel reshuffle will be submitted to the Ninth National People's Congress (NPC), slated to open March 5, is attracting widespread attention, said the daily, adding that if it is approved, this would be the first time for Beijing authorities to accept a middle-aged politician for the post of vice president.

The plenum deliberated and adopted a list of candidates for the leading positions in government bodies to be submitted to the First Session of the Ninth NPC, according to mainland China's official Xinhua News Agency. The plenum also drew up another list of candidates for the high-level posts in the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), which will be given to the First Session of the Ninth CPPCC National Committee, Xinhua said.

Incumbent mainland Chinese Vice President Rong Yiren, 81, is due to retire because of his age. The plan to have him succeeded by Vice Chairman of the 8th NPC Standing Committee Buhe (* editors note: one name *) of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region has been changed, the Japanese daily said.
The personnel reshuffle, observed the daily, is meant to cultivate Hu, a member of the "fourth generation" of mainland China's leadership, as Jiang's successor.

Hu, a native of Shanghai and a graduate of Qinghua University, has held the posts of CPC secretary for both Guizhou Province and the Tibet Autonomous Region, according to the report. He was promoted to the CPC Politburo at the 14th National Congress in 1992 and made a member of the Standing Committee. Hu is seen as a crony of the late CPC General Secretary Hu Yaobang and Song Ping, ex-head of the Organization Department of the CPC, said the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 FUGITIVES TAKEN BACK TO TAIWAN FROM THAILAND

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan fugitives were escorted back to Taiwan from Thailand by Yang Tzu-ching, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, on Saturday.

The three wanted criminal suspects were identified as Kao Chi-yuan, 51; Kung Ching-yun, 38; and Liao Tun-ching, 44. They have been wanted by local law enforcement authorities on charges of gambling, drug trafficking and fraud, respectively.
Yang left Taipei for a Southeast Asian tour last weekend. He first visited Hong Kong and then traveled to the Philippines and Thailand.

Yang said upon his return that the weeklong three-country tour was fruitful. "I have exchanged views with senior police officers in the three places on fight against cross-border criminal activities, including drug trafficking, firearms smuggling and cyberspace crimes."
Yang also asked Hong Kong, Thai and Philippine police authorities to help bring to justice more than 10 Taiwan fugitives who are believed to have fled abroad.
Yang was accompanied by several other senior CBI officers on his southeast Asian visit. (BY Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBIAN PRESIDENT VALUES HIS COUNTRY'S FRIENDSHIP WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Gambian President Yahya Jammeh said here Friday that the Republic of China is one of his country's best partners.

Jammeh made the remark when he met with Joe Hung, representative of the ROC in Italy. He told Hung that President Lee Teng--hui of the ROC is most welcome to visit his country, and that the Gambian government hopes to further promote the relations between the two countries.
President Jammeh is visiting Italy at the invitation of the Italian government. He has met with Italian Premier Romano Prodi and Pope John Paul II during his three-day stay in Rome.
Hung is acquainted with President Jammeh. They met last year when the President changed planes in Rome on his way to Taipei for an official visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND POLICE CONTINUE TO DETAIN DISSIDENTS

TEXT.P: Three mainland Chinese dissidents were detained by public safety officers in the past three days.

According to information released by the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, Yang Qinheng and Zhang Rujun were taken away by public safety officers in Shanghai on Feb. 26 and 27 respectively.
Another dissident, Ma Lianggang, was taken away from his home in Hefei, Anhui Province on Feb. 28.

The information center in Hong Kong said that, with the meeting of National People's Congress (NPC) drawing near, mainland Chinese authorities may detain more dissents on the mainland in order to silence them. The NPC is mainland China's parliament.

Yang and Zhang were among the 17 dissidents who sent an open letter to the NPC on Feb. 26, asking for the exoneration of former party leader Zhao Ziyang and the pro-democracy students involved in the 1989 Tiananmen incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN BAHRAIN FOR VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Bahrain, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Yang I-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan arrived in Bahrain from the Jordanian capital of Amman on Friday evening for a private visit.
Lien is the highest ROC official ever to visit the Persian Gulf island state, which doesn't maintain formal diploamtic ties with Taiwan.

Lien's visit was seen a breakthrough in ROC-Bahrain relations as the oil-rich emirate had many times rejected visa applications by ministerial-level ROC officials in order to safeguard its friendly ties with mainland China.

Although Lien and his entourage managed to enter Bahrain smoothly, 15 Taiwan reporters intending to cover Lien's Bahrain visit were barred from entering the country. Bahrain would not offer them landing visas. They were stranded at the airport.
Su Chi, deputy secretary-general to the ROC President and a member of Lien's entourage, has asked the ROC representative office here to help Taiwan journalists resolve the visas issue.
Lien dined with staff members of the ROC representative office and Chinese communisty leaders here on Friday. During the dinner, Lien expressed the government's concern for them.

Lien is scheduled to tour major construction projects, including a bridge linking Bahrain to Saudi Arabia, on Saturday. The vice president will also meet with staff members of an ROC agricultural mission stationed in Bahrain.
Sources said Lien may meet with senior Bahrain officials during his stay here.

Bahrain is a major oil expertor in the Middle East and an important base of the US Navy Fifth Fleet. Taiwan impots more than US$100 million worth of crude oil from Bahrain annually. And annual trade between the two countries exceeds US$150 million.
Lien reportedly may travel to another Middle East country following his Bahrain visit.
Lien originally planned to journey to the war-torn Middle East state of Lebanon after wining up a visit to Jordan. But he was forced to cancel such a travel plan due to strong pressure from Beijing.

Before coming to Bahrain, Lien concluded a four-day fruitful visit to Jordan. Lien said he managed to meet with all Jordanian very important persons (VIPs) he intends to meet. He also received a honorary doctoral degree in social sciences from the University of Jordan.

Following his Middle East swing, previous press reports said, Lien will make a stopover in Kuala Lumpur on his way home to meet with top Malaysian leaders on feasible cooperative measures to address the current Asian financial turmoil. Lien is expected to return to Taipei on March 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY HEAVYWEIGHT WARNS PARTY TO SHORE UP ITS SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Jaw Shau-kong, a heavyweight with the opposition New Party, on Saturday warned that if the party fails to take effective steps to regain its popular support, it is destined to suffer a serious setback in legislative election scheduled for the end of the year.

Jaw, one of the party's founding members, said that the New Party has gradually lost its supporters, citing its rout in the last two local elections. He expressed concern that without a plan to win back supporters, the ambiguity of the New Party's official line will further damage the pro-unification party's already-low popularity.

Jaw was referring to the "one China, two countries" scheme that several New Party members proposed a few days ago. The formula, which concerns Taiwan's relations with mainland China, contradicts the party's official mainland policy and has drawn severe criticism from some party heavyweights and supporters.
The Democratic Progressive Party, despite intraparty squabbling, has never changed its goal of seeking "Taiwan independence," he noted.
Jaw made the remarks in his second press conference since Friday, both of which were held for him to express his thoughts on national issues and on the development of the New Party.

The New Party should convene a national party congress as soon as possible to help save the party from being abandoned by its supporters, he said, stressing that the direction and development of the party should be decided by all party members, not by a small group at party headquarters.
Jaw said that one issue that ought to be discussed at this congress would be how New Party candidates should be nominated. He suggested using primaries to determine the party's nominees.

He warned that if the New Party cannot live up to the expectations of its supporters, its target of garnering 15 percent of the total vote in the year-end legislative election is impossible, adding that he questions whether the party can secure even 5 percent of the turnout if no improvements are made in the party.

Jaw, who has gradually withdrawn from the political arena since his failure to win the Taipei mayoral election some three years ago, also said that Wang Chien-shien, acting secretary-general of the New Party, should express a firm determination to run for the post of Taipei mayor.

Wang has said that he will seek the party's nomination to run in the next Taipei mayoral election if Taiwan Governor James Soong or former Minister Without Portfolio Ma Ying-jeou doesn't stand in that race.

Such insufficient determination is the reason Wang has failed to win support in recent surveys, Jaw said. Wang has no reason to hesitate since his political experience and moral character exceed even those of Soong and Ma, he added.

Jaw also said that incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who has announced his determination to seek reelection, is already past his peak popularity and can be defeated. The New Party, which received the second most votes in the last Taipei mayoral election, has a good chance to win the post of Taipei mayor this time, he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONUMENT INAUGURATED AT FLASH POINT OF 2-28 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: A monument was inaugurated at the flash point of the February 28 Incident of 1947 on Taipei's Nanking West Road on Saturday to remind the nation to learn a lesson from the incident to avoid the recurrence of similar tragedies in the future.
Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian presided over the inaugural ceremony, which proceeded amid solemn music in memory of all those who lost lives in the tragic incident.

Chen said the inscription on a monument erected by the central government in Taipei's 2-28 Peace Memorial Park was destroyed by unidentified disgruntled persons a few hours after it was unveiled on Feb. 28 last year.

"This was mainly because the inscription failed to give an accurate, clear-cut account of the incident," Chen claimed, adding that the destruction of the inscription also indicated that the wounds and divisions left by the 2-28 incident have not yet been completely heeled. "Many of our ordinary citizens want the government to more honestly clarify its role or responsibility in the incident."

The outspoken mayor from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said to probe who should be held responsible for the incident is by no means aimed at encouraging hatred or revenge. "Our main purpose is to remind the people to learn a lesson from the past tragedy. We believe only those who can honestly face history can dedicate themselves to pursuing permanent peace."

Against this backdrop, Chen said the Taipei City Government has decided to erect a monument at the site where the first shot in the infamous incident was fired on Feb. 28, 1947. "By so doing, I hope the history will not be forgetten, the historical wounds will heal and the souls of the innocent dead will be comforted."

The monument features Chinese and English inscriptions detailing the background and start of the tragic incident, which resulted in the death of thousands of innocent people and caused decades of hatred and bitterness between native Taiwanese and mainland Chinese immigrants.
The 750-word Chinese inscription blamed Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek for ordering military crackdown which planted the roots of ethnic division in Taiwan.

Kuomintang (KMT) troops were called in from the Chinese mainland to quell the riots which erupted after government inspectors beat an elderly woman selling untaxed cigarettes on Feb. 28, 1947. The violence spread across the island and led to deep resentment of mainland immigrants and the KMT government.

Reference to the incident remained taboo until a few years ago. Taiwan's democratization has enabled open discussion and research on the tragedy, leading to an open apology from President Lee Teng-hui three years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPUTER SHOW TO OPEN IN GRENADA
DOC.DATELINE: St. George's, Grenada, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Eduardo Chen)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan computer show will open on Saturday in St. George's, capital of the Caribbean nation of Grenada, as part of a science and technology exhibition during the ninth inter-sessional meeting of the CARICOM Summit of heads of government, scheduled to open in St. George's in early March.
Organized by the Republic of China Embassy in St. George's, the show will take place at the Grand Anse Trade Center from Feb. 28 to March 3.
ROC Ambassador to Grenada Lin Yung-loh expects that Taiwan will gradually develop an increasing partnership with CARICOM members in the field of science and technology.

The show is being co-sponsored by Taiwan computer giant ACER, one of the top ten brand names in the world computer industry. ACER will present to the general public in Grenada the latest models of its various computer and related peripheral equipment.

According to the 1997 Yearbook of the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry, Taiwan's production value of personal computers and related hardware in 1996 totaled US$24.2 billion. Personal computers, monitors, notebooks, and motherboards accounted for 80 percent of the total.

Many of Taiwan's personal computer products, such as scanners, motherboards, mice, keyboards and monitors now rank top worldwide in terms of global sales. Overall, Taiwan's information industry has grown to the point where it now follows only those of the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S PARLIAMENT ALLOWS TABLING OF TAIWAN TIES REPORT

TEXT.P: Canada's House of Commons gave unanimous consent this week to the tabling of a parliamentary group's report on bilateral relations between Canada and Taiwan.

This is "the first time in memory" that the House has allowed the tabling of a report from an unofficial parliamentary organization, said Paul Szabo, chair of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group.

The group has a membership of 75 parliamentarians, an indication that more and more Canadian MP's and their constituents are getting interested in their country's relationship with the Republic of China.

The report was jointly adopted by Szabo and six other members who visited Taiwan on Jan. 11-17. The Liberal MP from Toronto was pleased his group "received all party support" on Wednesday to table the report on cultural and trade issues.
He noted: "Our organization provides an important opportunity for all parliamentarians to promote bilateral initiatives which we feel will benefit Canadian trade and relations with Taiwan."

The nine-page report covers issues ranging from visa to cultural exchanges, with recommendations for the House and the government to work out measures that will help promote Canadian interests in Taiwan.

It pointed out that last year, Canada issued more than 140,000 visas to ROC nationals and Canadian officials report "very few problems" except a concern over document security. "PRC nationals have used Taiwan documents to claim refugee status in Canada," it said.

In view of the high volume and track record between the two countries, the MP's saw "a strong case" for waiving the visa requirement if the refugee-claim issue can be addressed. "This is a `pride issue' which would enhance bilateral relations," they stressed.

Taiwan officials based in Ottawa said Canadian immigration authorities were inclined toward waiving visa requirement if Taipei agrees to accept false claimants returned by the Canadian customs. Negotiations are continuing in this regard.

The Canadian report also suggested that Ottawa upgrade its immigration services in Taipei to a "full service office" so that Taiwan applicants do not have to fly to Singapore for interviews. It noted that "this matter would not be considered a concern to the PRC" and "the move would be seen as an important enhancement to the economic and cultural relationship between our countries."

On negotiations about signing a Double Taxation Arrangement (DTA), which have been stalled because of protests from the Taiwanese Canadian community, the report urged the resumption of talks. Canadian business is at a competitive disadvantage without such an arrangement, it claimed.

Another reason Canada needs a DTA is that Taiwan is effectively becoming a "science island" which offers many opportunities for Canadian business. A DTA with Taiwan "will be an important element in opening up those opportunities," according to the report.

It further pointed to the R&D opportunities in "genetic engineering of farm animals and crops," an area Taiwan has extended to after becoming a world leader in semiconductor and other high technologies. Since Canada has high expertise in agriculture, it should make "a full review" on how to identify and act on these key opportunities, the report said.

On cultural exchanges, the report urged the House to "ensure an appropriate level of Canadian government support" for the True North Festival, a private-sector initiative which will showcase Canadian music and visual arts in Taiwan and mainland China in December 1998.
It finally recommended a full assessment of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOC) facilities, which the visiting MP's found to be "cramped and inadequate."

Changes should be made at the CTOC to stimulate trade opportunities, to provide the staff with a more productive environment and "to signal to Taiwan the importance we place on our relationship with them," the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COPYRIGHT PIRACY COSTS US FIRMS US$10.8 BILLION

TEXT.P: Copyright piracy of music, books, movies and computer software cost US industry an estimated US$10.8 billion in 1997, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Friday.

The International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA) listed 55 countries and recommended to US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky that Greece and Bulgaria should be designated as Priority Foreign Countries unless significant improvements in enforcement are made by April 30, the WTO report said.
US pressure has already prodded mainland China into clamping down on pirate CD factories.

"We are now asking Ambassador Barshefsky to take on the largest exporter of pirate CD products in Europe -- Bulgaria -- and to continue to press the largest exporter of pirate products in Latin American -- Paraguay -- to do the same as China," IIPA president Eric Smith was quoted by the WTO report as saying.
"Greece has also failed to take the necessary enforcement actions to halt blatant and ongoing TV piracy at a level unprecedented in Western Europe."
"Both European countries show a lack of political will to crack down," Smith was quoted as saying.

In Paraguay, which the group alleged is a major production and transport center for pirated and counterfeited copyright products, the IIPA said the problem has grown out of control and is damaging markets for legitimate products throughout Latin America.
The IIPA recommended that 19 new countries be added to the "Priority Watch List," subjecting them to increased scrutiny from US authorities.
The IIPA is a coalition of industry groups representing over 1,350 US companies producing and distributing products around the world that are protected by US copyright laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BLOOD TEST SEEN REVOLUTIONIZING PRENATAL TESTING

TEXT.P: A newly developed blood test could revolutionize prenatal testing by allowing prospective parents to screen their unborn baby for genetic diseases at six weeks' gestation, if the method succeeds in clinical trials later this year.

The mass circulation newspaper The Australian reported Saturday that PreScreen, developed jointly by Flinders Technologies in Adelaide and BMC in the United States, is designed to detect defects four to 10 weeks earlier than present methods -- and without the risk of causing a spontaneous abortion.

John Turner, managing director of Flinders University's commercial development arm, told the daily that while the test is not yet perfect, it is already about 80 percent accurate, with trials in Australia and overseas expected to lift that above 90 percent.
He said the test will be an enormous international money spinner as more parents take the opportunity to reduce the risk of abnormal offspring.

He said PreScreen could be on the market as early as next year and is able to detect Down's Syndrome, cystic fibrosis, diabetes and Huntington's disease, as well as the blood conditions thalessemia and hemophilia.
He said one likely impact of the test if it succeeds -- and some experts remain skeptical -- will be an increase in the termination of fetuses in planned pregnancies.
But Turner said early detection would also allow doctors to correct some conditions while the fetus is in the womb and its low immune system does not reject certain treatments.
He said the test is able to extract fetal cells from a mother's blood using special antibodies that only lock into fetal material.

The antibodies have charged particles attached, allowing the fetal cells to be separated from a mother's cells by a magnet. Once isolated, colored stains indicating a genetic fault could be applied. But Turner said that in the early stages of the test's development, the result would still need confirmation by existing tests.
These tests access fetal cells -- with their genetic information -- through a syringe inserted into a mother's abdomen.
This can be done at 10 weeks with chorlonic villus sampling and at about 16 weeks with amniocentesis. Both carry a small risk of aborting the fetus, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DEVELOPING NEW RESCUE PACKAGE FOR INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australia is developing a new rescue package to help Indonesia reorder its massive private banking debts and stabilize the hopelessly devalued rupiah so that Jakarta will be able to quell food riots and social disorder.

The rescue package will be similar to the international assistance to South Korea and will involve Australia and other countries providing coordination and organizational support to the scores of private banks that have financed Indonesia's economic development projects.
Australian Prime Minister John Howard said Australia's role will not involve any extension of the existing financial aid to Indonesia through the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

He said a combination of the IMF's economic reform demands, local food shortages because of drought, international reluctance to invest in Indonesia and the huge devaluation of the rupiah have pushed food prices out of the reach of ordinary Indonesians, sparking rioting in many places in the world's biggest Islamic country.

Howard said Australia is deeply concerned about social disruption in Indonesia and that the latest proposal is the third step aimed at providing assistance in addition to the IMF's economic rescue package.
He did not give details, however, of the new rescue package, saying only: "One of the ways in which you can ameliorate the social strain is to have a bit of stabilization in the exchange rate.

"It's the dramatic fall in the value of the rupiah which is one of the things feeding into the current crisis. Restoring international confidence in relation to both the economic and political decision-making process in Indonesia is one of the ways in which you will stabilize the exchange rate.
"We are conscious of how important Indonesia is, not only to us, but also to the whole region," he said.

Australia has already agreed to provide food aid and organizational assistance to Indonesia on a bilateral basis and has succeeded in convincing the IMF that it should soften the impact of its austerity measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWRA LOWERS SECOND QUARTER SURCHARGES

TEXT.P: Lower marine fuel prices and the dramatic weakening of Asian currencies against the US dollar have prompted the Transpacific Westbound Rate Agreement (TWRA) to lower its fuel adjustment factor (FAF) and currency adjustment factor (CAF) surcharges, effective for the calendar quarter beginning April 1.

TWRA said it will reduce its FAF from US$120 to US$80 per 40-foot and 45-foot container, from US$96 to US$64 per 20-foot container, from US$60 to US$40 per vehicle for automobiles, from US$12 to US$8 per 1,000 board feet for lumber and from US$6 to US$4 per revenue ton for cargo otherwise rated.

At the same time, TWRA will lower its CAF on shipments to Taiwan from 8 percent to 4 percent. The CAF on cargo to Japan will fall from 39 percent to 35 percent, while the CAF for Singapore will be lowered from 13 percent to 9 percent. The CAF for South Korea, which was reduced to zero last year, will remain suspended in the coming quarter.

CAFs are special surcharges, broken out from freight rates, that are designed to fluctuate with exchange rates and help offset high local currency costs in Asia that are outside carriers' control. Similarly, FAFs fluctuate with world prices of marine fuel at key transpacific loading points. They are designed to help offset extraordinary fuel expenses that make up a large share of total voyage costs.
TWRA is a rate-making group of nine ocean and intermodal carriers serving the trade from port and inland points in the United States to destinations throughout Asia and the Indian Subcontinent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CRUNCH MAY CUT S'PORE BUDGET SURPLUS IN HALF

TEXT.P: The Singapore government's budget for the next fiscal year, which was unveiled in Parliament Friday, shows that excess income over spending for the financial year starting April 1 will leave a bottom line surplus of S$7.27 billion (US$4.38 billion) in the government's coffers.

This compares to a surplus for the year ending March 31 this year of S$14.33 billion -- up considerably from the S$12.62 billion surplus projected last July, when the 1997-98 budget was presented, The Straits Times reported Saturday.
The 1998-99 fiscal year starts April 1, 1998 and ends on March 31, 1999.
The Singapore Ministry of Finance said Friday that the low forecast for the upcoming fiscal year "is consequent to the slowdown in economic growth in the region."

Some economists had speculated earlier in the week that the government might target a balanced budget or even run a deficit for the first time in 12 years due to fallout from the regional economic turmoil.

However, their fears were unsupported. In fact, although the bottom line surplus is smaller than in previous years, the budget includes a huge 25 percent jump in development expenditure on new social and economic infrastructure projects.
The bottom line surplus -- the excess of receipts over outlays -- is made up of budget surplus, net investment income and net capital receipts minus net lending by the government.

The budget surplus itself is what is left over from the operating revenue after provisions for operating and development expenditure and contributions, if any, for Edusave and Medical endowment funds and pre-Medisave top-up and Medisave top-up schemes, the report said.
This surplus for the 1998 financial year is projected at S$2.68 billion, down from 1997's revised figure of S$4.2 billion.
The big jump in this year's revised surplus figure is largely due to healthy economic growth last year despite the economic woes.

Figures released by the Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry earlier this week showed that Singapore's economy expanded by a robust 7.8 percent last year, compared to the 6.9 percent growth recorded in 1996.
Meanwhile, the government's operating revenue is estimated will grow by a modest 3.8 percent to S$29.95 billion in the 1998-99 fiscal year, over the revised S$28.84 billion figure for 1997-98.
Overall, tax collection is expected to increase by S$554 million, or 2.5 percent, to S$23.15 billion, mainly because income tax is estimated to increase by S$480 million to S$10.38 billion.

However, revenue from stamp duty is expected to drop by S$350 million to S$1.3 billion. This would largely be due to the slower property market, which has seen a significant drop in sales of homes, and the fall in stock market trading volumes, the report said.

On the spending side, total expenditure in the 1998-1999 financial year is estimated at S$27.22 billion, a jump of 15 percent over the previous year. Of this, operating expenditure accounts for 60 percent and development expenditure for 40 percent.

As in previous years, the biggest slice of the pie goes to three sectors: social and community services (37 percent), security (34 percent) and economic and infrastructure development (21 percent). The remainder goes for general services.
The Finance Ministry said the government's operating expenditure for running expenses is projected to go up by S$1.12 billion, showing an increase of 7.8 percent, to S$15.47 billion.
But perhaps the most significant aspect of the new budget is the increase in development expenditure, which is projected to rise by S$2.34 billion to hit S$11.75 billion.
Provisions for social and economic infrastructure projects, including capital subsidies for public housing and research and development funding, take up about 80 percent of development expenditure.

DOC.HEADLINE: S'PORE IMPOSES TOUGHER PENALTIES ON PORN FILMS, VIDEOS

TEXT.P: Singapore has imposed tougher penalties on the making and distribution of obscene films and videos, under amendments to the Films Act passed in Parliament Friday.
The amended law also bans the distribution and exhibition of party political films, with a fine of up to S$100,000 (US$60,240).

The definition of "film" has also been widened to include CD-ROMs, VCDs, DVDs and computer files with moving images similar to those found in a movie or video. Films sent via e-mail now come under this definition.

Speaking at the second reading of the bill, Singapore Information and the Arts Minister Yeo Yong Mong said the amendments were in response to technological advances. They were also prompted by the fact that current penalties against obscene films seemed to be insufficient deterrents, he added.

He said in line with a "practical approach" policy, his ministry had decided to take a step-by-step approach, amending the relevant acts one by one instead of going for an omnibus legislation covering the entire media field. This was because technology is still unfolding and not all problems could be foreseen, he said.
The changes in penalties:
-- For selling obscene films: the fine has increased from S$1,000 per film to S$2,000, with the maximum doubled to S$80,000.
-- For possession: the fine has doubled from S$500 to S$1,000 per film, up to a maximum of S$40,000.
-- For exhibiting these films: the penalty has been raised by a hefty 10 times, to S$10,000, regardless of the number of films.
-- For bringing them in through Customs check-points: a minimum fine of S$1,000 per film and/or a jail term of up to one year.
-- For duplicating obscene films: a lump sum fine of between S$20,000 and S$40,000, and/or a jail term of up to two years.
-- There will also be additional penalties for those who use children to make, import or distribute obscene films.
